The guitarist was David Leisner, who took over on short notice from Martin Mastik.

description: To the Editor:

title: MALAYSIAN COMPANY REORGANIZES
description: In a complex restructuring plan, the Malaysian conglomerate Diversified Resources will make a general offer for shares it does not already own in three listed associate companies: Gadek; Gadek Capital , the 58 percent-owned financial arm of Gadek; and Hicom. The transaction will be financed through the issue of new Diversified Resources stock. The combined company will be renamed DRB-Hicom. Through various units, Diversified Resources and Gadek are involved in the automotive business, real estate, construction and financial services.

title: No Broadway Move for First 'Wild Party'
description: Putting an end to weeks of speculation, the producers of the musical ''The Wild Party'' said yesterday that they would not try to transfer the show from its current home at the Manhattan Theater Club to a Broadway theater.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  CHASSEN, MARY
description: CHASSEN-Mary. On February 28, 2000. Beloved mother of Sheldon Chassen, Howard Chassen and Gloria Green. Cherished grandmother of Cheryl Frydman, Stacey Mintz and Ethan Green, Stuart, Ira, Shari and David Chassen, and Mark and Michael Chassen. Adored great grandmother of eighteen. Funeral service today, 1:30 PM, Schwartz Bros., Queens Blvd, Queens, N.Y. Donations may be made to AMIT Women.

title: Business Travel; Southwest Airlines' success with online bookings has caught the travel industry by surprise.
description: SOUTHWEST AIRLINES sent an e-rocket through the travel industry this week when it announced that a quarter of its passenger revenue last month came from bookings on its Web site.

title: BP AMOCO AGREES TO PURCHASE EL PASO'S STAKE IN PIPELINE
description: BP Amoco P.L.C. agreed yesterday to buy the El Paso Energy Corporation's one-third stake in a natural gas pipeline that stretches from the Gulf of Mexico to Tennessee. The purchase, for $160 million, increases BP Amoco's interest in the Destin Pipeline to two-thirds. The company exercised its right to match a bid El Paso accepted last month from an unidentified buyer. The 255-mile pipeline can ship 1 billion cubic feet of gas a day. It delivers the fuel from fields in the eastern Gulf of Mexico to a BP Amoco processing plant in Pascagoula, Miss., and five interstate pipelines. Houston-based El Paso agreed to sell the stake to win federal antitrust approval for its October acquisition of Sonat Inc. for $6.6 billion. The Shell Oil Company owns the other one-third stake in the pipeline.

title: Hong Kong's Local Preference; Home-Grown Contender Wins in Phone Deal
description: The last British governor sailed out of this teeming Asian port in 1997. And today, with the decision of Cable and Wireless P.L.C. to sell its Hong Kong telephone company to a local Internet start-up, Hong Kong has thrown off another vestige of its colonial past.

title: 2 Shootings by the Police, 2 Prosecution Strategies
description: Four years ago, Manhattan prosecutors won a conviction in the case of a white New York transit police officer who mistakenly shot and wounded a black colleague. On Monday, as District Attorney Robert T. Johnson of the Bronx defended his office's unsuccessful prosecution of the officers who killed Amadou Diallo, he was asked why he did not use similar tactics in the Diallo case.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  KROUWER, HENRI
description: KROUWER-Henri. Of Mount Vernon, N.Y. Died peacefully on Feb. 10, 2000. Dearly beloved husband of Nadia. Devoted and loving father of Tom, Peter, & Jan. Proud grandfather of Jennifer, Margot and David. Loving and beloved husband of the late Margot Krouwer. Born in Holland Sept. 5, 1907. Colonel in the Dutch Army. Studied in Switzerland and France; 10 years in Indonesia with the company Europa-Azia, founded by his father Abraham Krouwer. Emigrated 1940 to U.S.A., first working for the Netherlands Purchase Commission, then Founder and President of Kroulee Corporation. Henri loved life, travel, the arts, poetry, music and had great respect for the sciences. He was a devoted family man, caring, compassionate, charitable, open-minded, gracious host and great cook. His sense of humor was inevitably contagious. Henri, you touched our lives deeply and you will always be in our hearts. Memorial service March 4, 4 PM, Unitarian Church, 468 Rosedale Ave, White Plains, N.Y. In lieu of flowers, donations may be made to Hospice of Westchester, 95 South Broadway, White Plains, N.Y. 10601.

title: Gates Foundation Gives $350 Million to Education Programs Over the Next 3 Years
description: The Bill and Melinda Gates Foundation will spend $350 million over the next three years on education programs, foundation officials said today.

title: A Woman On the Verge Of Another Breakdown
description: The hard-working demons who possessed little Linda Blair in ''The Exorcist'' have nothing on the forces raging within one Marjorie Taub, the title character of ''The Tale of the Allergist's Wife,'' which opened last night at the Manhattan Theater Club.

title: The Rangers' Attention Turns to Defensive Zone
description: The rematch with Dominik Hasek was a day away but the Rangers spent no more than 60 seconds practicing their offense today. Instead, Coach John Muckler put them through two hours of intense defensive drills.

title: LATIN INTERNET DEAL
description: Argentina's biggest Internet company, El Sitio Inc., agreed to buy the Web retailer DeCompras.com Inc. of Mexico. The price was not disclosed. El Sitio, which raised $131 million in a public stock sale in December, is spending heavily to bolster content and compete with StarMedia Networks Inc. and other rivals. The purchase of DeCompras.com is intended to fortify its content in Mexico. El Sitio also posted a wider fourth-quarter loss of $22.4 million, or $1.17 a share, in the period that ended on Dec. 31, compared with a loss of $1.7 million, or 29 cents a share, a year ago. Revenue climbed to $5.3 million from $171,000 a year ago.

title: Gruyre Omelet
description: This version of the omelet uses grated gruyere, which will be added late in the process and quickly melt as the omelet is folded. The same technique can be used in making any "stuffed omelet" that uses cooked ingredients. Think of sauteed mushrooms, or sauteed spinach, two delicious examples.

title: When Best-Laid Plans Fail, Improvisation Succeeds
description: WHAT do you do when it's 6:30 p.m. and you have just discovered that the fancy custard you were planning to serve 12 people at dinner is still sloshing around instead of standing firm?

title: Reckonings; D.O.A. at the I.M.F.
description: Nothing in the bylaws of the International Monetary Fund says that its managing director has to be European. Still, there is a long tradition to that effect -- part of a gentlemen's agreement that gives the considerably less critical directorship of the World Bank to an American.

title: Counting Democracy's Friends in Albany
description: A vote scheduled for today in the New York State Senate will test which comes first with Republican members -- party loyalty or democratic principle. At issue is the fate of Senate Bill 6482, the measure devised by the Democratic minority leader, Martin Connor, to clean up the closed-ballot system that forced Senator John McCain to wage an expensive legal battle to compete statewide in New York's March 7 presidential primary.

title: THE MARKETS: CURRENCIES
description: EURO WEAKENS. The euro slipped against the dollar ahead of reports that will most likely show United States economic growth outpacing Europe's. In New York, the euro settled at 96.55 cents, down from 97.19 cents on Monday.

title: Economists Readjust Estimate Of Overstatement of Inflation
description: More than three years after concluding that the Consumer Price Index overstated inflation by 1.1 percentage points a year, a group of prominent economists says changes made to the index since then have narrowed the overstatement to about eight-tenths of a percentage point a year.

title: History Hovers Darkly Over Paris Opera Stage
description: At the final dress rehearsal of the Paris Opera's new production of ''War and Peace'' this month, some guests were evidently piqued by Prokofiev's -- and before him Tolstoy's -- take on the French invasion of Russia in 1812. The portrayal of Napoleon as a buffoon and French troops as savages proved too much. At the curtain call, hearty cheers for Napoleon turned to boos for Marshal Kutuzov, the Russian general who drove out the French.

description: Why did Philip Morris, a company that long regarded the federal government as its arch-enemy, suddenly announce it was willing to accept some government regulation?

title: China Dismisses Furor Over Its Taiwan Policy
description: A new Chinese policy paper on Taiwan, which has prompted a furious reaction in the United States, merely ''reiterates the government's consistent stance'' and does not represent a change in policy, a senior Chinese official said today.

title: De Beers Tries to Ensure Gems Don't Finance Insurrection
description: Stung by accusations that the diamond trade has supported war against governments in Africa, De Beers, the giant of the industry, said today that it would give written guarantees that its stones do not come from rebel groups in the continent.

description: Faced with a fiscal meltdown and a major lawsuit challenging Nassau County's antiquated property tax system, two Republican county officials reversed course today and agreed to press for the reassessment of all 415,000 residential and commercial properties in the county.

title: Charges Are Traded in Summations at Officers' Cover-Up Trial in Louima Torture
description: Appealing to the jury's sympathy, a lawyer for a former police officer convicted of helping torture Abner Louima and then accused of hiding his role in the attack said yesterday that his client was a victim of mistaken identity and lies by government witnesses.

title: JAPANESE OUTPUT IS UP
description: Japan's industrial output rose in January and was expected to increase for a third straight quarter. Output was up 0.9 percent in January from December, seasonally adjusted, and probably gained 2.7 percent in February, according to figures from the International Trade and Industry Ministry. While January's gain was smaller than expected, February's expected increase is bigger than the initial estimate of 0.6 percent. A separate report showed that while unemployment was stuck at 4.7 percent in January, just below its record high of 4.8 percent, more jobs are being offered and workers are working more overtime.

title: Chief Executive Quits at Reliance Group
description: Saul P. Steinberg, one of the best-known corporate raiders of the 1980's, stepped down yesterday as the chief executive of Reliance Group Holdings, a troubled insurance company that announced another quarter of disappointing earnings.

title: People
description: Richard Gerstman, president at Interbrand Gerstman & Meyers, New York, the product packaging identity and design unit of the Interbrand Group, part of the Omnicom Group, was promoted to chairman at Interbrand. He succeeds Alvin Schechter, who became chairman at the Interbrand Foundation.

title: Yes, It's Still the Economy, Stupid, but With an Asterisk
description: If Vice President Al Gore has counted on anything in this tumultuous political season, it is that the strong economy will give him the upper hand in the general election should he win the Democratic presidential nomination.

description: Mercifully, the end is near.

description: O'CONNELL-The Reverend Brian J. of the Vincentian Community at St. John's University, past president of Niagara University and Dean of St. John's College of Liberal Arts and Sciences on February 28, 2000. Fr. O'Connell is survived by his brothers Dan and Jerry O'Connell. title: Camby and Ward to Return None Too Soon
description: A few more days, and the Knicks' cure for the ordinary will arrive. Marcus Camby will be back dropping in like a parachutist, ready to turn an innocent rebound into an energizing event. Charlie Ward will return to toss his body across the floor like a tumbleweed, scrambling to turn a loose ball into a fast break.

title: Florida Utility Settles Air Pollution Lawsuit
description: The government's campaign to make seven utilities bring old coal-fired electric plants up to modern pollution standards showed its first results today when a Florida utility agreed to spend about $1 billion to switch one plant to natural gas and make major changes at a second.

title: WALLACE COMPUTER SERVICES TO CUT PLANTS AND JOBS
description: Wallace Computer Services Inc. said yesterday that it would close four plants and cut its work force by more than 300. Wallace will close unprofitable printing plants in Cleveland, Tampa, Fla., and Miami in the next two to three weeks. It will phase out a multiple-use plant in Lebanon, Ky., over the next three months. Wallace, based in Lisle, Ill., provides computer services and supplies. Wallace stock closed at $10.4375, down 50 cents, on the New York Stock Exchange.

title: A Weill Pageant, Altered and Returned to Life
description: ''Der Weg der Verheissung'' has stirred the blood of Kurt Weill scholars for more than 60 years. Born of the political confusion surrounding European politics in the mid-1930's and a victim of the cross-purposes of its creators, this medley of biblical and pre-Holocaust history stumbled into public life in 1937 and then withdrew from sight. Variously lost, forgotten, corrupted or simply put in storage, depending on your point of view, Weill's paean to the Jewish experience has gradually reassembled itself and found new life through a German theater (the Chemnitz Opera) and a proselytizing American conductor (John Mauceri).

title: Robinson Lerer To Be Taken Over
description: Robinson Lerer & Montgomery, one of the nation's best-known and most powerful public relations agencies, said yesterday that it had agreed to be acquired by Young & Rubicam Inc., which operates public relations shops in addition to agencies in advertising, direct marketing and other fields. Terms were not disclosed. Both are based in New York.

title: 'La Boheme' Is Among City Opera's Seven New Productions Next Season
description: The New York City Opera's 2000-1 season is to include new productions of Donizetti's ''Roberto Devereux,'' Prokofiev's ''Love for Three Oranges,'' Douglas Moore's ''Ballad of Baby Doe'' and two Handel operas, ''Rinaldo'' and ''Acis and Galatea.'' Also among the seven new productions are fresh stagings of Verdi's ''Rigoletto'' and Puccini's ''Boheme.''

title: Democrats in Congress Introduce Resolution Attacking Bob Jones U. as Intolerant
description: Hoping to make Republicans squirm over their visits to Bob Jones University, House and Senate Democrats introduced a resolution today condemning the college for intolerance and criticizing its many visitors for staying silent on its anti-Catholic views.

title: Corrections
description: An article on Monday about a decline in the number of Puerto Ricans in New York City referred incorrectly to the distinction borne by Luis Munoz Marin. He became the first native-born elected governor of Puerto Rico in 1948. The first native-born governor was Jesus T. Pinero, in 1946, but he was appointed.

description: THE REPUBLICANS

title: Afghan Heroin Feeds Addiction In Region, U.N. Report Declares
description: The United Nations Drug Control Program says in a report made public today that Afghanistan is now not only the largest producer of opium but is also becoming a major manufacturer of heroin, which is contributing to a rise in addiction throughout the region.

title: BIDDERS DIVIDE UNITED BISCUITS
description: Ending a five-month stalemate, Danone S.A. of France and the Nabisco Holdings Corporation will jointly buy United Biscuits P.L.C. for $:1.26 billion ($2 billion) and carve up the business, abandoning competing offers for the world's fourth-largest cookie company. Nabisco agreed to join the Danone-backed bid of 265 pence a share for the company, which makes McVitie's cookies and KP snacks. Nabisco will gain operations in China, Hong Kong and Taiwan, and Danone will get businesses in Southeast Asia, Scandinavia and Eastern Europe. Nabisco's partner in its bid is the Dallas investment firm Hicks, Muse, Tate & Furst Inc.

title: THE MARKETS: COMMODITIES
description: ORANGE JUICE FALLS. Orange juice prices fell as ideal weather improved prospects for Florida's orange crop. In New York, frozen concentrated orange juice for May delivery fell 3.35 cents, to 82.55 cents a pound.

title: Harold M. Mulvey, 86, Judge At Tense Black Panther Trials
description: Harold M. Mulvey, the Connecticut Superior Court judge who presided calmly over the emotionally charged murder trials of several Black Panthers in the early 1970's, died Sunday at a nursing home in Hamden, Conn. He was 86.

title: Gary Journal; City Known for Trouble Sees Hope in a Pageant
description: Better known for violence, rust and urban decay than as a destination for beautiful women wearing sequins and gold lame, Gary, Ind., an aging, gritty city just east of Chicago, entered a contract today to be the site of the nationally televised Miss USA Pageant.

title: A Sushi Showcase With a Cool Demeanor
description: SUSHI YASUDA looks like a restaurant that was headed for TriBeCa and took a wrong turn. In the grim stretch between Grand Central Terminal and the United Nations, one of the city's dreariest restaurant neighborhoods, it glows like a strange mineral, with a cool, celery-green facade nearly as enigmatic as its emblem, a slightly blurry ink print of a sea bream.

title: Commercial Real Estate; Brooklyn Offices for Theater Groups
description: The Alliance of Resident Theaters/New York has bought a five-story, 19,200-square-foot building in Fort Greene, about five blocks from the Brooklyn Academy of Music, and is leasing it out as office space for use by small theater companies that cannot afford the increasingly high commercial rents in Manhattan.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  WEINBLATT, ROSYLN
description: WEINBLATT-Rosyln. Cherished wife of the late Marvin Weinblatt, beloved mother of Susan Weinblatt, Dr. Alan and Lisa Weinblatt, Buddy and Gwen Weinblatt, loving grandmother of Ananda, Michelle, and Lara. Dedicated special education teacher, retired. She bettered the lives of many and will be missed by all who loved her.

description: UHLMAN-Rudolph Ernst, on February 26, 2000, at Pennswood Village retirement community, Newtown, PA. Formerly of White Plains, NY, and Mount Desert Island, ME. Retired lawyer, with Guggenheimer & Untermyer, NYC, for 48 years. He was born August 10, 1909, in Stuttgart, Germany. Survived by his son, Thomas M. Uhlman, two daughters; Susan A. Sten and Marian Uhlman Duncombe; a sister, Marianne Knorr; and five granddaughters. Memorial service 2 P.M. Sunday, March 5, at Congregation Kol Ami, 252 Soundview Ave, White Plains. In lieu of flowers, contributions may be made to Leo Baeck Institute, 129 E. 73rd St, NYC 10021.

title: Avocado Skips the Appetizers
description: GUACAMOLE may be the dip of summer, but avocados are at their prime right now. This tropical fruit, with its soft, pale flesh, can go a long way in adding interest to a winter diet. Green vegetables often disappoint at this time of year, but the avocado brings a blast of summery freshness.

title: Inquiry Into Diallo Officers Could Take Police Months
description: One of the four officers acquitted in the slaying of Amadou Diallo has returned to work, but police officials predicted yesterday that it would be months before the Police Department could complete an internal investigation into whether the officers should remain on the force.

title: HIGHER PROFITS AT TELEFONICA
description: Spain's largest telephone company, Telefonica S.A., earned 1.81 billion euros, or $1.75 billion, in 1999, up 38 percent. Excluding extraordinary items and writedowns of assets, earnings grew by 18.8 percent. The company's consolidated revenue rose 10.5 percent, to 13.5 billion euros, on the strong expansion in its mobile phone unit, Telefonica Moviles, which had an increase in revenue of 32.9 percent. In Latin America, where Telefonica is the leading communications company, some of its units reported losses. Al Goodman

title: Every Bite You Take, They'll Be Watching You
description: AS you savor your tuna tartare in an elegant dining room, your companion may not be the only one to notice you are ignoring the sesame toasts the chef has made to accompany it. The chef may be fretting about it, too.

title: EU Takes Steps to Create a Military Force, Without Treading on NATO
description: PARIS  The European Union plans to unveil an institutional arm to handle defense Wednesday. It will be the first concrete step by Europe's major countries to set up their own military forces as a complement to NATO.

title: THE BOSS; Cheers for Work! Rah! Rah!
description: I work 70, 80 hours a week -- I love to work. It has been that way since I was 12 and I got my first job at a movie theater in Grand Prairie, Tex. That is also when I made up my mind that I was going to be an executive and not have any children.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  BERNSTEIN, FAY
description: BERNSTEIN-Fay. In her 92nd year. Devoted wife of the late Samuel. Loving mother Naomi, Howard and the late Rachel. Dear mother-in-law of Paul Kronish, Marcy Bernstein and Alan Paul. Sister of Thelma, Sylvia and Helen. Mama Fay to her eight grandchildren and fifteen great-grandchildren. Her strength and love will be with us always. Service Wednesday, March 1, 1:15pm at ''The Riverside'', 76th Street and Amsterdam Avenue.

title: CANADIAN BUILDING SERVICES COMPANY REACHES U.S. DEAL
description: The Bracknell Corporation, a Canadian company that provides technical services to buildings and factories, agreed yesterday to buy Sunbelt Integrated Trade Services Inc. of Las Vegas for at least $127 million. The price could rise to $200 million if Sunbelt meets earnings targets, Toronto-based Bracknell said. Sunbelt's services include installing air-conditioning and ventilation systems, and designing and maintaining water-treatment plants.

title: QRS TO BUY MAKER OF INTERNET PROCUREMENT SOFTWARE
description: An Internet software company, the QRS Corporation, agreed yesterday to acquire the privately held RockPort Trade Systems Inc. for about $100 million in stock. RockPort makes software that allows companies to compare, over the Internet, the cost of various supplies. QRS, based in Richmond, Calif., will pay about 1.1 million shares for RockPort, based in Gloucester, Mass. QRS's shares were down $2.78125, to $94.375, in Nasdaq trading.

title: Havas Unit Acquires Stake in Tyee Group
description: Euro RSCG Worldwide in New York, a unit of Havas Advertising, said yesterday that it had acquired a majority stake in the Tyee Group in Portland, Ore., an agency specializing in direct response television advertising like infomercials. Terms were not disclosed.

title: Hong Kong's Local Preference; Shrinking an Empire to Fit
description: When Graham Wallace became chief executive of Cable and Wireless P.L.C. a year ago this week, he had been expected to be the consummate company man, reluctant to shake up the far-flung telecommunications company that once symbolized Britain's imperial reach.

title: Bronx Hospital to Drop Its Rikers Contract
description: After three years of investigations and charges of medical negligence, St. Barnabas Medical Center in the Bronx will stop providing health care to inmates on Rikers Island within the next year, the hospital and city health officials confirmed yesterday.

title: Italians Welcome the Return Of an Ancient Gold Platter
description: With fanfare and the kinds of fulsome speeches usually reserved for wedding toasts, Italian officials thanked their American counterparts today for returning a fourth-century B.C. gold platter that Italy has been seeking to recover for nearly 20 years.

title: Cleanup on Cat's Feet
description: To the Editor:

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  KLUGHERZ, DAN
description: KLUGHERZ-Dan. Formerly of New York City, and Southampton, New York. Died in Sarasota, Florida at age 84. Award winning documentarian with such films as ''The Real Julia'' (correcting the Hellman memoir), ''Marked for Failure'', ''Women in Sports'', ''The Great Black Hope'', ''American Samoa: Paradise Lost?'', and many others. Awards include: Blue Ribbon and Red Ribbon of the The American Film Festival; Cine Golden Eagle; NEA School Bells Award; and Best Documentary of the Year (TV-Radio Life Magazine). Mr. Klugherz directed ''20th Century'' for CBS and ''NET Journal'' and ''The 51st State'' for PBS. He was a 2nd Lieutenant in WWII, serving in the Signal Corps as a cameraman, writer, and director. Dan Klugherz is survived by his beloved wife, Patricia Klugherz, daughters Alice Klugherz and Tana Kamine, grandson Jack Kamine, and a sister, Dr. Marjorie Klugherz.

title: A Fair Verdict on Strawberry
description: There is something terribly sad about Darryl Strawberry. He is by all accounts a personable man with a nimble sense of humor. He is also, even now, a formidable baseball player, blessed with coordination, power and one of the smoothest swings in the game. He came up with the New York Mets in 1983 and drew comparisons to the young Ted Williams. He hit 280 home runs before he was 30, but has hit only 55 since then -- partly because he has had a bad back, as well as colon cancer in 1998, but partly because of his drinking and drug habits. Yesterday, a little over five weeks after he tested positive for cocaine, Major League Baseball gave him his third drug-related suspension since 1995, this time for a full year. Considering his age, 38 this month, we may have seen the last of Strawberry in a major league uniform.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  HELLER, SOL
description: HELLER-Sol. The Partners, Associates and Staff of Thurm & Heller, LLP are saddened by the passing of Sol Heller, father of our partner, Anthony Heller, and extend our sincerest condolences to the family.

title: FRENCH JOBLESS RATE IMPROVES
description: France's unemployment rate fell to 10.5 percent in January, its lowest level since September 1992, though the rate of decline was modest compared with the heady falls in French joblessness in recent months. The number of job seekers declined by 28,000, to 2,711,000, in January, according to the Labor Ministry. In the 12 months through January, the unemployment rate fell nearly 10 percent.

title: Mets' Competition for Reserve Roles Centers on Taking Turn to the Left
description: With the Mets' exhibition season starting Friday, these are the final days of the unbridled optimism of spring. Every name on the chalkboard in the manager's office is filled with promise, from the players on the 40-man roster whose names are in blue to the 14 invitees whose names are in orange. If you are on the board -- and your main job is not singing country music -- you have a chance to help the Mets.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  DRUCKER, JENNIE
description: DRUCKER-Jennie. Died February 27, 2000, dearly beloved sister of Tanya Adler, loving aunt and loyal friend. Interment private.

title: Undermining a Myth On American Conductors
description: It may appear that progress has been slow in the business of developing young American conductors, but that's mainly because so many of the larger American orchestras still regard them as unsalable nonexotics. They are out in increasing numbers though, and Robert Spano's ascension from an assistantship with the Boston Symphony to directorships of the Brooklyn Philharmonic and now the Atlanta Symphony shows that the path is not entirely obstructed.

title: Michelin Guide, 100, Giveth and Taketh Away
description: LE GRAND VEFOUR in Paris, the newest three-star restaurant in the Michelin firmament, is hardly new at all. The restaurant, anointed in the latest Michelin guide to France, which was published on Monday, is a piece of the city's history.

title: AMDOCS TO PURCHASE NET SOFTWARE COMPANY IN TORONTO
description: Amdocs Ltd. agreed yesterday to acquire Solect Technology Group, which provides Internet billing and customer service software, for about $1.1 billion in stock. In the transaction, which is expected to close in April, Amdocs will exchange 15.5 million shares and options for Solect. Amdocs, based in St. Louis, provides systems for customer service, billing and order management for communications and Internet services. It had revenue of $626.9 million in the year ended Sept. 30. Solect, which is privately held, is based in Toronto. Shares of Amdocs jumped $8.6875, to $74.1875, on the New York Stock Exchange.

description: With relations between the bitter foes India and Pakistan at their worst point in three decades, New Delhi announced a 28.2 percent increase in military spending today. It is the largest single-year increase in the nation's history.

title: Children With Guns
description: Americans should be outraged that any 6-year-old could get a gun and fire it to kill another 6-year-old in their first-grade classroom. The shooting yesterday at Buell Elementary School, near Flint, Mich., is the latest episode of gun violence in schools. Investigators say there might have been a playground quarrel between the two children the day before. But sorting out intent may be difficult, if not irrelevant. The responsibility for the death has to lie with the adults who allowed a first grader to get access to a gun. It also lies with lawmakers in Washington who have blocked efforts to protect children from this kind of senseless death.

title: City Ballet Serves Up Candied Chestnuts

title: JUPITER COMMUNICATIONS TO BUY NET RESEARCH COMPANIES
description: Jupiter Communications Inc. agreed yesterday to buy two closely held companies for $50.6 million in cash and stock to expand its research on online commercial transactions. Jupiter provides research reports on online commerce to subscribers like America Online and Qualcomm. It will pay $20 million in cash and $30.6 million in stock for Net Market Makers and Internet Research Group. The New York-based company did not say how much it was paying for each acquisition. Net Market Makers, based in Berkeley, Calif., offers conferences for those interested in doing business online. Internet Research Group sells research reports and conducts custom research projects. The shares of Jupiter rose 75 cents, to $32, in Nasdaq trading.

The best chardonnays, for example, whether from California or Burgundy or even Australia, tend to be rich and creamy, full of exotic flavors buttressed by sensations of toasty vanilla and butter that are induced by aging in oak barrels. Then there's Chablis, one of my favorite wines and an exception to most other wines made from the chardonnay grape.

title: KOREAN CONSUMER PRICES UP
description: South Korean consumer prices increased only slightly in February, indicating the country's fast economic recovery has not yet generated inflationary pressures, the Finance and Economy Ministry said. South Korea's consumer price index edged up 0.3 percent in February from January, the lowest monthly rise since 1988, the ministry said. In the first two months of this year, the index rose 0.4 percent, which is well below the average increase of 2 percent in the corresponding periods between 1990 and 1999. Samuel Len

title: Sharon Cautions West Against Aid to Syria in Any Peace Deal
description: Presuming that Israeli-Syrian peace talks will resume because President Clinton ''will make every effort to see that it happens,'' Ariel Sharon, leader of the opposition Likud Party, began campaigning today against Western aid to Syria as part of any deal.

title: Mr. Bush's Comeback
description: With his sweep in Virginia, North Dakota and Washington, Gov. George W. Bush's troubled presidential campaign has wrung an essential victory from three disparate states. But once again Senator John McCain pointed up the soft spot in Mr. Bush's candidacy by drawing strong support in Virginia and possibly elsewhere among independents, moderates and Democratic crossovers. Mr. Bush's partisans argued last night that Senator McCain's challenge to religious fundamentalists had backfired, rallying loyal Republicans to the governor's side. All of the results set up a tremendously important showdown in the March 7 ''Super Tuesday'' primaries. The battleground states of California and Ohio, where Mr. Bush leads, and in New York, which is a toss-up, may well determine whether Mr. McCain will be remembered as a transforming or a transitory figure in the G.O.P.

description: Senator John McCain intensified the battle over the political power of the religious right today as he accused Pat Robertson and the Rev. Jerry Falwell of having an ''evil influence'' over the Republican Party.

title: A Downtown Head Trip Plants Its Feet Uptown
description: Visiting a little show called ''Squonk'' during its brief run in the East Village last summer was like walking into a neighbor's garage and discovering a homemade fun house. Staged in one of the upstairs rooms of Performance Space 122, ''Squonk'' was clearly a product of obsessive, original minds and limited means.

title: Basic Vietnamese Cooking As a Culinary Crossroads
description: THE story of Corinne Trang's family personifies the story of Vietnam. And so her book, ''Authentic Vietnamese Cooking'' (Simon & Schuster, $30), not only serves as a good introduction to the cuisine, but also gives a sense of how the country's history has shaped its food.

title: Guilty Verdicts in Trial Implicating Camden Mayor
description: Two Camden men were convicted on federal drug charges yesterday after a trial in which witnesses accused Mayor Milton Milan of buying and selling cocaine, the United States Attorney's office said.

title: SEIZURE POSSIBLE IN THAI BANKRUPTCY
description: A dispute between Thailand's biggest corporate debtor, Thai Petrochemical, and its creditors has raised doubts about repayment of billions of dollars of bad debt in the country despite economic improvements since the Asian financial crisis in 1997. Thai Petrochemical has balked at an agreement to restructure $3.5 billion in debt. The creditors, including the World Bank's International Finance Corporation and the United States Export-Import Bank, have petitioned Thailand's bankruptcy court to declare the company insolvent and allow them to take it over. A hearing is set to begin today. Wayne Arnold

title: Official's Testimony Hints at Slow Progress on Internet Attacks
description: The official in charge of the government's cybercrime-fighting unit told a Congressional panel today that the Federal Bureau of Investigation was uncertain whether one or more groups was responsible for the recent attacks on e-commerce sites.

But even after all that time, his teammates do not know what Strawberry might do outside of baseball now that his career is in jeopardy.

description: Mirage Resorts Inc. rejected a $3.3 billion takeover bid yesterday from its casino rival, MGM Grand Inc., as inadequate and opportunistic, and it put in place a ''poison pill'' takeover defense.

description: Steven Rattner, the deputy chairman of the investment bank Lazard Freres & Company, is leaving to start a New York investment firm with three other Lazard bankers.

title: Introduction
description: As a young cook in Paris, Pierre Franey -- who would later become one of America's most influential chefs -- was required to prepare his first omelet for paying customers. He knew that this relatively simple procedure was subject to the rules of tradition: it had to be absolutely pale (no brown spots) with a completely smooth surface when it was finished. Both characteristics contribute to the delicacy of a classic omelet. He could do it. He'd practiced. But as he cooked that one omelet -- in this case the mixed herb omelet called omelette aux fines herbes -- his boss, a tyrannical chef, stood over him to be sure it came out right.

title: Cap Gemini to Acquire Ernst & Young's Consulting Business

title: BERTELSMANN PROFIT SOARS
description: Germany's largest media company, Bertelsmann, said its operating profit rose 75 percent in the first half of its fiscal year as acquisitions widened sales. The company said operating profit in the six months ended Dec. 31 rose to more than a billion marks ($500 million) as sales climbed 12.2 percent, to 14.5 billion marks. Excluding acquisitions, sales rose 9.1 percent. The company did not provide net income figures.

title: INTERNET FEES ARE CUT
description: Britain's biggest traditional phone company, British Telecommunications P.L.C., slashed 15 percent from the monthly fee for its Internet service and added free weekend and evening access to help it compete with free and fixed-rate providers. Starting today, the company said customers of its BT Internet service will pay 9.99 [pounds] ($15.91) a month instead of 11.75 [pounds] and would not have to pay call charges for weekend or evening access. At other times, customers will pay local phone charges. The service also cut its annual fee to 109.89 [pounds] from 129.25 [pounds].

title: Hey, Don't Touch the Wall!
description: LAST fall, Carole and Dick Cline were looking for something to hang over the fireplace in the sitting room of their new home, which overlooks a golf course near Chicago. The couple's art consultant, Deborah Lovely, brought by a few paintings, but none worked with the couple's antique furniture and multicolored rug, Mr. Cline said. Then Ms. Lovely suggested a Sol LeWitt mural -- a ''wall drawing'' in the artist's parlance. By Christmas, the couple had something to match the rug: a geometric drawing in diluted India inks, covering two walls of their sitting room -- about 250 square feet.

title: Money Laundering Prompts U.S. Drive For a Tougher Law

title: A Literary Peddler Plies the Trade Routes
description: Oddly enough, there can still be romance in being a bookseller, an embattled yet ennobled calling these days. More accurately, let's say there can be passion and adventure in trafficking in books: buying, selling and bartering them, rather like dealing for salt along the old trade routes. A woman who owns a bookstore in Cape Town, South Africa, does just that. She bargains in books and jokingly refers to herself as ''the last of the great salt-trading people.''

title: The 20's Are Hot in the Year 2000
description: ''We're just in the first inning of this,'' marveled John Sollo, curator of the auction of 20th-century furnishings scheduled for Sunday at David Rago Modern Auctions in Lambertville, N. J. ''This market just keeps getting stronger.'' The sale will include an Eames desk for Herman Miller (estimated at $3,000 to $4,000) and some lilac Arne Jacobsen Egg Chairs for Fritz Hansen ($1,800 to $2,500). Added into the mix are the collection of the entertainer Shari Lewis, who was an early patron of the New Hope School of craft artists, some Pop Art pieces owned by Charles and Eleanore Stendig, and a covey of Warren McArthur chrome and lacquer pieces from the Shoreham Hotel in New York (a 1920's side chair, side table and settee, top, are estimated at $1,000 to $8,000 each). Paul Schreckengost's Art Deco teapot (above, $3,500 to $4,500) and Gilbert Rohde's vanity ($11,000 to $15,000) round out the offerings.

title: CISCO PURCHASING SCOTTISH SOFTWARE COMPANY
description: Cisco Systems Inc. agreed yesterday to acquire the privately held software developer Atlantech of Scotland for $180 million in stock. Atlantech makes software to help businesses configure and monitor computer network hardware. The company will keep its employees and offices in Glasgow. The deal is another step in Cisco's strategy of expanding its ability to help companies with all aspects of setting up and managing computer networks. Cisco, which is based in San Jose, Calif., has acquired 21 companies in the last 12 months. Its shares fell 50 cents, to $131.6875.

title: NIKKEI INDEX CLIMBS
description: The Nikkei average of 225 Japanese stocks rose on Wednesday to its highest point in two and a half years, paced by computer-chip-related shares like the Toshiba Corporation as a rally by United States chip makers led to optimism about higher prices for chips. The stock average gained 122.15, to 20,081.67, the highest close since July 31, 1997, after rising as high as 20,165.51.

title: BELL ATLANTIC MAY REPURCHASE 80 MILLION MORE SHARES
description: The Bell Atlantic Corporation, the No. 2 United States local-telephone company, said yesterday that its board had authorized the repurchase of as many as 80 million common shares to help the value of its stock, which has fallen 12 percent in the last year. The new buyback would cost $4.4 billion based on Bell Atlantic's closing price yesterday and represents about 5.2 percent of shares outstanding as of Dec. 31. The board of the New York-based company rescinded a previous authorization to repurchase as much as $1.4 billion of shares, with about $310 million of that allotment remaining. Bell Atlantic's shares rose $6 each, to $54.9375.

title: ECUADOR'S DOLLAR PLAN ADVANCES
description: After a military coup and a month of heated national debate, Ecuador's Congress approved legislation making the United States dollar the country's currency. Within six months, all sucres are to be replaced by dollars at a rate of 25,000 to 1. The decision, taken after a visiting United States government delegation cautiously endorsed the plan, is expected to lead to an agreement with the International Monetary Fund and a renewal of talks with creditors about rescheduling Ecuador's $13 billion in foreign debt.

title: THE MARKETS: CURRENCIES
description: YEN GAINS. The yen surged against the dollar after the Nikkei index, buoyed by computer stocks, rose to the highest level in two and a half years. In New York, the dollar settled at 107.12 yen, down from 110.19 on Tuesday.

title: In Senate Campaign, Charges Linking Supporters and Guns
description: As Hillary Rodham Clinton warned elementary school children here about the danger of guns today, her campaign staff sharply criticized Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani for accepting a donation from Charlton Heston, the president of the National Rifle Association.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  ALLEN, JOHN MACNAB
description: ALLEN-John Macnab, March 1, 2000. Loving husband of Mary Stanton Allen. Devoted father of Mana Allen Model & her husband Ben, William C. Allen and his wife Christina Sessa Allen, Joanna Allen Lodin and her husband Jeffrey. Cherished grandfather (''GP'') of Joseph, Christopher, Penn Lodin and Molly Model. He was a noted New York actor, author, director and playwright. He will be deeply missed by his family, friends and the New York theatrical community. Friends may call at Frank E. Campbell, 1076 Madison Avenue at 81st St., Saturday, March 4th, 2-5 and 79PM, and Sunday 2-5PM. Funeral private. Memorial service to be announced at a later date.

title: 11 Big Aid Groups Quit Sudan in Dispute With Rebels on Control
description: Eleven of the biggest aid agencies working in the continual crisis of war and hunger in southern Sudan have left the region because of a dispute with the main rebel group over their operations.

title: A Virtual Pop Star On the Rise
description: THESE days, pop stars are so carefully packaged that critics constantly harp about artificiality. But a new German crooner is reveling in it.

title: DEFENSIVE MEASURES
description: Fighting a hostile $165 million bid from the Sara Lee Corporation, Courtaulds Textiles P.L.C. of Britain said it would return more than $79 million to shareholders. The move pushed its stock up by as much as 9 percent, or 11.5 pence, to 137 pence. Courtaulds, the manufacturer of products including Gossard and Berlei lingerie, said it would sell a residual furniture business, its Lyle & Scott sportswear brand and George Rech clothing brand. It would then buy back an unspecified number of shares for up to 175 pence each.

title: On Campaign Trail, Gore Is the Stealth Candidate
description: Nothing captures Vice President Al Gore's relationship with his traveling press corps -- and the state of mind of the Gore campaign -- like the scene here on Tuesday night, when Mr. Gore was winning a soaring victory over his all-but-vanquished rival, Bill Bradley.

title: Roy Blough, 98, Official at the Treasury
description: Roy Blough, an economist who served in the Roosevelt and Truman administrations, died on Friday at a retirement home in Mitchellville, Md. He was 98.

title: Staten Island Brain Surgeon Denies That He Made Mistakes While Operating
description: Brandishing medical textbooks and x-rays last night, his voice choked with anguish, the Staten Island neurosurgeon accused by the State Department of Health of operating on the wrong side of a patient's brain and other medical blunders vehemently denied nearly every allegation.

title: Drug Officer Kills Suspect In a Struggle
description: A 23-year-old man was shot dead by a plainclothes police officer last night after a struggle in a Bronx apartment building, just three blocks from where Amadou Diallo was killed last year, the police said.

title: In Their Own Words
description: Following are comments from Vice President Al Gore and Senator Bill Bradley about committing American military power to defend Taiwan. The question was asked in their debate last night.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SALZER, HEDWIG
description: SALZER-Hedwig. Died peacefully at home on February 29, 2000, at the age of ninety-five. Dear wife of the late Dr. Felix Salzer, and beloved aunt of J. Miguel Steiner, Anne-Catherine Quibell, Claude M. Steiner, Susanne Lindtberg Fankhauser, Bettina Lindtberg Bucher and Florian Baalcke. Cherished by all of her family and her many friends. Private interment on Friday, March 3rd. Memorial service at The Mannes College of Music to be announced. In lieu of flowers, contributions in her memory may be made to the scholarship fund at The Mannes College of Music, 150 West 85th Street, New York, New York 10024.

title: In Era of T-shirts, Kurung Survives : Malaysians' Garment of Choice
description: KUALA LUMPUR  The advent of modernity in Southeast Asia has done to traditional fashion what fast-food restaurants did to the neighborhood tea stall.

title: KOREAN TRADE SURPLUS RETURNS
description: South Korea posted a trade surplus of $802 million in February, after a $391 million deficit in the previous month, according to a preliminary report released by the Ministry of Commerce, Industry and Energy. But February's trade surplus was lower than the $1.7 billion surplus South Korea posted in the corresponding period of last year. Samuel Len

title: A Frame To Hold Your Pixels
description: THE problem with old-fashioned picture frames is that they can display only one photograph at a time. If you have a lot of pictures, you need a lot of frames, and if you have a lot of frames, you need a lot of space on your desk, bedside table, mantel, walls and so on. That is rarely a problem for grandmothers, who miraculously seem to have infinite space for photos of the kids and grandchildren.

title: PAREXEL CUTS 500 JOBS BECAUSE OF LOST CONTRACT
description: The Parexel International Corporation, a drug research company in Waltham, Mass., said yesterday that it would cut as many as 500 jobs and it lowered its earnings estimates through 2001 because Novartis A.G. had canceled a contract. Parexel shares, down 64 percent in the last year, fell $5.125, to $8.50. The cancellation by Novartis, the world's third-largest drugmaker, will cause Parexel's clinical-research unit to have reduced revenue and earnings. Novartis canceled the contract because of changes in its drugs in research, Parexel said.

title: Video Technology to Make the Head Spin
description: WATCHING video images on the Internet is one of those computer tasks with more Next steps than a mambo. Viewers have long been forced to download many programs with many levels to squint into little windows on computer monitors to see smudgy, sputtering shadows.

title: Hazards Are Cited at Seton Hall Dormitory Where 3 Died
description: Six weeks after a dormitory fire at Seton Hall University killed 3 students and injured 58 others, state officials issued a report yesterday citing hundreds of code violations at the university's buildings, including 35 in Boland Hall, the site of the Jan. 19 blaze.

title: TOM.COM SHARES SOAR
description: Internet mania continued unabated in Hong Kong, as Tom.com, a start-up backed by Li Ka-shing, the billionaire, soared more than fivefold in its first day of trading. Tom.com set off a frenzy last week when its shares were offered to the public, causing near riots at local banks. Shares of the company, which has been in business for barely a month, began trading at more than four times their offering price of 1.78 Hong Kong dollars, or 23 cents, a share. They zoomed to a high of 9.70 Hong Kong dollars before closing at 7.75 Hong Kong dollars. Mr. Li's son Richard controls Pacific Century CyberWorks, another Internet start-up, which won a takeover battle for Cable and Wireless HKT this week. Mark Landler

title: Despite Criticism, Giuliani Pursues Ballparks as Economic Catalysts
description: In Coney Island, the steel skeleton of the Parachute Jump stands like a 250-foot-tall grave marker to bygone glory. On Staten Island, a muddy parking lot sits at the water's edge next to the dilapidated St. George ferry terminal.

title: An Ex-Con on the Run, Ducking Bullets and Jokes
description: Imagine a scenario in which a young black man, just freed from the penitentiary for the second time, haplessly stumbles into a situation that, thanks to the popularity of ''three strikes and you're out'' laws, could put him on ice forever. He must simultaneously try to prove his innocence and evade the police and the angry criminals who come after him. In the hands of a director like Charles Burnett or Sidney Lumet, this story might yield a rich, tense psychological thriller rippling with righteous political anger. It would have everything going for it: Hitch cockian suspense, heart-swelling melodrama, and up-to-the minute social relevance.

title: McCain Apologizes for Characterizing Falwell and Robertson as Forces of Evil
description: Under growing fire over his recent attacks on leaders of the Christian right, Senator John McCain apologized yesterday for remarks the day before in which he characterized Pat Robertson and the Rev. Jerry Falwell as ''forces of evil.'' He said those remarks had been intended as a joke.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SCHANTZ, FRIEDA
description: SCHANTZ-Frieda. On February 29. Beloved wife of the late Henry. Loving mother of Ronnie Schwartz. Cherished grandmother of Stephanie, Randi and Stephen & great-grandmother of Zachary, Monica and Stella. Services will be private. Family requests donations to be made to the Gurwin Jewish Geriatric Center.

title: Alabama, Florida and Georgia Fight Crucial Water War
description: In the Southeast, where rivers, swamps and marshes abound and high humidity and heavy thunderstorms are not uncommon, few ever thought that a lack of water would become a major problem. But urban growth, particularly here in Atlanta, and droughts in the last two decades have precipitated a battle among three states that experts are calling one of the biggest water wars in the United States in the last 30 years.

title: At Braves' Complex, The Circus Is in Town
description: Atlanta Manager Bobby Cox was pacing around the batting cage watching the Braves smack baseballs on an empty field when he saw Jim Schultz, the team's public relations director, in the dugout. Cox suddenly summoned Schultz as if he needed a closer in the ninth inning.

title: Stylish Picking at Outlet Prices
description: THERE is no better quick fix for a home than a new piece of furniture, especially if it's 50 years old. And even better, if it's bought at near-garage-sale prices -- in New York City. Some recently opened warehouses and ''pickers'' sell midcentury-modern furniture to the public at wholesale prices. While the quality and condition vary, the money saved can more than offset the cost of any reupholstering or refurbishing that may be necessary.

title: Those Distasteful Cookies
description: To the Editor:

title: Mahler's Fourth By the Dozen
description: Absolute Ensemble

title: DoubleClick Reverses on Using Personal Data
description: March 2, 2000

title: Met Rookie Needs To Limit Walks Before He Pitches
description: Grant Roberts's coaches used to have a joke for him. Roberts, the Mets' top pitching prospect, would be cruising along, entering, say, the fifth inning, and a coach would ask if he was tired and wanted to come out.

title: Paid Notice: Memorials  CLINE, CARROLL
description: CLINE-Carroll. Shared brief reminiscences will be welcomed at the memorial gathering on Thursday, March 2, at 4 PM at The Museum for African Art, 593 Broadway (near Houston Street)

title: Resignation Ploy in Austria
description: Jorg Haider's resignation as leader of Austria's Freedom Party is a tactical stunt that changes little. With or without the title of party leader, Mr. Haider remains the dominant figure in this racist and Nazi-admiring party and, sadly, a defining force in Austria's current coalition government. Europe, Israel and the United States have rightly distanced themselves from Vienna, and should continue doing so.

title: Another Day of Gun Violence
description: It just keeps getting more senseless. On Tuesday a first grader in Michigan shot and killed a 6-year-old classmate. Yesterday an adult gunman in Pennsylvania shot a worker at his apartment building, then fired on customers at two fast-food restaurants, killing two people and wounding three. He fled into a nearby office building before finally surrendering. These new eruptions of violence, coming just a day apart, only confirm the urgency of solving the nation's gun problem.

title: Paul Taylor Tickles Eyes And Ears, Seriously
description: The most popular choreographer working today is Paul Taylor. He needs no guest stars to fill a house, and his wide appeal to a general theater audience does not run counter to the seriousness of his enterprise.

title: Trapped in Afghanistan
description: To the Editor:

title: Noted Hacker Speaks Before Senate Panel
description: Noted Hacker Speaks Before Senate Panel

title: Action by Players Reinstates Season
description: The Arena Football League reinstated the 2000 season after a majority of players said they would act as their own collective bargaining unit.

title: Mars Shifts Account For Twix Brand
description: Mars Inc. in McLean, Va., said yesterday that it had shifted the creative duties for its Twix snack brand in the large American and European markets to offices of Grey Advertising in New York. Offices of D'Arcy Masius Benton & Bowles in New York, which had handled the creative account around the world, retain the creative duties in the smaller Asia-Pacific market.

title: WESTERN BUYS EUROPEAN UNIT OF PROTECTION ONE
description: Western Resources Inc., a Kansas utility company, bought the European operations of its money-losing home-security affiliate, Protection One Inc., yesterday for $244 million. Western's Westar Capital unit paid Protection One $183 million in cash and gave it debt securities with a market value of $61 million. Protection One has 126,341 customers in six European countries, along with 1,571 employees. Protection One will use the proceeds to reduce debt owed to Westar Capital. Protection One had a line of credit with Westar that allowed it to borrow up to $250 million. Western Resources, based in Topeka, Kan., owns 85 percent of Protection One, the second-biggest electronic home and business security company.

title: You Can Always Walk It Home
description: K2's new human-powered Kickboard, a scooter-skateboard hybrid made of aluminum, carbon fiber and wood, is one way to cut down on pollution. The machine has three wheels, a brake, a telescoping steering rod -- and that's about it. With a springy deck that makes doing stunts like 360-degree spins on the back wheel a breeze, the Kickboard is for progressive urbanites. It is $300 through select K2 distributors; information: (800) 972-4063.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SHULTZ, FLORENCE
description: SHULTZ-Florence Reiser. Died peacefully on February 27, 2000, at the age of ninety-two. She was the wife of the late Irving Shultz, sister of the late Helen Sheller, and aunt of the late Ed Sheller. She is survived by her brother-in-law, Robert Sheller, and her nieces and nephews, Elly, John, Daniel, and Kate Rufer, and Alex and Chris Sheller. She will be deeply missed by those who loved her.

title: Justices Rebuff Inmate's Bid On Early Supervised Release
description: The Supreme Court ruled today that a federal prisoner's term of ''supervised release'' begins when the inmate gets out of prison, even if it is clear that the person should have been released months or years earlier.

title: AN OVERHAUL IN JAPAN
description: Deutsche Bank A.G. said it had been told to overhaul five Japanese units after a four-month investigation by regulators, the latest in a string of investigations of financial companies. Deutsche Bank has until March 28 to tell the Financial Supervisory Agency what ''remedial action'' it will take. The German bank declined to comment on newspaper reports that it used derivatives to enable customers to hide losses.

title: Mother and Daughter, 5, Arrested on Drug Charge
description: A woman and her 5-year-old daughter have been arrested at Newark International Airport with more than two pounds of heroin concealed in the soles of their shoes, a United States Customs official said yesterday.

title: COMPANY BRIEFS
description: SPIEKER PROPERTIES INC., Menlo Park, Calif., the largest commercial real estate investment trust on the West Coast, acquired buildings in Bellevue, Wash., and in the North Bay area of San Francisco for $74.5 million.

title: A Strange House and Its Strange Story
description: LIKE many people who meander regularly through the storybook streets of the West Village, Tom Fontana had always wondered about the strange house on 13th Street near Eighth Avenue.

title: Pursuing Redemption, On Screen and Off
description: IN the shadow of the Brooklyn Bridge it seems to rain grime, or maybe we are just succumbing, here in Gleason's Gym, to the legend of the ring and the sadness of trainers.

title: Europe Plans to Collect Tax on Some Internet Transactions
description: Testing the ability to enforce national tax laws in cyberspace, the European Commission is planning to collect sales taxes on music and software delivered over the World Wide Web.

title: From 'Elektra' to Electric, Throngs Come Out in Sydney
description: This city's summer festival season opened to the conventional crescendos of grand opera and will close on Saturday with a three-hour gay and lesbian parade.

title: Jane Nickerson Steinberg, 83, Food Editor
description: Jane Nickerson Steinberg, a former food editor of The New York Times, died Sunday at a hospital in White Sulphur Springs, Mont. She was 83.

title: More Than 300,000 Face Summer School
description: Almost one of every three New York City public school students has been warned of the possibility of attending classes this summer to prevent being left back, the interim schools chancellor, Harold O. Levy, said at a board meeting yesterday.

title: Young Designers Are Customizing Secondhand Clothes : A New Twist to Old Threads
description: PARIS  Looking for something chic to wear to the Oscars? How about late 1960s Yves Saint Laurent? In a strange twist of fate, some of the hottest looks in style at the start of the millennium are born again. While bright young things are turning heads in vintage couture, young designers are customizing secondhand dresses, tearing apart old T-shirts, and putting their newest shapes in fabrics found at the flea market.

title: WORLD BUSINESS BRIEFING: AMERICAS; MEXICAN BOND OFFER
description: Offering bonds for the first time, Mexico's bank bailout agency issued $106 million in three-year bonds, which were placed by the Banco de Mexico, the central bank. The bond sale was well received, with demand significantly exceeding the amount offered, the bailout agency reported. The agency plans to sell at least $6.4 billion worth of the bonds this year to refinance $93 billion in debts the government assumed since the banking system nearly collapsed after the devaluation of the peso in December 1994. Dan Fineren

title: L.A.'s Ungovernable Police
description: Los Angeles is not the only American city that has problems with its police department, but the L.A.P.D. seems uniquely hospitable to rogue cops and uniquely resistant to reform. Only eight years after the Rodney King episode, the city is suffering a new scandal that has led to charges of perjury, evidence tampering and attempted murder, and has attracted the attention of the Federal Bureau of Investigation, the United States attorney and California's attorney general. A report released yesterday by the Police Department acknowledged that a ''breakdown'' in supervision had led to the scandal. But the report perpetuates the myth that the department can police itself.

title: Italian Designers Make Doors Fade Into the Woodwork
description: LEAVE it to Italians to solve a design problem homeowners didn't know they had: clunky doors. Try achieving a sleek and modern interior while dealing with throwback elements like doorjambs and thresholds, lintels and hinges, much less carved paneled doors. It's enough to make a minimalist swoon.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  GOODMAN, RITA
description: GOODMAN-Rita, Vice President Emeritus, The Johnson Foundation, Racine, Wisconsin died February 28, 2000, in Sarasota, FL. She was preceded in death by her husband, Arnold Goodman. She is survived by three sons and daughter-in-law, David and Kazuko, Norman and Kathy, Andrew and Sharon; five grandchildren, Yael, Kai, Moshe, Meira, and Alexandra; and her companion, Sanford Solender. At her request, her remains were cremated and scattered in the Gulf of Mexico. Memorial services will be held at 3:00 PM, Sunday March 5, 2000 at Temple Beth Isreal on Longboat Key, FL. Memorials to your favorite charity will be appreciated. For more information contact Toale Brothers Funeral Home, Colonial Chapel, Sarasota, FL.

title: BUSINESS DIGEST
description: Technology Shares Propel Nasdaq to Yet Another High

title: Finding Adventure In Endless Winter
description: As the ski and snowboard season heads into spring, it's still not too late to infuse the waning season with a bit of adventure. Groomed trails and the steeps are not bad for a steady diet. But how about Sno-Cat skiing, a weekend clinic, or an overnight excursion?

title: In New York, McCain Faces Sharp Attacks
description: Fresh from his three-state victory Tuesday night, Gov. George W. Bush yesterday turned his attention to New York, unleashing a stream of attacks -- by mail, radio and top surrogates -- that questioned Senator John McCain's record on financing breast cancer research and portrayed him as repeatedly voting against New Yorkers' concerns.

title: Metro Business; Bank Merging Branches
description: HSBC Bank USA plans to consolidate 21 metropolitan New York branches as a result of the merger with Republic National Bank of New York, pending regulatory approval.

title: Picnickers, Be Prepared
description: Survivalists in the bush (and city picnickers) have no reason to forgo seasonings, thanks to Zelco's clever all-in-one FoodTool, designed by Stuart Harvey Lee of Prime Studio in New York. The 5.7-inch aluminum-cased unit, above, combines a three-inch laser-edge knife, can opener, screwdriver, Teflon-coated corkscrew, bottle opener and salt and pepper shakers hidden in the easy-to-grip handle. The $29.99 tool is at the MoMA Design Store, Bed, Bath & Beyond and other specialty stores.

title: Essay; Toward 'Titanic Tuesday'
description: In his powerful Virginia speech declaring war on the religio-pols who long dominated the selection of Republican losers, John McCain turned his campaign into a crusade reminiscent of Dwight Eisenhower's 1952 upset of Robert Taft.

title: Bush Flunks Letterman's Late-Night Examination
description: When Gov. George W. Bush showed up by satellite on ''Late Show with David Letterman'' last night, he was smiling, good-natured, prepared to laugh at himself. Imagine, then, what a comic flop he had to be to elicit groans and boos from the audience, as he did with jokes about Mr. Letterman's recent heart surgery.

title: Aetna Receives $9.9 Billion Takeover Bid From 2 Companies
description: Aetna Inc. said yesterday that it had received a $9.9 billion purchase offer last week from ING America Insurance Holdings, a financial services company in the Netherlands, and WellPoint Health Networks, a California-based national managed care company.

title: Vatican Outline Issued on Apology for Historical Failings
description: A Vatican document was released today outlining the conditions and limits to a sweeping apology Pope John Paul II plans to deliver later this month for the Roman Catholic Church's historical failings.

title: The Eichmann Memoirs
description: To the Editor:

title: In America; The Wrong Man
description: A little before 12:30 p.m. on Dec. 30, 1997, a masked gunman walked into a bodega on Strauss Street in the Brownsville section of Brooklyn. There were four other people in the store: the owner, Jesus Martinez, known affectionately in the neighborhood as ''Poppy,'' a teenage employee named Frankie Rodriguez, and two young customers, Candace Daniel, 13, and Steven Green, 15.

title: Third of Pupils May Require Summer School, Officials Warn
description: Almost one of every three New York City public school students has been warned of the possibility of attending classes this summer to avoid being left back, the interim chancellor, Harold O. Levy, revealed yesterday as he unfurled an ambitious plan to prevent some of the problems of last summer.

title: U.S. Is Moving to Crack Down On Discount Telephone Services
description: The federal government said today that it would begin to crack down on what it said was widespread deception in the way discount telephone services have been promoted.

title: Sony Vaio Player Puts Music in Your Pocket
description: Several new audio players have the look and feel of anything but digital technology. The recently released Rome, for example, resembles a cassette tape, a pleasant retro shape for those MP3 users old enough to remember cassette tapes. The new Sony Vaio Music Clip has the weight and dimensions of a pen you might have received as a high school graduation gift.

title: WORLD BRIEFING
description: EUROPE

title: Iran's Nuclear Ambition
description: To the Editor:

title: BP Amoco Responds to F.T.C. on Merger
description: With wide gaps remaining in settlement negotiations, BP Amoco and the Atlantic Richfield Company accused the Federal Trade Commission today of misinterpreting antitrust law in an effort to block their $30 billion merger.

title: You Win Some, You Break Some
description: IT was a night like any other.

title: FOOTLIGHTS
description: NEWS

title: Opinion on L.I. Reassessment Shifts With Neighborhood
description: To Raymond and Anna Veit, who have spent years paying more than their fair share of property taxes, the news that Nassau County is moving to reassess their tidy brick Cape Cod here, along with every other property in the county, is more than welcome.

title: BUOYANT BUSINESS AT GAS LEADER
description: Buoyed by a vigorous second half, Air Liquide S.A. of France, the world's biggest supplier of industrial gases, said its profit in 1999 rose 9.1 percent, to 563 million euros ($546 million), up from 516 million euros the year before. Profit in the second half of 1999 soared 17 percent, to 303 million euros, or $294 million. Air Liquide, which joined Air Products and Chemicals Inc. of the United States last July to acquire and split up the world's No. 2 industrial gas supplier, BOC Group P.L.C. of Britain, in a deal worth $11.2 billion, said it expected earnings per share to rise by at least 10 percent this year, and by 50 percent in the following three years. John Tagliabue

title: Strawberry Checks Into Rehabilitation Clinic
description: Darryl Strawberry checked into a drug-rehabilitation clinic today in Florida, two days after he was suspended for a year by Major League Baseball for violating his after-care program.

title: Jobs Data for 1999 Paint a Rosier Picture for Upstate New York
description: Upstate New York, where the economy remained bleak even as an economic boom swept the rest of the nation, suddenly spurted ahead of much of the country in terms of job creation, according to new data for 1999 released yesterday by the New York State Department of Labor.

title: Czech Line Does Some Damage, But Rangers Get a Bad Bounce
description: The Rangers' Czech line forwards dominated their countryman who happens to be nicknamed the Dominator last night, but the Rangers let another third-period lead slip away. And that disturbing tendency is something the Rangers may have all summer to think about after games like last night's 3-3 tie with the Buffalo Sabres at Madison Square Garden.

title: Rocker Permitted To Attend Camp, To Selig's Dismay
description: Baseball's arbitrator slashed by about two-thirds yesterday Commissioner Bud Selig's suspension of John Rocker, the Atlanta Braves pitcher, who in a magazine interview disparaged foreigners, gays and members of minority groups.

title: Gore and Bradley Sing in Harmony in Latest Meeting
description: Meeting in their last debate before more than a dozen states vote in primaries and caucuses on Tuesday, Vice President Al Gore and former Senator Bill Bradley appeared uncharacteristically harmonious together tonight, going out of their way to agree on virtually every issue and avoiding the kind of attacks that characterized their raucous debate just over a week ago in Harlem.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SINGER, SOL
description: SINGER-Sol, 90, of PA, formerly of Lynbrook, NY, on February 29. Husband of the late Gloria Haines. Graveside service 11 AM, Friday, Mt. Hebron Cemetery, Flushing. Ashton Funeral Home, Easton, PA

title: Ads and Promotions At New High on TV
description: Clutter on television -- the time devoted to nonprogramming content like commercials and promotions -- reached its highest level ever last year, according to an annual report from agencies and advertisers, which are concerned that such clutter makes viewers less likely to watch or remember spots.

title: Mary Bodne, Ex-Owner of Algonquin Hotel, Dies at 93
description: Mary Bodne, who with her husband, Ben, fell in love with the Algonquin Hotel on their honeymoon and later owned it for 41 years, died on Monday at Lenox Hill Hospital in Manhattan. She was 93.

title: HOUSE BACKS END TO EARNINGS LIMIT ON SOCIAL SECURITY
description: The House voted 422 to 0 today to allow most Social Security recipients for the first time to earn as much money as they want without sacrificing any of their retirement benefits, repealing a Depression-era policy intended to discourage older people from holding jobs so younger workers would have a chance.

title: So Far, Britain Grants Asylum to Few on Hijacked Afghan Jet
description: Only four of the dozens of passengers who applied for political asylum after their plane was hijacked from Afghanistan last month will definitely be allowed to remain in Britain, the government said tonight. Twenty-seven others have been ordered to leave the country with their families, while the status of the remaining passengers has yet to be decided.

title: Design, Buildings and Grounds
description: All Design, All the Time

title: The Religion Wars
description: In 1960, having assured Southern Protestants that he would not take his orders from the Church of Rome, John F. Kennedy became the country's first Catholic president, and for the next 20 years Americans comfortably assumed that sectarianism had been taken off the political table. In the 1976 campaign, Jimmy Carter added ''born again'' to the political lexicon. But it was not until Ronald Reagan allied himself with the Christian right in 1980 that religious leaders began to assert a larger role in American politics in general and the Republican Party in particular.

title: 3 Massacres In Chechnya Are Described
description: An investigator for Human Rights Watch told Congress today that his group had documented three ''large-scale massacres'' by Russian forces in Chechnya. That prompted Democratic and Republican senators to criticize the Clinton administration, saying that it was playing down Russia's conduct in the war to keep its relationship with Moscow intact for other issues like arms control.

title: HEAVY POSTURING SEEN IN I.M.F. RIFT
description: When President Clinton pledged this week to block a German finance ministry official from assuming the top post at the International Monetary Fund, in effect vetoing the man the European Union had chosen for the job, he seemed to risk a diplomatic confrontation across the Atlantic.

title: Reid, an Ex-Drug Dealer, Finds Success in the Ring
description: As a boxer, if David Reid does not take care of things in the ring with his fists, his fate rests in the hands of judges. But there was once a time when a Pennsylvania court judge held Reid's fate in his hands, and his decision could have derailed Reid's future as an Olympic champion and a world champion.

title: Extensive Genealogy Package With a Focus on Ellis Island
description: With all the major home genealogy programs providing users with baskets of historical records on multiple CD-ROM's, it seems the only thing missing in the box these days is Ellis Island itself. Sierra Home's Generations Family Tree Millennium Collection fills that particular bill with an extensive collection of data from the Ellis Island station, including immigrant records, census images and ship's passenger lists. The company says the package is ''the first compendium of Ellis Island information available to consumers.''

title: A 'Moral Meltdown'?
description: To the Editor:

title: Vienna Journal; No Dance Partners? Austria Becomes a Wallflower
description: Elisabeth Gurtler, the heiress to the Sachertorte fortune, is a discreet woman who keeps the original recipe for that gorgeous chocolate cake in a safe and her deepest feelings about the fiasco surrounding this year's Vienna Opera Ball to herself. ''I'm certainly not happy,'' is all she will say.

title: Japan Software Suppliers Linked to Sect
description: Computer companies affiliated with the Aum Shinrikyo doomsday sect developed software programs for at least 10 government agencies, including the Defense Ministry, and more than 80 major Japanese companies in recent years, police officials said today after a surprise raid on the group's sites on Tuesday.

title: Another New Retro Store
description: Emmemobili, an Italian furniture manufacturer, combines clean, retro forms with contemporary materials and production techniques. The company is represented exclusively in the United States by Property, the new home furnishings store in SoHo owned by Stefan Beckman and Sabrina Schilcher. In rich woods with complex curves, Emmemobili's simple and versatile products meld well with vintage pieces or contemporary ones. The Summer shelves ($1,600), Spring chair ($520) and Escher coffee table ($1,320) are made of African wenge wood. Property is at 14 Wooster (Canal): (917) 237-0123.

title: Survey Shows Americans Love Their Computers and the Net

title: Examining A Settled Life And Marriage

Musicians wouldn't pretend to be anything but what they were: no fancy stage clothes, no show-biz facades, no posturing. As rockers grow older and more stable, with their adolescent and postadolescent dramas receding, many find less to write about and less to interest listeners. But Yo La Tengo -- formed in the mid-1980's by the guitarist Ira Kaplan and the drummer Georgia Hubley, who are married -- proves that the settled life is still worth examining.

The affiliate, Canadian Occidental Petroleum Ltd. of Calgary, will pay $592 million for 20 million of its own shares. The Ontario Teachers Pension Plan Board will pay $600 million for 20.2 million shares. Timothy Pritchard

title: Corrections

A small number of the 100,000 restaurateurs and small businesses that use the system encountered billing problems because they had not updated their software. The CyberCash system itself did not break down.

title: U.S. and Mexico Are at Odds Over Truth About Lie Tests
description: The chairman of a House committee with oversight over drug policy said today that Mexico, embarrassed by the poor showing of its anti-drug agents in lie detector tests, had canceled the testing program last August.

description: The National Collegiate Athletic Association president rebuked St. John's yesterday, saying school officials had misrepresented the facts surrounding Erick Barkley's eligibility case to the news media and had refused to follow the organization's procedures.

title: Oh Mom, I'm Sick Of 'Fur Elise'; To the Rescue of Intermediate Pianists
description: Children taking piano lessons today can choose from an extensive repertory of elementary-level pieces by the greatest of composers. Bach and Schumann wrote volumes of such works, though they had personal as well as pedagogical reasons to do so: both were doting fathers. Lots of little minuets and dance pieces by Mozart are ideal for children, which only makes sense: he composed them when he was a child himself. Beethoven wrote quite a few works for beginning-level pianists, though he may have been motivated more by a chance to make extra money than by genuine affection for children. Still, the Minuet in G and ''Fur Elise'' have been played by grateful youngsters ever since.

description: Charles Cermele

title: Will That Be Cash or Cell Phone?; Wireless Payment Systems Might Mean Dialing Inot Your Own Wallet
description: CYBERSPACE is littered with the flotsam of online-payment schemes that have failed. Companies like DigiCash, First Virtual Holdings and CyberCash have either gone bankrupt or undergone makeovers.

title: TICKETS.COM ACQUIRES FIRST CALL INTERNATIONAL
description: Tickets.com Inc. agreed yesterday to acquire the privately held First Call International Ltd., the second-largest ticket seller for entertainment events in Britain, for up to $126.7 million in stock. The deal would give Tickets.com of Costa Mesa, Calif., access to First Call's interactive TV technology, which allows customers to buy tickets at home by using their remote controls. Tickets.com, which was founded in 1995, sells tickets to events over the phone and Internet and through retail outlets. The final price of the deal -- which could range from $103.6 million to $126.7 million -- will depend on Tickets.com's average stock price over the 30 days before the transaction closes. Shares in Tickets.com closed at $10.875, down $2.75, in Nasdaq trading.
