description: In the morning, the boy pulled out a pistol and killed his first-grade classmate Kayla Rolland.

title: Bennigan's Picks Richards Group
description: Bennigan's Irish American Grill and Tavern, part of the Metromedia Restaurant Group, has named the Richards Group in Dallas as its agency of record to handle strategic planning and creative work. Billings were estimated at $5 million.

title: Corrections
description: An article on the Management page in Business Day on Feb. 16 about the daunting task of young managers who have to fire employees included one example erroneously. IVillage.com says it has never laid off employees for economic reasons and has not recently trimmed its staff.

title: Kosovo Rebels Regrouping Nearby in Serbia
description: Just across the boundary line from Kosovo, guarded more visibly now by American troops in watchtowers, armed Albanians wearing uniforms of a new branch of the Kosovo Liberation Army are training for a battle the West does not want them to have.

description: Scouts and coaches this week began dissecting an overflow of paperwork, interviews and videotape on more than 320 college players. It is their time to focus on last weekend's combine in Indianapolis.

title: In Lieu of Patriots, Hartford Gets a Check for $2.4 Million
description: Ten months after the New England Patriots backed out of a $375 million deal that would have made Hartford a star in the National Football League's constellation of football cities, Connecticut finally got some payback today.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  REIS, MILDRED (NEE RUBIN)
description: REIS-Mildred (nee Rubin), Of East Hampton, New York City and Coconut Creek Fl. Devoted, loving wife to Rudy Reis, sister to Bernice Meyerson, and Rita Levey, and aunt to Robert (Bunny), Paul (Betsy), and Daniel Meyerson, and Frances and Eric (Hope) Levey, and stepmother to Susan Lyons and Vivien Reis. Mildred devoted her professional life to the advancement of human rights as Administrator for the Anti Defamation League of B'nai Brith. She hosted U.S. Presidents and other dignitaries around the world during her 35 year career. She loved music, art, literature and theater. Services will be held at Riverside Memorial Chapel, West 76 St, Sunday, Mar 5, at 11:30 AM.

title: A Legendary Filmmaker, But Without His Camera
description: ''Drawing and dancing are branches of the same tree,'' wrote the Russian filmmaker Sergei Eisenstein (1898-1948). ''Of course, they are just two varieties of the same impulse.'' It was the movement of line in the two disciplines that excited his imagination.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SIMON, EDWARD
description: SIMON-Edward. The management and employees of Edlaw Pharmaceuticals, Inc., Farmingdale, NY, express their great sadness at the passing of the Founder and Chairman of the Board of this company. He was a great gentleman and his advise and counsel will be missed. We offer our deep sympathy to Marvin and Edwina Marks, and the members of the family. Scott Giroux, Vice President

title: Bush and McCain Trade Bitter Criticism As Campaigns in New York Gather Steam
description: John McCain and George W. Bush head into New York today to begin personally campaigning in a state whose primary seems likely to help determine their fates, after setting a bitter stage yesterday with a harsh round of exchanges about the way each man is trying to win the White House.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  RITCH, MINERVA G.
description: RITCH-Minerva G. Born August 11, 1908 in Ansonia, Ct. Died March 2, 2000 in Hamden, CT. Preceded in death by her husband Edward Lewis Ritch. Loving mother of Dr. Robert Ritch of Manhattan and Dr. Paul S. Ritch of Milwaukee, WI. Also survived by her daughter-inlaw Dr. Marjorie Vukelich, grandsons Paul Edward Ritch and John Michael Ritch, sisters Gertrude Levitin of Delray Beach, Fla, and Edith Brenner of Richmond, VA., brother Dr. Sidney M. Grossberg of Cheshire, CT., brother-in-law Dr. Phillip Brenner. Period of mourning private. In lieu of flowers contributions may be made to the New York Glaucoma Research Institute, 310 E. 14 St., NY, NY 10003.

title: Round, Opulent and Very Young and Hip
description: PARIS  Ever since queens and courtesans began to emphasize their necks with precious opalescent spheres, pearl necklaces have been every woman's best friend. In the 1930s, Coco Chanel wore her sumptuous rope of natural pearls  the token of a grand duke's affection  mixed with a cluster of costume jewelry, inventing a style that was to become a classic. In the '50s, their image became proper and ladylike. A few seasons ago, John Galliano triggered a new craze for pearls when he dressed up a Dior collection with spectacular pearl chokers.

description: Here is a selective listing by critics of The Times of new or noteworthy movies and film series playing this weekend in New York City. *denotes a highly recommended film or series. Ratings and running times are in parentheses. An index of reviews of films opening today appears on Page 16.

title: Rocker Returns, and the Reaction Is . . . Polite
description: After John Rocker was sneaked into the Atlanta Braves spring training complex around 8 a.m. today, he walked through the doors of an anxious and awaiting clubhouse. Rocker wore a smile, perhaps a nervous one, as he returned to the place where some teammates once said he would never be wanted again.

description: OBERFIELD-Gilbert R. Died sud denly on March 1st. He was an intelligent, adventurous, exuberant and wonderful man who loved life, laughter and his family. He is survived by his wife Naomi Danis, his children Sophie, Ezra and Talya, his parents Ruth and Bernard. Siblings William, Richard and Sara Hohn, parents-in-law Seymour Z''L and Ruth Danis, and many more relatives, friends and colleagues who will miss him. Funeral 9:30am Friday Schwartz Brothers, Forest Hills.

title: Panel Seeks Web Posting Of Sex Offender Data
description: Defying a federal judge's order that the state tighten its law on notification about sex offenders, an Assembly panel approved a bill yesterday to allow the posting of information about sex offenders on the World Wide Web.

title: ART GUIDE
description: Here is a selective listing by critics of The New York Times of new or noteworthy art, design and photography exhibitions at New York City museums and art galleries this weekend. Addresses, unless otherwise noted, are in Manhattan. Most galleries are closed on Sundays and Mondays, but hours vary and should be checked by telephone. Gallery admission is free.

title: A Cool, Lucid Mysticism in Beethoven
description: A few years ago, the pianist Murray Perahia was recuperating from complicated hand surgery after a serious finger injury. For a while it seemed possible that his performing career might end.

title: Brightening Up By Wrapping Up Shawls Add a Dash of Flair
description: PARIS  The current craze for pashmina shawls of all styles and prices might in the end prove to be detrimental to the status of cashmere as a luxury product. But its impact on women's wardrobes is likely to be lasting by focusing on an accessory  the shawl  which has become a hot fashion ticket.

title: Corrections
description: An article yesterday about the novelist Dennis Cooper, subject of a symposium at New York University in Fales Library, which houses his archives, misidentified two scheduled participants in a reading of his work tonight. Thurston Moore is the guitarist of the rock band Sonic Youth, not its bassist; Robert Gober is a sculptor, not a painter.

title: Consumers' Spending Spree Continues Online and in Stores
description: Even though the Federal Reserve raised interest rates, oil prices increased and the stock market grew more volatile, American consumers continued their spending spree in stores and on the Internet, two reports showed yesterday.

title: Corrections
description: An article in Business Day on Monday about the business plans of Healtheon/WebMD, an online health care information company, misspelled the surname of an executive who supervises software programmers and computer engineers. He is Pavan Nigam, not Nigram.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  CASHIN, BONNIE
description: CASHIN-Bonnie on February 3, 2000. A memorial service will be held Thursday, March 9th at 2:30PM at St. Thomas Church, 5th Avenue and 53rd Street, NYC. In lieu of flowers, contributions may be made to the Educational Foundation for the Fashion Industries at FIT (indicate for the Bonnie Cashin Fund) and sent to the Office for Institutional Advancement, Room C-913D, Fashion Institute of Technology, 7th Avenue at 27th Street, New York City 10001.

title: Some Oil Producing Countries Agree Output Should Rise
description: With the high cost of oil and gasoline spreading alarm through Western economies, oil ministers from Saudi Arabia, Venezuela and Mexico -- all among the world's major exporters -- met here today and agreed that production should be increased to stabilize prices, but they declined to make firm commitments on the timing or the amount.

title: From Old Buenos Aires to a Brave New World
description: BUENOS AIRES 1910: Memories of the World to Come'' is the latest ripple in a wave that has been undulating through art, architecture and entertainment for almost a generation: the rise of the City as an icon for cultural globalization. In museum shows, scholarly books and MTV dance marathons, not to mention tourism promotions, individual cities are being recast as the neighborhoods of one vast cosmopolitan condition. Images of Moscow, New York, Prague, Brasilia, Berlin, Vienna, Lisbon, Chicago, Havana, Dublin, Lagos, Macao, Barcelona and others are converging like segments of an ever-expanding Baedeker map. The Buenos Aires show, on view at the World Financial Center, adds a few new folds.

title: 19 Charged in Stock Scheme Tied to Mob
description: The scheme was straight out of a Hollywood pitch meeting, the authorities said: ''Goodfellas'' meets ''Boiler Room.'' For nearly three years, they explained, a cadre of stockbrokers cheated unsuspecting investors out of $40 million -- with the support and muscle of the New York mob.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  LEW, NORMA
description: LEW-Norma. The members of Memoria Activa (Active Memory) of Argentina sadly mourn the passing of their President and CoFounder. Valiant Norma led us in our fight to find truth and justice in the case of the AMIA Buenos Aires Jewish Community Center bombing in 1994. Norma miraculously survived the attack while her eldest son Agustin was killed in the explosion along with the other 85 victims. Our hearts are with her family. May her memory be a blessing.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  IRWIN, JOHN N. II
description: IRWIN-John N. II. The Board of Trustees and community of The Chapin School mourn the passing of John N. Irwin II, who generously served the school as a memeber of the Board from 1961-1970. We extend our sincere condolences to the entire Irwin family but most especially to daughter Jane Irwin Droppa, an alumna of the school, and to son John N. Irwin III, who also served Chapin as a Trustee. Cera B. Robbins, President Sandra J. Theunick, Head of School

description: On Thursday afternoon, the America's Cup went for a spin.

title: Summer School Isn't a Solution
description: This summer, the New York City Board of Education intends to hold back one of three public school students -- 320,000 children -- and send them to summer school. This initiative will be a disaster. Harold Levy, the interim chancellor, who inherited it, should change course before it is too late.

title: Talk About Jet Lag
description: In ''What Planet Are You From?'' Garry Shandling (left) plays an alien with a mission: to find an Earth woman to bear a son he can take home. But the flakiness of Earthlings soon affects him in this Mike Nichols comedy.

title: Management Changes at Global
description: The maneuvering within Global Crossing Ltd.'s crowded executive suite took an unexpected turn yesterday as Robert Annunziata, who joined the company barely a year ago, stepped down as chief executive in favor of Leo J. Hindery Jr., who joined the company just three months ago.

title: Devils Fall Apart in the Second Period and Are Shut Out
description: The Devils may have the best record in the Eastern Conference, but they allowed three goals in 94 seconds and suffered a humiliating 5-0 loss to the Colorado Avalanche tonight.

title: Police Unit's Scope Is Crime in the Housing Projects
description: The Police Department unit involved in the fatal shooting of a Bronx man on Wednesday night was one of several formed to deal with crime problems ranging from drug use to quality-of-life issues in and around housing projects.

title: The Rev. Brian O'Connell, 59, Dean at St. John's University
description: The Rev. Brian J. O'Connell, a sociologist who was dean of St. John's University's College of Liberal Arts and Sciences and a former president of Niagara University, died on Monday at a hospital in Rockville Centre, N.Y. He was 59 and lived on the St. John's campus in the Jamaica section of Queens.

title: Viva la Brasserie!
description: In France a brasserie traditionally specialized in beer and Alsatian food; in fact, the word itself is French for beer hall or brewery. Today's brasseries, which tend to focus on wine rather than beer, are enjoying great popularity in Manhattan. Here are a dozen to choose from. (These summaries are taken from dining reviews, columns and articles in The Times by William Grimes, Eric Asimov and others.)

title: Beauty for Beauty's Sake
description: For breadth and beauty of sound, the Minnesota Orchestra's concert at Carnegie Hall on Tuesday evening could not be faulted. Eiji Oue, the orchestra's music director, demonstrated that his orchestra's strings have both the interpretive and technical flexibility to produce the bright, trim sound appropriate for a Mozart concerto, the glassine, otherworldly timbre demanded by Aaron Jay Kernis's ''Musica Celestis'' and the velvety texture called for in the Largo of Shostakovich's Fifth Symphony and the more strident tone in the work's finale. The wind and brass playing in the Shostakovich was well-tuned, solid and equally vivid.

title: Custody Case Trial Focuses On Intent of Militia Leader
description: On this point, at least, the prosecution and the defense agree: On the afternoon of Sept. 30, 1996, Bo Gritz, a former Green Beret commando and a leader of the far-right militia movement, was sitting in a car in the parking lot of McAlister Middle School in Suffield, Conn., a small town on the Massachusetts border far from his favorite stamping grounds in the Idaho hills.

title: QUOTATION OF THE DAY
description: ''I'm nuts. I took a leave to go to the funeral of my friend who was killed by a missile, and then I actually came back, two weeks before I'm supposed to get married. You'd think I'd be saying, 'What's the point?' ''

title: A World History, Until Woodstock
description: If two singing and mugging middle-aged men shamelessly striving to be naughty and adorable, dismantling a penthouse apartment, changing clothes onstage and spending altogether too much time in their underwear sounds like smashing entertainment, then ''The Big Bang'' is the show you've been waiting for.

title: Congressman Refuses Right-to-Life Support
description: Averting a crisis within his newly adopted party, Representative Michael P. Forbes, a Long Island Democrat who left the Republican Party last summer, announced yesterday that he would not accept the endorsement of the Right to Life Party.

title: Corrections
description: A brief report in Science Times on Tuesday about undue optimism and the terminally ill misstated the degree to which most doctors in a study overestimated the remaining lifetimes of patients who had been referred to hospices. It was by a factor of 5.3, not by 5.3 percent.

title: Candidates Return to Familiar Issues: Recriminations and Religious Tolerance
description: The setting was surreal tonight, with Gov. George W. Bush standing at a lectern and his main opponent, Senator John McCain, beaming from a television monitor a few feet away. Yet all of the bitterness of the Republican presidential race was on full display as the rivals rehashed mutual recriminations in a debate four days before a round of critical primaries across the country.

title: INSIDE
description: No Leader Yet for I.M.F.

title: CONOCO AGREES TO BUY A BUSINESS FROM PETRO-CANADA
description: Conoco Inc., the fourth-largest United States oil company, agreed yesterday to buy most of Petro-Canada's natural gas liquids business for as much as $206.4 million. A final purchase price has not been reached because some of Petro-Canada's partners in the gas liquids business have the right to bid on its assets, and that may reduce how much Conoco will buy in the transaction, a Petro-Canada vice president, Norman F. McIntyre, said. The final purchase price could be as low as $138 million. Natural gas liquids are fuels like propane and butane extracted from natural gas before it is shipped to market by pipeline. Petro-Canada, based in Calgary, Alberta, is selling the fifth-largest natural gas processing plant in North America.

title: Timing Is the Key In Barkley's Case
description: Erick Barkley remained ineligible yesterday and probably will not fly to Miami with the team today for St. John's Big East season finale Sunday in Miami.

title: Rarae Aves: Audubon At Auction
description: ''The climate in Scotland is very good for books,'' Francis Wahlgren, the head of Christie's books department in New York, said with a smile. ''It's damp and cold.'' He was commenting on the the fine condition of four giant volumes of John James Audubon's ''Birds of America,'' which had been in a Scottish house since 1909 before being consigned to Christie's.

title: KOREAN STOCK RALLY
description: Korean stocks staged their biggest rally in more than 18 months, led by Samsung Electronics and Hyundai Electronics Industries. ''Foreign investors turned aggressive buyers,'' said An Gyoo Sun, an analyst at Hanvit Securities. The Kospi index rose 66.28, to 894.66. It was the largest one-day percentage gain since June 17, 1998.

description: John Starks may get another chance at a title -- perhaps in a Knicks uniform. An arbitrator could decide as early as today whether Starks can void the remaining $900,000 of his contract, shed his odd-fitting Chicago Bulls' uniform and join a contending team.

description: Bright House in Atlanta has agreed to buy itself back from its parent, the Omnicom Group. Terms were not disclosed.

title: Man Charged in 2 Rapes In Queens Based on DNA
description: A 31-year-old Queens man has been charged with two 1999 rapes based on DNA linking him to the crimes, the police said yesterday.

title: Caution: Falling Yugo Zone Ahead
description: In the pulpy comedy ''Drowning Mona,'' Bette Midler, as Mona Dearly, looks a mess, with a dye job the color of Tang, similar to the faded taffy hue of the Yugos that dot the front yards of Verplanck, the tiny upstate New York town where the movie is set. A series of crude shots -- some of which are very funny -- that pop the small cast of yokels right between the eyes, ''Mona'' is a dreary crash of malapropisms and slapstick maimings wrapped very loosely around a murder mystery.

title: Sales of New Homes Fall 4.2%, To Lowest Level in Four Months
description: Sales of new homes fell to the lowest level in four months in January, government figures showed today, signaling that higher borrowing costs are starting to discourage buyers.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  MATTHIASDOTTIR, LOUISA
description: MATTHIASDOTTIR-Louisa. The members of the American Academy of Arts and Letters note with sorrow the death of their esteemed colleague whose passing will be deeply mourned by the world of art.

title: ADIDAS CHIEF TO STEP DOWN
description: The chief executive of the world's No. 2 sporting goods maker, Adidas-Salomon A.G., Robert Louis-Dreyfus, left, said he would step down in favor of his deputy, Herbert Hainer, 46. He was named chief operating officer in November and aims to slim the product range by 20 percent by the middle of this year. ''I will be here all this year and if he performs as I'm sure he will, I will leave in 2001,'' Mr. Louis-Dreyfus said.

title: Indianapolis Church Challenges the I.R.S. in a Battle Over Payroll Taxes
description: The Internal Revenue Service is on a collision course with an Indianapolis church, one of a small but growing number of New Testament churches that say they are not subject to federal tax laws requiring employers to withhold income, Social Security and Medicare taxes from workers.

title: The Story of a Meteorite
description: In the history of the Willamette Meteorite, there are at least two memorable photos. The first shows the meteorite in Oregon, resting on a rough sledge made of logs, its inertia almost palpable. The second shows the meteorite chained to a heavy dray, about to be unloaded at the American Museum of Natural History in 1906. Somehow, it looks even heavier in New York. Since 1935 the Willamette Meteorite, the largest ever found in the United States, has been housed in the Hayden Planetarium. Now it is mounted beneath the Hayden Sphere in the new Rose Center for Earth and Space.

title: Corrections
description: A report in the News Watch column of Circuits yesterday about the Sony Vaio Music Clip, a personal audio player, referred incorrectly to the digital audio files it can play. It accepts any MP3 file, not just those that have been converted to the Antrac3 format.

title: Reprieve for Houston TV Station
description: Lee P. Brown, the mayor of Houston, stepped in to prevent a scheduled shut down of the ABC television station yesterday by announcing that he had won an agreement from ABC and Time Warner's cable unit to extend their contract in Houston for seven days.

title: Nancy B. Reed, 75, Who Wrote Musicals
description: Nancy Binns Reed, a composer of musicals and operas, died on Saturday at her home in Burke, Va. She was 75. The cause was lung cancer, her family said.

title: AVNET TO ACQUIRE SAVOIR TECHNOLOGY IN A STOCK DEAL
description: Avnet Inc., a computer-parts distributor, said yesterday that it had agreed to buy the Savoir Technology Group for about $140 million in stock and assumed debt. Each Savoir share is to be exchanged for 0.11996 of an Avnet share, or $7.85, which is below Savoir's recent price. Savoir, based in Campbell, Calif., sells I.B.M. mainframes and servers. It had 1999 revenue of $767 million. Avnet, based in Phoenix, said the acquisition would make it the world's No. 1 distributor of I.B.M.'s midrange servers. Shares of Avnet, which had sales of $6.35 billion for the year that ended July 2, fell $1.25, to $64.1875. Shares of Savoir fell $1.25, to $7.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SUOZZI, JOSEPH M.
description: SUOZZI-Joseph M. Of Glen Cove, N.Y., London, England and formerly, Tokyo, Japan. Unexpectedly on February 25, 2000. Devoted husband of Marea and loving father of Maggie and Patrick. Cherished son of Judge Joseph A. and Marguerite Suozzi and son-in-law of Dr. Anne Grosso and Dr. Joseph E. Mule. Beloved brother of Rosemary Lloyd (Lewis), Dr. William (Jacquelyn), Christopher (Nicole) and Mayor Thomas R. Suozzi (Helene). A graduate of Chaminade, Boston College Cum Laude, Northeastern and Saint John's Law School. A CPA and attorney, he served in various capacities at Morgan Stanley New York and Tokyo, Credit Suisse First Boston Tokyo and London, and, most recently, Deutsche Bank London. The family will receive friends Saturday and Sunday, 3-5 and 7-9PM at the McLaughlin Kramer Megiel Funeral Home, 220 Glen St, Glen Cove. Funeral Mass Saint Patrick's Church, Monday, 10AM. Contributions may be mailed to the Joseph M. Suozzi Memorial Fund, 9 September La., Glen Cove, N.Y. 11542.

title: Attired in Black Pantsuit, She Takes on Uniform of Power : Hillary Gets Down to Business
description: WASHINGTON  When Hillary Rodham Clinton made her candidacy for the U.S. Senate official, she did so dressed in a sleek black trouser suit. For the occasion, her blonde hair was swept away from her face in a polished and sophisticated manner. As she stood before a crowd of cheering supporters, she looked very much like the strong, independent career woman that the media have, from the beginning, made her out to be.

title: Soaring in a Concert on Flight
description: Flight, exploration and the man who more than anyone else epitomized the two, Charles Lindbergh, were the themes of Sunday afternoon's concert by the American Composers Orchestra at Carnegie Hall, conducted by Dennis Russell Davies. One premiere and three seldom-heard works fit neatly into the themes, but only one stood out: ''Der Lindberghflug'' (''The Lindbergh Flight'') with text by Bertolt Brecht and music by Kurt Weill.

title: At Young Victim's School, Reassurance and Questions
description: Two days after a 6-year-old boy took a gun to first grade and killed a classmate, school officials in this working-class district just north of Flint tried to reassure parents that it was safe to send their children to school.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  WHEELER, GEORGE YANDES, II
description: WHEELER-George Yandes, II. Died peacefully on February 1, at his home in Hobe Sound, FL. A radio announcer, NBC war correspondent and executive with the RCA, he is survived by his loving wife of 35 years, Katherine Gatch Wheeler; four children George Y. Wheeler, III, Jedediah L. Wheeler, Jane C. Wheeler and Dr. Elizabeth E. Wheeler; three stepchildren Percy J. Orthwein, II, James B. Orthwein, Jr., and Katherine O. Snowden; a sister, Elizabeth K. Dunn; four grandchildren and eight step grandchildren. A true polymath, his civic contributions and love of words, skill at golf and unmistakable joie de vivre will be deeply missed. Services in Hobe Sound on March 4, and in Watch Hill, RI on July 15. Gifts in lieu of flowers to the Bradley Hospital Foundation, PO Box H, Providence, RI 02901.

title: I.M.F. Directors Fail to Rally Around Any New Leader in Poll
description: Directors of the International Monetary Fund failed today to rally around any of the people who want to lead the world financial institution, and expectations rose that Europe would search for a new candidate to keep its half-century lock on the job.

title: COMPANY BRIEFS
description: TIFFANY & CO., New York, a specialty retailer, said it planned to discontinue wholesale distribution of Tiffany brand jewelry, watches and accessories in Europe starting July 1.

description: Fashion Institute of Technology

title: In a shift, DoubleClick puts off its plan for wider use of the personal data of Internet consumers.
description: YIELDING to pressure from privacy advocates and Wall Street, DoubleClick Inc., the nation's largest online advertising company, said yesterday that it would put a hold on its plan to link personal information to anonymous data it collects about consumers on the Internet.

title: DOUBTS ABOUT ALUMINUM MERGER
description: Shares of Pechiney, the French aluminum company, fell more than 11 percent on investor fears about the future of a planned merger of Pechiney with Alcan Aluminium of Canada and the Alusuisse Lonza Group of Switzerland.The concern was fueled by news that the three companies' chief executives had met on Wednesday with the chief European antitrust regulator in an urgent effort to remove obstacles to the merger, which was announced in August. The companies' plan to merge, creating a $21 billion behemoth, appeared to herald a major shakeout in the global aluminum business. All the companies said they were still in discussions and would proceed with the merger. The European Commission has until March 22 to rule on it. John Tagliabue

But there being practically no middle ground of critical opinion when it comes to this film, the added features on the DVD version ($24.98) are interesting, at least to a point.

title: A Fund-Raiser's Guilty Verdict
description: A sorry chapter in the Democrats' 1996 fund-raising abuses led yesterday to the conviction of the only person in the scandals to face a trial so far. The verdict was a blow to Vice President Al Gore, even though no evidence has surfaced suggesting that he knew of the scheme at the center of this case. The vice president is affected indirectly, however, because Maria Hsia, a longtime Gore supporter, was found guilty of all five counts related to her involvement in an illegal scheme to raise money at the Hsi Lai Temple in Hacienda Heights, Calif., where Mr. Gore famously appeared. The vice president later denied that he knew of any fund-raising going on at the temple.

title: Military Rumblings Over Taiwan
description: The triangular relationship between China, Taiwan and the United States seems to veer from one crisis to the next. The latest one was provoked last week by Beijing's threat to take over Taiwan by force if island leaders do not soon agree to reunification on the mainland's terms. Now Taiwan and its supporters in the Pentagon and Congress want Washington to provide the island government with four American destroyers equipped with sophisticated Aegis radar and antimissile technology. There must be a more constructive way to manage the sensitive issue of Taiwan's future status.

title: SGI IS SELLING CRAY SUPERCOMPUTER BUSINESS TO TERA
description: SGI, formerly Silicon Graphics Inc., said yesterday that it had agreed to sell its Cray supercomputer business to the Tera Computer Company of Seattle. Terms were not disclosed, but analysts said there was little doubt that Tera paid a fraction of the $740 million that SGI had paid to acquire Cray Research Inc. in 1996. SGI shares closed at $9.875, down 25 cents. Tera shares fell $1.125, also to $9.875. In addition to the Cray name, Tera is gaining about 775 employees in Egan, Minn., and Chippewa Falls, Wis., and the rights to sell three lines of Cray supercomputers. Silicon Graphics is retaining certain assets that will remain part of its high-performance computer business.

title: Stern With the Generations He's Nourished

He has coached students in chamber music, brought critical attention to emerging talents by performing with them, given benefits to raise money for scholarships and, perhaps most important, spread the word about young musicians who needed support among the conductors, teachers and managers he knows (and he knows almost all of them).

title: Air of Mystery Clouds Shot at McCain
description: This advertisement lends a bit of mystery to the presidential campaign. The mystery is the advertisement's sponsor, Republicans for Clean Air, a group unknown to political professionals and the Federal Elections Commission. The Bush campaign says it knows nothing about the group. Advertising time was bought by the Multi Media Services Corporation, an advertising firm that worked on the campaign for a 1996 environmental referendum pushed by Gov. George E. Pataki, the chairman of Gov. George W. Bush's campaign in New York. The group lists an address that is a post office box in Virginia belonging to Lydia Meuret, a consultant who runs a political action committee headed by Representative Henry Bonilla of Texas, a Bush ally. Ms. Meuret said there was no connection between Republicans for Clean Air and Mr. Bonilla or his political action committee, other than that she was a consultant to both, and she refused to say any more about who paid for the advertisements. The advertisement praises Mr. Bush's environmental record, while criticizing Senator John McCain's; environmental groups like the Sierra Club say neither man has a good record, though Mr. McCain's might be marginally better.

title: BROADCOM IS BUYING STELLAR FOR $162 MILLION IN STOCK
description: The Broadcom Corporation, a chip maker, agreed yesterday to acquire the privately held Stellar Semiconductor Inc., a maker of graphics chips in San Jose, Calif., for $162 million in stock. Broadcom, based in Irvine, Calif., sees the deal as a step to offering three-dimensional video games, video conferencing and other video applications to hand-held devices. Broadcom said Stellar's technology required less capacity and memory to deliver video across electronic networks. Broadcom, which issued about 785,000 shares for the acquisition, had $518.2 million in revenue in 1999. Its stock was up 12.5 cents at $206.125. The stock has risen 66 percent since the beginning of the year.

title: CNL GROUP SCRAPS ITS PLAN TO CREATE A $1.5 BILLION REIT
description: CNL Group Inc. has called off a plan, announced last year, to merge 16 partnerships it manages and other assets into a $1.5 billion real estate investment trust. The trust would have been the largest single owner and financier of restaurant properties in the United States. CNL, based in Orlando, Fla., decided to drop the merger because, among other things, the share prices of REIT's have been in a two-year slump, the company said in a Securities and Exchange Commission filing. The combined company would have owned or had investments in more than 1,400 fast food and casual dining properties operated as Boston Market, Pizza Hut and Jack in the Box, among others.

But these plans come a bit late for Los Angeles: our area is finally built out.

description: IN that first scene in a Connecticut kitchen -- with its country table and canisters of beans, Trix cereal and tricolor pasta on the counter -- you can almost smell the decaf brewing, taste the lemon almond polenta cake Beth devours down to the last crumb and ache with her as she confesses to her closest friends, Karen and Gabe, that her husband, Tom, is leaving her for another woman.

title: FREED BY BRITAIN, PINOCHET IS FACING A BATTLE AT HOME
description: Britain abruptly dropped extradition proceedings today against Gen. Augusto Pinochet, who then headed home to Chile where his political opponents were waiting, intent on making him face months, if not years, of additional court proceedings.

title: A Luxury Condo Project on Fifth Avenue Is Attracting Buyers
description: Scaffolding covers a former 11-story office building at 838 Fifth Avenue and East 65th Street as it is transformed into one of Manhattan's newest and more expensive condominiums, complete with separate staff apartments and wine and storage units.

title: Get Surreal: Repackaging Dali for a New Generation
description: One known as the clown prince of Surrealism, Salvador Dali (1905-1989) saw his muse as ''Paranoia,'' and he painted her in 1935-36, a kitschy bust with a bosom deep in Hollywood decolletage. Her fugitive face is composed of a Leonardo-esque battle scene, with eyes formed by the rumps of warriors' horses and the nose and mouth a twisted figure. The setting is pure de Chirico (an artist from whom Dali freely appropriated), a stagy floor of boards reaching back in long perspective to the rocky seascape of Cadaques, Dali's home in northern Spain.

title: A.W. Stiles, a Veritable Santa, Dies at 89
description: Archibald W. Stiles, the little boy who had no toys but grew up to become Santa Claus -- and run an eccentric antiques business that let growing children exchange their old ice skates for somebody else's bigger ones -- died Tuesday at a New Jersey convalescent home. He was 89.

title: ALBUM OF THE WEEK
description: AMEL LARRIEUX: ''Infinite Possibilities'' (Epic/550 Music). Undulating vamps, the glassy tinkle of electric piano and playful phantom choruses surround Amel Larrieux on her debut album.

title: The Risk in Tightening Forfeiture Laws
description: To the Editor:

title: Casting Light, Bright and Dark, On a Nation's Historic Journey
description: Thank God Ping Chong has a sense of humor. In his new work, ''Pojagi,'' right in the middle of a serious commentary on 19th-century Korean social stratification, two of the cast of three burst into a few bars of ''You're the Top,'' then one (Esther Chae) chirps, ''I'll have my slave call your slave.''

title: Creative Executives Leave Two Agencies
description: Top creative executives at two agencies are moving on.

title: Louise Lawler
description: Metro Pictures

title: FOR CHILDREN
description: Theater

title: HEINEKEN LOOKS AT BASS BREWING
description: The Dutch brewer Heineken N.V. said it was considering making a bid for the Bass P.L.C. brewing business. ''Bass would be a perfect fit in our strategy to achieve a broad leadership in a large beer market,'' said Karel Vuursteen, chief executive of Heineken. Word of Heineken's possible bid came as it posted second-half profit of 306 million euros, or $295.4 million, up from 255.5 million euros a year earlier. Shares of Heineken fell 2 euros, to 50.5 euros. Andrew Ross Sorkin

title: False Threat Leads School To Lockdown
description: A high school here was locked down for two and a half hours today after a student claimed that another had threatened to take a gun to school. But the warning was a hoax, the police said, and the 16-year-old student who reported it was charged with false public alarm.

title: School Shootings: What's the Answer?
description: To the Editor:

title: Clinton Seeks to End an Impasse on Gun Control Legislation
description: Responding to two high-profile incidents of gun violence this week, President Clinton said today that he would invite legislative leaders to the White House next week to try to ''break the logjam'' on gun control legislation.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  MCCOY, DAISY V.
description: McCOY-Daisy V. On February 27, 2000. Beloved mother to Mary B., Charles H., Jr., and Charlesann McCoy. Also survived by one grandchild Noelani, brother William and sister Frederica, many nieces and nephews, son-in-law Joseph Zeller and loyal friend to many. She will be missed. Memorial services March 4 at 11 AM, Faith Mission Christian Fellowship Church, 160 West 129 St., NYC.

title: Let Rhode Island Keep Its 'Plantations'
description: To the Editor:

title: 'American Beauty,' British Honors
description: The director SAM MENDES was calling from London, where ''American Beauty'' had swept the British Film Critics Awards for best film, best actor (KEVIN SPACEY), best actress (ANNETTE BENING), best screenplay (ALAN BALL) and best director (Mr. Mendes).

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  BOGGS, JONATHAN DAVID
description: BOGGS-Jonathan David. Died on Sunday, February 27, at the Hunterdon Medical Center in Raritan Township, New Jersey. He was 54 years old. David, as he was called by his family and friends, was born in Pittsburgh, PA. He lived in New Jersey for over 50 years and resided at the Hunterdon Developmental Center in Clinton, NJ. His parents, the late Dr. Fitzhugh Boggs and Dr. Elizabeth Monroe Boggs, who resided in Hampton, New Jersey, were founders of the Association for Retarded Citizens (Arc) of Essex County, The Arc of NJ and the Arc of the United States, which his mother served as its first woman president. He is survived by his cousin, Pamela Monroe, of Medford, OR, and 15 additional first cousins; an aunt, Mary Soles, of Penn Yan, NY; an uncle, Norman Tower Boggs, of East Brunswick, NJ; and close friends. A memorial service will be held at 10 AM March 7 at the multi-purpose room of the Hunterdon Developmental Center. Contributions in David's memory may be made to the Hunterdon Medical Center, 2100 Wescott Dr., Flemington, NJ 08822 or the Arc of the United States' Dr. Elizabeth Boggs Fund for the Public Policy, 1010 Wayne Avenue, Suite 650, Silver Springs, MD 20910. For more information, contact the Garefino Funeral Home, 12 N. Franklin St., Lambertville, New Jersey.

title: When Life Is Not a Dream But an Unending Nightmare
description: In ''Sueno'' (''Dream''), Jose Rivera stands on its head a Spanish theatrical masterpiece about the traps sprung on a person plodding through the complexities of life as if in a dream. In Mr. Rivera's play -- produced by the MCC Theater under Lisa Peterson's direction -- the audience is caught in the dream, in which a parade of bondage, rape, torture, mutilation, murder, treason and civil war, accompanied by the music and rhythms of flamenco, arouses the uneasy laughter of confusion.

title: Report Links Heart Attacks To Marijuana
description: In what is believed to be the first documented link between smoking marijuana and heart attacks, a study has found that a middle-age person's risk of heart attack rises nearly fivefold in the first hour after smoking marijuana.

title: DINER'S JOURNAL
description: Midtown Manhattan, laid out on the grid plan, does not abound in secret, tucked-away corners, but Sir Terence Conran, the English designer, has managed to find one for his new restaurant, Guastavino's. It's hidden in plain sight, in tiled vaults designed by Rafael Guastavino under the Queensboro Bridge (related article, page 47 of Weekend).

title: U.S. Sends Rescue Team to Help Flood-Ravaged Mozambique
description: The United States began sending search-and-rescue teams to Mozambique today and sent additional emergency supplies in response to weeks of severe flooding in southern Africa.

title: KOREAN CAR SALES RISE
description: South Korea's three major carmakers reported that sales increased sharply in February. Hyundai Motor, the nation's largest carmaker, said domestic sales rose 39 percent from a year earlier, to 51,609, and exports rose 61 percent, to 60,081. Helped by strong sales of recreational vehicles, Daewoo Motor sold 24,268 vehicles on the domestic market, up 26 percent, and exports more than doubled, to 52,513. Kia Motors, a Hyundai unit, said its local car sales surged 95 percent, to 31,116, while exports rose 35 percent, to 40,660. Samuel Len

title: A World of Objects United by the Passion of 2 Collectors
description: Can art collecting itself be an art? If you doubt it, see ''The Guennol Collection: Cabinet of Wonders'' at the Brooklyn Museum of Art.

title: A Governor Would Give Every Student A Laptop
description: Gov. Angus King of Maine announced a plan today to give every seventh grader in the state a laptop computer, to use at school or at home.

title: Report Sees Major Hurdles for Internet Election
description: March 3, 2000

title: Other Bids for Aetna Unlikely, Analysts Say
description: Investors bought up shares of Aetna Inc. again yesterday, but the buying spree slowed as it became apparent that rival bidders were unlikely to emerge to challenge the $9.9 billion offer announced this week by Aetna.

title: Just a Gigolo? Louis Prima As an Irreverent Bit More
description: Early in ''Louis Prima: The Wildest,'' Don McGlynn's buoyant documentary portrait of Las Vegas's reigning 1950's musical clown, there's a television clip of Prima and his wife at the time, Keely Smith, goofing their way through ''That Old Black Magic.'' After delivering the song in rapid-fire call-and-response bursts, the pair suddenly skid into farce, bumping foreheads as Ms. Smith adopts a sour Southern twang and crosses her eyes, while Prima bends the lyric into a fat joke. ''You're the blubber I have waited for/You're the weight that fate had me created for.''

title: Passions of Emptiness
description: In ''Ghost Dog: The Way of the Samurai,'' Jim Jarmusch tries to do to the samurai epic and the gangster movie what he did to the western in ''Dead Man'' (1997), his dreamy, elegiac deconstruction of cowboys-and-Indians mythology. Like a postmodern magpie, Mr. Jarmusch likes to scavenge shiny bits of pop-culture flotsam -- mobsters in their sharkskin suits, gaudy cartoon animals, sleek imported luxury cars, iridescent CD's -- and weave them into quirky, ramshackle habitations.

title: Metro Business; Generating Power at Sea
description: Enron Corporation, the world's largest marketer of power and natural gas, said it planned to generate electricity on barges off the coasts of New York, Connecticut and Massachusetts during periods of high demand this summer.

title: UNILEVER ENTERS HONDURAS
description: The British-Dutch consumer products giant Unilever, whose brands include Dove soap and Lipton tea, agreed to acquire the Honduran consumer products company Grupo Cressida for $314 million. The deal will double the size of Unilever's business in Latin America. Unilever had $4.6 billion in sales in the region in 1999. The privately held Cressida makes detergents, soap, food and beverages.

title: Who Needs Diplomacy In This Town?
description: THREE years ago, apparently feeling that he could always use a few more enemies, Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani went on a crusade against the United Nations and its many diplomats who sniffed at New York's parking laws with the disdain they might give an indifferent Burgundy. You may remember how the mutual nyah-nyah's flew.

title: THE MARKETS: COMMODITIES
description: PALLADIUM FALLS. Palladium prices dropped after Russia approved export quotas and signaled an end to a prolonged delay in shipments. In New York, palladium for June delivery fell $24, or 3.5 percent, to $658.90 an ounce.

title: A Major West Bank Campus Suspends Classes in a Protest
description: Students and teachers at Bir Zeit University, the leading Palestinian academic institution in the West Bank, have suspended classes indefinitely to protest arrests of students by the Palestinian security forces.

title: Ponchos Reborn in Los Angeles
description: LOS ANGELES  Those 60-degree winter days in Los Angeles may not warrant pulling out a mink, but they certainly call for something to cut the chill emanating from the Pacific.

title: Fiscal Overseer Sought
description: As Nassau County's fiscal crisis continued, Democratic lawmakers began a new push yesterday for a state board to oversee its budgets and finances.

title: LEAR ANNOUNCES STOCK BUYBACK AND A TAKEOVER DEFENSE
description: The Lear Corporation, the largest maker of automotive interiors, adopted a takeover defense yesterday and said it planned to buy back as many as 6.7 million common shares, about 10 percent of its stock outstanding. The company's board approved a preferred-share purchase- rights distribution to ''assure that all of our stockholders receive fair and equal treatment in the event of any proposed takeover.'' The rights let stockholders buy preferred stock at a discount after a tender offer. Lear shares have tumbled 36 percent in the last 12 months. They rose 31.25 cents yesterday, to $22.3125, after touching a four-and-a-half-year low of $22.

title: Plans for Mexican Salt Plant Are Canceled
description: Yielding to pressure from environmental groups, the government and Mitsubishi of Japan canceled plans today to build a giant salt factory at a pristine Pacific Coast lagoon.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  GALLAGHER, HELEN (NEE AUTH)
description: GALLAGHER-Helen (nee Auth). Age 85 of Mendham, NJ on Thursday, March 2, 2000. Wife of the late Joseph T. Mother of Terence J., New Vernon, NJ, Helen G. Chapin, Santa Fe, NM and Joseph A. Skillman, NJ. Also survived by nine grandchildren and four great grandchildren. Mass of the Resurrection will be offered on Monday, March 6 at 11AM at St. Joseph Church, Mendham. Interment Gate of Heaven Cemetery, East Hanover. Memorial gifts may be made to the Somerset Hills Hospice, 12 Olcott Ave., Bernardsville, New Jersey 07924.

description: Sotheby's Holdings could do little to dispel investors' concerns over the outcome of a federal antitrust investigation yesterday as it discussed its Internet prospects and fourth-quarter results.

title: Summer's Colorful Helpers
description: PARIS  This season you can't see the clothes for the accessories  from extravagant gypsy head scarves to colorful sling-back beaded mules  and everything seems to be covered in beads and jewels.

title: Perfecting Eugenics Is as Hard as Perfecting People
description: There's something intrinsically creepy about the scientific quest to create a new and improved human being, and ''Homo Sapiens 1900,'' Peter Cohen's unsettling documentary history of eugenics, mercilessly zeroes in on exactly what that is. In turning people into laboratory specimens and using genetic theory to try to breed superior strains of people, scientists play God by making value judgments about the most desirable human qualities, usually deemed to be measurable intelligence and physical endowment.

title: Footsteps That Interpret Ellington
description: Inventive. Surprising. Those words easily describe the music of Duke Ellington. They can also describe the dances of Donald Byrd, who paid an imaginative choreographic tribute to the composer with ''In a Different Light: Duke Ellington,'' the new three-act production that Donald Byrd/The Group took to the Joyce Theater on Tuesday night.

title: Voyagers, Far From Home, Lose Their Moral Compass
description: What becomes of the old ways in the New World?

Service Friday, 11:15 AM, at ''The Riverside,'' 76th Street and Amsterdam Avenue.

title: Puzzling Over the Intentions On a Bumpy Road to Heaven
description: It would be unfair to challenge viewers leaving ''Mr. Baldwin Goes to Heaven'' to say what the play is about. But it is a safe bet there would be almost as many answers as members of the audience.

title: Review/Fashion; For the Coquette With Aspirations
description: Early in ''The Arcades Project,'' Walter Benjamin's recently published 1,073-page study of mid-19th-century Parisian habits, there is the following observation: ''Making money becomes the object of an almost sensual fervor, and love becomes a financial concern. In the age of French Romanticism, the erotic ideal was the working girl who gives herself; now it is the tart who sells herself.''

title: WORLD BUSINESS BRIEFING: AMERICAS; MEXICAN WEB VENTURE
description: Mexico's fourth-largest bank, Grupo Financiero Banorte, has agreed to a strategic alliance with the Hewlett-Packard Company to provide business-to-business electronic marketplaces and logistics and financial services. The idea is to create an online business community for Latin American companies and their partners. The venture will first link corporate suppliers and customers in Mexico, Banorte said. If it is successful, it will be expanded to cover Latin America. Dan Fineren

title: BUSINESS DIGEST
description: Shares of Palm Pilot Maker Soar on First Day of Trading

title: Senate Backs Education Savings Measure
description: The Senate today easily passed a bill that would provide modest tax breaks for parents who save for elementary and secondary school expenses, including private school tuition, but it faced a likely veto.

title: Sensuous Curves Ascend Above the Hard-Edged City
description: In a Guastavino tile ceiling, the sum of a thousand right angles is a curve worthy of nature.

title: Union Sq. Bubbles Over as Water Main Bursts
description: A cast-iron water main installed five years after the end of the Civil War ruptured beneath 14th Street just before dawn yesterday, shutting down three subway lines during the morning rush, causing delays and misery on many other lines and tying up traffic for dozens of blocks around Union Square.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SIMON, IRENE
description: SIMON-Irene. Of Manhattan on February 18, 2000, actress, tap dancer, USO and humanitarian will be sorely missed by daughters Cheri and Lisa, granddaughters Rachel and Sarah, family and friends. Services Sunday 10:30AM (March 5) at Gilda's Club, 195 West Houston Street, NYC.

title: Stuffy Bostonians Smarten Up
description: BOSTON  Money can buy you smiles, status and sometimes even love, but the question here these days is "Can money buy you style?" Boston is awash in wealth, so much disposable income that it seems like Monopoly money, and it is changing the city's look and attitude toward fashion.

Proud and cherished grandfather of Elizabeth, Randy, Sarah, Leslie and Merril; greatgrandfather of Jill, Kate and Victoria. Private family services. His rich and generous life touched all his family and friends and he will be deeply missed by all. We love you very much, Merril

title: Remarks Rally Christian Right Against McCain
description: It is hard to know how many Bob Harrisons are out there. But each one is a nightmare for Senator John McCain.

title: Recalling A Sondheim Precursor
description: John Latouche's name comes up now and then. Whenever there's a revival of ''Candide,'' for which he wrote some of the original lyrics. Or when a cabaret performer rediscovers one of his gems, like ''Take Love Easy.'' But over all, for a man who wrote the lyrics, book or both for more than 20 musicals from the 1930's to the 50's, Latouche is extremely unknown.

title: Revealing Malpractice
description: To the Editor:

title: Essence of Time and Tone In Big-Band Arrangements
description: Every time Tom Harrell took a fluegelhorn solo during his harmonically dense big-band compositions on Tuesday night at Iridium, his language was disarmingly potent. Mr. Harrell's playing is a model of willed precision: it's like someone talking extemporaneously without using the connectives ''uh,'' ''so,'' ''you know'' or anything else to forestall the goal of complete meaning at the end of the discourse.

title: THE 2000 CAMPAIGN: THE OTHER McCAIN; Unexpectedly, Cindy McCain Basks in a New Political Role
description: At every campaign stop, John McCain introduces his wife, Cindy, as ''the one who everyone says, 'Why isn't she the candidate?' '' But until a few months ago, no one, including either of the McCains, saw her as someone who could take on even a supporting role in a national campaign.

title: Oh, Your Daddy's Gay, And Your Mama's a Yogi
description: Something happens to Madonna when she stops singing, dancing and posing and is forced to play a screen character who speaks in plain, everyday English. The extraordinary drive that made her a world-famous entertainer becomes stifled, and the personality that wafts off the screen is a curt, cool cookie who, even in misty-eyed moments, conveys traces of a sour self-absorption.

title: James J. O'Leary, 85, an Economist
description: James J. O'Leary, an economist and a former vice chairman of the U.S. Trust Corporation, died Monday at his home in Westport, Conn. He was 85.

title: European Central Bank Holds Interest Rates Steady for Now
description: Despite worries about inflation and the euro's slump to a record low this week, the European Central Bank decided today not to raise interest rates, while warning that it would probably do so soon.

title: ENHANCE FINANCIAL TO CONSIDER SALE AND OTHER MOVES
description: Enhance Financial Services Group Inc. said yesterday that it had hired the investment banker Morgan Stanley Dean Witter & Company for advice on improving shareholder value, including a possible sale of the company. Enhance, a New York-based insurer, will consider ''all reasonable alternatives,'' Daniel J. Gross, Enhance's president, said in a statement. Either all or part of the company could be sold, a spokesman, Bernard Kilkelly, said. The shares of Enhance rose 56.25 each, to $11.9375. At that price, the company is valued at more than $450 million.

Campbell, 1076 Madison Avenue at 81st St., Saturday, March 4th, 2-5 and 79PM, and Sunday 2-5PM. Funeral private. Memorial service to be announced at a later date.

title: Saul Steinberg: A Model for Today's Internet Barons
description: HOT stocks traded for hundreds of times their earnings, if they had any. Companies with concepts that caught the eye of eager investors could acquire companies many times their size. Public enthusiasm for stocks was higher than at any time since the 1920's.

title: Police Contrast Killing in Bronx With Diallo Case
description: The Bronx neighborhood where Amadou Diallo died mourned yesterday for yet another unarmed man killed in a confrontation with the police, but Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani cast the case as starkly different, saying the victim had a history of drug crimes, was carrying heroin and had fled from and struggled with an officer.

title: Sports of The Times; Baseball Drug Policy Not Specific Enough
description: EVEN before Darryl Strawberry checked into a rehabilitation clinic in Florida to ''take control of my drug addiction once and for all,'' he provoked two reactions. Sympathy for the slugger, scorn for the system.

title: McCain's Mutineers; Upstarts in Unpretentious Places Toil to Rattle G.O.P. Leadership
description: Travelers driving through the wintry brown hills of western New York might miss this place, technically considered a town. Its center comprises little more than a railroad crossing, a Roman Catholic church and the Sad Dog Saloon.

title: ECLIPSYS MAKES HOSTILE BID FOR SHARED MEDICAL
description: The Eclipsys Corporation, a maker of software for the health care industry, said yesterday that it had made a $2 billion hostile bid for a rival, the Shared Medical Systems Corporation, whose shares have fallen 28 percent in the last year. Eclipsys offered $67 a share in stock or a combination of stock and cash. Shared Medical closed yesterday at $38.25, down $1.1875. Shared Medical, like many other makers of health care software, has struggled as customers delayed purchases because of concerns about Year 2000 computer problems. It warned last month that revenue would be weak in the first half of the year and strengthen in the second half. Shares of Eclipsys, based in Delray Beach, Fla., rose $3.0625, or 12 percent, to $28.625.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  FUCHS, RHODA
description: FUCHS - Rhoda. Congregation Kneseth Israel, Far Rockaway, N.Y. mourns with heartfelt sorrow the passing of our esteemed member and extends condolences to the entire family. Tzvi Flaum, Rabbi Ralph Pelcovitz, Rabbi Emeritus Noah Fleschner, President

title: INVESTOR VICTORY IN RUSSIA
description: A St. Petersburg appeals court reinstated the privatization of the Lomonosov Porcelain Factory, returning equity stakes to the Congressionally financed United States-Russia Investment Fund and other foreign shareholders that had been stripped from them by an earlier nationalization of the plant. In October, the Russian government sued to annul the privatization of the 255-year-old plant, voiding the majority stake held by the $440 million fund and a group of shareholders consisting of executives of the Wall Street buyout firm Kohlberg Kravis Roberts & Company. It now appears that the government will not challenge the latest ruling. Neela Banerjee

title: No Rush: 64 Years Later, Morgan Has a New Car
description: THE venerable Morgan Motor Company did something here this week it hadn't done in a long time: It introduced an all-new car, its first since the year that Edward VIII abdicated the British throne to marry Wallis Simpson, the divorced woman he loved.

title: Key Officer at Gap Resigns To Be Chief of Wal-Mart.com
description: Jeanne Jackson, the Gap executive who is credited with building the Banana Republic division into a retail powerhouse and who started the Gap's online store, has resigned to become the new head of Wal-Mart.com.

title: Positive Overtures on Gun Control
description: Some encouraging things are being said about the need for stronger gun control laws in the wake of this week's fatal shooting in Michigan of a first-grader by a 6-year-old classmate and the rampage at two fast-food restaurants in Pittsburgh. Republican Congressional leaders, who bear responsibility for the legislative logjam on gun control, need to listen hard. So for that matter do the Republican presidential contenders, Gov. George W. Bush and Senator John McCain, who have budged little from their reflexive anti-gun-control records.

title: Negotiations Begin on a Health Care Bill
description: Negotiators from the House and the Senate, meeting for the first time, said today that they were optimistic about their chances of cutting a deal on legislation that would establish a wide range of new rights for patients and new duties for health insurance companies.

title: The Cars Seldom Change; Neither Do the Bosses
description: ASIDE from the longevity of its automobiles' design, the Morgan Motor Company has another distinction: No other carmaker is still wholly owned by the family that started it. Even today, 91 years after the British company was founded to manufacture three-wheeled cars, management is in the hands of only the third generation of Morgans.

title: Kariel Gardosh, 79, Who Created Israeli Icon
description: Kariel Gardosh, an Israeli political cartoonist who captured the national psyche in depictions of his country as an innocent boy in a tough neighborhood, died on Monday in Tel Aviv. He was 79.

description: It was a collision as jarring as cymbals crashing together when Dikembe Mutombo and Patrick Ewing went sprawling onto the glossy floor of Philips Arena tonight.

title: GILLETTE IN DEAL TO SELL WHITE RAIN SHAMPOO BUSINESS
description: The Gillette Company, the world's biggest maker of razors and blades, said yesterday that it had reached an agreement to sell its White Rain shampoo business to an undisclosed buyer. The company, which makes Mach 3 razors, Duracell batteries and Oral-B toothbrushes, said the sale would include a factory in St. Paul that employs about 270 people. The White Rain unit has about $100 million in annual sales, including hair products under the Adorn, Tame, Toni, Mink Difference and Dippity-Do brands. The buyer and other details will be disclosed after a final agreement is reached this month, Gillette said.

title: Networks Enthusiastically Share Ratings Star: Tiger Woods
description: When Tiger Woods plays golf, television executives swoon. With his rare power to move ratings, he is the sports version of ''E.R.'' or ''Who Wants to Be a Millionaire,'' a singular programming entity capable of clubbing rival networks in their Nielsens in his pursuit of tournament victories.

title: Essie G. Edmiston, 61, Dealer Who Represented Black Artists
description: Essie Green Edmiston, an art dealer who represented many 20th-century African-American artists through her Harlem gallery, died on Feb. 26. She was 61 and lived in Manhattan.

title: Changing Events Give G.O.P. Opportunity to Retain House
description: After a series of twists in their favor, Republicans have improved their chances of keeping control of the House in this year's elections, according to party leaders, analysts and strategists from both parties.

title: Baron Enrico di Portanova, 66, Flamboyant Member of Jet Set
description: Baron Enrico di Portanova, one of the most flamboyant members of the international jet set, who once listed the best things in life as ''sun, sex and spaghetti,'' died on Monday at his home in Houston. He also had homes in Rome and Acapulco, Mexico. The baron's Italian passport gave his age as 66, although longtime friends believed that he was perhaps older.

title: Palms IPO Tempts Investors With Arbitrage Ideas
description: March 3, 2000

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  POON, PETER
description: POON-Peter. On March 3, 2000. Devoted father of Jin Fan Pan and father-in-law of Judi Pan. Adored grandfather of Paul, Tony and Emma Pan. Reposing at Krtil Funeral Home; Yorkville Funeral Service, Inc., 1297 First Avenue, New York City, Saturday 2-4 and 79 PM only. Buddhist services on Monday, 10 AM, at funeral home. Entombment is in Cypress Hills Cemetery. His family and friends are deeply saddened by the loss of this kind and noble man.

title: G.O.P. Race Challenges Loyalties, and Families
description: The Odyssey Diner here is one of those old-fashioned political hangouts, where establishment pols, mostly Republicans, gather at the counter or in a side room to hash things out over the famous cheesecake and coffee courtesy of the affable Doukases, who have run the place for 27 years.

title: Corrections
description: An obituary of the artist Louisa Matthiasdottir on Thursday misstated the given name of a postwar artist with whom she shared the belief that abstraction and representationalism were not mutually exclusive approaches to painting. The artist was Virginia Admiral, not Catherine.

title: Agency Rejects High Duties on Imported Steel
description: In a stinging and unusual disappointment for United States steel producers and workers, a federal trade agency refused today to levy punitive import duties on a variety of steel products from Japan and five other countries.

title: Corrections
description: An article and a picture caption on Thursday about the shooting of 6-year-old Kayla Renee Rolland in Mount Morris Township, Mich., misstated the site of her wound. The bullet entered through her shoulder, not the neck or the chest.

title: Mrs. Clinton Speaks Out Against Police Misconduct
description: In remarks leading up to what her aides say will be a major policy statement on police conduct and the Diallo case tomorrow, Hillary Rodham Clinton said yesterday that New York City ''obviously has a problem when an innocent, unarmed man is gunned down.''

title: New Jersey Tackles Fire Safety Flaws
description: Since the fatal dormitory fire at Seton Hall University in January, state officials have tallied up long lists of fire-safety violations on New Jersey campuses. Now they are starting to address the weaknesses in their own role that have allowed those hazards to persist.

title: SHARED MEDICAL SYSTEMS STOCK RISES AS IT REJECTS BID
description: The shares of the Shared Medical Systems Corporation surged 60 percent yesterday after the company, the No. 2 United States maker of health care software, rejected a $2 billion hostile offer from the Eclipsys Corporation. Shared Medical rose $25.25 a share, to $63.50. Late on Thursday, Eclipsys, whose chairman and chief executive, Harvey Wilson, co-founded Shared Medical in 1969, offered $67 a share in stock, or stock and cash for the company. Shared Medical said it had received the Eclipsys offer but was not interested. Shared Medical has been struggling because of customers' slowing purchases. Still, in its rejection note, Shared Medical said it had $1.2 billion in revenue last year, while Eclipsys had $249 million.

title: QUOTATION OF THE DAY
description: ''If he's two strokes behind the leader, producers and directors will show his shot going to commercial to plant the seed of coming back to see more of him.''

title: Judge Temporarily Bars County Inmate From Having Abortion
description: A State Supreme Court justice in Watertown, N.Y., issued a temporary order this week barring a jail inmate from having an abortion until a court hearing on whether county corrections officials should pay for the procedure.

title: With Stock Lagging Badly Borders Hires an Adviser
description: Borders Group, one of the nation's leading booksellers, said yesterday that it had hired Merrill Lynch & Company to explore steps it might take to bolster its faltering stock price.

title: 5 Family Members Are Discovered Slain Within Blocks in the Bronx
description: A 6-year-old girl and her 13-year-old brother stumbled upon a trail of murder Thursday night stretching across their tidy Bronx neighborhood when an elevator door opened to reveal the body of a woman, the first of five related victims discovered in a 10-hour period.

title: To the Last Sigh: A Dark Portrait of Shostakovich and His Era; A New Way to Listen, a New Way to Play
description: ''I had one idea,'' Simon McBurney, the director of ''The Noise of Time,'' said yesterday. And that idea was to listen to the 15th Quartet of Shostakovich ''in another way.'' He added quickly: ''I'm not suggesting that there was one way. The way the mind decodes music is an individual mystery. But the physical circumstances can change the way you listen.''

title: February Jobless Rate at 4.1%
description: The unemployment rate climbed slightly in February, to 4.1 percent from 4 percent, as only 43,000 jobs were created, suggesting the economy may be slowing. Page C1.

description: To the Editor:

title: Second Murder Trial Opens In Subway Shoving Case
description: The second murder trial of a schizophrenic man who threw a woman to her death in front of a subway train began yesterday, as his lawyer promised to try to show jurors the depths of his illness when he is not taking medication.

title: Suitor for Iridium Backs Out, Moving Company to the Brink
description: The cellular telephone pioneer Craig O. McCaw said today that he was dropping plans to acquire Iridium, the troubled global satellite telephone company that filed for Chapter 11 bankruptcy protection last August.

title: WACHOVIA BUYING COMMERCE NATIONAL FOR $40 MILLION
description: The Wachovia Corporation agreed yesterday to acquire the Commerce National Corporation, a Florida bank company, for $54 a share, a total of $40 million. Commerce National's stock rose $5.75 a share yesterday, to $27. Commerce National owns National Bank of Commerce, a bank with three branches in Winter Park, Fla., which is north of Orlando. Wachovia, based in Winston-Salem, N.C., owns Wachovia Bank, one of the biggest banks in the Southeast, with more than 700 branches in Florida, Georgia, South Carolina, North Carolina and Virginia. Commerce National had $181 million in assets as of Dec. 31. Wachovia had $67.4 billion in assets, making it the 16th-largest bank in the United States.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  EIGEN, ROSE
description: EIGEN-Rose. Beloved wife the late Simon J., loving mother of Ellen and Steven Edelson, and Carol and Steven Tannenbaum. Cherished grandmother of Lynda and Jeffry Edelson, Lisa and John Hanselman, and Keiko and Mark Tannenbaum and great-grandmother of three. Dear sister. Services ''Boulevard-Riverside'', 1450 Broadway, Hewlett, Long Island, at 12:30 P.M., Sunday.

title: To Improve the Health of Infants
description: To the Editor:

title: Bradley Turns to Foreign Policy in a Detour From Traditional Campaigning
description: With only four days before primaries that could seal his fate as a presidential candidate, former Senator Bill Bradley today defied conventional political wisdom and spoke about an issue of little concern to voters this year: foreign policy.

title: Learning to Live Without the Welfare Check
description: The framers of the welfare overhaul of 1996 believed that families would be better off if parents had jobs rather than depending on government checks. But there is no consensus about how well it has worked.

title: Visiting Beirut, Arab Leaders Bolster Front Against Israelis
description: The crown prince of Saudi Arabia today ended a two-day visit to Lebanon, which Arab diplomats said was aimed at strengthening a common Arab front after Israel's recent bombing of three Lebanese power plants, the breakdown of Israeli-Syrian peace talks, and the similar impasse in negotiations between Israel and the Palestinians.

title: NETDIRECT, INTERNET RETAILER, ENDS TAKEOVER ACCORD
description: The Netdirect Corporation International, an Internet retailer of electronics, said yesterday that its board had decided to terminate an agreement to be acquired by Compositech Ltd. because of a change in strategy. Netdirect, based in Minneapolis, said it planned an acquisition of HardwareStreet.com for about $32 million as part of a new focus on strategic partnerships as a way to lower costs and improve profit and revenue. Compositech and Netdirect agreed in December to a stock swap with a value put at $175 million at the time.

title: Dominic Bruce, 84, Briton Who Tried to Escape Nazis 17 Times
description: Dominic Bruce, a British bomber pilot who made no fewer than 17 attempts in four years to escape from his German captors at the famous Colditz prison, died on Feb. 12 in England. He was 84.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  O'BRIEN, MICHAEL B.
description: O'BRIEN-Michael B., of New York City and Westhampton Beach, on March 1, 2000. Beloved husband of Madeline. Devoted father of Joanne Ciccotto, Eileen O'Brien, Patricia Scanlon and Elizabeth O'Brien. Dear brother of Ellen Joyce and Catherine O'Brien. Interment was Friday at the Calverton National Cemetery, Calverton, NY. A memorial mass will be celebrated at 1 PM Saturday, March 4, at St. Francis Xavier Church on West 16th Street in New York City.

title: Corrections

title: The Rangers Climb a Notch In the Race for a Playoff Spot
description: The Rangers' power play was startlingly inept earlier this season, but now it could end up being one of the factors that helps the team grab a playoff spot for the first time in three years.

title: Cities Reduce Crime and Conflict Without New York-Style Hardball
description: With the city's stunning drop in crime in the 1990's, many New Yorkers have come to assume that aggressive police tactics and crime reductions are inextricably linked.

title: Corrections
description: An article on Feb. 25 about allegations of brutal hazing on a high school wrestling team in Trumbull, Conn., misstated the town's distance from Bridgeport, the nearest big city. Trumbull borders Bridgeport; the centers of the two places are five miles apart.

title: Enough With The Piety
description: During an earlier presidential campaign, a senior aide to a major candidate called and asked for a campaign stop at an African-American church active in our organization. The candidate wished to focus on urban poverty, and the aide asked if the host church could guarantee the presence of 300 listeners, ''mostly women, not well dressed.''

title: California's Poisonous Proposition
description: The text of Proposition 22, which appears on the ballot of California's primary on Tuesday, contains only 14 words. But it is one of the more mean-spirited measures to come along in any election in quite a while.

title: Bach as a Fount for Taylor's Choreographic Games
description: ''Cascade,'' which the Paul Taylor Dance Company presented as the second New York premiere of the troupe's season at City Center, is one of Mr. Taylor's most elegant pure-dance works.

description: To the Editor:

title: In a Slam, an Ace Not Taken Can Make All the Difference
description: The oldest series of matches in the world is probably the one between Oxford University and Cambridge University in England. It began in 1935 and has been played annually ever since, with a break during World War II. This writer played in several of them half a century ago.

title: THE MARKETS: CURRENCIES
description: EURO FALLS. The euro declined against the dollar as weak economic data allayed concern that sharply higher U.S. interest rates were inevitable. In New York, the euro settled at 96.09 cents, down from 96.63 on Thursday.

title: Balloonist Ends Flight In Myanmar
description: An American balloonist's solo bid to circle the world ended well short of that goal yesterday when he landed safely in Southeast Asia.

description: John Starks's desire to void his contract with the Bulls so he could become eligible to play in the postseason was dealt a severe blow last night by an independent arbitrator.
