Jaros. Her children are Elizabeth Levine Jaros Biers (Martin H. Biers, M.D.) and Edwin J. Jaros (Sheila Greene); grandchildren, Eric L. (Carolyn R.), Carl D. Biers (Nina Browne) and John M. Biers. Cynthia Gordon is her sister as was the late Mildred (Mimi) Falk. Elsie Jaros held a Masters Degree in Sociology from Columbia University Teachers College. She was a brave and loving person and a friend to many. Service Sunday, 1PM at ''The Riverside'', 76 Street and Amsterdam Avenue.

title: For McCain, Concerns In the Senate Are Subtle
description: At one level, John McCain has been a model of conservative Republican orthodoxy in his 13 years in the Senate, with a voting record close to that of Jesse Helms, who sets the standard for Senate conservatives.

title: While Cows Give Birth and Tools Break, Life Goes On
description: To go these days to the handsome little Irish Repertory Theater on West 22nd Street to see ''The Country Boy'' is to be happily reminded of a time when theatergoing was not a major quest for ''the experience of a lifetime'' but an excursion into entertainment on a par in price, professionalism and pleasure with a night at the neighborhood movie house.

title: A Hefty Farewell Package For Former Coke Executive
description: Coca-Cola's former chairman and chief executive left the company last month after two turbulent years in which Coke's growth stagnated, its earnings fell and its image became stained by problems like the biggest product recall in company history and a racial discrimination lawsuit. So dismal was the company's performance in 1999 that no one in Coke's top management got a bonus.

title: Ticket Prices Raised
description: The Jets, who went four years without a price increase during their lean years before the Bill Parcells era, announced their third straight increase yesterday.

title: CALIFORNIA REFINERY IS TO BE SOLD FOR $895 MILLION
description: The Exxon Mobil Corporation, the world's largest publicly traded oil company, said late on Thursday that it had agreed to sell its refinery in Benicia, Calif., and about 340 gasoline stations in the state to the Valero Energy Corporation for $895 million. The stations are among the 2,431 that the Exxon Corporation agreed to sell to win United States antitrust clearance for its $85.2 billion purchase of the Mobil Corporation last year. Exxon Mobil agreed to sell 1,740 East Coast stations to the Tosco Corporation in December and must still sell or sever supply contracts with outlets in Texas.

title: MUSIC REVIEW: To the Last Sigh: A Dark Portrait of Shostakovich and His Era; A Haunting Epilogue to a Life
description: In a sense, every committed performance of a Shostakovich string quartet is already a dramatic presentation. This Russian master's 15 quartets are haunting and confounding works, at once craftily composed scores and deeply personal chapters of a musical memoir. So the idea of creating a multimedia theatrical work to depict the life and times of Dmitri Shostakovich that had as its core a performance of his searing final string quartet from 1974 would seem to be fraught with potential pitfalls.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  ADLER, BEATRICE ROSS
description: ADLER-Beatrice Ross. On March 2, 2000. Age 88. Wife of the late Benjamin Adler. Mother of Betsy Picket, Susan Bers, Pamela and Jane. Grandmother of Stacey and Craig Picket, Alice and Diane Bers, and Benjamin Andre. Private family services. Contributions in her memory may be made to the Benjamin Adler Scholarship Fund, Polytechnic University, 6 MetroTech Center, Brooklyn NY 11201.

title: Making Breast Cancer a Political Issue Against McCain
description: Seeking to damage Senator John McCain's support among women, Gov. George W. Bush's campaign portrays Mr. McCain as hostile to breast cancer programs in this radio advertisement being run in New York. Prominent Republicans in New York, including Gov. George E. Pataki, have often tried to offset the party's traditional disadvantage with women by highlighting their advocacy of breast cancer programs. Mr. Pataki, who is spearheading the Bush campaign in the state, is now turning to an ally active in breast cancer groups and Republican politics, Geri Barish of Nassau County, to help Mr. Bush.

title: THE MARKETS: COMMODITIES
description: COCOA RISES. Cocoa prices climbed 2.9 percent, continuing to rebound from a 27-year low set a week ago, as the harvest season in Ivory Coast wound down. In New York, cocoa for delivery in May rose $24, to $845 a metric ton.

title: MOULINEX CUTBACKS
description: A big European appliance maker, Moulinex of France, will shed 9 of its 13 European factories and eliminate 2,100 jobs over two years to cut costs and reduce debt. The company, best known for its Moulinex and Krupps appliances, has been struggling with increased losses, and earlier this year it announced an ambitious plan to raise as much as $133 million in fresh capital and reduce costs by subcontracting outside Europe the production of vacuum cleaners, microwave ovens and components like electric motors. John Tagliabue

title: Pinochet Receives Hero's Welcome on Return to Chile
description: Gen. Augusto Pinochet received a muted hero's welcome from the military high command as he returned home today from his long exile and house arrest in London to salutes, brassy martial music and a low-flying air force helicopter entourage.

description: Job growth suddenly weakened in February, the Labor Department reported yesterday, but almost nothing in the unexpectedly sharp decline suggested a softening of the economy itself.

description: In what clean-air advocates called a watershed ruling, a federal appeals court yesterday upheld rules limiting pollution from Midwestern states that causes unacceptable levels of smog in the Northeast.

description: Considering that he had started playing organized basketball only two years earlier in his native Brooklyn, Darren Phillip found himself in a somewhat implausible setting in March 1997 in Winston-Salem, N.C.

title: Rafter Is Eliminated
description: Patrick Rafter, the Australian star returning from a shoulder injury, was ousted from the Citrix championships last night, falling, 4-6, 6-1, 6-2, to Paul Goldstein in a quarterfinal at Delray Beach, Fla.

title: Dominican Aid Halted Over New York Fugitive
description: The head of the House Committee on International Relations has invoked a rarely used power to block $6 million in aid to the Dominican Republic unless it hands over a man charged with a 1991 murder in the legislator's district in Westchester County.

title: Father Kills Himself and Son in Leap From Roof
description: A man leapt from the roof of his apartment building with his 9-year-old son in his arms early this morning, killing himself and the boy, the police said. The deaths occurred after the man had attacked his common-law wife and her 15-year-old daughter with a hammer and a knife.

title: Sandra Schmirler, 36, Dies; Olympic Curling Champion
description: Sandra Schmirler, the star of the first women's curling team to win an Olympic gold medal and one of Canada's most popular athletes, died Thursday in Regina, Saskatchewan. She was 36.

title: WEALTHY TEXAN SAYS HE BOUGHT ANTI-McCAIN ADS
description: A wealthy Texas businessman who is one of Gov. George W. Bush's biggest campaign contributors said today that he had paid $2.5 million for political commercials that sharply criticized Senator John McCain and promoted Mr. Bush's environmental record.

title: TIMKEN, BEARINGS MAKER, TO CUT 600 JOBS WORLDWIDE
description: The Timken Company, a maker of bearings and steel alloy products, said yesterday that it planned to cut 600 jobs worldwide because of overcapacity and lower prices for its products. The Canton, Ohio, company has been struggling for the last year because of weaker demand for its products worldwide. Since last May, its stock has slid more than 50 percent. It closed yesterday at $14.75, up 68.75 cents. The latest round of job cuts follows the elimination of 1,700 positions in 1998 and 1999. The company has 21,000 workers worldwide, including 13,000 in the United States.

title: A Skewed Tuition Tax Break
description: The Senate approved an unfair education bill this week that would give tax breaks mostly to upper-income families with children in private schools. President Clinton vetoed a similar proposal in 1998, and he should veto this legislation when it reaches his desk. The centerpiece of the bill, introduced by Senators Paul Coverdell, Republican of Georgia, and Robert Torricelli, Democrat of New Jersey, would allow families with annual incomes of up to $150,000 to deposit up to $2,000 a year per child in after-tax dollars into education savings accounts. The interest earned on the accounts would be tax-free, and the money could be used to pay for private school tuition and other educational expenses.

title: American Topics : Devotees of Wurlitzer Organs Are Keeping the Tradition Alive
description: The theater organ, once used to accompany silent films, was a versatile and powerful instrument. It could duplicate a full orchestra, or real-world sounds like ocean waves roaring, train whistles screeching or the clip-clop of horses' hooves. And it could shake the floor under viewers' feet. But with the advent of "talkie" pictures in the 1920s, most of these organs, which sat in 6,000 American movie houses in their heyday, were junked or sold.

title: MANOR CARE GAINS ON DUELING BUYOUT OFFERS
description: Shares of Manor Care Inc. rose 28 percent yesterday after the company, a nursing home operator, received competing buyout offers from its chairman, Stewart Bainum Jr., and its senior management. Manor Care, which owns 301 nursing homes in 31 states, rose $2.8125 a share to close at $12.6875 on the New York Stock Exchange. At that price the company's stock is worth about $1.31 billion. Mr. Bainum, who owns more than 10 percent of Manor Care, proposed a recapitalization, buyout or similar transaction at a price ''significantly in excess'' of Manor Care's current stock price. The other offer for the company, which is based in Toledo, Ohio, came from a group that includes members of Manor Care's senior management. The company said it would review the options.

title: 'War Requiem' Hasn't Lost Any of Its Power to Wound
description: Benjamin Britten's ''War Requiem,'' of 1961, was a delayed response to World War II, using poems written by Wilfred Owen during World War I, in which Owen was killed. The message of the Requiem, a reflection on the horrors of war couched in a liturgical context, was obviously meant to be universal, and there appears, alas, no danger that it will lose pertinence anytime soon.

Bush and Senator John McCain brought their tense battle to New York yesterday, as Mr. McCain accused the state's political leaders of trying to ''hijack the campaign'' for Mr. Bush, while the Texas governor mocked his opponent for ''squealing.''

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  AUSTIN, MARY
description: AUSTIN-Mary, 85, of Columbus, OH, formerly of New York City, passed away Friday, February 25, 2000 at Mt. Carmel West. The cause was complications following open heart surgery. She had been a resident of Kensington Place at the Columbus Lutheran Village since 1995. Mary worked for the National Union of Hospital Workers (District 1199) for 35 years, where she managed the collection of membership dues. She was a committed trade unionist, an ardent supporter of civil rights, and a generous contributor to progressive social causes. She was a humanist who consistently worked toward social justice and equality for all people. She was a proud liberal Democrat all of her life. Mary participated in Yiddish cultural activities, enjoying literature and music. Predeceased by her husband, Moe, and survived by her son, Jerry, and daughter-inlaw, Sharon, of Westerville, OH; and her daughter, Carol, and sonin-law, Bob, of Calgary, Alberta. Also survived by her granddaughter, Kacy, and grandson, Zack, of Columbus; her grandson, Nicholas Pecko, of Columbia, SC; her sister, Syd, and brother-in-law, Bernie; and her brother, Bill, and sister-inlaw, Nettie, of Delray Beach, FL. She will be greatly missed by her brothers and sisters of Local 1199 (SEJU). In lieu of flowers, the family requests donations be made to Operation Smile, 97 Glenn Drive, Worthington, OH. 43085.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  STRAUS, MARTHA (TURIM)
description: STRAUS-Martha (Turim). Loving beloved wife of the late Eli Straus, died Saturday at home. At her 100th birthday party, July 16, 1999, surrounded by a few dozen of her four generations of admiring nieces and nephews, she recalled that she had enjoyed ''living it my way,'' recommended her independent life-style to all her ''progeny'' and urged them to continue to cherish their family's special closeness, renowned generosity and independence of thought and spirit. Born in 1899 on New York's Lower East Side, she graduated from Hunter College in 1920, was a NYC mathematics teacher for almost 40 years, and was a leadership member of New York's United Federation of Teachers, who honored her recently. She loved European travel and keeping up with all the marriages and births in the Turim family. But her favorite hobby was always attending adult education at Hunter. A special person; a special role model; a very special Aunt, particularly to Ruth and the late Sidney Botvinik, Eleanor and George Fox, Shirley and Paul Rothkrug, Rose Kalman and their successor generations. A ceremony celebrating her life will be scheduled.

title: The Way We Work Now: 3-5-00; Office Romance
description: I sometimes miss the old days, when offices operated on the feudal system. There was the boss, or liege lord, who occasionally dispensed favors (raises, that is) but more often withheld them. For his gaze to fall upon you was supposed to be reward enough. There were the knights, in their three-piece armor of worsted and sharkskin, and beneath them the courtiers -- the toadies and rumormongers who pored over the entrails of the wastebasket, in hope of clues to the lord's disposition. There were the executive ladies-in-waiting, with their white-out and their carbon paper -- this was really back in the dark ages, before the Xerox machine even -- and there were the handmaidens, recent graduates of Seven Sisters colleges, dewy and bright-eyed and as renowned for their pulchritude as for their ability to type 60 wpm.

title: Come Back, Company Man!

Downsizing and re-engineering made it clear that employees were expendable commodities, not valued resources. Today, many bright workers are getting their revenge by fleeing their fickle employers for better-paying rivals -- or dot-com start-ups. Indeed, quitting has become so fashionable in Silicon Valley that the turnover rate for companies there has reached an estimated 25 percent a year. The average American 32-year-old has already worked for nine different companies. Workers today fantasize not about landing a ''dream job'' but about having a ''portfolio career'' -- one dream job after the other.

title: Partying With an Artistic Excuse
description: A large blinking eye was projected onto a screen as a band dressed in quasi-spacesuits performed digitally created music. Two women in bikini tops and regular shorts danced in a bathtub, as onlookers sat on chairs made of toilet seats. That was the scene at a raucous loft party in SoHo one recent Saturday night given by Move*ment, a company of artists, musicians and night-life entrepreneurs that creates events merging the club world with the art scene. ''It's a way to get the creative stuff that's out there out to people,'' said Don Melamed, the company's music coordinator. Since last year, its parties have been held at different locations throughout the city. (For information, 917-209-0610.) The Saturday party, with a $20 admission charge, went from 10 p.m. to 4 a.m. and drew more than 500 people, from art students to die-hard clubgoers. title: Pages in Time
description: A calendar is a sort of slow-motion clock, usually in the line of sight, marketing the passage of time, appointments, birthdays, holidays and other important events. But more than a clock, a calendar is a piece of aesthetic or commercial design. Having recently flipped the page to the year 2000, the Newark Public Library thought this a good time to think about calendars. The staff there fathered about 1,000 and selected about 200 of them to show in ''The Essential Calendar: The Art and Design of Calendars, Thematic, Historic and Artistic Examples.'' There are calendars with themes like cats, dogs, movie stars, wildlife (meant to encourage preservation) and European cities (meant to encourage visits). There are also pop-up and 3-D calendar art, and appointment books and wrist watches that show the date (are they ever right?). More consciously artistic examples include a single-page annual calendar illustrating the moon's phrases and one featuring 18th-century flower illustrations. The exhibition is in the library's third-floor gallery through April 29. You can mark the date.

He is survived by his son, John Williams Jr., daughters Elizabeth Williams and Johnna Williams, and by many friends of Bill W., on whose lives he had a profound effect and to whom he will be a power of example forever. Born in Washington DC in 1924, he served with distinction in World War II as a member of the 82nd Airborne, receiving the Bronze Star and Purple Heart for his heroic actions in the Battle of the Bulge. Upon his return from the war, he earned a Bachelor of Arts degree from Yale University. Mr. Williams retired from Morgan Guarantee Bank as Vice President for Special Health Services where he founded the program for providing counseling and assistance to employees suffering from alcoholism. He had served as Director of Public Relations at Pepsi-Cola Company prior to his work in the field of alcoholism. In 1967 he was named as Special Deputy on Alcoholism to the NYC Commissioner of Health and launched the first successful effort to open city hospital beds and to provide out-patient and aftercare services to alcoholics. Later, he created employee assistance programs for many of the Fortune 100 companies which are now a mainstay of corporate employee benefits programs. title: The Way We Work Now: 3-5-00: Salient Facts: Employment; Help Wanted Really Badly

The national unemployment rate of 4.0 percent, as of January, is lower than it has been since 1970 -- and it is far lower than that in some areas. Mitch Potter of William M. Mercer Inc., a human resources consulting firm, says the word in Silicon Valley is, ''The only way to find an unemployment rate is if you count people in cars on their way from one job to another.'' The situation is so extreme that it is driving some understaffed employers to desperate measures: the Plano, Tex., IHOP has had to offer a $4,000 signing bonus to attract managers. Lord & Taylor sent out part-time-job solicitations with its monthly charge-card statements this past Christmas. And a Chicago-based staffing agency, the Harris Group, has arranged 160 $100,000 signing (and retention) bonuses for Web-savvy hires at one company alone. title: Paid Notice: Deaths  BOGEDAL, ERIC
description: BOGEDAL-Eric. Passed away on February 28 in the Hospice of the Piedmont at Martha Jefferson Hospital in Charlottesville, VA. A native of New York City, Eric was born on July 26, 1928 to Viggo and Laura (nee Knudsen) Bogedal, Danish immigrants who soon became citizens. He attended school in Queens, NY, the challenging Stuyvesant High School in Manhattan, and received a BA degree from Columbia College in 1952. Eric served in the U.S. Army in communications and was honorably discharged as a T4 (Sergeant). He began his career as editor of in-house publications at Mutual Benefit Life Insurance Co. and later served as public relations manager for Corning Glass and American Brake Shoe. He then entered the advertising industry, joining BBDO, Inc., where he worked in account management from 1962-1978. At that time, he followed BBDO President Jim Jordan, who left the agency to form his own company, James Jordan, Inc. (later Jordan, McGrath, Case & Taylor, Inc.). At the time of his retirement in 1989, Eric was a senior vice president of that agency, now known as jmcp.inc. He retired to a farm in Bedford, VA, where he continued to work as a computer consultant for the company he had served for so long. In July 1995, he married Eileen Murphy and moved with her to Greene County, VA. Eric is survived by Eileen; his mother, Laura; his former wife, Barbara Taylor; his four married children Robert, Steven and David Bogedal and Debra Hocker; his step-brothers Carl and John Skinner of Slate Hill, NY; and his step-children Chris and Noreen Murphy. He also has five grandchildren. Eric was a model railroader, amateur musician and jazz buff, lifetime member of Mensa, member of the Madison Avenue Motorcycle Club and the Long Island Sports Car Association. A memorial service will be held in New York at a future date for family, friends and coworkers. Eric would have preferred that, in lieu of flowers or other memorials, donations be made in his memory to Hospice of the Piedmont, 1490 Pantops Mountain Place, Suite 200, Charlottesville, VA 22911 (804-975-5500), where he was lovingly cared for at the end.

Whatever we may think about telecommuting in pajamas, we have become much more particular about what we want out of a workplace, creating all sorts of challenges for designers. Offices today, even in gigantic converted warehouse spaces, have to be more open, flexible, communal -- and personal. This is especially crucial for Internet companies, whose workers tend to be not only quite young but also highly mobile.

title: Books in Brief: Fiction; The Bees Went Crazy
description: ''I love, love, love Jane Austen's understatement,'' Mary White says minutes before the LSD kicks in. In Matthew Sharpe's first novel, NOTHING IS TERRIBLE (Villard, $23.95), understatement and absurdity combine to make this potentially shocking book clever -- if a little creepy -- fun. Everything that happens in ''Nothing Is Terrible'' is terrible indeed: Mary, the narrator, is orphaned at 10. Months later, her twin brother dies after she insists he play ''making the bees go crazy.'' She then falls for her sixth-grade teacher, Miss Skip Hartman, a 37-year-old WASP with expressive hair and baroque syntax. Skip almost literally buys Mary from her uncle and whisks her off to Manhattan's Upper East Side where, following an introduction to the pleasures of the flesh and of crisp white duvets, she is home-schooled by a pot-dealing physics whiz and a Nietzschean supermodel. (When asked if she's read ''Beyond Good and Evil,'' Mary replies, ''No, but I've lived it.'') A truly rotten kid, Mary hurts the ones she loves and offends everyone else with her ''perpetually rejuvenating force field of hatred and suspicion.'' But through more adventures involving drugs, piercings and adult diapers, Mary's education is complete when she becomes, well, sentimental. Beneath Sharpe's cynicism and postmodern surrealism -- both of which were also on display in his first book, a collection of short stories titled ''Stories From the Tube'' -- beats a sweet heart, as felt when Mary and her tutor share their ''favorite anthology of shortbreads'': ''Intimacy is protean, and we used our mutual devotion to soft, sodden, sugary biscuits as a springboard for meaning-making activity of inexhaustible nuance.'' Warped and oddly touching, ''Nothing Is Terrible'' is brain candy for the bright and jaded. Christine Muhlke

Dolce & Gabbana's beaded and sequined denim slides (far right, $730 at Saks Fifth Avenue), Ria Geon-Plum's flip-flops with a rainbow thong ($58 at Henri Bendel) and Neal Decker's embroidered shopping bag (far left, $145 at Calypso stores) are made of dark indigo denim. France Luxe offers plastic hair clips printed with a very convincing photographic image of denim ($7 to $18 at Bergdorf Goodman). And Stila has created a denim collection for the spring (near right, $12 to $24 at Barneys), with eyeshadow, lipstick and compacts in denim-printed casing. title: Tokyo, Scrutable City
description: THE major thoroughfares of Tokyo have rhythmic names, like Hibiya, and Asakusa, and Waseda. But ordinary streets, where a person can have his hair cut, or grab a bowl of noodles, or lose his shirt at Pachinko -- these have no names at all. An address does not mention the street; it specifies first the name of the ku, or ward; then the name of the cho, or neighborhood; and finally the name of the chome, or cluster of blocks. Within a chome blocks are numbered, and within a block buildings are numbered: sometimes sequentially, sometimes chronologically, sometimes in some other order that probably makes sense to someone.

description: WHEN David Brancaccio hit town the other day, he was ready to spend money -- spend big and spend fast.

title: His Canvas a TV Screen, His Brush a Camera
description: MERCE CUNNINGHAM once told Charles Atlas: ''When approaching a new work, ask yourself, 'What are the possibilities of this situation?' Go as far as possible. Work with all the possibilities.'' Mr. Atlas (known by his friends as Charlie) was with Mr. Cunningham as protege and collaborator for more than 13 years, during which they invented what Mr. Atlas calls ''mediadance.''

title: Theft Under the Taliban? Perish the Thought
description: If the Taliban are anything, they are holier-than-thou. And that's what made the big heist so embarrassing.

title: The Gem Amid the Malls
description: Hidden behind the strip malls, neo-colonial subdivisions and glimmering office parks of the state's most densely settled region lies an unlikely swath of wilderness: 1,300 acres of marsh and red maple where coyote, red foxes and black bear roam and humans seldom venture.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  KAYE, MELISSA ANNE
description: KAYE-Melissa Anne. In our hearts forever. We miss you and think of you always. Love, your family and friends.

title: A Class Feminists Might Abhor
description: CHERYL MARKS has a good job and close friends. She travels often. She's healthy. What's missing? A relationship. And though she never defined herself by her marital status, after turning 31 last year, she decided to take action.

title: SCHOOL DECLARATION LOSES AGAIN
description: Senator Gerald Cardinale's 13-year effort to get a bill through the Legislature requiring schoolchildren to recite part of the Declaration of Independence daily failed again last week. Black legislators said they felt the words of the Declaration did not include black people because they were enslaved at the time of the American Revolution. KAREN DeMASTERS

title: Political Briefing; California Senator's Outlook Is Sunny
description: Amid all the hoopla surrounding the presidential primaries, it has gone almost unnoticed that there will be a United States Senate race on the ballot when Californians vote on Tuesday.

title: Anxious Weekend After False Alarm
description: The rumor started at 3 p.m. on Friday: the jury had decided, a verdict in the Abner Louima conspiracy trial was in.

title: The Other Side Of Fashion Ave.
description: Young fashion enthusiasts continue to have fun dressing. Their look is far removed from the 1950's Park Avenue ladies' style that designers are trying to revive. Teenagers are tying on dust-ruffle leggings (left). Others save for a pair of funky Prada boots (right), an inflated-tube shoulder bag (far right) or the Helmut Lang tunic with dangling pink ribbons.

title: Skirts and Halter Tops For the Young and Free of Spirit
description: Six years ago, a Greek designer, Christina Kara, founded Blue, a fashion store in the East Village that originally offered ready-to-wear clothing but now specializes in custom formal and wedding wear. Wanting to return to self-designed, less formal fashions, in December Ms. Kara opened Blue Skirt at 137 Avenue A. The store offers modern, playful fashions, from day to cocktail wear.

title: American Subtracts Seats to Add Legroom
description: Coach passengers on American Airlines will soon have as much legroom as they did more than a decade ago. The airline is spending $70 million to remove two rows of seats from each of its 700 jetliners, giving passengers at least an extra three inches of legroom, the airline says.

title: Ancient Tribal Longing vs. Modern Housing
description: ENIGMATIC to outsiders, often divided internally and habitually guarded in dealings with a community many see as biased, the 500 members of the Shinnecock tribe do not always speak with one voice, if they speak at all, about affairs outside their 800-acre reservation in Southampton.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  KERPEN, ROSALIE
description: KERPEN-Rosalie. On March 3 at age 95. Beloved wife of the late Oscar. Loving mother of Grace Wechsler and her husband Irving, and Ellen Cohen and her husband Edmond. Adoring grandmother of Susan Segal and her husband Kenneth and Nancy Cohen. Interment private.

title: Troubles
description: Water, Carry Me

title: PLAYING IN THE NEIGHBORHOOD
description: FLUSHING

title: Bye, Frying Pan. But Where Did That Fire Come From?
description: When a grandmaster is taken by surprise in an opening variation he has not kept up with because he did not expect his opponent to use it, he usually takes what he hopes will be a neutral course, an old variation that has not attracted attention for a while. He does not expect to put pressure on the opponent, he just hopes to avoid the latest tactical tricks. He wants to get to a quiet middle game and see what turns up.

title: Commercial Property/Incubators; Providing a Helping Hand to Internet Start-Ups
description: THE proliferation of new-media and other Internet-related companies in New York and the scarcity of available office space are creating a new type of business: incubators that provide prebuilt space to start-up companies, often in return for the right to obtain stock at favorable prices.

title: Something Wicked
description: IN THE NAME OF THE WOLF

title: How Could a 6-Year-Old Kill?
description: To the Editor:

title: Convention Center Shapes Boston Harbor Area
description: WITH a 2.3-million-square-foot convention center as its vanguard, a new commercial neighborhood with luxury housing is emerging on Boston Harbor, which for almost four centuries has been the heart of this compact city perennially in search of expansion space. Nine projects valued at $3 billion are being developed in a district once dominated by wharves, ship terminals, fish processors and warehouses.

title: The View From/Seymour; The Pockets of a Town Are Suddenly Empty
description: NOT too long ago it seemed that things were going well in this Naugatuck Valley community of 15,000 people.

title: George L. Street, 86, Commander of the Submarine Tirante in World War II
description: Capt. George L. Street III, who won the Medal of Honor in World War II for directing a daring submarine attack that destroyed three Japanese ships off the coast of Korea, died on Feb. 26 at a nursing home in Andover, Mass. He was 86.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  ALLISON, PAMELA E.
description: ALLISON-Pamela E. Beloved daughter of Wana E. Allison Barnett of the San Francisco Opera Ballet and New York Broadway and live television and the late John Lambourne Allison of IT&T. Beloved stepdaughter of Frank E. Barnett of Union Pacific Corporation. Pamela was a graduate of the Chapin School, Sarah Lawrence College, and the University of Michigan Graduate School.

title: Psychiatric Medication Is Moving Into the Lineup
description: Ballplayers used to go to spring training to dry out, slim down and refocus their batting eyes. Those who didn't have to spend the winter working in the local hardware store got fat on the rubber-chicken circuit telling stories about Mickey and Billy getting lost in the woods with Jim Beam and rifles.

title: Ara Geller, Lonnie Tinter
description: Ara Brooke Geller, the daughter of Enid Schneider-O'Sullivan of Manhattan and Bruce A. Geller of East Rockaway, N.Y., was married last evening to Lonnie Craig Tinter, a son of Cheryl and Gerald Tinter of Valley Stream, N.Y. Rabbi Ronald Androphy performed the ceremony at the East Meadow (N.Y.) Jewish Center.

title: From Far-Off Shores to Long Island
description: IN the beginning, there were the Native Americans: the Algonquin tribes like the Matinecocks, the Shinnecocks and the Montauks. Then in the 17th century came the English and the Dutch, with their African slaves, in the first of what was to become succeeding waves of immigrants to Long Island.

title: POSTINGS: West Village Landmark; Lofts and Duplexes Replace Vintage Cars
description: When the 11-story building at 132 Perry Street in the West Village opens to tenants near the end of the year, adding its mix of condominium lofts and skylit duplex apartments to the quiet neighborhood, the sign on the building will still say Cooper Classics, the name of the automobile sales and restoration business that had occupied 132 Perry since 1978. (It moved across the street last May.)

title: Paid Notice: Memorials  FAY, VALLE WEBER
description: FAY-Valle Weber. March 5, 1919-St Louis, Missouri. January 22, 1997-Norwalk, Connecticut.

title: Museum Tries to Make a Point: At Sea, Everyone Is Equal
description: IN 1943, the four-man crew of the Danish lighthouse tender Gerda III hid 20 Jews in the ship's hold each night and ferried them to safety in Sweden the next day. In all, the Gerda III saved 300 of the 7,000 Danish Jews that German officials had decided to deport to death camps.

title: Handicapping Super Tuesday: How to Tell Who Won
description: WHEN the primaries or caucuses came one at a time like Iowa, New Hampshire, South Carolina and Michigan -- it was easy to tell whether Gov. George W. Bush or Senator John McCain was up or down. And even when there were three contests last Tuesday, figuring out who was up was easy because one candidate, Mr. Bush, swept Virginia, Washington State and North Dakota.

title: Child-Friendly In the West 50's
description: ANGELO'S COAL OVEN PIZZA

title: POSTINGS: Real Estate Board's Residential Program; From Skyline To Fire Safety
description: From grand plans for New York City and its skyline to more prosaic subjects, like fire safety and psychological tips for residential marketing, a wide range of seminars and speeches is scheduled for the Real Estate Board of New York's fifth annual trade show and convention next Friday at the New York Hilton Hotel.

title: TOMS RIVER CANCER
description: A report released by state health officials last week said that Toms River residents may have been exposed to carcinogens that had seeped into the town's water supply from the Ciba-Geigy chemical plant. The report is part of a $10 million study into why 90 Toms River children were found to have cancer between 1979 and 1995, a rate 74 percent higher than normal in a town its size. Health officials said known carcinogens like benzene and chloroform had been found in private wells near the Ciba-Geigy plant, adding that the site, closed in 1996, no longer posed a threat.

title: Thugs on Ice
description: To the Sports Editor:

title: McCain's Candidacy in U.S. Reopens Wounds for Canada
description: Next month's 25-year anniversary of the fall of Saigon and the presidential campaign of Senator John McCain are reopening a long forgotten fissure between two groups of Canadian 50-somethings: the roughly 25,000 American draft dodgers still living here, and the almost equal number of Canadians who volunteered to fight in Vietnam.

title: In With the Old: Shopping Abroad
description: ONE spring long ago, my husband and I flew to London on a Swinging Weekend charter flight, sharing a sleepless night with friends, casino-bound New Jerseyans and a Broadway star, her husband and her lawyer. The star was going to London to buy an African carving; the three were pooling their duty-free allowance so it would enter the United States without tax. Returning, they carried their trophy aboard in delight.

title: Sending Out a Search Party for the Western
description: TWO movies set in a once-renowned but now rarely visited arena will open this year. Next month, Miramax will release ''Texas Rangers,'' starring the television pinups James Van Der Beek and Ashton Kutcher, among others, as wet-behind-the-ears recruits in Stetsons and bandoliers who take on a band of renegades. Disney's ''Shanghai Noon,'' starring Jackie Chan as a 19th-century Chinese man trailing a Chinese princess in the American West, follows in the summer.

title: IDEAS & TRENDS: Dark Matters; A Cosmic Hall Of Mirrors
description: REACHING beyond earth, air, fire and water, Aristotle insisted that the heavenly spheres -- the realm of the stars and gods -- must be composed of something less mundane. This ethereal fifth essence, or ''quintessence,'' was the very substance, medieval theologians went on to propose, of which the angels themselves were made.

title: Make an Immigration Policy for Today's Needs; Temporary-Visa Abuse
description: To the Editor:

title: Sagging Crowds and Optimism Don't Sap Bradley's Energy
description: Just before 10 o'clock yesterday, on a chilly morning in Washington Square Park, former Senator Bill Bradley returned to the neighborhood where he had come the day after his narrow loss in New Hampshire.

title: When the Weather Demands Simple, Warming Fare: Stews
description: ONE winter several years ago I stayed in an inn that was surrounded by cross-country ski trails. It had a mediocre restaurant, which was redeemed by a short, underpriced wine list (a good bottle of burgundy cost less than the price in the liquor store). The food was basic, mostly stews, done without much flair. But when you have skied all day you are ravenously hungry, and everything tasted wonderful. After dinner, we were tucked up in a room with a fireplace, fast asleep well before 10.

title: FILM; Getting Past Fabulousness To Real Life
description: THE itinerant movie extras and crew guys in shorts were trying not to stare. One of the world's most instantly recognizable woman had just emerged from a black car with darkened windows and popped open an umbrella large enough to shelter a family of four. Flanked by a pair of young assistants and two armed bodyguards, Madonna leveled the umbrella above her. It was June, but here in the chic Los Angeles neighborhood of Silverlake, where half-million-dollar houses cram together with quarter-of-a-million-dollar fixer-uppers, Madonna had arrived to shoot a New Year's Eve party scene for her new movie, ''The Next Best Thing,'' which opened on Friday. The party was set in the parched backyard of a colorful Spanish-style triplex that doubled as home to Madonna's character, a yoga instructor helping to raise a son sired by her good friend, a gay man played by the pop star's own good friend, Rupert Everett.

title: Carnival Is A Good Idea For All of Us
description: CARNIVAL dances in this weekend across the Caribbean, South America, southern Europe and that splendid cultural biosphere, New Orleans. From now through Fat Tuesday, carnival's first paradox is that it ties profane delights to the church calendar, wrapping up before Lent begins on Ash Wednesday.

title: Paid Notice: Memorials  MILANO, ROBERT J.
description: MILANO-Robert J. On January 29, 2000. A memorial will be held Monday, March 6 at 10:30 AM at New School University, Tishman Auditorium, 66 West 12 St., NYC.

title: Plan to Limit Political Donations Gets Unlikely Help
description: Cowboys have long been a vanishing breed in California, but when it comes to campaign finance, this is still the wild, wild West. It is one of only six states, and the only big one besides Illinois, with no restrictions on political contributions or spending. Its Democratic governor, Gray Davis, raised a record $13.2 million in his first year in office last year.

title: Rockets' Other Big Man Rejects Nets' Bid
description: For the Nets to visit the Compaq Center and have their victory plans foiled by a Houston Rockets big man is nothing new. Hakeem Olajuwon, one of the greatest centers in the history of the game, has been doing that for years.

title: Jennifer Ross, Itai Zukerman
description: Jennifer Felicity Ross and Itai Zukerman are to be married today at the Angel Orensanz Foundation Center for the Arts in Manhattan. Rabbi Burt Aaron Siegel is to officiate.

title: Meet Mr. and Ms. Median income
description: Michael Eisner, the chairman of Disney, needed to work only two hours to earn $33,000 last year. Somebody making the minimum wage would have had to work almost 18 hours a day, seven days a week, every week of the year to earn the same amount. Between those extremes, however, was the average full-time American worker, who last year made just about $33,000 before taxes.

title: Guyana's Capital
description: To the Editor: I was delighted with the photographs of Georgetown, Guyana, accompanying the article ''Guyana's Capital, Tropical Victorian'' (Feb. 6), although I do not intend to visit the country. It is sad that some of the buildings are in disrepair for lack of resources. Is there an organization raising funds for restoration?

title: State Cancer Map: One Step In the Search for the Causes
description: AS the white stretch limo zoomed westward on the Long Island Expressway, the passengers giggled and gossiped, catching up on old times and remarking how good it was to be united after years of divisive squabbling in their pursuit of separate but overlapping agendas.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  KATZ, GEORGE
description: KATZ-George . On February 15, 2000 at his home in Roosevelt, NJ. Formerly of NYC, he is survived by his wife Margaret Erle Katz, his daughter Lisa Jayne and son-inlaw Jeffrey A. Scheinert of Hallendale, FL, his son Mark Wayne, daughter-in-law Judy, and granddaughter Rachel Lauren of North Wales, PA, and his daughter Cheri Rose Katz of NYC. His gracious humor and unflagging devotion to his family, friends, and communities will long be remembered.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  MORRISON, ESTELLE BUTLER
description: MORRISON-Estelle Butler, of Larchmont, NY, on March 2, 2000. Beloved wife of the late Joshua Morrison, mother of Alan Butler Morrison and Peggy Morrison Horan, mother-in-law of Anne Scherck Morrison and Richard Horan. Grandmother of Nina Rauh Morrison, Rebecca Butler Morrison, Lucia Rose Morrison Horan and Jasmine Star Morrison Horan. Sister of Ada Butler Gravin. Also survived by two sistersin-law, 13 nieces and nephews, and countless friends. Funeral services at Larchmont Temple at 12:30 PM Sunday, March 5. Interment will follow at Mt. Hope Cemetery. Contributions may be made in her memory to the Joshua and Estelle Morrison Endowed Scholarship Fund, Clark University, Worcester, Massachusetts.

title: CAMDEN DRUG CONVICTIONS
description: A jury in federal district court in Camden last week convicted two men of conspiracy to distribute large amounts of cocaine. During the eight-week trial of Jose Rivera and Luis Figuerio, five self-confessed drug dealers named Camden's mayor, Milton Milan, a childhood friend of Mr. Rivera's, as a mid-level North Camden drug dealer during the 80's and early 90's. Mr. Milan is the focus of a grand jury investigation into his connections with the dealers, but has not been charged with any wrongdoing. PETER J. PERROTTA

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SIEGEL, GEORGE
description: SIEGEL-George. Died March 3 after a long illness at age 76. Professor of Russian Literature and Doctor of Philosophy. Loving companion to Faye Mittelman. Devoted brother and brother-in-law to Jesse and Wilma Siegel. Proud uncle to Hillary Levin and Nancy Siegel. The Siegel family loses by his passing, love, intellect, caring and good counsel that is irreplaceable. Funeral services Sundday at 11 AM, at Frank E. Campbell, 1076 Madison Ave. at 81 St. Burial Westchester Hills Cemetery in Westchester.

title: Appalachian Spring, in Winter
description: THE word spa conjures up for me images of somewhere warm and dry, with palm trees and organic vegetables available year round. But often when you need a break from routine, you have neither the time nor the resources to travel far. You're all set if you live in, say, northern Mexico, but rural western Pennsylvania in the middle of winter?

title: The Way We Work Now: 3-5-00: How It's Done in South Africa; Under Rock, in a Hard Place
description: The cage deposits you a mile closer to the center of the earth -- and only then do you begin the long commute to work, two miles along the crosscut to the gold reef. All around you trudge a stream of silent, overall-clad figures -- shadowed faces beneath helmet lamps, drained of all emotion as if the drop into the earth has pulled a mask of blankness over them. The passageway has the look of Victorian industrial fantasy: overhead pipes sputter and hiss with the water and the air that make the underground habitable. You are in a tunnel 10 feet high and 10 feet wide, but the accretion of so many years of activity evokes not claustrophobia but rather another civilization, in which the components of surface life -- space, time, sound, light, climate -- have been rearranged unintelligibly.

title: Hats to Top And to Tip
description: For brotherhood, children and the Frick.

title: Cambodia's City of Temples Is a Timeless Survivor
description: WELCOME to the New Millennium -- Peace, Culture and Tourism,'' read the brochure in my hand, a cheery guide to the celebrations planned in Angkor Wat for the year 2000. The taxi was hot and had come to a halt in the middle of the street. A funeral procession, one of seven I saw during my short stay in Siem Reap, Cambodia, solemnly filed through the intersection, a river of white-clad mourners and orange-robed monks.

title: Key Zoning Question: Just What Is a School?
description: A CENTER for disabled children, a Jewish day school and a Pentecostal church have presented plans to build two schools and a sanctuary on former horse farms here, and have thus set off a small furor among residents who warn about noise, traffic and overdevelopment.

title: Sports of The Times; Pettitte's Father Shows His Resolve
description: THE pitching line was two and one-third innings, four hits, two runs. These numbers meant nothing, nor did the game, and for those very reasons, Andy Pettitte's father took a seat behind the Yankee dugout, in the warm Florida sun, to watch his boy pitch.

title: The Idled Workaholic
description: Mark Cuban is sitting on a very soft couch, in a room of his house in which the ceilings are at least 20 feet distant and the television is larger than the fireplace. ''Money,'' he says, ''is a scoreboard where you can rank how you're doing against other people.''

title: Black History Awards
description: In honor of Black History Month, the county and its Millennium Commission have honored eight African- Americans for outstanding accomplishments.

title: Starks Deserving Of Free Agency
description: From South Florida to New York last week, pro basketball zealots were again talking about John Starks. Miami Heat fans were salivating over the possibility of the team acquiring him for the playoffs, if for no other reason than to stick it in the Knicks' faces. Hard-core Knickies were telephoning WFAN Radio, begging to know if it was true. Was Starks close to wearing orange and blue again? Conjecture and gossip, always good for the game, abounded.

title: What Becomes A Scandal Most
description: REAL scandals often require not just scandalous facts, but a trigger, a nettlesome event, to activate public outrage. In Los Angeles, for example, a police corruption scandal in which officers brutalized, framed and, in at least two cases, shot innocent people has suddenly erupted after quietly simmering for five months.

title: McCain's Ethnic Slur: Gone, But Not Quite Forgotten
description: THE brushfire over Senator John McCain's use of the anti-Asian slur ''gooks'' flared and faded within a few days late last month.

title: Feel the Burn? It's More of a Glow
description: SPA is one of those curious words that is redefined every generation or so. A century ago, spas in the United States were mineral springs, where visitors suffering from ailments such as arthritis, rheumatism or jangled nerves soaked in steamy, sulfurous waters. A 1950's spa was a fat farm, with a lettuce-leaf diet and a battery of beauty treatments. Fitness spas, where chirpy instructors screamed ''Feel the burn,'' typified the 1980's; everyone jumped and sweated for hours in big, mirror-lined rooms and almost never went outdoors.

title: A Classroom for the Creation of Art That Is Both Inspired and Inspiring
description: ADAM SWART is an art teacher who does most of the painting for his students. During a recent class, Mr. Swart repeatedly asked one of them if the paint he was mixing was the right color for what the student wanted to do, if he was using enough water, if the line he was drawing was straight enough or long enough.

title: New Interest in the Smokestacks
description: Smoke was once again visible from the stacks on Friday as Old Economy companies retook a leadership role that they had relinquished to New Economy technology companies of late.

title: The Face of Drug Use
description: To the Editor:

title: JERSEY DIARY
description: DEAR DIARY:

title: Warm Jade Stones Between Your Toes
description: EVERYONE'S tired of hearing how tired working mothers are all the time, so I won't say how tired I was when I set out for a three-day respite at two resorts on the California coast in November. Let's just say I was not at all sorry to abandon fourth-grade homework, a second-grade class dinner, the subway, my office, two weekend soccer games and the cat box. I was sorry only to leave the other working parent in our household behind. But not as sorry as he was.

title: Foxwoods-Glen Cove Ferry Rules the Sound
description: WHEN a Glen Cove councilwoman, MaryAnn Holzkamp, showed up on Wednesday to greet the Tatobam as it arrived in Hempstead Harbor to inaugurate high-speed ferry service from New London, Conn., there was no fanfare. In fact, she barely had time to get on board before an aide was whispering that the crew was ready to pull up the gangplanks for the return trip to Connecticut and they had to get off.

title: U.S. Dangled Poison Secrets Before Soviets, Book Reports
description: An American double agent working for the F.B.I. provided the Soviet Union with nerve gas data in the 1960's that may have spurred Moscow's own efforts to develop chemical weapons, says a new book on the espionage case.

title: Zowie! Kazam! A Web Site for Comics!
description: Anyone who collects comics knows that finding them can be difficult, especially limited edition and vintage copies not found in most stores. A new source for those rarities is ComicSeller.com, an Internet site begun in December by Jake Shapiro, 22, who runs it from his home in the East Village. ComicSeller is a clearinghouse that links buyers and sellers. Prospective sellers submit their collections to the site, and they are instantly e-mailed to the list of registered buyers.

title: At the Planetarium, an Impresario of Crowd Control
description: It was midafternoon, and the line for the new planetarium at the Rose Center for Earth and Space seemed to stretch from here to Saturn. Upward of 400 people clutched ''cosmic passport'' tickets for the 3 p.m. show, and hundreds more stood around waiting for later programs. The line, which started at the elevators, snaked five times and spilled into the main hallway. Children darted about at warp speed, while adults complained about the length of the wait.

description: To the Sports Editor:

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SCHMUGER, HELENE
description: SCHMUGER - Helene. Beloved wife of the late Morris W. Schmuger. Loving mother of Connie Greenberg, Sheila Zemsky, Carol and Lawrence Krug, Steven and Lynne Schmuger. Cherished grandmother and great grandmother, dear sister. Her profound dignity, gentleness and loving kindness is the foundation of her family. Services will be held at Gutterman-Musicant, 402 Park Street, Hackensack, New Jersey, Sunday, at 10:30AM.

title: San Francisco
description: San Francisco is always up for company. It always looks beautiful, always hums with energy, always jumps at the chance to show off.

title: What Do You Do All Day?
description: The Bureaucrat, JULIET CRUZ, 29, representative, Department of Motor Vehicles.

title: Strawberry Out for One Year
description: Four boxes of fan mail were stacked in front of Darryl Strawberry's locker at the New York Yankees' spring training complex in Tampa, Fla., obscuring the uniform he won't need this season, or perhaps ever again. Strawberry, who turns 38 this week, was suspended for one year by Bud Selig, the baseball commissioner, for using cocaine. It was Strawberry's third suspension from baseball, and for the third time he checked into a drug rehab center. BUSTER OLNEY

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  TUCKER, LILLIAN
description: TUCKER-Lillian. To my loving sister, deceased February 17, 2000. Widow of Morton; loving mother of Ellen, husband Peter; grandmother of Ethan and Matthew; sister of Myron Susser, deceased. Sister in-law of Doris, Esther and Ruth; adored aunt of Loren, Mitchell, Peter, Marc, Roy and Andrew. We love you and will miss you greatly. Herbert Susser

title: Iona Relies on Defense To Advance Past Rider
description: With Rider milking every possession and Iona's players logging too many minutes to be able to press, the Gaels were resigned to a plodding halfcourt game tonight in the quarterfinals of the Metro Atlantic Athletic Conference men's basketball tournament at Pepsi Arena.

description: A state agency reversed itself and backed her landlord, and Anne Gilman says she cannot afford to pay $2,223 a month and $47,000 in back rent. By Trish Hall 4

description: It was chilly at Blackberry Slump, a farm in Augusta in northwestern New Jersey owned by Jeanne L. Austin and Peter Nadolny -- sweater weather. The 31 cashmere goats there were perfectly comfortable.

description: TYLER-William, 79, of the Bronx, New York. Passed away on February 29, 2000. For information Granby's Funeral Service, Inc., Bronx, New York.

title: Regina Foont, Brook Haberman
description: Regina Elizabeth Foont, a daughter of Evelyn and Paul Foont of Long Beach, N.Y., and Brook A. Haberman, a son of Henryka and Jacob Haberman of Manhattan, are to be married today. Rabbi David Halivni will officiate at the New York Hilton.

title: Saying Goodbye to the 'Burbs
description: AS this city's biggest apartment developer, John A. Williams and the company he founded -- Post Properties Inc. -- helped make Atlanta a symbol of urban sprawl bursting out of control. Through the 1970's and 80's, he turned thousands of acres of suburban forest into vast expanses of garden apartments.

title: THE VIEW FROM/Peekskill; Sure, There Will Be a St. Patrick's Parade, but Six Months Late
description: WHEN it comes to the calendar, some things seem incontrovertible. Shamrocks and shillelagh, for example, are part of March as surely as back-to-school clothes, apples and chrysanthemums belong in September.

title: Tokyo Dropouts' Vocation: Painting the Town
description: For Misa Horii and Ami Yamazaki, Saturday night begins at 7, when they set out to prowl the streets of the trendy Shibuya district sporting bleached-blond hair, chalky makeup and pink highlights methodically applied atop their deep copper tans.

title: Not Funny?
description: To the Editor:

title: Food Fights
description: For overworked Americans, the two-martini lunch, or a series of hurried snacks, consumed at the desk or in a Spartan break room. Etiqueete hasn't kept up. Half-eaten sandwichs are stolen from their owners' desks, while office microwaves and refrigerators ooze with months of grime. And few workplaces seem to have an desk-top-dining rules. Send your spiciest stories to On the Job, Money & Busines, The New York Times, 229 West 43rd Street, New York, N.Y. 10036. Or send them by e-mail to onthejob@nytimes.com. Include your name and telephone number. All submissions become the property of The Times and may be republished in any medium.

title: Crime
description: The best suspense stories are the ones that creep up on you, breathe on your neck and jump back in the shadows when you turn around. Michael Kimball plays that game with unnerving skill in MOUTH TO MOUTH (Avon, $24), a psychological thriller with the scariest kind of villain -- a handsome, helpful, utterly winsome sociopath with an evil agenda that his victims fail to see until it's too late.

title: 0%* Unemployment
description: Karl Marx spent all those years dreaming about the worker's paradise. Yet he never got to sit in the conference room at Berbee Information Networks Corporation and listen to Jim Berbee rattle off all the luscious perks he offers his employees. They get stock options, of course, but also Palm Pilots, cell phones and a $1,000 bonus to help with the down payment on their first homes. If they want to work in their pajamas, the company pays to install and maintain high-speed I.S.D.N. lines in their bedrooms. Two years ago Berbee took everybody in the company and their families to Disney World. Bagels and muffins are free on Fridays, the sodas in the office machine are free all the time (consumption went up 400 percent after that change), and if employees want to use the office copiers for personal use, no problem. An auto-repair service comes to the employee parking lot every other Wednesday to do oil changes and tire rotations. There's dry-cleaning delivery four days a week and pizza at least once a month (which for some reason employees still have to pay for).

In the liner notes for ''S&M,'' Mr. Kamen writes that the collaboration was not instantly harmonious. ''The first contact with the audience was a frightening, deafening roar which terrified the orchestra,'' he said. ''Orchestra players leapt to their feet.'' title: Books in Brief: Nonfiction; Freedom From MOMA
description: In 1986, Arthur Danto called Norman Rockwell's images of American life ''a shovelful of stardust.'' Rockwell's work may be more revered and heatedly debated than any other artist of our past century. The essays, by critics including Maureen Hart Hennessey, Judy L. Larson and Robert Rosenblum, in NORMAN ROCKWELL: Pictures for the American People (Abrams, $35), argue that his work helped shape popular perceptions of American culture in the 20th century. They further assert that Rockwell single-handedly turned high art into an everyday experience. Rockwell began training as an illustrator early in life, staying his traditional course even as the art world embraced modernism and abstraction. His tenacity brought success, first as the art editor of Boys' Life, the magazine of the Boy Scouts of America, then as primary illustrator of The Saturday Evening Post, for which he completed 322 cover illustrations over 47 years. Rockwell avoided themes that required explanation, once saying that he preferred to paint scenes of everyday life from Vermont: ''This is where I can find America the way I want it.'' As Thomas Hoving points out, it is high time we pay Rockwell his due: ''Rockwell is more and more identified -- correctly -- as a cultural phenomenon, one who made a sea change in the perception of art in this nation.'' Amy Todd

title: The Legacy of a Prodigy Lost in Mystery
description: THE most celebrated black concert artist of the 19th century is virtually unknown today. Although he sustained a career that spanned 50 years and performed for all manner of distinguished critics and adoring crowds, the artist, Thomas Greene Wiggins, known to his fans as Blind Tom, lived a life filled with controversy and with exploitation of Dickensian proportions. His career remains a disturbing mystery. A recent, well-made CD of Blind Tom's compositions by the New York pianist John Davis, including piano solos and dance pieces similar in character to the simpler works of Schumann, Gottschalk and Chopin, has led to a re-examination of Tom's life and legacy.

Writers and artists as varied as Mark Twain, Leonard Bernstein and Thornton Wilder once lived and worked here. Even those less famous have prized this neighborhood for its classic beauty and its privacy. Eleventh Street between Fifth and Sixth Avenue is one of the choicest streets, with brownstones evoking an atmosphere resonant of the last turn of the century.

It leaves me less room for error in catching the train, but the new trains are much more comfortable. The seats feel plush and the lighting is at least 10 times better. This is important because I spend seven to eight hours a week in my ''mobile office.'' With space, my laptop and my cell phone, I can accomplish a lot as I travel to Philadelphia. Green Fund for Clearwater Urban Outreach of the Hudson River Sloop Clearwater, to the New York Civil Liberties Union, or to the New Israel Fund.

title: In the Region/New Jersey; Along Rt. 1 Near Princeton, the Market Is Booming
description: THE office market along the Princeton Route 1 corridor is on a roll: over the last year 800,000 square feet of space in six mostly speculative buildings became available, and all but 100,000 square feet has been leased.

title: MCCAIN AND BUSH FACE CRUCIAL TEST IN TUESDAY VOTING
description: After an extraordinary five-week roller coaster of contests, the Republican presidential contenders head into Tuesday -- the most consequential and climactic primary day of the 2000 campaign -- with Senator John McCain determined, at long last, to crack Gov. George W. Bush's hold on party loyalists.

title: Thinking Out Your Landscaping
description: THE landscape around your home is important because it can enhance the home's appearance, and add as much as 15 percent equity to its value, real estate agents estimate.

title: The Jazz, Not Modern by N.B.A. Standards, Plods On
description: In February 1994, Jeff Hornacek boarded a flight for Salt Lake City to play for his third team in three seasons. Traded from the floundering Philadelphia 76ers to the veteran and, it seemed, utopian Utah Jazz, the shooting guard was invigorated about having a shot to win a National Basketball Association championship.

title: Lockheed Deal To Sell F-16's
description: The Lockheed Martin Corporation, the world's No. 1 military contractor, has signed a contract worth $6.4 billion to sell 80 advanced F-16 fighter jets to the United Arab Emirates, the company announced today from Abu Dhabi, the capital of the United Arab Emirates.

title: Sibling Rivalry at Advance Publications
description: Since taking over as chief executive at Fairchild Publications in December, three months after the company was bought by Advance Publications, Mary Berner has dismissed dozens of staff members, including the entire Fairchild Internet group, and reorganized the company, which publishes Footwear News, Jane magazine and 10 other publications. Perhaps more important, she has already begun to irritate her former colleagues at Conde Nast, which is also owned by Advance.

title: Scholarship Winners Proved Themselves Amid Hardship
description: Sam King was barely 12 when AIDS struck his mother, and he had to become her caretaker. He had already spent a childhood moving from one apartment to another in a small Alabama town, but when his mother died the summer before he was to start high school, Sam had to make yet another move -- to Jamaica, Queens, to live with an aunt whose only income was a monthly government check of $500. He had not yet turned 14.

title: China Is All Bluster on Taiwan (for Now)
description: The furor over China's threat to use force against Taiwan if negotiations toward reunification are indefinitely delayed has put the Clinton administration in a diplomatic jam. In response to the threat, Taiwan is requesting increased American military aid. But the debate has overlooked a fundamental question: Can China successfully attack and occupy Taiwan? China's bluster leaves the impression it can subdue the island if it decides to, but in reality, the situation is quite different.

title: Web Research Transforms Visit to the Doctor
description: Victoria Schlesinger had a puzzling rash on her face, so she visited her doctor to ask what it was. The doctor told her she might have lupus, but declined to elaborate.

title: China's Fierce War on Smuggling Uproots a Vast Hidden Economy
description: From a small storefront in an old section of this neon-laced seaside city, Zheng Jie has an unusual way to quantify the effect of China's current antismuggling campaign: he counts snakes.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  MCCARTHY, JOHN G.
description: McCARTHY-John G. Passed away March 5, at Beaumont, Bryn Mawr, PA, age 90. Loving husband of Lily Lambert McCarthy for 56 years. Devoted father of John Jr. and Ann Zavala, and stepfather of David Fleming, Lily Norton and Peter Fleming. Cherished grandfather of John III, Angela McCarthy, Xavier Zavala and Ana Maria Zavala. Graduated from Williams College, Harvard Business School and Harvard Law School. Served as Lt. Commander in US Naval Reserves in WW II. As President of the Motion Picture Export Association and later the Television Program Export Association, he opened overseas markets in Europe, South America and Australasia for Hollywood feature films and television programs by negotiating removal of trade barriers at the highest levels of foreign governments. Im mid career, President Eisenhower named him US Representative to the Organization for European Economic Cooperation and as US Minister for Economic Affairs at the North Atlantic Treaty Organization in Paris from 1957 to 1960. Memorial contributions may be made to the English Speaking Union Palm Beach Scholarship Fund, PO Box 2945, Palm Beach, FL 33480.

title: CUNY to Seek Bids to Teach Remedial Classes
description: The City University of New York will turn to an outside company to teach basic skills to students least prepared to do college-level work.

description: MELCHNER-Bernard. Beloved husband for 68 years of Lucille. Passed away peacefully March 4. Father of Richard and Susan. Loving grandfather of Leanne Rettig, Jason and Gordon. He will be missed by the family he loved.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  AMES, HERBERT M.
description: AMES-Herbert M. Founder and past President of Pack and Process, Inc. Died on March 4 of prostate cancer. He was 82. Mr. Ames resided in Palm Beach, FL, and Bantam, CT, with his wife of 58 years, Lillian. He was born in the Bronx, NY, and was a graduate of CCNY. By his early 30's, he was responsible for operating five breweries in NYC, consolidating them and then moving and installing the equipment from those breweries internationally. He then started Pack and Process, a contract packaging business in Wilmington, DE, serving major food processors. In his later years he was the Chairman of the Board of the West Point Jewish Chapel, involved in fundraising, constructing and supporting the chapel at the Military Academy. He is survived by his wife Lillian, his daughters Barbara Schwartz of Baldwin Harbor, NY, Janet Scharf of Rockville Centre, NY, his sons Steven Ames of Greenville, DE, his sisters Adrienne Rieger and Elaine Friedberg of Boca Raton, FL, nine grandchildren and one greatgrandchild.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  PHILLIPS, MADELYN S.
description: PHILLIPS-Madelyn S. Madelyn Phillips passed away peacefully and comfortably in her home last Friday, March 3. Born in 1905, raised in Brooklyn, and educated at Cornell and Adelphi. She married Seymour J. Phillips in 1924. She was a helpmate to her beloved husband throughout his business career at Phillips-Van Heusen and his involvement with Beth Israel Medical Center. She hosted an annual party for the graduating class of nurses at her home for many decades. She raised two children, Carol P. Green and Lawrence S. Phillips and shared the thrill of the birth of Carol's three children, Cathy, Douglas and Janet, and Larry's two children, Laura and David. Despite her advanced years, she presided over an annual Passover Seder in her home. Each year the attendees increased as her grandchildren entered the world. Madelyn Phillips is survived by her two children, Carol Green and Larry Phillips, five grandchildren, Cathy, Douglas, Janet, Laura and David, and six great-grandchildren, Michelle and Victoria Starr, Kristine and Matthew Mikkelsen and Joseph and Alexandra Black. Memorial services will be held at a later date. The memory of Madelyn Phillips would be enhanced if contributions would be made to the Nurses' Scholarship Fund of Beth Israel Medical Center, 16th St. and 1st Avenue, New York, NY 10003.

title: Mr. Greenspan's New Economics
description: Chairman Alan Greenspan has gained worldwide acclaim for his cautious stewardship of the Federal Reserve. But in recent testimony before Congress, Mr. Greenspan unveiled some unorthodox ideas. He suggested that a high rate of productivity growth -- something economists usually regard as an unmitigated blessing -- has a nasty downside, actually encouraging inflation. He also suggested that the Fed might need to raise interest rates again to keep stock prices from rising too fast.

title: Making the Rich Richer

Last week I opened the newspaper to find that the House of Representatives has voted unanimously to have the money sent to me anyway. The Senate and the president, it appears, are quite prepared to approve this change. So in the course of this year I shall get government checks for about $20,000. About $8,000 of it will go for federal and state taxes, but I shall still have a net $1,000 extra a month that I never expected to have.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SHERMAN, DONALD
description: SHERMAN-Donald. Age 62. Peacefully passed away on March 3 with his family by his side at his home in North Miami Beach, Florida. For 44 years, he was the beloved husband of Marcia (nee Spirer) of Englewood Cliffs, New Jersey. Loving father of Debra and Filip Tiffenberg and Ronald and Barbara Sherman of Tenafly, New Jersey. Cherished grandfather of Erica and Danielle Sherman and Jodi and Michelle Tiffenberg. Devoted son of Rhoda and the late Michael Sherman of Hackensack, New Jersey. He is sadly missed by his dear brother, Marshall, sistersin-law, Rosemary Sherman and Eva Mullane, and brother-in-law, Lawrence Mullane. After graduating from Lincoln High School in Jersey City, he married his childhood sweetheart and went to work in the family business, the Sherman Paint Store in Jersey City. By the age of 21, he had become a successful real estate developer. In the 1970's, he became involved in the taxicab industry in New York City. During the next twenty years, he built Midtown Operating Corp. into the largest taxi fleet in New York City. For many years, he was a member of the executive board of the Metropolitan Taxicab Board of Trade. He also served on the Board of Directors of the Fort Lee Community Center. He was a generous supporter of numerous charitable and civic organizations but his philanthropic contributions were almost always made anonymously. Because he understood what was truly important in life, he retired ten years ago to devote himself to his family. He gave his love, support, counsel, and assistance to his family, his friends, his colleagues, his employees or anyone who sought it. His concern for others remained undiminished even during his quiet and courageous battle against cancer. His generosity of spirit will be his legacy to all who knew him. Memorial contributions may be made to: Memorial Sloan-Kettering Cancer Center, NY, NY 10021.

title: Those G.O.P. Attack Ads

title: Voters, Read the Ballot Carefully
description: For all the excitement about how New Yorkers finally have a chance to help pick this year's presidential nominees, the act of voting in today's primary may prove confusing to many citizens. The names in big print on the Republican ballot will be candidates to be delegates to the party's national convention. Voters will have to look hard to see that tucked under each delegate's name is the name of the presidential candidate he or she is pledged to support at this summer's nominating convention. To know whether they are voting for Gov. George W. Bush or Senator John McCain, New Yorkers who are voting Republican, like anybody else worried about being sold a bill of goods, will have to read the fine print.

title: COMVERSE TO BUY LORONIX FOR $232 MILLION IN STOCK
description: Comverse Technology Inc., the largest seller of messaging systems to phone companies, agreed yesterday to buy the digital-video equipment maker Loronix Information Systems Inc. for about $232.6 million in stock. Comverse, based in Woodbury, N.Y., said it would pay 0.1925 share, or $45.36, for each share of Loronix. Comverse said it would take a charge of less than $15 million for the transaction. Comverse has about 60 percent of the $800 million cellular voice-mail market. The company will issue about 987,000 new shares to purchase Loronix, which is based in Durango, Colo. The shares of Loronix jumped $9.625 each, to $41, in Nasdaq trading. Comverse rose $8.125 a share, to $235.625.

It has plans for a 1,000-room seaside hotel, a 45-hole golf course and a ski slope. And it has done all this with the approval of North Korea's reclusive Communist leaders.

title: G.M. LOOKS TO INCREASE NUMBER OF SHARES IN HUGHES
description: The General Motors Corporation, the world's No. 1 automaker, said yesterday that it would ask shareholders in June to increase sixfold the number of G.M. G.M. shareholders will be asked to approve the increase to 3.6 billion Class H shares. G.M. directors said they expected to split the stock shortly after the meeting, at a rate to be announced at that time. Hughes runs the DirecTV satellite-television service. G.M. said last month that it would cut its Hughes financial stake by almost half to $18 billion, bowing to shareholder demands to make the unit's stock more widely held and increase the value.

description: XIE-Xide. We will miss our beloved Madame Xie or ''Hilda'' as she was known to many of her friends. She passed away Saturday night in Shanghai, China at the age of 79. Madame Xie was President of Fudan University in Shanghai. She graduated from Smith College, received her Ph.D. in physics at MIT and a mathematics degree from Xiamen University in China. Madame Xie was a dear friend and mentor and we wish to convey our deepest condolences to her son, Cao Weizheng, her daughter-in-law, Ker, and her granddaughter on whom she doted, Karen. Madame Xie taught us the meaning of selflessness. Our sincerest condolences to her friends in China and her friends all over the world. Ginny Kamsky and Kamsky Associates, Inc.

title: Protection for the Wetlands
description: Two successive presidents, George Bush and Bill Clinton, have promised to stop the steady erosion of the nation's wetlands -- the 100 million or so acres of swamps, marshes and fens that help prevent floods, filter harmful pollutants, provide habitat for endangered species and nourish tiny organisms essential to the food chain. They have succeeded in beating back the big threats, including efforts by former Vice President Dan Quayle and, later, the Contract With America Republicans to transfer millions of these valuable acres to private interests almost overnight. But they have been less successful in persuading the Army Corps of Engineers, which actually regulates wetlands, to take a harder line on developers and others who covet wetlands for commercial purposes.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  MACKLER, DR. ALFRED.
description: MACKLER-Dr. Alfred. Bar-Ilan University in Israel and its American Friends mourn with deepest sorrow the passing of one of its most beloved and distinguished leaders, Dr. (honoris causa) Alfred Mackler, and extends profound condolences to his beloved wife, Helen, their children and grandchildren, & to his surviving sister, Charlotte. A prominent member of the Bar-Ilan Global Board of Trustees, Alfred Mackler personified the greatest ideals of leadership & commitment to the Jewish people. He served with distinction for several decades as Secretary and Treasurer of the American Board of Trustees, and as the accountant and national administrator for Bar-Ilan's U.S. operation. In recognition of his vital contributions to the University's growth and development, he was awarded an honorary doctorate degree from Bar-Ilan. A man of singular integrity and tact, his involvement in every aspect of university activity established a standard of excellence for others to follow. Through the Joseph Alexander Foundation, the Macklers are major Bar-Ilan university benefactors who have made possible the establishment of the Joseph Alexander Memorial Library in the Department of Social Sciences, the expansion of the Maria Finkle and Ruth Rackman Student Couseling Center, and many other vital projects. We extend heartfelt condolences to the Alexander Foundation Trustees-his wife, Helen, his son, Harvey, Bob Weintraub, and Arthur Alfert. A consummate gentleman and an individual of impeccable personal character, he was loved and respected by faculty, students, lay leaders and staff alike. His interpersonal relationships exemplified, as he did in his home, the beautiful family values he cherished-values shared by Helen. Despite his illness for many years, and illness in his family, he did not falter, performing his duties with characteristic diligence as a hero worthy of emulation by those whom God tries. His pivotal leadership contributions to BarIlan University and the Jewish people make him irreplaceable, and his record of service to BarIlan University has formed a most impressive chapter in the annals of our University. May the entire family be comforted by inspiring memories and among all the mourners of Zion and Jerusalem Rabbi Emanuel Rackman, Chancellor, Bar-Ilan University Prof. Moshe Kaveh, President, Bar-Ilan University Mr. Aharon Dahan, Chairman, Global Board of Trustees Mr. Charles Dimston, Chairman, American Board of Trustees Mr. Melvin Stein, President, American Friends Brig. Gen. (Ret.) Yehuda Halevy Executive Vice President Bar-Ilan University
