title: Paid Notice: Deaths  LOCALIO, S. ARTHUR, MD.
description: LOCALIO-S. Arthur, MD. Age 88. Of Deerfield, MA. Died March 4, 2000. Born in NYC. He was the son of Joseph and Carmella Localio. Dr. Localio graduated from Cornell University and the University of Rochester School of Medicine. In 1942 he received a Doctor of Medical Science degree from Columbia University. Dr. Localio spent his entire professional life in NYC where he was professor of surgery at the New York University School of Medicine. He was a member of the American Surgical Association, The Royal Society Medicine, and the New York Academy of Science. In 1972 he was named the Johnson and Johnson Distinguished Professor of Surgery. He was a major in the US Army Medical Corps. for four years in WW II serving with the Seventh Evacuation Hospital in the South Pacific. He was honored on his retirement by the establishment of a professorship and a research laboratory in his name at New York University. Dr. Localio served for ten years as Trustee of Deerfield Academy where he established an endowment for the purchase of books in the field of Art. He leaves his wife, Ruth (Adkins), a daughter, Susan of Dolores, Colo., and three sons, William of Mansfield, Conn., Russell of Media, PA., and David of Los Angeles. He also leaves four grandchildren, four sisters and several nieces and nephews. A memorial service will be held at The Second Congregational Church of Greenfield, Mass. on Wednesday, March 8 at 2 PM. In lieu of flowers, contributions may be sent to The Deerfield Rescue Squad, 84 Greenfield Road, South Deerfield, Mass. 01373 or to the S. Arthur Localio Professorship Fund, C/O Kenneth Eng, MD, 550 First Avenue, NY, NY 10016.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SHERMAN, DONALD
description: SHERMAN-Donald. Age 62. Peacefully passed away on March 3 with his family by his side at his home in North Miami Beach, Florida. For 44 years, he was the beloved husband of Marcia (nee Spirer) of Englewood Cliffs, New Jersey. Loving father of Debra and Filip Tiffenberg and Ronald and Barbara Sherman of Tenafly, New Jersey. Cherished grandfather of Erica and Danielle Sherman and Jodi and Michelle Tiffenberg. Devoted son of Rhoda and the late Michael Sherman of Hackensack, New Jersey. He is sadly missed by his dear brother, Marshall, sistersin-law, Rosemary Sherman and Eva Mullane, and brother-in-law, Lawrence Mullane. After graduating from Lincoln High School in Jersey City, he married his childhood sweetheart and went to work in the family business, the Sherman Paint Store in Jersey City. By the age of 21, he had become a successful real estate developer. In the 1970's, he became involved in the taxicab industry in New York City. During the next twenty years, he built Midtown Operating Corp. into the largest taxi fleet in New York City. For many years, he was a member of the executive board of the Metropolitan Taxicab Board of Trade. He also served on the Board of Directors of the Fort Lee Community Center. He was a generous supporter of numerous charitable and civic organizations but his philanthropic contributions were almost always made anonymously. Because he understood what was truly important in life, he retired ten years ago to devote himself to his family. He gave his love, support, counsel, and assistance to his family, his friends, his colleagues, his employees or anyone who sought it. His concern for others remained undiminished even during his quiet and courageous battle against cancer. His generosity of spirit will be his legacy to all who knew him. Memorial contributions may be made to: Memorial Sloan-Kettering Cancer Center, NY, NY 10021.

The Boise, Idaho, company wants to buy the minority stake to increase its distribution business. Shares of Boise Cascade Office Products were up 37.5 cents, to $15.25.

title: Novelists' Friendship Distilled Into Prose
description: It was like a scene out of a Graham Greene novel. On a rain-swept December morning in the late 1960's, the novelist Shirley Hazzard was sitting by herself at a table in a cafe on Capri. While working on a crossword puzzle, she overheard a conversation at the next table. A man she recognized as Greene was quoting the Robert Browning poem ''The Lost Mistress'' to a friend. He reached the penultimate line, ''I will hold your hand but as long as all may . . .'' and was unable to remember the end of the poem. After Ms. Hazzard had finished her coffee and the puzzle, had paid her bill and put on her raincoat, she said, as if passing on a coded message, ''The line is 'Or so very little longer.' '' Without waiting for a response, she walked out of the cafe.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SNOW, RICHARD B.
description: SNOW-Richard B. A NYC architect whose career span six decades died February 21, 2000 at the home of his stepdaughter. He was 94. Born in California, he graduated from Columbia College, and from the Columbia School of Architecture in 1931. In 1939 he recruited the architects Edward Stone and Morris Ketchum to work with him on a competition sponsored by the New York World's Fair. Their entry won, and Mr. Snow was commissioned to design a monumental emblem for the Focal Food Pavillon (the result, four 100 foot high steel wheatstalks, also later spent a quarter century in front of Steeple Chase Amusement Park in Coney Island). In 1942, Mr. Snow entered the Navy as a Lieutenant. He served in the Atlantic aboard a destroyer escort and took part in the action that sank the U-546. At war's end, he joined the staff of O'Connor and Kilham, working mainly on university and public buildings, among them the Barnard College library and the Firestone Library in Princeton. Mr. Snow married Emma Folger of Bronxville, N.Y. and after her death in 1976, married Martha Love McCagg, an architecture school classmate. He is survived by his son, Richard, the editor of ''American Heritage'' Magazine, his step-children Dr. Caroline McCagg-Kelly of Plainfield, N.J. and Edward McCagg of Seattle, WA., and two grandchildren.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  LOCALIO, S. ARTHUR, MD.
description: LOCALIO-S. Arthur, MD. Age 88. Of Deerfield, MA. Died March 4, 2000. Born in NYC. He was the son of Joseph and Carmella Localio. Dr. Localio graduated from Cornell University and the University of Rochester School of Medicine. In 1942 he received a Doctor of Medical Science degree from Columbia University. Dr. Localio spent his entire professional life in NYC where he was professor of surgery at the New York University School of Medicine. He was a member of the American Surgical Association, The Royal Society Medicine, and the New York Academy of Science. In 1972 he was named the Johnson and Johnson Distinguished Professor of Surgery. He was a major in the US Army Medical Corps. for four years in WW II serving with the Seventh Evacuation Hospital in the South Pacific. He was honored on his retirement by the establishment of a professorship and a research laboratory in his name at New York University. Dr. Localio served for ten years as Trustee of Deerfield Academy where he established an endowment for the purchase of books in the field of Art. He leaves his wife, Ruth (Adkins), a daughter, Susan of Dolores, Colo., and three sons, William of Mansfield, Conn., Russell of Media, PA., and David of Los Angeles. He also leaves four grandchildren, four sisters and several nieces and nephews. A memorial service will be held at The Second Congregational Church of Greenfield, Mass. on Wednesday, March 8 at 2 PM. In lieu of flowers, contributions may be sent to The Deerfield Rescue Squad, 84 Greenfield Road, South Deerfield, Mass. 01373 or to the S. Arthur Localio Professorship Fund, C/O Kenneth Eng, MD, 550 First Avenue, NY, NY 10016.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SAMMONS, ROBERT LEE.
description: SAMMONS-Robert Lee. Died peacefully on January 20, 2000, age 74, after a long illness. Survived by his sister, Lucille Schelich of Celina, OH, nephews Robert and Tom Schelich and niece Jackie Colburn. A resident of Manhattan for over fifty years, Bob was best known for his uncanny sense of humor and his love of music and the written word, the theater and the arts, and for travel. He was Travel Editor of Town and Country Magazine in the '60's and early '70's and later Senior Travel Editor for East/West Network. He was an active member of the New York Travel Writers Association, of which he served as President, and of the Society of American Travel Writers. A 1949 graduate of Ohio State Univ., he was a member of the U.S. Air Force from 1943-45 and flew 34 combat missions as a tail gunner and was honorably discharged as Staff Sergeant. Bob's family and friends will celebrate his life at a gathering in Manhattan in late spring/summer. Contributions in his name to the Central Park Conservancy are appreciated.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SHERMAN, DONALD
description: SHERMAN-Donald. Age 62. Peacefully passed away on March 3 with his family by his side at his home in North Miami Beach, Florida. For 44 years, he was the beloved husband of Marcia (nee Spirer) of Englewood Cliffs, New Jersey. Loving father of Debra and Filip Tiffenberg and Ronald and Barbara Sherman of Tenafly, New Jersey. Cherished grandfather of Erica and Danielle Sherman and Jodi and Michelle Tiffenberg. Devoted son of Rhoda and the late Michael Sherman of Hackensack, New Jersey. He is sadly missed by his dear brother, Marshall, sistersin-law, Rosemary Sherman and Eva Mullane, and brother-in-law, Lawrence Mullane. After graduating from Lincoln High School in Jersey City, he married his childhood sweetheart and went to work in the family business, the Sherman Paint Store in Jersey City. By the age of 21, he had become a successful real estate developer. In the 1970's, he became involved in the taxicab industry in New York City. During the next twenty years, he built Midtown Operating Corp. into the largest taxi fleet in New York City. For many years, he was a member of the executive board of the Metropolitan Taxicab Board of Trade. He also served on the Board of Directors of the Fort Lee Community Center. He was a generous supporter of numerous charitable and civic organizations but his philanthropic contributions were almost always made anonymously. Because he understood what was truly important in life, he retired ten years ago to devote himself to his family. He gave his love, support, counsel, and assistance to his family, his friends, his colleagues, his employees or anyone who sought it. His concern for others remained undiminished even during his quiet and courageous battle against cancer. His generosity of spirit will be his legacy to all who knew him. Memorial contributions may be made to: Memorial Sloan-Kettering Cancer Center, NY, NY 10021.

description: CRUDE OIL FALLS. Crude oil plunged more than 8 percent after Iran and Saudi Arabia signaled that OPEC would produce more oil. In New York, crude oil for April delivery fell $2.87, or 8.4 percent, to $31.26 a barrel.

title: Three at ABC Get New Positions In Revamping of News Division
description: ABC realigned the management of its news division yesterday giving three executives new duties under the division's president, David Westin.

title: Bush Needs McCain Backers, but Winning Their Votes Won't Be Easy
description: Gov. George W. Bush of Texas has a mighty mountain to climb if he is to persuade supporters of his vanquished rival, Senator John McCain of Arizona, to back him in November against Vice President Al Gore.

title: Officer and 2 Firefighters Die in Ambush at Memphis House
description: Two firefighters and a sheriff's deputy were shot to death today, ambushed as they arrived at a burning house where the body of a woman, apparently the wife of the suspected gunman, was later found inside.

title: A Victory Gives Seton Hall a Reason to Believe
description: In the 21-year history of Big East basketball, no team with at least 20 victories after the conference tournament has failed to be selected for the National Collegiate Athletic Association tournament. Yet Seton Hall, despite its 19-8 record, was thought to be uncertain of receiving an N.C.A.A. bid as the Big East tournament started.

title: Using 40's Wood. 1540's, That Is.
description: BUYING an old English barn seemed like a good idea at the time. Richard and Stephanie Stern wanted to add a great room onto their too-small summer cottage in the Berkshires. They had met an architect through friends, who showed them homes he had designed using dismantled and reassembled 16th-century barns hauled across the Atlantic from England.

title: Jumping Straight Into a Slam and Making It
description: Thousands of enthusiasts converge on Cincinnati today for the 10 days of the American Contract Bridge League's Spring National Championships, but fewer than 50 of them have serious hopes of carrying off the big prize. The Vanderbilt Knockout Teams begins Sunday and continues for a week, with a group headed by George Jacobs of Chicago defending the title it won in Vancouver a year ago.

title: Executive Names Her Own Price and Style
description: AT the news last month that Heidi G. Miller was leaving her dizzying perch at the world's largest financial services company for an Internet gamble that has yet to turn a profit, murmurs of dismay were heard among women at her old workplace, while the stock at her new one rose a gleeful 9.4 percent.

title: Hearkening To Africa
description: THERE'S a new furniture designer on the block, and a new block on which to buy furniture. The Bench is Linda Lindsay's first design in a new collection, called Ethnic Essence. ''I am trying to combine American design with African design,'' Ms. Lindsay said.

title: Biden Joins G.O.P. in Call for Delay in Missile-Defense Plan
description: Adding weight to a growing bipartisan movement, a senior Democratic senator has warned President Clinton that he should leave the decision on deploying a national missile-defense system to the next administration.

title: NEWS SUMMARY
description: INTERNATIONAL A3-11

title: Clinton Sends to a Wary Congress A Long-Delayed China Trade Bill
description: President Clinton today sent Congress his bill to usher China into the World Trade Organization. He then opened a new front in the debate on the subject in his own party, arguing that opening China's markets will undermine Communist Party control.

title: Militia Leader Acquitted of Plotting to Kidnap Boy
description: Bo Gritz, the former Green Beret commando and a leader of the far-right militia movement, was acquitted yesterday of charges that he tried to kidnap a young boy from the parking lot of a middle school in Suffield, Conn., in September 1996.

title: Money Management Company Acquires a 6% Stake in Aetna
description: Southeastern Asset Management Inc., a money management company based in Memphis, said yesterday that it had acquired a 6 percent stake in Aetna Inc. for $444 million.

title: More on Martha
description: To the Editor:

title: Basketball Player's Foul Draws a Jail Term
description: Just over a year ago, 18-year-old Tony Limon was a proud senior starter for the Bobcats, the South San Antonio High School basketball team, and weighing the offer of a college basketball scholarship.

title: The Surging Nets Find a Couple of Reasons to Smile
description: Today was the type of day that has often seemed reserved for professional basketball franchises outside New Jersey. It was a day when everything from doctors' reports to jump shots fell favorably for the Nets.

title: Afghanistan's Girls Fight to Read and Write
description: Her name is Fatima, and she was risking a beating. Defiantly, she stood outside, talking to a man. Her face was uncovered.

title: GARDEN Q.&A.
description: A Hungry Eye for Cardoons

title: I.M.F. and World Bank Blueprint
description: More than half a century after their creation, the International Monetary Fund and the World Bank could use some fresh thinking about their operations. Thanks to a Congressional commission that unveiled its recommendations about the institutions yesterday, there are some bold new ideas to consider. Some of the suggestions are ill conceived, but others deserve serious consideration by the United States and other nations that belong to the two organizations.

title: Signs Point to New 'Sensation' at the Whitney
description: The Whitney Museum of American Art's Biennial is an exhibition of new and often cutting-edge American art.

title: Gatti's Manager and Promoter Say He Made His Weight
description: The manager and the promoter for Arturo Gatti both said yesterday that the boxer was not over the prescribed weight of 141 pounds on the day that he weighed in for his Feb. 26 junior welterweight bout against Joey Gamache at Madison Square Garden. They also question the accuracy of the scales that Home Box Office used to weigh Gatti on the night of the fight that showed he weighed 160 pounds.

title: Teams Are Not Smiling At Locker Room Cameras
description: When the National Basketball Association began an experiment nearly two months ago of having coaches wear miniature microphones during nationally televised games, the idea was to give fans a perspective seldom seen in professional sports. The hope for the N.B.A. and its broadcast partners, NBC and Turner Sports, was to increase sagging ratings by using a fan-friendly device.

title: City to Pay 3 Men Shot by Officers
description: The city agreed yesterday to pay almost $2 million to settle a police brutality lawsuit stemming from the 1997 shooting of three men in Harlem by plainclothes narcotics officers.

title: EMPLOYMENT SERVICE ACCEPTS A MANAGEMENT-LED BUYOUT
description: Westaff Inc., a provider of temporary staffing services, agreed yesterday to be acquired by members of its management and an investor group led by the buyout specialists Cornerstone Equity Investors IV L.P. and Centre Partners Management L.L.C. for $160 million plus assumption of debt. Cornerstone and Centre Partners will acquire all outstanding shares of Westaff for $10 a share in cash. The shares rose 81.25 cents yesterday, to $8.8125. Westaff is based in Walnut Creek, Calif.

title: Top Tax Expert Calls for Tougher Penalties to Deter Corporate Cheating
description: The tough penalties Congress enacted to discourage abusive corporate tax shelters are so riddled with loopholes that they fail to deter tax cheating by large companies, Congress's top tax expert told the Senate Finance Committee today.

title: PlayStation 2: Catching Next Wave From Japan
description: The new Sony PlayStation 2 game console, introduced last week in Japan, has already sold more than a million units there and is expected to be equally popular when it reaches the United States this fall, despite a list price of nearly $400.

title: The New York Times: Technology - Circuits
description: March 9, 2000 Stuart Goldenberg

title: Paid Notice: Memorials  LOWENSTEIN, BOB
description: LOWENSTEIN-Bob. 1945-1995. We wanted to share the Millennium with you - memories aren't good enough. Love, Dad and Han

title: Lawsuits Threatened Over Arsenic Levels in New Jersey Water
description: As many as 700,000 New Jersey residents are drinking water that is contaminated with dangerously high levels of arsenic, according to a coalition of environmentalists that is trying to force the state to tighten acceptable levels of the substance, a known carcinogen.

title: Duff & Phelps Acquired
description: The ratings agency Fitch IBCA said this week that it had agreed to acquire the Duff & Phelps Credit Rating Company for $528 million in cash. The deal will give Fitch a stronger position as bond issuance spreads throughout Europe. Fitch is a unit of the holding company Fimalac S.A.

title: Paid Notice: Memorials  RUTLEDGE, ELIZABETH
description: RUTLEDGE-Elizabeth. A memorial service celebrating the life of Beth Rutledge will be held at 11:00 AM, Friday, March 10 at The Church of St. John the Evangelist, 55 St., between 1st and 2nd Aves., in NY City. All Beth's friends and colleagues are welcome. Contributions in Beth's memory can be made to ''The Friends of Beth Rutledge Memorial Fund'', c/o Tides Foundation, PO Box 29903, San Francisco, CA 94129.

title: Metro Matters; Voter's Guide Should Begin: 'Be Patient'
description: I went not to vote on Tuesday. No, that was not a typo. I went to my polling place to make sure I could not vote. Turned out I could. Something was wrong.

title: In America; A Delicate Balance
description: Hillary Rodham Clinton uses the term ''the trust divide'' when she talks about the suspicion and hostility that have created such a devastating gap between the law-abiding residents of some big-city neighborhoods and the police officers who are supposed to protect and serve them.

title: Genome Decoding Plan Is Derailed by Conflicts
description: With the race to decode the human genome nearing completion and the stocks of genome companies soaring, a last-minute merger negotiation between the public and private competitors has foundered in a clash of principles and egos. In an exchange of letters over the last week and a half, each side sought to blame the other for the breakdown and for failing to negotiate in good faith.

title: THE MARKETS: Market Place; All Tech All the Time Tells Only One Side of the Story
description: Is it still a bull market if it is running on only one leg?

title: DEVELOPER OF 'VIRTUAL TOURS' BUYS NET IMAGING COMPANY
description: The Internet Pictures Corporation agreed yesterday to acquire PictureWorks Technology Inc., whose products allow still photos and other media content to be published on the World Wide Web. The all-stock transaction was valued at about $175 million. Internet Pictures is best known for its IPIX technology, which provides 360-degree virtual tours of everything from real estate properties to landscapes. The company, based in Oak Ridge, Tenn., will issue 4.7 million to 6.2 million shares to acquire privately held PictureWorks, depending on the average price of its stock. Internet Pictures stock was up $2.1875 a share at $31.875 on the Nasdaq. PictureWorks, based in Palo Alto, Calif., markets Internet imaging technologies.

title: Islanders Pay For Lapointe
description: Claude Lapointe, the Islanders forward who was on the verge of a trade or unrestricted free agency, got just what he wanted yesterday: a three-year, $3.6 million contract extension.

title: India Isn't Happy at Clinton's Changed Itinerary, but Pakistan Is
description: Indian officials reacted today with understated disgruntlement to President Clinton's decision to call briefly on their adversary, Pakistan, after a five-day tour of India this month. Pakistani officials were happy and relieved.

title: African Trade Bill Hurts U.S. Workers
description: To the Editor:

title: CURRENTS; ABC CARPET
description: With its romantic domestic vignettes of antiques and reproductions, ABC Carpet & Home is to the average home furnishings store what salmon mousse is to tuna salad. And that comparison certainly extends to its flower shop. Using a wide range of botanicals and unusual containers, the designers Catherine Guialdo and Triana Sinclair create romantic vignettes of their own -- like the 18th-century Japanese teapot, left, brimming with ranunculus, sweet peas, andromeda, poppies and narcissus ($240; $195 for the pot). ABC Carpet & Home, 888 Broadway (18th Street); (212) 505-6655.

title: Corrections
description: An article in Science Times on Tuesday about herbal remedies misstated the location of the University of Erlangen, the institution of Dr. Felix Stickel, who said the herb comfrey can cause liver failure. The university is in Erlangen, Germany, not Heidelberg.

title: BELGIAN CORPORATION AGREES TO PURCHASE DICTAPHONE
description: Lernout & Hauspie Speech Products N.V. of Belgium agreed yesterday to buy the Dictaphone Corporation, maker of the hand-held recorders used by thousands of doctors, for about $510 million in stock. It will also assume about $425 million in debt. The company, controlled by Stonington Partners, a New York private investment fund, had been considering an initial public offering. Lernout & Hauspie intends to sell shares in a unit combining Dictaphone's health care products with its own medical software and services. Dictaphone, based in Stratford, Conn., has made a rapid transition from analog recorders to digital dictation machines.

title: In the Small Print Are Clues To Bush's Delegate Numbers
description: A day after their most tumultuous primary in memory, it was clear yesterday that New York Republicans' convoluted way of awarding presidential delegates helped George W. Bush -- and equally clear that even Bush supporters found that system wanting.

title: West's Primaries Are Denied Spotlight
description: The effort began three years ago as a way to give the West a little influence in the presidential selection process. Gov. Michael O. Leavitt of Utah led a vigorous bipartisan campaign to create a Western primary day for the eight states just this side of California.

title: Led by Staten Island, New York City Grew in 1999, Census Reports
description: Continuing a trend that has surprised demographers, New York City's population grew again last year, with Staten Island adding people more rapidly than some of the fastest-growing counties in suburban New Jersey, Connecticut and Long Island, according to census data released yesterday.

title: Clinton's Words on China: Trade Is the Smart Thing
description: Following are excerpts from President Clinton's speech today at the Paul H. Nitze School of Advanced International Studies of the Johns Hopkins University, as recorded by the Federal News Service, a transcription company:

title: INSIDE
description: Disciplinarian From Moscow

title: Boston Tunnel Project to Dig Deeper Into State's Pockets
description: Grilled until their ears glowed pink, the top overseers of Boston's Big Dig tried to explain to Massachusetts lawmakers today how the project, the largest public works endeavor under way in the country, came to be $1.4 billion over budget, and why they did not disclose the overrun earlier.

title: National News Briefs; Teenager Is Charged In Attack on Web Site
description: A New Hampshire teenager was arrested yesterday on state charges that he vandalized the Web site of the antidrug organization D.A.R.E.

title: Mother Nature Would Be Agog
description: Just before the Philadelphia Flower Show opened on Sunday under the banner ''Gardens for the New Millennium,'' Edward L. Lindemann, its director, felt like a chef who had planned an impossibly ambitious menu and was suddenly hearing the guests at the door.

title: THE MARKETS: CURRENCIES
description: THE YEN DROPS. The yen fell after Japan sold its currency for the second time this year, a day after it rose to a record against the euro. In New York, the dollar settled at 107.04 yen, up from 106.16 on Tuesday.

title: Shostakovich, The Mehta Assessment
description: To a city suddenly awash in Shostakovich -- with the Emerson String Quartet's having just finished a cycle of the 15 quartets and a theatrical capper, ''The Noise of Time,'' and the Metropolitan Opera tonight beginning a run of ''Lady Macbeth of the Mtsensk District'' -- Zubin Mehta and the Israel Philharmonic Orchestra added a little more on Tuesday at Avery Fisher Hall.

description: Manhattan

description: For Demanding Devices, Try Powering Up That Bus

title: Director Named For Newark Development
description: James A. Schmidt, a former top official of the New York City Economic Development Corporation and the man who oversaw the creation of the Rose Center for Earth and Space Project at the American Museum of Natural History, has been named the executive director of the New Newark Foundation, a private group that is seeking to redevelop part of the city's downtown.

title: IBM, i2, Ariba Form Alliance
description: March 8, 2000

title: INVESTMENT GROUP TO BUY MAJORITY STAKE IN RIGHTWORKS
description: Internet Capital Group Inc. said yesterday that it had agreed to acquire a majority stake in the privately held software developer RightWorks for $657 million in stock and cash to get a piece of the growing online business-to-business market. RightWorks of San Jose, Calif., makes software that automates the ordering of supplies over the Internet. Internet Capital agreed to pay $635 million in stock and $22 million in cash; the Wayne, Pa., company invests in and helps operate Internet companies. It had $16.5 million in revenue in 1999.

title: Partisan Fighting Flares Anew Over Handling of the Census
description: After weeks of peace and cooperation, the partisan wars over the 2000 Census have erupted again.

title: China's Sniping Heeded By Some Taiwan Voters
description: With Taiwan's presidential election only 10 days away, China has uncorked its vitriol on the Democratic Progressive Party candidate, Chen Shui-bian, calling him a separatist and a silver-tongued liar. To hear Mr. Chen tell it, Beijing is doing him a favor.

title: CURRENTS; BLOOM
description: Lesly Zamor's designs at Bloom, which opened in 1996, follow the European approach of juxtaposing flowers with fruits and vegetables. This means hitting both flower and produce wholesalers at dawn to find the most perfect flowers, as well as the most visually appealing produce.

title: Panel Urges More College Assistance for Poor
description: New York State should sharply expand its financial aid to college students and continue to concentrate on low-income families rather than the middle class, a panel of prominent educators and former government officials appointed by the State Senate to study financial aid said yesterday.

title: 845 Years in Prison, If the Authorities Can Catch Him; F.B.I. Says Fugitive Has a Flair For Fraud and Hiding Stolen Cash
description: In the pantheon of white-collar criminals, Sholam Weiss, a rumpled businessman from New York, has earned his place among the giants.

title: INDUSTRY WEB SITE OPERATOR TO ACQUIRE SOFTWARE MAKER
description: The Web site operator VerticalNet Inc. agreed yesterday to acquire the privately held Internet software company Tradeum Inc. for $475 million in stock. Tradeum makes software used to develop online catalogs and Web sites that match business buyers and sellers. VerticalNet, based in Horsham, Pa., operates industry Web sites where companies can get industry information and exchange products. VerticalNet had $20.8 million in revenue in 1999 and has a current market capitalization of $8.6 billion. The company said Tradeum will keep its San Francisco headquarters. VerticalNet's shares rose $16 each yesterday, to $253.50, in Nasdaq trading.

title: There's Little to Say In Knicks' Defense
description: Once all the awkward introductions and internal dysfunction were peeled away last season, the Knicks discovered they were defiant, intense and an act hotter on the road than a rock-'n'-roll band.

title: Favored High Yield Gets the Speed Post
description: High Yield drew the inside speed lane at Gulfstream Park today and was made the 8-5 favorite among 10 colts entered in the Florida Derby. And his rider, Pat Day, was prompted to visualize a plot along these lines: ''He has tactical speed, but I don't think he needs to be in front. Still, you never know how they'll handle that extra eighth of a mile until you push the button.''

title: Nature's Designs Unfurl on the Wall
description: WALLPAPER designers have again taken inspiration from nature. What's new is that modern printing techniques allow wallpapers to mimic woven palm fronds, primitive tapa cloths and stone mosaics.

title: Stop, Thief! You've Got Mail
description: THE race to build the ultimate wired home is on. Near Seattle, Bill Gates has his digital dream palace. Across the country, cable providers and phone companies are pushing broadband Internet access for the rest of us. In Europe, the appliance manufacturer Electrolux is even working on a way to put the family refrigerator online.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  BRADY, MONSIGNOR, DANIEL J.
description: BRADY-Monsignor, Daniel J. Died Wednesday March 8, 2000 at the age of 83 years. He is survived by his sisters Mary Brady and Alice Fath. Funeral Mass Saturday 9:30AM at St. Patrick's Roman Catholic Church, Armonk, NY. Interment Calvary Cemetery, Queens, NY. Friends may call Friday, 4-9PM, at the Ballard-Durand Funeral Home, 2 Maple Avenue, White Plains, NY. In lieu of flowers contributions to Rosary Hill Home, 600 Linda Avenue, Hawthorne, NY 10532, would be appreciated.

title: Airplane Flight Recorders: The Boxes That Live to Tell the Tale
description: BEFORE the mid-1950's, commercial passenger aircraft looked much like the one that parted Ingrid Bergman and Humphrey Bogart at the end of Casablanca -- they had propellers on each wing, and they flew at what we would now consider a leisurely pace. It was not until the British company de Havilland leveraged wartime research on jet propulsion into a commercial jet airliner called the Comet that rapid air transport became feasible.

title: Laundry Room Fire Injures 9 at Seton Hall, Where 3 Died in a Dormitory Blaze
description: A small fire in a clothes dryer in Seton Hall University's athletic center caused minor injuries to nine students and workers here Tuesday evening, less than two months after a fatal fire and just a week after state officials cited the university for hundreds of fire-code violations.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  ELKIN, ROSALIND
description: ELKIN-Rosalind. On March 6, 2000. Died suddenly at home. She was a social worker for many years for the City of New York and later with private social welfare agencies, including most recently Stanton House. She was loved and respected by all who knew her and a joy to those whose lives she touched. She will be deeply missed. Survived by brother, Robert Elkin. Graveside service Sunday, 1:30 PM, at Beth Moses Cemetery, Pinelawn, LI. For further information please call ''The Riverside'' 212-362-6600.

title: A Dizzying Dinner With Hemingway's Ghost
description: It's so odd these days to confront an unmitigated reverence for Ernest Hemingway -- the man! the myth! -- that to do so is to be cheered by an uncomplicated sentimentality. Back in 1961, the year of his suicide -- before the decade or so of his waning literary powers became his lingering image, before feminist appraisal of his work excoriated his pompous sexist bias -- he was just an American hero, our Nobel-winning poet of macho, bard of appetites.

title: The Bad News Braves: Smoltz Out for the Year
description: Only the season will determine which part of the anatomy will have a greater effect on the Atlanta Braves' attempt to win their ninth consecutive division championship -- John Rocker's mouth or John Smoltz's right elbow. The Braves could have done without both.

title: Rely on Social Security?
description: To the Editor:

title: Getting More Than You Bargained For
description: So beguiling is its songfulness that ''Porgy and Bess'' can conceal how complicated it really is. George Gershwin called his piece a ''a folk opera.'' The words might apply to Carlisle Floyd's ''Susannah'' or the Douglas Moore ''Ballad of Baby Doe'' -- both compact, simple in outline and beholden to the larger musical impulses that shaped them.

title: Sports Authority Picks Two Agencies
description: The Sports Authority in Fort Lauderdale, Fla., a sporting goods retail chain, has divided its account, with billings estimated at $30 million, between two agencies: West Wayne in Tampa, Fla., for creative duties, and Horizon Media in New York, for media duties.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SINGER, ELEANOR
description: SINGER-Eleanor age 79 of Delray Beach, FL. Wife of the late Earl Singer, mother of Susan Schwartz and Nancy Berman (David). Predeceased by son Kenneth. Beloved grandmother of Alicia, Pamela, Matthew and Elizabeth. Services are Friday, March 10th. For information Robert Schoem's Menorah Chapel, W-150 Rt. #

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  HUTCHESON, ROSEMARY DODGE
description: HUTCHESON-Rosemary Dodge of Bronxville, NY on March 7, 2000. Mother of Rand Hutcheson. Grandmother of Sarah Hutcheson and Ian Hutcheson. Sister of Yvonne Dodge Emery of Casper, Wyoming. Many nieces and nephews survive. Memorial service at the Reform Church of Bronxville on Sunday, March 12, at 2pm. In lieu of flowers, contributions may be made to the Reform Church of Bronxville or Jansen Hospice.

title: CURRENTS; MICHAEL GEORGE
description: Long recognized as a top name in the floral design business, Michael George is still in the vanguard of flower design. He describes his work as very architectural, and he likes to use a single variety of stiff-stemmed blooms, which he masses together and twists into a sculptural arrangement.

description: To the Editor:

title: Noel Annan, 83, Versatile Englishman, Dies
description: Noel Annan, an educator, historian and critic whose wide-ranging scholarly pursuits, military experience during World War II and powerful posts in universities and cultural institutions made him an influential member of the British intelligentsia for more than half a century, died on Feb. 21 in London. He was 83.

title: Gore Seeks Soft Money
description: Aides to Vice President Al Gore were launching a program to help the Democrats raise $35 million in the unlimited campaign donations known as soft money over the next few months, even as Mr. Gore challenged Gov. George W. Bush to stop raising such funds.

description: Seventeen international arms experts have been chosen for a new commission, led by Hans Blix of Sweden, that is charged with completing the disarmament of Iraq.

title: Corrections
description: A picture caption in some copies yesterday about Gov. George W. Bush, his wife and a supporter misidentified the supporter. He was Brad Freeman, finance chairman for the Bush campaign in Southern California, not Donald L. Evans, a friend of Mr. Bush.

title: Essay; Getting Over It
description: When the jailed D.C. Mayor Marion Barry came roaring back to win re-election a few years ago, he delivered a classic message to those he had trounced: ''Get over it.''

title: Mac Users Can Now Say 'I Love You' Out Loud
description: Not only are some of the major video game makers coming back to the revitalized Macintosh platform, but productivity software is also appearing on the once-dusty store shelves in the Mac section. I.B.M.'s ViaVoice for Mac software, a continuous speech recognition program, allows members of the Apple corps to freely dictate their thoughts and have the computer do the typing.

title: Widening Breach Develops In Philippine Insider Case
description: A scandal in the Philippines over accusations that a friend of President Joseph Estrada engaged in insider trading escalated today into a showdown between Mr. Estrada and the country's top securities regulator.

title: Israeli Court Rules Arab Couple Can Live in Jewish Area
description: The Israeli Supreme Court ruled today that an Israeli Arab couple could not be barred from living in a community built solely for Jews.

description: A chart yesterday outlining results from surveys of Republican voters in several presidential primaries on Tuesday was omitted from some copies and replaced by a duplicate of the Democratic chart. An updated version of the Republican chart appears today, on Page A24.

title: I.N.S. Is Looking the Other Way As Illegal Immigrants Fill Jobs
description: Salvador Silva often used to worry that immigration agents would raid the commercial laundry where he works. If they did, he had a plan. He would jump onto a table, hoist himself into an air-conditioning duct, and hide there until the agents left. He practiced this more than once.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  HYDE, JAMES R.
description: HYDE-James R. Retired attorney. On March 4, 2000 at his home in Providence RI. The son of Eleanor G. O'Rourke and the late Robert E. Hyde. description: An art review on Monday about ''Greater New York,'' a survey of new works at the P.S. 1 Contemporary Art Center in Long Island City, Queens, included an erroneous reference from the museum for one artist. Do-Ho Suh is a man, not a woman.

title: Shares Rebound as Oil Prices and Fears on Inflation Ease
description: Stocks staged a modest rebound yesterday, overcoming early jitters to close broadly higher as oil prices eased and a Federal Reserve survey found inflation still limited despite intensified pressure on wages.

description: U.S., Strapped for Labor, Lets Illegal Workers Stay

title: The Dot-Com World Opens New Opportunities for Women to Lead
description: Last week, Jeanne Jackson surprised the retail community by resigning from her high-profile post as head of the Banana Republic division of Gap Inc. to take over the helm of Wal-Mart.com, a new Internet store. The news was shocking because Ms. Jackson had been rumored to be on the short list of executives who might one day succeed the Gap's longtime chief executive, Millard Drexler.

title: Paid Notice: Memorials  EDDINS, BENJAMIN
description: EDDINS-Benjamin. Missing you and what you would have become.

title: Fresh Run at I.M.F.
description: Germany began a diplomatic offensive to install one of its citizens, Horst Kohler, president of the European Bank for Reconstruction and Development, as head of the International Monetary Fund. But the campaign received a generally lukewarm reception in both Europe and the United States.

title: A Digital Camera That Will Fit Palm III and Upgrade Esteem
description: Owners of the Palm III organizer have been known to be a little envious of colleagues who have upgraded to its more expensive cousin, the V. After all, the III looks a little pedestrian in its gray plastic shell, while the V is encased in sleek anodized aluminum.

title: Panel Says Drug Policy Favored Top-Tier Stars
description: An investigation into the National Football League's drug policy by a Senate caucus on drug control found indications that the league at one time practiced a policy of allowing star players to escape punishment from failed drug tests while lower-tier players did not.

title: MIDEAST LEADERS PLAN TALKS IN U.S.
description: Palestinian and Israeli leaders agreed today to resume the fitful peace talks this month in Washington, holding to their self-imposed deadline of Sept. 13 for a final treaty despite a long history of stop-and-go negotiations.

title: Ambassadors Transcending Time and Race
description: The Civil War had barely ended in 1866 when missionaries and freedmen founded Fisk University in Nashville to educate freed slaves. The school immediately assembled a nine-member choir, and it started to tour in 1871, first in the South, then nationally, then internationally.

title: George Siravo, 83, Arranger for Pop Stars
description: George Siravo, a pop music arranger who worked with Frank Sinatra, Doris Day, Tony Bennett and other singers, died on Feb. 28 at his home in Medford, Ore. He was 83.

title: Nunnally's Hitting Has Mets Noticing
description: In all of the categories that commonly define a good baseball player, Jon Nunnally rates above average. The Mets' outfielder can hit for average and power, he can field and has a strong arm, and he runs well. He is solid all-around because he had to be.

title: Senate Votes to Revise Law That Limits Payments in Air Crashes
description: The Senate voted 82 to 17 this evening to modernize an 80-year-old law that airlines have used in the last few years to limit payments to families of passengers killed in crashes at sea.

title: President Says Measure Raises the Minimum Wage Too Slowly
description: With a checkout clerk at his side, President Clinton said today that a minimum wage increase set for a House vote on Thursday would cut business taxes too much and raise the pay of low-wage workers too little.

title: Study Jolts Views on Recovery From Extinctions
description: Over the past 500 million years, there have been dozens of episodes of extinction on the planet, the most famous being the titanic event that swept away the dinosaurs. Scientists have assumed that the time it takes for the living world to bounce back is proportional to the damage done: more time should be required to fill all of the earth's empty corners with newly evolved life after gargantuan extinctions and less time should be required after a more minor die-off.

title: New Rules on Organic Foods
description: In late 1997 the Department of Agriculture proposed rules that would have established a nationwide certification program for organic foods. During the 90-day comment period that followed, it became clear just how badly the department had stumbled. Rather than heed the advice of its own National Organic Standards Board, the agency would have allowed the use of irradiation, sewage sludge and genetically modified organisms in the growing and preparation of foods to be called organic. Whatever one thinks of those particular practices, they are hardly what most people would consider ''organic.'' The outcry from consumers and organic farmers forced reconsideration.

description: YOUNG-Jenni Munro. Of West Islip, NY, died on March 7 at Huntington Hills Nursing Home at the age of 81. She had previously suffered a severe stroke and speech loss. Born in Columbus, OH she attended Ohio State University. During WWII she held an administrative position at Grumman Aircraft. In the post-war decades she became a much sought-after designer of exquisite interiors for many upscale homes on Long Island, Chesapeake, and Florida. She also found time to make long cruises under sail, including Bermuda, with her husband of 45 years, John F., who survives her. She was a member of Shelter Island Yacht Club for 32 years. There are no funeral plans but a memorial will be announced later. In lieu of flowers, donations to animal humane societies would be appreciated.

It is with deep sorrow that the American Academy of Arts and Sciences mourns the loss of Edward Levi, Attorney General of the United States and President of the Academy from 1985 to 1989. Throughout his presidency, he worked to renew the Academy's historic mission to bring together distinguished individuals from all fields and professions in service to society. description: THERE has been a spate of deals this week involving agencies and companies that work with them, ranging from reorganizations to acquisitions to affiliations.

title: WORLD BUSINESS BRIEFING: AMERICAS; EBULLIENCE AT THE BOLSA
description: Exuberant that Mexico's debt rating had been upgraded by Moody's Investors Service, investors snapped up Mexican stocks for a second day and pushed the main share index up 3.61 percent to a record. Mexican banking shares strengthened in particular. Dan Fineren

title: A LIMIT TO CINAR'S EXPOSURE
description: The Montreal-based producer of children's television programs, the Cinar Corporation, which fired its No. 3 executive this week after asserting that he had made $122 million in unauthorized investments, said its financial exposure would not exceed $86 million. Shares of the company plunged Tuesday on concern that the money might have been locked up in risky investments.

description: AUTO RACING

title: Murphy and Notre Dame Make It to the Next Level
description: When you have won Big East player of the year honors, your name should be spelled in lights outside Madison Square Garden, not smeared with blood on the back of your jersey.

title: The Political Post-Mortems Begin
description: To the Editor:

title: How Original! How Vile! Plastic in the Parlor!
description: AT the Terence Conran Shop last week, plastic chairs were as much in evidence as plastic money (not coincidentally, they were often seen together). For a moment, you could even believe they were the obvious accessories for the middle-aged woman, impeccably coordinated in cashmere and leather, who was dragging a concave thumb-shape chair across the floor. She had bought the $295 plastic chair in six colors and was headed for a glass dining table to admire the fit. ''I've always loved plastic,'' said the woman, Monique Knowlton, an art dealer. And there was plenty to choose from, opalescent as a rain slick or brittle as a lunch tray, from $49 to $495. ''They're very cool, as my son would say,'' she added.

title: CURRENTS; SPRUCE
description: A friendly, small-town kind of shop called Spruce, as in spruce up, opened in 1998 on a site in Greenwich Village where a florist's shop has stood since 1921. Within the walls of Spruce, romantically rustic arrangements are displayed.

title: As It Takes On Corruption, China Executes an Official
description: China executed a former provincial vice governor today for taking bribes. He was the highest official put to death for corruption in the 50 years since the Communists came to power.

title: Paid Notice: Memorials  KUNAR, ROBERT J.
description: KUNAR-Robert J. 1946-1995. Fifth Anniversary, we miss you now more than ever, you are always in our hearts. Your loving family and all new additions that will know you and love you.

title: Out There in Never-Bell Land; Where Phone Service Is Way Above Average, and Competitive
description: The hand-cranked phone boxes are long gone. The party lines are, too. But the residents of tiny Richmond, a former mining town in the Berkshires, still dial the operator when they need the local news.

title: The Greatest Thing Since, Well, Since Refrigeration
description: With all the buzz about how the Internet is changing Life as We Know It, it's nice to see things from a different perspective every once in a while.

title: Bible Verses on Homosexuality Are Covered Up on Billboards
description: Two billboards on Staten Island that angered civic and gay leaders by using a Biblical verse to condemn homosexuality were covered up yesterday, just as the identity of the man responsible for the messages was revealed.

title: Germans Try A Second Run At I.M.F. Post
description: Defying warnings that history might repeat itself, Germany began a diplomatic offensive to install one of its nationals as head of the International Monetary Fund and received a generally lukewarm reception today in both Europe and the United States.

title: More on Martha
description: To the Editor:

title: TWO MAKERS OF COMPUTER NETWORK EQUIPMENT TO MERGE
description: Apex Inc. and the Cybex Computer Products Corporation agreed to a merger valued at $1.14 billion that will bring together two rival makers of equipment for managing computer networks. Cybex shareholders will get one share of the merged company for each share held. Apex shareholders will receive 1.0905 shares of the new company for each share held. The two companies make equipment that lets network administrators control several computers from a single keyboard, monitor and mouse. Apex and Cybex are the only two publicly traded companies that make these systems. Apex's shares rose $6.125 each, to $42.125, in Nasdaq trading, where Cybex shares fell $3.8125, to $41. The combined company will be based in Huntsville, Ala.

title: Oh, the Places He's Been: A Life in Perpetual Motion
description: AT age 23, sitting in a village in Afghanistan drinking salty tea with a party of desert tribesmen, Robert Edison Fulton Jr. asked for water. A boy ran into the road to get it, filling a jug in a muddy puddle, then offering Mr. Fulton a cup.

title: Computer Forensics Teams Learn to Follow Digital Footprints
description: JOHN LEESON smiles as he straightens out a paper clip and inserts it in the back of a portable Zip disk drive of a personal computer that he has put into standby mode. The disk, which contains an unknown password that allows access to the computer's hard drive, pops out and Dr. Leeson inserts another disk. When prompted by an on-screen message, he chooses ''remove protection'' and enters a new password that will give him access to valuable information on the hard drive that had previously been blocked.

title: GAMBLING MACHINE OPERATOR TO PUT ITS MONEY ON THE NET
description: Jackpot Enterprises Inc., one of the biggest operators of gambling machines in Nevada, announced yesterday that it planned to transform itself into an Internet investment company, with an emphasis on the business-to-business sector. The Las Vegas-based company, which will change its name to J Net Enterprises, said it would set up a $100 million fund to invest in Internet-related and business-to-business enterprises. The company will also make an undisclosed investment in Digital Boardwalk and acquire control of Meister Brothers Investments, which has investments in nine Internet companies. Shares of Jackpot surged $7, to $21.125.

title: The Piano Players
description: To the Editor:

title: Jurors' Trust in Police Erodes in Light of Diallo and Louima
description: For prosecutors, the testimony of police officers is often the bedrock of their efforts to win criminal indictments and convictions. In many cases, the outcome hinges on whether jurors believe the account of an officer, such as an undercover narcotics officer who buys drugs or a detective who extracts a confession.

title: Clemens Showing Signs of His Old, Aggressive Style
description: Roger Clemens eased his way onto the Yankees last year like the new kid joining an elementary school class in the winter, his personality sometimes muted by unfamiliar surroundings. But he is one of them now, and he intends to stay.

title: States Try Online Option For Drivers
description: ONE of the scourges of modern life -- waiting in line at the motor vehicle department -- may soon be a thing of the past as states begin to make driver's license renewals, along with motor vehicle registration and other types of licensing, available online.

title: Editorial Observer; An Attorney General Who Trusted the Law
description: Edward Levi, who died on Tuesday, brought the simple gift of integrity to Washington when he became attorney general in 1975. In the two brief years that he led the Justice Department, Mr. Levi set an example of respect for the Constitution and the rights of Americans that remains a benchmark for distinguished public service today. Few of his successors at Justice have come close to that high standard, and several have fallen abysmally short. That is good reason to recall Mr. Levi's principled, fair-minded performance.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  NEAL, ALFRED CLARENCE
description: NEAL-Alfred Clarence. On March 8, 2000 in Sarasota, FL., age 87. Former first Vice President of the Federal Reserve Bank of Boston, retired President of the Committee for Economic Development, teacher, author and economic consultant. Beloved husband of the late Marguerite (nee Stephenson) Neal, survived by four sisters and two brothers. Funeral services private.

description: Turnout for Republican presidential primaries hit record highs in 12 of the 18 states that have held them so far, and it was clearly a result of John McCain's candidacy, now suspended, according to a new nonpartisan analysis of voting.

title: Jury Deliberating Case of Officer Who Killed Fugitive
description: While intense attention has been focused on the trials of police officers in the death of Amadou Diallo and the assault on Abner Louima, a jury in State Superior Court here has been hearing the case of the first Connecticut police officer ever charged with murder in the shooting of a suspect while on duty.

title: Kohl Says He'll Pay Fines in Party Fund-Raising Scandal
description: Helmut Kohl, the former German chancellor, emerged from weeks of seclusion today to announce that generous friends and a mortgage on his house had enabled him to raise enough money to cover the financial damage suffered by the Christian Democratic party as a result of his ''mistakes.''

Loving father of Steven Cirker and Victoria Fremont. Dear grandfather of Jason and Oliver Fremont. Services ''BoulevardRiverside Chapel'', 1450 Broadway, Hewlett, L.I. Sunday March 12 at 11:30AM. description: A last-ditch effort by Qwest Communications International to rekindle its negotiations to be acquired by Deutsche Telekom of Germany ended yesterday as Qwest failed to convince U S West, its previous merger partner, to go along with a Deutsche Telekom deal.

title: More Deception Is Suspected In Cancer Study
description: New details emerging from an investigation into research fraud in a South African breast cancer study suggest that the deception and violations of ethics were even more serious than initially recognized and may have included patients' being given experimental treatment without their knowledge or consent.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  POMPER, LEWIS
description: POMPER-Lewis, 93, Died on March 6, in Boca Raton, FL, after a brief illness. He was an attorney practicing law in NY for over 40 years. Prior to WWII, specialized in immigration law and assisted refugees trying to enter the US from Nazi Germany. He later established a law firm with Joseph Marro and Howard Cosell in NYC; Mr. Cosell left the firm to pursue a career in sports broadcasting. Marro and Pomper built up a sizable law practice in Huntington, NY, and NYC, specializing in mortgage and banking law. Eventually the firm became Pomper and Rubinton. Mr. Pomper was a founder of Walt Whitman Savings and Loan Association now North Fork Bank and Trust Co. He was an officer for many years of the Suffolk County Bar Association and Chairman of the Suffolk County Planning Committee. An active member of the Jewish Community, Mr. Pomper was a founder of Temple Beth-El in Huntington, and served as President, and was Chairman of Suffolk County United Jewish Appeal. Survived by wife: Doris of Boca Raton, daughter: Ann, and son: Samuel, and four grandchildren. Funeral services, March 9, in Boca Raton, FL.

title: Man Accuses Diallo Officer Of Beating Him
description: A Bronx man has sued Kenneth Boss, one of the police officers recently acquitted in the fatal shooting of Amadou Diallo, alleging that Mr. Boss and three other officers from the Street Crime Unit wrongfully stopped him and then brutalized him during an arrest two months before the Diallo shooting.

title: Composers Linked by Resonance And Grace
description: The Japanese pianist Chitose Okashiro alighted at Miller Theater on Wednesday evening to play a program devoted largely to the music of Messiaen and Toru Takemitsu. In their piano music, at least, the two composers often make similar sorts of sounds: plush, static harmonies, rather short melodic phrases that will often be repeated, progressions that turn within circles. Messiaen's range was broader, as Ms. Okashiro partly indicated, but both composers had a love of the slow tempo and drift that together with their rapturous harmonic-melodic materials suggest an attained state of ecstasy or grace.

title: RESIGNATION IN MANILA
description: President Joseph Estrada of the Philippines, left, accepted the resignation of the Securities and Exchange Commission chairman, Perfecto Yasay. Mr. Yasay's resignation, submitted several weeks ago, takes effect on March 25. Mr. Yasay said he would not take back his resignation as he had threatened to do on Wednesday. At the height of an investigation of the trading irregularities in the gambling company BW Resources, Mr. Yasay said that Mr. Estrada had tried to pressure him into stopping the investigation and clearing a presidential friend of wrongdoing. Mr. Estrada denied the accusations.

title: Off to Hell in a Handbasket, Trusty Book in Hand
description: For those with an interest in seeing a dinner-theater version of ''Eyes Wide Shut,'' then look no further. Roman Polanski's ''Ninth Gate,'' with its wizened decadence -- Darius Khondji's velveteen cinematography looks as if it came out of Rembrandt's Fotomat -- and its tired stabs at comedy, is calling your name.

title: Led by Technology Issues, Main Gauges Rally Sharply
description: Technology issues paced a strong stock market rally yesterday as the Nasdaq composite index soared through the 5,000 mark for the first time while the broadest market gauge of all, the Wilshire total market index, surged above 14,000, also a record.

title: WORLD BUSINESS BRIEFING: AMERICAS; BIG BUSINESS COMMITMENT IN MEXICO
description: The Mexican Council of Businessmen, an association of the country's wealthiest entrepreneurs, announced in a meeting with President Ernesto Zedillo that their corporations would make $8.5 billion in new investments in 2000, an increase of 23 percent over 1999 investments of $6.9 billion. Francisco Hoyos

title: Boat People Losing (Uneasy) Haven
description: Ask Nguyen Kim Lien about life inside the barbed-wire fence of the Pillar Point Vietnamese Refugee Camp here and she is remarkably stoic. Her family lives in squalor -- a couple of rooms in a dilapidated housing block, where rats prowl brazenly outside the door. Her husband, who is out of work and addicted to heroin, spends his days wandering the camp in a haze.

title: COVAD COMMUNICATIONS SAYS IT IS ACQUIRING LASERLINK
description: Covad Communications Group, a provider of high-speed Internet service, agreed yesterday to acquire LaserLink.net, a privately held Internet access provider, for 4.3 million shares, worth about $396 million in stock. LaserLink, based in Media, Pa., sells Internet access to businesses, which then offer it under their own brands. Covad, which has its headquarters in Santa Clara, Calif., sells digital subscriber lines through Internet service providers. Covad's stock jumped $5 a share, to $95.25, in Nasdaq trading.

title: Courting the Vanquished, Gingerly
description: He has not even been officially crowned the Republican presidential nominee, but already Gov. George W. Bush finds himself confronted with a classic predicament, one that poses a significant test to his leadership skills: How does he win over Senator John McCain -- and his crucial block of independent and Democratic loyalists -- without antagonizing the Republican establishment that pulled Mr. Bush to victory?

title: After Long Delays, Senate Confirms 2 Judicial Nominees
description: Three weeks ago, Polly Paez, a Mexican-American woman with immense pride in her son, who is a federal judge in Los Angeles, decided she had to do something to save his long-stalled nomination to a higher court.

title: PROFITS SURGE AT UBS
description: Switzerland's largest bank, UBS A.G., said its fourth-quarter earnings had more than doubled to 1.1 billion Swiss francs, or $660 million, on the strength of vibrant securities markets. The banking company, created by the 1998 merger of Union Bank of Switzerland and the Swiss Bank Corporation, said earnings for the year doubled to 6.3 billion francs, or $3.79 billion. UBS said it planned to list shares on the New York Stock Exchange this year. Elizabeth Olson

title: Small Step for Man, but a Big Whoop for Martians
description: As in ''Apollo 13,'' Gary Sinise gets to watch all his pals go off into space without him. In ''Mission to Mars,'' he's Jim, a morose astronaut pining for his dead wife, and his depression makes him an unlikely candidate for the Mars mission. ''He's good,'' explains Cmdr. Woody Blake (Tim Robbins), ''but not for this.''

description: RODIN-Ida B., 89, of Kingston, PA on March 8, 2000. Beloved wife of the late Philip Rodin. Adored mother of Marilyn Schulder & Sherry Sulkes and wonderful mother-in-law of Howard Schulder & Marc Sulkes. Cherished grandmother of Amy Schulder Arn & Marcy Schulder Barkan. Services, Friday in Wilkes Barre, PA followed by interment in Utica, NY.

title: ROCHE PLANS TO SELL 3 MILLION GENENTECH SHARES
description: The Swiss company Roche Holding A.G. plans to sell 17.3 million shares of Genentech Inc., raising about $3 billion and taking advantage of a fourfold increase in Genentech's stock price since July. Genentech, the world's second-biggest biotech company, filed with the United States Securities and Exchange Commission to register shares owned by a Wilmington, Del., unit of Roche. The prospect of more shares on the market sent Genentech's stock down $22.25, to $187.50. The stock sale will lower Roche's stake in Genentech to 58.9 percent from 65.6 percent. The sale is the latest in a series of transactions by Roche, Europe's fifth-biggest drug maker, intended to take advantage of increases in Genentech's share price. In January, Roche sold $1 billion in bonds exchangeable into Genentech shares.

description: The Chicago office of FCB Worldwide, part of True North Communications, said yesterday that it had withdrawn from a review by the J. C. Penney Company involving assignments like national corporate brand advertising, with billings estimated at $100 million or more.

description: Theater

title: Stained-Glass Expert Gets Prison Sentence
description: A renowned expert on Tiffany stained glass was sentenced yesterday to 27 months in federal prison for conspiring with a Queens grave robber and an antiques dealer to pilfer rare stained-glass windows from cemetery mausoleums and sell them overseas at a large profit.

title: Bradley Out; McCain Yields : Challengers Quit Presidential Race
description: WASHINGTON  Former Senator Bill Bradley of New Jersey and Senator John McCain of Arizona, two insurgents whose candidacies had made the 2000 primary contests among the most passionately fought in years, bowed out Thursday, but neither offered a full endorsement to his victorious rival.

description: Nolan/Eckman Gallery

title: When One City Was the Heart Of Art's Youth
description: In 1946 the Metropolitan Museum of Art acquired its first painting by Picasso, his portrait of Gertrude Stein, painted in 1906 when he was 24 and she was 32. (When told that Stein did not resemble his image of her, Picasso famously predicted, ''She will.'') Unexpectedly, Stein bequeathed the portrait to the Met; she wanted it hung in a museum whose stature was equal to her own. Not only was it the first Picasso to enter the Met, at that time scarcely interested in pursuing 20th-century European art, but it was also the museum's first acquisition by a living artist of the School of Paris. And it provided a cornerstone on which a modern collection could be built.

description: THE WEST

title: A Good Trade Deal With China
description: Congress should quickly approve legislation needed to smooth China's admission to the World Trade Organization. By helping China into the W.T.O., lawmakers would not be endorsing Beijing's policies in other areas, like human rights and Taiwan. They would be speeding the opening and reform of China's economy and subordinating Beijing's arbitrary authority in trade matters to the rule of international law.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  KOENIGSDORF, HEINTZ, JOAN, PH.D. (NEE LAMPERT)
description: KOENIGSDORF - HEINTZ - Joan, Ph.D. (nee Lampert), age 65, passed away on March 4, 2000 at her home in Kansas City. Loving wife of Jerry, devoted mother of Susan and Brian, dearest sister of Stanley and Roslyn, beloved aunt to Charles, Shari, Michael and Jonathan. Admired and loved by all.

title: Blaze That Led to 3 Killings Was Arson, Investigators Say
description: Investigators established today that arson was the cause of the blaze that drew firefighters to a suburban home on Wednesday afternoon where the off-duty firefighter who lived there apparently killed his wife and shot to death two fellow firefighters and a sheriff's deputy.

title: Letting an Artist Explain, Whether It Helps or Not
description: ''Condo Painting'' is not, as the title might seem to suggest, an instructional film for apartment owners, but rather an 87-minute documentary on the life, work and thought of George Condo, a garrulous painter with a mischievous sense of humor and an eccentric, quasi-mystical view of art and the world it inhabits. To call the film a documentary may be a bit misleading. Directed by the Chicago filmmaker John McNaughton (whose earlier work includes the cult classic pseudo-documentary ''Henry: Portrait of a Serial Killer'' and the feverish sex thriller ''Wild Things'') in close collaboration with its subject, ''Condo Painting'' tries not only to record the artist's aesthetic theories but also to apply them.

title: Corrections
description: A headline yesterday about a call by Senator Joseph R. Biden Jr., Democrat of Delaware, for a delay in a United States missile-defense plan referred incorrectly to others who have taken that position. They include Democrats as well as Republicans.

Dear brother of Loretta Martini, loving uncle of his nieces and nephews. Visitation Saturday and Sunday 2-4 and 7-9 pm at Weigand Brothers Funeral Home, 49 Hillside Ave, Williston Park, NY. Funeral mass Monday 11:15 am at St. Aidan's RC Church, Williston Park, NY. Interment Holy Rood Cemetery, Westbury, NY. In lieu of flowers donations in Richard's memory to the American Cancer Society, 839 Stewart Ave, Garden City, New York 11530.

description: SCHWARTZ-Louis. The Shelter Rock Jewish Center, Roslyn, NY mourns the loss of its longtime and devoted member and friend. Lou's dedication to his family, to our people and to our congregation will long be remembered. May his family be comforted with the memory of a good man. Rabbi Myron M. Fenster Laurence A. Feldman, President

title: SANTANDER'S LATIN PUSH
description: Spain's largest bank, Banco Santander Central Hispano S.A., agreed to acquire a controlling stake in Patagon.com International, a Miami-based online brokerage firm that caters to customers in Latin America. Santander's purchase of 75 percent of Patagon for $529 million in cash will allow the bank to use the brokerage firm's operations in Spanish- and Portuguese-speaking countries of Latin America to enlarge its Internet banking operations in the region. Simon Romero

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SCHEIDER, KATHLEEN N.
description: SCHEIDER-Kathleen N. Passed away suddenly on March 8 at age 70. Beloved wife of Edward J. Scheider; sister of Elizabeth Jones of Kitchener Canada. She was a dedicated volunteer and patron at the Metropolitan Museum of Art for 35 years; a member of the Box Committee at the Brick Church and a volunteer at the YWCA in NYC; an avid gardener and animal lover at Longview Farm in Fleischmanns, NY, and was a major sponsor and director of the Bellayre Conservancy. Supporter of Kids in the Katskills summer program as well as a member of the Margaretsville Hospital Womens Auxilary. Friends may call at Frank E. Campbell, 1076 Madison Ave at 81 St., Friday 2-5 and 7-9 PM, Saturday 2-5PM, with service following on Saturday at 7PM at Frank E. Campbell. Contributions in her memory may be made to Lennox Hill Settlement House, NYC, or any of the above.

title: A Commune Subsisting On Talk And Politics
description: ''District of Columbia'' -- a play by Michael Louis Wells, directed by Jamie Richards at the Ensemble Studio Theater -- is a good reminder of how difficult it is to remember nothing. As the voice of the father of the current governor of Texas whines on triumphantly from a television set on election eve in 1988, it occurs to one that the only memorable moment from that entire campaign was Michael S. Dukakis's disappearing under a helmet in an army tank. It's an odd emblem for the play, but not entirely unfitting.

Dyke Benjamin, a member of the Harvard class of 1959, in association with Peter X. Accardo of the Houghton Library in Harvard. Ruskin is well served by both of them.

title: MACHINERY ORDERS ARE UP
description: Core machinery orders to Japanese manufacturers rose in January to 991.72 billion yen, or $9.3 billion, up 0.8 percent from December, the Economic Planning Agency said. The rise contrasted with the expectations of economists in an informal survey. They had estimated on average that core orders fell 8.1 percent from the prior month. Machinery orders are regarded as a key leading indicator of private capital investment.

title: Independent Study Raises Safety Concerns for Space Shuttles
description: Efforts to cut the costs of operating the space shuttle are eroding safety, and NASA needs to take a more active role immediately in shuttle operations by private contractors to reduce risks, an independent study group said today.

title: Bleak Assessment Offered on City's Child Welfare System
description: In its latest assessment of the city's child welfare system, a panel of national experts painted a dismal portrait of Family Court, concluding that caseworkers are sometimes so ill-prepared that they are unable to explain to a judge why children were removed from their homes.

title: Texture Is Underscored By New Pittsburgh Baton
description: Mariss Jansons has done wonders with the Pittsburgh Symphony since he took it over from Lorin Maazel in 1997. When last encountered in a Carnegie Hall concert under Mr. Maazel's baton, the orchestra produced a respectable sound, with moments of brilliance giving way to playing that was plagued by ensemble problems.

title: OGDEN AGREES TO SELL THEME PARKS TO ALFA ALFA HOLDINGS
description: The Ogden Corporation, a manager of power plants, theme parks and airport services, agreed yesterday to sell its water and theme park assets to Alfa Alfa Holdings of Athens for about $148 million in cash. Alfa Alfa, also known as Aluminum of Attica S.A., will assume $80 million in debt as part of the transaction. The sale is part of Ogden's plan to sell its entertainment and aviation businesses and focus solely on its energy business. Ogden, based in New York, builds, owns and operates power plants. Alfa Alfa is a construction, packaging, recreation and public utilities company. Under the terms of the agreement, Alfa Alfa will also acquire Jazzland, a theme park that Ogden is building in New Orleans.

title: Why Rome Was Splendid In the 1700's
description: New York City considers itself the art capital of the world, but it will probably never be the equal of Rome in the 18th century. Rome was a mecca for cultivated citizens from all over the world. ''Rome in the 18th century was like New York today,'' said Peter Marino, a New York architect. ''You had to go and be seen there. It was the center of energy, where everything was happening.''

title: Corrections
description: An article in Business Day on Saturday about duties on imported steel referred incorrectly to actions taken last month by the United States International Trade Commission. The commission split, 3 to 3, on whether relief should be provided to makers of wire rod and voted 5 to 1 in favor of relief for pipe makers. Both recommendations were sent to President Clinton, as required by law, and he decided to impose duties. The commission was not unable to reach a decision.

title: A 'Year of Mavericks' Ends Swiftly, and Takes The Excitement With It
description: As they did so vividly three months ago in Claremont, N.H., the campaigns of John McCain and Bill Bradley again found common ground yesterday. In mirror-image speeches barely an hour apart, the conservative Republican and the liberal Democrat abandoned the presidential race, leaving the country to puzzle over the demise of a pair of candidacies that had once so captured the fancy of the American press and public.

title: Keeping the Cause Alive
description: In pulling out of the presidential race yesterday, John McCain and Bill Bradley vowed to keep fighting for reform. That promise was to be expected as part of the ritual of politics. But because both candidates inspired new voters and brought new vision to the campaign this year, their ability to continue influencing the debate is considerable. Mr. McCain, who ''suspended'' his candidacy but did not endorse Gov. George W. Bush for the Republican nomination, is in an especially crucial spot. He made overhauling the campaign finance system his central theme, and now he can refocus his energy to stop a coming orgy of corrupt fund-raising by both Democrats and Republicans.

title: Omigosh! Without Glasses I Could Be a Supermodel

And home is no better. Her little brother is a tattletale, and her father forces her to put on a chef's hat and coat and work on weekends for his catering company. Honestly, she might as well be dead.

title: A Tasting Menu of Gallic Cinema
description: No actress in the world is able to project more emotion through a mask of immobility than Catherine Deneuve, the enduring French star who gives one of her deepest screen performances in Philippe Garrel's film ''Le Vent de la Nuit'' (''Night Wind''). This beautiful but sad-hearted movie, a high point of the Film Society of Lincoln Center's annual ''Rendez-Vous With French Cinema'' series, is a meditation on the relentless passage of time and the suicidal impulses of two diehard romantics who refuse to accept life's inevitable changes.

title: CROWN CASTLE IS BUYING WIRELESS TOWERS IN AUSTRALIA

Under the deal, Crown Castle will also acquire the exclusive right to develop all future tower sites for Optus over the next six years. The transaction will position Crown Castle, based in Houston, as the largest independent tower operator in Australia. Shares of Crown Castle rose $1.0625, to $40.8125.

title: Corrections
description: The Personal Health column in Science Times on Jan. 25, about the risks of overdosing on acetaminophen, commercially known as Tylenol, referred imprecisely to the amount that becomes toxic. Treating a child five times a day or more for several days, at the recommended dosage, could result in a build-up to half or more of the toxic quantity. A single dose given once is about 11 percent of the toxic quantity. The drug's maker reported the error in a letter on Feb. 14, but the writer was away from the office and did not see her mail.

SCG, based in Phoenix, does business as On Semiconductor, and is one of the world's largest makers of semiconductor components for cellular phones, cable modems and network routers.
