title: Mayor Says School Board's Base Is for Sale, Study or No
description: Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani announced yesterday that the city was aggressively seeking a buyer for 110 Livingston Street, the Board of Education's decrepit and maligned headquarters in downtown Brooklyn, and that he was not going to wait for the board's study exploring the possibility of a sale.

title: Life at the Corner of Journalism and Activism
description: THERE was a time, back in the fiscally straitened 1970's, that the city was so desperate it turned to known members of the media for help. Thus did Osborn Elliott, departing editor of Newsweek, become a deputy mayor, largely on the strength of his side job as chairman of the Citizens Committee for New York City, which had recruited several thousand volunteers to fill city jobs left vacant by layoffs.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  GOULD, BEATRICE
description: GOULD-Beatrice. Survived by daughters Chameli Elaine Herdes, Rae Polis, son Richard Gould, grandchildren Stephanie Wechsler, Jonathon Herdes, Jacqueline Herdes, Eric Justin Gould, Elise Lorraine Gould, Matthew Polis, and Lauren Polis. Great-grandchildren Daniel and Julie Weschler, William Herdes and Pema Buckmaster Gould. Funeral service Sunday, 10AM at Robert Schoems Menorah Chapel, W-150 Route 4, Paramus, NJ. Memorials preferred to Sholom Home West, 3620 Phillips Parkway, St. Louis Park, MN. 55426.

title: McCain Gone, Bush Just Plows Ahead
description: Gov. George W. Bush of Texas briskly returned to the campaign trail today as if his competition had not withered away, seeking to sustain the momentum from his climactic victories on Tuesday and hone his attacks on Vice President Al Gore.

title: Traces of Deadly Virus Are Found in Hibernating Mosquitoes
description: Federal health investigators have found genetic evidence in hibernating mosquitoes collected recently in northeastern Queens that suggests the West Nile virus that killed seven people in the New York region last year survived the winter.

title: New Rule to Let Pickups Roll on New York Parkways Next Week
description: BEWARE the Ides of March? For commuters in and around New York City, that might be an overreaction, but a new era will begin next Wednesday as pickup trucks become eligible to join the traffic crush on parkways.

title: All Starry-Eyed In Grand Central
description: Nearly 30 years ago, when I was a brand-new New Yorker, I spent many a happy half-hour in the bar overlooking the main concourse of Grand Central Terminal. Sitting on a stool, I would slowly sip my martini and gaze down upon what a popular 1940's radio program called ''the crossroads of a million private lives.'' Grand. Central. Could any public building have been more appropriately named? In this quintessential urban space, where everyone was a stranger en route to somewhere else, the 26-year-old newcomer began to feel that she belonged.

title: Teaching Johnny Values Where Money Is King
description: Every day after school, 13-year-old Jeffrey Mendelman has a peanut butter and jelly sandwich with milk, finishes his homework -- and checks his stocks.

title: After a Slow Start, Duke Routs Clemson
description: ATLANTIC COAST CONFERENCE

title: AUTOS ON FRIDAY/Safety; On the Road. On the Web. In Danger?
description: WHEN car phones first became popular, some people asked whether motorists could talk and drive safely at the same time. A decade later, that question seems naive; many new cell phones can connect a laptop computer to the Internet, or the phones themselves have screens that can be used to browse the World Wide Web. Other potential distractions now popular in cars are navigation systems with maps to point the way to a destination, or maybe just to the nearest florist. Some high-end vehicles have video-screen controls for trip computers, built-in phones, air-conditioners or stereo systems.

title: National News Briefs; Internet Privacy Report Cites Need for Balance
description: The Clinton administration published a report on online security and privacy today, noting that law enforcement faced significant challenges in keeping up with criminals in cyberspace.

title: Mexico's Chief Justice Strives to Oil a Creaking System
description: Seated at his desk, Chief Justice Genaro Gongora Pimentel was partly hidden behind an 18-inch stack of judicial papers. With assembly line rhythm, a clerk was pulling writs and rulings from atop the pile, sliding scores of them, one after the other, under the chief justice's hand for his signature.

title: Protesting by Angry Police Leaves Louisville Unsettled
description: In an episode with incendiary aspects of racial divide, the aftermath of a deadly shooting by two officers has plunged this proud, resilient city into open doubts about the loyalty of its police force.

title: Daniel Yanofsky, 74, Canadian Chess Champion
description: Daniel Abraham Yanofsky, Canada's first chess grandmaster, died on Sunday at Seven Oaks Hospital in Winnipeg, Manitoba. He was 74.

title: NEWS SUMMARY
description: INTERNATIONAL A3-11

title: ON STAGE AND OFF
description: Inching Toward The Inevitable

title: Esiason Fires Back After Being Dismissed
description: Fired from ABC's ''Monday Night Football'' on Wednesday, Boomer Esiason vented his fury yesterday.

title: THEATER GUIDE
description: Here is a selective listing by critics of The Times of new or noteworthy Broadway and Off Broadway shows this weekend. Approximate running times are in parentheses. * denotes a highly recommended show.

title: A Broad Middle East
description: Middle Eastern food covers a broad swath of culinary territory, from Morocco to Egypt to Turkey to Iran. Here are 12 restaurants that evoke some of the savory cuisines of this varied region. (These summaries are taken from dining reviews, columns and articles in The Times by William Grimes, Eric Asimov and others.)

title: NATO Denies 'Spy' in Kosovo War
description: PARIS  The allied high command drastically curtailed the number of people who knew the details of bombing targets after the NATO air campaign in Yugoslavia got underway last year, alliance officials admitted Thursday.

title: MCCAIN QUITS RACE BUT STOPS SHORT OF ENDORSING BUSH
description: Senator John McCain, whose powerful insurgency became the surprise of the primary season, ended his maverick bid for the Republican nomination today with the hope that he would eventually prevail in ''making our party as big as the country we serve.''

title: Rangers' Playoff Bid Includes a Mystery
description: On the West Coast, the standings change by the hour, not by the day.

title: Rebuilding Kosovo: The Role of Europe; The Attacks Go On
description: To the Editor:

title: Stargazing, a Family Tradition
description: A writer who has had a love affair with the celestial ceiling of Grand Central Terminal for 30 years discovered recently that she was more intimately related to the station's vaulted room than she knew. In unearthing family history, she learned that a great-uncle, an astronomer, supplied the sketches on which the artist's rendering of the constellations was based.

title: INSIDE
description: Judge Wins Confirmation

title: Tournaments Begin Path to the Frozen Four
description: Four teams have plans to visit Minneapolis or Albany at the end of the month, and the remaining Division I men's hockey teams will try to survive conference tournaments to fill the remaining eight berths in the National Collegiate Athletic Association tournament.

title: DINER'S JOURNAL
description: The calendar says the year 2000 is here. Inside Metro Fish, the date is 1955. Or it could be 1935. Metro Fish is the kind of restaurant that invites diners to ask about ''the fisherman's catch'' and boasts that its clams and oysters are ''shucked to order.'' There's nothing self-consciously retro about any of this. The consciousness is pre-retro. Metro Fish offers, with a straight face, dishes like clams Casino, coconut fried shrimp and a broiled seafood platter. All entrees include baked potato, french fries or mashed potato. The night I visited, the children at surrounding tables seemed to be in seventh heaven. At last a fine-dining menu they could understand.

title: Jewish Artists Who Made Paris Their Exuberant Garret
description: It is by a remarkable coincidence that the Jewish Museum should have just opened an exhibition whose subject is largely identical to that of ''Painters in Paris: 1895-1950'' at the Metropolitan Museum of Art. The subject is the same, the time span is the same and quite a few of the artists are the same. But the Jewish Museum show is ''Paris in New York: French Jewish Artists in Private Collections.''

title: New York G.O.P. Senate Leader Urges Reform of Primary System
description: Calling New York's Republican presidential primary system ''absolute nonsense,'' the Republican leader of the State Senate called today for top-to-bottom reform, making ballots easier to understand, and making it simpler for candidates to get on the ballot.

title: Vibrant Area of Newark Suffers With Success
description: Soaring home prices. Sclerotic traffic. The maddening roar of new construction. Too many people, not enough room.

title: ALBUM OF THE WEEK
description: MEKONS: ''Journey to the End of the Night'' (Quarterstick/ Touch and Go). The 38th record by this fabled cosmopolitan art-punk band is a late work in every respect, not merely because the Mekons are deep into a seemingly endless career. Lateness is the album's theme and defines its tone. Its cycle starts and ends in myth, joining a tired Hercules in his 10th labor.

title: CABARET GUIDE
description: Here is a selective listing of new or noteworthy cabaret shows in Manhattan this weekend. * denotes a highly recommended show.

title: EVENTURES SAYS IT IS BUYING INTERNET GLOBAL SERVICES
description: EVentures Group Inc., an Internet venture-capital and holding company, agreed yesterday to buy the closely held Internet Global Services Inc., an Internet and communications-service company, for about $88.2 million in stock. EVentures will pay 2.8 million shares for all shares of Internet Global, or iGlobal. IGlobal, founded in 1994, sells online services that combine voice, data and video. EVentures invests in companies that manage Web sites, create Internet networks and develop data-storage services. The company is based in Jersey City and has executive offices in Dallas. Shares of eVentures rose $2.50, to $31.50. They were first sold to the public on July 8 for 12.5 cents a share.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  ELGART, BENJAMIN
description: ELGART-Benjamin. March 9, 2000. Beloved husband of Lillian. Loving father of Ellen and Myron Conovitz and Judith and Barry Schneider. Adoring Poppa of Amy and Robert Lindsay and Jennifer and Steven Russo and Andrew Schneider. Great-grandfather of Emma Kata and Liliane. Devoted brother of Philip and the late Nelson. Graveside service Friday, March 10th, Knollwood Cemetery.

title: After Personal Darkness, A Millennial Dawn in Rio
description: ''Midnight,'' which opens today at the Screening Room, takes place in Rio de Janeiro in the recent past -- about 10 weeks ago, to be precise. Its story begins on the morning of Dec. 30, 1999, and concludes two days later, in the bright dawn of a new millennium, with the world looking pretty much the same as it did before, which, given that the final scene takes place on one of Rio's spectacular white sand beaches, is not too shabby.

title: Foreign Affairs; The Water's Edge
description: So I was starting to envy the political reporters, because there seemed to be no foreign policy in this year's presidential primary campaign. But then I realized that there was no policy in this campaign, let alone foreign policy, so there was really nothing to envy. So far, this has been a campaign about campaigning -- who has the best ad strategy for distorting the other guy's position and re-inventing his own in order to mislead voters. We had a primary in New York in which people actually discussed whether John McCain was for or against breast cancer, and George W. Bush, who presides over one of the most polluted states in the nation, ran as the candidate from Greenpeace.

title: Sports of The Times; Old P.S.A.L. Names Reminisce a Little
description: THIS time of year,'' Dolph Schayes was saying. ''This is when I really start to think basketball: the N.C.A.A. and the N.I.T., then the N.B.A. playoffs. This is the time.''

title: Deutsche Bank Announces Merger Plans With Rival
description: Declaring the era of ''Germany Inc.'' had ended, the chief executive of Deutsche Bank A.G. outlined a radical plan today to merge with the bank's main rival and spin off their retail businesses serving 10 million customers.

title: Jets Are Talking, but No Word on Johnson
description: Keyshawn Johnson's future with the Jets remained in limbo yesterday, even as a high-ranking team official said that the trade talk surrounding Johnson this week has been overblown.

title: Bagwell Offers Zeile Advice: Stop Worrying
description: Jeff Bagwell had a message for Todd Zeile before today's exhibition game: first base will not seem like work for very long.

title: Improper Medicare Payments Rose Slightly in '99 to $13.5 Billion
description: Improper Medicare payments to doctors, hospitals and other health care providers increased slightly last year, after falling sharply in 1997 and 1998, federal investigators said today.

title: Executive Resigns At Hill, Holliday
description: Chuck Kushell is resigning after four years as president at the New York office of Hill, Holliday, Connors, Cosmopulos, part of the Interpublic Group of Companies, to become the chief executive at an Internet consulting agency he is forming with five other executives.

title: Giuliani at the Whitney
description: To the Editor:

title: Report on July Blackout Finds Weak Links, but Not Neglect
description: The New York State Attorney General, Eliot L. Spitzer, said yesterday that Consolidated Edison must work aggressively to eliminate weak links in its distribution system to avoid another heat-related blackout like the one that left 200,000 people in upper Manhattan without power for 19 hours last July.

title: Judge Splits Decision In Bagel Dispute
description: What's in a name? When it comes to New York bagels, enough money that a federal district judge has had to settle a dispute between two bakeries that sell bagels under the famous H&H name.

title: The Rebirth of Morphine, Now Smiling and Lively
description: ''I'm like a mirror; I'm nothing till you look at me,'' the bassist Mark Sandman sang on ''The Night'' (Dreamworks), the last album by Morphine, the band he led until a fatal heart attack onstage last year. The lyric, one of many inevitably prescient lines on that death-haunted album, took on a brighter meaning on Tuesday night at the Bowery Ballroom, when Mr. Sandman's former band mates and friends rejuvenated his compositions under the name Orchestra Morphine.

title: Third-Quarter Profit at Heinz Rose by 3.5%
description: The H. J. Heinz Company said today that its third-quarter profit rose 3.5 percent, the smallest gain in three and a half years, amid falling sales of baby foods, canned tuna and pet products.

title: Gliding on Snow (That's the Idea)
description: We stood by a snowbank at the side of a deserted country road in Vermont, 12 miles from the Canadian border. The wind was howling, snow was falling fast and I was freezing. Having been on cross-country skis just twice in the last two years, I couldn't figure out which borrowed ski went on which foot. Feeling like a child who had forgotten his lunch, I began slogging uphill behind a French Canadian who sank up to his knees in fresh powder.

title: Dell Says Notebooks May Have Flawed Chips
description: Dell Says Notebooks May Have Flawed Chips

title: Internet Board Agrees to Overhaul Election Plan
description: March 10, 2000

title: 2 Are Said to Be Linked To 5 Killings in Bronx
description: Forensic and ballistic evidence links two suspects already charged with the murder of one member of a Bronx family a week ago to the killings of four other members of the same family, prosecutors said yesterday. Each has blamed the other.

title: Selfish Owners Balk At Realigning Teams
description: Baseball owners have this magnanimous outlook on realignment. Realign? Absolutely, they say. Certainly we need to do that. It will improve the game and our revenue, and heaven knows, we need more revenue. But what's that? You want my team to change leagues, change divisions? Oh no, we couldn't do that. Not us. No, let the other guy move. We have the right to say no, and by golly, we're saying no.

title: Arafat and Barak Meet, With Mubarak as Host
description: After more than a month of sniping at each other, Israeli and Palestinian officials met today for an informal lunch and pep talk from President Hosni Mubarak as they prepared to resume peace talks in Washington this month.

title: Corrections
description: Because of an editing error, an article yesterday about contract negotiations for doormen, elevator operators and other workers in apartment buildings in New York City misstated the number of union members. It is 55,000, including about 26,000 workers in apartment buildings and about 29,000 in office buildings.

title: 4 Brooklyn Officers Accused Of Working With Mob Club
description: A sergeant and three police officers in Bensonhurst, Brooklyn were arrested yesterday and accused of fixing traffic tickets and checking license plates for the owner of a mob-affiliated social club and turning a blind eye to gambling there in return for stolen tools and other favors, the authorities said.

title: Corrections
description: A picture caption last Friday about Ronald Reagan's birthday on Feb. 6 referred incorrectly in some copies to the duration of his marriage to Nancy Reagan. It has been 48 years, not 52.

title: SOFTWARE.COM AGREES TO BUY @MOBILE FOR $400 MILLION
description: Accelerating its growth in the wireless Internet market, Software.com agreed yesterday to acquire @mobile.com for about $400 million in stock. Under the deal, Software.com, a company based in Santa Barbara, Calif., that enables providers of Internet services to offer messaging services like Web-based e-mail, will exchange 3.75 million shares of its common stock for all outstanding stock and options in @mobile.com. Shares of Software.com rose $32.6875, about 29 percent, to $146.8125. @mobile.com, based in Bellevue, Wash., provides wireless instant messaging technology and wireless network services.

description: A Taste Test For Oscar Night

description: KEITH-John P. A memorial service for John P. Keith, former president of Regional Plan Association, will be held Wednesday, March 15, 4PM, First Presybterian Church, 5th Avenue and 12th Street, Manhattan.

title: William Hamilton, 63, Dies; An Evolutionary Biologist
description: William Donald Hamilton, one of the towering figures of modern biology and the man who helped to unify Darwin's principles of natural selection with a rigorous understanding of Mendelian genetics, died on Tuesday in Oxford, England. He was 63.

title: Suit Charges Police Beat 4 Owners Of Web Site
description: Four recent Ivy League graduates filed a federal civil rights suit yesterday asserting that they were terrorized and beaten by police officers from the Street Crime Unit as they drove home from work two months ago in Manhattan.

title: When the News Turns Bad, Valuation Suddenly Matters
description: VALUE is scorned and ignored. Money managers who pay attention to the traditional measures of valuation post horrible results and see customers flee. But even as value is disdained by the multitude, the seeds of its revival are being sown. This week's debacle in Procter & Gamble, in which a moderate profit shortfall caused the maker of Tide and Crest to shed $40 billion in market value, may be a precursor of what will happen as other beloved stocks fall by the wayside.

title: From the Keyboard, Arizonans Cast Votes
description: March 10, 2000

title: China's Controls on Rural Workers Stir Some Rarely Seen Heated Opposition
description: China's long-entrenched controls over where people may live and work have become a subject of unusual public debate here, with critics attacking the stringent efforts by cities to curb the entrance of rural migrants and bar them from choice jobs.

title: I.B.F. Strips Trinidad's Title
description: The International Boxing Federation has stripped the welterweight title from Felix Trinidad Jr., who beat David Reid for the World Boxing Association superwelterweight championship last Friday in Las Vegas. The I.B.F. had given Trinidad 72 hours to decide whether to defend the welterweight title or relinquish it.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SOSNOWITZ, HILDA S.
description: SOSNOWITZ-Hilda S. Born January 6, 1922, in Greeneville, TN, died March 4, 2000, in Palm Beach, FL. Daughter of Morris and Mollie Aron Snyder, widow of Leroy Sosnowitz, and deeply loved mother of Linda Sosnowitz and Alex Gelinas, Mark E. Sosnowitz and Jan Sosnowitz and John Tomkins. Grandmother of Paul and Michael Gelinas and Kito Sosnowitz. Beloved sister of Philip N. Snyder and Ruth and Louis Mendelsohn. Wonderful aunt and cherished friend. Contributions in her memory may be made to Brooklyn Heights Synagogue, 131 Remsen St., Brooklyn, NY 11201; Temple Beth El, Stamford, CT; or the New Moon, Woodstock, NY. Memorial gathering Saturday, March 11, 2000, at 3 PM, 2784 South Ocean Blvd., Palm Beach, FL.

title: Hard to believe, but the direct marketer Draft Worldwide will acquire the iconoclastic AG.
description: IN an odd coupling that makes Felix and Oscar seem almost like clones, Draft Worldwide, a giant direct marketing agency owned by the Interpublic Group of Companies, is joining forces with AG Worldwide, the brand strategy and advertising agency owned by the iconoclastic creative executive Peter Arnell.

title: Abe Hirschfeld Gets Term of 90 Days in Jail
description: Abe Hirschfeld, the mercurial real estate developer, was sentenced yesterday to 90 days in jail and fined $8,000 for violating a court-ordered rule of silence and placing advertisements in newspapers during his two criminal trials last year. The trials, on charges of tax evasion and hiring a hit man to kill his business partner, ended in hung juries.

description: NEAL-Alfred Clarence. On March 8, 2000 in Sarasota, FL., age 87. Former first Vice President of the Federal Reserve Bank of Boston, retired President of the Committee for Economic Development, teacher, author and economic consultant. Beloved husband of the late Marguerite (nee Stephenson) Neal, survived by four sisters and two brothers. Funeral services private.

description: Ken Livingstone is the ghost of Labor past, an unsettling reminder to Prime Minister Tony Blair of the antic politics, overheated oratory and excessive promises that the British leader believes made the party he pointedly now calls New Labor unelectable for two decades.

title: Pee Wee King, 86, 'Tennessee Waltz' Writer
description: Pee Wee King, an eclectic and innovative country music entertainer who was a writer of the pop classic ''Tennessee Waltz,'' died on Tuesday at Jewish Hospital in Louisville, Ky. He was 86.

title: Censors in the Subway
description: Rush hour on New York City's subways has never been for the faint of heart. Yet the Metropolitan Transportation Authority has decided that its clientele would flee the subways if they were allowed to see a new advertisement that compares a crowded subway to an overloaded cattle car. The ad, part of a campaign for transit improvements by the Straphangers Campaign and the Regional Plan Association, features a picture of subway riders under the caption ''With livestock it's called animal cruelty. With people it's called a morning commute.'' The authority rejected the advertising last week as being ''directly adverse'' to the commercial interests of the transit system. Or as one official explained, ''it might drive riders away.'' The idea that New Yorkers might stampede if subjected to the livestock comparison would be a joke if rejecting this ad were not so clearly a serious challenge to free speech.

description: WEPRIN-Jack. 1930-1996. A dear friend is always remembered with love. Marti

title: National News Briefs; House Committee Issues White House Subpoena
description: A House committee chairman subpoenaed the White House today in an effort to determine whether the administration failed to provide e-mail sought in the panel's investigations of campaign finance.

title: COMPANY BRIEFS
description: TYCO INTERNATIONAL LTD., Bermuda, the world's largest maker of electronic connectors, said it would consider selling shares to the public in its businesses that make wireless-network semiconductors and fiber optics.

description: Report Says Privacy Challenges Are Significant

title: Gore Scents a Starring Role, and Seizes It
description: It was clear yesterday that the Senate would vote for President Clinton's judicial nominees, but so what? Vice President Al Gore had a chance -- his third in five weeks -- to cast his shadow over Senate Republicans. So he took it.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  MASTELLONE, BARBARA ANN (CAFFREY)
description: MASTELLONE - Barbara Ann (Caffrey). Of Monroe Township, NJ on March 9, 2000. Wife of Ron. Mother of Mary Ellen Clyne, Ann Marie Irmiere, Mitch and Linda. Grandmother of six. Daughter of Mary Ellen Caffrey. Sister of John, James and Michael. Visitation Sunday, 2-4 and 7-9 PM. Funeral mass Monday, St. Helen's RC Church, Westfield at 12 PM. For information contact The Gray Funeral Home, 318 East Broad Street, Westfield, New Jersey.

title: SONDHEIM'S BYGONE ERA
description: Stephen Sondheim, left, at the dawn of his brilliant career, with the ''West Side Story'' gang during rehearsals in 1957. Now 70, he speaks of the musical theater that he has outlived. A report by Frank Rich in The Times Magazine.

title: China Asks to Halt Arms Sales to Taiwan
description: China's foreign minister today blamed the United States for creating tensions between Taiwan and China and demanded that it halt all weapons sales to Taiwan.

title: Lipizzaner Stallions Dance Into Trade Brawl
description: If one-trick ponies dream, they dream of being Lipizzaners.

title: With Southern Comfort For a Loyal Following
description: Southern rock, that steadfast relic, wheezed into New York this week. With its leisurely pacing, its unregenerate lead-guitar worship and its unpretty musicians who just stand and play, Southern rock couldn't be more unfashionable by current pop benchmarks. But it's stubborn music that draws stubbornly loyal audiences; it played to packed houses.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SLOTKIN, BONNIE
description: SLOTKIN-Bonnie. On March 8, 2000 of Potomac, MD. Adoring Mommy of David and Jon-her love for her boys was unconditional. Dearest mother-in-law of Sharon. Smitten MomMom of Jayme. Loving, selfless wife and best friend of Jay. Cherished daughter of Shayne and Harold. Beloved Ba-Ba of Melanie and Marc. Loving soulmate of Abbey. Treasured daughter-in-law of Marjorie and Raymond. Her vivacious love for life was contagious. She navigated any obstacle with the utmost poise. She taught us to keep our heads high in the face of any adversity. Her smile and laugh lit up our lives. She shielded us from pain, while radiating her vitality, love, and humor unto us. She was, and always will be, our source of strength. We will never forget you. Her synagogue, B'nai Israel Congregation, 6301 Montrose Road, Rockville, MD will embrace her one last time on Sunday, March 12, 2000 at 1:00 P.M. Burial at Judean Memorial Gardens. Shiva will be observed at the Slotkin residence through Tuesday. Memorial contributions may be made to The Jay Slotkin Fund for Neuro Muscular Research, Johns Hopkins Hospital, 600 N. Wolfe St., Meyer 5-119, Baltimore, MD 21287. Edward Sagel Funeral Direction, Inc., Rockville, MD 1-800-217-9403.

description: SCHAEFER-Kenneth J. December 7, 1938-March 11, 1969 Forever young, forever loved. The Famil

title: DIME BANCORP SUES TO FEND OFF HOSTILE TAKEOVER
description: Dime Bancorp, New York's largest savings association, moved to fend off North Fork Bancorp's $1.73 billion hostile bid by suing it for violating antitrust laws. Dime, which plans to merge with Hudson United Bancorp in a $1.29 billion transaction, said North Fork and the FleetBoston Financial Corporation -- which is helping to finance North Fork's bid -- conspired to derail Dime's plans. Dime argued that combining the branches of Fleet, Dime and North Fork would create dominant banks in New Haven, with 35 percent of the market, and Suffolk County in New York, controlling 43 percent of the market, and, thus, violating Federal competition guidelines.

title: Schools Chancellor Names a Deputy
description: The interim schools chancellor, Harold O. Levy, has appointed David Klasfeld, one of his top advisers, to be deputy chancellor for operations.

title: Officials Urge New Generator For Troubled Nuclear Plant
description: A growing chorus of elected officials from communities near the troubled Indian Point 2 nuclear power plant is urging its owner, Consolidated Edison, to replace an aging steam generator that sprang a leak a month ago, prompting the biggest alert since the plant opened 26 years ago.

title: Sports of The Times; The Inquiry That Won't Go Away
description: ST. JOHN'S had just defeated Miami in another blood-feud game between these teams, a game marked by the pushing, shoving and emotional tug of war that has defined this new Big East rivalry. Andrew Glover sank the winning free throws and Leroy Hurd missed what could have been the tying free throw for Miami. The Garden exploded, the St. John's players mobbed one another, and Miami players sank into their seats, in shock.

title: Special Election Will Tip the Balance in Nassau's Legislature
description: While Nassau County politicians were reluctant yesterday to publicly discuss the race to succeed Barbara Johnson, the Democratic lawmaker from Port Washington, so soon after her death on Thursday, they say privately that the political calculations have begun and potential candidates are being considered.

title: Alienation Overtakes Bradley Ranks
description: Bill Bradley's failed presidential bid enlisted many who were new to politics, drawing on privileged, idealistic supporters alienated by both the interest-group politics of the Democratic Party and the compromises of the Clinton-Gore administration.

title: Boston's Big Dig Has Given This Man a Big Headache
description: IT'S as if a tunnel had collapsed on top of James J. Kerasiotes and he were digging himself out of the debris with his bare hands, all the while calling up through the settling dust, ''Even so, everybody, really, this project is a success!''

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  BERMAN, EUNICE T.
description: BERMAN-Eunice T. Beloved wife of Ronald Berman, daughter of Walter Soffer, loving mother of Theodore and Erica, died on March 9, 2000 after a long battle with breast cancer. Eunice was a Managing Director and group head of Taxable Credit Research at J.P. Morgan Securities. During her 30 year Wall Street career, she touched the hearts of everyone who knew her and influenced hundreds of people in the financial services, electric utility, telephone, and natural gas industries. Eunice was a Chartered Financial Analyst and a member of the New York Society of Security Analysts, the Association for Investment Management and Research, the Financial Women's Association, the Wall Street Utility Group, and the Fixed Income Analysts Society, of which she was a founding member, and a member of Congregation Sons of Israel and Barnert Temple. She provided an example of excellence, both professionally and personally, and inspired countless numbers of people to achieve their ultimate potential. The funeral will be held on Sunday, March 12, 2000 at ''The Riverside Memorial Chapel'', 180 West 76th Street, New York at 10A.M. Shiva will be observed on Sunday, 7-9P.M. and Monday through Thursday, 2-9P.M. at her residence, 150 West 56 St., apartment 6703, New York. In lieu of flowers donations may be made to The Eunice Foundation, C/O Ronald Berman, 150 West 56 Street, New York, NY 10019.

title: WORLD BUSINESS BRIEFING: AUSTRALIA; AUSTRALIAN BANK DEAL
description: In what would be the largest takeover in Australian history, the Commonwealth Bank of Australia offered 8 billion Australian dollars ($5 billion) for Colonial Ltd., a banking and fund management company. The offer is 8.64 Australian dollars for each Colonial share. If the bid succeeds, Commonwealth Bank will become Australia's biggest fund manager and retail bank, with more than 9 million customers and an estimated 68 billion dollars under management. The merger is expected to lead to the closing of about 450 branches and the elimination of about 2,000 jobs. Nina Bick

title: Pursuing 'Real' Sound, With Artifice As the Ideal

According to legend, when the sun rose, the statue spoke, greeting Memnon's mother, the Goddess of the Dawn.

title: Provincial Angst and Sex, Soviet Style
description: Updating an opera from its historical setting to the approximate present can often represent lazy thinking on the part of a director, a gimmicky way to make an older work seem relevant. But the director Graham Vick's production of Shostakovich's great tragi-satirical opera, ''Lady Macbeth of the Mtsensk District,'' unveiled at the Metropolitan Opera in 1994, demonstrates that the right kind of updating concept can be revelatory. The production returned to the Met on Thursday night, vividly conducted by Valery Gergiev, with the soprano Catherine Malfitano in an arresting portrayal of the title role.

title: LEGG MASON, FINANCIAL SERVICES FIRM, ADDS PERIGEE
description: The financial services company Legg Mason Inc. agreed yesterday to acquire the Canadian investment management company Perigee Inc. for $205 million in stock to expand its presence in Canada. The Baltimore-based Legg Mason said Perigee would continue to be managed by its principals. The deal, which is expected to close in late May, would give Perigee an 8 percent stake in Legg Mason. Perigee is the ninth-largest investment management firm in Canada, with about $14 billion in assets under management. It manages assets for institutional clients and individuals. Legg Mason had $104.2 billion in assets under management as of Dec. 31.

title: Corned Beef, Cabbage And a Friday in Lent
description: Catholics are used to giving up meat on Fridays for Lent, but once or twice a decade, they are faced with a clash between tradition and religion: when St. Patrick's Day falls on a Friday, can they eat corned beef with a clear conscience?

title: NATO Chief in Kosovo Fears a Cross-Border Insurgency
description: The commander of peacekeeping troops in Kosovo, with the former political leader of the disbanded Kosovo Liberation Army beside him, vowed today to stop any insurgency mounted from Kosovo into Serbia.

title: WORLD BUSINESS BRIEFING: AMERICAS; NEW BANK PECKING ORDER IN MEXICO

The Spanish bank's initial stake in the merged company will be about 26 percent, according to Ricardo Guajardo, above, Bancomer's chairman, who will be chairman of the combined bank. Dan Fineren

description: Alcoa Inc., which gained the most of any stock in the Dow Jones industrial average in 1999 but has dropped 19 percent this year, plans to buy back as many as 20 million, or 5.5 percent, of the company's shares. The buyback is valued at about $1.34 billion. The company, the world's biggest aluminum maker, purchased 12 million shares since July under a previous buyback plan. Alcoa shares more than doubled last year and reached a high of $87.25 on Jan. 1.

title: HITACHI CUTS ITS FORECAST
description: Japan's biggest electronics maker, Hitachi Ltd., slashed its earning forecast 71 percent for the year ending on March 31 as it cut prices on mainframe computers more than expected. The company now expects net income of 10 billion yen ($94 million) for the year, compared with its previous estimate of 35 billion yen. A slump in demand for its mainframe computers forced Hitachi to reduce prices more than could be offset by rising sales of semiconductors and liquid crystal displays, the company said. It does not disclose the revenue from its mainframes.

title: RAMBUS, COMPUTER CHIP CONCERN, PLANS TO SPLIT STOCK
description: Rambus Inc., which develops technology to make computer chips work faster, plans to split its shares four for one after they have risen more than fivefold in the last 12 months. Rambus, based in Mountain View, Calif., surged $41.547, to $421. The split is the company's first since it sold shares to the public in 1997 at $12 apiece. The Intel Corporation is backing Rambus technology in its race against Advanced Micro Devices Inc. to sell faster chips. Rambus's technology speeds information from one chip to another in a personal computer, letting the PC take full advantage of the faster processors Intel is designing. Shareholders as of May 24 will receive three additional shares for each one they hold, payable on June 14. A vote on the proposal is set for May 23.

title: Corrections

title: Turnaround on Clean Air
description: After nearly a year of steady bad news, including adverse court rulings and the usual indifference in Congress, clean air advocates have now won two important legal victories in quick succession. The rulings are a tribute to the persistence of Carol Browner, who has made cleaner air the signature issue in her seven-year tenure as administrator of the Environmental Protection Agency. They also send a clear message to the big utility companies that own the aging, coal-fired power plants that lie at the root of many of the country's pollution problems. The message is that these companies are running out of places to hide from the judges and the regulators -- and that instead of seeking legislative relief from Congress, they would be better off accepting the inevitable and installing the pollution controls they should have built years ago.

title: Talks to Settle Oneida Indians' Land Claim Fall Apart
description: A federal judge declared yesterday that a last-ditch effort to resolve a long-simmering land claim dispute between the Oneida Indians and New York State had failed, setting the stage for years of additional litigation and percolating tensions in central New York.

Bob will be greatly missed. Funeral services will be held on Monday, March 13th at 11:30AM at the Church of the Presentation in Upper Saddle River, NJ.

But one thing that baffles him, he said, is the price of going online because Germany has such bewildering choices of rival providers. title: CORECOMM TO ADD ATX TELECOMMUNICATIONS
description: CoreComm Ltd., a telecommunications service provider, agreed yesterday to buy the privately held ATX Telecommunications Services Inc. for $900 million in cash and stock. CoreComm said the deal would expand its operations in the Northeast. ATX, which is based in Philadelphia, provides long-distance and local phone service as well as Internet access and Web site operating services to business customers in the Philadelphia area. It is expanding its services to New Jersey, Baltimore and Washington. CoreComm provides telecommunications services to business and residential customers across the United States. CoreComm's stock jumped $6.6875, to $47.875, in Nasdaq trading.

Net income rose to 393 million euros ($380 million) in the last six months of 1999, from 292 million in the period a year earlier. The chief executive, Bertrand Collomb, said he expected ''as good growth in 2000 as in 1999.'' Lafarge is benefiting from growing demand for cement in Asia and Europe as well as rising prices in North America as economies expand around the world.

Reliable technology not only isn't here yet, but isn't on the horizon.

description: Addressing the nettlesome question of what race people will be considered if they check more than one racial category on their census forms, the Clinton administration declared today that those listing themselves as white and a member of a minority will be counted as a minority.

description: Even on paper, Carnegie Hall's expansive Perspectives series seemed like a good idea: by giving Daniel Barenboim, Pierre Boulez and Maurizio Pollini the freedom to compile programs that show the breadth of their musical interests, the series shakes up the comfortable but tired norm of concert presentation in which starry conductors and ensembles fly in, play a few concerts and then hop off to their next tour stop. It also leans on the imaginations of its honorees, challenging them to come up with programs that reach beyond the usual.

Waste Management, which has suffered from management turmoil, accounting irregularities and a slumping stock price, said it would use the proceeds from the sale to reduce debt, make selective acquisitions in North America and repurchase shares. Shanks is one of the largest landfill and waste disposal companies in Britain and Belgium. Waste Management's shares, which have lost nearly 77 percent of their value in the last 10 months, rose 18.75 cents, to $14.125.

Gunshots, sirens, car screeches, turntable scratching and lyrics played backward conceal words deemed dirty, derogatory or harmful to minors. title: Builder Fights to Finish High-Rise the City Says Never Began
description: The city has rejected the appeal of a developer who wants to build a 20-story high-rise on West 18th Street, where zoning rules were changed last year before the building's foundation was completed. A six-story building would be allowed. But the developer, Martin Brody, vows to fight on.

title: Seeking Insight, Not an Intrusion
description: The world did not end in 1997 when Fox Sports inadvertently let the world hear Yankees Manager Joe Torre curse on national television. It was the second season that Fox equipped managers and coaches with miniature microphones and a technician let the taped comment slip onto the air.

title: Sequel to 'Manhattan' Is a Horror Film of Sorts; In a 3-Minute Short, Woody Allen Conjures An East Side Attack of the Skyscrapers
description: Woody Allen made a film last month that did not have the romantic kookiness of ''Annie Hall,'' the tortured family drama of ''Hannah and Her Sisters'' or the hot 30's jazz of ''Sweet and Lowdown.'' This film was short -- 2 minutes, 53 seconds -- and went into what Hollywood types would call extremely limited distribution: about a dozen copies.

title: THE GUIDE
description: Return of Comedic Duo

title: Opposition, and International Monitors, Crying Foul in Peru's Presidential Campaign
description: As Alejandro Toledo, the leading candidate opposing President Alberto K. Fujimori's re-election, arrived in this desert city he was met by the headline in the local newspaper: ''Candidate Offers Tacna Nothing.'' When he toured downtown, Mr. Fujimori's supporters threw eggs and tomatoes at his campaign caravan while the local police stood by and smiled.

title: A Model Anchorman Can't Escape the Microphone
description: ROBERT Trout came out of a cold drizzle and into a nearly deserted midtown restaurant the other day, ordered a bowl of risotto and a glass of red wine and began to chat amiably, almost shyly, about broadcasting, cab driving and Warren G. Harding. Mr. Trout is 90 years old, and while osteoporosis has bent his back and skewed his sense of balance, he is still the very model of the suave, modern anchorman. And still very much in demand.

title: 'Slab Rat'
description: To the Editor:

title: Edmonds Is Central to Yankees' Plans
description: Plucking on the same two chords of his guitar on this lazy morning, the center fielder of the Yankees was asked if he would balk at switching to left field if the Yankees acquired Jim Edmonds from the Anaheim Angels.

title: Speak, Monkey
description: WILD MINDS

title: Dirty Tricks, Circa 1828, In a Nashville Exhibit
description: ''Elect Jackson,'' an exhibition recounting the campaign in 1828 that led to Andrew Jackson's becoming the seventh president, opens Wednesday and runs through Nov. 10 at the Hermitage, Jackson's Greek Revival mansion in Nashville. The campaign between Jackson and John Quincy Adams made history as one of the dirtiest in American politics and is credited with reviving the two-party system and giving rise to the Democratic Party. It is also significant for the fact that Jackson directed the campaign himself from the Hermitage instead of deferring to party leaders.

title: POSTINGS: 13-Unit Condo Conversion in SoHo; Titanium Outside, Wine Inside
description: On a trip to Spain last August, Edward J. Baquero was fascinated by the titanium exterior of Frank O. Gehry's Guggenheim Museum in Bilbao. So he decided that the metal, often used in aircraft, would make up part of the exteriors of two penthouses atop the Loft, a 13-unit condo conversion at 30 Crosby Street, between Broome and Grand Streets, in the SoHo-Cast Iron Historic District.

title: My Dress Is Older Than Yours Is
description: On a sale rack at Jeffrey on West 14th Street one day shortly after Christmas, there hung a cap-sleeve minidress cut in the same ''Jetsons go to Coconut Grove'' manner that led Courreges, the Parisian house that made it, to prominence three decades ago. Originally $1,500, it was marked down to $800.

title: For High-Tech Merger, No New Jobs Soon
description: THE proposed merger between Computer Associates International Inc. and Sterling Software Inc. of Dallas will not open the thousands of technology jobs that some Long Islanders had hoped for, contrary to several recent reports.

title: The Ponzi Paradigm
description: Charles Ponzi wasn't the first to try it, but he has joined Dr. Bowdler and Captain Boycott among those whose names will forever be terms of abuse. And the classic scam that bears his name -- using money from new investors to pay off old investors, creating the illusion of a successful business -- shows no sign of losing its effectiveness.

title: Steel Guitar Masters Pluck Regional Styles
description: A POTPOURRI of traditional American music will be showcased when the Masters of the Steel String Guitar visit the Down Jersey Folklife Center at Wheaton Village in Millville next Saturday.

title: Flight of the Lama
description: It was 10:30 on the evening of Dec. 28, but darkness had descended over central Tibet just an hour before. (Sunset comes late here, because Tibet runs on the same clock as Beijing, 2,000 miles to the east.) In the remote, beautiful monastery of Tsurphu, the seat of the 17th Karmapa, head of the Karma Kagyu school of Tibetan Buddhism, most of the monks were already busy with their evening studies. Others were settling down to watch the 10:30 news on the television set that only recently had been installed.

title: Conversations With Sondheim
description: In the old rehearsal snapshots from 1957, three of the four men who created ''West Side Story'' look as cool as the Jets and Sharks. The choreographer Jerome Robbins, the playwright Arthur Laurents and the composer Leonard Bernstein are all dressed in 50's hip. Only the true kid of the group, the 27-year-old lyricist making his Broadway debut, seems out of place. Stephen Sondheim is in a tie and a loud, boxy sports jacket, his hair slicked back, his grin forced -- a geek trying to cut it with the popular crowd.

title: A Different Kind of Test Puts Value Funds at the Bottom
description: Value funds have been in the doghouse, performance-wise, for years. Now a study from Morningstar Inc. says they lag behind their growth-oriented rivals in socially conscious investing, too.

title: Gore's Achilles' Heel
description: Now that Al Gore has locked up his party's nomination for president, it's time for him to start thinking beyond his loyal Democratic base. How can he appeal to independent voters?

title: A Flier's Guide To Complaining
description: COMPLAINTS to the Department of Transportation about air travel doubled from 1998 to 1999, rising to 20,495 from 9,608. The major factor in the rise was the opening of electronic portals, including those run by private companies that pursue passenger complaints. Instead of having to write, copy an address and find a stamp, disaffected consumers can send their grievances by clicking a mouse.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  KATZ, MORRIS
description: KATZ-Morris. Sutton Place Synagogue extends condolences to our devoted members and benefactors, Janice and Barry Levites on the loss of Janice's beloved father. Our sympathies to the entire bereaved family. Allan Schranz, Rabbi Robert W. Berend, President

title: A Decorative Tree in Winter And Delicious Nuts for Fall
description: FILBERT trees stand out in late winter. While the rest of my trees have little more than incipient buds on skeletal branches, the filberts are covered with yellow drooping catkins of male flowers, as if they'd been lavishly decorated for spring.

title: Aiding the Neediest Cases
description: Perhaps the most striking thing about the Neediest Cases Fund drive is its diversity. The money gathered -- more than $6 million this year, second only to last year's record -- goes to help an extraordinary array of people, and it helps them in ways that specifically match their individual needs. Moreover, the drive reminds us that generosity takes as many forms as need itself. This is money raised in large amounts and small. It comes from people who can easily afford to give and from people whose giving makes a real difference in their own weekly budgets. The gifts are seldom thoughtless or offhanded. The money is given not so that we can dismiss from our minds the poor or the sick or the helpless but so that we can remember them.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  BRYAN, ROBERT C.
description: BRYAN-Robert C., former Executive Director of Amsterdam Nursing Home Corp., and a veteran of a distinguished naval career passed away on March 1, 2000. In fond memory of an extraordinary gentleman who profoundly enriched the lives of all who came into contct with him.

title: A Welcome Reminder
description: To the Editor:

title: Jennifer Hogan, Scott Murphy
description: Dr. Jennifer Ann Hogan, a daughter of Elizabeth Hogan and Dr. Richard Hogan of Hudson Falls, N.Y., was married yesterday to Matthew Scott Murphy, a son of Alan Murphy of Columbia, Mo., and the late Marcia Murphy. The Rev. Paul Cox performed the ceremony at St. Mary's Roman Catholic Church in Glens Falls, N.Y.

title: Gore Discusses Reform With Ventura
description: They looked like twins, in their blue jeans, cowboy boots and black shirts. But Vice President Al Gore pointed out the big difference between them -- Gov. Jesse Ventura's boots were tan ostrich and Mr. Gore's were black leather. The governor said the ostrich camouflaged the dirt.

title: Washington Arch's Majesty Is a 9-Year-Old Memory
description: Nearly a decade after the Washington Square Arch closed for repair, the 105-year-old marble gateway remains fenced off. Though some work was done on it last year, community groups say the city is neglecting the landmark.

title: U.S. Begins Lonely Fight To Cut Back Its U.N. Costs
description: A long, hard battle to lower American payments to the United Nations begins next week, and diplomats from a wide cross-section of nations say there is no guarantee that the issue will be resolved.

title: Political Briefing; Waiting for Perot May Be in Vain
description: The drive to draft Ross Perot for a third run for president seems to be making little headway.

title: It's Not What You Know, But When You Know It
description: EVERYBODY knows that executives of technology companies have gotten hugely rich in recent years on stock option grants. Now comes academic research identifying another vein of gold they are mining: nonpublic information about their companies' products in development.

title: Peter Singer Clarifies His Attitudes on 'Sentience'
description: To the Editor:

title: Uniform of the Day
description: O.K., so Stan Herman is a designer, not a journalist or an advertising executive (The Way We Live Now, Feb. 20). But did it occur to anyone that, in describing JetBlue as an ''explosive New York airline,'' he couldn't have found a more inappropriate adjective?

title: Against Rival, the Third Time Is Not the Charm for El-Amin
description: When fully engaged in basketball competition, Khalid El-Amin resembles an overflowing laundry hamper on wash day. His shirt usually protrudes in the front, gradually coming untucked over his waistband. Even while in motion, El-Amin nervously grabs the legs of his pants and bunches the material in his fists.

title: The Voice Is All
description: To the Editor:

title: Who Wants Pets? We Have 2 Children
description: WHO would have thought, when we decided to have babies, that we were also signing up to bring all manner of the animal kingdom into our home, too?

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  KOSSOWSKY, WARREN, M.D.
description: KOSSOWSKY-Warren, M.D. Dr. Warren Kossowsky, 65, died peacefully in his home on March 10. Devoted husband of Susan, loving father of Alisa Strauss and Andrew Kossowsky, father-in-law of Jay Strauss and Cori Burros, grandfather of Sophie and Jessica Strauss, brother of Bob Kossowsky, brother-in-law of Nancy Kossowsky and Richard and Alison Dundy. A dedicated, caring doctor, loyal friend, athlete and scholar, Warren's depth of kindness will live in our hearts forever.

title: Mrs. Clinton Assails Mayor on Schools
description: Seizing on what she said was the prime issue in the race for United States Senate, Hillary Rodham Clinton assailed Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani's stewardship of public education in New York yesterday, asserting that he had resorted to ''gimmicks'' to rescue a school system that she portrayed as on the brink of collapse.

description: To the Editor:

title: Missing Their Man, Devotees of McCain Wonder Which Way to Turn
description: Holly Hamilton, a high school English teacher in suburban Seattle, had never voted for a Republican -- until the recent presidential primary, when she almost giddily marked her ballot for John McCain.

title: The Precious and Powerful Art of African Money
description: THEY look like swords, hoes, horns and armlets. But the swords do not cut, the hoes do not weed, the horns do not sound and the armlets -- some weighing as much as 30 pounds -- must be unwearable. These copper, iron and gold artifacts are too dull, too long, too short, too thin or too weighty to function the way they look as if they should.

title: Books in Brief: Fiction; The Man of the Family
description: Tawni O'Dell's potent first novel, BACK ROADS (Viking, $24.95), features the recurring image of a rusty pipe stuck in a concrete block, the remnant of the satellite dish that 19-year-old Harley Altmyer can no longer afford, now that his mother is in jail for killing his dad. The pipe, sunk into the ground in the family's front yard, represents hidden danger to Harley's three younger sisters, and he tries to find a way to remove it. But it's also a symbol for the deep-rooted legacy of pain and perversion that runs in his blood, a peril not only to Harley but to those around him. Harley has been a victim of physical abuse, and he both fears and feels a similar impulse. Yet he generally represses it, and manages to focus instead on keeping what's left of his family fed and sheltered. Harley attends state-ordered sessions with a shrink and seeks sexual release in a doomed affair with Callie Mercer, the 33-year-old mother of his youngest sister's best friend. When Callie is found dead in an abandoned mining office in the Allegheny Mountains, Harley is the obvious suspect, though the truth behind the murder reveals the depths and horrors of the Altmyer family's vein of violence and twisted sexuality. Tense, conflicted and involving, O'Dell's novel deftly captures the voice of a teenage boy who's in trouble and facing profound challenges, even if the narrative sometimes feels dramatically inflated in order to prove its point: that evil runs deep and rooting it out is a difficult, thankless chore. Erik Burns

title: After Another Operation, Another Comeback for Canseco
description: Ask Jose Canseco about home runs, and he talks about health. Ask him about his place in the batting order, and he talks about health. Ask him about the weather, and he talks about health.

title: Area of Radioactive Soil Burns at Research Center
description: A small fire broke out yesterday morning in a field containing radioactive soil at Brookhaven National Laboratory, but no increase in radiation levels was recorded

title: No Welcome Mat for New York's Garbage
description: AS New York City moves to shut down its Staten Island garbage dump, the world's biggest, officials are considering proposals to send some of the garbage to Long Island, where it would be transferred to larger trucks and taken out of state.

title: California Votes In Conservative Initiatives
description: Fueled by a surge in conservative primary voters, two of the most controversial measures on the California ballot were overwhelmingly approved: a ban on the recognition of same-sex marriages and tough new penalties for juveniles who stray from the law.

title: Paid Notice: Memorials  TULLY, ANN MARIE
description: TULLY-Ann Marie (Auntie B.) Happy first anniversary in Heaven. Miss you dearly. Your Loving Famil

title: Your $40 Pledge, Her $3 Tote Bag
description: Several times a year, public radio and television stations pre-empt their regular programs for fund drives to remind viewers that they simply cannot do without another coffee mug.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  WALPIN, IVY LEE
description: WALPIN-Ivy Lee. The bereaving parents and sister of Ivy Lee Walpin sadly and tearfully announce the cutting short of her life at 48. May God give her the peace and relief she sought and deserved from endless operations and failing health. Unfortunately, love could not ameliorate her pain and suffering. Thank God for the affection she had for her ''super'' nephews, Alexei and Katiah. Shiva will be at her parents' home after the funeral Sunday morning.

title: Hal's Hope Surprises High Yield In Florida
description: The saga of Hal's Hope added a chapter of storybook drama today when the 3-year-old colt won the Florida Derby by a head over the favored High Yield, and advanced one milestone closer to the Kentucky Derby with Harold Rose, his 88-year-old owner, breeder and trainer.

title: The Capitals Take the Devils Right Back Down to Earth
description: Minutes after their nine-goal victory in Atlanta on Friday night, the Devils were talking about what a severe test awaited them tonight against the Capitals. The Devils were eager to see how they measured up against a good team after an outing that looked more like a scrimmage.

title: Home-Style, Yet Sophisticated Thai
description: THE Lemonleaf Grill, a new restaurant in Carle Place, features freshly made, home-style, yet sophisticated Thai cooking in unpretentious surroundings at eminently affordable prices. Its sometimes complex but never convoluted dishes offer a zesty, vibrant meshing of hot, salty, sweet and sour tastes, combining Chinese and Indian influences into a unique, distinctive cuisine.

title: FUEL OIL SPILL
description: Fuel oil overflowing from a rooftop tank at the Travelodge motel in Mount Laurel Township last week contaminated wetlands and local creeks before the problem was discovered and the pumps shut off, Rich Cahill, a spokesman for the federal Environmental Protection Agency, said. The motel owners have accepted responsibility and are negotiating with environmental cleanup companies to remove the 700 to 1,000 gallons of oil from the waterways. KAREN DeMASTERS

title: Joseph Terenzio, 82, Leader Of New York City Hospitals
description: Joseph V. Terenzio, a New York City commissioner of hospitals under Mayor John V. Lindsay and a strong advocate of public health care for the poor, died on Tuesday in a nursing home in Miami. He was 82 and had been in ill health since suffering a stroke in 1993.

title: City Tinkers With Rules Of Queens Blvd. Olympics
description: For pedestrians in Sunnyside, Queens Boulevard is the great divide. Officials blame residents' aversion to crossing its 10 lanes for everything from low turnout at a voting place to older citizens' decision to take the bus to a community center, even though it is close to many of their homes.

title: Home Buyers' Diversity Prompts Broker Training
description: WESTCHESTER is no longer the bastion of the wealthy and the white, a fact that real estate agents can ignore only at their peril. Although the county's population remains static, the ethnic makeup of its residents has changed dramatically. The latest figures from the Census Bureau show that the Asian population makes up 5 percent of the county's population, black residents make up 15 percent and Hispanic residents make up 11.6 percent.

description: Knick Knack Paddy Whack

title: Chuck Close Rediscovers the Art in an Old Method
description: FROM the moment in 1839 when Louis Jacques Mande Daguerre announced that he could capture an image of the seen world on a silver surface, the daguerreotype both threatened and enthralled visual artists with equal force. The first form of photography, it drove an industry of miniaturists virtually out of business. Yet its delicate precision fascinated such painters as Eugene Delacroix, who collected daguerreotypes and recommended them to his students as an aid for improving their rendering of the human body. Both Daguerre and the man who brought news of his process to the United States, the inventor of the telegraph, Samuel F. B. Morse, were painters, and they viewed the ''silver canvas'' not as a threat to art but as a new art form.

description: THE millennial fireworks are long since over, but this spring and summer art in Europe sparkles on.

description: THIS is the European summer for those intrigued by Asian dance. Homegrown dance will also be easy to find. There will be new work by Anne Teresa De Keersmaeker and Lucinda Childs, the latter with a text by Susan Sontag. Americans will be able to catch up on the work of Maurice Bejart, rarely seen these days in the United States.

description: I am just shy of my 25th birthday the night I might kill, or be killed by, two New York cops. It is February 1975. An arctic blast has emptied the streets of uptown Manhattan.

description: I was moved to read about the ordinary Germans who helped save Konrad Latte's life, and I was relieved that Peter Schneider didn't succumb to the temptation to turn them into heroes. However brave, they did what many other Germans could, and should, have done.

description: A Greenport man who charges that he was beaten by town police in two racially charged incidents 15 months ago has filed a federal civil rights lawsuit against the Town of Southold.

title: Children's Books; Bookshelf
description: THE COLORS OF US. Written and illustrated by Karen Katz. Holt. $15.95. (Ages 4 to 8) A delicious story about Lena, a 7-year-old who is ''the color of cinnamon,'' and about the colors she finds to paint portraits of herself and her friends. So many shades of brown. There's French toast, peanut butter, chocolate, peach, honey, autumn leaves, cocoa brown and butterscotch. The illustrations show these friends and others in delightful detail. An inspiring tale.

description: AYOUNG man who goes by the nickname Kaos confided several months ago that he wouldn't mind being perceived as a bad-guy computer hacker, but reputation-wise, things weren't working out.

description: WHEN an investment product makes a hot debut, investors may want to look closely before they leap. That may well be the case with sector Holdrs, a type of equity trust invented by Merrill Lynch last year that is fast becoming its signature financial product.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  KIMMEL, HARRY, M.D.
description: KIMMEL-Harry, M.D. Beloved husband of Tanya. Loving father of Dr. Marina Kimmel and Dr. Michael Finkelstein, Dr. Barbara and Eric Cherches, and Andrew and Robin Kimmel. Cherished grandfather of Evan, Rachel, Joanna, Carly, Brian, Cody-Rose, Austin, Jesse and Bri. Loving brother of Beatrice Sebastian of Paris, France. Physician of pediatric medicine for more than 50 years, first in Romania and then in New York City for over thirty years. In lieu of flowers, contributions may be made in memory of Dr. Harry Kimmel to the Pediatric Department at St. Lukes Roosevelt Hospital. Services Sunday 12:30PM at ''The Riverside,'' 76th Street and Amsterdam Avenue.

title: Taiwan's Open Wallets Bring Fear of a Bought Presidency
description: Three days before Taiwan held its last presidential election in 1996, the local boss of this busy fishing village in southwestern Taiwan called on Yang Cheng-ho. After shooting the breeze a bit, he got down to business: the Nationalist Party hoped it could count on Mr. Yang's vote, and to show its gratitude, the boss thrust a wad of bills into his hand.

title: Portraits Reflect Era of Upheaval During the 1960's
description: THE exhibition ''Singular Voices/Voices of Many: Photographs From the 60's by James Hinton,'' at the Hudson River Museum here, features 45 black and white photographs.

title: Scaling the Barriers of Literacy and Language
description: It is the second week of school, and Kathleen Sampson has been presenting the same lesson for several days: ''Amina is from Somalia. Somalia is in Africa. Da Quan is a boy. Da Quan is from China. China is in Asia.'' She builds sentences using facts about the students in the classroom, repeating them over and over.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  WHEELER, MARK C. JR.
description: WHEELER-Mark C. Jr. aged 50, died of complications of a brain tumor on March 10 in Milwaukee. Vice - Chairman - Commercial Group at Firstar Corporation, he had left New York banking only a year ago. At that time, he served Fleet Financial Group jointly as President of Fleet Bank, N.A. and as Managing Director of its Specialized Finance Unit. In past years, Mark had worked for Fleet in Boston and in New York at Bankers Trust and Manufacturers Hanover. He was a graduate of Lake Forest College and of the Harvard Business School. Beloved husband of Pamela and father of Ann and Samuel. A memorial service is scheduled for 1 pm on March 17th at the Wellesley Congregational (Village) Church in Wellesley Square, Wellesley, MA. Memorial Contributions in lieu of flowers may be made to Milwaukee Hospice Home Care and Rresidence, 406 North 92 Street, Wauwatosa, WI. 53222.

title: The Show At the Shows
description: HAVE the Paris fashion shows become irrelevant? Those last week for the fall ready-to-wear collections clearly demonstrated the conundrum in which many houses find themselves: they are so terrified of boring their audiences and losing their avant-garde status, they send out designs women can't relate to.

title: NEIGHBORHOOD REPORT: SUNSET PARK; A Scandinavian Area Sees Its Northern Lights Fading
description: When Signe Ellertsen bought her Norwegian novelty shop 19 years ago on Eighth Avenue in Sunset Park, she was in familiar company, surrounded by Norwegian bakeries and bars, the Sons of Norway across the street.

title: A Short List (Real Spanish Food) Grows
description: DURING peak weekend dinner hours at the new Sevilla (pronounced suh-VEE-yuh) in Cos Cob, would-be diners can expect to wait 40 minutes or more for a table in the tiny dining room, a somewhat shorter time at the crowded tapas bar.

title: Wherever He Went, Joy Was Sure to Follow
description: THOUGH Louis Daniel Armstrong was actually born on Aug. 4, 1901, he and his manager, Joe Glaser, apparently cooked up the idea that they might as well say he popped from the womb on July 4, 1900, which is why his centennial celebration will probably go on for two years. That's all right, too, since it might take that long for people to begin to comprehend how extraordinary Armstrong actually was. As the writer Albert Murray has observed, the mythical date of birth is true in every way other than the facts. That is to say that if there was one musician who most completely wrote the American Declaration of Musical Independence, it was Armstrong.

title: Beyond the Revelry: The Saintly Life Of Patrick
description: When St. Patrick's Day revelers take a moment to consider the man they are celebrating, they may realize they don't know much about the missionary bishop beyond his legendary banishment of Ireland's snakes. The producers of a new television movie are out to remedy this, and perhaps bring the myths surrounding Ireland's patron saint a little closer to historical truth.

title: Our Towns; Mrs. Manners Answers Call For Etiquette
description: ''THE next trick we're going to learn,'' Mrs. Herbert Christopher Hoover Jr. told the 27 girls around the table, ''is how to use the telephone.''

title: EUROPE 2000:FESTIVALS: (Multi)Cultural Capitals; Nine cities earn the title in 2000 -- from Avignon, which ponders the nature of beauty, to Reykjavik, which wonders what Vikings ate
description: Each year since 1985, one city has been named European Capital of Culture by the Council of Ministers of the European Community. For 2000, nine cities have been chosen. Articles about two of them are in this issue: Krakow on Page 8 and Prague on Page 10. Below is a sampling of planned events. More information is available from the accompanying telephone numbers and Web sites.

title: . . . But Only They Can Shape a Tree
description: IF life in the big city is hard on humans, just think how rough it is on trees, especially the half million or so along New York's traffic-choked streets. Under constant assault from exhaust, accidents, disease, vandalism, dog waste, parasites and countless bicycle-lock chains, urban trees look as if they could use some T.L.C.

title: A Whitney Drops Museum Support Over New Show
description: Angry over a planned exhibit at the Whitney Museum linking Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani and other political figures to the Nazis, Marylou Whitney, the widow of Cornelius Vanderbilt Whitney, said yesterday that she had withdrawn her financial support of the museum and quit its national fund-raising council.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  HAFT, LILLIAN PARKER
description: HAFT-Lillian Parker. In her 100th year. Beloved wife of the late Joseph G. Haft. Adored mother of Helene and Larry Kurtis, Marlene and Arnold Haft. Loving grandmother of Joanne and Billy Marks, Marilyn and Michael Kurtis and Chris Haft. Great grandmother of her ''sweeties'' Jason, Lissy, Heather, Nicole, Samantha and Stephanie. Service Sunday, 12 noon, Riverside Memorial Chapel, 21 W. Broad St, Mount Vernon.

title: POSTINGS: Real Estate Board's Sales Report; Co-op Prices Increase In All Categories
description: With studios and one-bedrooms leading the surge, prices for co-op apartments of all sizes set records in Manhattan last year, according to the Real Estate Board of New York's Annual Cooperative Sales Report. ''Remarkably strong demand permeates this exceptional market, regardless of an apartment's size or age or location,'' said Hall Willkie of Brown Harris Stevens, chairman of the board's residential research committee.

title: When the Street Is Home, Lives Are in the Public Domain
description: THE SETTING -- Two men dressed in black rattled loose change in Greek-diner-style coffee cups, repeating the refrains of sidewalk solicitors, like ''Spare change, please'' and ''Show your love for the homeless.''

title: Corrections
description: The main front-page article in this section last Sunday, about the 1970 explosion in a house on West 11th Street where radicals were making bombs, misidentified one target of the radicals, Low Library at Columbia University. It is the administration building; the main library is Butler.

title: Blue Oyster Cult Hoping for a Resurgence
description: BLUE OYSTER CULT, once a multiplatinum rock 'n' roll band that filled arenas and had hit songs like ''Don't Fear the Reaper'' and ''Burning for You,'' is back in the studio after a decade-long hiatus from recording.

title: A more spacious Beaubourg
description: The Georges Pompidou Center in Paris has a new look and a new identity. True, its unusual pipes-and-glass exterior seems largely unchanged, albeit the better for a paint job.

title: A Small Step for Womankind
description: Women shoppers have often found it hard to find a bargain on shoes made by the Nine West Group. The company agreed to pay $34 million to settle charges by federal and state investigators that it had illegally fixed shoe prices since 1988. Unable to find all women who may have paid too much for shoes, the governments said the money will be divided among the states and dedicated to women's health, educational and safety programs. title: Cutting to the Chase: Awards for Actors Only

There's Roberto Benigni, getting a little too silly over his selection as best actor for ''Life Is Beautiful.'' But wait, Mr. Benigni isn't climbing to the stage over the theater seats and announcing that he's so happy he wants to make love with everyone in the world; he's onstage, lifting Helen Hunt into the air, announcing that he's so happy he wants to make love with Harvey Weinstein of Miramax.

title: Witches of Updike Flying to London
description: WHAT is to replace ''Miss Saigon,'' which has just ended a 10-year run at Drury Lane? Since this is London's oldest, grandest theater -- once owned by the dramatist Sheridan, who sat drinking nearby as it burned down and famously remarked, ''Surely a man may take a glass at his own fireside'' -- the answer is as important as it is surprising. The impresario Cameron Mackintosh is presenting a new musical by two Americans, John Dempsey and Dana P. Rowe, based on John Updike's novel about New England witches who use martinis and peanut-butter brownies to conjure up a demonic Lothario to be played by Ian McShane.

description: One of the National Football League's best personnel men was scouting a Penn State game last season, munching on a candy bar, trying not to get too much chocolate on his fingers or his fancy new binoculars, when he saw something that amazed him. The Penn State defensive lineman Courtney Brown was making an overwhelming power rush despite being triple-teamed, displaying his raw talent that has scouts drooling.

title: Living the Faith, Seeking a Home in Suburbia
description: ONE day soon, Samar Ibrahim will utter the handwritten prayer to Allah that she keeps in the kitchen, and find her way: ''I ask you because you are better than me, because you can and I can't, you know and I don't know, and you know the future.''

title: Gassing Up Goes Up
description: American drivers will have plenty of gasoline this summer, Energy Department analysts said. And they'll pay plenty for it: a national average $1.56 for a gallon of regular unleaded, much more in high-cost areas like New York City and California. By 2001, prices will be on their way down, the analysts said, assuming that oil countries step up production, as expected, and that there is no war in the Middle East. Those are big ifs.

description: IN pro football, the best players now resemble the cost of lobsters on a fancy menu. Just put ''market price'' next to their names.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  MYRON, ROBERT E., PH.D.
description: MYRON-Robert E., Ph.D. Hofstra University is profoundly saddened by the death of Dr. Robert E. Myron, Professor Emeritus of Fine Arts. Professor Myron received his BA and MA in Fine Arts from NYU and a Ph.D. from Ohio State University, where he was awarded a fellowship. Prior to joining the Hofstra faculty in 1953, he held faculty positions at St. Joseph's College and St. John's University. He was a member of the United States Air Corps from 1944-1946. A popular member of the Hofstra community, he will be remembered as a dedicated teacher and colleague. He is survived by his beloved wife of forty-six years, Marie-Rose, two sons, Daniel and Jacques, and a brother, Saul. Services will be held on Monday, March 13th from 9am-1pm at Krauss Funeral Home, Franklin Square, 1097 Hempstead Tpke, 516-352-2080. Burial will take place following the service at Pinelawn Cemetery. In lieu of flowers, contributions may be made to the Dr. Robert E. Myron Art History Scholarship at Hofstra University, C/O the Development Office, Hofstra University, Hempstead, NY 11549. In tribute to the memory of Dr. Myron, all Hofstra University flags have been lowered to half staff. James M. Shuart President John J. Conefry Chairperson, Board of Trustees Hofstra University

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  COOK FERRITER, JUDITH
description: COOK FERRITER-Judith, accomplished educator, died March 1, 2000 in Palm Desert, California. She founded Edgemont High School's Alternative Education Program in Scarsdale, NY in 1978 and served as Director for seventeen years. She was a resident of Larchmont, NY for thirty-three years. Her interests included education, music, and English literature. She is survived by her husband Roger; four daughters: Ellen, Catherine, Andrea, and Courtney; and four grandchildren. Memorial services to be announced. No gifts or flowers, please.

title: Where Science Makes Yachts Faster
description: IN his office at the Davidson Laboratory at Stevens Institute of Technology, Dimitri Donskoy has a big sandbox. But it is not for play. In it are buried rocks and other nonmetal objects along with defused anti-personnel land mines. To detect the mines, he sends seismic waves through the sand and uses sensors to create a digital image of how buried objects affect the waves. The mines, with their specific shapes and their hollow interiors, generate a particular digital image.

title: The Second Sexual Revolution
description: I would like to congratulate Hitt for his intelligent, funny and balanced article -- and to add my two bits' worth. There is yet a third ''revolution'' to better sex, besides psychiatric and medical treatment, and that is education. Most of us are brought up in rank ignorance of the functions of our own bodies and of erotic techniques. For example, there are simple exercises to strengthen the pubococcygeal ''love'' muscle in both men and women to help in arousal and erection. Male and female orgasms (which should be viewed not as a goal but simply moments of pleasure that occur along the way) can also be increased and prolonged with certain breathing methods. In fact, it is possible for a man or a woman to have long-lasting, full-body orgasms without any genital contact whatsoever. (Now that is safe sex!)

title: Some Suggestions On Social Studies
description: Shame on Dr. Andi Stix! Her response in the Q&A last Sunday [''Enlivening Social Studies to Meet the Test''] to the question that Anne Frank is an example of historical fiction is totally incorrect. Historical fiction is fictional accounts of past events or persons used to further explain an event in time. Certainly Anne Frank is not a fictional account of her life. Correct examples should have been ''Sing Down the Moon'' by Scott O'Dell, ''My Brother Sam Is Dead'' by Christopher Collier or ''Rifles for Waite'' by H. Keith.
