He wept easily -- but one film director said he fed on other people with the hunger of a praying mantis.

title: Suggestions for Making Hash With Leftover Corned Beef
description: SUPPOSE you decide to follow tradition and prepare corned beef and cabbage for St. Patrick's Day. And suppose you are then faced with an ample supply of leftover corned beef. Sandwiches would be one obvious option. Hash is another.

description: Republicans in Congress have begun to blame the Clinton administration generally and Vice President Al Gore in particular for the recent jump in the price of gasoline, and that seems sure to become a hot issue in the presidential race.

title: Audra McDonald Is Getting Up Close
description: AT 17, she won the Juilliard audition her way, improvising the last notes of Susannah's ardent fourth act aria from ''The Marriage of Figaro,'' after forgetting the ones Mozart wrote. Five years later, armed with a degree that permitted passage to the New York City Opera or the Metropolitan Opera, she headed instead for the far west reaches of Lincoln Center with a Broadway show tune in her heart. There, at the Vivian Beaumont, tryouts were in progress for a revival of Rodgers and Hammerstein's ''Carousel.''

title: A Good Fight Draws A Crowd
description: Whatever else John McCain's presidential candidacy accomplished, it drew voters. Eighteen states have already held Republican primaries. In 12 of them, voter turnout hit record highs. An analysis by the Committee for the Study of the American Electorate found that 13.6 percent of the voting-age population turned out, up 4.3 percentage points from four years ago and the highest turnout since Senator Barry Goldwater's campaign for the nomination in 1964.

His brother Kevin won the national indoor shot put title as a junior in 1997 and again in 1998.

One minted gold coins in the surrounding marshes. And two centuries later, the other turned the very marshland into a fortune all her own.

description: A woman at my gym is skeletally thin, and yet she exercises for hours. She appears to be wasting away, possibly killing herself. Does the gym have a responsibility to intervene? title: Paid Notice: Deaths  GRAYSON, STANLEY L.
description: GRAYSON-Stanley L. Died on March 6, 2000, age 92. Loving and devoted husband of Florence for 68 years. Deeply loved father of Nancy Lou Riccio; grandfather of Rebecca & Jim Fletcher; Victoria (Gahan) and Bert Cliche; Christopher and Katrina Gahan. Great grandfather of Rachel, Leila, Madeleine, and Stanley. Born in NYC. CPA; President of Grayson Shipping Lines; Controller of Tibbets, Abbot, McCarthy, Stratton Engineers; Controller and Associate Partner of Blauvelt Engineering Co.; Board Member and Executive Director of America-Israel Cultural Foundation; President of the Manhattan Chess Club. He began working at age 5 on a bakery truck and retired from the AICF at age 80. Stanley's integrity and leadership guided his family and business associates. We miss him greatly. Tickets.com, a Costa Mesa, Calif., company, has been selected as the ticket-selling service for the 2002 Olympic Winter Games in Salt Lake City.

title: In a Church's History, Helpmates for Spring
description: The Fordham Manor Reformed Church in the Kingsbridge section of the Bronx received a spring cleaning last week from volunteers from two Michigan colleges and an Iowa church. The congregation, which is now largely Hispanic, dates to 1696, when it was Dutch Reformed. The First Reformed Church of Orange City sent 19 volunteers to the 1941 church, while 30 more came from Michigan State University and Grand Valley State University in Grand Rapids. The Dutch left a long time ago, said the Rev. Irving Rivera, ''but the Dutch have come back this week.''

description: Bodega Dreams

title: The Ongoing Americanization of Michael Caine
description: MICHAEL CAINE'S cockney accent has become so much a part of his public persona that it always comes as something of a surprise to find him in a movie using a different one. And yet actors are always ''doing'' accents, and Mr. Caine has done his share. Indeed, in his most recent movie, ''The Cider House Rules,'' this Londoner sounds -- and looks -- convincing enough as a New England orphanage director to have won an Academy Award nomination for best supporting actor.

title: Campaigning in the New, Not-So-Solid South
description: ONCE it was solid, solidly Democratic. Then it began shifting, seemingly inexorably, toward becoming solidly Republican. And now? For the moment, at least, the South seems to have settled into a state of bipartisan equilibrium, where depending on the place, the year, the candidates, their resources, the economy and the issues, either party can prevail.

title: Six Authors in Search of Justice for Children
description: IN his celebrated 1950 film ''Los Olvidados'' (''The Young and the Damned''), the Spanish surrealist director Luis Bunuel chose brutal realism to portray the cruelty a gang of poor delinquents wreak on their weaker neighbors in the streets of Mexico City.

title: How a Black Man's Wallet Becomes a 'Gun'
description: When my fiancee's teenage son pleaded for a cell phone, his mother and I came back with an emphatic ''no.'' Like most people raising children, we want him to spend less time on the phone and more on his studies. But we also reminded him that he is a black teenager in New York City, where people of his description -- 6 feet 2, 200 pounds, with braids and the currently fashionable baggy pants -- attract disproportionate attention from wary citizens and the police. We do not want him mistaken for a drug dealer in the marginal neighborhoods he passes through in his travels around Brooklyn. Nor do we want him reaching into his pocket at some inopportune moment for an implement that in the bad lighting of a subway entrance might be mistaken for a weapon.

title: St. John's Rises Above the Turmoil and UConn
description: Stressed or not. Feuding or not. St. John's ended a difficult day -- better yet, a difficult Big East season -- by winning its first conference tournament championship in 14 years when the two backcourt mates who had lit into each other 24 hours earlier decided to light up Connecticut instead in an 80-70 victory that had plenty of love from the sold-out Madison Square Garden crowd last night.

title: Picky, Picky, Picky
description: My friend Benny did not know what a gimlet was. But when he tasted mine, he declared that it should have been colder and served in a chilled glass, and that I should send it back. It was the last thing on my mind. After all, we were lucky to have gotten a table at Bottino at the last minute. And even if he was a Hollywood player with a chauffeur-driven Mercedes waiting outside, who was I to make things harder for the staff? I told him my gimlet was fine, thanks, and it didn't require an upgrade. An evangelical look came over his face.

Lamenting that they were not meeting enough interesting men, these women in their 20's -- Sarah Rogers, Anne Enna, Margie Backstrom, Mari Nayvelt and Kirsten Bartok -- came up with a game to set one another up on blind dates.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  ALKIEWICZ, ANDRZEJ W.
description: ALKIEWICZ-Andrzej W. Formerly of Ridgefield, CT, died on March 9, 2000, at his home in Nevis, West Indies, after a short illness. Loved husband of Barbara Engel. Proud and loving father and stepfather of Maria, Christopher, Mark, Christine, Richard, Michele, Nicole and Roberta. Delighted grandfather of Kristen, Elizabeth, Kaitlin, Lily and Drew. Born in Poznan, Poland, on April 4, 1924. Survivor of Gross Rosen, Dora/Nordhousen and Bergen-Belsen Concentration Camps. He came to the U.S. in 1949 and pursued a successful career on Wall Street and in international consulting. President of Hoppin Watson and founder of Perception International. Andrzej often said that he had ''the perfect life''. He was a man of integrity, both civil and courteous. He was also a great dancer and grand fun to be with. He will be missed by his family and all his wonderful friends. The Funeral Mass will be at St. Theresa's Church, burial at St. Thomas Church, Nevis, West Indies. The family respectfully requests that in lieu of flowers, donations be made to The Yale Cancer Center, Attention: Dr. Lee Schacter, 333 Cedar Street, New Haven, CT 06520. The family also extends its heartfelt thanks to Carol Fowler, The Doctors: Schachter, Thwaite, Grossman and Jacob and all of those who gave so much help and comfort to him.

title: If You're Thinking of Living In/Amityville, N.Y.; An Easy Commute to a Victorian Past
description: RESIDENTS of Amityville, a 19th-century village on the South Shore of Long Island, may travel far and still face the same inevitable question.

title: A New Pharmacy Opens Near Hospitals
description: Last month, Boris Niyazov and his business partner, Alex Noskov, both pharmacists, opened ProHealth Pharmacy at 385 Second Avenue (22nd Street). Featuring vitamins, supplements and prescription drugs, ProHealth also has on-site private consultations with the pharmacists. Some products are arranged in categories like women's health, immune defense, cold/flu, and stress/insomnia/anxiety.

title: Close Call For Oscar
description: Imagine if some glittering Oscar presenter intoned, ''The envelope, please'' and got a brown envelope that read, ''You absolutely, positively have a chance to win $10 million!'' An Oscar moment indeed. Such a tableau was conjured by word that more than 1,000 of a missing 4,200 Academy Award ballots addressed to California members were found in a warehouse, mistaken for junk mail. The academy may just have to send out more ballots. And soon. The awards are March 26. HUBERT B. HERRING

title: When Nothing but New Masterpieces Will Suffice
description: WHILE waiting for the next Balanchine to fill the original Balanchine's shoes, the trick is to preserve his legacy and breathe fresh air into the company he founded. One solution, as the New York City Ballet demonstrated this winter, is to present an exuberantly danced season, introduce young and gifted dancers, and realize that there is no second Balanchine.

title: Seeking the Silver Screen's Missing Images
description: FOUR years ago, Carolyn Butts and Terra Renee were putting their souls on ice with day jobs and being creative in the interstices. Ms. Butts was working as a press secretary for a politician and publishing a literary magazine. Ms. Renee was working for an Internet company and making films. The two met at a professional gathering and discovered a shared hunger for voices and images reflecting black women's lives.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  LEE, MAIMIE
description: LEE-Maimie. March 6, 2000. Beloved sister of Patrick, Thomas, Clarence & Mailan Lee. Devoted aunt of Rupert Li, Michelle Lee and John Lee. Memorial service Tuesday, March 14, 1:00 PM at Frank E. Campbell, 1076 Madison Avenue at 81 St. Contributions in her memory may be made to Jacob Perlow Hospice at Beth Israel Hospital.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  PERLBERG, GERTRUDE
description: PERLBERG-Gertrude. In Palm Beach, FL, on March 9, at age 93. Beloved wife of 63 years to the late Fred Perlberg; daughter of Betty, and Isaac Ament, who died at age 106. Dear sister to Max Ament, deceased, she is survived by two older sisters, Anna Seidemann and Alice Blitzer, and one younger sister, Minna Black. Adored mother of Judith and Michael J. Chasanoff, Edward B. Perlberg and Hope Brown; cherished grandmother of Nancy and Michael Butler, Stephen and Susan Chasanoff, Robert and Veronica Chasanoff, Frederick Perlberg; caring great-grandmother of Daniel and Allison Butler, Jenna and Chloe Chasanoff; loving aunt to Renita Stern and Carol Pisano, Linda Weiss and Kenneth Black, deceased. No funeral services are planned. For remembrance, donations to Good Samaritan Medical Center, West Palm Beach, Florida, or any charity of choice would be welcome.

At that instant, the San Antonio Spurs began dancing around as unified as a string of paper dolls, using the pinwheel ceiling of Madison Square Garden as the backdrop for their championship celebration.

title: The Express Way
description: You're sitting all by your lonesome in a posh salon waiting for your color to set while the diva on the cell phone (with headset) two chairs down has a stylist plus assistant blow-drying her hair, a manicurist massaging her hand, a pedicurist buffing her foot and an aesthetician standing by with tweezers. There are steel magnolias who go to the salon to catch up on gossip. There are sybarites who spend the day passing from one pampering treatment to the next. Now, moving to the top of the food chain, there are the bottom-liners who get it all done at once, and salons and spas are scrambling to serve them. To see just how much of the traditional day of pampering could be crammed into an hour, I recently treated a small band of beauty underachievers to a sampling.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SUSSMAN, LEON, M.D.
description: SUSSMAN-Leon, M.D. The leadership of Beth Israel Medical Center and its parent company, Continuum Health Partners, acknowledges with great sadness the passing or our longtime friend and colleague, Leon Sussman, M.D., who dedicated himself to Beth Israel for almost sixty years. As a nationally recognized hematologist, Dr Sussman advanced the science of blood banking with such ground-breaking developments as ambulatory transfusion, paternity testing and autologous blood donation. He established Beth Israel's blood bank in 1946 among the country's first hospital-based, self-sustaining blood bank facilities and named the Dr. Leon and Ruth Sussman Transfusion Service in 1992. His foresight and expertise, as well as his extraordinary philanthropic support of the Medical Center, has helped us provide our patients with outstanding programs and services. His teaching of countless residents and medical students will ensure that his legacy endures. We all will miss him greatly. To his beloved wife, Ruth, his children and grandchildren, and all who loved him, we extend our heartfelt condolences. Morton P. Hyman, Chairman, Boards of Trustees Continuum and Beth Israel Robert G. Newman, M.D. President and CEO, Continuum Matthew E. Fink, M.D. President and CEO, Beth Israel Stefanie Steel Vice President for Development, Beth Israel

title: A Director With a Sense of Where He's Going
description: CALL it vision, or perspective, or intuition. Call it the residue of a boy's imagination (''From when I was about 7 to about 13, I had weird feelings, and people had to stay with me because I felt uneasy about the room or the house I was in.'') Ascribe it to a sensitivity earned from a youth in schools as the only Indian among Americans, the only Hindu among Catholics. Attribute it to the eye that is trained when a 10-year-old is given a movie camera, which he uses to make 45 short films before age 15. Whatever the reason, it should seem appropriate that M. Night Shyamalan -- M., for Manoj; Night, a name he adopted at 17 (''romantic, mysterious, poetic''); Shyamalan (pronounced SHA-ma-lan) -- would come up with ''The Sixth Sense.'' After all, it's a thriller about a boy, Cole, who sees things that no one else can see (dead people, as it happens), and it features an alarming secret, numerous clues to which have been sitting in plain sight. Mr. Shyamalan has a way of seeing things other people do not see, and recognizing things others are slow to grasp.

title: The Price for Taking Bribes
description: China executed Hu Changqing, a former provincial vice governor, for taking $600,000 in bribes. The government is seeking to demonstrate its resolve in cracking down on high-level corruption, which is damaging the Communist Party's reputation. Mr. Hu was the highest official ever put to death for corruption. An investigation has already linked dozens of relatively high-level local officials with a $10 billion smuggling ring in Xiamen in southern China. But many Chinese are skeptical that China's leaders will pursue the campaign to the top party ranks. When the Xiamen investigation was about to implicate the wife of the Beijing party chief, Jia Qinglin, party propaganda departments sprang to life, professing her innocence.

They responded that not everything is controllable when an undertaking is the most complex urban infrastructure project in the country's history. They have until Wednesday to come up with a plan to pay for the overrun.

title: Children's Books; 13th-Century Talent Search
description: The great Italian painter Giotto was born in the second half of the 13th century, and little is known of his childhood; even the date of his birth is disputed. The one story the historical record does provide, though, is a vivid one. Lorenzo Ghiberti's ''Commentaries,'' written about a hundred years after Giotto's death, describe a country shepherd more interested in drawing sheep and goats than in caring for them. The young Giotto used sticks to draw outside on rocks and in the dirt; he was discovered doing this by the master painter Cimabue, who was so taken with the boy's work that he immediately asked if he could become his teacher and mentor. The Italian art critic and writer Paolo Guarnieri and his wife, the illustrator Bimba Landmann, have used this anecdote to good effect as the inspiration for their picture book A BOY NAMED GIOTTO, translated by Jonathan Galassi (Farrar, Straus & Giroux, $17; ages 5 to 9). Guarnieri's young Giotto struggles with his artistic calling and talent and with his lack of technique. When he spies a beautiful painting being carried in a religious procession he is enthralled. '' 'Who made it? And how?' he asks in amazement.'' When he discovers the picture was created by someone named Cimabue he thinks, ''Certainly a painter would understand me.'' Later, when he meets Cimabue and goes to his workshop to see how pigments and gesso work, the young shepherd observes, ''Neither rain nor wind will ever erase this picture.'' The book's rich, gilded illustrations evoke the Byzantine style that preceded Giotto, while suggesting as well the more subtle colors and the emotional intensity for which he later became famous. In ''The Divine Comedy,'' Dante, a contemporary of Giotto, wrote, ''In painting, Cimabue thought to hold the field / Now Giotto is acclaimed by all / So that he has obscured the former's fame'' -- an achievement also alluded to in this gorgeous, deceptively simple book. Stephanie Deutsch

title: The Curious Popularity of Breath Mints
description: You'd think Seventh Avenue was facing a halitosis epidemic. Ever since the British-made Altoids hit these shores a few years ago, breath mints have been elevated to stylish accessory. No longer just an impulse purchase at a supermarket or drugstore, designer breath mints are now turning up at trendy shops, cafes and department stores. Alfred Dunhill has started carrying apres-cigar breath mints, while Starbucks and Borders Cafe both sell mints to counteract the aftereffects of latte. Neiman Marcus, Nordstrom, Marshall Field's and Target sell signature mints. At less than $3 a pop, they offer shoppers an inexpensive way to flaunt a logo. Kate Spade recently cashed in on the craze, selling $4 Clik-Clak tins in red, turquoise and ''Kate Spade green'' at her New York, Los Angeles and Boston boutiques. ''They were trying to think of things that would naturally go in a handbag,'' said Susan Anthony, a Spade spokeswoman. Even Tic Tacs have become chic. In Barneys New York's revamped Co-op, dressing rooms are wallpapered with boxes of them. But the coolest mints can't be bought: Bobbi Brown, the makeup maven, handed out promotional tins at the New York fashion shows. All the better for fresher air kissing. LAUREN DAVID PEDEN

And Alan Alda is brilliant as the brusque, wildly egotistical doctor who ended up sharing credit for having identified the virus. Matthew Modine quietly holds down the fort as the central character, the C.D.C. (Centers for Disease Control and Prevention) functionary who realizes just what kind of trouble the world is in for but can't get anyone with real power to listen him. No film has completely captured the emotional devastation of the first decade of AIDS, but so far this one, based on Randy Shilts's 1987 book, comes closest - Sunday at midnight on Lifetime.

The tradition began in 1997 with a one-time trail walk, which met with such enthusiastic tail wagging, the stable, which is run by the Somerset County Park Commission, offered the walks weekly. Martha Wells, the organizer, says dogs have showed up every Saturday, whatever the weather (27 dogs and 50 people attended the Jan. 2 walk). The events give people a chance to take a pretty hike of two or three miles, and the dogs look forward to socializing with their fellows, she says. Another benefit for people: no need to clean up after your dog. After all, no one cleans up after the horses. Walkers meet at the stable at 1 p.m. each Saturday (cost $3 a dog) and the walk starts at 1:30. Information: (908) 766-5955.

title: Drying Out Those Wet Basements
description: WATER in the basement can be a year-round problem, but it seems particularly acute during the spring and summer. In the early spring, melting snow turns into ground water that seeps through the soil. Pressure in the soil forces it through the foundation walls into the basement. Spring rains can trigger a deluge of water that dumps thousands of gallons of water around the house. This will percolate into the ground, where hydrostatic pressure will force the water through basement walls. In the summer, the humidity in the air condenses on the basement walls and drips down to form puddles on the floor.

title: The Way We Live Now: 3-12-00; Generation Rx
description: I have been treating a young girl since her father's sudden death six months ago. One Saturday night, while her mother is out with her new gentleman friend, she makes what we in the business call a ''suicidal gesture,'' which is much less than a full-fledged attempt, but obviously a sign that all is not well, and not likely to be, anytime soon. She is in the hospital from Sunday to Friday. On Friday, the ''discharge planner'' calls to notify me that my young patient will be returning home that afternoon. Her five days of covered hospitalization are now up, and since she is no longer a threat to herself (no suicidal gestures during the four full days of her hospital stay), and was never a threat to others, the H.M.O. says it is time to go and, by the way, it won't pay for family therapy. I suggest that a weekend of hanging around with her mother and the new beau is not a great treatment plan for an impulsive, nonverbal kid. A few more days might give her a chance to connect to the other kids on the unit, to have several sessions of family therapy with her mother, to come to terms with having found herself in a hospital in the first place. I tell the planner what a great girl this is (she is not a great girl yet; right now she is a sad, confused, self-pitying and irritable girl, but she might become a great girl, with some help) and the planner sighs.

title: Bookend; The Last Outsider
description: MORE than the literary traditions of other Western countries, the literature of the United States has relied on social and intellectual outsiders -- on madmen, crackpots, neurasthenics and dopeheads, on people who lived and died broke and often forgotten. Poe, the first great secular American writer, was an alcoholic and a newspaperman when the job offered neither prestige nor much pay, and since his time we can count few patricians and only a scattering of solidly bourgeois characters in our pantheon of lasting favorites. By the mid-20th century and the arrival of major postwar American writers like Norman Mailer, Flannery O'Connor, Ralph Ellison and James Baldwin, William S. Burroughs and the Beats, we had established a literary sensibility adamant about its status as opposition -- an opposition that, if it was not always political, was at least unmistakably spiritual.

title: Books in Brief: Nonfiction; Snazi Nazis
description: In Hollywood movies, Nazis have been good (Omar Sharif), bad (Peter Lorre) or funny (Peter Sellers). During World War II, when the film industry battled Hitler, Nazis were demonized. After the war, however, Nazi characters were given more human dimensions, as in ''The Young Lions,'' in which a Wehrmacht officer played by Marlon Brando showed his vulnerable, misunderstood and tormented side. Being cast as a screen Nazi had certain advantages. What actor wouldn't be willing to dress up in such snappy (and very photogenic) garb for his close-up? Many have, as Piotr Uklanski reveals in his curiously amusing though disturbingly obsessive compilation, THE NAZIS (Patrick Frey/Scalo, $39.95), an almost wordless (save for captions in the back) picture book of film and television actors who have portrayed Nazis. The book has no real organizing structure, just page after page of posed and action publicity shots, heroic poster paintings and gritty video captures (in color and black-and-white) of men in German uniforms, including Charles Bronson in ''The Dirty Dozen,'' Richard Burton in ''Massacre in Rome,'' Dirk Bogarde in ''The Night Porter'' and Ralph Fiennes in ''Schindler's List.'' Some images are eerie, like that of Anthony Quinn in ''The 25th Hour'' as an SS guard behind barbed wire holding up a copy of a Nazi propaganda magazine with his own picture on the cover. Some are haunting, like John Shea and David Warner as SS death camp overseers in the TV miniseries ''Hitler's SS: Portrait in Evil.'' One of Sonny Bono in ''Escape to Athena,'' is, well, absurd. Uklanski also intersperses comic images, like one with Michael Palin and Eric Idle from ''Monty Python's Flying Circus'' and a real surprise -- Buster Keaton in ''Due Marines e un Generale.'' Steven Heller

title: Starr's Successor Readying Final Reports on Clintons
description: Beginning as early as this week and continuing for several months, the special prosecutor for Whitewater matters, Robert W. Ray, will begin filing with a federal court a series of final reports on his office's investigations involving President Clinton and Hillary Rodham Clinton, lawyers who have been informed of the plan said this weekend.

title: Danger, Real and Affected, Lingers at Bikers' Jamboree
description: Bike Week 2000 headed for the finish wire on Sunday, leaving a trail of broken bodies and smashed motorcycles.

description: Justice Department Posts Cybercrime Web Site

title: Fiat Weighs Sale to G.M. Of a Stake In Auto Line
description: Fiat is close to selling a minority stake in its car operations to General Motors after apparently failing to sell the entire division to DaimlerChrysler, auto industry officials and executives close to the talks said today.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  COTTER, MARY VIRGINIA
description: COTTER-Mary Virginia, C.N.D. Died at the Provincial Center of the Congregation of Notre Dame in Ridgefield, CT, on March 12. She is survived by two brothers, Robert of Trumbull, CT and Thomas of Sarasota, FL. She is predeceased by a brother, Jack. She was formerly Professor of Biology at Notre Dame College of Staten Island. She had been Professor of Biology at St. Francis College in Brooklyn. She had also been a Professor at Marianopolis College in Montreal. Formerly a Provincial of the Congregation of Notre Dame, she was currently a college counselor at St. Jean Baptiste High School, Manhattan. Calling hours at 223 West Mountain Rd., Ridgefield, CT, 1:30-5 PM, on Tuesday, March 14, immediately followed by a Mass of Christian Burial. A Memorial Mass will be held at St. Jean Baptiste Church, corner of Lexington and 76th St., NYC, March 28 at 6:30 PM.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  MYRON, ROBERT
description: MYRON-Robert. Witty, handsome, smart-Bob enlightened and delighted Hofstra students and colleagues for many years. He brought Mayan and Mound building Indians to life-and us too. Sandy and Hy Enzer

title: Son Charged in Slaying Of a Brooklyn Man
description: A 74-year-old man was shot to death in his Brooklyn home Saturday night by his mentally disturbed son, who was then arrested, the authorities said yesterday.

title: Arab League Hotly Attacks Israeli Stand On Lebanon
description: Israel's ties with the Arab world received a fresh jolt today when a brusquely worded Arab League communique condemning Israel for its role in Lebanon prompted equally biting responses from leading Israeli politicians, one of whom called the Arab countries' attitude ''surreal.''

title: Rancor Over Selection of Chaplain Builds in the House
description: Of all the political trapdoors House Republicans have tried to tiptoe around this election year, the selection of the House chaplain, the man who delivers the morning prayer on the floor, was one few members ever thought would catch them by surprise.

title: Technologists Get a Warning and a Plea From One of Their Own
description: An unlikely prophet is voicing a plea for reason and restraint in the increasingly chaotic stampede toward the technological future.

title: No. 1 UConn Women Set for an Easy Start
description: There was not much reason for the Huskies to worry when the National Collegiate Athletic Association women's basketball tournament pairings were announced today. After all, Connecticut (30-1) was assured of being host to its opening-round game in the East Regional on Friday on its home court. The only surprise was which team the top-seeded Huskies would play. It will be Hampton University of Virginia.

title: Professional Wrestling vs. Harry Potter
description: Think Harry Potter has a stranglehold on children's best sellers? Think again. When Barnes & Noble recently convened a focus group of boys aged 11 to 14, the one hardcover each boy had bought in common was about a character named Mankind.

title: Cheap Oil's Tough Bargains
description: The press has trumpeted the news that crude oil prices are three times higher than they were a year ago. But it was the $10 or $11 price of February 1999, not the one today, that really deserved the headlines.

title: Spelman Prentice, 88, Rockefeller Grandson
description: Spelman Prentice, one of the last surviving grandchildren of John D. Rockefeller and a businessman active in oil and natural gas exploration, died on Thursday at his home in Montecito, Calif. He was 88.

title: Woman Fatally Stabbed In Harlem Apartment
description: A 43-year-old woman was fatally stabbed in her apartment in Harlem early yesterday, the police said.

title: Demystifying Sessions on the Couch
description: TALK IS NOT ENOUGH

title: Tango, Like Scotch, Is Best Taken Straight
description: Choreographers and dance company directors seem determined these days to fix unbroken dance forms, from flamenco to classical ballet, chiefly by fusing each with another form. That is one of the aims of TANGOkinesis, which performed on Thursday night in the World Financial Center Winter Garden as part of the center's free ''Celebrate Buenos Aires!'' festival.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SCHOENWIESNER, GERTRUDE
description: SCHOENWIESNER - Gertrude. The Officers and Staff of Local 1102 RWDSU and UFCW mourn the loss of a dedicated trade unionist and a loyal and trusted friend. ''Trudy'' was loved and respected by her members and coworkers for her honesty, integrity and sheer hard work. Trudy's devotion to the cause of working people has improved the lives of everyone she has touched. She will be greatly missed. We extend our sincere condolences to her family and friends. Frank S. Bail, President

title: Corrections
description: A pop review in Weekend on Friday about Orchestra Morphine at the Bowery Ballroom misattributed the music and the lyrics of ''Let's Call the Whole Thing Off.'' They were by George and Ira Gershwin, not Cole Porter.

title: Shots at Club In Brooklyn Kill One Man And Injure 2
description: A man was killed and two others wounded when gunfire erupted at a birthday party in a private Brooklyn nightclub early yesterday, the police said.

title: Aggressive Little Wines? China's Acquiring a Taste
description: Yao Yun pulls the cork on a bottle of red wine in a fashionable restaurant here and does something that might horrify a Frenchman: he pours himself half a glass and tops it up with Sprite.

title: A Crime, and Its Questions, Revisited
description: If John Mark Byers were a rich man, you might think he had bought his way out of trouble. But Mr. Byers, as he would be the first to tell you, is just plain folks. An apparently uneducated, overalls-wearing Arkansan who once owned a small jewelry store, he is the reason HBO's documentary ''Paradise Lost 2: Revelations'' is so horrifying and fascinating. It is also as disturbing as a film can be.

title: Spartans Repeat In Big Ten
description: Michigan State's Andre Hutson elbowed Cory Bradford in the nose during a scramble under the basket with seven and a half minutes left in the first half, temporarily knocking Illinois's leading scorer out of the game and permanently derailing the Illini.

title: Corrections
description: A film review in Weekend on March 3 about the documentary ''Homo Sapiens 1900'' misidentified the field pioneered by Gregor Mendel. It was genetics, not eugenics.

title: The Soul of A New University
description: In ''The Education of Henry Adams,'' describing his college experience under a curriculum that had not changed in several decades, Adams said he had received an 18th century education when the world was plunging toward the 20th. In a space of just a few years, education had fallen 200 years behind the times.

title: A Struggling Pulsipher Still Aims for Big Money
description: Bill Pulsipher is feeling the pressure. The Mets left-hander admits it. At 26, his world revolves around pitching, and right now it's on a wobbly axis.

title: Devils' White Is Among Sensational Rookies
description: With the rookie Colin White making it abundantly clear that he will remain a prominent part of the Devils' defensive rotation, the team finds itself with four rookies playing productive roles as the playoffs approach.

title: With a Yawn, Six States Await 'Stupid Tuesday'
description: It was supposed to be the Southern Super Tuesday, the day when the South finally muscled its way into the primary calendar and showed itself as a fearsome voting bloc. But Mike Francis now has a somewhat different name for it.

description: With a $2 million advertising campaign and other highly public warnings of an impending teacher shortage, the union representing New York City's teachers is leaning hard on Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani to give its members generous raises this year as he campaigns for the United States Senate.

title: Tribune Co. Is Seen in Talks On Union With Times Mirror
description: The boards of the Times Mirror Company, a media giant whose flagship newspaper, The Los Angeles Times, shaped and dominated Southern California for 119 years, and the company that publishes The Chicago Tribune were in advanced talks last night on a possible combination, according to a Times Mirror executive.

title: The Knicks Don't Flinch At the Sight Of the Spurs
description: As an opening moment in the evening, Latrell Sprewell took a look at the Knicks' demons before him and hurled himself through the turf of Tim Duncan and David Robinson like a rock from a slingshot.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  HACKETT, BRUCE C.
description: HACKETT-Bruce C. Age 61, died at his home in NYC, Friday evening, March 10, 2000. Mr. Hackett was formerly head of Global Equities and a member of the Executive Committee of Salomon Bros., Inc. He was most recently co-head of Global Equities at Wasserstein Perrela and Co. until early 1999 when he resigned for health reasons. Mr. Hackett was born and raised in Easton, PA, from which he attended the Lawrenceville School and Brown University. His career on Wall Street spanned nearly four decades, starting at Citibank, Bank of NY, Salomon Bros. and Wasserstein Perrela. He was also a member of the Board of Directors of the CBOE and the National Association of Securities Dealers (NASD). His wife Joann survives him with their two children Henry, age 11, and Daisy, age 9. In addition, he is survived by his brother Leeds Hackett of NYC and another daughter Ann Hackett of Pecos, NM. Mr. Hackett was a member and Governor of the Metropolitan Club of NY, a member of the Ardsley Country Club and the Southampton Club and the Meadow Club of Southampton, NY, and a Board Member of Project ALS. Friends may call at Frank E. Campbell, 1076 Madison Ave at 81 St, Sunday and Monday, 2-4 and 7-9 PM. Funeral service Tuesday, March 11, 10 AM, at St. James Episcopal Church, 71 St and Madison Ave, NYC. The family would prefer that in lieu of flowers or gifts that donations be made to Project ALS, 511 Avenue of the Americas, #

title: Gertrude Sanford Legendre, 97, Socialite Turned Hunter and Prisoner of War
description: Gertrude Sanford Legendre, an unlikely debutante of the 1920's who forsook society to become a big-game hunter and then to work during World War II for the Office of Strategic Services, predecessor of the Central Intelligence Agency, died on Wednesday at Medway, her historic lantation near Charleston, S.C. She was 97 and also had a home on Fishers Island, off Long Island.

title: Gore Assails Bush on Taxes And Calls Rival Inexperienced
description: Vice President Al Gore ventured into Gov. George W. Bush's backyard today and hurled spears at him, portraying his rival as so inexperienced that he would imperil Social Security for the sake of an unnecessary tax cut if elected president.

description: CIRKER-Hayward. The Friends of Rock Hall Museum of Lawrence, NY, mourn the passing of our Board Member, Hayward Cirker. His love of Rock Hall led to the Dover publication of ''Rock Hall: A Narrative History,'' forever linking him to our museum.

title: The Tribulations of Mozambique
description: The floodwaters in Mozambique have subsided, but the need to provide for the victims is by no means diminished. The United States and other wealthy nations should be generous in providing aid. Nearly a million of Mozambique's 17 million people have lost their homes, farms or food supplies. The official death toll of 400 is expected to rise into the thousands. Tens of thousands of villagers have fled their homes for the safety of high ground. The United Nations says 250,000 Mozambicans are now living in makeshift camps, and another 250,000 remain in ruined villages around the country.

title: Corrections
description: An article on Tuesday about Ralph Nader's Green Party presidential campaign misstated the year the party first fielded candidates on a statewide ballot. It was 1990, in Alaska. Candidacies in California came later, in 1992.

title: Machine Tool Orders Down 13% in Month
description: United States orders for tools that make manufacturing parts fell in January, with decreases in the Northeast, the South and the Midwest, according to an industry survey.

Cherished grandfather of Nicole Madonna, Nathaniel and Emily Silberstein, and Paul Nolan. Services Tuesday, March 14, 12 noon, at ''The Riverside,'' 76th Street and Amsterdam Avenue.

description: Spanish voters gave Prime Minister Jose Maria Aznar a decisive victory today, opting for another four years with a leader whose conservative fiscal policies have steered the country during a sustained period of economic growth and prosperity.

description: Saying ''we humbly ask forgiveness,'' John Paul II today delivered the most sweeping papal apology ever, repenting for the errors of his church over the last 2,000 years.

description: The arms and legs were removed from a crucifix outside St. Francis of Assisi Church in Brooklyn on Saturday night or early yesterday, in the most recent of about eight incidents of religious vandalism in the borough since September, Officer Valerie St. Rose said.

description: JACOBS-Lee. March 13, 1993. Miss you now more than ever. Our longing for you will never be healed by time. Aimee

description: Maybe it was the springlike weather, or the angry complaints of Republican voters who had to squint hard to find their presidential candidate listed in small print on New York's presidential primary ballot. But the past week saw encouraging signs that the breezes of political reform may finally be reaching Albany.

description: Three United States high school records were set, and Shalane Flanagan and Damion Drummond lost in upsets yesterday in the final day of the New Balance National Scholastic Indoor Championships at the Armory Track and Field Center in Manhattan.

description: During a weeklong road trip that began in California and ended in Pittsburgh on Saturday night with an embarrassing 3-1 defeat, the Rangers were reduced to their bare essentials.

title: Mostly New Cast Yields Old Result
description: The championship run began inconspicuously last April in the wake of the largely unexpected departure of five of Duke's top seven players. The holdovers Chris Carrawell, Shane Battier and Nate James went unbidden to Mike Krzyzewski's home to wish their coach well as he recovered from hip-replacement surgery, and to pledge their loyalty and to reaffirm their resolve.

title: Man Who Cried Candidate Has Bronx Politicians in Suspense
description: Larry B. Seabrook, a state senator in the Bronx, seems to be engrossed in his plans to oppose an incumbent congressman. At virtually every turn these days, the senator with the quick smile and hearty laugh will confer with friends, constituents or his fellow politicians about his fund-raising strategy, his political support and his resolve to beat Representative Eliot L. Engel.

title: Mighty Puts New Turn in Derby Road
description: The road to the Kentucky Derby, which took a dramatic twist Saturday when Hal's Hope won the Florida Derby at Gulfstream Park over the favored High Yield, took another turn today when Mighty won the Louisiana Derby in New Orleans over More Than Ready.

title: Sports of The Times; Jarvis Embarks On a Journey In the Spotlight
description: MIKE JARVIS passed through a thick, noisy crowd of well-wishers last evening as he led his St. John's players to their seats, where they would watch the traditional National Collegiate Athletic Association men's basketball selection show. Jarvis made his way through clusters packed three and four deep at ESPNZone in Manhattan, the place sizzling with the electricity of college basketball in March. They hollered, ''Congratulations, Coach,'' ''Way to go, Mike,'' ''Good job, Coach.''

description: To the Editor:

title: Forbes Uses 4 Covers For a Celebrity Issue
description: Forbes magazine had a pair of firsts last week. Not only did the magazine showcase its first cover to feature a pierced navel -- belonging to the pop star Britney Spears -- but it printed four different covers, becoming part of the latest trend in magazine publishing.

title: Post-Soviet Russia, too, insists its journalists follow the flag.
description: TWO news reports out of Moscow last week -- one probably false, one sadly true -- served as reminders of the rise of Russian journalism in the years just before the collapse of Communism, and its paradoxical retreat these days.

title: C.I.A. Director's Role in Deutch Case Is Disputed
description: George J. Tenet, the director of the Central Intelligence Agency, has defended his part in his agency's investigation of his predecessor, John Deutch, by arguing that he played a largely passive role in the matter.

title: Treasury Set to Auction Bills This Week
description: The Treasury's schedule of financings this week is confined to today's regular weekly auction of three- and six-month bills.

title: Diallo's Bronx Neighborhood Defies Stereotypes; Multiethnic and Poor, Soundview Is Neither All Shadows Nor All Contentment
description: When four police officers turned down Wheeler Avenue in the Bronx one night in February 1999, they saw a dark block in a high-crime neighborhood in a borough with an international reputation for danger. In part because of where they were, they read ominous shadows in innocent movements.

title: YankeeNets Enlists Investors To Finance Deal for Devils
description: YankeeNets will use outside investors to help finance the $175 million acquisition of the Devils, which has been pending since late last year.

title: Pitching Raises for Teachers
description: This is a 30-second commercial called ''Crisis,'' which the United Federation of Teachers has been broadcasting on New York City television stations since late January.

title: DNA Match Implicates Inmate in '79 Murder, Officials Say
description: Prosecutors in Westchester County say they have solved the 1979 murder of a young Mount Vernon mother by analyzing DNA evidence collected along a blood trail from the woman's apartment and comparing it with the state's database of DNA profiles of convicted felons.

title: AETNA FENDS OFF A TAKEOVER OFFER AND PLANS A SPLIT
description: Struggling to keep control of its business, Aetna Inc., the nation's largest health insurer, yesterday rejected a $9.9 billion takeover offer and announced plans to split the 147-year-old company into independent health care and financial services companies this year. Each new company would have its own stock.

title: Onetime Junior Champions Take Spring Nationals Title
description: Two young experts outdistanced the field to win the first major title at the American Contract Bridge League's Spring Nationals here on Saturday night. Mike Cappelletti of Red Bank, Tenn., and Larry Hicks of Coquitlam, British Columbia, both in their mid-30's, were resuming an old partnership. They represented North America in the 1989 World Junior Team Championship in England.

title: Yarnall's Debut Is Nightmare Inning
description: The Yankees' winter theory was that they could afford to trade Ramiro Mendoza because they have enough pitching talent to replace him. The rookie Ed Yarnall would become the No. 5 starter and someone else would fill Mendoza's role in the bullpen.

title: Glimpse of the AOL-Time Warner Future
description: Susan Wyland, the managing editor of Real Simple, a new magazine from Time Inc. that will arrive on newsstands in two weeks, sat in her austere office last week and showed off proof pages of the first issue. She pointed to an artful, stylishly minimalist photograph illustrating the article ''The Fastest, Easiest Way to Clean Your Bathroom.''

title: Corrections
description: The Making Books column on Thursday, about whether writers should remain loyal to small publishing houses that give them their start, misstated the month of publication for ''Girl in Hyacinth Blue'' by Susan Vreeland, a successful author who changed publishers. It was September, not December.

title: Forbidden Matters Then And Thorny Matters Now
description: By the middle of the first act of ''Waste,'' the nearly century-old drama by Harley Granville Barker at the American Place Theater, a vivid and effective discord begins to take hold. A play that opens as a mannered, drawing-room period piece -- the hostess of a weekend gathering is at the piano playing Chopin for her guests -- turns suddenly, with narrative grace but rather shocking frankness, into a complicated and unnervingly contemporary morality tale. When one guest, a rising politician, seduces a self-dramatizing young woman who happens to be married, if willfully separated from her husband, the events that unspool give the credibility of the national government a threatening shake.

title: Second Suspect Arrested In Killing of Volunteer
description: A second suspect was arrested yesterday in Friday's fatal shooting of a tenant patrol volunteer at a housing project in Far Rockaway, Queens, the police said. The man arrested, Hyman Tullie, 19, was charged with second-degree murder and weapons possession, Sgt. Brian Burke, a police spokesman, said.

title: Talks in Japan on Forming Banking Giant
description: Sanwa Bank Ltd. is negotiating to join the merger of Asahi Bank Ltd. and Tokai Bank Ltd., a combination that would create the third-largest bank in the world in terms of assets, executives close to the deal said today.

title: Some See Takeover of Fiat In Details of Deal With G.M.
description: General Motors and Fiat announced a strategic cooperation deal today that some analysts called a prelude to a G.M. takeover of the troubled automotive operations of Fiat, the Italian industrial giant. Fiat officials stressed that they expected their business to remain independent.

title: 3 Concerns Form Printer Venture
description: The Xerox Corporation said yesterday that it would announce a venture with the Fuji Photo Film Company and the Sharp Corporation to make low-cost inkjet printers.

title: White House and Clinton's Congressional Critics Feud Over Misdirected E-Mail
description: The Clinton administration and some of its Republican critics are quarreling over misdirected White House e-mail messages that were not produced when they were subpoenaed in 1998.

title: Allison Arrested
description: The starting forward Desmond Allison was arrested on charges of drunken driving and marijuana possession and is not expected to play in the N.C.A.A. tournament. Coach Tubby Smith suspended the 6-foot-5-inch sophomore on Sunday night.

title: Updating an Egyptian Femme Fatale
description: The orgy scene in ''Cleopatre,'' a big hit on the first tour of Serge Diaghilev's Ballets Russes in 1909, swept Parisians into raptures and the German Kaiser into congratulating Diaghilev in Berlin.

title: CDNow Deal With Sony and Time Warner Is Called Off
description: The online retailer CDNow and the direct-mail music giant Columbia House announced yesterday that their planned merger had collapsed for financial reasons, leaving both companies scrambling to find new strategic partners in the rapidly evolving market for recorded music.

title: A Tickling Tumor and an Urge to Laugh
description: Neurologists are reporting several cases in which small, tumorlike masses can cause people to feel as though they have to laugh.

title: Pataki and Bruno Back Bill to Let Patients See Malpractice Data on Doctors
description: Gov. George E. Pataki and the majority leader of the State Senate, Joseph L. Bruno, threw their support today behind a proposed law that would give patients access to information about doctors whose insurance companies had settled malpractice claims against them.

title: Albright Aide Cautions Both Serbs and Albanians
description: James P. Rubin, the State Department spokesman, urged both Albanian and Serbian leaders in Kosovo today not to play into the hands of President Slobodan Milosevic of Yugoslavia and to reject extremists who are behind recent violence.

title: Corrections
description: A picture caption in some copies on Sunday about Hillary Rodham Clinton's criticism of Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani's policies at a teachers' convention misidentified the woman pictured with Mrs. Clinton. She was Sandra Feldman, former president of the United Federation of Teachers, not Randi Weingarten, the current president.

title: A Big Maintenance Problem at the H.M.O.
description: The initials H.M.O. stand for health maintenance organization, but where, I'd like to know, is the ''health maintenance'' these organizations are supposed to provide? Despite the extensive reorganization of medical care that this country has witnessed in recent years, the system remains penny-wise and pound-foolish. And you, the consumer, are paying the price -- with your health as well as through your pocket.

title: Camby, After Practicing, Waits for Knee's Answer
description: Marcus Camby arrived early at Purchase College today, shot around and then joined the team for an hourlong practice. Then, as the rest of the team filtered to the locker room, he remained in the gym, first working on his shooting with the assistant coach Brendan Malone and then playing a not-so-spirited game of one-on-one with John Wallace. But what Camby could not determine from the hours he put in during his return to practice was whether or not he would be ready to help the team on Tuesday night, when the Knicks play host to the Houston Rockets.

title: Donating to the First Lady, Hoping the President Notices

title: Japan Is Back In Recession, Statistics Show
description: Defying official optimism, trillions of yen in government spending and other financial stimulants, Japan's economy showed its underlying weakness today in statistics that indicated a retreat back into recession during the final three months of 1999.

title: Judge Dismisses Charges Against Sharpton
description: A State Supreme Court Justice in Manhattan has dismissed charges against the Rev. Al Sharpton and eight other defendants accused of unlawful camping, assembling without a permit and breaching other city park regulations.

description: As St. John's met with National Collegiate Athletic Association investigators yesterday about Erick Barkley's qualifying SAT, his prep school coach talked about how the test was administered.

That said, Mr. Bush's fully justified criticism of Clinton-Gore fund-raising in 1996 should not divert attention from the fact that in the 2000 campaign debate Mr. Gore is right about how to fix the campaign finance laws, and Mr. Bush is wrong.

title: Purple Would Not Suit The Game's Top Passer
description: It was January in Jacksonville when Dan Marino saw his mortality flash before him as if he were watching a loud movie in Dolby stereo. His knees had been operated on so many times that they had aged in dog years. Marino called those operations ''oil changes.'' His throwing elbow pained him so much, he could barely bend it. And his arm strength, well, reaching the sideline with one of his bullets used to be easy; now it took a presidential order.

title: New Vaccines for the Poor

The proposal would address a severe problem. Malaria, tuberculosis and AIDS kill more than five million people each year. Yet effective vaccines do not exist, in part because most of the victims live in poverty and cannot afford drugs.

title: CHIRON SHARES DROP SHARPLY ON RESULTS OF DRUG STUDY
description: Shares of the Chiron Corporation lost almost a quarter of their value after the biotechnology company's experimental heart drug appeared ineffective in a large-scale study. Shares of Chiron fell $14.1875, to $45.75. The drug, designed to stimulate the growth of new blood vessels and increase blood flow to oxygen-starved heart tissue, did not appear to improve patients' ability to exercise any better than a placebo did. Initial results from a study of the drug, known as FGF, were presented at a conference last weekend. Chiron is one of a handful of profitable biotechnology companies.

title: Corrections
description: An article on Feb. 7 about efforts for job development in Willimantic, Conn., misstated the city's distance from the University of Connecticut campus in Storrs. It is about 11 miles, not 20. The article also misstated the population of the town of Windham during the heyday of a thread mill, now closed, that was once the town's major employer. In 1890, when the mill employed one-third of the town's residents, the population was about 10,000, not 21,000. A reader's letter dated Feb. 28 pointed out the errors; this correction was delayed by an editing lapse.

title: Pollution Takes Toll On Clouds and Rain

But they are essential to the formation of clouds and the production of rain and snow, and they also have a considerable cooling influence on the earth's temperature.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  DEL SAVIO, LOUIS
description: DEL SAVIO-Louis, of Lew Beach, New York, died on March 10, 2000, at the age of 89. Born in Caneva, Italy, on April 9, 1910, he was reared in the Bronx and was a member of Bricklayers Local 34. He was a founding partner of SalVio Masons, a leading masonry construction firm in New York City, whose accomplishments included Co-Op City, Rochdale Village, The New York Foundling Hospital and numerous residential and office buildings. He was a Charter member of the Subcontractors Trade Association of N.Y. and served on the Board of the Associated Brick Mason Contractors of Greater N.Y. He pursued his love of farming in Delaware County, serving on the Town Planning Board and as advisor to the Andes Historical Society. He is survived by his devoted wife, Louise Cason Del Savio, his loving children Louis, Jr., Arthur, and Rita Coscia; seven grandchildren; and ten great-grandchildren. He was predeceased by his first wife, Carmela DeLuca Del Savio; a son, Paul; and a granddaughter, Andrea Coscia. Contributions to the Beaverkill Valley Fire Department, HCR 1, Box 16, Lew Beach, NY 13758, or the Andes Society for History and Culture, P.O. Box 455, Andes, NY 13731 are welcome.

title: ECHOSTAR REPORTS ITS LOSSES GREW TO $219.9 MILLION
description: The EchoStar Communications Corporation, the third-largest United States satellite-television company, said yesterday that its losses widened to $219.9 million, or 97 cents a share, in the fourth quarter, from $113.3 million, or 68 cents, the previous year. That was more than the 64 cent loss expected by analysts surveyed by First Call/Thomson Financial. EchoStar increased advertising, promotions and equipment subsidies as it sought to remain competitive with DirecTV Inc., which is the industry leader, and win over customers from cable television. EchoStar, based in Littleton, Colo., added 1.4 million customers in 1999, an increase of 63 percent. It had 3.4 million subscribers as of Dec. 31. Shares of EchoStar fell $9.625, to $128.375.

description: KALKER-Leona Ruttenberg of Williamstown, Massachusetts and Boca Raton, Florida, died on March 12, in her 93rd year. The first and last wife of the late Harry Kalker, she was a caring and delightful mother, grandmother, and great-grandmother. In so many ways, her attitudes and perceptions were truly ahead of her time. As an example her views on nutrition anticipated many of today's established ways. She will be long held in cherished memory by her daughter Darce Davis of Rye, New York, her son, Philip Kalker of Williamstown, Massachusetts, grandchildren, Thomas, Jonathan, Jessica, Kathryn, Ginger, Peter, and three great grandchildren. A graveside memorial service is planned for late spring.

title: ZIONS BANCORP IS WARNED ON PURCHASE OF FIRST SECURITY
description: Zions Bancorp's financial advisers said yesterday that the price it agreed to pay for the First Security Corporation, a rival Utah bank, was unfair after First Security had warned that first-quarter profit would fall. The advisers, Goldman Sachs Group Inc., did not say what new information caused it to change its opinion. Zions, Utah's second-largest bank, postponed until March 31 the meeting in which its shareholders would vote on the offer to acquire the state's No. 1 bank. Analysts said Goldman Sachs probably changed its opinion on concerns that First Security may not contribute as much profit to the combination as Zions had expected. Zions shares rose 71.875 cents, to $37.96875. First Security shares fell 56.25 cents, to $11.50.

Michael Yeargan's Act I set suggests the interior of a church through just a few elements: black-barred gates that lead to chapel annexes; a scattering of votive candles grouped in a corner of the stage floor; a huge, dramatic silver cross that hangs oppressively from above.

description: It's becoming increasingly clear that Al Gore came within an inch of acquiring his own personal special prosecutor last year. But Attorney General Janet Reno wimped out at the last minute, ignoring the pleas of her own assistants.

title: Still Wary of Outsiders, Japan Expects Immigration Boom
description: This town an hour outside of Tokyo, unremarkable except for its sprinkling of Chinese and Southeast Asians, could soon be known as a forerunner of Japan's 21st-century immigration boom.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  WALSH, JAMES F.
description: WALSH-James F. of No. Reading, MA and formerly of NY, March 11. Husband of Mary P. (O'Hare). Also leaves three children, and two grandchildren. Son of the late James P. and Anna K. (Mulhern).

title: Metro Business; Federated to Expand Its Midtown Offices
description: Federated Department Stores Inc., which owns Bloomingdale's, Macy's and other chains, has signed a 15-year lease for 257,748 square feet at 11 Pennsylvania Plaza in Midtown Manhattan for its merchandising group's headquarters.

title: Microsoft to Back a Browser Keyword System
description: The Microsoft Corporation is expected to announce Tuesday that it is throwing its considerable weight behind a keyword system that aims to enable Internet users to navigate the Web without typing in the cumbersome addresses known as U.R.L.'s.

title: String Quartet, in Transition, Moves Beyond Disruptions
description: For a young ensemble, the Whitman String Quartet has already gone through more than the typical share of disruptions. There have been several personnel shifts and recently a change of name. Only two of the members, the violinist Michael Shih and the cellist Kristina Reiko Cooper, remain from the original configuration of Juilliard students who formed a professional group called the Magellan String Quartet in 1992. Patricia Sunwoo is the current second violinist, and the newest member is the violist Ori Kam.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  RIDLESS, MONROE
description: RIDLESS-Monroe. A loving uncle and constant friend to his nieces. You will always remain a part of our lives. Lyn Koplik, Helene Herman, Robin Ridless and Jaymie Ridless.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  ROSENTHAL, C. JULIAN
description: ROSENTHAL-C. Julian, M.D. The entire Beth Israel Medical Center family notes with sadness the passing of our dear friend and colleague, C. Julian Rosenthal, M.D., Chief of Oncology at our Kings Highway Division (KHD) and an attending physician at our partner institution, Long Island College Hospital. Dr. Rosenthal will forever be remembered for his tireless commitment to medical excellence and compassionate patient care. He will be greatly missed. To his wife Sanda, his children Lawrence and Irene, the entire Rosenthal family and all who loved him, we extend our heartfelt condolences. Morton P. Hyman, Chairman Board of Trustees Matthew E. Fink, M.D. President and CEO Henry Singman, M.D. President, Medical Board Robert L. Salant, M.D. President, Drs. Alumni Association Donald Ginsberg, M.D. Associate Medical Dir.-KHD Philip Schmidt, M.D., Pres. Medical Exec Committee-KHD John Byrne, Vice-President For Administration-KHD

title: I Love You, You're Perfect, Now Give Me Your Money
description: In the pre-Giuliani era, before street crime was abolished, some blocks along Broadway were home to operators of a diversion known as three-card monte or follow the queen. The enterprise required only a bottom-side-up cardboard box, three bent playing cards and a few accomplices and visiting suckers. The venturesome tourist or atypical New Yorker with more cash than sense was challenged to place a bet on which of the three cards placed face down on the box was the queen. No one, except a shill, ever came away a winner.

title: THE MARKETS: CURRENCIES
description: THE YEN GAINS. The yen rose as the first increase in Japanese business investment in nine months overshadowed the economy's slide into recession. In New York, the dollar settled at 105.55 yen, down from 106.22.

title: The Neediest Cases; $50,000 Gift Puts Amputee Closer to Dream House
description: Last April, in a widely publicized assault, Edgar Rivera was pushed in front of an approaching subway train by a stranger with a history of mental illness.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  LAURUSKA, ALBIN J.
description: LAURUSKA-Albin J., 80. Of Effort, PA. Formerly of the Bronx. Died Sunday, March 12. Mass of Christian Burial 11:30AM Tuesday from Our Lady Queen of Peace Catholic Church, Gilbert, PA. For further information contact Kresge Funeral Home, Broadheadsville, PA., 570-992-4768.

title: Madison Avenue considers the benefits and drawbacks of media megadeals.
description: AS Madison Avenue assesses the deal announced yesterday between the Tribune Company and the Times Mirror Company, the opinions reflect a belief in the power of consolidation along with a skepticism about whether the benefits will be as extensive as they are being billed.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  PERLBERG, GERTRUDE
description: PERLBERG - Gertrude. The Woodmere Club deeply regrets the passing of our longtime member, Gertrude Perlberg. We extend our sincerest sympathies to her family and friends. The Board of Governors The Woodmere Club

title: The Ballad Of a Tenor's Triumph; Ronan Tynan Offers Lyrical Inspiration
description: He walks onstage with the slight sway of a metronome and gives a mischievous grin made all the more impish by his fullback's frame. When he finally stops before the microphone, there comes a vague sense that a very public mistake is about to occur, that your man has somehow passed through the wrong door.

title: KING PHARMACEUTICALS TOLD TO HALT VACCINE PRODUCTION
description: King Pharmaceuticals Inc. was ordered by federal regulators yesterday to halt production of its flu vaccine because of manufacturing flaws, sending its shares down as much as 23 percent. The Food and Drug Administration cited problems with the purity and potency of the vaccine Fluogen made by King's Parkedale Pharmaceuticals unit. Fluogen had $28.7 million in sales in 1999. Shares of King, based in Bristol, Tenn., plunged $8.50, to $38.125. King shares have fallen 32 percent this year, compared with a 58 percent increase in the Russell 2000 Health Care Index.

title: For Fall, Ladylike Chic, Minus the Starch
description: After being abroad in the land of fashion, with a suitcase and Marianne Faithfull singing ''The Ballad of Lucy Jordan'' in your head as you drive around Paris, it is hard to come back to New York and the reality of clothes.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  KATCHER, MORRIS
description: KATCHER-Morris, M.D. The PLK-MSAS mourns the passing of their Past President and Chairman of the Board and beloved frater and expresses their deepest sympathy to his wife, Phyllis and the family.

title: WORLD BUSINESS BRIEFING: AMERICAS; MEXICO CREDIT UPGRADE
description: Less than a week after Moody's Investors Service upgraded Mexico's debt to investment grade, Standard & Poor's raised its rating on Mexico's debt from BB to BB+, one step short of investment grade. The announcement reflects S.& P.'s expectation that ''prudent macroeconomic policies will be maintained in the next administration by either of the two leading candidates in the presidential race.'' Dan Fineren

title: U.S. WILL ENDORSE EUROPEAN NOMINEE TO LEAD THE I.M.F.
description: President Clinton told Germany's chancellor today that he would accept Horst Kohler as the new head of the International Monetary Fund, ending a heated diplomatic contest over who would lead the institution that battles global financial crises.

title: Corrections
description: A picture with the Media column in Business Day yesterday, about the Russian government's treatment of two war correspondents, carried an erroneous caption and credit. The picture showed Artyom Borovik, who died on Thursday; it was by CBS News. (The Business Digest, in a cross-reference to the Media column, showed Andrei Babitsky, whose Chechnya coverage has irritated the Moscow government. He was photographed by Agence France-Presse.)

title: It's Invasive, It's Unpleasant And It Can Save Your Life
description: ''It's time. You're over 50,'' my internist said casually during my routine physical in November. ''I'm sure you don't want to hear this, but you really should have a colonoscopy. Is there colon cancer in your family?''

title: People
description: Iwan Thomis was named to the new post of senior partner and strategic planning director at JWT West, San Francisco, part of the J. Walter Thompson unit of the WPP Group. Mr. Thomis, who joins the new JWT West executive committee, had been senior vice president and planning director at FCB Worldwide, San Francisco, part of True North Communications.

title: Giving a Doctor His Due
description: To the Editor:

title: China and Taiwan Pursue Secret Nuclear Waste Deal
description: While they traded verbal hostilities this winter over Taiwan's political status, Taiwan and mainland China secretly agreed to pursue a surprising multibillion dollar deal in which more than 200,000 drums of radioactive wastes from Taiwan's nuclear power plants would be disposed of on the mainland in return for money and technical aid to the mainland's nuclear power industry.

title: The Pope's Apology
description: Over the course of his 21-year papacy, John Paul II has attacked the inhumanity of Communism and, more recently, the costs of unbridled capitalism. Now, in the twilight of his career, he has delivered a solemn apology for the errors of the Roman Catholic Church over the last 2,000 years. The pope's act of repentance, delivered as part of the liturgy of Sunday Mass in St. Peter's Basilica, was a courageous and historic declaration that many of his own cardinals and bishops opposed.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  BARON, ELEANOR
description: BARON-Eleanor. Beloved wife of the late Harry. Devoted mother of Marvin, Laura, David, Lorraine and Ed. Cherished grandmother, great grandmother and special friend. Dear sister of Leon Hyman & the late Dr. Gilmore and Jerome Hyman. Services at Boulevard Riverside, 1450 Broadway, Hewlett, L.I. today at 11 AM.

title: Just What's Going On Inside That Head of Yours?
description: Two hundred years ago, the German anatomist Franz Joseph Gall dazzled the public with his science of phrenology, the practice of divining personality and intellect from the shape of the bumps on a person's head. Each localized bump, he said, represented a different characteristic, like secretiveness, acquisitiveness or cautiousness. Later practitioners of phrenology even found locations for pampering children, gluttony and Republican politics.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  LEVINE, ABBEY
description: LEVINE-Abbey. Temple Israel of New Rochelle records with sorrow the death of its cherished member and extends its heartfelt sympathy to the family. Amiel Wohl, Rabbi

title: Front Row; A campy, sexually charged ad campaign: an examination of 'Beauty and the Beast' or a moment of confusion in fashion?
description: In the March issue of Elle magazine, a page introducing its spring fashion section informs readers that designers all over the world are having a love affair with femininity.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  JACOBS, MICHAEL
description: JACOBS-Michael. Temple Israel of New Rochelle records with sorrow the death of its cherished member and extends its heartfelt sympathy to the family. Amiel Wohl, Rabbi

title: Raptors and Sonics Are Fined $100,000
description: The tension has deepened between the National Basketball Association and its coaches over the issue of requiring miniature microphones to be worn during telecasts, with the league imposing fines of $100,000 apiece yesterday on the Toronto Raptors and the Seattle SuperSonics for the defiant actions of their coaches.

title: Campaign Briefing
description: THE REPUBLICANS

title: U.S. to Drop Longtime Ban On Luxuries From Iran
description: When moderates triumphed in parliamentary elections in Iran last month, they probably did not anticipate that their victories would resonate in the living rooms of wealthy Americans.

title: Giuliani Adds a Soft-Money Arm In an Effort to Fight Fire With Fire
description: Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani has set up a political committee to collect the largely unregulated donations known as soft money, and is asking supporters of his Senate candidacy to give as much as $50,000 per couple to attend the committee's inaugural dinner next week.

title: Strange New Math of Palm Inc.
description: Why is Palm Inc., which makes the wildly popular Palm organizers, worth more than 3Com, which owns more than 95 percent of it? Even in our current financial Twilight Zone, where losses are positive and price-to-earnings ratios meaningless, this anomaly is bizarre.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  PREVEN, RITA
description: PREVEN-Rita. Beloved wife of Donald. Devoted mother of Marc, Robert and Carole. Dear sister of Sandor and Norman. Loving grandmother of Jamie and Matthew. Services are today at 12:45PM at ''Parkside Chapel'', Queens Boulevard and 66th Avenue, Forest Hills.

title: Israeli Jets Pound Targets in Lebanon for Second Day
description: Israeli jets attacked targets in Lebanon for the second day in a row today, giving what Arabic-language newspapers here described as a military riposte to the 22-nation Arab League for its weekend meeting in Beirut and its harsh denunciation of Israel.

title: Campaign Briefing
description: THE REPUBLICANS

title: AMERICA ONLINE AND SEARS ENTER MARKETING AGREEMENT
description: America Online Inc. and Sears, Roebuck & Company agreed to market each other's products and develop a version of America Online's Internet service specifically for Sears customers. The program would provide direct communication with Sears customer service, special Sears offers and links to Sears Web sites. The 39 million holders of Sears credit cards will be able to pay America Online's monthly fee with their cards. Sears, based in the Chicago suburb of Hoffman Estates, Ill., will display America Online products and services at its 858 department stores. The company will also promote the service in its advertising. In exchange, America Online will promote Sears and its online shopping areas and products.

title: Man in the News; In the Midst of Upheaval, Yet Out of Public Sight: Horst Kohler
description: Horst Kohler, the veteran German banker now expected to run the International Monetary Fund, is not widely known, even in Germany. But he is no stranger to the kinds of seismic political and economic upheaval that come with the responsibility of managing a global lender to financially distressed nations.

title: In Their Own Words
description: GEORGE W. BUSH

title: A Suspenseless Tuesday Makes Gore and Bush the Nominees, Ready for a Long March
description: Vice President Al Gore and Gov. George Bush of Texas claimed their parties' nominations tonight, marking the official if anticlimactic end to their primary campaigns and the beginning of what promises to be one of the longest general-election campaigns in the nation's history.

title: Water Reports Failed, Environmentalists Say
description: The New Jersey Environmental Federation said yesterday that many of the state's water utilities failed to meet new annual reporting requirements that went into effect last year under the Federal Safe Drinking Water Act.

title: DEXIA BUYS BOND INSURER
description: The French-Belgian banking concern Groupe Dexia will acquire the New York-based municipal bond insurer Financial Security Assurance Holdings Ltd. for $2.6 billion in cash. The deal values the insurer at $76 a share. The company guarantees scheduled payments of principal and interest of municipal bonds and asset-backed securities. Financial Security's shares surged $14, to $71.6875. Dexia, a fast-growing European municipal lender, said the boards of both companies had approved the deal.

title: Pastoral Sounds Punctuated By Tensions
description: William Parker's Little Huey Creative Music Orchestra usually sounds incantatory: organized melodic motifs swim through a giant body of expressive honking, squealing, crashing sounds. Mr. Parker's bass playing has acted as the anchor for all of the group's work since it started in 1994. But the music he performed at Merkin Hall on Thursday, ''Songs for Mary Lou, Thomas and Bessie'' -- a suite that is part of the hall's ''Interpretations'' series -- had an altogether different personality.

title: Parking Rules
description: Because of the first, second and third days of Id al-Adha, alternate-side street-cleaning regulations will be suspended in New York City tomorrow, Friday and Saturday. Other regulations remain in effect.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  GABRIELE, TAREY ROBERT
description: GABRIELE-Tarey Robert, age 46 of Tuscon, AZ. formerly of Lebanon, PA. Beloved husband of Danita Layser Gabriele. Dearest Father of Skyler Joseph Gabriele. Loving son of Dr. and Mrs. A.M. Gabriele. Loving brother of Michael Scott and Timothy Blake Gabriele. Visitation 4:00-9:00 P.M. Friday at Hirsch Funeral Homes, West End Chapel, Lincoln Highway and Otto Blvd. Chicago Heights.
