A memorial service will be held 7:00 P.M., Monday, March 20th at Old Pine Street Church, 4th and Pine Sts., Philadelphia, PA. In lieu of flowers, memorials may be made to Cornerstone Christian Fellowship, 411 Cumberland St., Lebanon, PA 17042, 708-755-9014.

title: Mutt Obedience, Mafiosi Style
description: A play that is called ''The Dog Problem'' seems destined to be a shaggy one. David Rabe's loquacious new comedy, currently at the Long Wharf Theater here, obligingly fulfills the prophecy of its title, wandering hither and yon, bumping into the walls of probability and finally signifying nothing.

title: 10,776 Souls Open Hearts And Wallets For Needy
description: New York is, I firmly believe, the most charitable city in the world. Nowhere is there so eager a readiness to help, when it is known that help is worthily wanted; nowhere are such armies of devoted workers, nowhere such abundance of means ready to the hand of those who know the need and how rightly to supply it.

title: Insurers' Suit Accuses Doctors of Fraudulent Billing Scheme
description: Four major insurance companies have filed a joint lawsuit against a group of doctors -- including one whose license was revoked three years ago -- charging that they sold their names and licenses to chiropractors and other health care workers to steal insurance money.

title: Sandwich? A Mujaddara Is Much More
description: NOT long ago, my search for every possible variety of lentil took me to Kalustyan's, the 44-year-old shop on Lexington Avenue where just about every obscure ingredient from the Middle East or South Asia can be found. As I was browsing, I heard a man's voice from the back of the store: ''What kind you want today? You want hot sauce?''

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  BURROWS, GOLDIE R.
description: BURROWS-Goldie R., March 13, 2000, a resident of Pompano, Florida. Devoted mother of Lawrence Sporn. Loving mother-in-law of Patricia. Cherished grandmother of David, Jody, Lee, Matthew and Emily. Adored great-gradmother of Zachary. Services Thursday, 12 noon, at Beth Shalom Chapels, Inc., 760 Smithtown By-pass, Smithtown, NY. Interment to follow at Mt. Ararat Cemetery.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  HUPPERT, EVELYN
description: HUPPERT-Evelyn. Loving mother of Ronald, Ira, Louis. Sister of Sidney Milgrim and Seymour Milgrim. Grandmother of five. Interment Friday, March 17, 11AM, Mt. Hebron Cemetery, Flushing, Qns.

title: No Time Limit For Williams?
description: When Jayson Williams returns to the Nets' lineup within the next week, there is a possibility his playing time will not be limited by an insurance policy, the team said today.

title: 2 Men Are Indicted On Racketeering Charges
description: Two men believed to be members of the DeCavalcante crime family were indicted yesterday on federal racketeering charges accusing them of extortion and loan sharking on New Jersey construction projects from 1994 to 1999, federal prosecutors said.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  ATWATER, CHARLES B.
description: ATWATER-Charles B., age 85, died at his home on Friday, March 10. He was born May 19, 1914 in Elizabeth, New Jersey, the son of Edward S. Jr. and Jeannette S. (Brown) Atwater. Mr. Atwater was a 1931 graduate of Pingry School in New Jersey. He graduated from Princeton University in 1935, following graduation he served in the US Navy in WW II as Lt. JG. He received his Masters Degree in Education from Columbia University. Mr. Atwater was a teacher and headmaster at Pingry School in NJ. He then taught at Vermont Academy, Saxtons River, VT for five years and worked for the Windham Foundation in Grafton, VT. He was a member of the Immanuel Episcopal Church, Bellows Falls, VT. On Sept 11, 1938 in Scarboro, New York, he married Helen Emmens who died in 1998. He is survived by one son, Charles Jr. of Gambrills, MD, two daughters, Christine Atwater Jackson of Narbeth, PA and Sheldon Atwater Lekach of San Francisco, CA and four granddaughters. He was predeceased by one brother, Edward Sanford Atwater III. A memorial service will be held at the Immanuel Episcopal Church, Bellows, Falls, VT on Wednesday, March 15, at 3 pm. There will be no calling hours. Graveside service will be held at a later date in the Houghtonville, VT Cemetery. In lieu of flowers, memorial contributions in Mr. Atwater's memory may be made to the Charles Brown Atwater Scholarship Endowment Fund, Pingry School, PO Box 366, Martinville, NJ 08836.

title: Democrats Devise an Alternative to Clinton's Drug Plan
description: Moderate Democrats on the Senate Finance Committee are drafting their own proposal to offer prescription drug coverage to Medicare beneficiaries, as an alternative to President Clinton's plan, and they say their ideas could be a basis for a bipartisan compromise.

title: PUBLIC LIVES
description: Doodles in Bed And Cell Phones

title: European Regulators Halt Truck and Aluminum Mergers
description: European antitrust regulators took some of their most strenuous action against big corporate mergers today, blocking a planned $7 billion purchase by Volvo of the rival Swedish truck maker Scania and forcing three large aluminum companies to withdraw their proposed $17 billion combination.

title: Judicial Financial Reports Will Be Allowed on Internet
description: The judges who set policy for the federal judiciary said today that the judges' annual financial disclosure statements would no longer be withheld from organizations that want to put the information on the Internet.

title: E.P.A. Plans to Order Cuts In Diesel Fuel Sulfur Levels
description: The Environmental Protection Agency has decided to reduce sharply the level of sulfur allowed in diesel fuel, calling diesel emissions an important health hazard.

title: Big Game Hunting
description: The Discovery Channel even surprised itself with the success of ''Raising the Mammoth'' on Sunday, logging the highest number of viewers in the channel's 15-year history.

title: Corrections
description: A picture caption on Sunday with a front-page article about Vicente Fox Quesada, a candidate for the Mexican presidency, misidentified the town where he was campaigning. It was Sahuayo, not Tarecuato.

title: Virtual College, or Lively Campus?
description: To the Editor:

title: An Allegiance to Public Schools
description: BETWEEN a booming economy and reports of growing disillusion with public schools, you'd expect private school enrollment to soar. Yet the proportion of students in private schools has been falling nationwide.

title: Montreal Journal; Pokemon Wins a Battle but Not the Language War
description: With French billboards dominating the skyline, French prevailing in offices and boutiques, and tourism officials promoting this city on the St. Lawrence as ''Paris without jet lag,'' some Canadians argue that French North America is no longer under siege. Almost 250 years after losing the Seven Years' War, Quebecers can finally relax.

title: Man Surrenders After Robbing Bank
description: A man who robbed an Upper West Side bank of $4,500 last week apparently had a change of heart and returned most of the money yesterday, the police said. He was immediately arrested.

title: Webb Often Overlooked, But Never by Her Rivals
description: Karrie Webb has won every tournament she has entered this year, something that even Tiger Woods has not done. While Woods's exploits have dominated headlines in the golf world, Webb has also been brilliant, winning all three of her tour starts this year. If Webb wins this week's Standard Register Ping in Phoenix, she will become the first women's player since JoAnne Carner in 1982 to win four consecutive tour starts.

title: Retail Sales Remain Strong, Posting 1.1% Rise in February
description: Soaring gasoline prices did little in February to deter consumers from spending money on other goods like cars, food and clothes, a government report showed today.

title: More Surgery Planned for Berard
description: The injuries to Bryan Berard's right eye are so substantial that more surgery will be needed before eye specialists can tell how much of his vision -- if any -- can be saved, Dr. Rob Devenyl, a vitreoretinal surgeon with Toronto Hospital, said yesterday after examining the 23-year-old defenseman for the Maple Leafs.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  KAUFMAN, BETTY
description: KAUFMAN-Betty on March 13, 2000, of Sands Point, L.I. Born and raised in Plymouth, MA. Beloved wife of the late Louis. Devoted mother of Sandra and Howard Lipset. Adored grandmother of Andrew, Craig, Lance, Beth and Shani. Services today 10AM, at ''Gutterman's'', 8000 Jericho Tpk, Woodbury, Long Island.

title: CONSOLIDATED EXPLORES WAYS TO BOLSTER STOCK PRICE
description: The Consolidated Stores Corporation, the largest United States closeout retailer and operator of K-B Toys, hired Credit Suisse First Boston yesterday to help evaluate strategic alternatives to raise its stock price. Consolidated said it was exploring options that include recapitalization, business divestitures or combinations, stock repurchases or other means of enhancing shareholder value. The company's stock rose 93.75 cents, to $12.25 each, on the New York Stock Exchange.

title: Slain Girl's Mother Is Told 'You've Got the Wrong Guy'
description: Amid a huge news media stakeout reminiscent of the O. J. Simpson trial, Michael Skakel appeared in court for the first time today to face the charge that he murdered Martha Moxley, his friend and next-door neighbor, in Greenwich nearly 25 years ago, when they were both 15.

title: Favored Teams Lead in Bridge Tourney
description: All the favored teams survive in the Vanderbilt Knockout Team Championship at the American Contract Bridge League's Spring Nationals here, although two had to struggle Monday night.

title: Corrections
description: A brief report in some copies yesterday about Barry Toback, a Manhattan pharmacist who was arrested on cocaine charges, misstated his business affiliation. He operated the Bartob Pharmacy, which leased space inside the Pricewise Discount Pharmacy on Broadway near 81st Street. He had no other affiliation with Pricewise.

title: For a Winery, Value Is All in the Family
description: WHEN he graduated from Holy Cross College in 1973, Mike Benziger could have gone home to White Plains and built a nice life for himself. He could have joined Park-Benziger, the wine importing house founded in New York by his grandfather Joe 40 years earlier and run by his father, Bruno. But no. He chose to go to California for postgraduate work in skiing and surfing. To fill in the time between the slopes and the Pacific, he worked in a wine shop, using the knowledge he had acquired from the family business. He promptly fell in love with California wine.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  NOLAN, RAYMOND F.
description: NOLAN-Raymond F., 87, of Glen Rock, formerly of Ridgewood, on March 12, 2000. Born in Nyack, NY, Mr. Nolan had been a resident of Glen Rock for over 30 years. Prior to his retirement in 1977, Mr. Nolan had been an Assistant Treasurer with Texaco in N.Y. City. He is survived by his loving wife Mary C. of Glen Rock, a daughter Kathleen Nolan Taylor of Dover, NH, and two sons, Raymond F. Nolan III of Manchester, NH and Douglas G. Thompson of Nevada. Friends may call on Thursday March 16 from 2-4 & 7-9 at the CC Van Emburgh Funeral Home, 306 East Ridgewood Ave., Ridgewood, NJ 07450. A funeral service will be held on Friday March 17 at 11 AM at the Community Church of Glen rock with interment to follow at the Oak Hill Cemetery in Nyack. In lieu of flowers donations in his memory can be made to the Christian Home for Children, 275 State St., Hackensack, NJ 07601-5512.

title: THE MARKETS: CURRENCIES
description: THE EURO RISES. The euro climbed on speculation that European Central Bank policy makers will raise interest rates as soon as this week. In New York, the euro settled at 96.73 cents, up from 96.49 cents on Monday.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  ROTH, BERNARD SHELDON
description: ROTH-Bernard Sheldon. On March 13, 2000. Age 76 years. Best friend and husband of Virginia; loving father of Geneen and Howard; beloved grandfather to Grant and Alexander; loving stepfather to Melissa and Martha and beloved step-grandfather to Sasha and Bradley. Attorney, aficionado, businessman and a generous soul. We'll miss you. Services at 11:30AM on Wednesday, March 15 at Riverside-Nassau North Chapels, 55 North Station Plaza, Great Neck, New York.

title: EL SITIO EXPANDS BY ACQUIRING MEXICAN ONLINE RETAILER
description: The Web site operator El Sitio Inc. said yesterday that it had agreed to buy DeCompras.com Inc., a privately held Mexican online retailer, for $44.7 million in stock and cash. El Sitio, based in Miami, said the acquisition was part of its effort to become a major online seller of goods in Latin America. DeCompras, which began its Web site last year, sells a wide variety of goods, from technology products to toys. It had more than $1 million in revenue in its first eight months of operations. El Sitio provides content to Spanish- and Portuguese-language Web sites. It had $6.9 million in revenue last year. Its shares closed down $2.5625, at $19, in Nasdaq trading.

title: Digitas Soars in Its Debut
description: March 14, 2000

title: BP Amoco Moves to Seal ARCO Merger
description: Signaling that a settlement of the government's antitrust lawsuit is close, BP Amoco is preparing to announce that it has reached a deal to sell all of the Alaskan assets from its proposed merger with the Atlantic Richfield Company to Phillips Petroleum for more than $6 billion, two people involved in the settlement negotiations said late today.

title: Mets' Jones Expands Repertory on Mound
description: The most memorable of the 32 pitches Bobby J. Jones threw in the first inning today was a sidearm slider the Mets right-hander had never used during the regular season.

title: Three big advertising agencies kick off a worldwide partnership.
description: THE three partners in the world's newest giant agency company gathered yesterday for an unusual event that was part pep rally, part christening, part mixer and part Wall Street warm-up.

title: ALLSCRIPTS WILL EXPAND ITS OPERATIONS IN MERGER DEAL
description: Allscripts Inc. said yesterday that it would acquire the privately held MasterChart Inc. for $125 million in stock and cash in a deal that brings together two companies that develop technology used in doctors' offices. MasterChart, based in Bannockburn, Ill., makes a portable device that captures dictation and software that stores patient records. Allscripts, based in Libertyville, Ill., makes software that sends prescriptions from a doctor's office to a drugstore over the Internet. Allscripts stock fell $3.125 a share, to $79.875 each, in Nasdaq trading.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  WILSON, MALCOLM
description: WILSON-Malcolm, former Governor, State of New York, on March 13, 2000. Devoted husband of the late Katharine McCloskey Wilson. Devoted father of Kathy Wilson Conroy and Anne Wilson Matthews. Brother of the late Irene Wilson Baker, Donald C. Wilson and Mary Jane Wilson Couzens. Grandfather of Sean, Chris, Emmet, Brendan and Greg Conroy and David Matthews. Calling hours at The Fred H. McGrath &Son Funeral Home, Bronxville between the hours of 2 to 4 and 7 to 9 PM Tuesday and Wednesday. Mass of Christian burial Church of The Holy Family, New Rochelle, NY on Thursday March 16 at 10:30 AM. Interment Gate of Heaven Cemetery. In lieu of flowers contributions may be made to The Malcolm Wilson Scholarship Fund, Fordham Prepatory School, East Fordham Rd, Bronx, New York 10458 or The Katharine McCloskey Wilson Scholarship Fund, Notre Dame School of Manhattan, 104 St. Mark's Place, New York, NY 10009

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  LANE, NORA V.
description: LANE-Nora V., 84, died Saturday at The Medical Center at Princeton (NJ). Wife of the late Daniel J. Lane, she is survived by three sons, Daniel, Robert and Nathan and six grandchildren. Mass will be celebrated at 9:30AM today at Saint Paul RC Church, 214 Nassau Street, Princeton. Burial will be in Princeton Cemetery. Donations may be made to Broadway Cares/ Equity Fights AIDS.

title: Assembly Speaker Links Subway to Budget Vote
description: Sheldon Silver, the Assembly speaker, said today that there would be no state budget this year until the Pataki administration commits to building the Second Avenue subway the full length of Manhattan, and to a big increase in the state's contribution to the project's cost.

title: Making a First Impression
description: This 60-second commercial, titled ''Growing Up,'' is the first to be released by Jon S. Corzine in his campaign for the Democratic nomination for United States Senate from New Jersey. It will begin running today on television stations in New York City and Philadelphia, along with a 30-second commercial focusing on Mr. Corzine's health care proposals.

title: Spanish Harlem's Emerging Literary Voice
description: ON Friday morning, Ernesto Quinonez revisited his muse, Spanish Harlem, the changeling neighborhood where his childhood was spent and occasionally misspent, and where his talk-of-the-literati first novel is set. The trip was a bit of pre-publication business, and when an accompanying photographer asked him to pose by a wall mural, some passers-by promptly accused him of being famous.

title: Ex-Officer Gets Money From Gay Bias Suit
description: Nine months after a court awarded a Nassau County police officer $500,000 in a discrimination lawsuit against the cash-starved county, he finally collected his money yesterday after his lawyer froze $1 million in county assets.

title: Sports of The Times; The Ice Gets Thinner For Smith
description: At the trade deadline, the Rangers did what they have been doing all season: nothing. The Devils did what they needed to do: something.

title: Attacks on Firm's Computers Lead to Arrest of Programmer
description: A former database programmer for a Wall Street firm that provides software for online securities trading was charged yesterday with conducting coordinated attacks against the company's computer networks.

title: SCIQUEST.COM TO BUY SOFTWARE COMPANY IN STOCK DEAL
description: SciQuest.com Inc., which sells scientific products for laboratories, agreed yesterday to acquire Emax Solution Partners Inc., a provider of software for the life-sciences research industry, for $150 million in stock. After the deal, Emax will be renamed Emax Solutions. It will remain based in Newtown Square, Pa. SciQuest.com is based in Research Triangle Park, N.C. Shares of SciQuest.com tumbled $7.4375, to $60.6875 each, in Nasdaq trading.

title: Our Towns; After Injury, Added Insult Of Late Aid
description: THE horror began last Mother's Day. Sean Tobin, a young hospital corpsman at the Navy submarine base in Groton, told the police that he grew so frustrated with his 6-week-old son, who was crying and refusing a bottle, that he shook him until his ''neck appeared very loose and his head was rolling around.'' Then he slammed the baby on the couch.

title: PATAKI PROPOSES A BROAD PACKAGE OF GUN CONTROLS
description: Swimming against the tide of his own party, Gov. George E. Pataki today proposed a sweeping package of gun controls, including mandatory trigger locks with gun sales, a ban on assault weapons and steps to make it easier for the police to trace guns used in crimes.

title: THE MARKETS: Market Place; 19 Charged With Insider Trading Using the Internet and a Clerk
description: In the first criminal case involving the swapping of inside stock information over the Internet, the federal authorities accused 19 people yesterday of making $8.4 million on illegal tips from a part-time graphics clerk on Wall Street who passed some of the information through private chat rooms and America Online's instant messaging system.

title: Effort to Curb Binge Drinking in College Falls Short
description: Despite a decade of aggressive prevention efforts, heavy drinking on college campuses did not diminish in the 1990's, according to a study released yesterday by the Harvard School of Public Health. But attitudes toward alcohol among students have become more polarized, with increases in abstainers and in frequent binge drinkers.

description: The Orbital Sciences Corporation is one of the country's leading satellite companies. It launches rockets into outer space and wins contracts from NASA and makes devices that keep track of everything from ships to snow plows in Michigan blizzards.

title: HNC AGREES TO BUY PRIVATELY HELD SOFTWARE COMPANY
description: HNC Software Inc., which makes software that predicts consumer behavior, purchased the closely held Onyx Technologies Inc. of Atlanta yesterday for $44.1 million in stock and cash. HNC's products are used by insurers and financial service companies to gauge fraud risk in documents like credit applications and workers' compensation claims. Onyx Technologies makes similar software used by telephone companies. San Diego-based HNC wants to use Onyx's systems to start leasing its own products at lower prices. HNC shares closed down $2.625, at $111.25 each, in Nasdaq trading.

title: Europe and U.S. Reach Data Privacy Pact
description: The United States and Europe completed the wording yesterday on a data privacy agreement that will put strict new controls on how American companies collect personal information about European consumers.

I'm not suggesting that you are that someone -- neither am I -- but any butcher, including those who work in supermarkets, can and will perform this task pretty quickly.

description: Teachers of economics cherish bad policies. For example, if New York ever ends rent control, we will lose a prime example of what happens when you try to defy the law of supply and demand. And so we should always be thankful when an important politician makes a really bad policy proposal.

title: Closing the Books on Whitewater
description: Robert W. Ray, who succeeded Kenneth Starr as independent counsel, owes the American people a final report tying up the many loose ends of Whitewater and other aspects of a mammoth investigation that began six years ago. The $50 million inquiry covers a range of questionable activities involving Bill and Hillary Clinton that disappeared from public view the moment Monica Lewinsky came along. As a matter of both law and common sense, the public deserves a summing up -- delivered in one piece and delivered promptly.

description: SHALLOTS are like lingerie: a graceful and necessary underpinning, more appreciated in France than in America, and increasingly showing up in full view.

title: RUSSIA DEBTS DOWN, TAX REVENUE UP
description: Russia has reduced its debt obligations to 109 percent of gross domestic product from 150 percent a year ago, attributed in part to more effective tax collection, said Mikhail Kasyanov, Russia's first deputy prime minister and finance minister. Speaking before foreign investors, Russia's acting president, Vladimir Putin, and Mr. Kasyanov announced that businesses would be able to deduct from their taxes a far more significant portion of their expenditures on employee training, advertising and entertainment than they do now.

title: New Electronic Stock Market to Be Formed
description: Archipelago, an electronic trading network, said today that it would form what it called the first fully electronic stock market with the Pacific Exchange, the nation's No. 4 stock exchange in terms of activity.

title: MANAGEMENT: The Afterlife Of a Powerful Chief; 'I'm Actually Back Doing Things,' Says One Starting Anew
description: It was about noon on a Wednesday, and the retired Silicon Valley executive in a black V-neck sweater was considering a much more relaxed range of choices than he was accustomed to: Should he start with a merlot? Or perhaps a cabernet sauvignon? And should it be a recent vintage or an older, riskier one?

title: Graffiti Leads Police to 2 Boys, Who Are Charged With Arson at a School
description: Two Staten Island high school students who the police said left their distinctive graffiti inside an elementary school were charged yesterday with setting fires that caused extensive damage to the building.

title: National News Briefs; Washington State Limits On Taxation Are Voided
description: A state judge today struck down a sweeping law passed by the state's voters last fall that required a public vote on all tax and fee increases.

title: Peacekeepers Are Overwhelmed In Kosovo, Pentagon Envoy Says
description: In a sobering assessment of the deteriorating situation in Kosovo, a senior Pentagon official said today that the NATO-led peacekeeping operation, which includes American troops, had reached a ''decisive moment.''

title: CREDIT SUISSE NET JUMPS
description: Europe's sixth-largest bank, Credit Suisse Group, said second-half profit more than tripled, beating analysts' forecasts, as resurgent securities markets helped revive investment-banking earnings. Net income rose to 2.5 billion Swiss francs ($1.5 billion) from 700 million francs a year earlier. Like other banks, Credit Suisse's profit fell in the second half from the first, when the company earned 2.7 billion francs. Credit Suisse First Boston, the investment bank, rebounded to a second-half profit of 866 million francs after losing 1.27 billion in the second half of 1998, when a financial crisis in Russia sent stock and bond markets tumbling.

title: Micron in Deal For Kiosk Sales
description: Micron Electronics Inc. reached a deal today to put kiosks for ordering personal computers in 357 Best Buy stores.

title: The Selling of The Los Angeles Times
description: The trend toward consolidation of newspaper ownership is by no means new, but the Tribune Company of Chicago's agreement to purchase the Times Mirror Company offers several lessons about the economic and journalistic issues involved in today's mergers.

Terms were not disclosed. Lucent, based in Murray Hill, said it expected to complete the purchase in its third quarter, which ends on June 30. DeltaKabel sells modems and other equipment used to deliver high-speed Internet access and phone service through cable TV networks.

title: A Call for Sharing of Research Causes Gene Stocks to Plunge
description: President Clinton and Prime Minister Tony Blair of Britain said yesterday that the sequence of the human genome should be made freely available to all researchers. The statement led to a sharp sell-off in the stocks of biotechnology companies, which hope to profit by creating drugs based on genetic data.

title: Foods That Scorn the Efficiency Expert

But most of all, ''Italian Food Artisans'' by Pamela Sheldon Johns (Chronicle Books, $24.95) provides behind-the-scenes descriptions with alluring photographs to show how more than a dozen traditional Italian foods are made. The author also outlines the qualities that set those foods apart from their commonplace industrial versions.

title: Tuscan-Inspired Food to Fuel the Imagination
description: MAYBE it's the site on Cleveland Place near Kenmare Street, one of those timeless places in downtown Manhattan where the year could just as easily be 1925 as 2000. Or maybe it's the name, Va Tutto!, Italian for ''Anything Goes,'' complete with punctuation that demands you take heed. Either way, daydreaming comes easily at this warm and welcoming Tuscan-oriented restaurant, especially when it's 70 degrees in early March and a lovely garden looms invitingly through the open doors at the rear of the dining room.

title: Yanks Take a Tumble, But Hernandez Delights
description: Ken Caminiti was at the mercy of the Yankees' Orlando Hernandez today in an exhibition game, the count no balls and two strikes. But Caminiti fought off a fastball down and inside and dumped a single into short right field. The Yankees' pitcher watched the ball land, turned toward catcher Jorge Posada, and smiled.

description: After a week of bitter words and expensive fines between the National Basketball Association and its coaches regarding the wearing of microphones, the league struck a temporary compromise last night that, at least for one game, avoided a messy confrontation.

description: Ross Stretton, director of the Australian Ballet, has been chosen to become director of the Royal Ballet next year, it was announced today. He will be the first non-Briton to hold the post.

David, a long time supporter and advocate for persons with serious and persistent mental illness, worked extensively for not-forprofit organizations such as the Consumer Information Network and The Mood Disorders Support Group, Inc. At Pathways to Housing, David worked tirelessly as the Secretary of the Board of Directors and as a friend to Pathways staff and tenants. We extend our condolences to David's family and friends and share in their loss. Board of Directrs, Staff and Tenants, Pathways to Housing, Inc.

title: Dissonance At the Pump
description: The average price of gasoline has hit yet another record high, rising for the ninth week, to $1.53 a gallon. Such inflation is hard on commuters, trucking companies and owners of sport utility vehicles. But there is another vehicle-dependent class that may be among the hardest hit in the short term: rock bands and other touring musicians. For many fledgling acts crisscrossing the country on their own dime and performing low-paying gigs in hopes of building an audience, the surge in gas prices has been crippling.

The old Brasserie, which opened in 1959 and closed in 1995 after a kitchen fire, was so much a part of the city's fabric that the temptation must have been strong to reconstruct it, lovingly, piece by piece. Instead, Restaurant Associates called in Diller & Scofidio, an architectural firm that had never designed a restaurant, and turned it loose.

title: RAIL COMPANY HIRES TURNAROUND FIRM

In a six- month period that ended last September, Spoornet lost about $44 million. title: Found a Peanut And More at Hunts Pt.

But they seemed as scarce here as fresh bagels in Beaufort. Fried's, the dried-fruit and nut dealer next door to our Ludlow Street tenement, had hundreds of pounds of peanuts -- all roasted. ''Try Hunts Point,'' the counterman advised, then added, ''Wear your work boots.''

description: ROBIN KLEIN, a senior vice president at Chase Manhattan Bank, is loath to let her husband go grocery shopping. ''I've tried, but even when I make a detailed list he'll bring home the wrong brand, or the cottage cheese that's salt-free and you can't eat,'' she said. One memorable night he came home with two pounds of grapes that were turning brown. ''I went ballistic,'' she remembered. ''I was ranting like a lunatic over $3 worth of grapes.''

title: Egalite, Fraternite et Burgers

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  RANDOLPH, STEPHEN B.
description: RANDOLPH-Stephen B. A financial industry executive, died on March 12 at his home in Mt. Kisco, NY. He was 74. Born in Austria, he was a grand-nephew of Sigmund Freud, came to the US in the early 30's, and served in the Navy during the Second and Korean Wars. As an advisor for United Nuclear, he earned a patent for a radiation detection device called a Spintharoscope, and later became head of research for the Energy Fund, a partner at Ralph E. Samuels and an investment counselor at Neuberger & Berman. A life long lover of the mountains, his journeys ranged from Everest base camp to the summit of the Matterhorn. A noted collector of antique machinery, his collection included a 1922 Mack fire engine and a 1936 Caterpillar tractor. In addition to his wife Muriel, he is survived by his children, Marc, Lindsay, and Randolph, by his sister, Nancy Mulligan, and by three grandchildren. Memorial service will be announced at a later date.

A graduate of The Bronx High School of Science, and The City College of New York, he became a partner at Hewitt in 1975. Mr. Yanis was a member of ADATH OR, a Jewish Renewal Temple in Fort Lauderdale, FL. A chess player and Bronze Life Master in bridge, Mr. Yanis was also a highly competitive tennis player who served as President of The Wildwood Tennis Club in Great Neck, NY. The author of two bridge pamphlets, Mr. Yanis also wrote a book ''From Yanoshevsky To Yanis'', describing his parents' immigration from Russia. He was a man of adventurous and independent spirit who always strove to realize his dreams. He is survived by his wife, Kathleen Leonard, his son, Steven, a daughter, Elaine Bennett, two stepchildren, David Leonard, and Elizabeth Leonard, four grandchildren, Michael and Jillian Bennett, and Sophia and Jared Yanis. He will also be missed by many friends worldwide. Funeral services will be held on Wednesday March 15, 2000 at 10 A.M. at Temple Kol Ami in White Plains, NY. From his psychiatric residency here through his many years as Director of Medical Genetics, where he made many contributions to studies of Schizophrenia and ManicDepressive illness, to his pioneering studies in the treatment of the mentally ill deaf and his service as Co-Chairman of the Institutional Review Board, he was an inspiration to many. title: Black Reviews, Still a Secret
description: It matters that few people in book publishing seem aware of the existence of an ambitious, glossy bimonthly magazine devoted entirely to black literary culture, to books by or about blacks and to news about the few black people who work in publishing. The magazine, Black Issues Book Review, is a secret that doesn't want to be kept, and it matters that it is largely unknown in the industry because more books written by black authors are being published than ever before. Black Issues is trying, with some success, to reach African-Americans, particularly but not exclusively those on the high end socially and economically. In short, regular book customers.

title: TITAN AGREES TO ACQUIRE A RIVAL TECHNOLOGY COMPANY
description: The Titan Corporation, a satellite communications and information technology company, agreed to buy a closely held rival, Pulse Engineering, for an undisclosed amount of cash to compete better for government security contracts. Pulse Engineering, based in Hanover, Md., provides information technology and signal processing services to the military and other government agencies. The San Diego-based Titan expects to win more government contracts after the transaction and plans to seek commercial customers for Pulse's services. Pulse's 180 employees will become a part of Titan's information technology unit. Titan, which had sales of $406.6 million in 1999, has 5,400 employees. Shares of Titan rose $1.0625 yesterday, to $43.0625, far above their 52-week low of $4.75.

description: GENEVA  In the wake of two reports reproaching Switzerland for its treatment of Nazi victims' assets and of Jews fleeing Germany, a study made public on Wednesday said that 45 percent of Swiss citizens believe their country had "nothing to apologize about for its behavior to Jews" during World War II.

title: HIGHER CANADIAN INFLATION
description: Rising oil prices pushed Canada's annual inflation rate to a five-year high of 2.7 percent in February, up from 2.3 percent in January, Statistics Canada said. Gasoline prices were 31 percent higher than a year earlier. Excluding energy, the consumer price index rose by 1.6 percent last month, more than economists had expected after a 1.4 percent advance in January. With oil prices higher again this month, economists predict inflation for March will be close to 3 percent -- the maximum the Bank of Canada has said is acceptable. At the least, the central bank is expected to try to slow the economy by following any interest rate increases imposed by the Federal Reserve in the United States. Timothy Pritchard (NYT)

title: Sierra Club Foes Battle Over Ouster of Leaders
description: John Muir, the 19th-century founder of the Sierra Club who was known to scale mountain peaks in snowstorms, balancing on the tops of trees to watch nature's fury, would almost certainly have been dismayed by a gathering of New York's Sierrans on Sunday, when a fury of a different kind was on display.

title: CompuServe Faces Lawsuit Over Delayed Rebate Checks

But for a New Yorker who recalls too well the abuse Mr. Boulez suffered as music director of the New York Philharmonic in the 1970's, the clamorous ovation that persisted long after his fourth and final concert with the London Symphony Orchestra at Carnegie Hall on Monday evening was wondrous to behold.

title: VENEZUELA BUCKS INTERNET TREND

Telecommunications regulators in Venezuela cited what they called the need to protect small domestic companies that make revenue from charging for Internet service. Only about 300,000 of Venezuela's 23 million inhabitants are said to have Internet access, but it is widely viewed as a promising future market. Simon Romero (NYT)

description: American troops in Kosovo carried out raids on the strongholds of ethnic Albanian guerrillas on Wednesday, capturing bombs and other weapons in the largest effort to date by American forces there to end the guerrillas' threat to the NATO-led peacekeeping mission, American officials said.

description: That old Freudian maxim about the mind being the most important sexual organ certain applies to ''The Lifestyle: Group Sex in the Suburbs,'' David Schisgall's disquieting documentary study of middle-aged ''swingers.'' Although some may be stimulated by the movie's fleeting glimpses of gray-haired, potbellied, cellulite-jiggling, over-60 orgiasts lustily going at it in their suburban living rooms after an evening of barbecue and California dip, many more will probably be repulsed.

description: A simmering feud between the Los Angeles police chief and the district attorney over the handling of a major police corruption scandal erupted today, with the police chief refusing to cooperate fully with the local prosecutors and then being humiliated with a rebuke by several law-enforcement officials.

It lets RealNetworks equip its multimedia software to play files in Microsoft's Windows Media Player format; RealNetworks is not licensing the actual Microsoft player software.

title: COX COMMUNICATIONS SELLS STAKE IN FLEXTECH OF BRITAIN
description: Cox Communications Inc., the fifth-largest United States cable television company, said it sold its 13 percent stake in the British television broadcaster Flextech P.L.C. for $520 million to focus on providing cable and Internet service. Cox said it sold the investment in a private placement with institutional investors through Merrill Lynch. It acquired the stake when it invested in the UK Gold and UK Living TV channels in 1992 and 1993, which Flextech bought in 1997. Cox, based in Atlanta, has been selling noncable assets and using the proceeds to upgrade its networks to carry Internet service, phone calls and digital TV. Cox shares were unchanged at $43.

title: BMW Shares Soar on Possible Rover Sale
description: Shares of BMW A.G. soared 13.7 percent today amid widespread expectations that the German car manufacturer would decide on Thursday to sell Rover Cars, its loss-plagued British subsidiary.

title: Essay; Bless This House

description: In a landmark decision watched closely throughout Southeast Asia, Thailand's fledgling bankruptcy court declared Thai Petrochemical Industry, that country's largest corporate debtor, insolvent today.

Sema's stock fell 15 percent to close at 1,443 pence a share while LHS's stock jumped $12.375 a share, to $52. Andrew Ross Sorkin (NYT)

title: Sites Remember the Irish Potato Famine
description: IN May 1997, at a ceremony in Cork, Ireland, commemorating those who suffered and died in the great Irish famine, which began in 1845, Prime Minister Tony Blair of Britain said: ''That one million people should have died in what was then part of the richest and most powerful nation in the world is something that still causes pain as we reflect on it today. Those who governed in London at the time failed their people through standing by while a crop failure turned into a massive human tragedy. We must not forget such a dreadful event.''

title: HYUNDAI TO BUY BACK STOCK
description: The South Korea semiconductor giant Hyundai Electronics will buy back some of its shares this year in a bid to prop up the stock price while auctioning off several of its struggling overseas units. Hyundai's president, Park Jong-sup, said the proposed share purchases could be about as large as last year's profit of 200 billion won, or $178.7 million. The company will also sell two semiconductor plants, in Scotland and Wales, Mr. Park said. Samuel Len (NYT)

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  FRIEDMAN, DEBBY
description: FRIEDMAN-Debby. The Sh'or Yoshuv Institute, its Kehilla and greater Jewish community of Far Rockaway/5 Towns, mourn the passing of Mrs. Debby Friedman, cherished wife of our esteemed President, Maurice Friedman, and mother and grandmother, both to her children and grandchildren and the extended Sh'or Yoshuv family. Devoted founding members of our yeshiva, the Friedmans personified the dictum in Ethics of our Fathers, ''let your house be a meeting place for sages'' ''1:4,'' for the yeshiva was virtually born in their living room more than thirty years ago. Their generosity and on-going involvement have nurtured the growth and development of the Sh'or Yoshuv community, and Mrs. Friedman's warmth and compassion will be deeply missed and fondly remembered. Heartfelt condolences to the entire family. Rabbi Naftali Jaeger, Rosh Hayesheva Rabbi Avrohom Halpern, Menahel Rabbi Herschel Leiner, Executive Director

The Russian right wing, who was acquired from Vancouver on Tuesday, just before the trading deadline, showed little in his Devils debut as New Jersey suffered a 3-2 loss to the Dallas Stars in a game between division leaders. Mogilny's best chances came moments apart in the second minute of the third period while the score was tied. He was denied both times by goaltender Manny Fernandez, the first time from close range on the right and then on a backhander from the slot.

That was certainly the case on Tuesday evening, when she played Prokofiev's Third Concerto with Charles Dutoit and the Philadelphia Orchestra at Carnegie Hall. Had it ended there, a listener might have left with the contentment of having heard a dazzling and in many ways unusual reading.

Southwest, which clears securities trades for brokers in the United States, Canada and Europe, needs additional capital to maintain the rapid pace of growth caused by heavy trading volumes in financial markets, Mr. Bowman said. The company's stock fell $3.75 a share, to $39.

title: The Way We Ate

By the 1950's, people sometimes ate standing up or perched in front of a television. In ''Tabletop to TV Tray: China and Glass in America, 1880-1980,'' more than 500 objects from the Dallas Museum of Art and the Newark Museum reveal that how we eat is as much about social history as it is about food.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  RANDOLPH, STEPHEN B.
description: RANDOLPH-Stephen B. A financial industry executive, died on March 12 at his home in Mt. Kisco, NY. He was 74. Born in Austria, he was a grand-nephew of Sigmund Freud, came to the US in the early 30's, and served in the Navy during the Second and Korean Wars. As an advisor for United Nuclear, he earned a patent for a radiation detection device called a Spintharoscope, and later became head of research for the Energy Fund, a partner at Ralph E. Samuels and an investment counselor at Neuberger & Berman. A life long lover of the mountains, his journeys ranged from Everest base camp to the summit of the Matterhorn. A noted collector of antique machinery, his collection included a 1922 Mack fire engine and a 1936 Caterpillar tractor. In addition to his wife Muriel, he is survived by his children, Marc, Lindsay, and Randolph, by his sister, Nancy Mulligan, and by three grandchildren. Memorial service will be announced at a later date.

As part of the deal, Blockbuster, which is based in Dallas, will invest in San Francisco-based Food.com, which operates a Web site where customers can order food from 16,000 restaurants in 12 major markets nationwide. Takeout Taxi, which has 52 sites, delivers food for restaurants. The combined food and video delivery service would start this summer.

title: Death by Lynching

Some of the photographs are postcards and some are souvenirs that were printed by the dozens and hundreds by commercial photographers who had been at the scene. This exhibition, which chronicles an epidemic of lynchings in this country between 1890 and 1930, is called ''Without Sanctuary: Lynching Photography in America.'' It runs until July 9.

The company also predicted higher income in the next three years. Net income rose to 696 million euros, or $674 million, from 382 million euros a year earlier. BASF did not provide figures on its profit excluding the one-time items, which included gains from the sale of its Compo lawn-care unit and a stake in the fuel-station operator Aral. BASF said that its fourth-quarter sales rose 27 percent as it benefited from a steady improvement in a number of national economies around the world.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  ABRAM, MORRIS B.
description: ABRAM-Morris B. The American Jewish Committee, the international Jewish community, and all people everywhere who hope for a better world, have lost a cherished friend, a powerful advocate for freedom and justice, and a man of profound moral integrity and enormous human kindness with the passing of Ambassador Morris Abram. Since his early days as President of AJC's Atlanta Chapter from 1955-1957, through his role as AJC National President from 1963-1968, and most recently as Honorary President and Founding Chairman of UN Watch, AJC has always been extraordinarily proud and grateful for his leadership, wisdom, and friendship. His active association with AJC, including as an eloquent advocate for Jewish interests and causes and as a champion of the oppressed, helped to shape the work of our agency through tumultuous decades. A brilliant lawyer and diplomat with heartfelt convictions and principles, Morris changed the course of human history in the 20th century in education, law, civil rights and human rights, at home and abroad. A tireless warrior against the evils of anti-Semitism, racism and all forms of intolerance, he was appointed to posts by five American Presidents, most recently as US Permanent Representative to the UN in Geneva. Through his work with UN Watch, he passionately sought to fulfill Israel's quest for a rightful place in the family of nations. When AJC honored Morris in December, 1999 with our National Distinguished Leadership Award, international leaders came out in full force to pay much deserved tribute to this giant among men, including UN Secretary General Kofi Annan who rightfully described Morris as ''a global citizen of the first rank.'' Morris Abram was a man who believed that one person could make a difference, and then did. His legacy will be an inspiration for generations to come. We send our deepest condolences to his wife Bruna, his children, grandchildren and the rest of the grieving family. Bruce M. Ramer, President David A. Harris, Exec. Director

title: Grappling With the Teacher Shortage

Although the most comprehensive plan so far has come from the Senate majority leader, Joseph Bruno, other participants have some impressive ideas. But it is important that the various measures be targeted to benefit the poorest students.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  CHALLENOR, BERNARD, MD,
description: CHALLENOR - Bernard, MD, MPH. The students, faculty, alumni and staff of Columbia's Mailman School of Public Health are deeply saddened by the sudden death of Dr. Bernard Challenor. At the time of his passing, he was Associate Professor and Director of the General Public Health Program (Health Policy and Management). During his long and distinguished career at the School, Dr. Challenor served in various capacities, as acting dean ('78-'80), as acting head of the division of Epidemiology and as former associate dean for hospital affairs at Columbia's College of Physicians and Surgeons. His expertise spanned many areas: comparative health systems of Great Britain, Canada, China and Cuba; health and the developing world, famine, debt crisis, poverty; health care of the disadvantaged and health and poverty in the US. For decades, he was a mentor to countless numbers of students and we are less for his passing. We extend our heartfelt sympathy to his sister, Dr. Yasoma Challenor, and his legion of friends. A memorial service will be conducted on the Columbia campus at a time to be announced. Allan Rosenfield, MD, Dean

title: AN UPGRADE FOR TOSHIBA

description: We first encounter Erin Brockovich (Julia Roberts), a twice-divorced mother of three with emphatic taste in clothes, in the midst of a run of bad luck. After bluffing her way through a disastrous job interview, she is involved in a car accident. Although she accessorizes her short skirts and tight tops with a fetching neck brace, her lawsuit against the other driver, a wealthy doctor, fails. One baby-sitter quits, her replacement has the demeanor of a medicated psychopath, and a motorcycle gang has moved in next door. Erin's bank balance stands at $74, and her baby is running a fever.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  ZION, EDITH
description: ZION-Edith. SAR Academy notes with deep sorrow the sudden passing of Edith Zion. Beloved wife of Abe Zion, founder, long-time Benefactor and Trustee; adoring mother of our Trustee, Mark, Joshua, Adina, and their spouses, as well as cherished grandmother. May the entire family find consolation in her memory and comfort among the mourners of Zion and Jerusalem. Jack C. Bendheim, Pres. Ludwig Bravmann, Vice Chmn. Board of Trustees Rabbi Joel Cohn, Principal

title: Chris-Craft Loses UPN Ruling
description: A New York Supreme Court judge has upheld an ultimatum that Chris-Craft Industries has to buy or sell its interest in the fledgling UPN network by Monday, giving Viacom Inc. a big victory in its quest to complete its merger with the CBS Corporation.

title: THEATER GUIDE
description: Here is a selective listing by critics of The Times of new or noteworthy Broadway and Off Broadway shows this weekend. Approximate running times are in parentheses. * denotes a highly recommended show.

title: NATIONAL-OILWELL IS BUYING IRI FOR $320 MILLION IN STOCK
description: National-Oilwell Inc. said yesterday that it had agreed to acquire the IRI International Corporation for $320 million, about $8.04 a share in stock. Both companies are based in Houston, and both make oil drilling equipment. IRI's stock rose $2.125, to $7.875; National-Oil rose $2.75, to $26.50. National-Oil said the two companies had complementary businesses. National-Oil focuses more on offshore drilling, while IRI concentrates more on land drilling. The companies also make different types of tools used in oil wells. National-Oil had $745.2 million in revenue in 1999, while IRI had $92.2 million in revenue.

title: For Brooklyn, a New Rental Tower
description: The 32-story building rising on Montague Street is adding an imposing new presence to the Brooklyn Heights skyline and the first new luxury rental building in the neighborhood in nearly four decades.

title: Corrections
description: A letter in Science Times on Tuesday about a rheumatologic syndrome named for Dr. Hans Conrad Reiter misstated the surname of a doctor who advocates renaming the syndrome because of Reiter's participation in Nazi experiments. The physician is Dr. Michael Weisman, not Wasserman.

title: YankeeNets Adding The Devils to Its Team
description: An affiliate of YankeeNets bought the New Jersey Devils for $175 million, spending almost eight times what the owner, John J. McMullen, paid for the hockey team in 1982. The sale is a key part of the YankeeNets' plan to build an arena in Newark.

title: Who Thought 'That Girl' Would Go There?
description: THE show is over and Marlo Thomas is ravenous: this two-week stint as a co-star in ''The Vagina Monologues'' tends to whet the appetite, mental and physical. Lucky the pasta palace next door keeps late hours. What with all the postperformance kudos, feminist commiseration and air kissing (''Barry Diller came tonight, and he loved it,'' Ms. Thomas informs her producer), supper becomes synonymous with midnight snack.

title: NEW VIDEO RELEASES
description: Jakob the Liar

title: ON STAGE AND OFF
description: Wake Up And Move In

title: KRUNG THAI TO SELL LOANS
description: Thailand's second-largest bank, Krung Thai Bank, will sell a chunk of its bad loan portfolio to Thailand's central bank, in a move to help clean up the Krung Thai balance sheet. All of Krung Thai's loans in arrears at least a year will be purchased by the central bank's Financial Institutions Development Fund. The fund will also buy all assets of the First Bangkok City Bank, which the government forced Krung Thai to take over two years ago and which is now defunct. The fund will set up a new unit to manage those assets, said Supparat Kavattakul, director general of the Fiscal Policy Office. He did not give a purchase price.

title: Yogi and Boo Boo, Yes, But Not One Picnic Basket
description: ''Spectres of the Spectrum'' is a sci-fi thriller about a renegade scientist named Yogi and his daughter, Boo Boo, a psychic media terrorist, who set out one day in the year 2007 to disrupt a magnetic pulse that threatens to erase the memories of everyone on the planet. Wait, that's not quite right. Let's try again.

title: Gregory Crewdson 'Twilight'
description: Luhring Augustine

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SCHRADER, RAE
description: SCHRADER-Rae. On March 15, 2000. Devoted mother, sister and aunt. Although she faced many difficulties in life, she always turned lemons into lemonade. Services Sunday, 11:30 AM, ''The Riverside'', 76th Street and Amsterdame Avenue.

title: Beauty in the Eye (and the Fingertip)
description: Gary Schneider's photographic exploration of the universe that is the human body holds the kind of magic and wonder found in pictures of distant stars, nebulae and galaxies.

title: Against a Breathtaking Landscape, Young Adults Lacking in Vision
description: To the gleaming tinkle of ''Tubular Bells''-like music, the camera in Tom Tykwer's film ''Winter Sleepers'' swoops like a reckless downhill skier across the peaks and along the icy roads surrounding a picturesque skiing village in the German mountains. The gorgeously photographed film by the German director of ''Run Lola Run'' distills the beauty and peril of this wintry environment with a laserlike concentration that virtually blows a cloud of snow in your face. In an early scene, as a car skids off a mountain road and plunges into a snowbank, the sickening crunch of the vehicle hurtling into a drift is so perfectly coordinated with a shot of snow slamming into the windshield that for that split second you might as well be behind the wheel.

title: Nasdaq's Sign Is Great, but Does Its Market Measure Up?
description: THE signs of Times Square have long been amazing. Remember the cigarette billboard that blew perfect smoke rings? In retrospect, the tobacco companies might have been better off today if they had found another use for their money, but there is no doubt that the sign impressed a lot of tourists.

title: With Fast Feet and Fiddles, An Irish Perennial Returns
description: Admit to facing a first-time seeing of ''Riverdance'' and a reviewer is peppered with advice. ''Be nice,'' fans plead. ''Kill them,'' others hiss. ''Keep an open mind,'' the peacemakers add.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  NUSSBAUM, BETTY
description: NUSSBAUM-Betty. Beloved wife of the late Louis. Devoted mother of Richard.Dear mother-in-law of Carole. Cherished grandmother of Luna and Stephanie. Services Sunday 12:45PM at Gutterman's, 8000 Jericho Turnpike, Woodbury, L.I.

title: TRANSACTIONS
description: BASEBALL

title: When imitation is a sincere form of wanting to make an impact -- and not plagiarism.
description: TWO beverage marketers are running television commercials that no doubt have many viewers wondering whether they are seeing double.

title: THE MARKETS: COMMODITIES
description: COCOA CLIMBS. Cocoa rose on expectations that economic recovery in Europe and Asia will bolster demand for luxury items like chocolate. In New York, cocoa for May delivery rose $37, or 4.1 percent, to $935 a ton.

title: PUBLIC LIVES
description: Not Amused By Comic's Ad

title: Morris Abram Is Dead at 81; Rights Advocate Led Brandeis
description: Morris B. Abram, a small-town boy from Georgia who went on to play a role in the civil rights movement, become a leader of the American Jewish community, serve as president of Brandeis University and fill posts on a variety of commissions and panels under five presidents, died yesterday at a hospital in Geneva. He was 81.

title: Taipei Journal; In Weighty Times, an Island Lampoons Its Jitters
description: ''I have heard the rumors of various rates being paid to buy votes, and I solemnly declare that this is not an activity of my party,'' says the man on the screen, who bears an uncanny resemblance to President Lee Teng-hui.

title: BMW Will Shed Rover, Selling Sport Utility Vehicle Line to Ford
description: Six years and nearly $6 billion after buying the Rover Group, BMW of Germany abandoned the British automaker today.

title: Cash Run Hangs On to Win
description: Gulfstream Park closed its 63-day season today with a three-horse photo finish that saw Cash Run, the surprise star of last year's Breeders' Cup Juvenile Fillies, return to her favorite track to win the $200,000 Bonnie Miss Stakes.

title: A Chaotic Comedy on World War II
description: With the film ''Saving Private Ryan'' and the book ''The Greatest Generation,'' World War II has made a spectacular public relations comeback in the last three years as the United States has finally recovered from the lingering post-Vietnam blues. Triumphantly reclaimed, the war, in most people's minds, once again represents what it did in the 1950's: the apogee of American heroism and rectitude.

title: Yoshihiro Suda
description: D'Amelio Terras

title: Taking Stock of Modern Icons
description: HERE we go again. ''Making Choices,'' the second segment of ''MOMA 2000,'' the self-reflective (navel-gazing?) trilogy of exhibition cycles with which the Museum of Modern Art is greeting the millennium, has begun its staged landing. Its subtitle indicates what is in store in this second round: ''24 Exhibitions of Modern Art From 1920 to 1960.'' Eleven can be seen now, three more open on March 30 and the remaining 10 open on April 30.

title: Gamache Sees Defeat, And Courtroom Revenge
description: For the first time yesterday afternoon, standing in a boxing ring at the Downtown Athletic Club, Joey Gamache watched the videotape of himself getting knocked out by Arturo Gatti on Feb. 26.

title: Pataki Appoints an Adviser To Assess Nassau Finances
description: Warning that Nassau County's fiscal troubles could affect both its taxpayers and the Long Island economy as a whole, Gov. George E. Pataki named a special adviser today to evaluate the county's finances.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SALUSKY, ROBERT
description: SALUSKY-Robert in Orinda on March 14th at 84 years of age. A native of Montreal, Canada, lived in New York as a young man and then in Southern California for over 50 years. An optometrist for 37 years, a member of the American Optometric Association and avid gardener. Loving father of Ida, Anna, Sheppard, Monica (John Sutherland); devoted grandfather of Erica and Alexis Sutherland and leaves his former wife & friend Cacilda Salusky. Services were held under the direction of Sinai Memorial Chapel, Lafayette, CA. In lieu of flowers donations may be made to Jewish Family & Children's Services of the Greater East Bay, 2484 Shattuck Ave., Suite 210, Berkeley, CA 94704.

title: The Albanian Challenge in Kosovo
description: American troops took firm action this week against one of the most dangerous problems now confronting NATO in Kosovo. In a series of raids, they seized weapons and ammunition that ethnic Albanian guerrillas in the American-patrolled eastern part of the province have been using to launch cross-border raids into Serbia. Unless the guerrillas are forcibly disarmed and turned away from the border, their actions could embroil NATO in an unwanted new war with Belgrade.

title: Psychologists Fired After Disputed Release of Rapist
description: Amid mounting criticism of the New Jersey prison system's release of a convicted rapist last week, the state corrections commissioner today fired two psychologists who had prepared the evaluations that had led to the inmate's freedom.

title: John Wehle Jr., 53, Led Brewery
description: John L. Wehle Jr., the chairman of the Genesee Corporation, died on March 10 at the Genesee Region Home Care and Hospice in Rochester after a battle with cancer. Mr. Wehle, a Rochester resident, was 53.

title: Boston College Has 3 Finalists
description: Boston College's Jeff Farkas, Brian Gionta and Mike Motteau are among the 10 nominees for the 2000 Hobey Baker Award, marking only the second time a school has had three finalists for college hockey's top individual honor.

title: Top Music for Bottom Dollar
description: WHEN people who say they are curious about classical music but don't attend concerts are asked what keeps them away, some say they are intimidated by the ritualistic aspects of concertgoing, like when to applaud, and some say they aren't sure where to start. But the most persistent complaint among potential listeners -- and regular concertgoers as well -- is that ticket prices for the best-known ensembles and soloists are so high as to discourage experimentation.

title: The Blue Language Pales But Not the Mamet Music
description: Things and stuff like -- well, you know -- things and stuff are what make the world go round in ''American Buffalo,'' David Mamet's career-making conversion of sooty, carbon speech into diamond-hard theater. ''You want to tell me what this thing is?'' begins a typical exchange. Or: ''Forget the thing.'' Or: ''The thing, it ran two years.'' The listeners in the play, by the way, know exactly what the speakers mean. So do we.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  JAFFE, ELIZABETH G.
description: JAFFE-Elizabeth G. Most beloved daughter of Esta Sands and Burton Jaffe. Loved step-daughter of Eugene Sands and Judy Jaffe. Adored sister of Nanci and Jim Sapiro, beloved sister of Michael and David Jaffe, and Peggy and David Sands. Most wonderful aunt to Jordan, Ashlie and Kendall. Beloved by all her relatives and many friends. Her spirit soars. We will miss her greatly. Love from Harpo and Zeppo. We love you, Liz.

title: G.I.'s in Kosovo Hold 9 Suspected Rebels
description: American peacekeeping troops were holding nine men in detention today, suspected of involvement in an insurgency across the border against the Serbian police.

description: To the Editor:

title: Corrections
description: A brief report in Business Day yesterday about the new president and chief executive of the Stanford Management Company, which handles the university's investments, referred imprecisely to the current chief executive, Laurance R. Hoagland. He is leaving to oversee the investments of the Hewlett Foundation; its president remains Paul Brest.

title: Kurt Delbanco
description: Amos Eno Gallery

title: Patten and Holsey Lost to Free Agency
description: The reshaping of the Giants' roster continues. David Patten, a reserve wide receiver, and Bernard Holsey, the only experienced backup defensive end, have left, signing free-agent contracts.

title: In a Grand Space, the Puzzle of the Stars
description: To the Editor:

title: Small Firms Express Dismay At Plan for Nasdaq Spinoff
description: After months of breezy talk about a plan by the National Association of Securities Dealers to issue stock and spin off the Nasdaq stock market later this year, the fine print finally became public yesterday.

title: Josiah McElheny
description: Brent Sikkema

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  GLASS, GERALD G., PH.D.
description: GLASS-Gerald G., Ph.D. Devoted husband of Esther. Loving father of Susan, Jonathan and Matthew; grandfather of Emily, Abigail, Anna and Sam. Proud World War II veteran, recipient of the Bronze Star and Purple Heart. Professor of education at Adelphi University since 1958. Raised in the South Bronx, he called Patchogue, L.I. and Locke Mills, Maine home. His humor, generosity and spirit live on in us all.

title: Images of a Burnished Utopia Born in a Bleak Reality
description: You might not think that February 1930 was the best time to start a magazine about business. But then you are not Henry Luce. He was already the co-founder of one profitable magazine, Time, seven years earlier. He believed, with President Herbert Hoover, that the stock market crash was one of those corrections that would right itself in a few months.

title: Soft on Campaign Funds
description: With each fund-raiser, this year's New York Senate race offers new and brazen lessons in the nature of unrestrained political money-raising. Both Hillary Rodham Clinton and Rudolph Giuliani are scrambling for funds, speeding into the history books as participants in what is expected to be the costliest race ever for the United States Senate. Each new fund-raising gimmick expands the coffers of these two candidates even as it chips away at their reputations. The public is left to worry that big donors will be seeking a payback later.

title: THE MARKETS: CURRENCIES
description: THE EURO RISES. The euro gained as volatile technology stocks raised concern that European investors might bring back some of their United States holdings. In New York, the euro settled at 97.10 cents, up from 96.73.

title: Police Arrest Nine People In Restaurant Drug Raid
description: Nine people were arrested yesterday and 200 pounds of the drug khat were seized at two Middle Eastern restaurants in Brooklyn, the police said.

title: Nissan to Get Its First Non-Japanese Leader
description: Carlos Ghosn, the Renault executive dispatched to Japan a year ago to help restore the Nissan Motor Company's profitability, will become its president, officials of both companies said today. The promotion is the first time a foreigner has assumed such a prestigious role in a major Japanese corporation.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  DENNEDY, IRENE M.
description: DENNEDY-Irene M., of Lincroft, New Jersey, formerly of Brooklyn, died at home Wednesday. Beloved wife of the late Hugh P. Dennedy; mother of Kevin Dennedy, Margot Dennedy and Sharon Hasselmann; grandmother of Julie Vellender, Caroline Egbers, Betsey Blankenship and Peter Hasselmann; great grandmother of David, Allison and Kevin. Visiting Friday 7-9pm, Holmdel Funeral Home, 26 S. Holmdel Rd., Holmdel, NJ. Funeral Saturday 10am, St. Leo the Great R.C. Church, Lincroft. Interment Holmdel Cemetery. Memorials to Visiting Nurses Association, Hospice program, 141 Bodman Pl, Red Bank, NJ 07701

title: Two Weeks When East Meets West
description: ''None of us expected the Asian fair to be the huge success it's been since Day 1,'' said Khalil Rizk, director of the Chinese Porcelain Company in Manhattan. He was one of the instigators of New York's International Asian Art Fair, which opens on Thursday night and runs through March 29 at the Seventh Regiment Armory.

title: Idols to Look Down On, Sometimes
description: ''Can you imagine the level of a mind that watches wrestling?'' huffs the supercilious Max von Sydow in Woody Allen's ''Hannah and Her Sisters.'' The director Barry W. Blau stein includes that clip in ''Beyond the Mat,'' his documentary tracking his own obsession with professional wrestling, a devotion that began at age 8. His is apparently just the sort of mind that watches wrestling.

title: Van Gundy Jots Down Reminders for the Knicks
description: After a day off, the Knicks arrived at Purchase College today and waiting for them at each of their lockers was a memo from Coach Jeff Van Gundy.

title: Buchanan Wraps Himself In McCain's Flag of Reform
description: Grafting onto the lesson of the presidential primary contests, Patrick J. Buchanan unveiled a retooled stump speech today for his lagging third-party candidacy, packing this year's politically magic phrase ''campaign reform'' into its every jot and tittle.

title: Paid Notice: Memorials  HEISLER, HELENA MILES
description: HEISLER-Helena Miles. July 19, 1946-March 17, 1997. Always remembered. Always loved. Tom, Dan and Ellen

title: Europe's Central Bank Raises Interest Rate
description: As if it had needed an extra two weeks to summon up its courage, the European Central Bank followed up its warnings of inflation today and nudged up its core interest rate.

title: PIRELLI DEAL RUMORED
description: The stock of Italy's largest producer of tires and cables, Pirelli S.p.A., jumped amid talk that either the French tire maker Michelin or its rival Continental might bid for the company's tire business. ''There are rumors that Michelin or Continental might make a bid for Pirelli's tires business,'' said John Pellegrinelli, who helps manage $250 million at Zenit SGR in Milan. Pirelli, based in Milan, has made a push into more profitable business areas like telecommunications and fiber optics in the last year.

title: HEALTHCENTRAL MAKES A STOCK DEAL FOR VITAMINS.COM
description: HealthCentral.com said yesterday that it would acquire Vitamins.com in a stock transaction valued about $103.5 million. HealthCentral, based in Emeryville, Calif., operates a health information Web site for consumers and an online drugstore. It will issue about $103.5 million in common stock to buy Vitamins.com, an online provider of vitamins, minerals and supplements, adding 200,000 new customers. Vitamins.com, based in Falls Church, Va., also operates 10 retail stores and a direct mail catalog with 175,000 active customers. HealthCentral.com's shares rose 18.75 cents, to $6.875, in Nasdaq trading.

title: Rib Injury to Keep Nedved Out for Key Games
description: Ten games remain in the regular season, and the Rangers will be without Petr Nedved for weekend games in Philadelphia and Pittsburgh.

title: A Trio Whose Play Ranges From Stressed to Serene
description: In the first half of its concert at the 92nd Street Y on Wednesday evening, the Kalichstein-Laredo-Robinson Trio sounded a little pressed. Schubert's luminous lone Adagio, or Notturno, in E flat -- a movement he probably dropped from his B flat Trio when he had an even better idea -- lacked intimacy, and Dvorak's ''Dumky'' Trio lured the players into extravagance, making them sound as if they were performing a triple concerto without orchestra.

title: Accounts
description: * Charles Schwab & Co., San Francisco, to BBDO New York, part of the BBDO Worldwide unit of the Omnicom Group, to handle a new assignment, the introduction of Portfolio Consultation, a financial evaluation service for investors. title: Undercover Police in Manhattan Kill an Unarmed Man in a Scuffle
description: An unarmed Brooklyn man waiting for a taxicab was shot and killed outside a bar on Eighth Avenue in Midtown Manhattan early yesterday in a scuffle with three undercover narcotics detectives, the authorities said.

title: A Calling of Faith and Art in a Russian Church
description: God moves in mysterious ways, except, maybe, in Pskov, a city that has monasteries and grand churches and religious artifacts the way Americans have remote-control clickers and half-read copies of People magazine. This is a town where you can stand in one square -- they call it the square of seven churches -- and see, yes, seven churches. This sort of thing a god would appreciate.

description: ERICK BARKLEY walked down a long, winding corridor of the McKale Center yesterday afternoon, a corridor nearly splattered with St. John's tears just hours earlier.

title: XYBERNAUT SHARES FALL 25% AFTER AUDITOR'S WARNING
description: The shares of the Xybernaut Corporation fell 25 percent after its outside auditor warned of ''substantial doubt'' about the ability of the company, which makes wearable computers, to continue as a going concern because of continuing losses and a need for more capital. Shares of the company, based in Fairfax, Va., have risen more than twentyfold since September as it announced a sale to the Firestone Building Products Company and said it was in talks with several leading technology companies about joint projects.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  BUTKIEWICZ, JULIE (HERWITZ)
description: BUTKIEWICZ-Julie (Herwitz) of Bedford and formerly of NYC. Beloved wife of Vincent. Dearest daughter of David R. and Carla B. Herwitz of Swampscott, MA. Adored granddaughter of the late Harry and Ruth Barron, Harry and Sara Herwitz. Loving sister of Andrew and Johanna Herwitz, Alexei Cowett, and Victoria Bender. Dear aunt of Laszlo and Edith Herwitz. Services at Temple Emanu-EL, 393 Atlantic Ave., Marblehead, MA on Sunday at 2:30 P.M. Memorial Observance through Wednesday at her parents home. In lieu of flowers, expressions of sympathy in her memory may be donated to the American Cancer Society.

title: U.S. Regulators Impose 15-Month Moratorium On All Rail Mergers
description: Regulators in Washington imposed a 15-month moratorium on all rail mergers yesterday, abruptly blocking a plan to create an enormous cross-border freight system but giving a lift to rail stocks that have languished since the proposed North American rail merger was announced late last year.

description: Neither Gov. George W. Bush nor Vice President Al Gore has public events scheduled today.

title: Lacking Buyer, Iridium Is Set To Shut Down
description: Unable to find new investors willing to step in after Motorola Inc. and other founding partners declined to bail it out, Iridium L.L.C. moved yesterday to shut off the innovative portable phone and messaging service it designed to reach the remotest regions of the world.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  ROMERO, JOSEPH JAMES
description: ROMERO-Joseph James, age 86, March 16, 2000. Beloved husband of Louise. Loving father of Joseph, Lois, Fay Ellen, Mary, Gerard, Margaret, Dolores, Carolyn, Robert and Janet. Oldest brother of George, Ann, Veronica, Martha and of the late Winifred, Margaret and William. Beloved grandfather of 24 grandchildren. As a young man, Joseph helped his family survive the Great Depression and joined the Civilian Conservation Corp. in Idaho. During World War II, he worked in the Brooklyn Navy Yard as a welder and worked on the USS Missouri. He retired in 1988 after working 40 years for the ILA/CIO Union in various capacities. Visiting at Perry's Funeral Home, 118 Union Avenue, Lynbrook, NY, Saturday and Sunday, 2-4 and 7-9 PM. Funeral mass Monday, 10:30 AM, St. Raymond's, Atlantic Ave., East Rockaway. NY

title: How the C.I.A. Played Dirty Tricks With Culture
description: Many people remember reading George Orwell's ''Animal Farm'' in high school or college, with its chilling finale in which the farm animals looked back and forth at the tyrannical pigs and the exploitative human farmers but found it ''impossible to say which was which.''

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SOSNICK, ROBERT
description: SOSNICK-Robert on March 16. Beloved husband of SuSu Sosnick. Dear father of Julie Sosnick, Karen Sosnick (Jeffrey) Schoenberg, Tony Sosnick and fiancee Katrin Yaghoubi and Catherine Sosnick (Dr. Charles) Schwartz. Loving Papa Bob of Jason Cyrulnik. Devoted son of Ruth Sosnick and the late Harry Sosnick. Brother of Phyllis (Stanley) Satovsky, Judge Edward (Darlene) Sosnick and Sharon (Gar) Alperovitz. Services and interment on Sunday in Detroit, MI. For information call The Ira Kaufman Chapel, 248-569-0020

title: Battle Erupts Over Bonuses For Teachers
description: A plan for recruiting summer school teachers that began as a quiet negotiation has set off a power struggle pitting the Giuliani administration against the teachers' union and the interim schools chancellor, Harold O. Levy.

title: All Children Deserve What Charter Schools Offer
description: To the Editor:

title: A Meditative Pianist Shows He Can Set Off Fireworks, Too
description: The Norwegian pianist Leif Ove Andsnes, who turns 30 this year, has won such consistent praise for his fine pianism and thoughtful musicianship that it's easy to forget what a formidable virtuoso he is as well. He reminded us of this exciting other dimension of his artistry on Thursday night at Avery Fisher Hall when he gave a staggering account of Prokofiev's Piano Concerto No. 3 with the New York Philharmonic. The performance came just two days after Martha Argerich, playing with the Philadelphia orchestra, created a frenzy at Carnegie Hall in the same work. Mr. Andsnes tore through the piece with hell-bent energy, vanquishing its notorious technical challenges. His co-conspirator was the dynamic conductor Valery Gergiev.

title: Yarnall Is Mediocre Again In His Second Time Around
description: After Ed Yarnall allowed 10 runs in his first inning of spring training this week, David Cone constructed an orb of medical tape, roughly the size of a volleyball. ''Yarnall's fastball,'' Cone wrote on the side.

title: THE INVISIBLE POOR
description: The poverty rate is lower than it has been in decades, but poor people still abound in the United States, and they are more concealed than ever from the wealthy. A report by James Fallows in The Times Magazine.

title: Ambition Turns to Crisis Control as Clinton Visits the Subcontinent
description: When President Clinton first contemplated visiting India three years ago he was eager to open a relationship with the vastly populated, democratic country that had remained outside the Western fold during the cold war. He was also gripped with the ambition, his aides said, to display the fabric of modern India to the rest of the world.

title: Undercover Police Training Includes Identification Rules
description: Undercover narcotics officers, like the detective who fatally shot an unarmed security guard on Thursday, receive several weeks of special training to prepare them for the contingencies of street encounters, including specific instructions on when to drop their guise and identify themselves as officers, police officials said yesterday.

title: UNDER LEGAL SIEGE, GUN MAKER AGREES TO ACCEPT CURBS

title: BANK ONE PLANS TO CUT WORK FORCE BY 5,100 JOBS

The bank also said it gave its chairman and chief executive, John B. McCoy, a $10.3 million severance payment and a $3 million annual pension when he resigned in December after profit problems. The Chicago-based bank, which previously said it would cut jobs, disclosed the extent of the cuts, along with Mr. McCoy's severance agreement, in its annual report filed with the Securities and Exchange Commission. Bank One has warned four times in the last seven months that it would not meet analysts' earnings estimates.

The company, based in Farmington Hills, Mich., plans to use the money to expand its development centers in India and to finance employee recruitment and training programs. The company also plans to evaluate potential spin-offs and joint ventures.
