title: Paid Notice: Deaths  KELLA, POLLY JANE CURTIS
description: KELLA-Polly Jane Curtis, 80, passed away on March 10, 2000, in Seattle, WA. Polly was deeply devoted to the world of classical music, the history of Seattle, WA and the memory of her father, Asahel Curtis. She is survived by Kathleen Kella Ferris & John (Jake) Kella. Devoted wife of John James (Jack) Kella (deceased). Dear friend of Jerry Price of Seattle. Grandmother to Jonathan Kirkland Ferris, Kristen Joy Ferris and John William Edward Kella. Polly was the youngest daughter of Asahel Curtis, famed photographer of the Pacific Northwest, early conservationist and co-founder of the Mountaineers' Club. Polly contributed greatly to the Washington State History Museum's exhibit ''Golden Dreams: The Quest for the Klondike,'' featuring Asahel Curtis' photographs of the great Yukon Gold Rush of 1897. Polly's uncle, Edward S. Curtis, was the renowned photographer of American Indians. Edward Curtis' 20-volume opus called ''The North American Indian'' was a watershed study of more than 80 Native-American nations from Mexico to Alaska. Completed in 1930, this enormous project has been hailed as one of the finest works of photographic anthropology ever accomplished. Polly's love of music began early in her life in Seattle, where she graduated from the Cornish School of Music and studied with the noted music teacher, Madame Ingbert. Polly frequently gave concerts of chamber music in the Northwest and was a featured performer on the Alaska Steamship Line. During her time at sea, she met Jack Kella, whom she married in 1942. They moved to Honolulu, Hawaii, where they raised Kathy and Jake. Polly performed with the Honolulu Symphony Orchestra for more than 30 years. She also founded the International Strings, which provided chamber music performances to schools, hospitals, senior citizen homes and other under-served areas of society. Following the passing of her husband Jack in 1985, Polly moved back to Seattle and lived with her dear friend since childhood, Jerry Price, who survives her. Polly continued to enjoy music in Seattle, and performed with the Bellevue Orchestra from 1986 to 1996. Services for Polly were held at the University Congregational United Church of Christ in Seattle, WA. Polly's warmth, compassion and dedication will be greatly missed by all those who loved her.

title: ECUADOR WINS BANANA RULING
description: In another chapter of a long-running dispute over European banana imports, World Trade Organization arbitrators have ruled that Ecuador, the world's largest exporter of bananas, may retaliate against the European Union for violating global trading rules. Elizabeth Olson

They were miffed. They were scornful. And finally they took the matter into their own hands. They turned photography inside out.

description: Shares of Integrated Information Systems Inc., a provider of Internet consulting services to businesses, closed almost 40 percent above their initial offering price yesterday in their first day of trading.

title: UNIVERSAL LEAF TOBACCO TO CLOSE FIVE PLANTS
description: The Universal Leaf Tobacco Company said yesterday that it was shutting five plants and laying off 175 full-time employees and a further 1,400 seasonal workers because of expectations for a smaller crop, problems caused by Hurricane Floyd as well as ''unprecedented political and legal attacks'' on the industry. The company, based in Richmond, Va., is a subsidiary of the Universal Corporation, the world's largest buyer and processor of leaf tobacco. Universal is closing its leaf-processing operation in Rocky Mount, N.C., which has been shut since September 1999 because of flood damage caused by Hurricane Floyd. It will also shut extruder operations in Lexington, Ky.; Bowling Green, Ky.; Lumberton, N.C.; and Rocky Mount, N.C.

title: Surging Petroleum Prices Push Inflation Rate to 3-Year High
description: Surging petroleum prices pushed the inflation rate in February to its highest level in three years, the Labor Department reported yesterday. But beyond fuel and energy, the nation remained remarkably free of the rising inflation that the booming economy was expected to have produced by now.

description: The Boeing Company, battered by a 5 1/2-week strike by its engineers union that had delayed jet deliveries and helped send its stock price tumbling, announced a tentative agreement today to end the action.

title: A Breakthrough on Gun Control
description: In a major victory for public safety, the nation's largest gun manufacturer, Smith & Wesson, agreed yesterday to change the way it designs, distributes and markets guns. In exchange, the Clinton administration and other plaintiffs agreed to drop a threatened lawsuit against the company. The agreement marks the first big concession by industry to the mounting public and political pressure for stronger gun controls. It also represents a crushing defeat for the National Rifle Association, which has been arguing violently against the very reforms that Smith & Wesson has now agreed to undertake.

title: Abroad at Home; 'Cases That Cry Out'
description: Representative Lamar Smith, Republican of Texas, is a principal author of the 1996 Immigration Act. He acknowledges now that it has had some unduly harsh consequences, as in the case of the woman targeted for deportation because she was convicted of pulling another woman's hair. But he would like officials to handle those cases administratively rather than have Congress amend the act.

title: Fatal Shot an Accident, Officer's Lawyer Says
description: An unarmed man slain by a backup undercover narcotics detective outside a bar on Manhattan's West Side flew into a rage, punched an officer, ignored shouts of ''Police!'' and was shot when he grabbed the detective's gun and it discharged once into his chest, a lawyer for the officer said yesterday.

title: At 75, a Hipster on the Drumming Edge
description: It's very hard to believe that Roy Haynes is 75. He walks with rubbery, snapping, limping, rolling motions, like the most truculent, hard-core hipster you can imagine. He wears pants that flare at the bottom and button up the legs. And playing drums, he sounds earthy, minimal, hypermasculine and resourceful, orienting himself around the smashing and bashing of his small kit's high-hat and snare drum, implying as many beats as he articulates, liberating himself through subtraction.

title: Predatory Loan Scams
description: A Minnesota paralegal realizes too late that her home equity loan was for $13,000 more than she thought. A borrower finds out belatedly that her $45,000 loan required not only $90,000 of repayments over 15 years, but also a final additional payment of $41,000. These are despicable examples of predatory subprime home equity loans -- loans using the borrower's home as collateral that are made to people with blemished credit records and that impose exorbitant fees or conditions that virtually force the borrower into foreclosure.

Eight miles of track in all.

Here, that experience showed.

The weekends have been booked up so quickly that two years ago a three-day March festival was added. This year from next Friday to Sunday guests will see six new films that are scheduled to open in theaters in the late spring and early summer.

title: Correction
description: An article on March 5 about documents that have recently been made public about the Pinochet years in Chile referred incorrectly to the papers of former Secretary of State Henry A. But Mr. Kissinger has said that other classified papers in his collection are duplicates of documents in State Department and other government archives, where they are subject to normal declassification procedures.

title: Heat; Killer Clothes
description: Michael Kaplan, the costume designer, is somewhat amused. ''I'm flattered,'' he says with a laugh. ''But, hey, where's my cut?'' He is responding to a report from Milan in The New York Times that Donatella Versace's fall men's collection was inspired by the spirit of ''Fight Club,'' a movie whose clothes he created. One might well imagine a runway strewn, as the film was, with junked cars, broken glass and pools of motor oil in which models bloody one another with fists, elbows and boots, with the resulting globs of effluvia spattering the front row.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  LYNN, EDWARD J.
description: LYNN-Edward J., 81, of Little Silver, New Jersey, on March 17, 2000, after a heart attack. Born in Scranton, Pennsylvania, he grew up in South Amboy, New Jersey, where he graduated from St. Mary's High School in 1935. He enlisted in the Army Air Corps in 1941 and flew 50 combat missions as a P-38 squadron commander in Italy and North Africa. He was awarded the Distinguished Flying Cross and the Air Medal with eight Oak Leaf Clusters. He retired from active duty in 1946 with the rank of Major. Like many of his generation, on returing from the war he used the GI Bill to complete his bachelor's degree in Business Administration from Pace University in 1949. He earned his C.P.A. certificate in 1952. He married the former Rose McGuire of Perth Amboy, New Jersey, in 1944. Mr. Lynn, a native of South Amboy, NJ, had worked for 32 years for The Continental Group, originally Continental Can Company. He helped to manage its growth as a diversified, multi-national company, supervising acquisitions in Europe, especially Germany, and planning the company's move to Stamford, Connecticut, in 1979. The company's first C.P.A., he rose through the accounting and finance ranks, retiring as Controller in 1983. Mr. Lynn lived most of his life in New Jersey. He and his wife raised their family in Metuchen before moving to Southport, CT, in 1979. They remained in Connecticut for 11 years, where they were members of St. Luke Church in Westport and the Patterson Club in Fairfield. They returned to New Jersey in 1991, moving to Little Silver. In recent years Mr. Lynn served as a volunteer at Riverview Medical Center in Red Bank, NJ. Mr. Lynn was an active parishioner at Holy Cross Church in Rumson, NJ, and was a member of Beacon Hill Country Club, Atlantic Highlands, NJ. Mr. Lynn had also served as a member of the Advisory Board at St. Benedict's Preparatory School, Newark, NJ. He is survived by his wife of 55 years, Rose McGuire Lynn, a native of Perth Amboy, NJ; five daughters: Katharine Thornton of Newark, NJ, Anne Rahill of Washington, DC, Jean Lynn of Arlington, VA, Mary Hickey of Falls Church, VA, and Patricia Saclyn of Medina, OH; six sons: Edward of Cologne, Germany, James of Silver Spring, MD, Thomas of Mount Vernon, WA, John of Springfield, NJ, Robert of Budd Lake, NJ, and Paul of Wyomissing, PA. Also surviving are two sisters: Ann Henry and Rosemarie Muchanic of South Amboy, NJ, a brother, John, of Colonia, NJ, 18 grandchildren and one great-grandchild. A Mass of Christian Burial will be celebrated at Holy Cross Church, Rumson, NJ, on Tuesday, March 21, 2000, at 10 AM. Visiting Monday, March 20, from 2-4 PM and 7-9 PM, at John E. Day Funeral Home, Red Bank, NJ. In lieu of flowers, contributions may be made to the Edward J. Lynn Scholarship Fund, St. Benedict's Prep., 520 King Blvd., Newark, NJ 07102-1314, Attn: Development Office.

title: Mr. Clinton's Journey to South Asia
description: With just 10 months left in office, President Clinton today begins one of the most important trips of his presidency. Though India, Pakistan and Bangladesh make up a sixth of the earth's population, no American president has visited this turbulent region since Jimmy Carter in 1978. In part, the long neglect is attributable to the cold war, when Pakistan was assigned the role of front-line ally against the Soviet Union while India got written off as a friend of the Kremlin. Today it is the tensions between these two countries that threaten a nuclear war, and the United States needs to re-energize its approach to their problems.

The years and the smoke from steaming and sizzling dishes, however, seem to have taken their toll. Brilliant colors, mirrors and brass have become murky. Decor has been left to languish, and food, once so vibrant and promising, seems to have suffered a similar decline.

title: Taking Care With Bearing Walls
description: THERE are two types of walls in a house, partition and bearing. Partition walls divide the interior space into rooms but support no weight. Bearing walls function as dividers, but they also hold up part of the house. Serving as important structural elements, bearing walls transfer the weight of the roof and upper floors to the foundation. All exterior walls are bearing walls. They support the roof at the ends of the joists. The interior bearing walls support the floors above and the attic weight. They support the joists at midpoint.

title: At the Edge of Order

Everything is matted to the earth or anchored in the mud except the ridges an eastern mole has made while tunneling round and round. The early bulbs seem desperate just now. Nothing else catches the hint of spring from them.

This was 1975, the early Polyester Period of the Cenozoic Era, and the only thing wider than the bright horizon on which I projected my youthful ambitions was the tie I wore to work. It was an age of great social and technological upheaval: American women abandoned the spiritual impoverishment of the home for the spiritual impoverishment of the workplace, and, in response, men began using hair dryers and wearing platform saddle shoes. Microwave ovens delivered bad popcorn in only half the time. Back in Minnesota, we recorded and reported these events with all due dispatch and the appropriate gravity.

title: A Vision of Suburban Bliss Edged With Irony
description: THE picture on the back cover of the new edition of Bill Owens's classic 1970's photographic essay, ''Suburbia,'' says much about when and where it was taken, and about the delicate balancing act that characterizes the project of which it is a part. In the image, a young couple stand in their large, immaculate kitchen. On the table in front of them sit two icons of abundance, a bowl overflowing with preternaturally shiny fruit and a chubby baby. The stylish mother distractedly guides creamed corn into the child's mouth, while Dad clutches a freshly poured cocktail. As is often the case with Mr. Owens's images, a quote from the subjects serves as the photo's caption: ''We're really happy. Our kids are healthy, we eat good food, and we have a really nice home.''

title: Books in Brief: Nonfiction; Man and Beast
description: If you were to judge a book by its cover, Yann Arthus-Bertrand's GOOD BREEDING (Abrams, $49.50) might seem perfect for the same audience that loved the rural charms of ''Babe.'' Here, gazing proudly out at us, is a smiling farmer surrounded by a swirl of astonishingly tidy piglets and their even tidier mother. Delve into the book, though, and a different impression takes hold. Arthus-Bertrand's studies of prize-winning domestic livestock -- photographed against simple canvas backdrops at agricultural shows in England, France, Italy and Argentina and lighted like Caravaggios -- turn out to be a curiously appealing blend of art and kitsch. Arthus-Bertrand, the author of more than 20 books of aerial photography, including ''Earth From Above'' and ''New York From the Air,'' prefers to get breeders and handlers in his pictures, so if you're not a connoisseur of Lincoln sheep or Chianina cattle, it's the interplay between human and animal that will catch your eye. Some of Arthus-Bertrand's not-so-still lifes -- like the action sequence of a French shepherd shearing a Rambouillet ram and ewe, pausing for a tolerantly impatient glance at the photographer -- suggest high drama tinged with comedy. Others -- like the Auxois mare and her aristocratic French owner, both caught in majestic profile, and the bespectacled Lincolnshire breeder hunkered down next to a Portland ram who exactly mirrors his expression of attentive politeness -- suggest that the old saw about pets resembling their owners might hold true for farm animals as well. Their names also provide fertile ground for speculation: Anas, the Gascon cow; the moist-nosed Limousin bull called Fripon (son, we are told, of Brutus and Sedentaire); the gigantic scrunch-faced Middle White pig whose official name, Gillhouse Fairlady V, usually yields to Little Pudding. And what about those pigs on the cover? They're Italian, not Australian: Felomena and her children, from Verona. But their sturdy owner, Giovanni Ottorino, could be Farmer Hoggett's long-lost cousin -- except for that rakishly angled fedora. Alida Becker

''People were afraid of the altitude. The musician who was supposed to play the music was afraid of heights, and he wouldn't ride in the cable car. Nobody except me thought it was going to work out.''

title: Corrections

It has indeed developed a drug that qualified for use on the human body: Vitravene was approved by the Food and Drug Administration for treatment of cytomegalovirus retinitis, an eye disease.

description: FOR an actress who epitomized American cool, Audrey Hepburn is inspiring a lot of nervous sweat. In life, her fragile beauty and elegantly pared-down fashion sense made her one of the most distinctive, most admired stars on the Hollywood screen. And that is precisely the problem.

title: Town Adjusts to Historic Verdict
description: PEARLYLYN and Dwight Reid spent Monday evening at their New Milford home with family and friends, exchanging hugs and high-fives and clinking Heineken bottles in celebration of a historic verdict that found a New Milford police officer guilty of manslaughter for shooting their 27-year-old son, Franklyn.

title: Quick Trip to a French Gilded Age

description: The year 2000 Michelin hotel and restaurant guide to France was released Feb. 29, awarding the prized three-star rating to one of the country's oldest establishments, the 18th-century Grand Vefour in Paris. The restaurant, under the direction of 43-year-old Guy Martin, is known for its modern, inventive cuisine and ornate decor, with dining rooms overlooking the Palais Royal gardens. This brings the number of three-star restaurants in France to 22 -- 7 in Paris and 15 in the provinces.

title: A Mighty Fortress
description: In a world where ''bumper-sticker Christians'' cut you off in traffic in their luxury S.U.V.'s, it was refreshing to read about those who actually follow some tenets of their faith. The greed, commercialism, materialism and rampant overconsumption that trouble the Scheibners are also deeply disturbing to many in my Unitarian congregation, as they are to good-hearted people of all faiths.

title: Retail Therapy; Tommy, Can You Hear Me?
description: Every spring, when the new fashions walk off the runways and into the stores, men everywhere ask the same two questions: ''This is guy stuff, right?'' and ''Who would wear this?'' While most fashion magazines would have us believe that these clothes are designed for Everyman, I believe the demographic to be a tad smaller. In fact, I believe that there are only four types of men who wear these styles: male models; men who want to be male models; men who sleep with male models; and men who sleep with men who want to be male models. So, what about us regular Joes? The irregular Joes? The butchers, the bakers, the Internet makers? Will we continue to live our lives trapped between a runway and a workplace? Well, throw away those Sears and J. C. Penney charge cards, my fashion-stunted brothers, because this year the top designers have decided that it's all about you. They've abandoned their usual muses and designed their spring lines in direct response to letters from real men with real jobs and real fashion needs.

Only a few wore identification badges dangling from their necks, but most, whether American citizen or foreigner, had something to say about the Department of Energy's new security rules for foreign scientists at Brookhaven.

For the trench they are digging, which will be home to a state-of-the-art fiber optic cable transmitting data and voices around the globe, lies on the front lines of the battle for the heart and soul of the Japanese economy.

title: Food; Alice Waters Cooks Her Turkey Too Long

Procrastinators can rejoice that they have 249 (or 281) days to plan but not execute, and the better-adjusted can analyze leisurely instead of rushing to the stove, ripped magazine recipe in hand, on Thanksgiving or Christmas morning. And tortured perfectionists like Barbra Streisand can practice, practice, practice.

title: Civics and Culture In Greenwich

Instead, I believe my friends and neighbors are sympathetic to all the victims; the slain young girl, her parents and family, those who have been accused rightfully and wrongfully, a prominent family that has no connection to the slaying except for being related to one or more of the suspects and, indeed, a town that just happens to be the site of the tragedy.

title: Enforcing A Ban On Dogs

Our floor had three dogs when we moved in, but that number has grown to seven. The last four arrived after the ''no dog'' rule went into effect. The super and the management office know what is happening, but despite four years of complaints from neighbors about noise and smells, nothing has been done. What are our rights? We are awakened all the time and are stressed out by constant barking. . . . Lisa Quinn, Manhattan

title: Being Charlie Kaufman
description: Charlie Kaufman, the author of ''Being John Malkovich,'' one of the strangest and most original screenplays in years, was standing near his table at the Golden Globes ceremony in January in Beverly Hills, shrinking into himself. In his mid-30's, Kaufman is boyishly slight beneath a somewhat unruly corona of frizzy, dark hair, but his obvious discomfort was making him appear smaller still. With Cameron Diaz, one of the stars of ''Malkovich,'' sitting just to his right and Spike Jonze, the film's director, nearby, he anxiously greeted well-wishers. No sooner did one of these people turn to leave than Kaufman's shoulders hunched and his eyes searched for something in the vicinity of his shoes. ''I am hot,'' he said. ''I am uncomfortable. I am nervous.'' He said this twice.

title: Footnotes
description: 1. All of Nashville has been resting easier now that two drifters have been charged with the two-year-old murder of 78-year-old Skull Schulman. A Nashville institution in his own right, Schulman was owner of Skull's Rainbow Room on Printer's Alley, where he gave countless country stars their first break. When a TV producer came to town in the 60's looking for talent, Schulman assembled some of Nashville's most promising young stars, and ''Hee Haw'' was the result. title: Footnotes
description: 1. David Bowie, who took his name from a knife, has always been on the cutting edge of art rock. For 30-odd (really odd) years, he's spent an undue amount of time in hair and wardrobe. How refreshing, then, that he showed up for this shoot in jeans and a sweater. Did the man who sold the world his own overbaked image suddenly fall to earth? Where's that bloodless alien whose icily distant voice and intergalactic fashions influenced so many other narcissists? Where's the glitter, the (lip) gloss? (Try the CD ''The Man Who Sold the World,'' $13.99 at Tower Records.) 2. ''Bowie is going for a clean, natural look,'' announced Herve of Frederic Fekkai, whom Bowie specifically tapped as his mane man. ''But may I plug our hair products -- Baby Blonde Shampoo ($18.50) and Smooth Hair Hydrating Hair Creme ($16.50)? Do you know Bowie has not a single gray hair? Eez fantastique!'' (For products, call 888-333-5524.) 3. Off-camera, Bowie picks up a Prada shoe, remembering that in England during the reign of mods and rockers, such items were called chiseled-toe high-pointers. Now they're the big thing in footwear ($350, at Prada, 841 Madison Avenue). 4. Fans, you have just a few hours to see Bowie's Ziggy Stardust get-up at the Costume Institute's show at the Met (closing today). The gear has devotees cooing: visionary! And detractors sneering: pretentious! Nothing clean and natural there. 5. The Bowie camp issued a food list for the shoot. Nouveau vegan perhaps? Something exotic from his wife Iman's native Somalia? No, Starbucks French roast coffee and ham and cheese sandwiches. Pity Bowie didn't know about these six-foot heroes, $96 from Manganaro's Hero Boy, 492 Ninth Avenue. ''Heroes'' was one of his more humanoid songs, and much more than a sandwich. 6. Bowie's last major film was ''Basquiat,'' in which he played a cameo as Andy Warhol in charmingly dotty fashion. Want that Warhol wig for yourself? Fifi Mahony's French Quarter New Orleans wig shop (www.fifi-mahony.com) might oblige. Or, better yet, try Fifi's harlot hair for around $120. 7. Besides ''Heroes,'' Bowie has written some memorable songs, like ''Modern Love'' and ''China Girl.'' He has also had great luck producing Iggy Pop's ''The Idiot'' and ''Lust for Life'' ($12.99 each from HMV Records). But Bowie will be best known for ''Space Oddity'' (No. 60 in VH1's greatest all-time rock songs). 8. So how does a rock star with an underwhelming string of hits rack up a huge fortune? In 1997 Bowie was the first rocker to offer asset-backed bonds paying 7.9 percent on his catalogue and future earnings. Instant jackpot: $55 million. And now there's Bowiebanc.com offering mortgages and 5 percent interest on checking. Wall Streeters like to quip: There are bulls, bears and pigs. Repulsed by the triumph of commerce over art? That's so-o 60's. Get over it.

title: Food Fights

Etiquette hasn't kept up. Half-eaten sandwiches are stolen from their owners' desks, while office microwaves and refrigerators ooze with months of grime. And few workplaces seem to have any desktop-dining rules. Send your spiciest stories to On the Job, Money & Business, The New York Times, 229 West 43rd Street, New York, N.Y. 10036. title: Magic Bullets for a New Age
description: There's a pill for every physical and mental ailment. But what if you've got spiritual problems? A handful of artists are at work on remedies that will test the limits of the placebo effect. Vitamin S capsules, designed by Pearl and Noelle Maremont, a mother and daughter team in Santa Monica, Calif., are meant to nourish the soul. Each contains a hand-rolled scroll with an inspiring quotation; a vial of 120 is $24.95 at Vitaspirit.com. The Canadian artist Dana Wyse makes a ''Do It Yourself Pharmacy'' whose pills and other nostrums promise users, among other things, they will ''Be Blonde Immediately'' and ''Stay in Love Forever.'' The cure-alls are $7 at the New Museum of Contemporary Art at 583 Broadway. Jacqui Millar of the Idealogue design firm makes pills that are alternatives to greeting cards. ''Maybe you've upset your best friend and want to say you're sorry,'' Ms. Millar said. ''There's the standard apology note waiting at the local stationery store, or you could send one of my 'undo' pills.'' Meant to engender forgiveness in the recipient, they are sold in sets of three mini-boxes for $20 at Alleged Galleries (809 Washington Street, at Horatio Street). BILL POWERS

title: Feel Good, Smell Good
description: Had to catch the Paris shows on TV? Well, if you can't afford couture, at least you can get a whiff of it now that haute fragrance houses are offering customized scents. ''While custom-blending has been around for years, it always had a mom-and-pop approach,'' said Annette Green, president of the Fragrance Foundation, an industry group. ''Now for the first time, it's being done by knowledgeable high-end perfumers.'' At Creed, the French perfume boutique at 9 Bond Street, specialists guide clients through 200 scents to create their own blend; the customer leaves with a personal formula and 1.7 ounces of Eau de Self ($400 to $600). Sarah Horowitz, a California-based perfumer, conducts hourlong consultations ($355) called the Fragrance Journey. Mixing aromatherapy with notes of psychotherapy, she asks: ''What perfume did your mother wear? Did your father smoke a pipe? When were your happiest times?'' She assembles these fragrance ''memories'' into signature scents that ''cause my clients to remember and love themselves,'' or at least smell good. Appointments: (310) 589-1089. ELLEN TIEN

More recently, in the wake of Jon Krakauer's best-selling book ''Into Thin Air,'' the image of the mysterious Shangri-La has suffered. Katmandu has been reduced to a polluted staging ground for mountain adventure, while the trails themselves sound as crowded as the Long Island Expressway on a summer weekend. One friend advised that I visit neighboring Bhutan instead. ''Nepal is finished,'' he told me.

title: Why I Was In Vietnam
description: Twenty-five years after the fall of Saigon, the Vietnam of the war years seems a vanished and discredited civilization animated by obsessions worthy of Melville. The circumstance that begat the struggle -- the cold war -- has vanished. The personalities that drove it -- Ho, Kennedy, Johnson, Nixon and their advisers -- have vanished, mostly. All the soldiers are middle-aged or older, and many are dead. The memoirs have slowed. Of the Americans, only McNamara and Kissinger continue, self-consciously, to brood out loud. Yet the ghosts remain at the table, rising whenever Washington contemplates a military adventure. Nicaragua, Grenada, Panama, Somalia, Haiti, Bosnia, Serbia and Kosovo were all seen through the shadow of Vietnam. For American statecraft, the legacy is as profound as that of World War Two.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  ADELSON, LORETTA
description: ADELSON-Loretta. Mother of Beth & Stewart, widow of the late Henry, sister of Hy, Sara, and the late Bob and Bette. Was a cherished sister and daughter, stalwart support of four siblings and helpmate of immigrant parents; Organizer of neighborhood baseball team and award-winning amateur vaudeville performer with siblings; Night student at Hunter College, street-corner organizer for social justice and civil rights, volunteer nurse's aide in WW II; A most gracious, charming, dignified, yet unassuming lady, she found purpose and joy in helping others. PhD, Deputy Chair of Department of Speech at Brooklyn College, grant-winner and creator of college's program of recording for the blind called of ''Incalculable Value'' by chairman; Outstanding, creative, inspiring teacher, deeply interested in and loved by students; Cherished wife of over 50 years, inexhaustibly dedicated to husband's well-being and comfort during long illness; Above all else, most caring, affectionate and thoughtful mother possible, never missing an opportunity to fill children's lives with security, joy, curiosity and love. ''Jerry Robbins sat down with me and said, 'Is there anybody you're interested in that I could help you identify by name?' '' Mr. Feld recalls. ''I had been watching Damian dance, and I said, 'That boy over there in the gray tights -- he is magical!' Jerry said: 'You think so?' Sometimes when you live in a place, you become myopic. But for me, he was young and beautiful, like a little boy-god. And he danced with such wonderful musicality and phrasing, which is very, very rare in dancers.''

title: Walking Out On Uneasy Success

But once in Paris the feisty Ms. Kidjo, a singer who contemporizes traditional music from across Africa, soon became a modern-day Josephine Baker, selling out concerts at the renowned Olympia concert hall. She lived a comfortable life in Paris's fashionable Marais -- that is until a couple of years ago, when she moved to Brooklyn. ''I had to get out,'' Ms. Kidjo said recently from her brownstone in Park Slope. ''France was stifling me.''

title: PULSE; Oscar Night Accessories
description: Read any good movies lately? Screenplays have become trendy tie-in products for movies that don't lend themselves to souvenir action figures. While less fun than an Annette Bening doll or a frog-proof umbrella, Oscar-nominated shooting scripts for ''American Beauty'' and ''Magnolia'' can grace your coffee table in time for next Sunday's Big ''O'' festivities. Other hot releases include John Irving's screenplay for ''The Cider House Rules'' and Anthony Minghella's for ''The Talented Mr. Ripley,'' both from Talk Miramax Books. Scribner is selling Frank Darabont's take on Stephen King's ''Green Mile,'' while Faber & Faber is offering Mike Leigh's ''Topsy-Turvy'' script. ''Tie-ins work because people want to stay with characters longer,'' said Esther Margolis, a publishing consultant for Columbia Pictures and publisher of Newmarket Press, which recently added ''American Beauty'' and ''Magnolia'' to its Shooting Script series. Often illustrated, annotated and boasting an introduction by the director (features that pirated scripts bought off the street can't claim), published screenplays lend a screenwriter a certain cachet, even if they don't generate the huge sales of some film-based novelizations. While 10,000 copies is considered a successful press run for a shooting script, this year's Oscar front-runner, ''American Beauty,'' has four times that many in print. Seeing the movie on paper adds a dimension to the experience, Ms. Margolis said. And perhaps for the first time you can grasp the nuances of that overlapping dialogue in ''Magnolia.'' But will owning the scripts help increase your odds in the office Oscar pool? FRANK DE CARO

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  WILBERT, WENDLA
description: WILBERT-Wendla. Died at home March 15 after a long illness. She was a graduate of Colby Sawyer College and Boston University. She received a Master's degree in social work from New York University. She had previously been employed as an Editorial Assistant and worked as a social worker for Beth Israel and Roosevelt Hospitals. She was an active volunteer at The International Club and United Nations where she taught English as a second language. She was also a member of the Art Students League. She is survived by her father, Theodore R. Wilbert of Key Largo, FL, her two sisters; Cornelia Grondahl of Lebanon, NH and Alexandra Fleischman of Northborough, MA and Southampton, NY. She also leaves several nieces and nephews. Services at Frank E. Campbell,1076 Madison Avenue at 81st Street, Monday, March 20th, 11:30 AM.

title: MOVIES: CRITIC'S CHOICE
description: JOHN HUSTON knew how to cap off a brilliant directing career. His last film was THE DEAD (1987), a blissfully evocative adaptation of James Joyce's story about a Dublin holiday party and a hotel-room conversation afterward. The same story is being told, of course, in a current Braodway production. Adjelica Huston and Donald McCann star in the film as the married couple who learn, in the wee, quiet horus of the morning, that the past is inescapable and the dead are always with us - Friday/Early Saturday at 4 a.m, Saturday at 1:30 p.m. on Bravo.

title: American Modernists At the National Gallery
description: Visitors to the National Gallery of Art can get a short course in American modernism by walking through the East Wing, where ''Twentieth-Century American Art: The Ebsworth Collection'' is on view till June 11.

title: A One-Sided Image
description: To the Editor:

title: Bracing for Newest Round of Inquiry in Providence
description: Renaissance, shmenaissance, some things in Providence, R.I., remain very much the same, it seems.

title: If You're Thinking of Living In/Carnegie Hill; Small-Town Feeling, Big-City Prices
description: IN 1996, the Rev. Dr. Jim Burns and his family moved from Lexington, Ky., to Carnegie Hill. He remembers the day clearly. As their moving van maneuvered through a narrow side street, it backed into a tree.

title: Treasure or Eyesore, Old Building Evokes Passion
description: Between the Manhattan Bridge and the Brooklyn-Queens Expressway, nestled under the shadow of the mammoth Watchtower Society headquarters, sits one of the most elaborately decorated industrial buildings in Brooklyn.

title: An Insecure City Loses, or Rediscovers, Its Identity
description: PEOPLE here recoiled at the news last week that The Los Angeles Times had been sold to an out-of-town company, with many moaning that this insecure city -- frequently described by its residents as a shapeless megalopolis that doesn't even have, or deserve, a professional football team -- had been robbed of an essential piece of its identity.

title: No More Cherry Trees, And the Hill Is Leveled
description: In the town that for better or worse represents post-war suburban development in South Jersey, there has been a lot of rethinking lately about what this sprawling area should do with its remaining swaths of land.

title: Its Voters Have Spoken. Now Meet Iran's Gunmen.
description: AFTER 21 stressful years of living under clerical dictatorship, most Iranians would happily settle for a more normal life. But last week, just as they were celebrating the reformist landslide in Febuary's parliamentary elections and the hope of a peaceful progression toward a more democratic society, an assassin's bullet provided a shocking reminder of how grim and uncertain a struggle may yet lie ahead.

title: Storehouse Of Tibetan Culture
description: DANZHU LANGJIA, a 40-year-old Tibetan monk, knows all about difficult journeys. From Kumbum Monastery in Qinghai province, he has traveled south by foot and ramshackle bus across the arid steppes of the Tibetan plateau. After five days, he has arrived at the sales counter of the Dege Printing House, where he reaches into the folds of his crimson cloak and counts out 153.2 yuan -- about $18.50.

title: Corrections
description: An article last Sunday about three Hollywood character actors misstated the release date of the movie ''Bossa Nova,'' starring Stephen Tobolowsky. It opens April 28, not in May.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  FRIEDES, BERNICE
description: FRIEDES-Bernice. Beloved CoPresident of NCJW New York section. Bernice Friedes was admired for her caring and courage. Her concern for others was demonstrated by her dedication and enthusiasm for projects that served the needy. Her love of family was the compass for her life. Jean Krosner, Co-President Helen Caplin Heller, Exec. Dir.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  VAN ECK, FRED MARINUS
description: VAN ECK-Fred Marinus. Of New York City, passed on March 15, 2000 at Tenacre Foundation in Princeton, NJ. Born in San Francisco, CA Sept 14, 1918. Beloved son of Baron Jan Carel van Panthaleon van Eck of the Netherlands and Agnes Tillman of San Francisco. Caring brother of John and Bart R. van Eck, Agnes Reed of Aptos, CA, and Henriette Warfield of Anapolis, MD. Uncle of Jan and Derek van Eck, New York City, and eight additional nephews and nieces. A former partner of J.H. Whitney & Co., then an active businessman with interests in the U.S. and the Netherlands. A private memorial service will be held in Santa Barbara, CA. Donations may be made in Fred's memory to ''Save The Redwoods'', 114 Sansome St., San Francisco, CA 94104.

title: A Determined Fighter Who Paid a Price
description: People here who know Taiwan's president-elect, Chen Shui-bian, often describe him as remote and impersonal. In interviews, the 49-year-old politician comes across as almost robotic, reciting policy positions with a blank gaze and a frozen smile.

title: Giving Those Poor Substitute Teachers Some Support and Advice
description: Every time a substitute teacher takes over a class, he or she walks into unknown territory, often with scant preparation and no knowledge of the students. Rearranged desks, dropped books and students answering to the wrong names may be the least of the obstacles presented to a substitute by students who want to test the patience of an inexperienced teacher.

title: Two Shows Define Basics of Each Other
description: TWO shows at the Neuberger Museum of Art at Purchase College here go a long way in defining the basic differences between Modern and contemporary art. Representing Modernism is a show called ''Milton Avery: Selections From the Permanent Collection.'' The other show, ''Inner Eye: Contemporary Art From the Marc and Livia Straus Collection,'' gives a sample of the most important artists creating Conceptual art in the final decades of the 20th century.

title: Corrections
description: Because of an editing error, an article and a picture caption last Sunday about the video release of ''A Cry in the Dark'' misstated the year the movie opened. It was 1988, not 1982.

title: Constructing a Stellar 'Ring' of Diverse Parts
description: RECORDINGS of Wagner's tetralogy, ''Der Ring des Nibelungen,'' are no longer the cultural milestones they were at midcentury. The first studio recording -- Decca's -- took shape in stages from 1958 to 1966, with the as yet unknighted Georg Solti leading the Vienna Philharmonic and a cast headed by Birgit Nilsson, Hans Hotter and Wolfgang Windgassen. More than three decades on, remastered and reissued on at least two occasions, it remains the best-selling ''Ring'' in the catalog.

title: Mr. Goodbucks, the Sequel: True Confessions
description: IT was true confessions time in this space two weeks ago. Single career women, talking about what they want in men, admitted to a nagging voice that tells them to assess a man's financial status along with his looks and other qualities.

title: Paid Notice: Memorials  KURZ, ARNOLD WOLFGANG
description: KURZ-Arnold Wolfgang. My darling Arnie-surely goodness and mercy have followed you. A beautiful life has been lived upon the earth, we are richer for having known such joy. You are the captain of your soul and mine. You bless us always. Missing and loving you every minute, Your Donna, Arnold James, Kim and Morgan

title: Offspring Still Not Up to Snuff of Parent
description: SOHO BISTRO in Rockville Centre is a sequel of sorts. It, and the Focaccia Grill in Wantagh, are owned by Brian Arbesfeld, a chef who saw previous service at the highly regarded Il Toscano in Douglaston, Queens. Both of Mr. Arbesfeld's ventures are laid-back storefronts with candles, soft lighting and menus with an Italian spin.

title: Corrections
description: An article on Page 1 of Arts & Leisure today about Audrey Hepburn misstates the date of her death. It was 1993, not 1963.

title: A Nasdaq Correction; Now Back To Business
description: DID last week's stock market hubbub change anything? Of course, the highflying Nasdaq market has suffered repeated sinking spells but the latest one -- last week's three consecutive triple-digit declines amounting to just under 10 percent -- was accompanied by a revival in industrial stocks of the Old Economy. The Dow Jones industrial average soared nearly 500 points on Thursday, the most ever.

title: Fanciful Figurines
description: FOR many couples, the traditional plastic or porcelain bride and bridegroom figurines that decorate the tops of wedding cakes are about as appealing as shag rugs. The bridegroom tends to look like Oliver North and the bride like a 1950's airline stewardess who's stingy with the drinks.

title: A Second Look, and a Second Chance to Forgive
description: STRUGGLING to complete ''A Moon for the Misbegotten'' before illness permanently silenced his writing in 1943, Eugene O'Neill fancifully described the character based on his older brother, James O'Neill Jr., as an ''alien.''

title: Political Briefing; Mapping a New Route For a McCain Run
description: Gov. Jesse Ventura of Minnesota, the nation's most successful third-party candidate, says that Senator John McCain could win the presidency if he would only take that route now. But Mr. Ventura insists he is not pressuring Mr. McCain, the Arizona Republican, to bolt his party and go for it this fall.

title: Executive Producer Search Is On
description: The search for a new executive producer is on at American Stage Company in Teaneck. A news release dated March 2 announced the departure of James N. Vagias after nine years, effective at the end of the season. No hoopla, no surprise.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  TEOMMEY, CHARLES E.
description: TEOMMEY-Charles E. Of Edina, MN, born December 12, 1907, in Brooklyn, NY, died March 15, 2000. Devoted husband of Edna for almost 65 years. Survived by wife Edna; daughter Dr. Susan (Dr. Robert) Rydell, Minnetonka, MN; grandson Christopher (Sangrail) Rydell, great-granddaughter Megan Rydell, St. Louis Park, MN; and other dear relatives and friends. Retired teacher and assistant headmaster, The Buckley School, NYC, and former community faculty member in French at Metropolitan State University, Minneapolis-St. Paul. Memorials preferred to The Spence School, Teachers College Columbia University, The Buckley School, or the Silver Bay Association, Silver Bay, NY.

Ms. Axelrod is no day worker hawking soap samples on the street. She is a business executive, and she spent Thursday asking anyone who would listen: ''Do you have any clinical research experience? Do you have any clinical research experience?''

My anger and sadness for their children grew by leaps and bounds as I read the article. There were so many shocking revelations: the ''border collie'' look directed at little Baleigh when her attention wavered from the endless sermonizing, the bullying of Katie at the supper table into articulating the benefits of courtship over dating, Stephen Scheibner's ''rules'' for spanking.

title: A Touch of Gray Is No Barrier To a Job Today
description: NO one else but seniors would take this job,'' said Theresa Delaurentis, a representative of REH Marketing, who gets paid $8 an hour to travel to supermarkets throughout the Island and ask shoppers to sample different products. On a recent afternoon at Pathmark in Woodbury, Ms. Delaurentis, a Bethpage resident who acknowledged only that she is over 65, was offering graham crackers to customers as they shopped.

title: South Africa In a Furor Over Advice About AIDS
description: President Thabo Mbeki's decision to seek advice from two Americans who argue that H.I.V. does not cause AIDS has touched off an outcry at home and abroad and raised fears that South Africa's already soaring infection rate will climb still further.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  FOX, ELEANOR
description: FOX-Eleanor. Loving, beloved wife of George Fox. Loving mother of Nicki. Cherished grandmother of Zoe, Chad and Sarah. Mourned by her loving son-in-law James, cousins Florence, Paul, Ruth, Sam, Selma and Shirley. Great sons-in-law Josh and John & great daughter-in-law Deborah. Forever in our hearts. Services are at Rocky Point Funeral Home, on Friday, March 17, at 1 P.M.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  HUNTINGTON, REV. MSGR. CHRISTOPHER
description: HUNTINGTON-Rev. Msgr. Christopher. Died peacefully on March 10, at age 89, at his residence at Kendal of Hanover, NH. Retired Pastor of Most Holy Trinity Church, East Hampton, NY. He served in the Parish of St. Aloysius, Great Neck, NY; was Dean of the College Division of St. Pius X Seminary; and taught at the Cathedral of the Immaculate Conception, Douglaston, NY. Served as Lt. Commander USNR, with Naval Intelligence during WW II. He earned his AB degree from Harvard, 1932, and STL from Catholic University, 1952. He was ordained to the preisthood in 1952. Revered brother-in-law of Lee Pennock Huntington of Norwich, VT, and uncle of Lydia Sparrow, Madge Huntington, Mary Silloway, Francis Huntington, Lawrence Huntington, Susan Fisher, and the late Sarah Fletcher, and the late Samuel Huntington.

title: More Asian-American Businesses, Yet Few Seek Loans
description: For all of New York's famous assertiveness, its Asian-Americans are bringing up the rear when it comes to seeking loans from the federal Small Business Administration.

title: Frogs in Full Throat
description: So it isn't Niagara Falls, or even the Great Falls. And it isn't the finale to Beethoven's Ninth, either. But both a natural wonder and a choral event it is nevertheless: the spring peeper frogs filling the night with an almost deafening high-pitched cry. Performances start around now, at a pond near you, according to ''25 Nature Spectacles in New Jersey,'' by Joanna Burger and Michael Gochfeld (the authors suggest the Great Swamp, the Hirair Hovnanian Plant and Wildlife Sanctuary and a few other places). The frog concerts are the first of the list. The shad run on the Delaware and the appearance of glass eels at Cheesequake follow. Then among summer highlights are the nesting herons at Avalon, fiddler crabs at low tide on the beach and the American lotus at Mannington Marsh in Salem County. Fall is time for migrating monarch butterflies at Cape May, and bats at the abandoned Hibernia Mine in Morris County. In winter, it's migrant snow geese at Brigantine and swans at coastal lakes. Just in time for the spring peepers again. The book, which costs $5 in hardback and $20 in paper and is published by Rutgers University Press, includes 99 illustrations.

description: Relief Doctor to Speak

title: Mia Laudato, Daniel Liebowitz
description: Miamatilda Maria Laudato and Daniel Sidney Liebowitz were married yesterday by the Rev. Joseph Spina, a Roman Catholic priest, at St. Bernard de Clavivoux Episcopal Church in North Miami Beach, Fla. Rabbi Barry Silver took part in the service.

title: A Flutist Into Jazz And Business, Too
description: THE flutist Sherry Winston never met a stereotype she could not break. She is one of a few female African-American jazz recording artists and former record company executives of the 1980's. She also defies the perception that gifted musicians lack business acumen by managing her own career successfully.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  KOHL, SYD
description: KOHL-Syd, age 91, on March 17, 2000 in Stamford, CT. Widow of Milton Kohl. Devoted mother of Nancy & Donald Wergeles, Susan & Jerome Katz. Cherished sister of Anne Robinson. Loving grandmother of John & Jean Wergeles, Adam & Melissa Wergeles, Peter & Janice Katz, David & Shelly Katz. Adoring great grandmother of Maya & Emma Wergeles, Alexandra & Jacqueline Katz, Jared, Daniel & Caroline Katz. Services Monday 11 AM at Beth David Cemetery, Elmont, NY.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  KRINSKY, ARNOLD L.
description: KRINSKY-Arnold L. Died March 12, 2000 at the age of 68 after a courageous battle with myelodysplasia. Loving husband to Doreen for 15 years. Also survived by daughters Danelle, Laurel, Nancy and Carolyn and grandchildren Joshua, Jeremiah, Angela, Gabriel and Sepharia. Sisters Arlene (Norman), Vivian (Jack), Florence (Alvin). Arnold taught at Erasmus Hall High School for 30 years and built Tax City, a successful income tax business for 41 years. Arnold was an intelligent and generous man who loved life and lived it to its fullest. He will be missed.

title: Opening the World's Eyes to the Struggles of Iran
description: ON a sunny Friday afternoon last fall, the director Majid Majidi, in town for the New York Film Festival from his native Tehran, was in demand. Negotiations for the American distribution of his latest film, ''The Color of Paradise,'' which opens March 31, were under way. Earlier in the week reporters had been talking with him about Iranian films, about why they are so often about children (many of the directors worked with the state-sponsored Institute for the Intellectual Development of Children and Young Adults) and what it is like making films under censorship (it has eased up in the last two years). By Friday, Mr. Majidi was in Cliffside, N.J., at the home of a friend, Jamsheed Akrami, a professor of film and television at William Paterson University in Wayne, who was interviewing him for a documentary. Looking out over a sparkling Hudson River at Manhattan, Mr. Majidi fielded calls on a portable phone as Mr. Akrami instructed a student to videotape him from first one angle, then another.

title: CLEAN WATER
description: Under 1996 amendments to the Safe Drinking Water Act, federal regulators last October began requiring water companies and utilities to mail reports to customers about where contaminants exceeded permissible levels. But information in the Consumer Confidence Reports for New Jersey's 600 water suppliers has been incomplete, regulators and environmentalists said last week. The New Jersey Environmental Federation, a non-profit group, said the reports were not encouraging. Only 110 of the water suppliers responded, and among those, 62 received a failing grade from the group. Newark, the state's largest municipal water utility, got an F for not providing foreign-language information despite a large non-English-speaking population. Pam Goldstein, a city spokeswoman, said its water quality consistently passed with flying colors. ''That's why all the breweries came to Newark,'' she said. STEVE STRUNSKY

title: Residents Seek More Room For Trucks in Tight Spots
description: For the drivers of trucks leaving the Stella D'Oro biscuit factory on West 237th Street, navigating the intersection with Broadway can be dicey.

title: Term Life: The Safety Net Comes at a Higher Price
description: THE life insurance industry is battening down its hatches -- and consumers, it turns out, will pay the price.

description: Though play in the National Collegiate Athletic Association tournament has been guard-driven in recent years, size drives the four teams playing Sunday in the South Regional.

description: Animal Triste

title: Help From the Hometown
description: At 3:45 p.m. on Super Tuesday, Mary Sibley was still in Scarsdale, leafletting for the Bill Bradley campaign. Then she raced home here, stopping at Party City to pick up Barbie plates and favors for her daughter Isabelle's fourth birthday party later that day.

title: POSTINGS: 16 Floors at 340 East 29th Street; In Kips Bay, a Rental Building With a Landscaped Courtyard
description: The 16-floor rental building under construction at 340 East 29th Street, between First and Second Avenues, will add 120 new apartments to the Kips Bay area when completed this summer. It will also add a rarity in Manhattan, a 50-by-114-foot landscaped courtyard entered through a gate.

title: Wall Signs of Old Times
description: THOUGH controversy swirls around today's giant advertising signs, oversized ads are nothing new. As evidence, the Municipal Art Society is putting on an exhibit called ''Art of the Wall Dogs: The Painted Signs of Yesteryear.'' The work of the ''wall dogs,'' from around the turn of the last century, has been documented in photographs by Sava Mitrovich, who was born in Belgrade and immigrated to New York in 1969.

title: Ranting; Stubble trouble
description: Not that you asked, but I don't know if I could be close to a man with a soul patch. Just the name gives me the jimjams. It has other, perhaps even more unfortunate, monikers, like the coy and nauseating ''my jazz.'' I've never actually spoken to a man who displays such a thing, but I think should the occasion arise, I might find myself trying not to stare at it, the way you do when someone's fly is open or he has some awful piercing, though it would dominate my thoughts and then, inevitably, I would be staring, revolted. I feel the same way about sideburns. Or maybe especially about sideburns. Ditto goatees.

title: Swimming With Dolphins; Talking, Too
description: FOR most of the past decade, Kathleen Dudzinski has spent thousands of hours in the waters off the Bahamas and Japan studying how dolphins communicate with each other.

title: Some Risks Are Worth the Reward
description: Eric Seleznow may have been the only person in Maryland who was not surprised when a team of young prison inmates took second prize in a stock-picking contest.

title: Mets' Reed Goes All Out For the Perfect Practice
description: When it comes to taking the ball out of Rick Reed's hand, Al Jackson has succeeded where Reed's mother never could.

title: Points of Pride
description: Five men and the passions that inflate their sense of self.

title: 'Redwood Curtain' on Stage in Croton Falls
description: ON the streets of Arcata, a lumber town in Northern California, the playwright Lanford Wilson was startled by living ghosts, hovering in the light of day. ''They just stared at me,'' he recalled in a conversation last October when his newest play, ''Book of Days,'' was in previews at the Hartford Stage in Connecticut.

title: In Nassau, a New Police Leader and a First
description: IN 1953, a young man from Glen Cove, fresh from the Navy and the Korean War, returned home and wanted to become a police officer. His father and friends told him to forget about the Nassau County Police Department because it already had its quota of Negroes. They warned him that the police department would justify keeping him out by saying he had high blood pressure.

title: The Art, and Travail, of Public Speaking
description: JUST about the worst thing that can happen to anybody is being forced to drive to La Guardia Airport on a weekday morning and trying to park there. The second worst thing is being called upon to speak in public. In both cases, the victim suffers from cold sweats, nausea and feelings of inadequacy and impending failure.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  LONDON, JEAN
description: LONDON-Jean. Beloved mother of Eileen Schwartz-Bizar and Peter Schwartz; beloved sister and grandmother, was buried on Sunday, March 19. Her indomitable spirit will always be remembered.

title: A Mighty Fortress
description: Thanks for Margaret Talbot's refreshing article on the Scheibner family. It was the most uplifting article I have read anywhere in the news media for longer than I can remember. It makes me believe there is still hope that our nation can be morally renewed.

title: A Film Surprise This Year Is in the Audience as Well as on the Screen
description: Not so long ago, the way to promote a major mainstream movie was to put up a trailer that in the case of a comedy included all the best jokes and in the case of a drama included almost all the crucial plot points.

title: Backtalk; The Sports Ethicists Come Out in Force. Let's Ignore Them, O.K.?
description: Call this the Era Between the Vinces. Big-time spectator sport is struggling to figure out how much of its market wants that old-time religion (as preached by Coach Vince Lombardi of the Green Bay Packers) and how much wants the new-time sensations (as peddled by Vince McMahon of the World Wrestling Federation.)

description: Now that it is all but certain who the presidential nominees will be this fall, the buzz is beginning about which states will hold the key to victory.

description: SCHULMAN-Celia. Of Sarasota, FL. Formerly of Brooklyn, N.Y. Beloved wife of Max. Devoted mother of Suzanne Hausdorff. Loving grandmother of Karen Pruzansky, Dr. Mark Hausdorff, Lisa Sanders and Fanny Elefant. Cherished great-grandmother of 14 grandchildren. Services Sunday, 1:30 PM, at Gutterman-Musicant, 402 Park Street, Hackensack. Shiva will be observed at the home of Rabbi and Mrs. Pruzansky, Teaneck, NJ.

title: Date Nears for Owners To Re-Register Pistols
description: THOUSANDS of otherwise law-abiding Westchester residents may find themselves in trouble with the police April 1 for failing to re-register pistols.

title: Coyote, a Wily Survivor, Is Alpha at His Zoo Home
description: The coyote ceremoniously captured last year in Central Park is alive and well in Flushing Meadows.

title: Artists and Buildings In Need of Advocates
description: I am ashamed of our city planners, the mayor, the Maritime Museum and the Norwalk Redevelopment Agency for their unwillingness to see the potential of the Lock Building as a multi-use arts center, and for not protecting one of Norwalk's most valuable resources: its artists (''Artists Must Leave a Building They Saved,'' Jan. 16).

title: Footnotes
description: 1. Before hitting the beach, surfers gather at Surfin' Donuts Coffee House, San Clemente's answer to the Manhattan corner deli. ''Six to seven o'clock is our busiest hour,'' says the co-owner, Doug Lemon. ''Surfers come here to get their energy fix -- a Surfin' Donut, a muffin, some coffee.'' We followed. 2. Even surfers get pasty in winter. To compensate, the groomer Maralyn Salameh mixed SmashBox foundation sticks ($28 each; 888-558-1490) with Vaseline and smoothed the concoction onto the surfers' arms and legs. 3. For messy surfer hair, ''blow-dry every which way,'' then scrunch the front pieces with a dime-sized dollop of texturizer, like Tigi's Bed Head Manipulator ($16.95; 800-256-9391) or American Crew Pomade ($8.50; 800-598-2739). 4. Much like surfer hair, surfer clothes are thrown together -- almost anti-fashion. So it's ironic that designers like Cynthia Rowley (who showed her spring collection poolside) and Sandy Dalal (who mixed sleeveless T's with knee-length shorts) would -- and did -- put these carefree looks on their painstakingly planned runways. 5. This 1955 Chevrolet ''phantom'' woodie station wagon has old-school surfer written all over it. According to David Miller, founder of www.oldwoodies.com, woodies (vehicles with wood paneling) helped conserve steel during the World War II shortage. ''By the 60's, used-car dealers had tons of cheap, beat-up woodies, which surfers found perfect for lugging their longboards.'' Interested? Contact George Coleman at (901) 373-5555. 6. ''I love listening to my sons talk about their adventures that I've had nothing to do with,'' says Dr. Dorian (Doc) Paskowitz, 79, the surfing guru who started Paskowitz Surf Camp at San Onofre State Beach in 1972. Maybe that's because Paskowitz is a risk-taker himself. The Stanford-trained doctor passed up cushy medical practices to wander the globe with his wife and nine children (see sons Jonathan and Joshua on page 91, second photograph from top), working in medical clinics and living in campers. Today, Paskowitz is still ''on call for the world'' as a missionary doctor; his son Israel runs the surf camp, and his sons Jonathan and Abraham design a line of surfwear for Tommy Hilfiger. 7. A little story about being in the right place at the right time: during this shoot, Karen Swainson, the photographer's assistant, was innocently crocheting one of her charming hats when our style department editor David Farber insisted on photographing it. Now she makes them to order for $50 to $150 each. Call the artist formerly known as the photographer's assistant (718) 398-8817. Wearing Karen's hat is our ''hilarious,'' ''knows everybody,'' ''haven't-seen-him-in-a-month'' shoot guide, Jed Morouse, who was missing at the time of reporting. Not even Surfin' Donuts knew where he was. So Jed, dude, if you read this, call home.

title: The Heart Wants . . .

For this meeting at his cigar club, Hamilton's, in Pasadena, Calif., he was dressed in a charcoal-gray suit with a navy wool polo shirt and leather loafers so soft they looked as if they'd melt if he stood over a heated vent. His silver-black hair was cut short and spiky, and his hands looked as if they'd never done anything more brutal than downshift a speeding Ferrari. Coming from the high mesas of southern Colorado, where the cool desert air cleanses mind and body of civilization's poisons, Anna finds herself smothering in the soft, rank fecundity of the humid South. ''The South was thick with life, crowded with it,'' she says. ''There was a feel of sentience to the soil, the night, the forest.'' More alien yet are the local life forms: the ticks, the alligators, the good ol' boys who'd just as soon toss her in a swamp. title: The Way We Live Now: 3-19-00: Salient Facts: Demolition; Bringing Down the House
description: THE ULTIMATE TEARDOWNOn March 26, at precisely 8:30 a.m., the largest concrete domed structure in the world will fall to the ground. According to Mark Loizeaux, whose Maryland-based Controlled Demolition Inc. has been hired to bring down the 24-year-old Seattle Kingdome so that another stadium can rise in its place, ''It's wanted to do that since the day it was built.'' But it needs help, because the Kingdome is also one of the strongest buildings in the world. The dome alone contains 25,000 tons of concrete, and each of its 40 vaulted ribs incorporates seven lengths of two-and-one-quarter-inch reinforcing steel bar. Massive columns of concrete -- and more arm-thick rebar -- support the dome. Holding everything in place at the base of the dome is an enormous ring of concrete laced with yet more rebar: this tension ring, tightened to 8.8 million pounds of tension, secures the dome's ribs like a rubber band around a bouquet of flowers. Destroying the Kingdome is the most complicated of the 7,000 demolitions Loizeaux's company has undertaken. Nearly three months of preparations are needed for an implosion that will last less than 20 seconds. Cost: $9 million.

title: Books in Brief: Fiction; Burning Volvo
description: Roberto Silva believes he's ''making a comeback in life.'' Downsized from his job as a security guard at an Oakland bank, homeless and penniless and reduced to crawling through the mud on his belly in order to elude the police, Roberto nevertheless sees an ''enterprising future stretched ahead.'' Like Silver Mendez and Gus Hernandez, the men who share with him the unforgiving world of Gary Soto's memorable new novel, NICKEL AND DIME (University of New Mexico, cloth, $29.95; paper, $16.95), Roberto is a man whose flawed vision and good heart make him an endearing if tragic figure. The interconnected stories here follow the declining fortunes of the three men: Roberto, whose innocent scheme to keep from starving backfires when a Christmas wreath he sells sets a man's Volvo on fire; Silver, an aging poet who hasn't sold any of his work in years; and Gus, Roberto's compadre from the bank, whose 19-year service as a security guard ultimately amounts to nothing. Soto's characters cross paths in unlikely places, and their wanderings join together the disparate lives of people who seem to have little connection to one another. Soto, who is also a poet and writer of young adult fiction, recounts with sensitivity and humor the travails of his characters, Mexican-American men who are living on society's margins. Soto's sympathy with their dreams and his refusal to preach about how society has cheated them makes ''Nickel and Dime'' a powerful novel, unpretentious and brutally honest. Laura Ciolkowski

title: A Dancing Juggler Whose Act Plays Tag With Gravity
description: THE music hall and the circus are not the places devotees of dance hang out looking for revelations, which as a rule probably saves them disappointment, but every so often a revelation comes along. A case in point: the 29-year-old Ukrainian juggler Viktor Kee (born Kiktev), currently in San Francisco through next Sunday with Cirque du Soleil's extravaganza, ''Dralion.'' (The show moves to San Jose on April 6 and to Denver on June 6.) His act involves seven solid plastic balls, hand-molded by the artist himself, which he not only sends flying in arcs that amaze the eye but somehow also catches -- no hands -- on a shoulder, on a knee, on the back of his neck. At one point, planted on his knees, he lines up five balls straight down his undulating spine.

title: Aristocrats.com

(Hey, some of these mammals might not make it; better put your money on the dinosaurs.) But sitting in England, where tech fever is more recent but if anything runs even hotter, I feel the urge to put in something of a good word for the American technology boom. Put it this way: our investors seem moderate, sensible and on the right track -- at least when you compare them with their counterparts elsewhere in the world.

title: Mens Fashions of the Times; We're So Vain
description: Narcissus gave male vanity a bad rap. O.K., so maybe he did carry things to extremes, but you no longer need to look like a Greek god to justify your self-love. Kept within reason, vanity can be a positive force for all men, young or old, traditional or cutting-edge, handsome or plain, hairy or bald. Everyone has the potential to improve the way he looks and feels. And what we can't alter, we can at least learn to feel good about. Thanks to changing attitudes and a strong economy, men have gradually come to embrace the vanity they had always been taught to scorn.

title: Two Plus Two

So ''Queen Esther,'' which happens to be taking up space at the Forum Theater here, should be twice blessed. Both felicitous timing and popular myth are on the side of the new musical that means to roll along merrily as it rails against oppression.

title: Show & Tell; Making Up Is Hard To Do
description: The important thing to remember here is that I was carrying out an assignment. Having recently become an editor at a fashion magazine, I had already become suspect among my close male friends. If they found out I was wearing makeup, it might mean my last invitation to the Esquire Poker Game, a manly (if neurotic) gathering I'd been a part of since the mid-1980's. Ron and Gil would be brutal if they knew I was wearing a tinted moisturizer. It might also mean my last Sparks Lunch, an annual December excursion with some buddies to the midtown meat mecca for platters of seared cow flesh. They'd be merciless. And, worst of all, it might mean having women friends poke around in my medicine chest, looking to scam some mascara and maybe a little blush, and coming across my secret stash of old Valium prescriptions.

title: LONG AFTER THE STORM
description: Residents of Bergen ANd Somerset counties who were flooded by Tropical Storm Floyd last September are still awaiting federal aid, county officials said last week. William Schuber, Bergen County executive, said the storm caused $377 million in damage to private and public property in his county. Many of the businesses remain closed, and some people are still living in trailers. In Somerset, damage was estimated at more than $100 million, and the relief is insufficient, said Peter S. Palmer, a freeholder in the county. The Federal Emergency Management Agency has paid an average of $21,000 to qualified homeowners, which does not go far in northern New Jersey, said an aide to Mr. Schuber. KAREN DeMASTERS

title: Corrections

It dates from 1940, not 1941. The article also referred incorrectly to the Kingsbridge neighborhood at that time. It was already heavily settled; it had been many years since the area was farmland.

title: The Invisible Poor
description: The way a rich nation thinks about its poor will always be convoluted. The richer people become in general, the easier it theoretically becomes for them to share with people who are left out. But the richer people become, the less they naturally stay in touch with the realities of life on the bottom, and the more they naturally prefer to be excited about their own prospects rather than concerned about someone else's.

title: Echoes of a Fallen Kingdom
description: IN the remote badlands of far western Tibet lie the two remaining sites of the ancient Kingdom of Guge: Tholing, the 11th-century Buddhist monastery that was, in its time, the region's most influential lamasery; and Tsaparang, the old capital of Guge. At both sites, now largely in ruins, statuary and dozens of well-preserved murals in the brilliant West Tibetan style offer glimpses of a vanished age.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  ADELSON, LORETTA
description: ADELSON-Loretta. Mother of Beth & Stewart, widow of the late Henry, sister of Hy, Sara, and the late Bob and Bette. Was a cherished sister and daughter, stalwart support of four siblings and helpmate of immigrant parents; Organizer of neighborhood baseball team and award-winning amateur vaudeville performer with siblings; Night student at Hunter College, street-corner organizer for social justice and civil rights, volunteer nurse's aide in WW II; A most gracious, charming, dignified, yet unassuming lady, she found purpose and joy in helping others. Columbia U. PhD, Deputy Chair of Department of Speech at Brooklyn College, grant-winner and creator of college's program of recording for the blind called of ''Incalculable Value'' by chairman; Outstanding, creative, inspiring teacher, deeply interested in and loved by students; Cherished wife of over 50 years, inexhaustibly dedicated to husband's well-being and comfort during long illness; Above all else, most caring, affectionate and thoughtful mother possible, never missing an opportunity to fill children's lives with security, joy, curiosity and love. Cherished beyond any words. Donations may be made in memory to the following charities: Recording for the Blind and Dyslexic, 20 Roszel Road, Princeton, N.J. 08540; Memorial Sloan-Kettering Cancer Center, 1275 York Avenue, NY, NY 10021 or The National Audubon Society, 700 Broadway, NY, NY 10003.

Lauderdale, FL. In the mid 1970's he opened the Saugatuck Broward Marine plant at the mouth of the Kalamazoo River. Broward Marine Inc. is America's largest aluminum custom boat builder. He was preceded in death by his wife Gertrude Winslow Denison in 1997. Survivors: children, Christopher Denison, Frank Denison Jr., Kenelm and Vicki Denison, three grandchildren, two greatgrandchildren, sister-in-law Jacqueline Russell and Janet Winslow Ryder, nieces, nephews and cousins. Visiting 6-8 PM, Tuesday, Saugatuck Chapel, Dykstra Funeral Homes, and 10-11 AM, Wednesday at the church.
