title: Bosnia a Success? A Pointed Dissent
description: To the Editor:

title: House Republicans Rely on a Walking Political Almanac
description: REPRESENTATIVE Thomas M. Davis III does not want an asterisk next to his name in some political almanac with a footnote reading, ''Bungled Republican control of the House.''

title: Russell King, 45, Deputy Editor On the News Desk at The Times
description: J. Russell King, a deputy news editor of The New York Times who sharpened the prose of reporters, the precision of headlines and the meaning of news for readers with a learned, subtle and anonymous hand, died on Saturday night at St. Luke's-Roosevelt Hospital Center. He was 45 and lived in Manhattan and Brooklyn.

title: Shards of Misery, Not Far From Clinton Stop in Bangladesh
description: The wretched squatter colony known as the Kawran Bazaar Bustee straddles Dhaka's main railroad line, the relentless iron wheels of the trains rolling within feet of the flimsy hovels of scrap metal, thatch and muslin.

title: Waco Simulation Is Held, and Judge Seals Videos
description: Gathered deep inside the nation's largest military base, a group of government officials, special investigators and private lawyers watched an unusual simulation today that was intended to help determine whether the Federal Bureau of Investigation had been truthful about its role in the fatal Branch Davidian standoff in 1993.

title: Lightly Raced Red Bullet Wins and Aims for Derby
description: New York may not be the main road to the Kentucky Derby, but it has provided a direct route for some major racehorses in the past, stars like Native Dancer, Secretariat and Easy Goer. And it may have propelled another young star toward Churchill Downs yesterday when Red Bullet stayed undefeated in his third start and won the Gotham Mile by half a length over Aptitude in New York's first prep for the classics.

title: Woods Triumphs Again, Leaving Love in Awe
description: The story line was familiar, and so was the outcome. Tiger Woods protects Sunday leads like a miser protecting his money. Davis Love III must have felt like a rock climber, trying to scale a mountain that kept getting steeper and steeper. Love never made it to the top, falling once again to Woods, who has dominated Love and dominated golf for more than a year.

title: Corrections
description: A report in the News Watch column of Circuits on Thursday about the online version of the Oxford English Dictionary misstated the price of institutional subscriptions. They start at $795 and depend on the customer's size, the number of users and other factors; there is no universal price.

title: Giuliani Cites Criminal Past Of Slain Man
description: Pressed to respond to charges that he is demonizing the victim, Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani yesterday intensified his criticism of Patrick Dorismond, the unarmed man killed on Thursday by an undercover police officer, suggesting that his ''pattern of behavior'' and his actions the night of the shooting had contributed to his death.

title: Free Music Software May Have Rattled AOL
description: Justin Frankel, a 21-year-old programming wizard who sold his digital music company, but perhaps not his soul, to America Online last year, did not endear himself to his new masters last week by publishing free software that enables users to find and trade music files quickly over the Internet.

title: Altered Food: Passion All Around
description: To the Editor:

title: A Vatican Opportunity
description: To the Editor:

title: Bracing Views From a Man Of Mysteries
description: There is a scene in the novel ''Devil in a Blue Dress'' that peeps at the place where Walter Mosley's politics and art meet. Easy Rawlins has been pressed into detective service by DeWitt Albright, a mysterious, sinister man who lures Easy with enough money to make the overdue mortgage payments on his beloved home. Easy is a Negro and DeWitt is white in the Los Angeles of 1948.

title: Advisory Panel on Internet Taxes Unlikely to Reach Consensus
description: Making the Internet a tax-free zone seemed the right idea in Congress 14 months ago. The Senate voted 96-2 for a three-year moratorium on any new taxes on electronic commerce, and the House agreed by voice vote. Congress also created a national advisory commission whose members, Congressional Republicans expected, would recommend a permanent ban on taxing Internet sales.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  KOWAL, JOHN
description: KOWAL-John. Died March 18, at home with his immediate family, Deborah Guide, Lisa Kowal-Philipides and Robert Kowal. John was a loving father, and grandfather to Michele, David, Niko, Nakora and Rhys. He was a mentor and role model for his entire extended family and community. He will be loved and missed but his legacy will live on through all of us. Services 12:30 PM, Tuesday, at Congregation Rodeph Sholom, 7 W. 83rd St. Interment in Elizabeth, NJ.

title: In America; The Mud-Slingers
description: I'm curious. I wonder when it was that the mayor of New York misplaced his humanity.

title: Europe's Turn to Keep the Peace
description: A year ago, American and NATO warplanes began 78 days of air assaults that halted the murderous assault of Slobodan Milosevic on the Kosovar Albanians. If the United States has learned anything in the nine months of peacekeeping that followed, it should be that once again we are proving to be a lot better at waging war than we are at managing peace. Kosovo today appears to be on the verge of unraveling.

title: Ford Plans Job Cuts At Plant in England
description: The Ford Motor Company is likely to eliminate more than 1,000 jobs at a giant assembly plant in England and may close the entire factory, in another blow for the British government's industrial policy.

title: Compressed Data; A Product Good Enough For Government Work
description: It is not often that a business will promote its products' performance as being on a par with an activity of the federal government. But Royal Consumer Business Products is betting that such a connection will strike a chord with security-conscious consumers. The company is promoting its new line of low-cost paper shredders as enabling consumers to ''Shred Like the Feds.''

title: Six Hurt as Fire Truck Hits a Car in Brooklyn
description: Six people were injured last night, one critically, when a fire truck on the way to a fire struck a car in Sheepshead Bay, Brooklyn, the authorities said.

title: White House E-Mail Feud Grows
description: Representative Dan Burton said today that he would subpoena President Clinton's chief counsel to appear before a Congressional committee this week to explain a computer glitch that might have kept e-mail messages received by hundreds of White House officials out of the hands of Congressional and other investigators.

title: Holy Land Jitters Heighten Security for Papal Visit
description: A recent newspaper cartoon illustrated the anxiety here that something will befall Pope John Paul II on his six-day pilgrimage to the Holy Land, which begins on Tuesday. The cartoon shows Prime Minister Ehud Barak of Israel encouraging the pope to step out onto a bridge that extends into the Sea of Galilee.

title: Bush Calls Himself Reformer; the Record Shows the Label May Be a Stretch
description: With the long march to November under way, Gov. George W. Bush is arguing that his record in Texas proves he is best suited to bring reform to Washington. He has even coined a campaign slogan: ''A Reformer With Results.''

description: ''He betrayed Taiwan!'' ''He's a traitor who sold out the Nationalist Party!'' ''He's a monster, lower than a dog!'' ''Step Down Lee! Step Down Lee!''

title: Media Talk; Putin's Memoirs Set for Publication in U.S.
description: PublicAffairs, a New York company that is fast becoming the publishing house for Kremlin politicians, is preparing to rush into print in May with an English translation of the memoirs describing the life, travails and cold war spying adventures of Russia's acting president, Vladimir V. Putin.

title: Boycott Myanmar
description: To the Editor:

title: The Auction Hullabaloo Reverberates At Art Fair
description: When the doors to the European Fine Art Fair opened here on Friday afternoon, the 198 exhibitors were all smiles, eager to talk about the prized offerings they were placing before some 8,200 visitors who poured into the convention center where the fair is held every March.

title: Derby Fever Will Not Distract Drysdale
description: The trainer Neil Drysdale, who has never had a Kentucky Derby starter, may have two this year.

description: A partial list for this week.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  MCCABE, LORA T.
description: McCABE-Lora T. On March 18, 2000, at age 91. Beloved sister of Raymond F. Triebert. Dear sisterin-law of Marjorie Triebert. Interment private.

title: It's Wait Till Next Year For St. John's and Jarvis
description: For a team that expected to finish the season in the Final Four and survived a midseason slump as well as a late-season inquiry by the National Collegiate Athletic Association, St. John's had a remarkably dry-eyed locker room after the second-seeded Red Storm fell Saturday, 82-76, to 10th-seeded Gonzaga in the West Regional of the national tournament.

title: Managing the World's Water
description: The most precious fluid on earth is not oil, but water. There are few challenges as important as conserving the world's usable water and supplying clean drinking water and water for irrigation to those who need it. Yet this work is not getting done. Humans are depleting the earth's store of usable water at a rate that will soon threaten our food supply. Poor water management already kills millions of people a year and condemns hundreds of millions to hunger.

title: A Civil Action
description: Note: This lesson was originally published on an older version of The Learning Network; the link to the related Times article will take you to a page on the old site.

title: E-Commerce Report; Insurance companies, hampered by the industry's traditions, cautiously enter the Internet waters.
description: INSURANCE companies have always seen fit to take the long view of business, scanning actuarial tables for potential revenue streams years after their products are sold.

title: Unable to Pull Away, Top-Seeded Duke Holds On
description: Sometimes the seeding does not matter.

title: Different Cycles For News Media Test New Media
description: At 6:30 p.m. on Tuesday, Ron Insana, co-anchor of CNBC's ''Business Center,'' began his broadcast with an exclusive report, presented breathlessly: eBay and Yahoo were in discussions about a possible merger.

description: Compressed Data: Old-Line Law Firm Links Up to the New Economy

title: Metro Matters; Right to Know What Mayor Finds Relevant
description: IT wasn't entirely clear at first why the mayor and the police commissioner were kind enough to give the public all that information about Patrick M. Dorismond, the latest unarmed black man killed by a police officer. But over the weekend, the mayor enlightened us. ''The public has a right to know,'' he explained.

title: Vermin Problems Noted In Many Supermarkets
description: One-quarter of the city's supermarkets have vermin problems and more than half failed recent inspections, a state legislator said yesterday.

title: WHITE HOUSE SEEKS TO CURB PILLS USED TO CALM THE YOUNG
description: The White House will announce a major effort on Monday to reverse a sharp increase in the number of preschool children using Ritalin, Prozac and other powerful psychiatric drugs, administration officials said today.

title: Formula TV Fades Away, and Suddenly Everyone's Got a Gimmick
description: ''The Beat,'' a swift and engrossing series about a pair of improbably good-looking police partners, begins with the men sitting in a bar. Mike Dorigan (Derek Cecil), the fair-haired, clean-cut half of the team, tells the dark and impulsive Zane Marinelli (Mark Ruffalo), ''You have this thing for psycho women.'' Just then Zane's girlfriend wanders in wearing oversized pink flannel pajamas. ''I was sleeping, then I woke up,'' she says in a fog. ''Suddenly I felt compelled to see you.''

title: TRANSACTIONS
description: BASEBALL

title: At Kmart, an Anti-Gun Vigil Draws a Larger Counterprotest
description: The plan, anti-gun protesters said, was for a peaceful prayer vigil, a calm but determined way to demonstrate their displeasure with the sprawling Kmart store in Riverhead, on Long Island, for selling hunting rifles. But instead of quiet prayers and reflection, the 50 anti-gun demonstrators who arrived at the store on Route 58 yesterday afternoon were confronted by more than 200 noisy counterdemonstrators who drowned out the vigil with chants and taunts.

title: Corrections
description: An article on March 2 about a house on West 13th Street in Manhattan that was once renovated by the architect Paul Rudolph misidentified a client for whom Mr. Rudolph redesigned a house on the Upper East Side. It was Alexander Hirsch -- not the designer Halston, who bought the house several years later.

title: Sykora and Elias Help the Devils Subdue Florida
description: Pavel Bure and the Panthers took the lead twice tonight against the Devils, but the Devils played with gusto after trailing in the opening period and rallied for a 5-2 triumph that ended a two-game losing streak.

title: After a 10-Year Wait, Huskies Settle a Score
description: It took 10 years and 2 days to do it, but Connecticut got even with Clemson tonight at Gampel Pavilion. The Huskies did so by crushing the Tigers, 83-45, in the second round of the East Regional of the National Collegiate Athletic Association women's basketball tournament.

title: Fears of Shift Toward Right Are Dismissed By Chretien
description: When reporters needled Prime Minister Jean Chretien a few days ago about unfavorable poll results, suggesting that he should step aside, Canada's leader turned on them like a lumberjack, saying, ''Listen to me -- I am the boss.''

title: Power Authority Set to Choose Buyer of 2 Reactors
description: The New York Power Authority is expected to choose today between two out-of-state companies fiercely bidding for the authority's two nuclear plants, setting the stage for what would be the largest sale of nuclear plants in this country.

title: VIOLENT PROTESTS IN TAIWAN FOLLOW ELECTION DEFEAT
description: A day after Taiwan's Nationalist Party was swept from power after more than 50 years, the fury of the losers erupted tonight, forcing President Lee Teng-hui to barricade himself inside his party headquarters as thousands of disaffected supporters battled with the police for hours.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  HOROWITZ, STANLEY

description: HODGSON-Richard. I am saddened by the sudden death of Richard Hodgson, a giant in the electronics industry. He was a very good friend and my lunch partner for 40 years. Dick, I'll miss you. Martin P. Rosenblum

title: U.S. Judge Backs Ex-Workers For Pan Am in Pension Case
description: A federal judge has sided with employees of Pan American World Airways in a case related to their pension plan and the way it was administered by a federal agency after the airline went out of business.

title: Basketball Ratings Hit a Slump at NBC And That Is Costly
description: Just two years ago, the National Basketball Association was a very hot sports attraction on network television, the ratings for its playoff finals at times eclipsing those for baseball's World Series.

title: Siemens-Mannesmann Link Is Set
description: Siemens, Germany's biggest engineering company, said today that its car-parts unit was planning a partnership with the VDO auto-parts business of Mannesmann in the face of mounting competition in the car industry.

title: A Love Story to Stop the Heart
description: So many feelings in each awkward kiss; such endless shades of response in a quick clasping of hands.

title: Essay; Contrasting Elections
description: The first great test of a new democracy is not only in the way its government tolerates opposition, but whether it is willing to transfer power to that opposition after a fair election.

title: Bertrand Fox, 92, an Economist And Securities Expert at Harvard
description: Bertrand Fox, an economist and expert on the securities industry who taught for more than 20 years at the Harvard Business School, died Tuesday at his home in Lexington, Mass. He was 92.

title: The Knicks' Turnaround Becomes A Tall Tale
description: One at a time yesterday, the Knicks' big men would duck around the back of Shaquille O'Neal only to disappear behind the Lakers' perfect hide-and-seek prop. One at a time, they would plant a forearm in O'Neal's waist and stick a body on his frame only to be brushed off like lint from his lapel.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SEIFERT, ESTELLE HALPERN.
description: SEIFERT-Estelle Halpern. 87. On March 19, of emphysema, in West Palm Beach, FL. Preceded in death by husband Murray Seifert. Survived by loving daughters Susan and Roberta Seifert and grandsons Ben and Larkin Donley.

title: All of Humankind Are Strangers in a Strange Land
description: ''I have contempt for those books,'' said a friend when I tried to describe my mixed responses to photography books that try to counter passive ignorance or battle-active prejudice by celebrating social diversity and emotional complexity. You know the kind I mean. The ''those who have made significant contributions to their people'' books. The books that focus on the rituals that make ''us'' just like everybody else. And those that glorify the intimate, even exclusionary ties that bind a group: mothers and daughters, say; the Jews of the Lower East Side; the Cherokee people.

title: QUOTATION OF THE DAY
description: ''He made everyone who guarded him look 6 feet tall.''

title: Deadlines, Databases and DNA
description: Gov. George Pataki wants to tap the potential of DNA evidence to help solve crimes, and his instinct is surely right. The power of the technology was illustrated when biological evidence found at a crime scene 20 years ago was shown to match a DNA sample taken recently from a jailed robber for inclusion in New York's newly expanded DNA database. But Mr. Pataki's two new legislative proposals are so broad as to warrant concern. The Legislature needs to proceed with caution.

title: Malone's Power Overwhelms Van Horn and Ends Streak
description: The man who is arguably the best power forward in basketball history wheeled in the paint and began throwing around his muscle. His immense shoulders were smashing Keith Van Horn in the chest. His thigh-sized biceps were smacking him in the ribs. And 16,103 fans and a team of defenders were hoping against the inevitable.

title: Rex Everhart, An Actor, 79; Played Franklin on Broadway
description: Rex Everhart, a character actor who appeared in 26 Broadway productions ranging from ''1776,'' in which he played Ben Franklin, to ''Working,'' for which he received a Tony Award nomination, died last Monday at a hospice in Branford, Conn. He was 79.

title: Presidential Election Could Alter Shape of Tribune-Times Mirror Deal
description: In the pending merger of the Tribune Company and Times Mirror, the fate of three of Tribune's largest television stations and three of Times Mirror's largest newspapers may ultimately depend on who becomes the nation's next president.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  ABRAM, MORRIS B.
description: ABRAM-Morris B. The National Conference on Soviet Jewry (NCSJ), its officers, Executive Committee, Board of Governors and staff mourn the loss of our former Chairman, a giant in the Jewish world and leading pioneer for civil rights in the U.S. and human rights worldwide, whose leadership and moral guidance never ceased. He led and inspired the Soviet Jewry movement in the U.S. during one of its most critical phases, from 1983 to 1988. Condolences to his widow, Bruna, and the entire family. Denis C. Braham, Chairman Howard E. Sachs, President Mark B. Levin, Executive Director

title: Sears in Dispute With Focus Media
description: Sears, Roebuck & Company is ending a relationship with one of its media buying agencies, Focus Media in Santa Monica, Calif., after nearly a decade and filing a lawsuit against Focus for breach of contract.

description: No. 1-seeded Stanford and second-seeded Temple and Cincinnati lost in the N.C.A.A. basketball tournament.

title: Bob Blackman, 81, Coach of Dartmouth Football, Is Dead
description: Bob Blackman, an innovative football coach at Dartmouth, Illinois and Cornell in a career that spanned 34 seasons, died Friday at a hospital in Burlingame, Calif. Blackman, who lived in Hilton Head, S.C., was 81.

title: Maryland Hostage Siege Drags on Into Third Night
description: A former convict with a history of mental illness, hunted in a shooting spree that took four lives, maintained a standoff against the police today, crackling the air with warning gunfire as he held three hostages in this tense suburban neighborhood.

title: Among Modern Marvels, Still a Great Act
description: Mingling the traditional and the technological with modern spectacle and time-tested skills at Madison Square Garden, the Ringling Brothers and Barnum & Bailey Circus is marching, dancing, swinging, soaring, pirouetting, plodding, prat-falling and blasting off into its third century of lavish entertainment.

title: Corrections
description: An article in Circuits on Thursday about making personal Web pages gave an incomplete name for the editor of efuse.com, a site for page designers. He is Daniel Will-Harris, not Will Harris.

title: Yanks' Top Prospects Are, Well, Minor League
description: The Yankees, as the Bronx knows them, came together today, with Bernie Williams and Derek Jeter and Paul O'Neill and other regulars all in the same lineup. Opening day is two weeks away, and for the rest of spring training, Manager Joe Torre intends mostly to play his veterans, rather than minor leaguers wearing numbers of defensive linemen, youngsters known only to the most ardent fans.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  OBERG, JAMES L.
description: OBERG-James L. 82. Died March 18, 2000, in Old Lyme, CT. He was with M & T Chemicals, a division of American Can Corp., vice president of Bangor Punta Corp. and was president of Smith & Wesson until his retirement in 1982.

title: Promotion Dispute With W.W.F. Jeopardizes Film
description: The world of documentary filmmaking and the world of professional wrestling do not often come together, but it might be expected that if they did, there would be a fight.

title: Snagging an Elusive Prize With Drama
description: After a decisive final deal in which freakish distribution, fatigue, a bidding disaster, luck, brilliance and a communication problem were blended in perfect proportions, the Vanderbilt Knockout Team Championship ended here at 2 a.m. today. Victory went to Nick Nickell of Manhattan; Dick Freeman of Atlanta; Bob Hamman of Dallas; Paul Soloway of Mill Creek, Wash.; Eric Rodwell of Naperville, Ill.; and Jeff Meckstroth of Tampa, Fla., who have been the world's best team in the last five years. They have won the world title twice and had a series of national successes, but the Vanderbilt Cup had always eluded them. It almost did again.

title: Corrections
description: A theater review in Weekend on Friday about ''American Buffalo'' by the Atlantic Theater Company misspelled the given name of the director. He is Neil Pepe, not Neal.

title: Passion, Skulduggery and Merrymaking in Venice
description: The Collegiate Chorale was founded in 1941 by Robert Shaw, the most influential American choral conductor in the second half of the 20th century. When Shaw left the Chorale in 1980, Robert Bass took over. And though Mr. Bass has never attained similar prominence (how could anyone?), he has done excellent work and led the organization in ambitious, and expensive, new directions.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  MARONEY, DR. GEORGE E.
description: MARONEY-Dr. George E. Our partner, Tom, is known as a brilliant lawyer. What he has shown us is what it means to be a loving son. Thank you Tom, for reminding us what is truly important in life. All our love to you, your mom, and your beloved wife, Michelle. Your partners, Eileen, Jim and Brian

title: Squeezing a Long Career Into 90 Minutes
description: Hardly any other jazz musician could or would put on a show in a small club like the one Pat Metheny offered at the Knitting Factory on Wednesday night. It wasn't just a free-associating chunk of a longer discourse, a casual display of his current predilections; it more or less condensed a career of more than 20 years into 90 minutes.

title: A Mainstream Giant Goes Countercultural; I.B.M.'s Embrace of Linux Is a Bet That It Is the Software of the Future
description: A huge company with deep pockets, I.B.M. can afford to dabble in promising technologies. And that is what the International Business Machines Corporation seemed to be doing throughout much of last year with Linux, an increasingly popular version of the Unix operating system that is available free on the Internet.

title: Murder Most Foul, or Just Plain Wrong?
description: Over years of probing the criminal mind, Robert Blecker, a professor at New York Law School, has become convinced that death penalty laws fail to cull the most vicious killers from the merely mundane murderers.

description: THIS team had been ousted from the National Collegiate Athletic Association tournament. Mike Jarvis was making his way back to the St. John's locker room.

title: The Huskies, Off Balance, Lose Their Crown
description: Out of sync, weaving and bobbing on the brink, Connecticut could not gain its balance here today. Finally, it fell flat. Hard. With point guard Khalid El-Amin missing nearly 27 minutes because of an injury, Connecticut felt its crown slipping throughout its 40-minute waltz with Tennessee. It was reminded of the difference a year can make.

title: Roger Longrigg, 70; Wrote Comic Novels
description: Roger Longrigg, a prolific British novelist who often wrote under pseudonyms, male and female, died on Feb. 26 at the Phyllis Tuckwell Hospice in Farnham, Surrey, England. He was 70.

description: IF you could take the central processor out of your computer and slip it in your pocket, you might have the ultimate in portability: a lightweight, digital brain, full of memory, storage and processing power, that can be carried everywhere.

title: Clinton Begins Visit to India, But First Comes Bangladesh
description: President Clinton, accompanied by his daughter, Chelsea, but not by the first lady, Hillary Rodham Clinton, arrived to a low key welcome here tonight for a state visit that the administration hopes will set the foundation for a new relationship with India.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  YANKAUER, WILLIAM PLATT.
description: YANKAUER - William Platt. Passed away on March 18th in his 96th year. Husband of the late Marjorie Lobman Yankauer and uncle of Ellen Seibel and Theodore Yankauer III. Billy, as he was known to family and friends, was a ''hellraiser'' in his youth, a road runner long before jogging became popular, and in his retirement years, a master miniature furniture maker. He was an enthusiastic benefactor of a number of non-profit institutions including Mt. Sinai School of Medicine, the American Museum of Natural History and the NY Public Library. Contributions to any of the aforementioned are welcomed

title: The U.S. Scrambles to Keep a Lid on Tensions and to Rescue Its China Policy
description: For more than a decade, Washington has urged Taiwan to let true democracy flower, knowing that it could eventually lead to the defeat of the Nationalist Party by pro-independence forces and put the island, and even perhaps the United States, on a collision course with mainland China.

description: Anyone doubting the increasingly mainstream status of Internet start-ups need only hear two words: Bob Dole.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SIEGEL, ANNE
description: SIEGEL-Anne. On March 20, 2000, devoted mother of Arlene, dear sister of Sally Schnapp. Services Wednesday 11:30 A.M. at Schwartz Brothers-Jeffer Memorial Chapels, 114-03 Queens Boulevard at 76th Road, Forest Hills.

title: Herman B Wells, 97, President Of Indiana U. in a Crucial Era
description: Herman B Wells, the president of Indiana University during 25 years of steady growth and social change, died on Saturday at age 97 at his home in Bloomington, Ind., not far off the campus of the university that was the center of his life for more than 70 years.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  GILL, JUDGE THOMAS D.
description: GILL-Judge Thomas D., died March 19, 2000. Beloved husband of Marie T. Gill; loving father of Thomas D. Gill, Jr., Kathleen G. Miller, Barbara E. Gill, and Margaret A. Gill, and cherished grandfather of Emelie B. Miller and Charity A. Gill. The funeral will be Wednesday at 10:00 AM in the Church of St. Timothy, 1116 North Main St., West Hartford. Molloy Funeral Home, West Hartford for further information. Memorial contributions may be made to the YMCA of Metropolitan Hartford, 169 Jewell St., Hartford, CT 06103.

title: Restoration In Search Of a Revival; Furnishings Chain Hurt By Its Own Strategy
description: When the home furnishings chain Restoration Hardware was preparing for a public stock offering in June 1998, it appeared to be the rare case of a retail concept that could remake its market. Although the chain, with just 43 stores, was tiny compared with its competition, its founder, Stephen Gordon, was hailed as a new Ralph Lauren -- a man with an instinct for translating the aspirations of the moneyed into real stuff.

title: Editorial Observer; Searching for Justice in Chile and Argentina
description: Until 16 months ago, it appeared that Chile had come to terms with the crimes of the Pinochet years. The murders, torture and forced disappearances, most of which took place in the mid-1970's, had faded from public attention. Not much was happening in the courts. But on Oct. 16, 1998, Gen. Augusto Pinochet was arrested in London on charges issued in Spain, and the illusion of Chile's reconciliation abruptly ended.

title: Slipping in Polls, Fujimori Courts Peru's Indians
description: Slipping in the polls and besieged by international criticism over campaign irregularities, President Alberto K. Fujimori has been fighting off altitude sickness, putting on Indian garb and cutting ribbons across this Andean country in a flourish of pork-barrel politics.

description: RAGUSA-Albert. On March 18, 2000 of Forest Hills and Fire Island, New York. Member NY Athletic Club and West Side Tennis Club. Funeral Mass at Our Lady Queen of Martyrs Church Wednesday March 22 at 10:15 AM. Interment Mt. St. Mary's Cemetery. As an alternative to flowers donations to Calvary Fund, 1740 Eastchester Road, Bx, NY 10461 appreciated.

description: To the Editor:

description: ANOTHER unarmed man has been killed by the police, and critics are wondering why the Police Department and the mayor don't get it. Didn't they learn anything from the Diallo case? It's a fair question, but it also might be asked about the critics.

description: A band of suspected militants massacred 34 Sikh men on Monday night in a village in the Indian state of Kashmir on the eve of President Clinton's state visit to India, a visit he had hoped would help bring peace in violence-torn Kashmir, a disputed Himalayan region claimed by both India and Pakistan.

title: CNA FINANCIAL MAKES OFFER FOR CNA SURETY SHARES
description: The CNA Financial Corporation, an insurance company controlled by the billionaire investor Laurence Tisch and his family, offered yesterday to pay $215 million for the shares of the CNA Surety Corporation it does not already own. CNA Financial, which recently said it planned to sell its life insurance unit, is offering $13 for each share. CNA Surety's shares rose $2.50, to $14. CNA Financial already owns 62 percent of CNA Surety. CNA Surety sells surety bonds, which are used by contractors to guarantee completion of construction projects. CNA Surety did not immediately respond to the offer.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SCHONFELD, HILDEGARD
description: SCHONFELD-Hildegard. Beloved wife of Sidney, mother of Vicki, Gary, Liz and Victor; adored grandmother of Jared, Matthew, Remi, Sam and Zachary; and devoted sister of Marianne. A gracious, charming, dignified, proud and unassuming lady, she found joy and purpose in helping others. A truly modern, forward-looking woman, she embraced traditional values. Cherished wife of over 50 years, she was inexhaustibly dedicated to Sid's well-being. Above all else, she was the most caring, affectionate and thoughtful mother and grandmother possible. She never missed an opportunity to full our lives with joy, security, attention and unqualified love. Hilde was extraordinarily charitable and always giving of herself-especially to the Cultural Arts Program at the JCC on the Palisades; The Arnold P. Gold Foundation; and the Jewish Home and Rehabilitation Center. Her curiosity and love of learning were boundless-whether she was collecting Chinese snuffbottles, doing Ikebana flower arrangements, or coaching computer with her Seniornet buddies. We will cherish her memory forever. Funeral services will be held on Wednesday, March 22, 2000 at 10:00AM, Temple Emanuel-El, 147 Tenafly Rd., Englewood, NJ. Donations may be made in her memory to The Arnold P. Gold Foundation, 260 Lincoln St., Englewood, NJ 07631; Gilda's Club, 575 Main St., Hackensack, NJ 07601; or The Schonfeld Cultural Endowment Foundation, JCC on the Palisades, 411 East Clinton Ave., Tenafly, NJ 07670. For directions or questions, please call Gutterman-Musicant Funeral Home at 1-800-378-1892

title: A Weather Change Worth Celebrating
description: It looked like a squat drum, weighed 270 pounds and contained little more than a simple television camera. But the world's first weather satellite, which was launched into orbit four decades ago on April 1, 1960, let meteorologists track wide cloud movements for the first time. The satellite, known as Tiros, revealed unexpected bands, swirls and clusters that quickly gave a new dimension to the word forecast.

title: VITAL SIGNS: TREATMENT; After an Accident, a Lost Opportunity

title: Acidic Breath of Asthmatics Hints at Better Treatments
description: In a startling discovery that could radically alter the way asthma patients are monitored and treated, doctors at the University of Virginia have found that the breath of asthmatics who are having an attack is a thousand times as acidic as normal.

title: 'The Implication Was Obvious'

title: 60's Rights Leader Is Arrested in Death Of Sheriff's Deputy

title: EASTMAN CHEMICAL EXPECTS EARNINGS TO CLIMB
description: The Eastman Chemical Company said yesterday that it expected its first-quarter earnings to beat analyst estimates, helped by cost reductions and price increases on many products. The company, based in Kingsport, Tenn., said earnings for the period, to be reported on April 28, would exceed the 56 cents a share forecast by analysts polled by First Call/Thomson. Eastman is one of the largest producers of polyethylene terephthalate, which is used in plastic packaging. In October, it announced $200 million in cost cuts, including about 1,200 layoffs. Eastman shares rose 9 percent yesterday, gaining $3.75, to $43.5625, on the New York Stock Exchange.

title: Adolf K. Placzek, 87, Is Dead; Architecture Library Director

title: Masks Can't Hide Quirky Goings-On
description: The opening number of ''Carnival Knowledge,'' a revuelike show with sketches made out of masks, dance, slapstick and utter show-biz earnestness, is a lovely and unpretentious thing. In it the show's two creators and performers, Rob Faust and Paola Styron, hunched over in half-simian pose, dressed in black with turtlenecks stretched over their heads and wearing tiny masks suggestive of prehuman beings, do a vaudevillian duet with white canes, kind of a Neanderthal soft shoe.

title: A Suffragist In Her Den, Bracing for The Circus

title: An Excitable Werewolf, Still Howling
description: During his solo show at the Bowery Ballroom on Thursday night, Warren Zevon joked that he hadn't ''grown or evolved, musically or morally'' since he wrote ''Poor Poor Pitiful Me'' in the early 1970's. But back then, he had it easy. All it took to establish him as the wild man of Los Angeles songwriting were terse hints of gallows-humored mayhem: bulletins about a werewolf in London, glimmers of international intrigue in ''Lawyers, Guns and Money,'' matter-of-fact harm reports in ''Excitable Boy.''

title: NATIONAL COMMERCE TO BUY CCB FINANCIAL
description: The National Commerce Bancorporation, the parent of the Memphis-based National Bank of Commerce, agreed yesterday to buy the CCB Financial Corporation of Durham, N.C., for $1.95 billion. National Commerce will pay 2.45 shares for each share of CCB Financial, valuing the company at $48.23 a share. On the New York Stock Exchange, shares of CCB rose 62.5 cents, to $39.1875, while National Commerce's shares tumbled $3.1875, to $16.50. The combined banking company will have total assets of $15 billion, a market capitalization of $4.2 billion and 370 branches in the southeastern United States.

title: Raines Unlikely To Be a Yankee
description: Seeking some insight into his chances of making the Yankees this year, the veteran Tim Raines met with Manager Joe Torre before tonight's exhibition game. Raines, 40, is coming back from lupus, and it appears unlikely that he will make the opening-day roster. The Yankees have two designated-hitter candidates in Shane Spencer and Jim Leyritz, and their primary motivation for bringing Raines to camp, on a minor league contract, was to allow him to play in front of scouts of other teams.

title: Council Votes To Strengthen And Extend The Rent Law
description: The City Council voted yesterday for a three-year extension of the rent control and rent stabilization protections that cover 1.1 million apartments in New York City. Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani is expected to sign the measure into law next week.

title: Giddy Seton Hall Waits on Holloway
description: Seton Hall point guard Shaheen Holloway, who sustained a high ankle sprain eight minutes into the Pirates' upset of Temple in the second round of the National Collegiate Athletic Association tournament Sunday, was listed as day to day yesterday. The chance that Holloway, the senior leader of this surging team, might somehow be available when the Pirates face Oklahoma State Friday night in the Round of 16 was just the start of the good news from the giddy team that had given the tournament two of its most breathtaking moments.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  KOWAL, JOHN
description: KOWAL-John. Manhattan Community Board Seven mourns the passing of our friend and leader, who was a member of the Board for over 20 years, serving as Chairperson, Vice Chairperson and Chair of many committees. John loved the Upper West Side, fought passionately for a democratic and equitable community process, and worked tirelessly for decent, affordable housing for the homeless and for low-income residents. He was one of the major community architects of the West Side Urban Renewal Area Plan, a builder and advocate for SRO housing, and the conscience of the Community Board to work for all our neighbors who need a helping hand. Always courteous and charming, reasonable and practical, he never lost his indignation at injustice and always kept up the good fight to make the world a better place.

title: LOSS AT COREL
description: A larger-than-expected quarterly loss of $12.4 million was reported by the Corel Corporation, the Canadian maker of WordPerfect software. Although the loss was narrower than the $14.6 million loss a year earlier, it would have been wider without the partial sale of Corel's stake in GraphOn Inc., which resulted in a $8.94 million pretax gain. Quarterly sales gained marginally to $44.1 million vs. $40.3 million. Corel, based in Ottawa, is a leader in creating applications software for the Linux operating system, a rival to Microsoft's Windows. Timothy Pritchard

title: Corrections

title: Daumier's Domain
description: Behind Honore Daumier lies 19th-century Paris -- a city of bourgeois assurance and political uncertainty, stolid and histrionic. Like every great city, it breathed self-awareness. No one contributed more in midcentury to that collective Parisian sense of self than Daumier, who died at age 70 in 1879. The exhibition of his work at the Phillips Collection in Washington, on view until May 14, suggests the range of his artistic expression, if not its utter immensity. Daumier worked in unfired clay and oil paints, in bronze, plaster and watercolor. But his innumerable impressions of Paris are literally that -- drawings made directly on lithographic stone and printed for immediate use in one newspaper or another.

Berg was to take out a pistol he was carrying and shoot Heisenberg dead if he gave any hint that he was building a bomb.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  PLACZEK, ADOLF K.
description: PLACZEK-Adolf K. Dolf died peacefully at his home on March 20th, having recently celebrated his 87th birthday. Born in Vienna, he came to the United States in 1940. After serving three years in the U.S. Army, he returned to his position at the Avery Architectural Library of Columbia University. In 1960 he became Avery Librarian and Professor of Architecture. Upon his retirment in 1980, he continued, with unfailing grace and erudition, to devote himself to the preservation of the architectural heritage of his adopted country. He is survived by his wife, Beverley, by a large and extended family, by those beloved people chosen as family, and by his sister and brother-in-law, Susan and Paul Stern, their children and grandchildren. In memory of Dolf and in lieu of flowers, donations may be made to Buildings of the United States or to Doctors Without Borders. A memorial service will be held at Calvary Church, Park Avenue and 21st Street. The date and time will be announced later.

title: A Comeback for a Man of Freedom; Nostalgic Epic by Andrzej Wajda Strikes a Chord in Poland

Yet when freedom finally came to Poland a decade ago, the audience for his movies evaporated. He remained a cultural icon, a powerful witness to Communist oppression, but many Poles were now more worried about the future than the past. And, if anything, they preferred to be distracted by American films.

The alliance will allow customers to receive orders within an hour, with Kozmo being an option for some book, music and toy orders. Amazon.com agreed to a three-year alliance in exchange for warrants to buy more shares of Kozmo, which is closely held. Kozmo delivers videos, snacks and other items bought online in New York, Washington, San Francisco, Seattle, Boston and Los Angeles. The deal values Ocular Sciences at $18.03 a share. The stock was down 56.25 cents yesterday, to $16.375, in Nasdaq trading, while Wesley Jessen's stock fell $2.0625, to $22.9375. Wesley Jessen said the companies specialized in different segments of the market, so their businesses would complement each other. Wesley Jessen, based in Des Plaines, Ill., is best known for cosmetic lenses that change or enhance the color of the wearer's eye. It had $311.7 million in sales last year. Ocular Sciences, based in San Francisco, specializes in disposable lenses. It had $176 million in sales last year.

Bingham Financial, based in Birmingham, Mich., has been growing through acquisitions. The company, which completed its initial public offering in 1997, has $132 million in assets. Franklin Bank, based in Southfield, Mich., has four branches in the Detroit area and $500 million in assets. The price consists of $87.1 million in stock and $9.9 million in cash. ImageX and Creativepro make Web-based graphic software used by companies to design marketing material. ImageX, based in Bellevue, Wash., said it would hire Creativepro's 120 employees and keep its Portland, Ore., headquarters. Creativepro had about $21 million in revenue last year. ImageX had $11.5 million in revenue last year. Its stock fell $2.3125, to $17.9375, in Nasdaq trading.

title: KOREA EASES BANKING RULES
description: The South Korean government plans to cut the minimum capital requirement of financial institutions from one half to a third of current levels, in a bid to promote the establishment of new banks, the Ministry of Finance and Economy said. Currently, commercial banks are required to hold a minimum of 100 billion won ($89.5 million) in capital; securities firms, 50 billion won; and insurers and merchant banks, 30 billion won. Samuel Len

title: VITAL SIGNS: PATTERNS; Tracking a Brain Gain in London Cabbies
description: London taxi drivers are required to develop a tremendously detailed mental map of their complicated city -- so much navigational knowledge, in fact, that it may change the structure of their brains.

title: Robert E. Hillard, 82, Public Relations Executive
description: Robert E. Hillard, a durable public relations man who co-founded the St. Louis-based public relations firm Fleishman-Hillard and helped lay the base for an almost eightyfold growth in its annual billings in two later decades, died on Wednesday at his home near Caledonia, Mo. He was 82.

title: VITAL SIGNS: DEMOGRAPHICS; Experts Discover Where the Boys Are
description: The ratio of newborn boys to newborn girls is higher in southern Europe than northern Europe, an analysis of population data has found.

title: Warring Conclusions on Waco Simulation
description: The two sides in the Branch Davidian wrongful-death civil lawsuit offered starkly different conclusions today after hurriedly reviewing infrared videos taken of a unique court-ordered simulation conducted this weekend at Fort Hood in Central Texas.

title: Finding Hope Amid Despair in Treating Compulsive Disorders
description: In hindsight, Debbie McDowell now realizes that the quirks and idiosyncrasies her son Jake displayed when he was very young were the first warnings of an illness that would eventually debilitate her child and test her own mettle as a parent.

title: Accounts
description: Pharmaton Natural Health, Ridgefield, Conn., a division of Boehringer Ingelheim, to DDB New York, part of the DDB Worldwide Communications Group unit of the Omnicom Group, as agency of record. The account, with estimated billings of $15 million to $20 million, had been handled by the Sawtooth Group, Woodbridge, N.J.

title: Another Killing, More Questions
description: To the Editor:

title: Paid Notice: Memorials  BECKER, MURRY
description: BECKER-Murry. We miss you more each year and cherish the memories of the time we had together. Your children, grandchildren and great-grandchildren

title: Russia's Politicians Trying to Jump on Putin's Bandwagon
description: As Russia's election campaign moved into the home stretch, Acting President Vladimir V. Putin recently hopped a commuter train out of Moscow to meet with factory workers on the city's outskirts.

title: AOL in E-Commerce Deal
description: America Online and PurchasePro.com announced a three-year alliance today to build an e-commerce marketplace. PurchasePro will power the interactive marketplace, which will allow AOL business users to buy and sell their products and services. The two companies will share advertising and transaction revenue from the service, expected by the end of the second quarter. America Online shares rose $2.50 today, to $66.875, but PurchasePro.com fell $22.50, to $129.25.

title: THE MARKETS: Market Place; A Hard Fall As a Highflier Revises Figures
description: Until yesterday, MicroStrategy Inc., a software company that aggressively promoted itself and became a Wall Street darling, easily shrugged off criticism that its accounting was too liberal, enabling it to recognize revenue months if not years before it should have been reported.

title: TRANSACTIONS
description: BASEBALL

title: Camby Isn't Quite Up To Speed For Knicks
description: The Los Angeles Lakers had mindlessly drifted outside the paint, vacating a lane that left the Knicks' Marcus Camby flinging open his eyes like shutters. Usually, Camby would have sprung off his right leg at the sight of such a tantalizing path, drifted through the air and added to his career stash of dunks.

title: The Patrick Dorismond Case
description: Mayor Rudolph Giuliani took the right tack initially last week when he urged New Yorkers to reserve judgment until all the facts were in concerning the death of Patrick Dorismond, the third unarmed black man to be shot to death by New York City police officers in little more than a year. But the mayor soon made matters worse by denigrating the dead man as a violent person who was less than ''an altar boy'' and whose behavior pattern may have contributed to his death. The mayor also authorized his police commissioner, Howard Safir, to release Mr. Dorismond's arrest record in what looks like an attempt to justify the shooting based on past events that led only to disorderly conduct pleas.

title: A Lifting Regimen for a Healthier Heart
description: Lifting weights just two or three times a week can reduce blood pressure, body fat levels and improve glucose metabolism, according to an American Heart Association survey.

title: Corrections
description: An article on Thursday about an intramural battle at the Sierra Club over the ouster of leaders of the New York City chapter misstated the position held by Robert F. Kennedy Jr. at Riverkeeper, another environmental group. He is its lawyer, not its founder and director.

title: Kohl's Wounded Party Turns To a Leader From the East
description: Opting for drastic change, the Christian Democratic Union today nominated Angela Merkel, a physicist raised in the former Communist state of East Germany, to become its new leader.

title: Survival of the Farthest
description: Fruit never falls far from the tree, or so the old saying goes. But just as in a dysfunctional family things might be better if it did, so too in botany.

title: Supreme Court Roundup; Justices Decline Case on Race and School
description: The Supreme Court today passed up its latest opportunity to clarify the law on the use of race as a factor in assigning or admitting students to public schools.

title: Of Physics, Friendship and the Atomic Bomb
description: Historians and scientists are still arguing over whether Werner Heisenberg, the Nobel Prize winner who was Germany's leading scientist during World War II, told the truth about his role in the failed attempt to build an atomic bomb for Hitler.

title: PUBLIC LIVES
description: Some Hard Words About Soft Money

title: 3Com Plans to Sell or Shut Weaker Units
description: The 3Com Corporation plans to sell or close several slower-growing units, including its modem business and high-end networking products. The move will reduce its work force by about 2,500 to 3,000 people, but two-thirds are expected to join the acquiring companies.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  ABRAM, MORRIS B.
description: ABRAM-Morris B. The Trustees and staff of the Lower East Side Tenement Museum extend their deepest sympathies to the family and friends of Morris B. Abram. Father to the Museum's President, Ruth J. Abram, Morris Abram was a great friend to and supporter of the Museum since its inception. A champion of civil and human rights, Mr. Abram served as a role model to many, and he will be long in our memory.

title: Agreement on Internet Taxes Eludes Deeply Divided Commission
description: A commission advising Congress on whether and how Internet commerce should be taxed fell into disarray today, with members trading heated accusations and appearing increasingly likely to go back to Congress with no recommendation at all.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  CHARNEY, ROCHELLE
description: CHARNEY-Rochelle (Shelly) on March 19, 2000, a lifelong resident of New York City and employed by the Howard Sloan Koller Group. Daughter of the late Ann and George Charney, survived by her loving sister Stephanie (Marvin) Anzel and nephews Scott and Joshua Anzel. Services Tuesday 1PM at Montefiore Cemetery, Springfield Blvd, St. Albans, New York. Shiva observed after 7PM Tuesday, Wednesday & Thursday at the Anzel residence, Newtown, PA. For information: Orland's Ewing Memorial Chapel, 609-883-1400.

title: Bodies Rigid, as the Feet Put On a Show
description: The Trinity Irish Dance Company, the Chicago-based troupe specializing in new and old forms of Irish step dancing, has returned in an unusually festive fashion for a run through Sunday at the New Victory Theater.

title: Unions Predict Gain From Boeing Strike
description: As the Boeing Company's white-collar workers returned to work after a 40-day strike, union leaders there declared victory yesterday and national union officials said they hoped to capitalize on it.

title: Knowing What Designers Want Before They Want It
description: In the fall of 1998, truly a millennium ago in fashion chronology, women were besieged with gray. Stores were filled with gray knife-pleated wool skirts, flannel trousers, charcoal-colored cashmere sweaters. The trend was so pervasive, in fact, that it was possible to overhear grown-up men, the sort who move money around rather than garment racks, knowingly declare that ''gray has become the new black.''

title: Unresolved in Kosovo, a Year Later
description: To the Editor:

title: New Ripples in the Tide Against Job Discrimination
description: Been arrested or convicted of a crime? In seven states, that information is barred from employment decisions. Gay? In 11 states and the District of Columbia, sexual orientation is protected by fair-employment-practice laws. Have strong political opinions or been a whistle blower? Five states and the District of Columbia forbid employers to use job candidates' words against them.

title: Test Fever: What Happened to Reading?
description: To the Editor:

title: The Worldly Pleasures of Nursery Puddings; In England, there will always be whim wham and apple dappy.
description: FOR American kids, pudding means the gloppy, yummy stuff, usually chocolate or butterscotch, that comes out of a cardboard box.

title: Corrections
description: A brief report yesterday about the appointment of Kurt Masur as music director of the Orchestre National de France referred incorrectly to his future with the London Philharmonic Orchestra. Mr. Masur, who is also music director of the New York Philharmonic, will be the principal conductor of the London orchestra from September through the 2004-05 season; he does not plan to step down next year.

title: Sale of 2 A-Plants Is Shrouded in Uncertainty
description: The New York Power Authority's attempt to sell its two nuclear plants remained mired in uncertainty and speculation yesterday after the agency decided late Monday to postpone choosing a buyer because of an assortment of tax, legal and financial issues.

title: Despite High Court Victory, Tobacco Industry Is Still Waiting to Exhale
description: The United States Supreme Court decided yesterday to keep the tobacco industry alive. But its condition remains critical, and the court's decision sets the stage for another Congressional showdown on cigarettes.

title: No Cooling-Off Period
description: Q: Can you settle a disagreement? When we have leftovers, my wife insists on putting them in the refrigerator immediately after dinner, while the food is still quite warm. I say we should let the food cool down closer to room temperature before refrigerating it. Which is the better practice?

title: Giuliani Offers a Merit Plan For Summer School Bonuses
description: Seeking to trump a plan by the interim schools chancellor and the teachers union to give every summer school teacher a cash bonus, Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani yesterday proposed an alternative that would give the most effective teachers a hefty reward, enough to almost double their summer salaries, but give others no bonus at all.

title: Pentagon Delays Test Of Defense Using Missiles
description: The Pentagon announced today that it would delay by two months the next, decisive test of national missile defense technology, most likely pushing back to October President Clinton's decision on whether to deploy the system.

title: 'Titus,' Emperor Of Mondays
description: It has been a much better year to start up a dot-com than a sitcom -- unless you're the Fox network.

title: Term Limits Turn Old Allies Into Opponents; Protege Against Mentor, Backer Against Incumbent
description: Assemblyman Darryl C. Towns has only to turn to photo albums from a few years ago to see how his deep kinship with a fellow politician has been fractured by the most consequential revolution in city politics in decades: term limits.

title: Devils Lose Niedermayer to Suspension and Fall to Hurricanes
description: Devils defenseman Scott Niedermayer was suspended for 10 games today for hitting Florida's Peter Worrell on the helmet with his stick last Sunday night, and his absence will have a significant impact on the team.

title: F.D.A. Withdraws Drug for Diabetics, Citing Health Risks
description: The Food and Drug Administration announced yesterday evening that Rezulin, a diabetes drug linked to liver failure, would be removed from the market immediately.

title: Mystery Deepens in the Vandalism of Religious Statues in Brooklyn
description: The vandalism appeared to be another in a disturbing pattern of desecrations of Roman Catholic icons. And once more it was in Brooklyn.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  STAHL, GILBERT
description: STAHL-Gilbert, 71, on March 18. High-ranking Mason, sports enthusiast, pursuer of knowledge. Beloved husband to Phyllis, father of Jonathan, Andrew and Robert, loving grandfather and brother. Interment in Fort Meyers, FL.

title: In the Drama of Democracy, Taiwan's Star Turn
description: To the Editor:

title: Road-Court Disadvantage Dooms Knicks
description: Allan Houston dribbled to his comfort zone near the baseline and rose off the floor with the silent grace of a smoke plume. But as he lifted to shoot, he felt a sliver graze his skin. It was the human paper cut, Reggie Miller.

title: Commercial Real Estate; Faded Factory in Queens To Be High-Tech Center
description: If they noticed it at all, most people passing the faded six-story brick building at 27-01 Bridge Plaza North in Long Island City, Queens, would probably be surprised to learn that in earlier times it turned out horse-drawn carriages, Rolls-Royce autos and World War II fighter planes. Now, after years of decrepitude and declining occupancy, it is undergoing a multimillion-dollar refurbishment with the aim of transforming it into a high-tech center.

title: TODAY'S SCHEDULES
description: GEORGE W. BUSH: Orlando and West Palm Beach, Fla.

title: Citigroup Fills 2 Leading Executive Posts
description: Moving to fill two high-profile positions that were recently vacated, Citigroup, the nation's largest financial services concern, appointed a new chief financial officer and a new chairman of its consumer and commercial banking unit yesterday.

title: QUOTATION OF THE DAY
description: ''It is time for this little boy to move on with life at his father's side.''

title: Hunters' Spokesman?
description: To the Editor:

title: You Can't Judge a Leader By His Scores in the SAT's
description: WHEN he was applying to college, Bill Bradley scored 485 out of a possible 800 on the verbal portion of his SAT's, the intellectual equivalent of a night of air balls on the basketball court. George W. Bush, often portrayed as a cerebral lightweight, registered a gentleman's 566 -- hardly enough to predict that he would one day be the Republican nominee for leader of the free world.

title: Rush's Pass-Dunk Play Keeps U.C.L.A. Soaring
description: JaRon Rush is such a special player to watch because there is always the chance he will do something dynamic when U.C.L.A. has the ball. All he has to do is make eye contact with point guard Earl Watson, begin his ascent to the basket and then soar above the rim to accept another lob pass and finish the play with a spectacular dunk.

title: INTEL TO ACQUIRE BASIS COMMUNICATIONS FOR $450 MILLION
description: The Intel Corporation agreed yesterday to acquire the Basis Communications Corporation, a privately held semiconductor designer, in a transaction valued at $450 million in cash and assumed options. Basis Communications, which is based in Fremont, Calif., markets advanced semiconductors and products used in equipment that directs traffic across the Internet and corporate networks. Basis Communications would become a wholly owned subsidiary of Intel and operate within Intel's Network Communications Group. Intel said the acquisition would expand its line of communications products and the company's network processor line. Shares of Intel, based in Santa Clara, Calif., rose $3.4375 each, at $138.4375, in Nasdaq trading.

title: Marketers Try Infecting the Internet
description: March 22, 2000

title: He's a Singing Star, but Not in Quite the Way He Planned
description: Since his childhood in Syosset on Long Island, all Adam Pascal ever wanted to be was a rock singer. He dreamed of fronting his own band and writing his own music. Though Billy Joel was his idol as a singer, hard rock became his passion.

title: Gore Gathers Endorsements In Bradley's Old Territory
description: Vice President Al Gore swept into Bill Bradley's home state today and received the endorsements of top allies of his vanquished foe, welcoming them into his continuing march toward unifying the Democratic Party for the general election.

title: British Boom Lets Tax Cuts Be the Topic Of Contention
description: LONDON  The history of Labour governments in Britain has largely been one of economic crises: budget and balance of payments deficits, devaluations, even a bailout by the International Monetary Fund.

title: Judging by the Record
description: The dueling reactions to the shooting of Patrick Dorismond, an unarmed black man, by a New York City police officer seemed quickly to become a contest of records -- who could dig up the most about whom. It is a battle with uneven racial odds.

title: NATO Secretary General's Report Claims Successes in Kosovo
description: One year after NATO began its 78-day bombardment of Kosovo, the alliance's secretary general issued a report today highlighting what he said were the unsung accomplishments of the campaign.

title: Our Towns; Making Guns As Unusual As Open Land
description: THERE was no shooting at the local high school, no child killed while playing with his father's gun, no armed madman at a fast-food joint. There was just Michael O'Neill, a cook turned school tutor in East Hampton, who heard about the shooting in a day camp three thousand miles away in Granada Hills, Calif., last August and decided to do something about it.

title: Bush and Gore See Ruling As Prod for New Controls
description: Vice President Al Gore and Gov. George W. Bush, who both employ senior advisers with close ties to the tobacco industry, said today that the Supreme Court ruling on cigarette regulation should spur Congress to enact stricter controls on tobacco products.

title: Ramon Mitra, 72, Foe of Marcos Regime During Martial Law
description: Ramon Mitra, who rose from rural poverty to become a leading politician and democratic foe of the Marcos dictatorship in the Philippines, died on Monday in Manila. He was 72.

title: 'Realm' Reincarnated
description: Five months after it was canceled by Fox, Chris Carter's ''Harsh Realm'' will return to television on Friday night on the FX cable network. That must represent sweet vindication for Mr. Carter, creator of Fox's very successful ''X-Files,'' now in its season. Though the ''Harsh Realm'' debut on Oct. 8 was watched by 7.5 million viewers, only 3.7 million tuned in to watch its third episode.

title: Trying a Stern Hand on a Mediocre School District
description: When Michael A. Johnson first visited Intermediate School 192 in southeastern Queens last month, he found students capering down hallways and shouting out of windows during class.

title: Metro Business; Con Ed to Buy Plant Stake
description: Consolidated Edison Inc., the owner of New York City's electric utility, agreed yesterday to buy CMS Energy Corporation's 80 percent stake in a power plant in Lakewood, N.J., for $94 million.

title: Sawtooth Spins Off Branding Unit
description: The Sawtooth Group in Woodbridge, N.J., is spinning off its branding unit as an independent brand development agency. The new agency, to be called Trajectory L.L.C. and will be based in Morristown, N.J., will retain links to Sawtooth and will have six employees working on some Sawtooth clients as well as new clients. It will be led by Eric Brody, 42, the unit's leader since 1997.

title: Forced Offline, Library Users Look on Shelf
description: The computerized catalog system at the New York Public Library has been down since Monday, forcing users in all 85 branches to search the stacks visually and librarians to check out books by hand.

title: UBS SPLITTING STOCK
description: In preparation for its listing on the New York Stock Exchange, the Swiss banking giant UBS A.G., the world's largest assets manager, has announced plans for a two-for-one stock split. The move, which the bank will ask shareholders to approve at a meeting on April 18, will make the shares more affordable and comparable to those of rival investment banks in Europe and the United States. The shares closed at 413 Swiss francs, or about $248, on the Zurich exchange, after the stock-split announcement. Elizabeth Olson (NYT)

title: Paid Notice: Memorials  KLIGERMAN, ALAN
description: KLIGERMAN-Alan. 3 years. You live forever in our hearts. We miss you dearly. Miralyn, Cheryl, Andy, June

title: THE CHEF
description: THE combination of foie gras and apples has always had a powerful appeal to me. I even used to serve a foie gras ''burger'' in which the fruit acted as the bun for the meat. It was more than a culinary conceit: the sweet and tangy apple set off the rich and fatty duck liver to perfection.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  TURLEY, JAMES A.
description: TURLEY-James A., Jr. of Katonah, NY. Husband of Georgette. Father of Elizabeth Brydon, Susan Bedford, Mary McDevitt, James A. Turley III, and Sean Turley. Brother of Thomas Turley. Also survived by five grandchildren. Reposing at Clark Associates Funeral Home, Katonah NY, Wednesday, 2-4 and 7-9PM. Mass of Christian Burial at St. Mary's R.C. Church, Katonah, Thursday, 11:30 AM. Interment Holy Sepulchre Cemetery, New Rochelle NY. In lieu of flowers, contributions may be made to Mepkin Abbey H.C.69, Box 800, Moncks Corner, SC 29461.

title: A Victim's Sang-Froid in Very Coldblooded Times
description: I WILL BEAR WITNESS

title: In Oregon, Pinot Gris Takes On a New Identity
description: HERE is a grape with an identity crisis: In France it is known as pinot gris, except in Alsace, the French region where the grape reaches its zenith and is called tokay. In Italy, it is pinot grigio, a straight enough translation, but in Valais, a Swiss wine-growing region between France and Italy, it is known as malvoisie. Other aliases are auxerrois gris, rulander and szurkebarat.

title: Senate Fight Snags Aid Bill For Kosovo And Colombia
description: A $9 billion spending bill to help Colombia combat drug traffickers and to pay for American military operations in Kosovo is imperiled because of stiff opposition from Senator Trent Lott, Republican of Mississippi, the majority leader, and fiscal conservatives in the House and Senate.

title: Some Answers to Pesticide Questions
description: READERS often send me questions that are of interest to more than an audience of one, and lately they have almost all involved fruits and vegetables.

title: COMPANY BRIEFS
description: DIME BANCORP, Uniondale, N.Y., the largest savings and loan in New York, postponed for a second time a shareholder vote on its planned merger with the Hudson United Bancorp for $1.3 billion. The vote, which had been scheduled for Friday, was put off until May 17.

title: Taiwan Market Shakes Off Vote Results
description: Defying analysts who predicted that the victory of the opposition leader in Taiwan's presidential election would scare off investors, the stock market here roared back today. Taipei's exchange jumped 5.5 percent, more than making up for its 2.6 percent loss on Monday.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  BELL, WILMOT KENNEDY
description: BELL-Wilmot Kennedy, died on Wednesday, February 9, 2000, at Somers Manor, Somers, NY. The Pleasantville native was 97. Long active in village activities, he was a Captain of the Volunteer Fire Department Patrol Company, President of the University Club, a vestry man at St. John's Episcopal Church, and a tireless fund raiser for the Boy Scouts and Girl Scouts. A graduate of The Salisbury School (1921) and Williams College (1925), he retired from Metropolitan Life Insurance Company in 1967. His wife, Mildred Kelly Bell predeceased him in death in 1976. He is survived by his daughter Nina Bell Allen of Tucson, AZ, a retired assistant managing editor of Readers Digest. Funeral service will be held on Saturday, March 25, 2000, at 10:00 A.M. at St. John's Episcopal Church, Pleasantville, NY. Burial will follow at Kensico Cemetery, Valhalla, New York. In lieu of flowers donations to the Nantucket Conservation Foundation, Box 13, Nantucket, MA. 02554 will be appreciated. For Information: Beecher Funeral Home, Pleasantville, New York.

title: Who's Got The Sound? Baby Moguls And Techies
description: ''It's chaos out there right now,'' said Tim Quirk on Saturday afternoon, briefly retreating from the barbecue-munching crowd at Fat Tuesday's, one of many patio-style beer joints here. Mr. Quirk wasn't just making the usual observation about South by Southwest, the music, film and multimedia conference that concluded today. He was addressing a particular kind of chaos: the free-for-all over music on the Internet that enthralled this year's convention-goers as intensely as it has the industry in general.

title: On This Side Of the Pond
description: NEW YORKERS looking for the full-out experience of an English pudding have their work cut out for them. The city has no shortage of Anglophiles, but it does have a shortage of British chefs and, as a result, of British desserts. The French press recently had a field day when a Scottish chef treated Paris to one of Glasgow's finest inventions, a breaded, deep-fried Mars bar. Will New York ever get to try one?

title: Business Travel; Airlines are proving slow in responding to the increasing demand for high-protein food.
description: NOBODY in his right mind is actually enthusiastic when that service cart starts inching down the aisle with the flight attendants passing out the meals with their frightening soup-kitchen cheeriness. But it was 8:30 a.m., and back in the last row of steerage I was getting hungry in that first hour of the haul from New York to Dallas. Not hungry enough for Special K, though.

title: Still Profiting From Trading, Goldman Exceeds Forecasts
description: A heavy emphasis on trading has not turned out to be such a bad thing for the Goldman Sachs Group. The big investment banking firm reported yesterday that a surge in revenue from trading stocks, bonds, oil and other commodities pushed its fiscal first-quarter net income to $887 million, or $1.76 a diluted share, easily surpassing analysts' expectations.

title: Hold Resume Truths to Be Self-Evident? No Way
description: Companies that dawdle in hiring promising candidates may lose them to the competition, but Margie Mosher does not care. She has learned her lesson, and nobody gets a job at Allied Domecq Quick Service Restaurants until a thorough background check is completed.

title: American Home Is Selling Agricultural Chemical Unit
description: The American Home Products Corporation said yesterday that it had agreed to sell its struggling agricultural business to BASF, the German chemicals giant, for $3.8 billion in cash -- a move that added to Wall Street speculation that the drug company would try again to find a corporate mate.

title: Pope Visits Site Claimed for Baptism of Jesus
description: Pope John Paul II today visited a desolate wind-swept plain here near the Jordan River, on the bank of a tributary where Jordan says Jesus was baptized.

title: Pilgrims Progress
description: Note: This lesson was originally published on an older version of The Learning Network; the link to the related Times article will take you to a page on the old site.

title: Burn the Rug? No! Burn the Floor! It's Dance Fever
description: The idea was born at Elton John's 50th birthday party three years ago at Hammersmith Ballroom in London and grew into something that, well, let's put it this way: Nobody's grandparents danced quite this way on their wedding night.

title: Corrections
description: An article on March 3 about the indictments of two Canadian businessmen charged with defrauding the New York chapter, now closed, of the British bank Coutts & Company referred incorrectly to charges brought in a separate case against an Israeli businessman, Rachamin Anatian. He was charged with having submitted false promissory notes in a bankruptcy proceeding, but not with having defrauded Coutts & Company out of $40 million. The article also misstated the month that the indictment against Mr. Anatian was handed down. It was January, not February.

title: Who Wants to Be . . .
description: To take full advantage of its association with the Oscar special Sunday night, ABC is adding a special edition of ''Who Wants to Be a Millionaire'' on Friday night at 8: a show devoted to questions about movies.

title: THE MARKETS: CURRENCIES
description: THE EURO DROPS. The dollar gained after the Federal Reserve raised its benchmark interest rate, bolstering the appeal of deposits in dollars. In New York, the euro settled at 96.41 cents, down from 97.34 cents on Monday.

title: Nets Beat the Raptors, Carter and the Hype
description: With 27.1 seconds left tonight, and the sellout crowd at the Air Canada Center hardly able to believe its eyes, Stephon Marbury walked toward the Nets bench hollering, ''We remember that whipping they gave us.''

title: Alternatives For Passengers
description: The possible shutdown of US Airways this Saturday leaves passengers with plenty of options to consider for their travel plans.

title: Sundays With Ravioli: Where Have They Gone?
description: IT may have been my first love -- before Clark Gable, before Bobby Sherman, even before Jonathan Mink in the second grade.

title: A Town Becomes Fully Palestinian, Quietly
description: In this quiet town near Hebron, a newspaper danced in the wind down the main street this morning, an elderly man in a red-checked kaffiyeh rode his donkey and a few teenagers whizzed along on bicycles. There was no air of expectation, no feeling that a long-awaited moment had arrived.

title: Agency Moves By 3 Advertisers
description: Three advertisers and their agencies are parting ways.

title: As Life Fatefully Unspools at a Yada-Yada Cocktail Party
description: ''The Moment When,'' a new play by James Lapine that opened at Playwrights Horizons yesterday after more than a month of gestating in previews, has a lot going for it. It has a serious, intelligent theme; set over the past 16 years, the play is about how personal ethics are passed along, one generation to the next, subtly but perceptibly changed like the code in a game of telephone.

title: INTERNATIONAL BUSINESS; Microsoft and Telmex Plan A Latin Region Web Portal
description: The richest man in the world, William H. Gates, joined forces today with the richest man in Latin America, Carlos Slim Helu, in a battle to dominate the Internet in the region by creating a portal site that combines the expertise of the Microsoft Corporation with the communications reach of Telefonos de Mexico.

title: Fading Rangers Come From Ahead Again in Loss
description: If games were 40 minutes long, the Rangers would not have to worry about missing the playoffs for the third consecutive year.

title: Barkley Has Chat But Reveals Very Little
description: The St. John's point guard Erick Barkley met with Mike Jarvis yesterday but did not tell his coach whether he had decided to leave school for the National Basketball Association draft. The two expect to talk again today.

title: Suspect's Death Ends Siege; Hostages Are Safe
description: Three hostages were rushed to freedom tonight in a Baltimore suburb as the police broke in on a fugitive murder suspect and shot him to death, ending a harrowing four-day siege that terrorized the Dundalk neighborhood.

title: Pall Cast by Sikhs' Slayings Settles Over Clinton Visit
description: The first day of President Clinton's visit to India today was haunted by an atrocity committed last night in Kashmir, the Himalayan territory that is at the nub of half a century of conflict between India and Pakistan -- and that the Americans fear could be a nuclear flashpoint.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  COYNE, MARSHALL B.
description: COYNE-Marshall B. Passed on Thursday, March 16, 2000. There will be a memorial service Friday, March 24, at 1:30PM at Washington Hebrew Congregation, 3935 Macomb Street, NW, Washington DC. In lieu of flowers, memorial contributions may be made to The Lombardi Cancer Center, Georgetown University, 37th and O Streets NW, Washington DC 20057

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SCHULTZ, EDWARD J.
description: SCHULTZ-Edward J. Passed on March 18th. Husband of Attracta. He practiced law in New York City for many years. Sadly missed by his loving wife, brothers-in-law, sisters-in-law, nieces and nephews.

title: Vermont's Path For Gay Couples
description: To the Editor:

description: THE REPUBLICANS
