description: A New York Olives

title: Role as D.H. For Yankees Suits Spencer
description: Shane Spencer is not qualified for the job of designated hitter, based on the credentials of most designated hitters. He is 28 years old and not in the twilight of his career, as is Edgar Martinez. Spencer is actually a solid defensive outfielder; some designated hitters, like Harold Baines, rarely even play catch.

title: Test Fever: What Happened to Reading?
description: To the Editor:

title: Corrections
description: The headline of a brief report in Business Day yesterday about the takeover battle to acquire Dime Bancorp misstated the effect of a proxy vote. According to a court filing by North Fork Bancorp, which is the hostile suitor, Dime shareholders have voted to defeat the pending friendly merger with Hudson United Bancorp. Dime is not seeking to reject Hudson; its board has voted in favor of a deal with Hudson.

title: INFINITY TO EXPAND EUROPEAN OPERATIONS WITH BUYOUT
description: The CBS Corporation's Infinity Broadcasting Corporation, the nation's largest outdoor advertising and radio company, acquired the Paris billboard owner Giraudy yesterday for about $425 million. Infinity, which is based in New York, purchased Giraudy from the Deutsche Bank unit, Morgan Grenfell Private Equity. Giraudy, one of France's largest outdoor-advertising companies, has annual sales of about $230 million. Infinity also has operations in Ireland, Holland and Britain.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  KARP, WILLIAM
description: KARP-William, 78. Beloved father of Kenneth, friend to all, who truly loved life. For information call Robert Schoem (201) 843-9090

title: Two Latin Cuisines Meet, and One Emerges the Winner
description: IT'S hard enough for a restaurant to master one cuisine, much less two, so when a menu offers food from more than one land, the trick is knowing which way to go. I know that at Chinese-Cuban places, the arroz con pollo will always be a better bet than the moo goo gai pan. I know to steer clear of sushi bars in Chinese restaurants. Those are easy calls, but the Colombian-Venezuelan menu at Pachas in Jackson Heights, Queens, presented problems.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  GINSBURG, BOBBIE HOPE
description: GINSBURG-Bobbie Hope, much loved by her family and friends for 90 years, passed away on Tuesday, March 7, 2000, after a courageous battle against cancer. She was predeceased by her loving husband, Herman; parents, Anna & Harry Shapiro; brother, Al Shapiro Sands, and sisters, Vera Freeman and Mary Mersel. Aunt Bobbie will be greatly missed by Constance Robinson, Joy Gonzales, Daniel Mersel & their families. Contributions in her memory may be made to the Visiting Nurse Service Hospice Program, 1250 Broadway, New York, NY 10011.

title: Excerpts From the Opinions on the Regulation of Tobacco by the F.D.A.
description: Following are excerpts from the Supreme Court's decision today holding that the Food and Drug Administration had never received authority from Congress to regulate tobacco products. The vote in the case, Food and Drug Administration v. Brown & Williamson Tobacco Corporation was 5 to 4. Justice Sandra Day O'Connor wrote the majority opinion, and Justice Stephen G. Breyer wrote the dissent.

title: Paid Notice: Memorials  GITTLEMAN, IRWIN
description: GITTLEMAN-Irwin. Three years and you're wit and wisdom lives forever in my heart. Kid sister Phyllis.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  HURLEY, JOHN W.
description: HURLEY-John W. Age 74. Died at his home March 20, 2000. Devoted husband of Joan. Dear father of Mary LaCorte, Elizabeth O'Neill, Kathleen Durante, John P., James R. and Joan Marie Kwalwasser. Loving brother of Kathleen O'Connor and grandfather of twenty. Reposing at the Flynn Memorial Home Inc., 1652 Central Park Avenue, Yonkers, NY (1 block north of Tuckahoe Road). Mass, Church of St. Anthony, Nepera Park, Yonkers on Friday 10 AM. Interment Holy Ghost Cemetery, Bethlehem, PA. Visiting Thursday 2-4 PM and 7-9 PM.

title: In a Crowded City, Statues Are Elbowed Out
description: Less than a decade after carting the four-story-high Golden Boy and its global pedestal from Manhattan to Basking Ridge, N.J., AT&T officials have acknowledged what might have seemed obvious to some: that Golden Boy is a born New Yorker.

title: McCall Challenges Governor Over Promotion of Lottery-Based Scholarships
description: State Comptroller H. Carl McCall today accused Gov. George E. Pataki and lottery officials of overstepping their authority by advertising and promoting a new college scholarship program that had not been approved by the Legislature.

title: Police Officer Dies In Apparent Suicide
description: A Manhattan police officer was found dead in his home yesterday, apparently from a self-inflicted gunshot wound, the police said.

title: Those Frequent Fliers
description: With Pope John Paul II in Israel, President Clinton in India and the Russian elections approaching, the network news anchors are building up their frequent-flier miles.

title: US Airways Vows to Shut Down if Attendants Disrupt Flights
description: The 10,000 unionized flight attendants at US Airways are threatening an unusual walkout this Saturday, saying they will disrupt flights on 49 of the airline's busiest routes.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  LEDER, EMANUEL
description: LEDER-Emanuel. On March 21, 2000. Beloved husband of the late Mollie. Loving father of Randy Myrna and Ralph Cohen, Phyllis and Alan Wolpert, Ronald and Emily Leder. Cherished grandfather of Hunter and Terry, Niles, Jonathan and Beth, Erika and Jason, Ivan and Amy, Dana, Adena and Jeff and Matthew. Great grandfather of Robert, Zachary, Brandon, Taylor, Alexander, Eryn and Isabel. Dear brother of Leon, Aaron, the late Oscar and the late Sylvia. Services today 2 PM, at ''Gutterman's'', 8000 Jericho Turnpike, Woodbury, L.I.

title: Lewis may Fight Grant
description: The World Boxing Association championship committee has given special permission to allow Lennox Lewis to defend his heavyweight title against Michael Grant on April 29. It was granted on the condition that the winner of the bout fight the W.B.A. No. 1 contender within 180 days. Right now, the W.B.A.'s No. 1 contender is John Ruiz.

title: WORLD BRIEFING
description: EUROPE

title: INVESTMENT GROUP SWEETENS ITS BID FOR CAMERON ASHLEY
description: Cameron Ashley Building Products Inc., a Dallas company that sells building and construction supplies, said yesterday that an investment group that includes members of Cameron's management increased its buyout offer to $348 million. The offer was raised to $18.25 a share from $15.10. The bid follows two separate offers received last month from two privately held companies. One was from Guardian Industries of Auburn Hills, Mich., for $17 a share. The other was from the Bradco Supply Corporation of Avenel, N.J., for 60 percent of Cameron at $16.25 a share. The stock rose $1.9375, to $17.3125, on the New York Stock Exchange.

title: Arbitrator Issues Ruling in Starks Case
description: John Starks will not get his wish to compete in the playoffs this season. But the monthlong legal fight by the former Knicks guard and the National Basketball Players Association has significantly altered how N.B.A. teams can do business with their players.

title: The Joffrey Takes Leaps in a Battle for Survival
description: Mankind battles Fate with a capital F in ''Les Presages,'' the epic ballet by Leonide Massine that the Joffrey Ballet of Chicago has just performed so magnificently as part of its season here.

title: Puppy Love, Hubby Love, Dogfights
description: One thing I love about my business is that it has brought me into the culture and society of dogs. It's a really neat society. Dogs are great; they are always straightforward and honest.

title: Former G.M. Executive Forms Web Site for Minority Suppliers
description: A former General Motors executive announced today that he had formed an Internet company that would aim to make it easier for the largest American companies to buy parts and supplies from minority-owned companies.

title: MORE INOCULATION AGAINST INFLATION
description: The Federal Reserve clamped down a bit more on the economy today, raising interest rates a quarter percentage point in an effort to prevent an outbreak of inflation.

title: Sports of The Times; The Great Visor Debate In Hockey
description: HOCKEY advertises itself as the world's fastest game, but the safety of its players has always come slowly, if not reluctantly.

title: The Questions Multiply For Seton Hall
description: Shaheen Holloway's sprained ankle was not the only serious health problem facing the Seton Hall Pirates today as they prepared to face Oklahoma State Friday night in the semifinals of the East Regional.

title: Margaret Rosezarian Harris, Musician and Educator, 56
description: Margaret Rosezarian Harris, a musician and educator who was the first black woman to conduct the symphony orchestras of Chicago, Detroit, Los Angeles, St. Louis, Minnesota and 11 other American cities, died on March 7 in New York City. She was 56 and lived in Elmsford, N.Y.

title: Palestinians And Israelis Resume Talks
description: With much of the Middle East focused on President Clinton's coming meeting in Geneva with President Hafez al-Assad of Syria, Israeli and Palestinian negotiators quietly began conferring here today on a separate but equally critical series of issues.

title: Reckonings; Natural Born Killers
description: Here's a quiz: Two sectors of the global food industry grew rapidly in the late 1990's. The products of one have been extensively tested, without any evidence of harm. Those of the other are known to pose big health risks -- but nobody knows how big, because lobbying by the industry has blocked effective regulation, testing and even reporting. One of these sectors faces passionate public opposition, which may soon drive it entirely out of business, while the other basks in a warm glow of public approval. (a) What sectors are we talking about? (b) Which sector is in trouble?

title: Setback on Smoking
description: Yesterday's Supreme Court ruling that the Food and Drug Administration has no authority to regulate tobacco will unquestionably stagger the administration's drive to halt the spread of nicotine addiction among young people. But it must not be allowed to end the nation's efforts to curb the leading cause of preventable death in the United States. Instead the court decision throws the burden back to Congress, where meaningful legislation to control tobacco use has been thwarted for years by the powerful tobacco lobby acting through legislators addicted to its campaign contributions.

title: Backers of Housing for Aged Lose in Pelham
description: Three Republicans who were critical of a planned housing project for the elderly tonight soundly defeated three Democratic incumbents on Pelham's board of trustees in local elections here.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  PLACZEK, ADOLF K.
description: PLACZEK-Adolf K. A memorial service for Dolf Placzek, who died on March 20, will be held at Calvary Church, Park Avenue at 21st Street, on April 9th at 5 P.M.

title: Wine Bars Grow Up, Posing A Question
description: TWO decades ago, New York had plenty of wine bars. Evolving out of the wine boom of the 70's, they were often equipped with complicated wine-storing machinery and took themselves quite seriously, with daunting lists, coat-and-tie stuffiness and an attitude toward food that was either dismissive or overly reverent.

title: Hip-Hop Joins Martial Arts but Lets Plot Muscle In
description: Who wants to be a millionaire? Almost every character in ''Romeo Must Die,'' the first English-language starring vehicle for the Hong Kong action star Jet Li. There's Isaak (Delroy Lindo), who is waging an intimidation campaign against waterfront business owners so he can buy up their properties, like that of Silk (DMX), whose club may end up as the last standing opposition to Isaak's ambition. Mac (Isaiah Washington), Isaak's bad-tempered right-hand man, pushes around the people clinging to their shops and businesses while dreaming of his own day in the sun.

title: Bodies in Pit Suggest Slayings at Uganda Fire
description: As the last bodies were dumped into mass graves today, forensic investigators at the site of the inferno here that burned more than 400 people to death discovered the bodies of several others who appeared to have been murdered and dumped into a latrine pit.

title: Panel on Taxing Internet Sales Ends Its Meetings in Disagreement
description: Amid bitter accusations that one company's desire for tax breaks for itself had blocked a consensus, the commission created to advise Congress on Internet sales taxes ended its last scheduled meeting today in failure.

title: The Long Wait Is Worth It for the Purple Eagles
description: NIAGARA

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  KING, RUSTY
description: KING-Rusty. For dear Rusty, whose friendship these last 28 years meant so much. You taught me about being a better person, a better friend, and a better doctor. My world will be a lesser place without you in it. The whole office sends deepest condolences to his Mom, Mary Ann, devoted sisters, Leslie and Kit, and his many dear friends, especially Anne. Howard Grossman

title: Rapist Caught After Release Spurs Dispute In New Jersey
description: Raymond Alves, a rapist whose bungled release from a New Jersey prison sparked a 12-day nationwide manhunt, was arrested last night after he got off a New Jersey Transit train at a small station in Hunterdon County and went to use a pay phone, the authorities said.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  RAMUS, MYRON
description: RAMUS-Myron, of Jamesburg, NJ, on March 20, 2000. Beloved husband of Ruth (nee Finley). Son of the late Hilda and Ira Ramus. Devoted brother-in-law of Irene Heldman and Marion and George Norton. Reposing Macken Mortuary, 52 Clinton Avenue, Rockville Centre, NY, Wednesday 2-4 and 79PM. Religious service Thursday, 10AM, at funeral home. Interment Westport, CT.

title: UPBEAT GERMAN FORECAST
description: German executives were more upbeat in February than they have been in five years, a survey found, suggesting a rebound in Europe's largest economy is likely to gather steam. An index of western German business confidence rose to 100.9, the highest since November 1994, from a revised 100.2 in January, the Ifo research institute reported. Germany's most closely watched survey of executives, based on some 6,000 responses, rose for a fifth month.

title: Licorice Taste, in a Pure Form
description: I WAS sitting alone eating at the bar at Gary Danko, a restaurant close to the North Beach section of San Francisco. Dinner's swell had already lifted and passed. Tired and unable to deal with a dessert that was taxing to eat, I ordered ice cream. Licorice ice cream. I was looking forward to something cool on my tongue, and didn't mind the idea of a boozy ice cream packed with some kind of licorice-flavored alcohol.

title: Paid Notice: Memorials  PILMAR, HOWARD
description: PILMAR-Howard. It is four years since you were so brutally taken from us. We miss you so much and pray that your murderers will soon be brought to justice. Love Dad, Carol and Heathe

title: Unresolved in Kosovo, a Year Later
description: To the Editor:

title: QSOUND LABS AGREES TO ACQUIRE INTERNET VIDEO COMPANY
description: QSound Labs Inc. of Canada agreed yesterday to acquire StreamMagic Inc., a privately held Internet video company based in Los Angeles, for $100 million in stock. Before the deal is completed, QSound plans to spin off its non-Internet audio and electronic-commerce businesses. The company would then consist of its online audio business and StreamMagic. The stock rose $1.21875, to $4.8125, in Nasdaq trading. QSound develops software that enhances audio quality.

title: National News Briefs; Coalition Seeks to Extend Gun Safety Measures
description: The cities of Boston, Bridgeport, Conn., Providence, R.I., and San Francisco and the State of Maryland are joining a growing coalition of local and state governments nationwide that intends to use its combined buying power to try to force gun manufacturers to follow the lead of Smith & Wesson and accept last week's pact requiring new handgun safety measures.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  KLEMPERER, PETER
description: KLEMPERER - Peter. Beloved husband of Judith. Father of Jerusha and Ethan, son of the late Helen and George Klemperer, brother of Fred Klemperer. Passed away on March 21, 2000. Born June 20, 1945, Peter was a graduate of the MIT Class of 1966. He devoted most of his professional life to managing health care for the underprivileged of New York, serving for many years as a Vice President of the New York Health and Hospitals Corporation. Peter was also a prominent antiquarian book dealer and collector, widely recognized as an authority on New York City history. His intellect, wit, and ethic of selfless commitment to his family, his community and his many colleagues and friends will be long remembered. Service Thursday, 10AM, at Central Synagogue, 123 East 55 Street.

title: A New Way to Open a Mussel
description: MANY years ago in Barcelona, I saw mussels and clams cooked ''a la plancha'' -- on a thick slab of hot metal much like the griddles used by short-order cooks. The technique involved tossing handfuls of the shellfish onto the hot grill, then scooping them off as soon as they had opened up.

title: Reuniting a Father and Son
description: In dismissing a lawsuit by relatives of Elian Gonzalez who sought political asylum for the 6-year-old Cuban boy, Federal District Judge K. Michael Moore has essentially upheld the decision of Attorney General Janet Reno and the Immigration and Naturalization Service that the boy should be repatriated to Cuba to rejoin his father. Judge Moore's ruling should be read as affirming I.N.S. Commissioner Doris Meissner's declaration in January that Elian is too young to make legal decisions for himself and that his father has the sole legal authority to speak for him in immigration matters.

title: US Airways Facing Threat of Disruption
description: In an unusual job action, the 10,000 unionized flight attendants at US Airways are threatening to disrupt flights on 49 of the airline's busiest routes on Saturday.

title: Ivan Hirst, British Officer Who Revived VW, Is Dead at 84
description: Maj. Ivan Hirst, the British Army officer responsible for getting the Volkswagen factory running again after World War II in what is now Wolfsburg, Germany, died March 10 at his home near Marsden, in Yorkshire, England. He was 84.

title: PROCTER & GAMBLE PLANS TO SELL ITS COOKING OIL BRANDS
description: The Procter & Gamble Company said yesterday that it planned to sell its Frymax, Whirl and Sterling brands of shortening and oil products. The Cincinnati-based consumer products giant said it was soliciting bids for its ''away from home'' shortening and oil brands but would retain the business if it did not receive an acceptable offer. Away-from-home products are sold to restaurants, cafeterias and other large customers. Procter & Gamble makes about 300 brands, including Crest toothpaste. Shares fell $1.3125, to $56.8125 each, on the New York Stock Exchange.

title: Hargrove Takes On Flighty Orioles
description: A five-time division-winning manager meets a two-time payroll loser. It is not exactly the irresistible force meeting the immovable object, but developments require watching.

title: RECORD PROFITS FOR MANUFACTURERS
description: South Korean manufacturers posted record profits last year, as interest payments decreased, demand rose and assets were sold off, the Korea Stock Exchange said. The profits of manufacturers listed on the exchange totaled 14.46 trillion won ($12.93 billion), a significant turnaround from net losses of 9.06 trillion won in 1998, according to statistics compiled by the exchange. Sales among domestic manufacturers rose 9.8 percent, to 415.8 trillion won. Samuel Len (NYT)

title: U.S. and India, Trying to Reconcile, Hit Bump
description: The United States and India opened what they called an era ''of new beginnings'' on Tuesday in an effort to rebuild a relationship that President Clinton said had been neglected for more than two decades. But a series of encounters, including a sharp rebuke of the president in the evening, showed that the opening chapter was spiked with surprises.

title: CHINA'S W.T.O. MEMBERSHIP ADVANCES
description: A senior Chinese trade official expressed optimism that China would soon enter the final stage of its 14-year-old effort to enter the World Trade Organization. China's chief negotiator, Long Yongtu, said the country was hoping to complete agreements soon with 10 members of the trade group, including the European Union. China has said it intends to enter the W.T.O. even if Congress moves to deny it favored trading status. Mr. Long spoke after a meeting of a W.T.O. committee on China's membership application. Elizabeth Olson (NYT)

title: One Period A Disaster To Islanders
description: Islanders Coach Butch Goring went home thirsty.

title: Pope Arrives in Israel and Gets Taste of Mideast Politics
description: Pope John Paul II opened the first official visit by a pope to Israel today, declaring after he landed in Tel Aviv that he felt ''deep emotion'' on setting foot ''in the land where God chose to pitch his tent.'' Immediately on his arrival, he was also given a taste of the fierce politics that are likely to vein his long-awaited pilgrimage to the Holy Land.

title: Boyhood Pals in Poland, Ready for the Reunion
description: Yosef Bienenstock, who had survived eight death camps during the Holocaust because of his skills as a handyman, finally returned to Poland to get his little brother's bones in 1992.

title: Open Positions of Short Sales Climb 5.7% on the Big Board
description: After three consecutive months of declines, open positions of short sales climbed on the New York Stock Exchange, according to the most recent monthly data.

title: A Lapse at Home Comes to Haunt A British Export; U.S. Seeks More Oversight In Cleanup of Nuclear Waste
description: From simmering tanks of high-level nuclear waste in Washington State and plutonium laced with chemical poisons in Idaho to production of radioactive gases in South Carolina, the federal government's nuclear weapons program has festering technical and environmental problems like no one else in the country.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  YARK, PEARL
description: YARK-Pearl. Young Israel of Fifth Avenue records with sorrow the death of the mother of our esteemed member, Sandy Yark, and extends to her and the family our heartfelt condolences.

description: To the Editor:

title: U.S. to Urge Letting Iraq Double Money For Oil Gear
description: The United States will propose doubling the sums Iraq may spend on spare parts for its decrepit oil industry, neglected during almost 10 years of sanctions, diplomats said today.

title: The Belle of TriBeCa Is Now a Grande Dame
description: SOME restaurants win admiration. Others inspire love. Chanterelle does both. The restaurant, one of New York's longest-running shows, celebrated its 20th birthday last November. In a tumultuous industry where ''live fast, die young'' is the rule rather than the exception, two decades in the top rank is impressive. Chanterelle opened two years before ''Cats,'' and, unless a freak tornado sweeps it away, it will roll right along after the musical has closed.

description: March 21, 2000

description: KITSON-Thomas M. 9th anniversary. You were some piece of material. Your friends and family will always love and miss you.

title: BLACKSTONE GROUP REDUCES ITS OFFER FOR KROLL-O'GARA
description: The Kroll-O'Gara Company, a security and private-investigation company, said that the Blackstone Group L.P. had reduced its cash buyout offer to $16 a share from the $18 it offered in November. The new bid values the transaction at $422.2 million, 11 percent less than the original offer. The investment banking concern made its initial offer for Kroll-O'Gara, which is based in Fairfield, Ohio, two months after the company hired Bear, Stearns & Company to consider options, including a possible sale. Kroll O'Gara shares fell 43.75 cents, to $13.875 each, in Nasdaq trading.

title: Paid Notice: Memorials  BERGMAN, SONYA S.
description: BERGMAN-Sonya S. A lady with class and always with a smile. It's three years and I miss you more than ever. All my love, Henry.

description: Iranian Caviar to Return After a Two-Decade Exile

title: Jets Say Johnson Is No Longer on Trading Block
description: With an exchange of bluntly worded statements that offered a glimpse into an increasingly fractious relationship, the stalemate between the Jets and receiver Keyshawn Johnson solidified yesterday.

description: Power and Phone Companies Form Fiber-Optic Network

title: False Missile Deadline
description: With important technical problems still unresolved, the Pentagon has now postponed the next, crucial test of America's projected missile defense system for nearly two months, until late June. With time needed to analyze the results, that means President Clinton will be in no position to make an informed decision about whether to build the system before this fall at the earliest. The issue is too important to be decided in the heat of a presidential campaign and should be deferred until Mr. Clinton's successor takes office.

title: De La Hoya's plans
description: The promoter Bob Arum has mapped out Oscar De La Hoya's schedule for the next year and he has left room for Felix Trinidad (the welterweight version) to squeeze in if Trinidad can drop an arm or a leg to make weight.

title: McCain Is Subdued On His First Day Back
description: It was not John McCain the fiery maverick railing on the floor of the Senate this morning.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  KAYE, JEANNE
description: KAYE-Jeanne. A dear friend. Our condolences and love to Manny, Barbara, Cheryl, Bill and Bob. Ronne and Sam Wulwick

title: Screams and Dreams in Times Square
description: With girls slumped over barricades and screaming in decibels that could shatter glass -- all in the hope that members of the popular boy band 'N Sync would appear -- the streets of Times Square yesterday seemed like a good place for nuanced debate.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  LEWIS, HYLAN
description: LEWIS-Hylan. The Brooklyn College community mourns the passing of Professor Emeritus of Sociology Hylan Lewis. His many years of teaching and service will be long remembered. Christoph M. Kimmich, President Brooklyn College

title: JVC Festival Announces Latin Lineup
description: The 28th annual JVC Jazz Festival will begin with a series of concerts at the Kaye Playhouse, George Wein, chief of Festival Productions, announced yesterday. The festival, from June 12 to 24, includes a program on the music of Bill Evans, a 90th-birthday party for the bassist Milt Hinton and a concert tribute to Charlie Byrd and George Van Eps, guitarists who died last year.

title: National News Briefs; Rep. Crane of Illinois Says He Is Alcoholic
description: Representative Philip M. Crane, a senior Illinois Republican, said today that he was taking a 30-day medical leave from the House to receive treatment for alcoholism.

title: The Magical Mystery Orange
description: ON the surface, it is not one of nature's most beautiful creations: a bumpy, blotchy thick skin encasing a pale, seedy yellow pulp.

title: 9 Bankers Move To Robertson
description: Seeking to bolster its merger-advisory business in New York, BancBoston Robertson Stephens hired a team of nine investment bankers away from the PaineWebber Group, including David Reed, who was group head of mergers and acquisitions at PaineWebber.

title: Accounts Diverge on What Led to Killing Outside Bar
description: Five days after an unarmed man was shot and killed by a narcotics detective outside a bar on Eighth Avenue, investigators are focusing on two widely divergent versions of the events that led up to the shooting of the man, Patrick M. Dorismond.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  KELLER, LEO
description: KELLER-Leo, MD, of Woodbridge, CT formerly of Neponsit, NY, died on March 20, 2000. For almost his entire professional career, Dr. Keller practiced in NYC most of which was spent as Director of Radiology at The French Hospital. He attended NYU for college and medical education, receiving his MD in 1938. During WWII, he served as a captain and a physician for the US Army Engineering Corps in the South Pacific. After the war, Dr. Keller returned to work in NYC and lived in the Rockaways raising his family with his wife Freda who predeceased him in 1993 after 42 years of marriage. He is survived by his two sons, Marc S. Keller, MD of Woodbridge, CT and Jeffrey Keller of Upper Brookville, NY and two granddaughters Leslie and Meredith Keller of Woodbridge, CT. Funeral services will be held on Wednesday, March 22 at 1:30pm at Gutterman's, 8000 Jericho Turnpike, Woodbury, NY.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  MITCHELL, ALBERT
description: MITCHELL-Albert, 85, of Boca Raton, Fl., passed away on March 20. Beloved husband of Frances; devoted father of Martin, Lois, & Shelley; and stepfather of Carol Sommers, Edie Mueller, and Paul Aronowitz; doting grandfather of Sydney Mitchell, Sarah Longacre, & Audrey Tommassini; and doting step-grandfather of Steven and Zachary Aronowitz, Ariadne Mueller, Rosa, Lucas, Jesse, and Rio Longacre; and dear great-grandfather of Maxx Mitchell; loving brother of Claire Krubel. Born in Montreal, Albert was an industrialist, artist and adventurer who filled his life and those around him with the joy and spirit of hard work and hard play. Memorial services Sunday, March 26, 1 PM, Menorah Chapel, 2305 West Hillsboro Boulevard, Deerfield Beach, Florida, (954) 427-4700.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  HAINES, THOMAS F.D.
description: HAINES-Thomas F.D., age 98, of New York City, died March 20, 2000. Husband of the late Marian F. Haines and brother of the late Henry Alexander Haines, he is survived by his daughter, Marian H. Minton, of Princeton, NJ; sons, Thomas D. Haines, of Brooklyn, New York, and Alexander Haines, of Coral Springs, Florida; six grandchildren and three greatgrandchildren. A memorial service will be held in mid-April.

title: He's Russia's Front-Runner, and He's a a Mystery
description: As Russia ambles toward a second presidential election almost surreal in its absence of sturm, drang or even garden-variety suspense, perhaps its most amazing aspect is that nobody yet has a clear notion of what the front-runner in the race -- if it can be called a race -- would actually do if elected.

title: Dollars for Bowling: Internet Millionaires Buy Professional Tour
description: Bowlers have long been the Everymen of the nation's professional athletes, blue-collar practitioners of a low-tech sport.

title: Taiwan Fills Center Stage In U.S. Talks With Beijing
description: A senior American official said today that in two days of intensive talks Chinese leaders had demonstrated a ''cautious and prudent'' approach toward the new administration in Taiwan and seemed anxious to explore what the election outcome meant for the complicated relationship among China, the United States and Taiwan.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  ROSENBERG, RITA
description: ROSENBERG-Rita (Goldstein). On March 20, 2000. Beloved wife of the late Nathaniel. Devoted daughter of the late Dr. Benjamin and Anna Goldstein. Loving mother of Linda Mueller, Roger, Richard and Jonathan Rosenberg. Cherished grandmother. Dear sister of Marilyn Hershon and the late Judith Caplen and Dr. Jerome Goldstein. Services Thursday, 12PM, ''The Riverside'', 76th St. and Amsterdam Ave.

description: To the Editor:

title: CINAR SUES INVESTMENT FIRMS
description: The beleaguered Canadian producer of children's television programs, the Cinar Corporation, is suing three investment companies in the Bahamas and a principal, Robert Daviault, to recover $76 million it is missing. A month ago, the Montreal-based maker of animated films said $122 million had been invested without the approval of its board. Since then, about $45 million has been recovered from Norshield International Ltd. and its affiliates. Another $76 million is said to be invested in the commercial paper of a Bahamian company, but Cinar said requests for information had been rebuffed.

title: Yarnall Trying Hard Not to Win No. 5 Starting Job
description: The Yankees want Ed Yarnall to win the job as the fifth starter, and they want to keep Ramiro Mendoza in their bullpen. But Yarnall is not cooperating with the plan: the rookie left-hander pitched horribly again tonight in an 8-3 loss to the Toronto Blue Jays.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  BLEETSTEIN, ELAINE NONAS
description: BLEETSTEIN-Elaine Nonas. Died on March 19 in her 94th year. Beloved wife of the late Monroe Bleetstein. Adored mother of Nona Bleetstein and Marjorie and Michael Grunebaum. Cherished grandmother of Lauren, David, Christine and Ted Grunebaum. Loving sister of Miriam Blechner, Betty Lash, Dr. Gerson Nonas and Elliott Nonas. Services Wednesday, 11AM, at Riverside-Nassau North Chapels, 55 North Station Plaza, Great Neck, N.Y. Donations may be made to the Alzheimer's Association, New York Chapter.

title: Why a Victory in Taiwan Wasn't Enough for Some
description: Even tonight, three days after an opposition candidate was elected president, ending more than 50 years of Nationalist rule, Hsieh Tsung-min could barely contain his elation.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  DORF, MARTIN
description: DORF-Martin. Uncle Marty, you always had a way of making us laugh. You will always be remembered with lots of love. Amanda, Nicole and Andrew

title: Footlights
description: NEWS

title: Dutiful Daughter, Out of the Limelight
description: With her mother campaigning in New York, Chelsea Clinton stepped into the role of substitute first lady today. Dressed in a camera-shy gray dress and jacket, she drove with her father to the formal arrival ceremony at the presidential palace and, a few steps behind Mr. Clinton, shook hands with the dignitaries.

title: Judge Allows Lesser Charge In Trial of Subway Pusher
description: The judge presiding over the second murder trial of a schizophrenic man who pushed a woman to her death in front of a speeding subway train ruled yesterday that the jury could consider a lesser charge, manslaughter.

title: Dow Gains Despite Increase in Short-Term Interest Rates
description: Stock prices staged a broad, strong rally yesterday even though the Federal Reserve Board raised short-term interest rates and gave every indication it was prepared to do so again in about two months.

title: Made for Crepes, but Ideal for Everything Else
description: YEARS ago I was given a crepe pan. It was a hand-me-down, and it looked like one. I've grown to love it. And I've used it for lots of things -- sauteing mushrooms, searing duck, simmering onions. About the only thing I haven't used it for is crepes.

title: Compromise Proposed on Patients' Rights Bill
description: With the House and the Senate deadlocked on legislation to define patients' rights, an influential Congressman proposed a compromise today on one of the biggest issues in dispute: how many Americans should be protected by new federal standards?

title: DaimlerChrysler-Mitsubishi Talks Advance
description: DaimlerChrysler A.G. is in the final stage of talks with the Mitsubishi Motors Corporation about acquiring 33.4 percent of the Japanese automobile maker, and an announcement could come by the end of this week, executives close to the talks said last night.

title: Not for a Nigerian Hero the Peace of the Grave
description: ''I'm not happy, I'm not a happy man,'' said Jim Beeson Wiwa, 94, standing in a field here where he hopes to build a monument for the son whose remains he has yet to recover.

title: Liberties; Talking To the Spittoons
description: On the road, throngs fought to get near John McCain. In the deserted Senate chamber yesterday, he gave a speech on Kosovo to 99 empty mahogany desks and a few brass spittoons. No wonder he was feeling nostalgic, or ''shmaltzy,'' as he put it, about his zany revolution and his runaway bus.

title: Morales Vows To Win Rematch
description: A month after a brutal 12-round junior featherweight battle of attrition against Marco Antonio Barrera, Erik Morales was in New York yesterday looking none the worse for wear and vowing to clear up any impressions that his split-decision victory was somehow undeserved or a fluke.

title: HIGH COURT HOLDS F.D.A. CAN'T IMPOSE RULES ON TOBACCO
description: The Supreme Court today dealt a sharp blow to the Clinton administration's efforts to curb smoking, ruling 5 to 4 that the Food and Drug Administration had never received authority from Congress to regulate tobacco products.

title: BUSINESS DIGEST
description: Fed Raises Interest Rates In Effort to Slow Economy

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  EINHORN, WILLIAM
description: EINHORN-William died on March 11th, 2000 in West Palm Beach, Florida. Beloved husband of Lydia, devoted father of Stephen and Robert. Cherished grandfather to Jodi, Gregory, Daniel and Victoria. In 1949, Bill teamed up with television's first art teacher Jon Gnagy to produce and direct one of the industry's longest-running programs ''Learn to Draw'' which influenced the lives of many contemporary artists and millions of television viewers. Bill also wrote the book, music and lyrics for two community stage shows that have been revived numerous times, most recently by the Summer Chase Players, who plan to rename their group in his honor. Bill was a role model for his family and community. He is loved and will be missed by all he touched. A memorial servcice will be held on April 30 in Wellington, Florida.

title: For Former Radical, Old Battleground Became Refuge
description: When the law came for him again, 33 years after he first went underground, the man who was once called H. Rap Brown had returned to Lowndes County, where his life and those of so many others began to change in 1964.

title: Rift Deepens Between Britain and Germany Over Rover Deal
description: An increasingly bitter dispute between Germany and Britain over the BMW sale of the money-losing Rover Group threatened to spill onto the streets after British labor unions called today for a huge demonstration on April 1 to protest the thousands of job losses expected from the deal.

title: Trade Deficit Rises to Record $28 Billion
description: Swollen by a huge bill for foreign oil and a voracious spending spree by prosperous American consumers, the nation's trade deficit jumped to a record $28 billion in January, the Commerce Department reported yesterday. Exports sagged, breaking a streak of seven consecutive advances.

title: An international design agency's name becomes a shadow of itself in a move to bolster its identity.
description: A LOW-PROFILE international design and image firm, Desgrippes Gobe & Associates, which has high-profile clients like Air France, Coca-Cola and the Limited, is creating a new identity for a client it has known forever: itself.

title: THE MARKETS: Market Place; The Fed Has No Surprises and the Market Has a Reason to Rally
description: The no-surprises Federal Reserve Board gave investors just what they were expecting yesterday: a quarter-point increase in short-term interest rates. The full-of-surprises stock market delivered a smashing gain on the news, with two of the broadest indexes closing at new highs.

description: India and U.S. Set Technology Forum

title: Guilty Plea In Bankruptcy Fraud Scheme
description: A Queens man pleaded guilty yesterday to federal charges that he participated in a complex swindle. The man, John Thomas Kelly Sr., 58, of Breezy Point, pleaded guilty in United States District Court in Newark to one count of conspiracy to commit fraud. Prosecutors said the scheme had cheated 200 companies out of $2.5 million in merchandise purchased on credit by a company that declared bankruptcy to avoid making payments.

title: A Papal Pilgrimage Reaches to the Past
description: Pope John Paul II opened the first official visit by a pope to Israel, declaring after he arrived in Tel Aviv that he felt ''deep emotion'' on setting foot ''in the land where God chose to pitch his tent.'' Among the people he will meet are several elderly Jews, Holocaust survivors, from his own hometown in Poland.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  WEISHAR, JESSIE
description: WEISHAR-Jessie. In her 90th year. Loving and devoted wife of the late Irving L. Loving and spirited mother to Joseph, Rochelle Krieg (deceased), Maxine and Robert Sokoloff. Adoring grandmother to Margo and Peter; Harold and Steven; Sharon, Diann, and Steven. Proud great grandmother to eight children. Dear sister to Louis, Isadore (deceased), Jack, Fay, and Esta. Her generous, enabling life has given joyful inspirational memories to all whom she has touched. She kept her counsel, stayed true to her loved ones, and was a model who taught us all how to love. She will be sorely missed. Service Thurs. March 23, 9:45 AM at ''The Riverside'', 76 St & Amsterdam Ave.

title: Shooting Resonates Among Haitians
description: Among Haitians, from Port-au-Prince to Flatbush Avenue, most everyone knows the Dorismond name.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  LEWIS, DAVID J.
description: LEWIS-David J., 85, on March 15, 2000, after a long illness died peacefully at home with his loved ones beside him. Wife of 59 years, Gloria (nee Lehrer); children, Patricia and Gerald Borakove and Alisa and Richard Altabef; grandchildren, Jason, Nomi, Morry, Jacob and David. Services private. Memorial service at Little Neck Jewish Center, Sunday, March 26, 2000, at 3:30 PM.

title: A Plan for Online Trading of Metals and Oil
description: Morgan Stanley Dean Witter, Royal Dutch/Shell and five other banks and energy companies said today that they would create a Web site for trading precious metals and oil, two of the world's most heavily traded commodities.

title: A Long Look at Israel (And at His Wife's Toes)
description: Ron Havilio had a lovely idea. Capture the history of Jerusalem, where he was born in 1950, on film, mixing it with the history of his own family, which traces its history there for centuries. The resulting work is ''Fragments: Jerusalem,'' a six-hour film being shown at the New Directors/New Films series today through April 6. It is worthy and ambitious but somewhat soporific.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  GOLDRING, EDWIN I.
description: GOLDRING-Edwin I. Of Longboat Key and Buffalo, died March 18, 2000 in Sarasota, FL. Former Senior Vice President for Jacobson Stores, Inc. Predeceased by his wife, Vera, He is survived by his four children, six grandchildren, a great grandchild and his second wife, Judith. His strength, generosity, extraordinary competence and love for his family will be much missed.

title: INSIDE
description: Russia Votes, and Then?

title: THE BOSS; Sleepless in Cyberspace
description: When I was 9 years old, I was the founding editor, publisher, circulation director and finance director for the Archer Lane Scoop, in Lynnfield, Mass. It was your classic neighborhood newsletter. My biggest scoop was interviewing a neighbor on the one-year anniversary of her son's death by suffocation in a snowbank. She wouldn't talk to me after that. I learned early on what it was like to get doors slammed in your face.

title: The Race to Staff Summer Schools
description: Mayor Rudolph Giuliani and Harold Levy, the interim New York City schools chancellor, have not formally met to discuss policy in the two months Mr. Levy has been on the job, This may be due to the fact that Mr. Levy was appointed over Mr. Giuliani's objections, even though the chancellor seems to be the diligent manager the mayor said he needed. In any case, the chill between the two men has to end soon, if for no other reason than that plans for summer school for about 300,000 city schoolchildren are far behind schedule, and between the two of them they must find 17,000 teachers in short order if they wish to avert what could be an educational disaster.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  WEAVER, WILLIAM B.
description: WEAVER-William B. On March 21, 2000, beloved husband of Beth, loving father of Courtney and Charlotte, devoted son of Leonard and Dorothy Weaver, loving brother of Steven and David. He was a prominent investment banker and President of Weaver Capital. He will be deeply missed by all who knew and loved him. Memorial service to be announced at a later date.

description: OPPERMAN-Nancy Rosenthal, age 81, long time resident of NYC. Designer of Bloomingdales's orignal shopping bag, & wife of Martin Opperman, passed away March 10. She is pre-deceased by her husband, survived by daughter Amy (Paul), granddaughter Erin. Calling hours and service March 26th in Millbrook, NY. For info contact Royce-Chedzoy in Watkins Glen.

description: An article in Science Times yesterday about the play ''Copenhagen,'' which deals with the role of the physicist Werner Heisenberg in the Nazi atomic bomb effort, referred incompletely to a related seminar to be held on Monday. The seminar as a whole was created by the Ensemble Studio Theater and the Alfred P. Sloan Foundation in conjunction with the Graduate Center of the City University. The session on the play was organized by the Ensemble Studio Theater. The sessions involving the science and history of the bomb work were organized by Dr. Brian Schwartz, vice president for research at the City University.

title: NORTEL NETWORKS TO BUY CORETEK IN STOCK DEAL
description: The Nortel Networks Corporation, North America's No. 2 telephone-equipment maker, agreed to buy CoreTek Inc. for around $1.43 billion in stock to reduce the cost of making fiber optic transmission gear. The closely held CoreTek makes lasers that can be tuned like a radio to change the color of light they generate. Each color represents a wavelength that carries information on fiber optic networks. The devices are an improvement over today's lasers, which are limited to a single color. Shares of Nortel, the biggest maker of fiber optic equipment, rose $3.125 each, to $129.50, in New York Stock Exchange trading yesterday. CoreTek, based in Wilmington, Mass., has 120 employees.

title: BRITISH SURPLUS SURGES
description: Gordon Brown, Britain's chancellor of the exchequer, announced a budget surplus of $19 billion, the biggest since the booming 1980's, for the year ending March 31. Mr. Brown sought favor with Labor voters by promising increased spending on health and education, the poor and the old. But, in an annual budget that he said was devoted to maintaining fiscal prudence, he also increased taxes on expensive homes, wine, beer and cigarettes, drawing criticism from opposition Conservatives that any gains would be offset by increases in the overall tax burden. Alan Cowell (NYT)

title: Investment in Health Site
description: Internet Healthcare, a private company that finances Internet health care sites, said today that it received a $70 million investment from the Internet Capital Group. Internet Capital, based in Wayne, Pa., invests in and helps operate Internet start-ups. The company said its latest investment was part of its strategy of supporting companies involved in business-to-business online transactions. Internet Healthcare is trying to create a partnership of companies that conduct Internet health care transactions.

title: She Knows 'Hard Work Is What Matters'
description: DON'T open the refrigerator down in Room 37 in the basement of Port Washington's research-minded Paul D. Schreiber High School. What looks and smells like a science experiment going on in there actually is a science experiment. But it doesn't belong to Viviana Risca. Hers was made famous last week in Washington, where she won the nationwide Intel Science Talent Search (and a $100,000 scholarship) with a project that encoded a secret message in a strand of DNA.

title: THE MARKETS: COMMODITIES
description: PORK BELLIES FALL. Pork belly futures declined after a report showed meatpackers had increased pork supplies to meet demand. In Chicago, pork bellies for May delivery fell 2.45 cents, to 90.275 cents a pound.

title: Speak Freely (But Not About Those Things)
description: Tomorrow night John Stossel, ABC's scourge of the left, goes after what he considers constraints on free speech in the claimed interests of civility. ''You Can't Say That!'' wanders a bit with asides on Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani's attempts to stop marches and exhibits by groups he finds offensive, on efforts in Congress to outlaw flag burning and on mainstream television's restrictions on profanity, before it gets down to Mr. Stossel's real subject: current tendencies on the once-permissive left to crack down on what it deems racism or sexism.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  O'GRADY, THOMAS B.
description: O'GRADY-Thomas B. Born Chaelis, Washington, June 24, 1926 passed away on Monday, March 20, 2000. He was a retired executive of UST, Inc. where he had a long and celebrated career for 42 years, retiring as Vice Chairman of the corporation in 1991. In recent years, Mr. O'Grady devoted his time to philanthropic endeavors. He raised money for his Alma Mater, St. Martin's College, Lacy, Washington. His generosity included the Music and Arts Building and the O'Grady Library. He is survived by his wife Kathleen O'Grady, and his children Thomas P. O'Grady, Gail O'Grady (daughter-in-law), Kathleen O'Grady Brown, George Brown (son-inlaw), and Sheila O'Grady Edwards and four grandchildren, Shannon O'Grady, Sean O'Grady, Kasey Edwards, Kristen Edwards. The viewing will take place at Collins Funeral Home 92 East Avenue, Norwalk, CT, 203-866-0747 from 4:00 to 8:00 P.M. Wednesday, March 22, and Thursday, March 23. A Mass of Christian Burial will be celebrated Friday, March 24, at 10:00 A.M. in St. Thomas The Apostle Church, 203 East Avenue, Norwalk (for directions call 203866-0747). In lieu of flowers, donations may be made to the Thomas O'Grady Scholarship Fund for Students in The Arts at St. Martin's College, at 5300 Pacific Avenue SE, Lacy, Washington 98503-1297 or 360-438-4366, Young Composers Program at the New York Philharmonic Orchestra and Musical Theatre Development at Playwrights Horizons, New York City or the charity of your choice.

title: Gallery Accused of Cheating Prominent Artist
description: The international art gallery that was at the center of one of the art world's most spectacular scandals -- the plundering of the estate of Mark Rothko -- was accused in court papers in London yesterday of cheating a second prominent artist, the British figurative painter Francis Bacon, and systematically defrauding him and his heir.

title: Report on bin Laden Altered Clinton Plan
description: United States officials said today that President Clinton's plan to visit a Bangladeshi village this week was canceled after a terrorist threat possibly linked to Osama bin Laden, the Saudi exile who has been accused of terrorism.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SCHONFELD, HILDEGARD
description: SCHONFELD - Hildegard. The Board of Directors and staff of the Jewish Community Center on the Palisades deeply mourn the loss of Hilde Schonfeld, a beloved member and supporter of the JCC community, and devoted wife of longtime Board of Trustees member Sidney Schonfeld. Hilde was particularly influential at the JCC in her involvement with the Holocaust Memorial, SeniorNet, the Cultural and Visual Arts committees, and the planning of special events at the Center. All at the JCC were indeed blessed to know Hilde, a true woman of valor whose dedication and generosity enriched our lives tremendously. We offer our heartfelt sympathy to Sid; daughter, Victoria; son, Gary, and the entire Schonfeld family. May the Lord comfort them among all the mourners of Zion. Nancy I. Brown, President Avi A. Lewinson, Exec. Director

Donations to Hospice of Orange, 800 Stony Brook Court, Newburgh, NY 12550. For information: Smith, Seaman & Quackenbush, Inc., Monroe, NY.

title: Corrections
description: A picture caption in Business Day on Thursday with an article about Sam Wyly, the Texas investor and Republican campaign donor, misidentified the target of criticism of his management practices and those of his associates. It has focused on public companies in which Mr. Wyly and his family have interests. It has not extended to Maverick Capital, a private hedge fund that Mr. Wyly founded.

title: Body Parts Found In Queens Park
description: A human skull and foot were found in plastic food containers in a park in Queens yesterday, the police said.

title: Pride and Blood in Kashmir
description: There were horrifying scenes all around on Tuesday when I reached Chati Singhpora, the village in Indian-held Kashmir where, the night before, more than 35 Sikh men had been killed. In the courtyard of the local gurudwara (the Sikh prayer site), the dead men were being brought in on ladders, which improvised as stretchers. Covered in bright, coarse blankets, the corpses dripped blood on the muddy ground. Placed on thin rugs, the bodies were immediately surrounded by relatives, mostly women hysterical with grief and despair, their long hair loose, their bangles broken.

title: Court Lifts Stay of Execution for Tennessee Inmate
description: A federal appeals court today lifted a stay of execution for a child killer in Tennessee, making it possible that the state could carry out its first execution in 40 years early Thursday.

title: Room Service? One Romance, Please
description: The best television series, it seems, come from somebody's personal experience or vision. Like Linwood Boomer's growing up as the smart one in a rowdy four-boy household, which turned into ''Malcolm in the Middle.'' Or whatever it is that inspired Chris Carter to create ''The X-Files,'' about F.B.I. agents, conspiracies and extraterrestrials.

title: Corrections
description: Articles on Friday, Saturday and Monday about Jamil Abdullah Al-Amin, formerly known as H. Rap Brown -- who was arrested on Monday in the shootings of two sheriff's deputies in Atlanta -- referred incompletely to his organizational connection in the 1960's. (Other articles in recent years have also been incomplete.) Mr. Brown was best known for his role with the Student Nonviolent Coordinating Committee; he became its chairman in 1967. In 1968 he was made an honorary officer of the Black Panthers during an attempt to merge the two groups.

title: BERTELSMANN TO SELL STAKE IN UNIT
description: Germany's largest media company, Bertelsmann A.G., said it would sell 20 to 25 percent of its bol.com A.G. online bookseller in an initial share sale in the second quarter. Bertelsmann has said it expects to raise a total of 5 billion marks ($2.5 billion) from the bol.com sale and the sale of shares in its Lycos Europe joint venture with Lycos Inc.. That offering was priced yesterday at 24 euros, to raise as much as 773 million euros. The online retailer will use the money to continue an expansion that has placed it in six European countries in about a year.

title: Giuliani Asserts Mrs. Clinton Is the One Polarizing the City
description: Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani said yesterday that Hillary Rodham Clinton, who has accused the mayor of racially polarizing New York City, was projecting her own feelings onto him. The mayor's assertion came as the police shooting death of Patrick Dorismond reverberated through City Hall and the State Legislature and into the United States Senate campaign.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  HAAS, GILDA
description: HAAS-Gilda, of NYC, died peacefully at age 97 on March 20th, 2000. Beloved wife of the late Irving. Devoted mother of David and mother-in-law of Susan. Dearest grandmother of Jonathan and Pamela. Interment private.

title: In Nassau, Special Election and an Ultimatum
description: The Nassau County executive, Thomas S. Gulotta, set the stage today for two major battles, scheduling a May 2 special election that will determine which party will control the County Legislature and issuing a new ultimatum to the county's largest union.

title: Three Firms Invest $40 Million In Times Company's Digital Unit
description: The New York Times Company, which plans a public offering of a new class of stock in its Internet business division this spring, said yesterday that three venture capital firms had invested $40 million in the division, Times Company Digital.

title: Mets' Ventura Is Working His Way Back Into Form
description: The flashiest infielder in Chicago worked on the same side of the infield and the other side of town. The White Sox third baseman, Robin Ventura, would watch Shawon Dunston, the Cubs' shortstop, and the differences between them were obvious. The two would joke about it when they saw each other.

title: HIGHEST KOREAN GROWTH IN 12 YEARS
description: South Korea's economy recorded the highest growth rate in 12 years in 1999, the Bank of Korea said. The nation's economy grew 10.7 percent last year, rebounding from a contraction of 6.7 percent in 1998, during an economic recession. Gross domestic product rose 13 percent compared with the fourth quarter of the previous year. Samuel Len (NYT)

title: Police Officer Indicted On Molestation Charges
description: A Newark police officer was indicted yesterday on charges that he took a bag of marijuana from one teenager and threatened to plant it on two others he then molested, the Essex County prosecutor's office said.

title: WEB SITE COMPANY INVESTS TO GAIN NET TECHNOLOGY
description: The Web-site operating company Exodus Communications Inc. agreed yesterday to invest $637.5 million in the Mirror Image Internet Inc. unit of Xcelera.com Inc. Terms of the investment were not disclosed. Exodus, based in Santa Clara, Calif., has centers around the world that operate and maintain Internet sites for other companies, including CBS Sports, eBay and MSN Hotmail. With the investment in Mirror Image, based in Woburn, Mass., Exodus will gain access to technology that speeds delivery of content over the Internet. Xcelera is a holding company based in Grand Cayman Island that invests in Internet companies. Xcelera shares jumped nearly 22 percent, rising $37.75 each, to $212, on the American Stock Exchange, while Exodus was up $14.125 a share, to $169.375, in Nasdaq trading.

title: To Get Ahead, Badgers Hang Back
description: The Wisconsin Badgers offer no apologies for a style more suited to the era of peach baskets than slam dunks. They know exactly what would happen if they tried to shift their speed to a modern fast-paced college game.

title: Tar Heels Tread Lightly On Familiar Territory
description: Even with nine of the 16 highest-seeded teams already out of this year's National Collegiate Athletic Association tournament, it is a bit of a shock to have North Carolina's advancement to the Round of 16 come as a surprise.

title: Economic Scene; The golden formula for Hollywood success. It only happens in the movies.
description: AS Hollywood gathers on Sunday to heap Oscar praise on such surprise hits as ''American Beauty'' and ''The Sixth Sense,'' producers and studio marketing heads are revamping their idea of what makes for box-office success. Action heroes, happy endings, special effects and high-concept synopses are out. Flawed protagonists, shock value, downbeat twists and hard-to-explain plots are in.

title: Mayor and Schools Chief to Meet for First Time
description: Board of Education officials said yesterday that Harold O. Levy, the interim schools chancellor, plans to meet with Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani today, for the first time.

title: Technology Lifts Nasdaq and Pushes S.& P. Over 1,500
description: Irrepressible optimism about high-technology propelled the Nasdaq stock market to its biggest gain in almost three weeks yesterday and lifted the Standard & Poor's 500-stock index above the 1,500 mark for the first time.

title: Erard Matthiessen, 97, New York Architect
description: Erard A. Matthiessen, an architect and conservationist, died on March 8 at the home of a friend in Sanibel, Fla. He was 97.

title: Rivals Conceding Woods His Due, Not Another Title
description: As the world's best golfers prepared for one of their favorite tournaments, Tiger Woods remained a dominant figure and a dominant topic of discussion.

title: BG TO SPIN OFF PIPELINES
description: Shares in BG Group, Britain's natural gas network, jumped after the company said it would spin off its pipeline division as part of a strategy to diversify into telecommunications. The pipeline division, Transco, has said it wants to use its 160,000 miles of pipelines to carry fiber optic cables for telecommunications services. BG Group's rebound did not wipe out a long-term decline in its share price, which has slipped about 15 percent this year. Alan Cowell (NYT)

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  HENDRICKS, KLAUS J.
description: HENDRICKS-Klaus J., in Westport, CT on Mar. 20, 2000. Husband of Dorothy Hendricks. Father of Carol H. Rodriguez, Michael K. Hendricks, Charles H. Hendricks and grandfather of eight. Retired Assistant Treasurer of the World Trade Division for IBM Corporation. Services Friday, March 24th at 11 AM in Hope Church, 240 Wolf Pit Road, Wilton, CT. Interment Willowbrook Cemetery, Westport.

title: Tuboscope-Varco Merger Accord Is Set
description: Tuboscope Inc. said today that it would merge with a rival oil field equipment company, Varco International Inc., in a transaction valued at $834 million in stock.

title: Freed Rapist Traveled Openly by Bus Across East and South During Nationwide Manhunt
description: For most of the 11 days in which he was the object of a nationwide search, Raymond Alves was riding long-distance buses for thousands of miles, officials said today.

description: To the Editor:

title: Art Business Has Soared At Smaller Auction House
description: As the federal antitrust investigation of Sotheby's and Christie's continues, officials of Phillips, the distant third among worldwide auction houses, yesterday said that their New York business had exploded, with the house's coming spring sale setting what is far and away a record for the 206-year-old firm.

title: PROJECTOR MAKER ENDS REVIEW WITH NEW DIGITAL FOCUS
description: Ballantyne of Omaha Inc., the largest maker of movie projection systems, said yesterday that it had ended its review of strategic alternatives, which included the possible sale of the company. Ballantyne dismissed its adviser, Donaldson, Lufkin & Jenrette Inc., which it hired in October to explore a possible sale, acquisition or merger. Ballantyne now wants to ''get back down to business'' by focusing on building digital movie equipment, its chief financial officer, Brad French, said. Digital movie equipment is expected to replace the film projectors now used in theaters. Ballantyne fell 31.25 cents, to $3.8125, on the New York Stock Exchange.

title: TODAY'S SCHEDULES
description: GEORGE W. BUSH -- Orlando and West Palm Beach, Fla.

description: FRYDMAN-Gusta (Winchester). Died at home March 21. Born July 25, 1919 in Poland. Loving and beloved wife of Gregory, mother of Anne, grandmother of Sophia and Antonia, mother-in-law of Stephen Dixon, much loved friend and psychotherapist to many people, author of ''My Sessions with Kay.'' Services at ''The Riverside'', 76th Street and Amsterdam Avenue, Thursday, March 23, at 2 P.M.

title: Merger to Link Gay Print and Internet Outlets
description: A San Francisco Internet company, the Planet Out Corporation, and Liberation Publications Inc., the publisher of The Advocate and Out, two of the most influential magazines aimed at the gay and lesbian market in the United States, announced yesterday that they would merge.

title: Quartey Is Fighting to Prove He Belongs Among the Elite
description: Ike Quartey does not climb into the boxing ring for just anybody. He wants to fight only in big events. Consequently, Quartey has not been very active in the last three years. He did not fight at all in 1998, and after a 16-month layoff, he fought Oscar De La Hoya and lost a controversial decision on Feb. 13, 1999.

title: Implosion of Kingdome Will Be Live on the Net
description: Watch the Seattle Kingdome go down in history. On Sunday at 11:30 a.m., one day before the dome turns 25, it will be imploded. In the past two months, all the seats -- which have held 73,130,463 people between opening day on March 27, 1976, and Jan. 9 -- and the railings, ramps and fixtures were removed. The stadium will disappear in less than 17 seconds.

title: Huffing and Puffing to Keep Houses From Falling
description: Among the most revered houses here are the experimental ones by Charles and Ray Eames (left), Richard Neutra (center) and R. M. Schindler (right). They are fragile, having been built with lightweight materials for as little as $7,500 (the Neutra house). It will cost a great deal to guarantee their survival. The Neutra house, which needs $400,000 for restoration, has just been put on the list of the 100 most endangered sites by the World Monuments Fund. April fund-raising benefits include open houses at the Neutra house ($15, 323 953-8400); Eames house seminars ($300, 310 459-9663); and a tour of modern gems including six Schindler houses ($60, 323 651-1510).

title: U.S. Cracks Down on Rise In Appalachia Moonshine
description: Grinning seditiously, a prominent citizen of this Blue Ridge foothills town takes from his kitchen refrigerator an illegal gift from a moonshiner friend: a syrupy red liquor in a quart jar packed with grapelike damsonberries. He offers a taste to his visitor. It is a brandy, sweet and silky.

title: Hospital Is Fined for Removing the Wrong Kidney
description: For the third time in two months, the New York State health commissioner, Antonia Novello, has harshly rebuked a New York City hospital and imposed a heavy fine, this time charging that a hospital covered up a botched surgery in which a healthy kidney was removed from a patient who later died.

title: Movie Books, Starring Moguls
description: Good grief, it's Oscar time again. So book publishers are indulging in their annual fascination with the event and popping their movie books into the stores. What is perhaps different this year is that the books that are being talked about are about movie moguls, not movie stars.

title: Metro Business; Bargaining Begins On Site for Times
description: City and state officials formally began an exclusive 60-day bargaining process with The New York Times yesterday over the newspaper's proposal to build a 40-story headquarters across the street from the Port Authority Bus Terminal, according to executives involved in the talks.

title: Experiment in Wireless Technology Proves to Be More Art Than Science
description: A RECENT event in New York City might give pause to those masochistic souls who not only enjoy programming their VCR's but also look forward to operating them with a wondrous wireless device. A group of researchers from New York University conducted an experiment along those lines a few weeks ago -- and ran into a few glitches.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  BURKE, PAUL E. ESQ.
description: BURKE-Paul E. Esq., 56, formerly of NY City and Croton-on-Hudson died suddenly, Tuesday, March 21, 2000 at his home in Thurman, NY. Mr. Burke was a Trial & Corporate Pension Attorney

title: Corrections
description: An article yesterday about a trip by Al Gore to seek endorsements and campaign contributions in Englewood, N.J., and Manhattan misidentified John Wallach, who held a fund-raising luncheon. He is a former journalist, not a former investment banker.

title: Assad Meeting With Clinton Could Renew Peace Talks
description: The meeting scheduled for Sunday between President Clinton and President Hafez al-Assad of Syria could lay the groundwork for renewed talks between Syria and Israel, but a peace deal is by no means imminent, diplomats in the Middle East said today.

title: Bending Wire With a Whim of Iron
description: JUST fiddle around with hangers and a pair of pliers,'' said Simon Doonan, the display designer at Barneys New York. ''It only takes a few minutes to create something wonderful.'' Easy for him to say. Harder if you are not a designer like the Compana Brothers, Fernando and Humberto, from Brazil, who created a room divider of thin metal rods and wire.

title: Metro Matters; DNA Evidence Offers Hope, And Problems
description: IF you were a rape victim whose assailant had never been caught, you might be feeling a little hopeful right now.

title: I.L.O., Long in Eclipse, Regains Some Prominence
description: Marginalized by decades of obscure work and a lack of enforcement power, the International Labor Organization has recently gained some renewed prominence for a possible future role in helping police the way nations protect workers' rights.

title: Start-Ups Raise Pay and Offer Options as Candidates Dwindle
description: The anecdote, in its many forms, is already a part of Internet lore: An executive leaves a major company for a start-up, takes a large pay cut and hopes that stock options in the new company will instead bring fabulous wealth in the future.

title: THE MARKETS: COMMODITIES
description: CRUDE OIL FALLS. Crude oil dropped ahead of an OPEC meeting on Monday, at which oil ministers are expected to set higher production targets. In New York, crude oil for May delivery fell 35 cents, to $27.46 a barrel.

title: WHEELS FOR MISS PIGGY
description: After purchasing the Jim Henson Company for $680 million last month, EM.TV and Merchandising A.G. of Germany reached a deal to acquire as much as 75 percent of Formula One Holdings, which controls all media rights to Formula One car races. EM.TV will pay $1.63 billion in cash and stock to acquire 50 percent of Formula One and will receive an option to buy an additional 25 percent within the next 12 months. Edmund L. Andrews (NYT)

title: A New Era In Technology For Computers
description: Racing ahead of the most optimistic projections, a team of American computer researchers and chemists have quietly formed a company trying to open a new era of digital electronics by creating immensely powerful computing circuits based on trillions of individual building blocks, each no larger than a single molecule.

title: Justices Back Wal-Mart in Design Case
description: Siding with Wal-Mart Stores Inc. and other discount retailers, the United States Supreme Court said today that manufacturers can assert exclusive rights to their product designs only in rare cases.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  DEBOWSKY, BENJAMIN
description: DEBOWSKY-Benjamin. Sutton Place Synagogue extends condolences to our devoted members Arlene and Bernard Cohen on the loss of Arlene's beloved father. Allan Schranz, Rabbi Robert W. Berend, President

title: Into a Haunted Film Landscape With Philip Glass
description: For Philip Glass and his fans, this seems to be a season for reviewing the inventory, including both old favorites and recent editions. In the fall the Metropolitan Museum of Art began a Glass retrospective that ends next month with a performance of music from ''Les Enfants Terribles.'' And now the Brooklyn Academy of Music, which a few months ago presented the premiere of Mr. Glass's new soundtrack for the 1931 film version of ''Dracula,'' is devoting five concerts to Mr. Glass's film scores, some in concert excerpts and some performed live as accompaniments to the films.

title: Used to Riding High, Gazing Up After a Fall
description: THERE was a time in this country, before sushi, when Japanese food meant Benihana steakhouses. Yes, young ones, we were a meat-eating people then.

description: ''No one can ignore how much the Palestinian people have had to suffer in recent decades. Your torment is before the eyes of the world. And it has gone on too long.''

description: IT may look like the star of a new Japanese monster movie, but a robotic jellyfish unveiled in Tokyo last week is only a toy.

title: Leaving Paradise For the Movies
description: Penthouse life is not what one normally associates with Southern California, land of the rambling ranch and the gated compound. But if you were to imagine someone embracing the sun-washed, sweeping views atop a West Hollywood fake chateau, that person might well be Conrad L. Hall. The man knows a thing or two about light.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  MACAULEY, WALTER P.
description: MACAULEY-Walter P. In Fla., March 20, husband of Mary L. Macauley of 4601 Sanderling Cir West, Boynton Beach, Fla. formerly of Hamden, Conn. father of Walter W. of N.C. and Ann M. Anderson of Florida. Mass in St. Rita Church, Whitney Avenue, Hamden, Conn. Friday at 10 A.M. He was retired senior vice president of Wyatt Oil Corp of New Haven.

title: Metro Business; Grocer to Restructure
description: Pathmark Stores Inc., New Jersey's No. 2 grocery chain, said yesterday that it was in talks with a committee of bondholders about a financial restructuring and that it had hired an investment banker to aid in the discussions.

description: Letters to the Editor

title: Corbis Makes Acquisition
description: The Corbis Corporation, the image-archive company owned by the chairman of the Microsoft Corporation, William H. Gates, agreed today to buy Stock Market Photo Agency for an undisclosed price to add to its collection of commercial photography. The closely held Stock Market Photo has more than three million images from photographers around the world, Corbis said. Corbis, based in Seattle, already owns 65 million images, with 2.1 million of them online.

title: New Systems for Controllers May Ease Air Traffic Woes
description: A red warning on a screen told an air traffic controller here that two west-bound passenger jets, flying 100 miles apart over Tennessee and Alabama, were on courses that would intersect 250 miles ahead, setting up a possible collision over Arkansas.

title: A Shattered Mind, Jagged and Confused
description: The elements of what was once an imposing personality glisten like the fragments of a shattered mirror. As a character observes in ''The Waverly Gallery,'' Kenneth Lonergan's stirring and soulful comic drama, it is as if Gladys Green's mind had been ''smashed to pieces.'' You have to look hard to assemble those shards into anything approaching what she was. Look harder, if you dare, and you may see your own future.

title: Taiwan Doesn't Fear the Future
description: As the shock of Taiwan's presidential election wears off, a clear and promising picture of the island's political future is emerging. Yet American officials continue to fret over the wrong questions: What if the newly elected president, Chen Shui-bian, makes good on his party's longstanding promise to lead Taiwan toward formal independence? Was this a vote for independence?

title: Virginia Company to Resubmit Bid to Buy 2 Nuclear Plants
description: A Virginia company whose offer to buy the New York Power Authority's two nuclear plants expired on Monday said yesterday that it would jump back into the bidding process, less than a week before the authority is expected to select a buyer.

title: Helping Webmasters Land in Search Engines' Nets
description: ON some fronts, the battle for the Internet seems to have cooled. The fight between Netscape and Microsoft is in the hands of the courts. Microsoft's investment in Apple has temporarily imposed a truce in the hostilities between those two companies. And AOL seems to be getting along with everyone, or at least everyone it has taken over.

title: Campaign Memo; Gore, Mum on Reform, Raises $700,000
description: Perhaps it was best not to call attention to the incongruity. Vice President Al Gore has been trumpeting his ''passion'' for overhauling the campaign finance system, even while scooping up money and emerging from the primary season as the richest candidate in the race.

title: Out of the Mouths of Babes: Wirelessly
description: IMAGINE a junior high school cafeteria anywhere in America, clamorous with juvenile jokes, jabs and gossip as cafeteria fare and brown-bag meals are gobbled up and chased down with soda and chocolate milk.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  WUNSCH, DORIS
description: WUNSCH-Doris, on March 22, 2000 at the age of 72. Beloved wife of the late Harry. Loving mother of Debra and James Frank and Peter and Janet Wunsch. Proud grandmother of Alicia. Contributions in her memory may be made to the Huntington Breast Cancer Action Coalition or Commack Dollars for Scholars.

title: Drug Therapy for Preschoolers
description: The increase in the number of preschool children being prescribed Ritalin, Prozac and other psychiatric drugs in the last decade is troubling and cries out for closer scrutiny. Thus it was heartening that the Clinton administration said this week that it would conduct two research projects to address questions related to the use of such powerful drugs by the very young.

title: U.S.T.A. Sponsors Free Lessons
description: Billie Jean King did not start playing tennis until she was 11 years old and got free lessons at a public park in Long Beach, Calif. The United States Tennis Association thinks her experience is one worth repeating.

title: Cytec May Sell Paper Unit
description: Cytec Industries Inc. said today that it was exploring options for its paper-chemicals unit, including a possible sale, as part of a plan to increase profit by focusing on faster-growing businesses. Cytec said its paper-chemicals business had sales of about $100 million last year. The unit makes chemicals used in paper towels, tissues and other types of paper. Cytec, based in West Paterson, had sales of $1.4 billion last year. Its stock was down 18.75 cents in trading yesterday, to close at $29.4375.

title: Nets Can't Match Up, And Hornets Pour It On
description: If the Nets were not engaged in a daily battle for the eighth and final playoff spot in the National Basketball Association's Eastern Conference, it might be easy to write off their lackluster defensive effort against the Charlotte Hornets tonight as typical of a team impatient for the season to wind down.
