title: SWISS INQUIRY ON UKRAINE
description: The Swiss Federal Banking Commission said it was looking into Credit Suisse Group's role in alleged diversions of International Monetary Fund loans by Ukraine's central bank in 1997 and 1998. A commission spokesman said it would receive a report soon on whether funds were deposited at Credit Suisse First Boston, the bank's investment arm. The Swiss regulator will also receive the results of a Ukraine central bank audit done at the I.M.F.'s request by PricewaterhouseCoopers. Credit Suisse and the Ukrainian authorities have denied any wrongdoing. Elizabeth Olson (NYT)

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  KLEMPERER, PETER
description: KLEMPERER - Peter. Beloved husband of Judith. Father of Jerusha and Ethan, son of the late Helen and George Klemperer, brother of Fred Klemperer. Passed away on March 21, 2000. Born June 20, 1945, Peter was a graduate of the MIT Class of 1966. He devoted most of his professional life to managing health care for the underprivileged of New York, serving for many years as a Vice President of the New York Health and Hospitals Corporation. Peter was also a prominent antiquarian book dealer and collector, widely recognized as an authority on New York City history. His intellect, wit, and ethic of selfless commitment to his family, his community and his many colleagues and friends will be long remembered. Service Thursday, 10AM, at Central Synagogue, 123 East 55 Street.

title: America's Medal Hopefuls Stand Out in a Crowd
description: If members of the United States Alpine team rode horses instead of skis, Daron Rahlves and Kristina Koznick might be considered white knights. The connotation comes with good reason -- although part fun and part serious.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  ROUNICK, JACK A.
description: ROUNICK-Jack A. Born November 14, 1926. Of New York, Easthampton and Miami, passed on Monday, March 20, 2000 in Miami, Fla. after a long illness. Former President of Ma-Ro Hosiery and Rex Knitting Mills. Son of Max and Bessie Rounick and brother of the late Herbert Rounick. He is survived by sisters, Marjorie Blum and Eleanor Weiss and beloved sons, Scott, Christopher & Gustaf Rounick. He will be greatly missed. In lieu of flowers, please make contributions to your favorite charity. Funeral service will be held at the Independent Jewish cemetery in Sag Harbor, NY, Friday, March 24, 2000 at 1 P.M. Any inquiries can be made at Frank E. Campbell, 212-288-3500.

title: An Adventure Wears Its Art on Its Sleeve
description: IF system requirements were an accurate measure of a game's value, then France's latest contribution to the adventure game genre, Belisa Media's Isabelle, would be terrific. You need at least a Pentium 166, 32 megabytes of RAM and the latest version of DirectX.

title: Blunt Talk in India
description: President Clinton has paid his hosts in India the ultimate compliment this week. He has spoken to them candidly. Precisely because of the uneasy state of Indian-American relations, there was little to be gained from platitudes. In private meetings, public statements and a speech to Parliament yesterday, the president instead cut to the main point, emphasizing the vital importance of India's and Pakistan's turning back from their nuclear arms race and trying to resolve their differences peacefully. Indian leaders politely disagreed with much of what Mr. Clinton said. That was to be expected. But the exchange was healthy, and it could open the way toward progress in the future.

title: Stepfather Kills Himself After Son Is Found Dead
description: Hours after the police told him that the dismembered remains of his missing teenage stepson had been found in a park in Queens, a distraught man climbed to the roof of his house here early this morning, fired a rifle into the air and, when police officers arrived, begged them to shoot him.

title: Trial Lawyers Pour Money Into Democrats' Chests
description: Now that they have triumphed over the tobacco industry, trial lawyers have found a new target, Gov. George W. Bush, and they have been spending huge amounts of money from the tobacco settlement to keep him and other Republicans from being elected.

Also, the mower is doing all the work here -- the rolling forward, the backing up, the turn-on-a-dime maneuvering around the London plane tree. And, yes, the grass cutting.

title: Taiwan's President Is Expected to Quit Party Post Soon
description: Less than a week after the governing Nationalist Party was dealt a humiliating electoral defeat, President Lee Teng-hui has yielded to demands that he step down as chairman of the party, several senior party officials said tonight.

title: GUCCI PROFITS SURGE
description: Reflecting strong growth in the luxury goods industry, buoyed by lively sales in the United States and a revival in Japan, profits at Gucci Group N.V. soared almost 70 percent in 1999, to $330.3 million, on a 19 percent increase in revenue, to $1.24 billion. Profit in the fourth quarter rose 47 percent, to $97.7 million. John Tagliabue (NYT)

description: Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani's attacks this week on an unarmed black man shot dead by the police are causing bewilderment among members of his own party, who say they are concerned about Mr. Giuliani's temperament and the tenor of his United States Senate campaign against Hillary Rodham Clinton.

description: It is officially a personal pilgrimage. But as Pope John Paul II makes his first visit to Israel and the Palestinian territories, he also comes as a head of state who has sought to persuade leaders on both sides that he is a crucial temporal ally.

Brother of Mrs. Howard (Anne Puchir) Maher of Columbus, Ohio and Mrs. John (Margaret Puchir) Woodling of Whittier, California. Also survived by two grandsons, Michael Puchir Porter and Mark A.T. description: Shaheen Holloway remains questionable with a sprained ankle for Seton Hall's East Regional semifinal game against Oklahoma State tomorrow night, but the Pirates did have some other encouraging news yesterday.

title: It's O.K. to Cry if You Win, But Sweating Is Simply Forbidden
description: When the Oscars are telecast on Sunday evening, some people will be ogling the clothes, others will be waiting to poke fun at the musical numbers and still others will be analyzing the new stage set. The show's new producers, Lili and Richard Zanuck, said that this year they wanted a new look for the millennium. Out with the interpretive dance numbers (whew!) and in with lighting and colors that will make women look absolutely gorgeous. You may want to achieve this effect at home, but sketches for the new set are being kept under tight security. Some of those involved in making the millennium come to the stage of the Shrine Auditorium, however, did agree to reveal their thinking.

title: No More 'Pssst!' For Iranian Rugs, But Who Cares?
description: THE 13-year-old import embargo on Iranian rugs is lifting, but that doesn't excite anyone at the Bloomingdale's store in Manhattan.

title: Study Finds Violence Against Journalists Increasing Worldwide
description: Violence against journalists increased last year, as combatants around the world increasingly focused on reporters as unwelcome witnesses to war crimes and other abuses, a group that advocates press freedom said today.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  POSNER, IRWIN
description: POSNER-Irwin. The Board of Directors and staff of UJA-Federation of New York note with sadness the passing of Irwin Posner, a cherished friend, and a major supporter of our mission. In addition to Chair of the UJA-Federation Yonkers General Campaign, Irwin was a member of our Westchester General Campaign Cabinet, Vice President of the Jewish Council of Yonkers, and a member of the Board of the Westchester Jewish Conference. Our deepest sympathies go to the entire family. May you be consoled among the mourners of Zion and Jerusalem. Judith Stern Peck, Board Chair James S. Tisch, President Barry Effron, Chair, Westchester General Campaign John S. Ruskay, Exec. VP & CEO

title: Ross Russell, 90; Recorded Charlie Parker
description: Ross Russell, who recorded Charlie Parker on his small independent jazz label, Dial Records, and wrote a biography of Parker as well as a book on the history of Kansas City jazz, died on Jan. 31 at a hospital in Palm Springs, Calif. He was 90.

title: Despite Rescue Attempt, Man Dies in Harlem Fire
description: A man was pulled from a burning apartment in Harlem last night by firefighters but died later of smoke inhalation, fire officials said.

title: It's Poetry Slams And Slam-Dunks For Etan Thomas
description: Etan Thomas writes verse well enough to hold his own at poetry slams on the South Side of Syracuse. An entrepreneurship major, Thomas was picked by a Syracuse academic fraternity as one of eight outstanding men on campus. It's fitting that what he does best on the basketball floor reflects this mix of art, confrontation and science: Thomas blocks shots.

title: COMPANY BRIEFS
description: CHASE MANHATTAN CORP., New York, the second-largest bank in the United States, will split its stock three shares for two and raise its quarterly dividend by 17 percent. The split is scheduled for May 17 if approved by shareholders at the bank's annual meeting on May 16.

title: Transit Agency Receives Good Marks in Survey
description: Nearly 80 percent of the 18,000 passengers on New Jersey Transit trains who took part in a survey last year said they were satisfied with the railroad's service, the agency said yesterday.

title: Study Finds Gaps in Internet Content
description: THE past year has seen no shortage of studies that try to describe, explain and propose fixes for the digital divide, the gulf that lies between those who have computers and access to the Internet and those who do not.

title: CyberPatrol Sues Hackers Who Broke Into Filter Program
description: Another battle has flared in the war over the use of Internet filters. A few weeks ago, a group of self-described hackers broke into a filtering program called CyberPatrol and then posted their code-breaking program on the Web. CyberPatrol sued, claiming that its copyright had been violated.

title: Pope Tells Palestinians of His Empathy, but Words Go Untranslated
description: In his speech here today, Pope John Paul II articulated a more empathetic understanding of the hardships of refugee life than many Palestinians had heard for quite some time.

title: THE MARKETS: CURRENCIES
description: DOLLAR IS MIXED. The dollar was little changed on expectations that inflation will be kept in check. In New York, the euro settled at 96.02 cents, down from 96.41 on Tuesday. The dollar traded at 106.90 yen, down from 106.93.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  ROHTSTEIN, SANDRA
description: ROHTSTEIN-Sandra. On Wednesday, March 22. Of Fort Lee, NJ, formerly of Hull, MA. Loving mother of Eliot C. Nisenbaum and his partner Ronald Sandberg of Fort Lee, NJ and Risa Nisenbaum of Boston, MA. Dear sister of George and Dena Rohtstein of Chestnut Hill, MA. Sister-in-law of Harvey and Sylvia Nisenbaum of PA. Devoted daughter of the late Hyman and Belle (Wexler) Rohtstein. Services are private. Remembrances may be made to Columbia Presbyterian Hospital, NY or to a charity of your choice. For information contact The Levine Chapel, Brookline, MA.

title: Detective in Fatal Shooting Is Said to Be Misjudged, Too
description: In a week of characterizations by people who hardly know him, Anthony Vasquez, the police detective who shot and killed an unarmed man on a Midtown Manhattan street last week, has been portrayed by some as hot tempered, quick to draw his gun to resolve a problem.

title: Anti-Hacker Software
description: To the Editor:

title: VIRATA, A CHIP MAKER, TO PURCHASE SOFTWARE COMPANY
description: The Virata Corporation, a maker of chips for Internet-access equipment, agreed to buy the closely held Inverness Systems Ltd. for about $114.9 million in stock. Virata will pay 850,000 shares. Inverness Systems's software is used in communications and networking. The company is based in Kfar-Saba, Israel, and Jerusalem and has 30 employees. Shares of Virata, based in Santa Clara, Calif., rose $10.625 each, to $135.125, in Nasdaq trading.

title: For Simplifiers, a 7-Step Program
description: ON O2Simplify, a Web site devoted to streamlining daily life, there is a guide to planning a New Year's Eve party that contains 62 tips, not one of them ''Buy more tequila.'' There is also a guide to starting a rock band that includes 18 hints like ''Obtain your instrument, learn the basics'' and ''Don't forget tuning!'' Clearly, the online simplification industry has a ways to go before it is ready to offer the public a truly indispensable product.

title: Researchers Trace Roots of the Irish and Wind Up in Spain
description: For any observer of last week's St. Patrick's Day celebrators who wondered where all those Irish came from, science has provided an unexpected answer: Spain.

title: E.P.A. Asked To Crack Down On Discharges Of Cruise Ships
description: Fifty-four environmental organizations from New York to Alaska asked the Environmental Protection Agency yesterday to develop tougher regulations for monitoring and controlling waste discharged by cruise ships.

title: NASHUA AGREES TO BUY RITTENHOUSE, A RIVAL PAPER MAKER
description: The Nashua Corporation, a maker of specialty paper and printing products, agreed yesterday to buy a closely held rival, the Rittenhouse Paper Company, for as much as $63 million. Nashua will pay $57 million in cash plus as much as $6 million more if Rittenhouse, based in Chicago, meets cash-flow levels. Rittenhouse makes paper for automated teller machines, cash registers and labels. Shares of Nashua, based in Nashua, N.H., rose 75 cents each, to $10.0625, in New York Stock Exchange trading.

title: Glory Days of the Incline, Before the Decline
description: WHEN you go by funicular -- half elevator, half train -- getting there is most of the fun.

title: ELECTRONIC DATA SYSTEMS PLANS TO BUY BACK ITS STOCK
description: The Electronic Data Systems Corporation, the second-biggest United States computer services company, said yesterday that it planned to buy back as many as 9.5 million common shares this year to help finance its employee stock plans. The buyback would cost $665 million, based on the E.D.S. closing price yesterday, and represents about 2 percent of the outstanding shares. The company's shares rose $3.625 each, to $70, on the New York Stock Exchange.

title: Publicis Increasing Cyberspace Presence
description: Publicis S.A. in Paris is hoping to enhance its presence in cyberspace through moves that will include an investment of up to $387 million in Web-related communications businesses and an alliance with the management consultant Ernst & Young and the computer services company Cap Gemini S.A.

title: Ex-Radical Cites 'System' in His Defense
description: The man once known as H. Rap Brown has not explained his actions on the day when the police say he shot to death a sheriff's deputy. But his lawyer has already begun his defense: ''The system'' conspired to frame his client.

title: Boston Herald Selects an Agency
description: The Boston Herald in Boston, which is owned by publisher Patrick J. Purcell, said yesterday that it had named Hill, Holliday, Connors, Cosmopulos in Boston, part of the Interpublic Group of Companies, as its agency of record. The account, with undetermined billings, had been handled in-house for the last 13 years. Mr. Purcell said the decision came without a review.

title: Bear Hunt Is Proposed to Reduce Numbers
description: A few years ago, black bears had all but disappeared from New Jersey. Now there are so many -- 1,000 -- that yesterday the state's Fish and Game Council proposed a bear hunting season, which would be the first in the state since 1971.

title: CONSULTING FIRM TO INVEST $300 MILLION IN GARTNER GROUP
description: The technology consulting firm Gartner Group Inc. said yesterday that it would receive a $300 million investment from the venture capital firm Silver Lake Partners L.P. Gartner, based in Stamford, Conn., said it would use the money to repay debt and pay for business initiatives. Shares in Gartner rose $5.50, to $21, on the New York Stock Exchange. The investment by Silver Lake, Menlo Park, Calif., will be in the form of convertible debt. If converted into common stock, the investment would give Silver Lake 20 to 25 percent of Gartner. Gartner also acquired 90 percent of the privately held TechRepublic Inc. for $80 million in cash. TechRepublic, based in Louisville, Ky., operates a Web site for information technology professionals.

title: Interpublic's changing of the guard replaces a senior statesman of advertising with a veteran.
description: JOHN J. DOONER JR., the McCann-Erickson World Group executive who helped triple the size of the agency company and initiated a creative turnaround at its flagship agency, was officially named yesterday to succeed Philip H. Geier Jr. as chief executive of McCann-Erickson's parent, the Interpublic Group of Companies.

title: Palestinians Given Own Internet Domain
description: March 22, 2000

title: Audio Across the Sexes
description: To the Editor:

title: Ex-Chairman of Aetna to Get $3.4 Million
description: Aetna Inc., whose share price has fallen 35 percent in the last year, is paying its former chairman and chief executive, Richard L. Huber, $3.4 million to $3.6 million in severance, a regulatory filing said.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  CONNELLY, ALBERT RAY
description: CONNELLY-Albert Ray, died March 22, 2000, in his 92nd year after a long illness. Retired partner of Cravath, Swaine & Moore. Husband of the late Eleanor Milburn Connelly. Survived by his daughters, Mary C. Graff of Urbanna, VA, and Jean C. Mooney of Healdsburg, CA, by his granddaughters, Clare Mooney and Alexandra Mooney, and by a great-grandson, Henry Mooney. Services at St. James Church, Madison Ave. at 71st St. on Saturday, March 25, 2000 at 11AM. Contributions in his memory may be made to Berkshire School, Sheffield, MA 01257, for addition to the Albert R. Connelly Scholarship Fund.

title: Paid Notice: Memorials  GITTLEMAN, IRWIN
description: GITTLEMAN-Irwin. Three years and your wit and wisdom lives forever in my heart. Kid sister Phyllis.

title: Corrections
description: Because of an editing error, a front-page article on Sunday about the presidential election in Taiwan misstated the name of the province formerly governed by James Soong, who finished second in the election. It is Taiwan Province, not Taipei Province.

title: Oh, It's You Again
description: To the Editor:

title: Chip Index Was Higher in February
description: The semiconductor industry association's book-to-bill ratio, which gauges demand for chip-equipment tools made in the United States, rose in February for a fifth month to 1.41.

title: Mah-Jongg Memories
description: To the Editor:

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  KONING, URSULA
description: KONING-Ursula, age 85 of Port Washington, L.I. on March 20, 2000. Loving and much beloved mother of Thomas, Peter and Laurie, Andrew and Gretchen, Christopher and Pamela, Paul and Patricia. Devoted grandmother of nine grandchildren. Adored sister of Rena Schellong. Reposing at Austin F. Knowles, Inc. Funeral Home, 128 Main Street, Port Washington. Visiting Saturday 11:30 A.M. to 12:30 P.M. Funeral Service is at 12:30 P.M. Interment is private. She will be deeply missed.

title: Is Simplicity a Grand Illusion Or Grand Plan?
description: DRESSED a la Hepburn in a tight gray sleeveless dress that exposed the pumped-up biceps of a serious career gal, Susan Wyland sat at the edge of her living room sofa. She didn't touch the coffee and snacks she had set out on a tray in front of us. Instead, Ms. Wyland, the managing editor of Real Simple, a new magazine from Time Inc., fantasized about her ideal reader, described in a press release as ''today's overextended, overcommitted, overscheduled woman'' in her 30's and 40's.

title: Oil Producers' Loan Program Falling Short On Takers
description: A federal panel designed to offer subsidized loans to independent gas and oil companies whose business suffered when prices were low has received nearly two dozen applications for loans, the Department of Commerce says.

title: AIDS in South Africa
description: To the Editor:

title: U.S. Is Offering Record Amount In Sex-Bias Suit
description: The federal government agreed today to pay $508 million to settle a sex discrimination suit brought by 1,100 women who charged that they were denied jobs and promotions with the agency that disseminates news and information about the United States abroad.

title: A Videotape of Lennon and Ono, And a Bid for a Documentary
description: More than nine hours of videotape of John Lennon and Yoko Ono shot in February 1970 by Tony Cox, Ms. Ono's former husband, has come to light. Its new owners, a New England consortium of Beatles collectors who bought the video from Mr. Cox, say that they would like the tape to be the basis of a documentary about this turbulent moment in Lennon's career.

title: Windows Lost And Found
description: Q. Sometimes I accidentally move a window off the screen on my Windows 98 system and can't get the mouse cursor on it to drag it back and close it. Is there any way short of rebooting to get that window back?

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SCHNEBERG, BEN
description: SCHNEBERG-Ben. On March 21, 2000. Devoted husband of Esther. Dear father of Willa. Cherished uncle of Joan Stoller. Mr. Schneberg earned a Masters degree and was a graduate of Brooklyn College and CW Post College and was the oldest librarian hired by the Brooklyn Public Library. Service today 1 PM, ''Parkside'' Memorial Chapel, 2576 Flatbush Avenue, Brooklyn, NY (Near Avenue V).

title: Gas Prices Are Rising, but Not the Tempers, Yet
description: This is not the gasoline shortage of the 70's.

title: Flat Panel Display Prices Are Expected to Drop
description: Thin is in, again. After rising in 1999 in the aftermath of the Asian economic crisis, prices for flat-panel displays are going to fall steeply this year and next as supplies increase, according to speakers at the DisplaySearch Flat Panel Display conference this week in Austin, Tex.

title: POPE, AT A CAMP, DEPLORES PLIGHT OF PALESTINIANS
description: Describing the plight of Palestinians in refugee camps as ''degrading'' and ''barely tolerable,'' Pope John Paul II today blended his pilgrimage to the Holy Land with a stop in Palestinian-controlled Bethlehem that was, in everything but name, a state visit.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SEIDEMAN, EMANUEL (MANNY)
description: SEIDEMAN-Emanuel (Manny), at age 83, after a valiant struggle. A compassionate man filled with humor, kindness and optimism. Survived by his loving wife, Ruth of 62 years. Dearest respected father to Ellen and Larry, Barbara and Peter, Lisa and Charles; most adored grandfather to Michael, Bonnie and Brad, Wendy and Stewart, Abby, Zachary and Todd; affectionate great-grandfather to Jake. We all love you and you will be missed. Services Thursday, 12 Noon, at Schwartz Bros.-Jeffer Memorial Chapels, 114-03 Queens Blvd., corner 76 Road, Forest Hill.

title: Travel Web Site Puts Real Flight Times Online
description: Getting timely information about airline flights used to mean calling an 800 number and suffering through a long period on hold. Even then, arrival and departure times were often already out of date.

title: Wishing Hard for a Smooth Return Flight
description: Joe Kegler and Karen Roy were heading yesterday to Orlando for a short Disney World vacation, but as they waited to check in at the US Airways counter at La Guardia Airport they worried how they would get back home to Connecticut on Sunday if the airline shuts down in a labor dispute.

title: Architecture With Nature in Mind
description: Recent Architecture

title: CANADIANS RAISE RATES
description: Canadian interest rates have been raised by one-quarter of a percentage point, matching increases by the Federal Reserve and United States banks. The Bank of Canada raised its rate for loans to the banking system to 5.25 percent, and banks followed with increases in their prime lending rates to 7 percent. Timothy Pritchard (NYT)

title: Met Opera's 2000-1 Season
description: The Metropolitan Opera's 2000-1 season will offer the company's first performances of Busoni's ''Doktor Faust'' and Prokofiev's ''Gambler,'' as well as new productions of Beethoven's ''Fidelio'' and Verdi's ''Nabucco'' and ''Trovatore.'' Details of the season were released yesterday.

title: Sports of The Times; Right Man Is a Winner While Losing
description: IT is not as if Elton Brand hadn't dealt with losing before he joined the Chicago Bulls, and it became as involuntary a habit as a nervous twitch. In his 21 years and 12 days, Brand roughly estimated that he must have dropped at least 15 games.

title: Corrections
description: A film review yesterday about a documentary playing at the Walter Reade Theater at Lincoln Center reversed the words of the title at one point. It is ''Fragments: Jerusalem.''

title: Relief for Subway Victim's Family, but a Sense of Duty, Too
description: There was, of course, relief and satisfaction -- though tempered by sadness -- but the family of Kendra Webdale felt something else as well yesterday: a sense of duty.

title: Japanese Terrorist Case Inspires Accusations Against Lebanon
description: The arrangements that saw four members of the Japanese Red Army terrorist group flown back to face charges in Japan last weekend after they had failed to obtain asylum here have stirred protests among left-wing and Arab nationalist groups here that have accused the Lebanese government of double-dealing.

title: Adapter for Playing MP3 Files Impersonates a Cassette Tape
description: Technophobes, take heart. You may not have to surrender your beloved tape decks in the face of the MP3 revolution.

title: Barkley's Mother Wants Him to Stay
description: St. John's Erick Barkley met with Coach Mike Jarvis again yesterday to discuss his future, and although the point guard has still not made his decision official, it is almost certain that he will enter the National Basketball Association draft.

title: Corrections
description: An article on Monday about the National Rifle Association's clash with President Clinton over gun control misstated the surname of an association board member who has been critical of Wayne LaPierre, the group's executive vice president. He is Neal Knox, not Fox.

title: CONECTIV TO SELL TWO HEATING AND COOLING SUBSIDIARIES
description: Conectiv, a utility based in Wilmington, Del., said yesterday that it would sell Conectiv Services, which provides heating and air-conditioning services, and Conectiv Thermal, which runs heating and cooling systems. Company officials valued Conectiv Services at $50 million and Conectiv Thermal at $130 million. The company also said it would build a second $300 million, 550-megawatt power plant in addition to one announced late last year. The plants will be able to burn either natural gas or oil. Conectiv's shares rose $1 each, to $16.3125.

title: Team, Once Cut, Lights Up a Campus
description: The Sooners' team bus rounded the corner to the Lloyd Noble Center, on campus in Norman, Okla. In the dreamy blackness of 4 a.m., the players and administrators were still numb from their upset over Purdue, the defending women's champion.

title: In Search of Ways to Heal a Child
description: To the Editor:

title: Turks Debate Human Rights And Links With Europe
description: Three months after Turkey was offered a chance to join the European Union, the country is caught up in a fervent debate over whether it should make the profound political changes necessary for membership.

title: Twinkie Strike Afflicts Fans With Snack Famine
description: Seldom in the course of labor negotiations does the half-life of junk food come to the forefront. But in the dispute between the maker of Twinkies and the Teamsters, the longevity of the beloved snack adds urgency to the issues.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  ROCHE, EDWARD P.
description: ROCHE-Edward P. Born July 11, 1928 in the Bronx, NY. He grew up in Saint Margaret's Parish in Riverdale and graduated from Manhattan Prep. Mr. Roche served as a paratrooper with the 188th Parachute Infantry Regiment of the US Army, receiving an honorable discharge. Mr. Roche attended Manhattan College. He worked in the sales department of Lindenmeyer Paper Corporation for over forty years. Upon retirement in 1993, Mr. Roche moved from Scarsdale, NY to Spring Lake, NJ. He had been a summer resident of Spring Lake since 1970. Mr. Roche is survived by his wife Carol, sons Edward and Kevin, daughter-in-law Phyllis, two sisters, Patricia Cheetham and Helen Fries, brother James Roche, and numerous nieces and nephews. In lieu of flowers, donations can be made to the Spring Lake First Aid Squad. Visitation Thursday, 2-4 and 7-9 at Meehan Funeral Home, Spring Lake Heights, NJ. Funeral mass 11:00AM, Friday, St. Catharine's R.C. Church. Burial at St. Anne's Cemetery, Wall, New Jersey.

title: Japan Remains at Odds With U.S. on Telephone Deregulation
description: After two days of meetings, the United States and Japan failed to reach any agreement today on further deregulation of the telecommunications market here and extended their talks to a third day.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  KRAUSE, ANN
description: KRAUSE-Ann, of Douglaston, NY, on March 20 at her home. Predeceased by her husband Saul & son James. Funeral services Friday, March 24, at noon at Gutterman's of Woodbury, 516-921-5757.

title: Bonuses for Teachers
description: To the Editor:

title: Expert Says Iraq Got Bomb Data From U.S.
description: A former high-ranking official in Iraq's secret nuclear weapons program says that before the 1991 Persian Gulf war, Iraqi students in the United States combed university libraries for bomb-building information, and Iraqi agents and scientists collected valuable data at American scientific conferences.

title: Terms of Khmer Rouge Trials Still Elude U.N. and Cambodia
description: A team of United Nations negotiators left Cambodia today after failing again to reach agreement with the government on the ground rules for a trial of the surviving leaders of the Khmer Rouge.

title: Comptronix Insider Trading Penalty Set
description: The Comptronix Corporation's founder and two others agreed this week to pay a total of $470,000 in financial penalties to settle inside-trading charges.

title: Fox TV President Is Resigning, Despite 'Malcolm' Comedy Hit
description: Doug Herzog, the former cable executive recruited by Fox to bring some innovation to the network's programming, resigned yesterday after slightly more than a year as president of Fox Entertainment.

title: Insanity Defense Fails for Man Who Threw Woman Onto Track
description: A jury yesterday rejected the insanity defense of Andrew Goldstein, the schizophrenic man who threw a woman to her death in front of a subway train last year, finding him guilty of second-degree murder.

title: NO STUDENT VETO FOR CAMPUS FEES
description: The Supreme Court ruled today that public universities can collect student activity fees even from students who object to particular activities, as long as the groups given the money are chosen without regard to their views.

description: Republicans in Congress would love to reap political advantage from the recent surge in gasoline prices, but they are so divided over what to do that they cannot act decisively.

description: Sites and Events This Week

title: Using Trash as Text; Class at N.Y.U. Looks for Deeper Meaning at Fresh Kills
description: This is the landscape of urban legend. Yes, there are rats the size of cats. No, they are not afraid of humans. No, there are no bodies here. Not that anyone knows of, that is.

title: A Design Center Holds Up a Mirror To Itself and Asks, 'Whither?'
description: The Oscars are the high point for the movie industry each year, and WestWeek, starting Wednesday, is the annual focus of interior designers and architects here. But the three-day market has had a bumpy ride, as has the Pacific Design Center, inset right, its home. Designed by Cesar Pelli, the two buildings form a landmark. But they have never filled up with tenants and have a dismal, mall-like interior with few stylish showrooms.

title: Subtlety Instead Of a Samba Suite
description: The second album by Virginia Rodrigues, one of the most impressive new singers to emerge from Brazil in recent years, is dedicated to the music of Carnival in her native city of Salvador de Bahia, during which scores of electric trios play from the tops of trucks while dancing throngs follow them through the streets.

title: Enjoy Your New Software, and Check Out the Advertisements
description: WITH product offers popping up all over America Online and flashing banners festooning practically every commercial site, online advertisements are virtually impossible to duck. While that is hardly a revelation, what is more surprising is that advertising has found its way into software -- into programs you pay for as well as free programs.

title: Mexico to Raise Oil Output, but Tells U.S. Not to Be Pushy
description: Joining the frenetic jockeying before an oil producers' meeting next week, Energy Minister Luis Tellez said today that Mexico had decided on an oil production increase of less than 325,000 barrels a day starting in April.

title: Steinbrenner Is Unhappy at Any Time of Day
description: The squad of security personnel lingered on the first floor of Legends Field late Tuesday night, long after the Yankees had lost for the 11th time in their past 12 exhibition games. The detail cannot leave until George Steinbrenner, the principal owner, has departed from the building, and Steinbrenner was still in the fourth-floor offices as midnight approached, demanding answers from General Manager Brian Cashman.

title: Council to Call for Tax Cut Weighted to Help the Poor
description: The City Council, answering Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani's $2 billion tax cut package, intends to propose exempting poor people from the city's income tax and giving a much larger tax cut to the middle class.

title: In America; The Police in Crisis
description: The evening was cold, wintry, and the hundreds of people making their way to the Bethel A.M.E. Church on 132nd Street in Harlem were upset. Another unarmed black man had been shot dead by the police and almost before his body hit the sidewalk the mayor and the police commissioner were rummaging through court records in search of dirt to smear him with.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  BRABEC, ERVIN J.
description: BRABEC-Ervin J. Passed away March 22, 84 years old. Beloved husband of Claire for 37 years. Proud father of Todd and Jeff (Randye). Brother of Irene Madura and brother-in-law of Mae Rose Brabec. Former executive of MCA and Madison Square Garden and President of Marketing Concepts, Inc. Mass of Christian Burial to be held on Saturday, March 25 at 11AM at St. John the Evangelist Church, 348 East 55 Street.

title: A New Sort of Gala, A New Breed of Ballet
description: The Ballet Tech Company opened its five-week season at the Joyce Theater on Tuesday night with a gala that said a lot about the company and its director, Eliot Feld. There were few of the usual bored gala patrons in attendance, if any. The Champagne was for everyone.

title: Building Workers Threaten a Strike
description: Members of the union representing doormen, porters and maintenance workers voted last night to authorize a strike if their leaders do not reach an agreement with the owners of 3,000 apartment buildings in New York City by April 20.

title: PC Shuffle: Order and Reorder
description: RAPID change and premature obsolescence have always been hazards for computer shoppers, but the pace has escalated in the last few months. The processing speed of new Windows-based computers has doubled in the past year, lurching forward every few weeks and outpacing the ability of some personal computer makers to build and ship their top-end models before a faster chip arrives.

title: Babes in Electronic Toyland
description: Note: This lesson was originally published on an older version of The Learning Network; the link to the related Times article will take you to a page on the old site.

description: With bay views of sea gulls, seals and sailboat regattas, a wooded peninsula here named Deadman's Island seemed just right for luxury condominiums, tailored for one of Canada's hottest real estate markets.

title: Paid Notice: Memorials  LEVICK, RONALD E.
description: LEVICK-Ronald E. April 26, 1929 to March 23, 1998. Always loved, never forgotten. Love, your family

title: Corrections
description: An article in Science Times on Tuesday about children with obsessive compulsive disorder misidentified the class of drug to which Anafranil belongs. It is a tricyclic antidepressant, not a selective serotonin reuptake inhibitor or S.S.R.I.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  GORDON, DOROTHY ROFFMAN
description: GORDON-Dorothy Roffman. At 95, on March 21, 2000. Beloved wife of the late John J. (Jack) Gordon. Survived by daughters, Mae Shievitz (Art) and Ronny Widener (Michael); 4 grandchildren, Toby, Michael, Scott and Pamela; and two great-grandchildren, Stephen and Johnathan. Services private.

title: Coke's Black Employees Step Up Pressure To Resolve a Racial Discrimination Lawsuit
description: At a rally this month, black employees held empty Coke cans aloft outside an Atlanta church to protest Coca-Cola's treatment of blacks. A similar rally is scheduled for Saturday. And when Coca-Cola holds its annual shareholder meeting in Wilmington, Del., on April 19, many of the company's current and former black employees plan to travel to it by bus convoy to make a statement about their frustrations at the company.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  MCCAFFREY, IRENE B.
description: McCAFFREY-Irene B. March 15. Wife of the late Francis J., former State Senator of New York. She is survived by her brothers James O'Hara, Richard O'Hara and Vincent O'Hara; four children, Francis Jr., Joan Patton, David and Susan; and four grandsons, Francis, Joseph, Luke and David. Upon graduation from Cathedral High Shool on Park Avenue in 1939, she worked for the BBC and the War Relief Fund. She received her BS from Fordham University in 1944 and her law degree from Fordham University School of Law in 1948. She was one of three women in a class of 110. She later received her BA in History and Literature, graduating Magna Cum Laude from the College of Mount St. Vincent, and in 1997 she studied at Oxford University. Irene worked for the Youth Service Agency for the City of New York under Mayors Wagner, Lindsay and Beame, and as Deputy General Counsel for the Human Resources Administration for the City of New York during the Koch administration. Memorial donations for cancer research may be made payable to Columbia University, C/O Dr. Gregory Mears, Room 932, Columbia Presbyterian Hospital, 161 Fort Washington Ave., New York, NY 10032.

title: A Sitcom in a Precinct With Inventive Brutality
description: Capt. Madeleine Dunleavy is a police chief America could love to hate. Played by the sharp and sophisticated Elizabeth Perkins, the last person you might have ever expected to see in a sitcom, Madeleine has, let's say, a strong sense of self.

But the ball landed in the hands of Elton Brand, thwarting a fast-break opportunity and making Coach Jeff Van Gundy wince.

title: Corrections
description: An obituary on Tuesday about Herman B Wells, former president of Indiana University, referred incorrectly to an athlete he had urged the university to recruit. Bill Garrett, who played basketball for Indiana in 1948, was not the first black player of a varsity sport at a Big Ten college. Conference records give that distinction to Julian Ware, who played basketball for the University of Wisconsin from 1900 to 1902.

title: THE MARKETS: Market Place; So much for the theory that old-economy stocks are finally regaining their place in the sun.
description: EARLY last week, the technology-rich Nasdaq composite index plunged, while the Dow Jones industrial average surged. That brief move led to chatter about the resurgence of the old economy and investors' sudden preference for value stocks, which trade at low multiples of their profits and sales, over high-growth technology stocks. Skeptics, who have watched the Nasdaq soar higher in disregard of traditional stock valuations for years, were especially excited that the market was returning to its senses.

title: After Diabetes Drug, New Questions for the F.D.A.
description: When a drug is declared unsafe and taken off the market, as the diabetes drug Rezulin was on Tuesday after reports of liver failure and death, several questions inevitably arise: Should the drug have been approved in the first place? If it did belong on the market, might the harm it caused have somehow been avoided?

title: NBC in Space.com Deal
description: The NBC television network said yesterday that it had acquired a minority stake in the closely held company Space.com, which provides news about space over the Web and is headed by the former CNN news anchor Lou Dobbs. In the agreement, NBC will pay a combination of cash and television advertising time on its TV network for its Space.com stake. It did not disclose financial details. NBC will gain rights to Space.com's content through the pact and will pursue promotion, marketing and content distribution with Space.com.

title: Clinton Implores India's Legislators to Shun Nuclear Arms
description: Before leaving politics behind and heading out to tour India's heartland, President Clinton laid out a picture of the world today in which this nation would have the ''ability to shape the character of our time'' by renouncing its nuclear weapons.

title: Princeton Considers Smoking Ban, but Taverns Vow to Fight
description: It is all but certain that a local health panel will make Princeton Borough and Township the first localities in the New York metropolitan region to outlaw smoking in almost all public places, including bars and restaurants. But tavern owners are promising not to give up their smokers without a legal battle.

title: Gentlemen, Merge Your Manufacturers; Consolidation Hits on Virtually All Cylinders
description: The consolidation of the global auto industry has reached a full-throttle roar as automakers around the world respond to the changing economics of the business.

description: PEOPLE who live in glass houses are few and far between.

title: Beside the Bay, Reimagining Jazz
description: Saturday night's jazz concert at the Masonic Auditorium was something New Yorkers could get jealous about. The saxophonist Wayne Shorter, a sphinxlike figure who has turned increasingly to large-scale composition and rarely appears in small-group jazz settings that are worthy of him, played the saxophone. Quite a lot.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  BINA, HARABANIT RACHEL
description: BINA-HaRabanit Rachel. March 22, 2000. Jerusalem, Israel. American Friends of Yeshivat Hakotel mourns the passing of HaRabanit Rachel Bina, beloved wife of HaRav Aryeh Bina zl, and mother of HaRav Aharon Bina, Rosh HaYeshiva. Rabanit Bina was truly an Ayshet Chayil, leaving a profound and lasting impression on all who knew her. Her legacy is embodied in the spirit and learning of countless talmidim worldwide. May all the members of the Bina family be comforted among the mourners of Zion and Jerusalem. American Friends of Yeshivat Hakotel

title: NEWS SUMMARY
description: INTERNATIONAL A3-13

title: Finding Jobs for Welfare Clients
description: The battle over New York City's welfare-to-work program escalated yesterday when City Comptroller Alan Hevesi rejected the largest contractor for the program on grounds that it had been selected through negotiations flawed by cronyism and favoritism. Mayor Rudolph Giuliani retorted that the talks had been fair and lawful, and his office said he would sue to force Mr. Hevesi to approve the contract. The legal issues will need to be sorted out by prosecutors and the courts. Meanwhile a more fundamental struggle is under way, between the mayor and the City Council, over the best way to guide workfare clients into permanent jobs.

title: 2 More Titles in Cincinnati
description: Two major titles were decided on Sunday, the final day of the American Contract Bridge League's Spring Nationals in Cincinnati. The Women's Swiss Teams was won by Linda Lewis of Las Vegas; Valerie Westheimer of Manhattan; Hjordis Eythorsdottir of Huntsville, Ala.; Judy Wadas of Chicago; and Karen Barrett of Vancouver, Wash. Second was a team of players who have many world titles: Kathie Wei-Sender of Nashville, Tenn.; Juanita Chambers of Schenectady, N.Y.; Betty Ann Kennedy of Shreveport, La.; Jill Levin of Riverdale, in the Bronx; Janice Seamon-Molson of Miami; and Tobi Sokolow of Austin, Tex.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SZOKE, ELIZABETH
description: SZOKE-Elizabeth, age 91, died March 15th, 2000 after a short illness. Mrs. Szoke was a retired language teacher at Riverdale Country School in the Bronx. Born in Hungary, she moved to the U.S. in 1939 along w/her husband Stephen and daughter MaryAnn. She is survived by a grandson, Daniel Porcher, of Hopewell, NJ and two great-grandchildren, Rachel and Adam. A memorial service will be held on Saturday, March 25th, 2 PM, at Friends Meeting House on E. 15th St., NYC. In lieu of flowers, donations to the American Friends Service Committee.

title: And on the Fifth Day, Mets Will Rely on Rusch
description: The Mets named Glendon Rusch their fifth starter today, but the other contenders had known for a while who would win the job.

title: Kazimierz Brandys, 83, Dies; Wrote of Poland's Discontent
description: Kazimierz Brandys, a prolific novelist and diarist who began his career as a promoter of Socialist Realism in Poland and ended it in exile in Paris, died here on March 11. He was 83.

title: 4 Hospitalized in Upper Manhattan Melee
description: In an outburst of mayhem in Upper Manhattan yesterday, a man stabbed a store manager in an argument, was himself attacked and stabbed by angry passers-by, then drove his car into two pedestrians and the storefront, the police said.

Brother-in-law of Douglas Nadler. Robbie graduated the Mamaroneck Special Education System in 1990. He will be remembered as a happy soul who did not back down from adversity. title: MANAGEMENT-LED GROUP MAKES BUYOUT OFFER FOR U.S. CAN
description: The U.S. Can Corporation said yesterday that an investment group led by the company's chairman had offered to buy it for $21 a share, or about $282 million. The offer, made by the chairman and chief executive, Paul W. Jones, and Berkshire Partners, based in Boston, is 41 percent more than Tuesday's closing price. The shares rose $4.9375 each, to $19.8125. U.S. Can, based in Oak Brook, Ill., was formed in a leveraged buyout in 1983 of the can-making business of the Sherwin-Williams Company, based in Cleveland. U.S. Can, which had $714 million in sales last year, formed a committee to evaluate the offer.

description: HANFLING-Nathan. Congregation Machane Chodosh mourns the passing of its beloved member Nathan Hanfling, who was, and always will be remembered as a man of piety and goodness, modesty and generosity. We express our deepest sympathy to his bereaved wife, Felicia, and to his family. May Hashem grant them an abundance of comfort. Manfred Gans, Rabbi Herbert Jaffe, President

title: Senate Backs End to Penalty On Earnings in Retirement
description: The Senate voted 100 to 0 today to remove limits on how much money most Social Security recipients can earn without losing part of their retirement benefit, reflecting the politically potent combination of an aging population and a strong economy.

title: Checketts Tries to Talk Rangers Down From the Ledge
description: Dave Checketts already had today penciled on his calendar to take a limousine to Rangers practice. The Madison Square Garden president wanted to speak to the players about the Garden's charity, Cheering for Children.

title: Andersen Consulting to Aid Employees
description: Andersen Consulting, the world's largest consulting firm, said this week that it would invest $200 million in electronic-commerce companies this year and distribute the proceeds to employees.

title: Tricked Into Opening Door, Women Are Sexually Attacked
description: Two young women were sexually attacked in their Brooklyn Heights apartment Tuesday night after opening the door to a woman who said she was seeking the apartment's owner but was followed inside by two armed men, the police said yesterday.

title: The International Pastime?
description: First John Rocker, now Mark McGwire? McGwire, the home run champion, struck some as xenophobic when he criticized Major League Baseball's decision to open this year's regular season in Japan, with two games next week between the Mets and the Chicago Cubs. ''I have nothing against anybody else in another country,'' McGwire said. But he added: ''This game belongs here. People come to America, they come here to watch our game.'' He blamed greed as the league's motivation.

title: COBALT NETWORKS IS BUYING CHILISOFT FOR $70 MILLION
description: Cobalt Networks Inc. agreed yesterday to acquire the privately held software developer ChiliSoft Inc. for $69.9 million in stock. ChiliSoft, based in Bellevue, Wash., makes software used to create Web pages that use databases. Cobalt, based in Mountain View, Calif., makes appliances that link multiple computers to the Internet. The appliances are used by businesses, Internet service providers and schools to provide Internet access. With ChiliSoft software, Cobalt users will be able to use common Web development programs with Cobalt's appliances. Cobalt had $22.8 million in revenue last year and has a market value of $1.8 billion. Its stock closed at $60.9375, up 18.75 cents.

title: PubliCard Business Shift
description: PubliCard Inc., a maker of ''smart card'' software and readers, said yesterday that it would discontinue some businesses, including card making, to focus on products that allow people to shop online through their television sets. PubliCard said it expected to raise $25 million from selling its smart-card manufacturing business, as well as its unit that makes coin-metering products used in commercial laundry machines and its disk duplication operations. Smart cards hold embedded chips that store personal or financial data.

description: The head of the emerging markets business of Credit Suisse, the European banking giant, said yesterday that his institution engaged in unusual transactions on behalf of Ukraine's central bank, but he maintained that all of them were legal and were undertaken only at the central bank's request.

title: Still Producing Riddles, Still Profoundly Opaque
description: Some artists are provoking enough over a long career that any turn they make, however brash or subdued, is of interest. Jasper Johns, 70, who has a series of new works on view at the Yale University Art Gallery, is such an artist.

title: A Wise Ruling on Campus Fees
description: By a surprisingly lopsided margin, the Supreme Court this week rejected an effort by conservative Christian law students to prevent the use of their student activities fees to support groups whose views they find objectionable. The 9-to-0 decision against the students was a ringing and heartening affirmation of the right of universities to establish forums for the free exchange of contending ideas as part of the educational process. It also dealt at least a temporary setback to groups intent on ''defunding the left'' and on pushing universities in a more conservative direction.

title: A Wagner Teaser With Familiar Faces
description: The Metropolitan Opera's much-anticipated presentation of Wagner's ''Ring des Nibelungen,'' the first of three complete cycles, officially begins tomorrow afternoon. But it got off to an early start on Wednesday night with an extra performance of the first of the four operas, ''Das Rheingold.''

title: JUSTICE OFFICIALS BEGIN AN INQUIRY INTO WHITE HOUSE
description: The Justice Department has begun a criminal investigation into whether White House officials illegally suppressed large numbers of e-mail messages subpoenaed in investigations of Clinton administration campaign fund-raising and other activities, documents filed in federal court disclosed today.

title: With Sugar And Spice, And Ravioli Eaten Cold
description: The title of ''All I Wanna Do'' tells you nothing at all about the movie except, by inference, that it's for and about teenagers. Like ''She's All That,'' ''Down to You'' and ''Whatever It Takes,'' this innocuous, intermittently charming coming-of-age comedy has been given a name that refers to nothing at all, evokes no particular associations and is likely to be forgotten shortly after you leave the theater.

title: Texas Pursuing Seventh Title
description: Troy Dumais won the 1-meter springboard and the 400-meter medley relay team collected a title last night as Texas took a 22-point lead over defending champion Auburn after the first day of the men's N.C.A.A. swimming and diving championships in Minneapolis.

title: INSIDE
description: Making Ours Look Cheap

title: The Wee Small Hours
description: New York has a reputation for never sleeping, but it can be surprisingly difficult to find a restaurant that's up past midnight. Here are 12 places that stay open to satisfy late-night cravings. (These summaries are taken from dining reviews, columns and articles in The Times by William Grimes, Eric Asimov and others.)

title: Still Never Having to Say You're Sorry
description: ''Here on Earth,'' with its shameless sob story on teen loss, is the Best Movie of 1961, lacking only the beautiful and vacant visages of Troy Donahue and Suzanne Pleshette to make it complete. A pair of teens finally find each other and fall in love, only to learn -- sob -- that she's dying of cancer: it could be called ''Love Story, Too.''

title: ELI LILLY SAYS IT WILL BUY BACK UP TO $3 BILLION IN STOCK
description: Eli Lilly & Company said yesterday that it would buy up to $3 billion of its stock, its largest repurchase ever. Its shares have fallen 24 percent this year, in part because of weaker sales of its antidepressant Prozac. Under the plan, Lilly could buy about 47.2 million shares, or 4 percent of its 1.09 billion shares outstanding, based on Wednesday's closing price. Lilly, based in Indianapolis, rose 81.25 cents, to $64.375.

title: MBNA EXPANDS IN IRELAND
description: The credit card issuer MBNA plans to more than double the size of its sales and data-processing operations in Ireland, opening a center employing 300 people in the rural western part of the country. The expansion will make the company, which is based in Wilmington, Del., one of the largest employers in rural Ireland. It runs a European services center in Dublin. Brian Lavery

title: Corrections
description: A report in the Compressed Data column of Business Day on March 13 about myCustoms.com, a new company, misstated a previous title held by a founder, Manoj Karamchandani. He was a systems manager for eBay, in charge of international Web site operations and technology, not a vice president.

title: A New Whitney Team Makes Its Biennial Pitch
description: THE 2000 Biennial at the Whitney is not, as you may have been led to believe, another ''Sensation.'' Relieved? Disappointed? The little pre-game flap over Hans Haacke's ''Sanitation'' may have created an impression that this Biennial would be akin to that Brooklyn exhibition or maybe to the Biennial in 1993, which was heavy on heavy-handed politics. But Mr. Haacke, it turns out, is the only artist among nearly 100 in the show whose work fits that bill. It is the most uncontroversial Biennial in years.

title: Retelling A Drowning Of 2 Boys Down South
description: Susan Smith, the South Carolina woman who drowned her two young sons in the local lake and tried to hide her crime by saying the boys had been abducted by a black man, is among the more pathetic of the last decade's celebrity criminals. Her tabloid Medea story is awful and squalid, and in reconstructing it in ''Down the Drain,'' the Adobe Theater Company, with a script by Stanton Wood, has mined it for both tragic resonance (understandably) and laughs (not). It's a misfire.

title: Iraq Builds Base for Rebels Fighting Iran, U.S. Contends
description: Iraq has spent tens of millions of dollars in recent months to build a military headquarters for an Iranian opposition group that the Clinton administration considers a terrorist organization, senior administration officials said today.

title: Ladies' Man, Pleasing And Teasing
description: There were shrieks and squeals of joy when D'Angelo finally took off his shirt during his encore at Radio City Music Hall on Monday night. With his pumped-up shoulders and chiseled abs, D'Angelo is one of the reigning sex symbols in rhythm-and-blues, singing respectful come-ons in a voice that can be sweetly imploring or insouciant and assured.

title: IPALCO AGREES TO SELL THERMAL SYSTEMS FOR $162 MILLION
description: Ipalco Enterprises Inc. agreed yesterday to sell the thermal energy systems owned by three of its units to Citizens Gas and Coke Utility for $162 million. Ipalco, based in Indianapolis, is the holding company for Indianapolis Power and Light. Ipalco said the systems being sold were the Perry K Steam Plant and downtown steam-distribution system operated by Indianapolis Power and Light, the central city chilled-water cooling and distribution system owned by Mid-America Energy Resources Inc. and chilled-water cooling services provided by Indianapolis Campus Energy. Citizens Gas and Coke Utility, which also is based in Indianapolis, is a public charitable trust that provides natural gas in Indianapolis and other parts of central Indiana.

title: John Mullen
Jean Howard, the House Photographer For Hollywood's Glamour Set, Dies at 89
description: Jean Howard, who rode the comet of her extraordinary beauty, ethereal glamour and insouciant intelligence to become a Ziegfeld girl, a Hollywood starlet, a legendary hostess and the house photographer of the film colony, died at her home in Beverly Hills, Calif., on Monday. She was 89.

title: After Months of Rancor, Speaker Names a Catholic Priest as House Chaplain
description: Seeking to quell a political and religious furor over the selection of the House chaplain, Speaker J. Dennis Hastert took to the House floor today and appointed, by fiat, a Roman Catholic priest who had not been in contention for the job.

title: Corrections
description: A front-page article on March 14 about opposition in Europe to genetically modified food attributed an assertion erroneously to Benedikt Haerlin, who leads a campaign against such food for the environmental group Greenpeace. While he attacked the conclusions reached by many scientists in the debate, he did not refer to scientists as liars.

title: John Paul's Mideast Journey
description: There has been a poignancy to the televised images of an elderly, enfeebled Pope John Paul II indomitably pressing ahead through windswept Masses and candlelit prayers on his pilgrimage to the Holy Land this week. But the impression of infirmity belies the nimbleness he has shown in making his way through one of the most complex and combustible corners of the world. John Paul has skillfully blended the sacred and the secular in a delicate balancing act. The only disappointment has been his reluctance to acknowledge more explicitly the Vatican's failure to confront the Holocaust.

title: Bad Things (Losses, Losing Seasons) Come in 3's
description: Before the season, Dave Checketts, president of Madison Square Garden, was asked if he thought the Rangers, fresh off an off-season spending spree, were a playoff team. Checketts answered yes.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  PLACZEK, ADOLF
description: PLACZEK-Adolf. Colleagues at Avery Library and Columbia University mourn the passing of Dolf Placzek, Avery Librarian, teacher and scholar. Dolf's passion and dedication to Avery Library are a lasting contribution to architectural scholarship. We extend our deepest sympathies to his widow, Beverley, his family and his many friends. He was a role model for many, beloved by all and he will long be in our memory. Contributions can be made to the Adolf Placzek Memorial Fund for Classic Architectural Books in Avery Library.

title: Cowboys Plan to Keep Pirates From Shooting
description: Doug Gottlieb of Oklahoma State was asked whether age and experience would help his veteran Cowboys against the young and injury-depleted Seton Hall Pirates here on Friday night in the semifinal of the East Regional of the National Collegiate Athletic Association basketball tournament.

title: Signs in Grisly Killing Point to Bias and Stepfather Who Killed Himself
description: From the Social Security number written in black marker on a human skull found on Tuesday in Alley Pond Park in Queens, detectives had little trouble concluding that 19-year-old Steen Fenrich had fallen victim to a twisted murderer.

title: Latest Battle With Virus To Be Fought In Backyards
description: Until last summer, the presence of mosquitoes in and around New York City was about as consequential as the presence of pigeons -- and far less obvious. Then came West Nile, a mosquito-borne virus that killed seven people in the metropolitan region, caused brain infections in 62 others and prompted widespread spraying of insecticides in the city and its suburbs.

title: The Mets Begin Their Journey as Time Travelers
description: The clocks displaying Tokyo time were the first reminders. Then came the four shelves of bottled water added to the clubhouse refrigerator this morning. But it is hard to prepare for the unknown, and there is a certain amount of trepidation as the Mets leave for their season-opening two-game series with the Chicago Cubs in Japan.

title: Survey Finds Subways Are Hurt by Success
description: After two years of rosier opinions about the condition of the city's subways and buses, riders gave the transit system a harsher assessment last year -- calling it slower, less reliable, less safe, more crowded and even smellier, according to a survey of riders conducted by the Metropolitan Transportation Authority.

description: Marina Shurina, a 25-year-old underemployed lawyer, sat in a small, spare room with white walls and empty shelves, waiting for voters to call about the campaign of Ella Pamfilova, one of the 11 people, and the only woman, running in Russia's presidential election on Sunday.

description: Opening a new window into the mysteries of animal design and the nature of life, biologists described here today how they had decoded almost the entire genetic rule book for making the Drosophila fruit fly, an organism whose study is deeply interwoven with the progress of modern biology.

title: Spartans Rally Past Orangemen
description: For all of the first half and the beginning of the second, Michigan State's sharp-shooting left-handers, Charlie Bell and Morris Peterson, had barely been heard from. Their lack of presence showed on the scoreboard as Syracuse was poised not only to upset the top-seeded Spartans tonight, but also to thoroughly outplay them. Bell and Peterson had combined for a total of 8 first-half points.

title: Knicks Look to Johnson to Start Making Shots
description: For one strong two-minute span Wednesday night, Larry Johnson looked like his old self, even his pre-Knicks self. Attacking the rim with power and effectiveness, he used his strength and maneuverability to hit three consecutive shots and score 6 straight points against the Chicago Bulls. His final basket was especially impressive, coming on a short running hook over Elton Brand.

description: The Federal Nuclear Regulatory Commission accused both Consolidated Edison and its own staff yesterday of mishandling an earlier inspection of the Westchester nuclear plant that leaked radiactive steam last month.

title: Sex Out of Sight but Not Mind
description: ''A Pornographic Affair,'' one of the two movies that open the New Directors/New Films festival at the Museum of Modern Art tonight, may shock you, but not necessarily for the expected reasons. It concerns the relationship of two anonymous, respectable people (Nathalie Baye and Sergi Lopez) who spend each Thursday afternoon in a Paris hotel room doing something that dare not speak its name. If you're anticipating the next ''Last Tango in Paris,'' think again. ''A Pornographic Affair'' is more like ''When Harry Met Sally'' remade as a panel discussion on the highfalutin French talk show ''Apostrophe.''

title: Police Internal Affairs Duty Is Unpopular, a Survey Shows

title: Paid Notice: Memorials  GERMAIN, LAWRENCE
description: GERMAIN-Lawrence, 9th Anniversary. Precious memories, my husband Lawrence. Passed away March 24, 1991. Lord, I know you are always busy, for you have many things to do, but when sorrow overcomes me, well I need to talk to you. For I lost my husband Lawrence, he is with you up above. He is someone that I needed and someone that I loved. I would like to say so many things, I don't know where to start, I only know I miss you Lawrence from the bottom of my heart. When I'm sad and lonely and everything goes wrong, I seem to hear you whisper, cheer up and carry on. Meet me in my dreams, Lawrence. Talk to me once more. Ease this everlasting pain that makes my heart so sore. I know you walk beside me and when my life is through, I pray that God will take my hand and lead me straight to you. I'll put my arms around you and kiss your smiling face, then the pieces of my broken heart will fall back into place.

title: At Yad Vashem, Pope Tries to Salve History's Scars

title: Taiwan Calm, So China's Bid for Entry Into Trade Group Gains
description: A rare burst of moderation on both sides of the Taiwan Strait has fortified proponents of granting China permanent trading rights in the United States as a Senate committee formally took up the trade measure today. Administration officials said prospects for passage had improved.

title: CABLE COMPANIES GET CLOSER
description: Canada's two largest cable companies -- Rogers Communications Inc. and Shaw Communications Inc. -- have agreed to swap some assets and merge Internet operations, escalating their war with the telephone utilities for supremacy in electronic commerce. An exchange of some of their cable holdings makes Shaw, based in Calgary, the dominant cable operator in western Canada, while Rogers, based in Toronto, consolidates its hold in the central and eastern parts of the country. The two will also combine Internet divisions, providing a single national portal. Timothy Pritchard

title: RUSSIA SEEKS DEBT TALK EXTENSION
description: Russia has asked the Paris Club of creditor governments for a three-month extension of the deadline of March 31 for it to conclude negotiations with individual countries on the restructuring of debt payments due in the last two years, the Russian deputy finance minister, Sergei Kolotukhin, said. Last summer, Russia reached an agreement with the Paris Club to reschedule over 15 years the $8 billion it owed in 1999 and 2000. Russia owes about $38.6 billion in Soviet-era debt that it would like to restructure. Russia is negotiating with each Paris Club member state about what it owes that country, but the talks have proceeded slowly. Neela Banerjee

Next will be Michael Mann's ''Insider,'' to be released on April 11, then Sam Mendes's ''American Beauty,'' available on May 9 (but don't expect the DVD until fall). Warner plans Frank Darabont's ''Green Mile'' for early summer. Lasse Hallstrom's ''Cider House Rules'' is to arrive in June or July. All but Mr. Darabont are nominees for best director.

title: CHILE ENTERS RECESSION
description: Chile's economy contracted 1.1 percent in 1999, despite the country's reputation as South America's leading beneficiary of market-oriented economic changes. Sluggish prices for copper, Chile's main export, combined with contagion from financial crises in Brazil and Southeast Asia, contributed to the decline in gross domestic product. It was Chile's first recession since the early 1980's. Simon Romero

title: Cobbling Together This Really Cute Young Band

The show constructs from scratch a new group called O-Town, with cameras capturing auditions that pare down the applicants to the eight chosen at the end of tonight's premiere. Over the next weeks they will compete for the five slots in the band, and O-Town will be ready to record, make money and appear on MTV.

title: WEEKEND WARRIOR; On a Roll After Midnight, When Every Lane's a Fast Lane
description: It's 3 o'clock in the morning, I'm in Greenwich Village and I am bowling. I am also doing so in the dark. Cradling an iridescent blue ball, I stare down toward a set of multicolored, glow-in-the-dark pins. Red lights border my lane like airport runway beacons, and ceiling-mounted ''black'' lights render the world in dark shapes and electric whites. I float along, fueled by pitchers of Samuel Adams and waves of rhythmic dance music. I am feeling it, I am on fire, I am in the bowling zone.

title: BP DEAL WITH PETROCHINA
description: The world's thirdlargest publicly traded oil company, BP Amoco P.L.C., said it would buy a stake in the PetroChina Company and form a joint venture with the Chinese concern to sell natural gas. BP Amoco said it planned to take 20 percent of the shares being offered in PetroChina's initial public offering, up to a maximum value of $1 billion. The China National Petroleum Corporation is selling a 10 percent stake in PetroChina. China is ''an immensely important market for us,'' said John Browne, BP Amoco's chief executive. The two companies will form a joint venture to acquire or build gas stations and to supply gas to the city of Shanghai.

title: ALBUM OF THE WEEK
description: DO MAKE SAY THINK: ''Goodbye Enemy Airship the Landlord Is Dead'' (Constellation). One of the original intents of rock 'n' roll, and later punk and now indie rock -- that whole series of basement rebellions since the 1950's -- has been to show up the professionals. But at a certain point, naivete isn't enough. Charming technical limitations become insurmountable walls, and applying amateurish rock technique to more complicated music seems contrary to the point, or not worth the effort.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  KLEMPERER, PETER
description: KLEMPERER-Peter. The management and staff of Greater New York Hospital Association deeply mourn the passing of Peter Klemperer. Peter was one of our most brilliant and trusted advisers on the full range of financial, reimbursement, and strategic issues facing the hospital community. He was also our valued friend. He thought and cared deeply about how to improve health care for all New Yorkers, but particularly the poor and uninsured, and his ideas and work have helped shape health care delivery in New York City. Peter was a gentle soul who was blessed with intellectual gifts that commanded the highest respect of his colleagues. We extend our deepest condolences to his wife, Judith, and children Jerusha and Ethan, and to our colleagues at the New York City Health and Hospitals Corporation, for the loss of this very special person. Gladys George, Esq., Chair Kenneth E. Raske, President Greater New York Hospital Assn

title: BAUSCH & LOMB MAKES BID FOR WESLEY JESSEN
description: Bausch & Lomb, the maker of contact lenses, made an unsolicited offer of $600 million in cash yesterday to acquire Wesley Jessen VisionCare, a specialty lens manufacturer. The offer came just three days after Wesley, based in Des Plaines, Ill., proposed buying Ocular Sciences, a big Bausch rival, for $413 million, a move that would create the world's second-largest soft contact lens maker. The offer by Bausch, based in Rochester, was $34 a share. Wesley Jessen's stock surged almost 34 percent yesterday, up $8.5625, to $33.4375. Bausch's stock fell 87.5 cents, to $55.50, and Ocular dropped $1, to $16.25.

title: PRIME HOSPITALITY AGREES TO BUY LEASES FROM SHOLODGE
description: The Prime Hospitality Corporation, owner of the AmeriSuites and Wellesley Inns hotel chains, agreed to buy the leases of 27 Sumner Suites hotels from ShoLodge Inc. and convert the hotels to AmeriSuites. ShoLodge said it expected to receive $54 million in cash at the purchase's closing and $3 million in rent payments later for the 27 hotels. Under the deal, Prime Hospitality said it would buy ShoLodge's interest in a lease for 20 hotels owned by Hospitality Properties Trust. ShoLodge said it would sell four hotels to another owner who would lease them to Prime. And ShoLodge will lease three hotels it owns to Prime. Prime will also buy land in Mount Laurel, N.J., and Sterling, Va., from ShoLodge to build AmeriSuites properties.

title: The Ghosts of Idealism And an Obsessive Love
description: Keith Gordon's painfully earnest screen adaptation of Scott Spencer's novel ''Waking the Dead'' grasps at a fusion of historicism and heartbreak that we normally expect to find in sprawling Hollywood epics, not in interior psychological dramas like Mr. Spencer's novel. But in falling short of its goal, the movie raises the question of whether it's possible to film an intelligent tear-jerker that prompts us to think and cry at the same time. Or are serious suds and serious ideas a cinematic oxymoron? At its best, ''Waking the Dead'' suggests an intellectually upscale answer to ''Love Story.'' At its weakest, it comes off as a stiff, muted exercise in countercultural nostalgia.

title: Editorial Notebook; Biennial 2000 at the Whitney Museum

Their comments on contemporary art are placed on the wall in a typeface that is meant to recall the dictates of the Third Reich.

Board and writing a Hebrew column for the Nat'l magazine, to United Jewish Appeal where she served as co-chair of Greater New York Women's Division and on the Speakers Bureau, to the founding and support of Jewish Education with her husband: Shenkar Textile College in Israel, the Lilian & Ben Marcus pre-school in Jerusalem and the David Posnack School in Florida. She served on the New York Board of Jewish Education, the America-Israel Cultural Foundation, CLAL, the Hillcrest Jewish Center. All who knew her respected her intellectual ability and generosity of self. A lady of grace, dignity and elegance who filled our lives with love and beauty. She will be missed because she is irreplaceable. May G-d bless and keep both Lilian and Ben. May their souls be bound up in the Book of Life. title: Paid Notice: Deaths  GREENE, LEE A.
description: GREENE-Lee A., 90, of Lawrence, NY. At University Hospital at Stony Brook, Tuesday, March 21, 2000, following by less than 9 months the death of her beloved and adoring husband of 66 years, Dr. Barnett Greene. Devoted mother of the late Stuart and his wife, Sherry, and of William and his wife, Beverly; grandmother of Douglas, Stephanie and Bradley and of Ilyssa, David and Lauren. Daughter of the late Samuel and Sadie Adelman and sole surviving sibling of David, Frances and Milton. Lee loved her father for ''his kindness, his loving disposition, his concern and generosity to his family and his intelligence'' and her mother for ''her devotion to her family and her great sense of humor.'' She was the embodiment of both-an Arista student at Girls' High School, a graduate of Hunter College, an outstanding public elementary school teacher and reading specialist in Brooklyn, a hard working and creative member and officer of Hadassah, and a disciplined, funny, temperate person who listened well and spoke even better. She became and remained the ''modern woman'' while retaining fundamental values of family, friendship and decency. Above all, she was Barney's partner, in marriage and in life-in the sacrifices during the Depression to support his education and early career, in the loving raising of their sons while he was in the European theater in World War II and while both she and he became and remained consummate professionals. Barney, and especially Lee, gave to their children security, morality, ambition and goals and offered the wisdom to use them wisely. But many will remember her and Barney for their partnership in ballroom dancing that was so emblematic of their lives-for 60 years, on and off the dance floor, they moved in unison, with precision, grace and superb timing; with attention to detail and appearance; and with love and enthusiasm. A woman of valor, her family and friends are devastated at their loss. Funeral services will be held at 1:30 PM Sunday, March 26, 2000 at Boulevard-Riverside Chapels, 1450 Broadway, Hewlett, New York (516-295-3100). Shiva will be observed and the family will receive visitors at the family's home in Lawrence. Please call the funeral home for details. Donations may be made to the Woodmere Chapter of Hadassah or to the American Heart Association, Nassau or Suffolk Chapters.

title: INTERNATIONAL SPECIALTY RAISES ITS OFFER FOR DEXTER

In January, International Specialty, based in Wayne, N.J., a maker of chemicals, mineral products and filters, made an unsolicited bid to buy Dexter for $45 a share, or $933.4 million. Dexter, based in Windsor Locks, Conn., rejected the offer as inadequate. Late last month, however, Dexter, a maker of materials used in aerospace and other applications, consented to let International Specialty and other third parties view its financial records. Dexter's shares rose $3.6875, to $51. International Specialty's shares were up 12.5 cents, to $6.125.

The company said it would sell Mobil's 49 percent stake in more than 315 stations in Austin, Dallas and San Antonio to Tetco Inc., Mobil's partner in the venture that owns the stations. 7-Eleven Inc. agreed to buy Mobil's stakes in 7 Dallas-area service stations plus 3 stations in the Fort Worth area. Mobil's supply contracts in Houston and Bryan-College Station, representing about 102 stations, will go to the closely held Petroleum Wholesale Inc.

title: MetroStars Search for Right Mix For Climb Up the M.L.S. Ladder
description: The upgrading of the MetroStars was the top priority of Major League Soccer for its fifth season. But it appears that the league fell short of its goal, because the MetroStars are still not on the 12-team league's top tier.

title: Budget Rift, Not a Chasm
description: This year's partisan battle over the federal budget, which lurched forward early today when the House narrowly passed a Republican tax-and-spending blueprint, has a familiar ring.
