title: Director Named At 92nd Street Y
description: Hanna Arie-Gaifman, a pianist and music administrator who has directed several cultural organizations in Prague, has been appointed director of the 92nd Street Y Tisch Center for the Arts. The position involves overseeing the Y's classical and popular music programming as well as the activities of the Unterberg Poetry Center. Frederick Noonan, director of the Y's musical programs, and Karl Kirchwey, director of the poetry center, are to continue to direct their departments.

title: Gore Goes to Bush Country to Raise Cash for Democrats
description: Vice President Al Gore cannot count on Texas for electoral votes in November, but he can still bank on it for Democratic money.

title: Man Admits Fraud in Joining CD Clubs Thousands of Times
description: For the second time since November, a New Jersey man has pleaded guilty to defrauding mail-order music clubs of thousands of compact discs by using false names and addresses to exploit the clubs' introductory offers.

title: A Pilgrim, Not a Pawn
description: The pope's visit to the Holy Land seemed to be a game of political football, with both the Israelis and the Palestinians claiming he was rooting for their team.

title: Barkley's Decision Is Expected Today
description: Erick Barkley is expected to tell Coach Mike Jarvis today whether he will return to St. John's for his junior year. The decision will come just four days after the sophomore point guard caught Jarvis by surprise when he brought an agent with him to speak with Jarvis about his future.

title: CANADIAN AIRLINES GETS PROTECTION
description: Threatened with legal action by one group of creditors, the Canadian Airlines Corporation has been given protection under Canada's federal Companies Creditors Arrangement Act while Air Canada, the carrier's new owner, guides Canadian Airlines toward a financial restructuring. Earlier, a group of American financial institutions had asked an Alberta court to force Canadian Airlines to repay $184 million owed in principal and interest on secured notes. The airline responded by seeking court protection from creditors, under a Canadian law similar to Chapter 11 of the United States Bankruptcy Code. Timothy Pritchard

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  KITROSSER, MOLLY
description: KITROSSER-Molly. In Madison, CT, March 24, 2000. Molly Kitrosser, wife of the late Jerome R. Kitrosser. Mother and mother-in-law of Richard and Helen Kitrosser of Madison. Grandmother of Daniel Kitrosser of Guilford, CT, David and wife Jennifer Kitrosser of Exton, PA. Funeral and burial in Riverside Cemetery, Lodi, NJ. c/o Guilford Funeral Home, 115 Church Street, Guilford, CT.

title: SURVEY OF TROOPS FINDS ANTIGAY BIAS COMMON IN SERVICE
description: Antigay remarks and harassment are commonplace in the American military, especially in the form of offensive speech and gestures, and an overwhelming majority of service members believe their superiors and colleagues tolerate it ''to some extent,'' according to a Pentagon survey released today.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SCHAPIRA, LEE
description: SCHAPIRA-Lee. On March 17, 2000, age 93. Beloved wife of the late Harold, devoted mother of Alexander and mother-in-law of Doris, dear grandmother of Joan. Services private.

Alexander and David Pertsemlidis and Bailey, Stephen and Eliza Whiteman.

description: With its best player sitting on the bench in street clothes, Seton Hall's improbable tournament run ended in dramatic fashion tonight.

title: Kennedy Defeats St. Raymond's
description: Saying it was doing its part to shatter the public schools' inferiority complex against Catholic schools, Kennedy of the Bronx emerged a 52-49 upset winner over St. Raymond's of the Bronx last night in a Class A semifinal of the State Federation boys' basketball tournament at the Glens Falls Civic Center.

title: Polita Grau, 84; Headed Effort On Behalf of Cuban Children
description: Polita Grau, a member of a prominent Cuban political family who helped to spirit thousands of children out of Castro's Cuba, which later jailed her for nearly 14 years as a C.I.A. conspirator, died on Wednesday at a nursing home in Miami. She was 84.

title: Still So Earnest After All These Years
description: Love and loneliness, causes and reminiscences all converged on a wistful serenity when Joan Baez performed on Thursday night at the Bowery Ballroom. Quietly finger-picking her acoustic guitar while her band whispered its accompaniment, Ms. Baez sang about the dignity of humankind, the perfidy of individual men and the longing for home in a voice that suggested a poised compassion for all her characters.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  CREMMINS, DENNIS
description: CREMMINS-Dennis. On March 21, 2000. Beloved husband, father, brother and friend. Through music, humor, concern and sheer love, the ''plant man'' made all of our lives richer. We vow to ''keep it real.''

title: Off-Target Duke Is Latest No. 1 To Get Dismissed
description: In a tournament full of upsets, another giant fell tonight. Duke, a top-seeded team and winner of 26 straight games in the East Regional since 1986, was suffoctaed by Florida's full-court trapping defense and lost by 87-78 in the regional semifinals of the National Collegiate Athletic Association men's basketball tournament at the Carrier Dome.

title: Corrections
description: A front-page article on Wednesday about a lawsuit by the estate of the painter Francis Bacon in Britain's High Court included three names erroneously among those cited. As the article reported, Bacon's estate is suing Marlborough International Fine Art, which represented him. The suit argues that it defrauded Bacon and his heir. The suit also names Marlborough's London gallery and the estate of Marlborough's founder, Frank Lloyd. Although the court papers mention Mr. Lloyd's son, Gilbert (a Marlborough director), and two other directors -- the Duke of Beaufort and Gilbert de Botton -- they are not defendants.

title: A Victory As Knicks Hit Road In Neutral
description: Hours before their departure for the West Coast, the Knicks were in search of a send-off complete with a Champagne-bottle christening and celebration streamers last night.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  MARCUS, LILIAN KAPLAN
description: MARCUS-Lilian Kaplan. Beloved wife of the late Ben S. Marcus, devoted mother of Judith (Alan) Chyten and Ina Ross, adored Sabta of Marc, Robin, Ricky, Kimberly, Stan, David and Jonathan. Treasured great grandmother of Eric Marcus and Lindsay Nicole Ross, Stephanie Elyse and Matthew Brian Pilavin. Sister of Dr. Louis Kaplan (and the late Esther Sabbah, Hannah Marcus, Dr. Nathan Kaplan). She was a woman of extraordinary intelligence and commitment: to her family, whom she nurtured and supported, to Hadassah, serving on the L.I. Board and writing a Hebrew column for the Nat'l magazine, to United Jewish Appeal where she served as co-chair of Greater New York Women's Division and on the Speakers Bureau, to the founding and support of Jewish Education with her husband: Shenkar Textile College in Israel, the Lilian & Ben Marcus pre-school in Jerusalem and the David Posnack School in Florida. She served on the New York Board of Jewish Education, the America-Israel Cultural Foundation, CLAL, the Hillcrest Jewish Center. All who knew her respected her intellectual ability and generosity of self. A lady of grace, dignity and elegance who filled our lives with love and beauty. She will be missed because she is irreplaceable. May G-d bless and keep both Lilian and Ben. May their souls be bound up in the Book of Life. Graveside services will be held at Beth David Cemetery, Elmont, NY on Sunday, March 26, at 2:30 PM. Shiva will be at the home of Ina Ross, 37 Somerset Drive South, Great Neck, NY

title: The Past, the Pit, the Plants; Togetherness in the Balkans
description: From the most raked-over historical fields to the latest technology, scholars and researchers continually manage to ask new questions, rethink old verities and produce fresh insights. Arts & Ideas takes an occasional look at what some of today's thinkers -- the established as well as those who yearn to be -- are working on. Some ideas may turn into breakthroughs and others may turn out to be dead ends, but the journey is rarely boring. Here is a handful of works in progress.

description: Pope Stays Above the Fray

title: Slacker and His Surprising Roommate
description: ''Idle Running,'' Janez Burger's portrait of Dizzy (Jan Cvitkovic), a lean, bearded Slovenian college student who whiles away his time smoking cigarettes, stoking himself with coffee and cheap liquor, watching television and playing cards with his friends, reminds us that you don't have to be American to be a slacker.

title: India Wins Battles in Its War on TB, but It Has a Long Way to Go
description: For a year, 10-year-old Chaitanya Pusa suffered from recurring fevers, a hacking cough and debilitating weakness. She saw healers who chanted mantras over her and private doctors who missed her real illness.

title: Talks at US Airways Go On Past Deadline
description: US Airways and its 10,000 flight attendants continued to negotiate as the deadline passed at 12:01 a.m. today. The airline had said it would suspend operations if no settlement were reached or if talks were not extended to avoid disruptions that the union had threatened. Passengers were awaiting the outcome nervously and trying to switch airlines.

description: GEORGE W. BUSH

description: INTERNATIONAL A3-8

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  KAHN, GEORGE
description: KAHN-George. March 22, in his 94th year. Beloved husband of Sylvia. Survived by his brothers, Herbert and Harvey, and sister, Sylvia Mann, & loving nieces & nephews. A very special person. Service Sunday, 11:30AM, ''The Riverside'', 76th and Amsterdam Avenue.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  GORDON, GUSTAVE G., M.D.
description: GORDON-Gustave G., M.D. At 87 years of age, after a long and courageous struggle with Parkinson's disease. Beloved husband of Adeline (Addy), adoring father of Miriam Gordon, Joanne G. Sampson, Leonore Gordon and daughter-inlaw Amina Rachman. Loving ''Papa'' to Matthew, Rachel and Joshua. Devoted son of the late Rose and Morris Gordon. Affectionate brother to Frances Berne, to sister-in-law Simme Klebanow, and the late Paula Diamond and Sylvia Rothman. Loving uncle and cherished friend and neighbor. Loved by all whose lives he touched. WWII veteran and a dedicated and compassionate physician. Services Sunday, 11:30AM at Sunset Chapels, 1285 Northern Blvd., Manhasset, L.I. Family requests that donations be made in his memory to the Parkinson's Disease Foundation, 710 West 168 Street, NY, New York 10032. He will live eternally in our hearts.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  STURZ, CONSTANCE NORTHRIDGE
description: STURZ - Constance Northridge. Devoted wife and high-spirited companion of Irwin Sturz, munificent friend and family member, a person in her own right: bold, curious, savvy-with mountainous courage. Passionate about politics, she died short of the 2000 election results, to her regret and all of ours. Memorial service are forthcoming.

title: A Scholarship Endowment Fund Is Created
description: The New York Times announced yesterday that it had established an endowment fund to support and supplement a college scholarship program it created last spring.

description: High anxiety has replaced great expectations in this capital, with people anticipating that President Clinton will arrive on Saturday not just to say hello, but also to deliver a scolding.

title: Showdown on Irish Pact in Today's Unionist Vote
description: The Northern Ireland peace agreement faces a showdown vote on Saturday as members of the Ulster Unionists decide whether to keep David Trimble as their leader or return their party to its harder-line past.

title: No Schoenberg? Let Me Out of Here
description: Jessye Norman was to have sung works by Ravel and Schoenberg in the first half of her concert at Carnegie Hall on Wednesday evening, and the second half was to be devoted to the premiere of an orchestral song cycle she commissioned from the composer Judith Weir with texts by the poets Maya Angelou, Clarissa Pinkola Estes and Toni Morrison. But during rehearsals with the Orchestra of St. Luke's, Ms. Norman decided to drop the works on the first half. Instead, the poets read their contributions and the pianist Ursula Oppens played selections from the ''Carnegie Hall Millennium Piano Book'' as interludes between the poems. Miss Weir's work was performed after the intermission.

title: 88 Million and Counting; Nintendo Remains King of the Handheld Game Players
description: The last month has redefined the video game business worldwide. In Japan, Sony sold nearly a million Playstation 2 video game consoles in the first two days on the market. And in California, Microsoft jolted the industry with the announcement of X-Box, a Windows PC masquerading as a video game console.

title: Clerk Is Stabbed in Neck At a Brooklyn Hospital
description: A clerk at the Brookdale Hospital and Medical Center in Brooklyn was stabbed in the neck while on duty yesterday by a woman who may have been a patient, the authorities said.

title: For Robinson, a Bright but Bittersweet Debut
description: Larry Robinson may have carried an empty feeling into his first game as the Devils' head coach, but he left with a sense of satisfaction after New Jersey thumped the Islanders, 8-2, to make his debut a resounding success.

title: XIRCOM STOCK TUMBLES ON POOR EARNINGS OUTLOOK
description: Shares of Xircom Inc., a maker of adapters that connect networks to portable personal computers, plummeted yesterday after the company said its second-quarter earnings would be well below Wall Street estimates. Shares of Xircom, based in Thousand Oaks, Calif., tumbled $4.50, to $36.50, in Nasdaq trading. Xircom said it expected to report earnings, excluding amortization of good will and other acquisition-related items, of 30 cents to 35 cents a share. Analysts surveyed by First Call/Thomson Financial had predicted earnings of 56 cents a share for the period.

title: Rendezvous With Mr. Assad
description: Syria's aging and autocratic president, Hafez al-Assad, does not travel abroad very often. His willingness to meet with President Clinton in Geneva tomorrow is a sign that he may be ready to return to peace talks with Israel.

description: BERNSTEIN-Sol. For all the history of grief, an empty doorway and a maple leaf. Five months alone. Barbar

title: Corrections
description: A Public Lives profile on Thursday about Rocky Aoki, founder of the Benihana restaurant chain, misstated the length of his probation in an insider-trading case. It is three years, not three months.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  RUBIN, LILLIAN
description: RUBIN-Lillian. Beloved wife of the late Louis Rubin. Adored mother, grandmother, great-grandmother. Loving friend to all who knew her. Went to her final rest in her ninety-seventh year. Rest in peace, Grammy. We loved you so much. Harriet, Buddy, Scott and Steven

description: Four musicians at the Apollo Theater in Harlem want a musicians' union to represent them in their work on ''Amateur Night at the Apollo.''

description: A teacher at a middle school in Harlem was arrested yesterday on charges that he sexually abused two 13-year-old female students, the police said.

description: The New York Times Company said yesterday that it was changing the name of its Internet business division to New York Times Digital from Times Company Digital.

title: Son Chosen to Run for Mother's Seat
description: Nassau County Democrats announced today that they had chosen Craig Johnson, a lawyer, to run for the seat in the County Legislature left vacant by his mother, Barbara J. Johnson, who died earlier this month of cancer. Republicans are expected to pick their candidate for the crucial race early next week.

title: Early Boulez as an Exercise in Mime
description: Maurizio Pollini has denied that his performance of a work will or should be influenced by its context in a program, but the Debussy Etudes in the first half of his concert at Carnegie Hall on Monday night seemed to be looking forward in terms of density and sheer speed to the work that was to come after intermission: Pierre Boulez's Second Sonata.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  MESNICK, SHELDON
description: MESNICK-Sheldon. March 23, 2000. Beloved husband of Elaine for 33 years. Devoted Dad of Mishie, Susan and Marcia and sonsin-law Greg, Sam and David and adoring Poppy of Joshua, Rachel, Mikey and Becky. Shelly's sweet smile, gentleness, enthusiasm, love and laughter will be a cherished memory for all who were touched by him. Funeral Sunday at 1:00 P.M. at Weinstein's Chapel, 1283 Coney Island Ave., Brooklyn.

title: EXXON FILES SUIT TO BLOCK ARCO'S ALASKA SALE
description: The Exxon Mobil Corporation, the world's largest publicly traded oil company, said yesterday that it had sued to block the sale of the Atlantic Richfield Company's Alaskan oil fields to the Phillips Petroleum Company. The lawsuit, filed yesterday in state court in Los Angeles, seeks a preliminary injunction that could delay the proposed $33 billion purchase of ARCO by BP Amoco. Exxon Mobil's suit is based on the company's right of first refusal to purchase certain ARCO Alaskan assets that are included in the sale to Phillips. The rights were given, Exxon Mobil says, in contracts and agreements dating to 1964. London-based BP Amoco and ARCO agreed last week to sell ARCO's Alaskan business to Phillips Petroleum for about $7 billion.

title: State TV Ties a Putin Rival To Jews, Gays and Foreigners
description: Russia's state-owned television has broadcast reports that the nation's leading liberal challenger to Vladimir V. Putin is supported by Jews, homosexuals and foreigners.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  KIRSHNER, JANET
description: KIRSHNER-Janet. One day before her 67th birthday a force of nature has left us too soon. She was the center of many people's lives. Husband Les, daughter Lizzie and her husband Andy, son Jonny & his wife Esty, grandchildren Matty, Jessie, Elie & Ari and her very large extended family of friends will miss her vital presence. Funeral services on Sunday, March 26, 9:30 A.M., at Schwartz Brothers, 114-03 Queens Boulevard, Forest Hills. In lieu of flowers, please make donation to your favorite charity.

description: The House passed a Republican budget blueprint early yesterday by a vote of 211 to 207. The nonbinding blueprint sets targets for spending and tax cuts for next year.

description: With two federal judges pressing Microsoft and the government to settle their antitrust case soon, Microsoft presented a formal written proposal today that would restrain some of the company's business practices, officials said.

description: KESSLER-Leonard. Suddenly, on Tuesday, March 21, 2000. Retired New York City high school teacher. Loving brother-in-law of Martin Remnitz and Philip Sears. Loving uncle of David and Stacey, Leslie, Alexandra and Benjamin Remnitz, George and Stuart Sears. Graveside funeral services will be held at Knollwood Park, Ridgewood, New York. On Sunday, March 26th, at 11 A.M. We love you and will miss you.

title: Slip-Free Pilgrimage
description: It was inconceivable that Pope John Paul II, as he glided serenely though the Holy Land on a personal pilgrimage and a secondary mission of interfaith healing, would transform a region characterized by divisiveness and hatred. Not even for a few days.

title: DOW CHEMICAL TO ACQUIRE GENERAL LATEX AND CHEMICAL
description: The Dow Chemical Company agreed yesterday to acquire the privately held General Latex and Chemical Corporation to expand Dow's reach in the polyurethane and latex markets. Financial terms of the deal, which is expected to close in the middle of the year, were not disclosed. General Latex, based in Cambridge, Mass., supplies compounds produced from latex and makes polyurethane products. It had $100 million in sales last year and has plants in Ashland, Ohio; Brampton, Ontario; Billerica, Mass.; Rancho Cucamonga, Calif.; Dalton, Ga.; and Charlotte, N.C. Dow Chemical, based in Midland, Mich., is one of the largest chemical, plastic and agricultural products companies in the world.

She has recorded some of the centerpieces of her repertory several times, but even when she repeats a work, she rarely repeats an interpretive idea. title: Hatred in Action
description: Ronald D. Rotunda, a law professor at the University of Illinois, was an ethics adviser to Kenneth Starr. The other day he made an extraordinary attack on federal judges in Washington. Writing on the op-ed page of The Wall Street Journal, he said judges appointed by President Clinton had dealt improperly -- politically -- with cases important to him. The headline was, ''Another Clinton Victim: The Integrity of the Federal Courts.''

description: The authorities acknowledged today that they had twice misidentified a man killed in a shooting on Thursday.

description: PAPKA-Claudia Rattazzi. Memorial service, Sunday, March 26th, 2PM at St. Paul's Chapel, Columbia University. In lieu of flowers, checks made out to the Fund can be sent to Columbia University, English Dept., attn: Joy Hayton, 602 Philosophy, 1150 Amsterdam Avenue, MC4927, NY, NY 10027.

title: Rating Agency Gives Nassau An Ultimatum
description: Under the threat that a major credit-rating agency will downgrade Nassau County's bonds to junk status, county legislators said today that they were asked to sign a pledge agreeing to raise taxes this year if the government failed to close a budget gap.

title: CHALLENGE TO VIDEOTRON DEAL
description: The giant fund that manages pension money for all civil servants in Quebec plans to block the $4 billion sale of the province's largest cable operator, Groupe Videotron, to Rogers Communications Inc. of Toronto and to make a bid of its own. The pension fund, the Caisse de Depot et Placement du Quebec, owns 16 percent of Videotron's voting stock. It said that under a 1995 pact with the company's controlling shareholders, its approval of a sale is required. The fund, with the Montreal-based media company Quebecor Inc., is expected to make a counterbid next week. Timothy Pritchard

description: Since Pat Mahomes was traded from the Minnesota Twins to the Boston Red Sox in August 1996, he has gone 20-2 in North America, and he has not lost a game in the major leagues.

description: A technological revolution is shaking up Wall Street, and federal regulators are scrambling to keep up. The explosive growth of electronic brokers is bringing investors lightning-quick, low-cost execution of trades. But with the benefits of this new form of competition come threats that some investors may not get the best price for their stock.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  LUMPKINS, WILLIAM
description: LUMPKINS-William, 90, native New Mexican and longtime Santa Fe resident, passed away March 20. Artist, architect, author, solar energy pioneer, founder of the Santa Fe Art Institute; his many friends mourn his loss, his strength & his gentleness, & offer condolences to his wife, Norma, his four children & five grandchildren. The memorial is at the St Francis Auditorium at 11 AM March 28, followed by a gathering at Santa Fe's La Fonda Hotel. In lieu of flowers, donations can be made to the Hospice Center/Transition Program (1400 Chama Ave, Santa Fe, NM) and the Lumpkins Memorial Fund (Fine Arts Museum, Santa Fe).

title: DOANE PET CARE TO PURCHASE AROVIT PETFOOD OF DENMARK
description: The Doane Pet Care Company, North America's largest maker of pet food for grocery chains and pet stores, agreed yesterday to buy Arovit Petfood of Denmark for $156 million in cash, tripling its business in Europe. Doane will also assume $8 million in debt. The acquisition would give Doane the resources to become the largest private-label maker of food for cats and dogs in Europe, it said. The company, based in Brentwood, Tenn., has been gradually expanding in Europe since late 1996. The closely held Arovit, based in Esbjerg, Denmark, is one of Europe's largest producers of wet and dry private-label pet food.

title: Ftorek Did Not Bend, Causing Devil Breakup
description: I admired Robbie Ftorek the first time I saw him and always wanted to like him. The year was 1972, and my view was from the balcony of the old Olympia Stadium in Detroit. Ftorek, a Red Wings rookie, was an American and a United States Olympian. Back then, these were not advantages in a National Hockey League filled almost exclusively with Canadians bred in major junior leagues.

description: Negotiators for US Airways Group and its flight attendants union continued talking early this morning as the 12:01 a.m. deadline for the talks passed.

description: Ever since books of cowboy poetry began to appear in the 1890's, the lyrical verses have evoked a sense of lost romance and a disappearing way of life.

title: AUTO TRADE PACT
description: Easing tension over a contentious economic issue, South America's two largest countries -- Brazil and Argentina -- reached an agreement on the trade of automobiles. The five-year accord will establish an equal balance of imports and exports between the nations, in addition to a shared tariff of 35 percent on imports from outside the Mercosur trade bloc: Brazil, Argentina, Chile, Paraguay and Uruguay. The agreement is seen soothing relations after Brazil's sharp currency devaluation in January 1999, which lowered the prices of Brazilian goods and labor costs, causing some manufacturers to shift production of cars and parts to Brazil from Argentina. Simon Romero

title: Key Rates
description: Percent

title: Where Is That Super? Try the Web; A New Site Links Co-Op and Condo Tenants to Services
description: Life in the cocoon of Manhattan's newest real-estate phenomenon, the cyberbuilding, has its mysteries. This explains why 18 apartment house superintendents were occupying black-plastic conference-room chairs on a recent afternoon, staring at the image of a new Web site on a projection screen. ''So, how many of you have surfed the Web?'' asked their trainer, Derek Viglianti.

title: Campaign by Confession in Bid for Kennedy's Senate Seat
description: PUT yourself in the shoes of Jack E. Robinson III.

title: Growths of Green Soften a City of Hard Spaces
description: Summoned outside by the warm breezes yesterday, five Beacon High School students took their McDonald's burgers and headed for the nearest park, to eat and philosophize.

title: Senior Manager at M.T.A. Is Charged With Extortion
description: When the senior contract manager at the Metropolitan Transportation Authority demanded a $7,000 kickback this month from a commercial electrician doing work for the agency, federal prosecutors said, the manager was full of helpful suggestions and reassuring words.

title: Sutton Maintains Control Of Emotions and Round
description: In almost every round at the Players Championship, adversity is unavoidable. Players who remain resilient have a chance to win. Players who succumb to frustration find themselves hopelessly behind.

title: The Mayor Can Defuse the Dorismond Case
description: New Yorkers are especially sensitive to racial tensions and have historically placed great emphasis on how politicians deal with issues of race. In the 1960's, for example, Mayor John Lindsay was hailed as a civic hero for walking the streets of black neighborhoods to head off urban unrest. In more recent years two mayors, Edward Koch and David Dinkins, were sent packing from City Hall at least partly because of public disappointment over how they handled racial conflicts.

title: MERISTAR HOTELS ADDING BRIDGESTREET ACCOMMODATIONS
description: MeriStar Hotels and Resorts Inc. agreed yesterday to acquire BridgeStreet Accommodations Inc. for $3 a share, a total of $24 million in cash and stock. Washington-based MeriStar said that the deal was part of an expansion strategy and that the transaction would give it a foothold in the London market. The deal includes the assumption of $11 million in debt. BridgeStreet, which is based in Cleveland, provides apartments, town houses and condominiums to corporate customers for long-term stays. Its stock rose 56.25 cents, to $2.125, on the American Stock Exchange. MeriStar operates hotels and resorts in the United States, Canada, Puerto Rico and the Virgin Islands.

title: The Past, the Pit, the Plants; Rose Is a Rose Is a . . .  Nut?
description: From the most raked-over historical fields to the latest technology, scholars and researchers continually manage to ask new questions, rethink old verities and produce fresh insights. Arts & Ideas takes an occasional look at what some of today's thinkers -- the established as well as those who yearn to be -- are working on. Some ideas may turn into breakthroughs and others may turn out to be dead ends, but the journey is rarely boring. Here is a handful of works in progress.

title: Wisconsin Versus Purdue Is a Matchup of Hard Knocks on Hardwood
description: They are Big Ten Conference rivals, but in the case of Wisconsin and Purdue, familiarity breeds hostility, not contempt. The last meeting between the Badgers and the Boilermakers, a 78-66 Wisconsin victory in the quarterfinals of the Big Ten tournament, surpassed the lofty standards of physical play in the conference. It produced 49 fouls, 63 free throws, 2 cuts, 7 stitches and numerous bruises in a variety of colors.

title: GENRAD BUYS UNITS OF THERMO INSTRUMENT SYSTEMS
description: GenRad Inc., a maker of computer and electronic testing equipment, based in Westford, Mass., said yesterday that it had bought two units of Thermo Instrument Systems Inc. for $40 million to add X-ray testing and repair tools to its products. One of the units, Nicolet Imaging Systems, based in San Diego, makes X-ray testing equipment used to inspect assembled circuit boards and air bags. The other, Sierra Research and Technology Inc., based in Westford, makes printed circuit board repair equipment. The cash transactions are expected to add to GenRad earnings next year, said Walter Shephard, chief financial officer. Thermo Instrument Systems, based in Waltham, Mass., sells measurement instruments for medical and chemicals companies.

title: Tribal Or Urban, A Scary Bunch
description: Now here's something really different: ''Nodrog Doggo,'' Eliot Feld's first premiere of the season for his company, Ballet Tech, is as provocative and offbeat as its title. Performed on Thursday night at the Joyce Theater, it is a wildly imaginative piece and a trance dance for our time.

title: Man Dies in 15-Story Fall Trying to Flee Apartment Fire
description: A man fell to his death from his 15th-floor apartment yesterday morning as he tried to escape a fire through a window of his building in Clinton.

title: For Fear of Debris, NASA Will Cut a Mission
description: After a three-month review of the risks of doing nothing, NASA engineers and scientists decided yesterday that the safest course would be to direct the crippled 17-ton Compton Gamma Ray Observatory to make a suicidal plunge out of orbit and back toward Earth while they can still control its destructive fall so that it comes down far from inhabited land.

title: UConn's Abrosimova Is Finally Settling In
description: When Svetlana Abrosimova calls her mother in St. Petersburg, Russia, she lies. Only well-meaning lies intended to create a comforting picture of college life at Connecticut, where she plays for the nation's top-ranked women's basketball team.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  KLEMPERER, PETER
description: KLEMPERER-Peter. Colleagues from the New York City Health and Hospitals Corporation will always remember and miss Peter Klemperer-a much-valued guide and friend. Peter brought a broad range of knowledge and a unique vision to the Corporation for more than a quarter-century. Peter's thinking and deep concern for the health of all New Yorkers influenced reimbursement policy and legislation throughout New York State. Those who worked with Peter found, in this forthright and honest man, the extraordinary combination of superior analytic thinking and love for ideas. He always demonstrated genuine appreciation, curiosity and generosity toward other people. The Corporation will miss his leadership, strategic thinking and dedication, as well as his warmth, humor, compassion and sensitivity. We wish to extend our heartfelt sympathies to Judy, Jerusha and Ethan, who have lost a loving husband and father. We share in your tremendous loss.

title: TODAY'S SCHEDULES
description: Neither Mr. Bush nor Mr. Gore has public events scheduled today.

title: Ah! The Delicious Defeat Of Moral Righteousness
description: Broadway loves those old nemeses, virtue and vice, and in ''Tenderloin,'' the musical by Jerry Bock and Sheldon Harnick that is the latest entry in the Encores! revival series, here they are again, spitting on their hands, duking it out like a couple of weary old pugs and nonetheless winding up as strange and smiling bedfellows. A chuckleheaded marshmallow of a show (that's no insult, really), it ran for 216 performances after it opened on Oct. 17, 1960, and it is being cleverly and cheerily half-staged (there's more than just concertizing going on) at City Center this weekend for four more performances, including two today, one tomorrow and a gala on Monday night.

title: Helen Venturelli, 86; Fought for Police Widows
description: Helen Venturelli, a champion of better benefits for widows of police officers and firefighters killed on the job, died March 15 at Westchester Square Hospital in the Bronx. She was 86 and lived in the Bronx.

title: COMPANY NEWS
description: PRIME HOSPITALITY CORP., Fairfield, N.J., which operates more than 200 hotels in the United States and the Virgin Islands, said it had sold its five remaining HomeGate hotels to the Amerand Corp., a hotel operator in Texas, for $17.7 million.

title: Broker Admits Selling Drugs On Floor of Stock Exchange
description: Shares of Time Warner and Citigroup are among the typical things bought and sold at the New York Stock Exchange. But one broker pleaded guilty on Thursday to selling cocaine to undercover officers on the trading floor, prosecutors said.

title: THE MARKETS: CURRENCIES
description: SWISS FRANC GAINS. The Swiss franc surged for a second day after an increase in interest rates by the country's central bank. The franc ended at 1.6277 per dollar yesterday, up from 1.6465 per dollar on Thursday.

title: THE MARKETS: COMMODITIES
description: COCOA FALLS 4.1 PERCENT. Americans are losing their sweet tooth and eating less chocolate this year than last, sending the price of cocoa lower. Cocoa for May delivery fell $36, or 4.1 percent, to $840 a metric ton.

title: WIT CAPITAL SHARES CLIMB ON UPBEAT FORECAST
description: Shares of Wit Capital Group Inc. rallied more than 29 percent yesterday after the online investment bank said first-quarter revenue and profit would far exceed analyst estimates. Shares of New York-based Wit jumped $4.875, to $21.4375, in Nasdaq trading. Wit said late Thursday that it expected to report its first profit, in contrast to the loss of 5 cents a share expected by analysts polled by First Call/Thomson Financial. First-quarter revenue will exceed $85 million, the company said, compared with estimates ranging from $47.6 million to $54.0 million. Wit, which went public in June 1999, reported a fourth-quarter net loss of 10 cents a share on revenues of $21.0 million.

title: Uncovered Short Sales Rise
description: Open positions of short sales on the Nasdaq stock market surged 34.8 percent in the month ended March 15, the National Association of Securities Dealers, which operates the market, said yesterday.

description: Visiting a high school here that was a historic battleground in the fight to integrate public schools in the South, Gov. George W. Bush faced open skepticism today from several educators and a student leader who questioned his proposals to improve education for minority and disadvantaged children.

title: An Enigmatic Pianist Reclaims Her Stardom
description: Few people who have heard the tempestuous Argentine-born pianist Martha Argerich play ever forget it. She is a colossal technician, a powerfully intuitive musician and an electrifying performer. Just last week at Carnegie Hall, as soloist with the Philadelphia Orchestra in a concert conducted by Charles Dutoit, Ms. Argerich vanquished the formidable challenges of Prokofiev's Piano Concerto No. 3. Her fiery, ecstatic performance elicited a frenzied ovation, including 10 curtain calls, from a sold-out house.

title: Religion Journal; 2 Leading Rabbis Voice Appreciation for John Paul
description: When Pope John Paul II stood in silent meditation on Thursday inside Yad Vashem, the Holocaust memorial in Jerusalem, he created a visually riveting moment symbolic of a major theme in his 22-year-old pontificate: the establishment of healthy relations between Roman Catholics and Jews. Those who have followed the pope's statements know it as a concern to which he has returned again and again.

title: Shooting Raises Scrutiny Of Police Antidrug Tactics
description: Two months ago, to curb drug dealing and the violence it spawns, New York City embarked on an ambitious $24 million narcotics enforcement drive known as Operation Condor. Each day, there are 500 additional police officers -- some in uniform, some in plainclothes -- on the streets in high-crime neighborhoods, working overtime to stage drug stings and roust dealers from their street corner haunts.

title: Indian Bureau Recommends Federal Recognition for Two Pequot Tribes in Connecticut
description: The Bureau of Indian Affairs recommended yesterday that the Eastern Pequot and Paucatuck Eastern Pequot tribes of Connecticut be granted federal recognition, a step that would provide new government benefits and economic opportunity for tribe members and perhaps bring more casinos to Connecticut.

But his second divorce was still fresh, and her first marriage had been a disaster, so they decided to try a road test of sorts. They moved in together.

description: The Ugandan police today discovered 153 bodies buried in shallow graves on land belonging to the same doomsday cult involved in hundreds of deaths late last week, the authorities said.

Weldon Anderson, Kevin Kornicki, Jana Losey and Casi Pacilio, will close after the matinee tomorrow at the Helen Hayes Theater, 240 West 44th Street, Manhattan. The show, directed by Tom Diamond, will have run for 32 regular performances and 24 previews.

title: HARDING LAWSON AGREES TO TAKEOVER BY MACTEC
description: Harding Lawson Associates agreed yesterday to be acquired by the privately held Mactec Inc. for $11.50 a share in stock, a total of about $57.5 million, in a deal that combines two engineering and environmental service companies. Denver-based Harding Lawson said the deal was driven by competitive pressures in the rapidly consolidating engineering services industry. Its stock rose $1.375 a share yesterday, to $10.625, in Nasdaq trading. Mactec, based in Golden, Colo., said the transaction would double its annual revenue to $325 million. Harding Lawson had $58.1 million in revenue in the six months that ended on Nov. 30.

title: Governor Cuts His Teeth On JonBenet Murder Case
description: He pushed hard for gun control measures, which failed, and for educational reforms, which are expected to pass. But when Colorado's legislative session has ended, the lasting impression of Gov. Bill Owens, a first-term Republican, could be of a battle he fought outside the House and Senate chambers.

title: Stephen King's Week of Terror
description: It took Al Jolson in blackface in ''The Jazz Singer'' to persuade America that talking pictures were no passing fad. It took Uncle Miltie in drag for the TV set to usurp radio in the nation's living rooms. Is Stephen King's ''Riding the Bullet,'' the first hit book distributed exclusively through the Internet, speeding the end of the Gutenberg age and the dawn of a fully digitalized cultural world?

title: Sports of The Times; Grappling With Elusive Bottom Line
description: ON a cold night on Jan. 19, a raging fire swept through Boland Hall, the freshman dormitory at Seton Hall. Three students died, 62 were injured and the university community at the school of 9,500 students was traumatized.

title: DISAPPOINTING FORECAST FOR EIDOS
description: The shares in Eidos P.L.C., the manufacturer of video games like Tomb Raider, Nomad Soul and F1 World Grand Prix, dropped by about half after the company announced slowing sales and forecast much lower profits. The company, Europe's biggest video game maker, said customers were delaying new video game purchases until manufacturers like Sony, Nintendo and Microsoft roll out a new generation of games consoles. Alan Cowell

title: Tracing the Severed Roots Of an Elusive Husband
description: An air of desolation hangs over ''Hidden River,'' the feature-film debut of Mercedes Garcia Guevara, an Argentine director who shows herself an adept conjurer of cinematic moods, especially when she turns the camera on a sunset illuminating the wild mountains of western Argentina. ''Hidden River'' might be described as a murky emotional mystery story that raises more questions than it answers. What at first appears to be a sudsy drama about a suspicious wife's investigation of her husband's possible adultery deepens into a portrait of a woman's instinctive quest for an elusive spiritual and emotional authenticity.

title: PROMISING CASPIAN DISCOVERY FOR LUKOIL
description: Russia's largest oil company, Lukoil, announced plans to develop a new oil discovery in the Caspian Sea, the first to be found in the Russian section of the oil-rich region. Lukoil has already invested $200 million in an exploratory offshore well that showed a field of about 2.2 billion barrels of oil, making it equal to early large fields found in the North Sea. The new field increases Lukoil's reserves by 15 percent, furthering the company's long-term goal of gradually replacing its aging west Siberian fields. Neela Banerjee

title: 2 British Youths Held in Theft of Credit Card Accounts on Internet
description: The F.B.I. said yesterday that it had assisted British and Canadian law-enforcement officials in the arrest of two 18-year-old British youths in connection with the theft of more than 26,000 credit card accounts over the Internet.

title: A Chill Scene for Shadowy Characters
description: Though its human protagonists are intriguing enough, the most complex and arresting presence in ''Suzhou River'' may be the title character, a grimy man-made waterway that snakes through the industrial districts of Shanghai. The narrator of Lou Ye's moody exercise in modernist film noir is a videographer -- unseen except for an occasional hand reaching in front of the camera -- who trawls the river for images and stories. As he makes his way through the shadowy criminal demimonde at the river's edge, he is drawn, like a character in a Borges story or a Paul Auster novel, into a looking-glass world of crossed destinies, urban legends and mistaken identities.

title: G.M. BUYS STAKE IN FUJI
description: The world's largest automaker, the General Motors Corporation, said it would buy the shares held by the Nissan Motor Company and its affiliates in Fuji Heavy Industries, the maker of Subaru cars. The purchase of 25.4 million shares, or roughly 4 percent of Fuji's shares outstanding, is part of G.M.'s agreement to buy a 20 percent stake in Fuji. Stephanie Strom

description: Warren Egbert Magee, a lawyer who represented Nazi war criminals, corrupt politicians and Senator Joseph R. McCarthy, died on Feb. 25 in Washington. He was 91.

title: Vodafone Receives a German Bid for a Car-Parts Operation
description: The British mobile telephone giant Vodafone AirTouch P.L.C. said today that it had received an unsolicited offer from ThyssenKrupp A.G., the largest steel maker in Germany, for the auto parts and engineering unit of Mannesmann. Vodafone recently agreed to acquire Mannesmann for $183 billion in the biggest hostile takeover ever.

title: Gore, the Earnest Student and Natural Teacher, With a Sweet Tooth
description: Vice President Al Gore was sitting around with a group of students when Sally Hannert, the drama teacher, plucked him out to participate in a theatrical exercise. A look of mild panic froze his face, but he gamely plunged in.

title: Corrections
description: Because of an editing error, a sports article yesterday about the Players Championship golf tournament misstated the number of eagles made by Hal Sutton, the first-round leader. It was one, not four.

title: JB Restaurant Chain Sold
description: Santa Barbara Restaurant Group Inc. said this week that it had agreed to sell its JB's Family Restaurants Inc. subsidiary to a group led by Lynn Whiteford, JB's chief operating officer. Santa Barbara Restaurant did not disclose the price of the sale. It said the sale would allow it to focus on its La Salsa and Timber Lodge brands while rolling out its Green Burrito/Carl's Jr. dual concept restaurants. The JB's business, which Santa Barbara acquired in 1998, includes 81 JB's and 6 Galaxy Diner restaurants.

title: COURTAULDS ACCEPTS BID
description: A British clothing supplier, Courtaulds Textiles P.L.C., agreed to a sweetened offer from the Sara Lee Corporation of Chicago that values the company, which makes Gossard lingerie, at $238 million, or 145 pence ($2.31) a share. Courtaulds, the top global supplier of clothes for private labels, had dismissed an earlier offer of 100 pence a share. Alan Cowell

title: Action Plan For a Reluctant Greenspan
description: FOR all those who doubt that a speculative bubble hangs dangerously over the economy -- and the doubters number in the tens of millions -- Robert J. Shiller's new book is sobering. He describes a market so out of control that the run-up in the Roaring 20's looks like a molehill, compared with the Mount Everest of the 90's.

title: Plenty of Bucks, but Still Prowling for Buys
description: I AM on the Aegean, wearing big sunglasses, and I have on something turquoise with lots of jewelry, lots of flash. I'm very tan.''

title: Government Should Tax and Tell
description: TAX time is a nightmare for many people, especially those who work for cash. Almost everyone I deal with -- plumbers, roofers, lawn-care people and photographers -- expects to be paid in cash, as if credit and checks had never been invented. ''It saves on paperwork,'' the owner of a local garage said after replacing my clutch and relieving me of a huge wad of banknotes.

title: Where the Jobs Are
description: College seniors dusted the sand off their resumes earlier this month in Panama City, Fla., and headed to the Spring Break Career Expo 2000.

title: A Less Lovely 'Lord of the Flies'
description: PETER BROOK has said that while his film ''Lord of the Flies'' lessens the magic of William Golding's story about the descent of 30 British schoolboys into savagery, it ''introduces evidence.'' In his book ''The Shifting Point,'' the director wrote that Golding's fable is so beautiful that ''it can be refuted as a trick of compelling poetic style.'' In the film, he added, that's not possible. ''No one can attribute the looks and gestures to tricks of direction,'' he wrote. ''The violent gestures, the look of greed and the faces of experience are all real.''

title: Ruling Will Let Third Parties Share in the State's Largess
description: A State Superior Court ruling last week overturning a state law that restricted eligible voters from registering as anything other than Republicans, Democrats, Independents or Unaffiliated handed a powerful tool to alternative political parties in their effort to achieve an official status and the considerable benefits that accrue.

title: At Antique and Gem Store, Their Pain Is Your Gain
description: A banner saying ''No Reasonable Offer Refused'' is hanging in the window at 50 Central Park South. The store there, Metropolitan Antiques and Gems, is not just offering a sale on its inventory of jewelry, artworks and furniture, whose prices are from $100 to thousands of dollars. Another banner in the window says: ''Lost Our Lease.'' After four years there, the store is closing. The last day will be in a few weeks, employees said.

title: Hold the Phone. Better Yet, Blow It to Smithereens.
description: THE season's final performance of Strauss's ''Rosenkavalier'' at the Metropolitan Opera last month was one of those inspired evenings when everything goes beautifully for reasons no one can explain. The principals sang splendidly: Susan Graham as Octavian, Heidi Grant Murphy as Sophie, and Renee Fleming, who brought her poignant voice and subtle intensity to the role of the Marschallin.

title: Music; Amy Fradon, Singer, Finding Her Own Way
description: AMY FRADON'S childhood friends probably expected her to be an artist when she grew up. After all, her father, Dana Fradon, was a cartoonist for The New Yorker magazine and her mother, Ramona Fradon, illustrated the comic strip ''Brenda Starr.'' Amy Fradon's future, however, was never etched in stone.

title: Good News for the Elderly
description: The Senate voted unanimously to repeal a Depression-era provision that forced Social Security recipients to give up all or part of their retirement benefit if they earned more than $17,000 a year. The House passed the same measure this month, and President Clinton said he would sign it.

description: David Trimble today held off a surprisingly strong challenge to his leadership of the Ulster Unionist Party but emerged with his authority and his room to maneuver in conducting peace negotiations diminished.

title: A Sheep-and-Goat Drive Across the Iranian West
description: WHATEVER else they're known for, the mountains of western Iran have yielded fine documentaries. In 1923, 10 years before they made ''King Kong,'' Merian C. Cooper and Ernest B. Schoedsack toted their cameras into the peaks and ravines to make ''Grass,'' a classic silent account of the Bhaktiari tribe's harrowing effort to herd what looks like every animal in creation across the central Asian equivalent of the Swiss Alps. A half century later, Anthony Howarth's ''People of the Wind'' (Milestone, $39.95) crosses much the same ground with the Babadi, an arm of the Bhaktiari, as they drive a million sheep, goats and pack animals into great boulder fields, across icy turquoise rivers, upward into mountain passes and down to vast expanses of pasture.

description: To the Editor:

title: Things Fall Together
description: Anne Carson is a poet who likes to get under people's skin. Her new collection, ''Men in the Off Hours,'' features verse in which she variously inhabits the minds (and bodies) of Tolstoy, Lazarus, Freud, Catullus, Sappho and Emily Dickinson. Perhaps her boldest act of channeling, though, comes in a prose poem, ''Irony Is Not Enough: Essay on My Life as Catherine Deneuve,'' which casts the French movie siren in the role of a witty classics professor. (''Sweater buttoned almost to the neck, she sits at the head of the seminar table expounding aspects of Athenian monetary reform.'') Although Carson herself is a classics professor, that's not the connection that led her to write it. ''I saw this movie, 'The Thieves,' about Deneuve being a philosophy teacher in Paris,'' she explains to me. ''In it, she had a sweater just like one of mine. Afterward, I went home and began thinking about what it would be like to be Catherine.''

title: Political Briefing; Poll Suggests Bush Has the Right Issues
description: George W. Bush spent much of last week promoting himself as the ''education candidate.'' But that's not to say he has abandoned or is playing down his earlier pitch about Al Gore's ''credibility problem.''

description: She Captains

title: Suriname
description: To the Editor: The article on Suriname (''Warm Welcome in the Jungle,'' Feb. 20) had special meaning for my wife and me. We made the trip in 1973, arriving in Paramaribo without any advance arrangements. We finally met Utta Elgaard, a long-time Dutch resident of Suriname who spoke Dutch, English and Taki-Taki, a patois of the Djukas. She agreed to take us to visit the Aucaners, one of five tribes of the Djukas -- descendants of slaves who escaped into the jungle in the 18th century. This journey necessitated a trip by dugout canoe 100 miles on the Maroni River.

title: MOVIES: CRITIC'S CHOICE
description: EVEN Anne Rice, who wrote the novel and wasn't crazy about the casting, had to admit that the film version of INTERVIEW WITH THE VAMPIRE (1994) turned out beautifully, thanks to the director, Neil Jordan, and the gorgeous nighttime cinematography by Philippe Rousselot. Tom Cruise is both darkly seductive and thrillingly funny as Lestat, a vampire with a past. Brad Pitt is gorgeous and tortured as Louis, his unwilling partner in crime. And Kirsten Dunst, just 12 at the time, is enchanting as the littlest of the undead, a plague victim whom Lestat and Louis snatch from the jaws of death in New Orleans and condemn to eternal childhood. And the final scene, as Mr. Cruise drives away from San Francisco, with the top down, the radio blaring, his lace cuffs fluttering in the breeze, is worth watching again and again - Tuesday at 8 p.m. on Cinemax.

title: Brian M. Barish And John D. Freeman AHA Diversified Equity Fund
description: TWO heads are often better than one. And when it comes to the task of managing a portfolio of large-capitalization value stocks, which have badly lagged behind the broader market lately, the extra brain power may come in handy.

title: Books in Brief: Fiction & Poetry; Castoffs
description: After years of prowling the fringes of Detroit looking for bargains to fill his junk store, Richard Stalling has become the king of bowling shirts and Bakelite. He's a familiar type: an emotionally undernourished, even adolescent grown-up, apparently satisfied with his carefully furnished solitude. ''I've found that people don't like dwelling on their own irrelevance,'' he says. ''Me, I wallow in it.'' Then his surviving parent -- his mother -- dies, and Richard has a few weeks to rescue the good stuff out of the family house before it's carted away. In Michael Zadoorian's colorful first novel, SECOND HAND (Norton, $23.95), the task erodes what's left of his cool, to the point where he finds himself crying uncontrollably in his shop. That's when Theresa, in her thrift-store frock and skull necklace, walks in. Theresa knows something about castoffs, too: she works at an animal shelter. The two of them embark on a romantic adventure that explores what Yeats called the foul rag-and-bone shop of the heart, and it will make you feel as if Zadoorian's got you in an emotional Veg-O-Matic: it's that sad. Maybe the story isn't entirely unpredictable, and maybe its cultural references seem arcane. But if you're a yard sale lover or, especially, an animal fan, ''Second Hand'' may feel like a gift from the (Tiki) gods. Sally Eckhoff

title: When Tabloids Were Noir
description: THE nature of the crime in question is not clear in the photograph above, but the nervous energy in the auto is palpable. The picture, which was taken by Tom Cunningham and published on Feb. 15, 1953, in The Daily News, is titled ''Pondering His Fate.'' Scenes like this one will be explored in a lecture at the School of Visual Arts on Tuesday by William Hannigan, a photo library archivist at The News, based on his recent book ''New York Noir: Crime Photos From the Daily News Archive.'' The lecture is held in conjunction with an exhibition at the Queens Museum of Art of more than 100 photos, some of them quite explicit, taken between 1920 and 1960. The show is accompanied by a 10-week film series that shows the relation between tabloid photography and the noir film style.

''God, Defender and Accuser,'' it turns out, is in Hebrew; it was composed for the Casale Monferrata Synagogue in Northern Italy.

title: The View From/Dobbs Ferry; Ballroom Dance Pizazz From Russian Emigres
description: WHEN she was a little girl in the city of Baku in what was then the Soviet Union, Lilia Borovski told herself stories about becoming a dancer and a princess. The princess part did not materialize, but she and her husband, Ilia Borovski, could be seen as royalty of sorts. Still in their early 20's, they are well known in the world of competitive ballroom dancing, having won dozens of international competitions doing everything from the stately waltz to the flashy Argentine tango.

title: Vietnam's Pall in Black Lives
description: EIGHTEEN: the coming of age, the age of consent, of adulthood. Because it is his 18th birthday, Leon Mobley, a black man who is accused of shooting a white police officer named Tank, won't be allowed to stand trial as a minor for attempted murder. Leon's mother, LaBrea, recalls that she was 18 when her son was born. His father, Roland, wanders the streets, wheeling a grocery cart, haunted by ''the pain and agony we left behind'' when he was one of America's ''paid killers and annihilators'' in Vietnam -- at 18. Roland's tortured memories won't go away. ''Where you stand when you cross into manhood, that's an important space,'' he says.

That upper chamber provides light, from high windows during the day and chandeliers at night, and a rich, reverberant acoustic.

When the U.S. trade deficit passed $100 billion for the first time, there was much wailing and gnashing of teeth. Four years ago, in an effort to attract the activity to the state, the governor signed a bill that allowed extreme wrestling to operate outside the auspices of the government. title: The Colorist
description: Not since the 1980's has name-dropping been so conspicuous in high fashion. This spring, many women are stepping out head-to-toe in luxury logos. But Sharon Dorram, the chief colorist at the John Frieda Salon on East 76th Street, prefers a subtler take on the trend. She wraps herself in a brown Mackintosh by Louis Vuitton patterned in tiny gold LV's. ''I like this particular coat because it doesn't scream 'logo,' '' Ms. Dorram said. title: Books in Brief: Nonfiction; What They Endured

Take the account from a 6-year-old about being raped by a soldier -- who had first raped her baby brother. Or that of the orphans who ate rodents caught with traps they devised themselves (''There were many times when we were grateful for the boiled remains of rats''). Or that from the youngsters who watched pigs devour corpses, then heard shots as soldiers killed the pigs (''But always they took the carcasses away. The stench was awful''). These children, survivors of the Balkans war, talked with Leah Curtin, an American nurse associated with the Franciscan Sisters of the Poor, an order of nuns who worked in a Croatian hospital. With the help of a local child psychologist, Curtin also persuaded them to make drawings of their experiences. One, of roughly painted brown and red strokes brightened at the top with a streak of blue, is captioned: ''She could not draw anything. She could only make splotches of paint.'' The children's desire to be normal again resonates throughout the book, as do the words ''peace'' and ''hate,'' words inadequate for the emotions engendered by the abuses they endured and the crimes they saw. Some children witnessed parents blown to bits and others nearly starved in bunkers; many endured both. But the children's strong, resilient voices emerge between the dark lines; they look toward the future's bright light. Dulcie Leimbach

title: Lives; High Concept
description: Eric Valli, a French filmmaker, was one of the first outsiders to visit the remote Nepalese region of Dolpo, where a Tibetan people maintain an ancient way of life. Soon thereafter, he showed some old American movies to Tinle Lundup, a local chief, who had never seen a film. ''He said: 'Eric, you have a nice house,''' Valli recalls, ''but you come here and get bitten by fleas and eat frozen yak meat. What are you doing here?' I said, 'I'm realizing a dream.''' Lundup had a better idea: make a film recording the tribe's vanishing traditions. * Valli shot on location (a three-week walk from the nearest road) using the Dolpo-pa themselves as actors. Hundreds of porters carried the production's 5 tons of kerosene, 10 tons of rice and 4 tons of lentils. * Shooting lasted nine months; cast and crew lived in tents, enduring five-week snowstorms and temperatures of minus 15 degrees. ''In the tradition of the Dolpo-pa people,'' says Valli, ''each time a leader dies, they write a biography, or a namdar. When they saw this film, they said, 'It is like the namdar of the Dolpo-pa.'''

title: Bookend; The Storyteller
description: He was James Farl Powers on his birth certificate and Jim Powers to his friends. In the history of modern fiction, J. F. Powers (1917-99) was a distinctive figure, a loner, emerging from quietness every few years when he published a book or won a prize, but otherwise content to mind his own professional business. He is sometimes described as a writer's writer, meaning that he was an artist too good to gratify the most casual reader, but he was also a reader's writer, if we assume a reader who thinks of fiction as intelligent art rather than low entertainment. Such writers tend not to be abundant. Powers published only a few books -- three collections of short stories, ''Prince of Darkness, and Other Stories'' (1947), ''The Presence of Grace'' (1956) and ''Look How the Fish Live'' (1975), and two novels, ''Morte D'Urban'' (1962) and ''Wheat That Springeth Green'' (1988). But these are treasured, guarded with jealousy by those who know of them. News of their quality is passed from one adept to another, like word of an idyllic village in an unfashionable part of France, not to be disclosed to the ordinary camera-toting tourist. Now that Powers is dead, he has become his admirers, as Auden said of Yeats.

description: When the Nets gathered for a workout today, the mood was still a little bit the way it was when they had left Continental Arena on Friday night, frustrated and disappointed with the result of that night's game as well as the realization that their playoff hopes had likely disappeared.

title: Travel Advisory; San Francisco Stretches Streetcar Run to Wharf
description: Cable cars still make the run to San Francisco's Fisherman's Wharf, but now there's another way to get to the waterfront: vintage electric streetcars running along a palm-lined boulevard beside the San Francisco Bay.

title: The New American Worker
description: Randall Patterson must have been reeling when he finished his interview with Mark Cuban (''The Idled Workaholic''). Not one reference to using some of his still-wet wealth to establish a foundation or other entity to address some of society's needs! Unless his girlfriend is simply ''arm candy,'' I hope she takes a Mercedes or two and gets out fast.

title: The Way We Live Now: 3-26-00: On Language; Anachronism
description: In imperial Japan before World War II, members of the ''thought police'' -- Shiso Keisatsu -- fanned out to suppress dangerous thinking in the populace. The thought police were disbanded by General MacArthur when he imposed freedom of speech on occupied Japan. The name of the group was later chillingly immortalized by George Orwell in his 1949 ''1984.''

title: The Way We Live Now: 3-26-00: ShopTalk; Road Rage
description: A new Transportation Department agency, the Federal Motor Carrier Safety Administration, is working on a proposal to update ''hours of service'' regulations. Last year Congress rejected an earlier proposal recommending mandatory on-board recorders for long-haul truck drivers. Such recorders can monitor speed, miles driven and date and time to ensure that truckers take required breaks.

title: Officials Decide to Release Man Who Killed 2 With Sword
description: Juan Gonzalez, who killed two people and wounded nine with a sword in a July 1986 attack on the Staten Island Ferry, has been granted unsupervised leave from his residence at the Bronx Psychiatric Center.

title: The New American Worker
description: Thank you for a generally excellent discussion of the changing world of work (March 5). Michael Lewis caught the zeitgeist dead-on (''The Artist in the Gray Flannel Pajamas''). I can't count the number of lawyers or other former professionals who have jumped ship to dot-coms. But I have to say that Nina Munk (''The Price of Freedom'') made the free-agent experience sound like some sort of Amway operation. Hardly the case at all. I've been working as a free agent and can testify that the work is out there, the lifestyle exists and the freedom is unbeatable.

title: My Oscar? Oh, That Old Thing
description: MANY envelopes will be ripped open tonight at the 72nd annual Academy Awards. But not one will contain instructions on how to display a much-hoped-for, much-obsessed-over Oscar at home so it won't look preposterous.

title: Polished Wood, Tough Talk
description: The market was down. Way down. Hundreds of points. But the turbulence did not shake the financial aeronauts dining at the ''21'' Club on East 52nd Street, did not suck the buoyancy from their balloons.

title: Technology Riches From Others' Castoffs
description: DENNIS M. LYNCH used to beat up computer geeks when he was a jock in high school. Now his fortune rests on those geeks.

title: Corrections
description: A picture caption last Sunday in Men's Fashions of The Times, Part 2 of The Times Magazine, with an article by David Bowie about rock 'n' roll fashion, misidentified the designer of the V-neck sweater he wore. It was by Paul Smith, not Paul Stuart.

title: NEWS SUMMARY
description: INTERNATIONAL 3-22

title: Spring, Time for the Roger Awards (Oscar? What's That?)
description: It's Academy Awards time again, time for the bestowal of the gilded Oscar so coveted in Hollywood. But New York has its own film award, with its very own statuette. It's called the Roger, and it's the brainchild of James Knowles, a sculptor and the proprietor of the Roger Smith Hotel in Midtown, for which the award was named.

description: To the Editor:

title: Corrections
description: A report in the Evening Hours column last Sunday about a benefit for Venetian Heritage at the St. Regis Hotel in New York misspelled the given name of a guest. She is Marit Gruson, not Marite.

title: Greenmarket Idea for U.N. Area Runs Into Unexpected Red Lights
description: For years, residents near Dag Hammarskjold Park fought for renovation of the public square on East 47th Street between First and Second Avenues, in the shadow of the United Nations. Now that the park has been improved, some people in the neighborhood want to see a weekly farmers' market on the site. But there's much more to creating an open-air market, they have learned, than rolling out the apple carts.

description: PARRIOTT-Joseph Marshall. A memorial service will be held for Joseph Marshall Parriott, Industrial Designer and Educator, at the Cathedral of St. John The Divine, on Monday, March 27 at 2:30 PM.

title: The Putin Puzzle
description: Unless the polls are badly mistaken or voter turnout is too low to validate the balloting, Vladimir Putin is likely to be elected president of Russia today. He might be best described as a K.G.B. democrat, with all the contradictions the term implies. Mr. Putin is a hybrid politician, the product of the recent transformation of Russia from a totalitarian state to a shaky democracy. Like his country, he seems suspended between Russia's history and its future, impressed by the benefits of liberty and free markets yet drawn to the idea of a firm leader who can restore stability. There is little doubt that he will be a forceful president, determined to reverse Russia's decline. The question is whether he will do so democratically.

title: Don't Forget the Boss
description: To the Editor:

title: Who Is That Man Posing As Richard Foreman?
description: HAS Richard Foreman found his alter ego at last? Could it be that the poor mad philosopher Friedrich Nietzsche is the perfect analogue for the playwright and director, who for more than 30 years has been breaking the boundaries of theater to combine the surreal, the disordered, the mysterious and, sometimes, the just plain nutty?

title: Baseball, Hot Dogs and . . .
description: When baseball season starts this week, a heated issue will return to the table: what wine goes with hot dogs?

description: Mary Katherine Feeley and John Alfred Hawk III were married yesterday by Msgr. James T. Mahoney at Corpus Christi Church in Chatham, N.J.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  PAPA, ANTHONY M.
description: PAPA-Anthony M. 65, of Brooklyn and Belmar. Beloved husband of Rosemarie (nee Forte). Devoted father of Mark (Linda Aragon) and Andrea. Loving brother of Pasquale. Son of the late Marino and Theresa (nee DiTrani). Adored brother-in-law, uncle and friend. Former CEO of the State Liquor Authority, Deputy Secretary of State and Assistant Commissioner of Agriculture and Markets during the Cuomo Administration. Assistant Professor at CUNY for 22 years. A devoted family man and a loyal, caring individual who will be profoundly missed. Funeral Tuesday, 9:15 AM, at Marine Park Funeral Home, 3024 Quentin Rd., Brooklyn. Mass St. Edmund's R.C. Church, 10:15 AM. Interment Greenwood Cemetery. Visiting hours 2-5, 7-10, Sunday and Monday. In lieu of flowers donations may be made to Chaplaincy Fund, the Valley Hospital, 223 North Van Dien Ave., Ridgewood, NJ 07450.

title: Poetic License
description: PURE POETRY

title: Diabetes Drug Withdrawn
description: Two widely used drugs, blamed for deaths among patients, are being taken off the market. The diabetes drug Rezulin, linked to 63 deaths from liver failure since 1997, was withdrawn by Parke-Davis. The 500,000 Americans taking the drug were urged not to stop until they get other treatment. Janssen Pharmaceutica, the maker of the heartburn drug Propulsid, which has caused 80 deaths from heart problems, said the drug would also be withdrawn. DENISE GRADY

title: Bonnie Sashin, Dennis Ditelberg
description: Bonnie Mae Sashin and Dennis Leonard Ditelberg were married last evening by Rabbi Andrew Warmflash at the bridegroom's home in Chestnut Hill, Mass.

title: Ex-Squatter, in a Novel, Details Life on Society's Margins
description: During the late 80's and early 90's, Seth Tobocman slept beneath a leaking roof, spent months without heat or hot water, and dodged police while entering and leaving his apartment. He also helped clear rubble from his building, repair the roof and rebuild a drain line.

title: Don't Try This at Home
description: Brotherhood

title: Dora and Her Discontents
description: The Fig Eater

title: Political Briefing; At the D.N.C., Upheaval as Usual
description: Last summer, when President Clinton picked Edward G. Rendell to be the general chairman of the Democratic National Committee, the expectation was that the party's war chest would soon be overflowing. Mr. Rendell, then serving his final months as mayor of Philadelphia, had a reputation as a first-class manager and a prodigious fund-raiser.
