description: Biennial at the Whitney, Asian art and a Jets helmet

title: Exploring the Farthest Edges of French Society
description: DRESSED in a leather jacket and jeans, the director Claire Denis, whose latest film, ''Beau Travail,'' opens on Friday, has a casual sophistication. At 49, she is petite, intense, reticent and, on occasion, disarmingly honest. Her voice is raspy but energetic, and in conversation she is at once very quick and very thoughtful. The daughter of a French civil servant, Ms. Denis grew up in Cameroon in West Africa during the final days of the colonial empire.

title: Jazz Solos As Sonic Wallpaper
description: JAZZ is a music of unmistakable personalities. Though ensemble interaction between these personalities remains one of the music's glories, the expression of individual identity has always been the essence of jazz, with players cultivating solo sounds as singular as fingerprints.

title: Mysterious Force Attacks Small Western Tribe's Young in the Womb
description: The tiny tribe that lives here on a wind-battered, rain-swept spit of land hard by the Pacific Ocean knows something about fighting for survival.

title: CLINTON ENTREATS PAKISTAN TO TREAD LIGHTLY IN KASHMIR
description: In an effort to defuse tensions in a region that he has described as the most volatile in the world, President Clinton today asked the military leader of Pakistan to show restraint in Kashmir, where Pakistan and India most recently battled last summer, and to reopen a dialogue with his Indian neighbors.

title: Salt, Fine in the Ocean, Intrudes in the Tap
description: Sprawling seaside growth, increases in the year-round population and drought have left New Jersey's shore towns with a problem -- the drinking water is becoming as salty as the ocean air.

title: Caution Ahead: The Mighty S.U.V.
description: To the Editor:

title: Commercial Property/Brooklyn Heights and Cobble Hill; National Chains Vie for Piece of the Local Retail Pie
description: BROOKLYN HEIGHTS and neighboring Cobble Hill have long been the home to locally owned businesses catering to the residents of the largely low-rise neighborhoods and the nearby court system. But now the area is beginning to attract national retailers, at the same time as some local businesses are expanding.

title: Love Letters in the Virtual Ether, Printed and Bound for Posterity
description: Four years ago, a woman walked into Joseph Landau's bookbindery with a stack of printed-out e-mails that she and her fiance had written to each other.

title: PrivateSector; Of the Future of Mice and Music
description: Strauss Zelnick, chief executive of BMG Entertainment, came to Silicon Alley recently to boast that his business had nothing to fear from the World Wide Web. His speech, ''How a Major Music Company is Aggressively Embracing the Net and Expects to Win the Digital Wars,'' came amid reports that the Napster software was making free downloads of music easier than ever.

title: New Group to Open Shelter For Elderly Victims of Abuse
description: When Mary Costello of Elmhurst, Queens, was too ill to care for herself at home, she was placed in the Queen of Peace Adult Residence, an assisted-living home in Queens Village operated by the Little Sisters of the Poor.

title: E-Mail Is Treacherous. So Why Do We Keep Trusting It?
description: IF the Microsoft Corporation's e-mail storage system had been as flawed as the one at the White House, the software company might have been spared many of the more painful moments in its continuing antitrust battle with the Justice Department.

title: When Dinosaurs Rocked
description: TODAY -- when the pop music industry has embraced the concept of a new flavor every week -- two rock movies recently released on DVD seem like endearing artifacts from a bygone era. Their release allows Led Zeppelin and U2 fans to see and hear their favorites as they looked and sounded during their heydays.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  MARKEL, FRANCES (NEE GILBERT)
description: MARKEL-Frances (nee Gilbert). Beloved wife of the late Jesse M. Markel. Devoted mother of Carl and Edith Markel, Judith and Leonard Lindey and Pat Feder and Jacques Crouzet-Pascal. Cherished grandmother of Jeffrey, Mark, Michael, David, Kenneth and Eric. And great-grandmother of nine. Lifelong friend of Beatrice Austrian. Services Sunday, 3 PM, at Riverside-Nassau North Chapels, 55 North Station Plaza, Great Neck, NY. In lieu of flowers contributions may be made to the Great Neck Senior Center, 80 Grace Ave, Great Neck, NY 11021.

title: Travel Advisory; In Indianapolis, a Showplace for Champions
description: The National Collegiate Athletic Association Hall of Champions, a hands-on museum celebrating college athletics, is to open Thursday next to the organization's new headquarters in Indianapolis.

title: Deep Political and Religious Rifts Disrupt the Harmony of Nigerian Towns
description: In a corner of this city in Nigeria's Christian heartland, where every other car seems to affirm the driver's love for Jesus, Muslim migrants from the north had managed to become landowners.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  ROSEN, EMANUEL, AKA MENDEL, MANNY
description: ROSEN-Emanuel, aka Mendel, Manny, age 92, of Singer Island, FL. Passed away March 21. Beloved husband of Pearl and the late Miriam. Loving father of Jane Rosen & Deena Hoagland. Cherished grandfather of Kate & Joe. We shall miss you forever.

title: Snake Charm
description: The Chinese are celebrating the Year of the Dragon, but the fashion world, which marches to its own beat, has declared this the Year of the Python. A nonpoisonous snake certainly presents no problem to young men who strut about the city in warm weather wearing their pet pythons like feather boas. Others just carry them. As winter turns to spring, real python-skin clothes and accessories are appearing on the fashion-conscious. Spring coats from Yves Saint Laurent (four above left) come in natural python colors. Jackets (three below at far left) have been riched up with color by Karl Lagerfeld for Chanel. There are also python-skin trousers, shoes and bags, as well as simulated python prints on a host of surfaces: the woman at bottom right carries a python-print paper folder to match her python-print jacket. Reptile skin, which keeps reappearing in fashion, was a hallmark of the 1940's, in platform shoes and matching handbags.

title: Peach Tree Care
description: If peach trees were disfigured last year by peach leaf curl, spray before flower buds begin to open with a Bordeaux solution (copper and lime fungicide). Or spray foliage monthly throughout the season with two tablespoons of seaweed fertilizer per gallon of water; this will also check the fungus that causes this disease by strengthening the tree.

title: A Son But Never A Mama's Boy
description: MADAME DE STAEL described 18th-century Russian government as ''despotism tempered by assassination.'' The most striking example of this is the brief reign, from 1796 to 1801, of the czar Paul I, who ruled with contempt for the sensibilities and rights of the westernized elite and paid with his life.

title: Deep In the Heart Of Mexico
description: WHEN it comes to traveling well, timing is everything. There are good times and bad times to go just about everywhere. And sometimes the best time is also, sadly, the worst time. The gleaming little town of Patzcuaro, a center of Purepecha Indian culture in the lush western highlands of the Mexican state of Michoacan, is just such a place.

title: 2000 Oscars: The U.S. Needs More Prozac
description: CINEMA is a powerful medium that often serves as a giant mood ring for the body politic, especially those films that earn Oscars. ''The Best Years of Our Lives'' (1946) captured the bittersweet hopefulness of post-war America. ''Mary Poppins'' (1964) was a timely diversion for a nation smarting from the conflict over civil rights. And didn't the country emerge from the contentious Watergate era with a little ''Rocky'' (1976) in its soul?

title: Travel Advisory: Correspondent's Report; Britain's Stately Homes Seek Commoner Appeal
description: IN the genteel manner to which they were once accustomed, Britain's stately homes are rising to the latest of many challenges that have turned them from the retreats of the leisured classes to tourist attractions. A hundred years ago Britain's 800 or so rambling piles still thrived as the exclusive haunt of the aristocracy, peopled by both those who inherited their money and those who earned it by running the baths, making the beds, cooking the food and grooming the horses.

title: Easy to Like and, Finally, Hard to Forget
description: IN jazz as in the other arts, worldly success can be a decidedly mixed blessing. As the critic Max Harrison has pointed out, ''People do not object to artists deserving success -- only to their getting it.'' The bigger the triumph, the snarkier the reaction, at least among those who mistakenly believe there is an inverse relationship between accessibility and quality. From Louis Armstrong to Diana Krall, talented musicians lucky enough to crack the code of popular taste without compromising their art in the process have invariably found themselves fending off flying brickbats. Some are flung by prissy colleagues who think jazz should be packaged in plain brown wrappers, others by critics who review reputations instead of music.

title: For AOL-Time Warner, Triumph of the Hard Sell
description: America Online, of course, is a master of the hard sell, from stuffing mailboxes with free trial offers to forcing subscribers to click through ads before they can get their e-mail.

title: Private Sector; Software as a Lifesaver
description: Bill Rus, a marketing executive for Autodesk Inc. in San Rafael, Calif., gets a thrill refining his company's mapping software for clients whose needs range from checking utility lines after earthquakes to tracking elk migration. ''It's really cool stuff,'' he said. Even cooler is that because of his serendipitous affiliation with Roots for Peace, a group of California vintners working to remove land mines, Mr. Rus is also refining the software into a humanitarian tool.

title: Will Chinese Food Go the Way of Pizza?
description: IT is a long way from any kind of Chinatown to the Fashion Square Mall in this upscale Phoenix suburb. But to Richard L. Federico, the usually-packed flagship restaurant in the P. F. Chang's China Bistro chain, nestled close to Nordstrom's and convenient to the multiplex, is more representative of Chinese food's future than are the tens of thousands of mom-and-pop Chinese restaurants that pepper the Main Streets of America.

title: Paid Notice: Memorials  SHACTER, CHARLES BANKS
description: SHACTER-Charles Banks. Special Birthday wishes Dad. Mom has joined you in paradise. Missing you both with lov

title: In the Region/New Jersey; Latest Amenity at Home: High-Speed Technology
description: TORI WILLIAMSON, a 32-year-old senior Web master for Oxygen Media in Manhattan, does not consider himself a workaholic. But he says he likes being able to access the Internet from his loft apartment across the Hudson River in Hoboken at the same fast speed he has at his job when he wants to surf the net late at night or work from home.

title: New Doctors, New Services, New Hope; The Company That Brought Nassau's Medical Center Gets Good Marks So Far (but Critics Emphasize 'So Far')
description: SIX months after the county sold the Nassau County Medical Center, critics say they are pleased to find that their fears that the private owner would neglect its mission to care for the county's poor have so far proved unfounded.

title: Paid Notice: Memorials  FALCO, LOUIS
description: FALCO-Louis, 3/26/93. Dearest Louis, thank you for your love, inspiration and contributions to dance, art and theater, your family and friends. We miss you. God bless you.

title: The Murky Politics of the Hollywood Tribe
description: TO most people, the Oscar is a sleek and gleaming statuette, 13 inches high and weighty enough to be a weapon in ''Clue.'' To political commentators, though, an Academy Award is something less substantial, on the order of a Rorschach test.

title: Dining Out; Steakhouse That Really Knows Its Beef
description: I'VE been by this restaurant hundreds of times and never thought about going in. Now I can't wait to return.'' The gushing young man was not the only one impressed with the North Shore Steak House. We'd just had a knock-your-socks-off meal at this 45-year-old Great Neck survivor. Every member of our party that night had ordered steaks, and beef was definitely the way to go.

title: Israel Greets Pope With Considerable Warmth, and a Little Heat
description: There with the pope, in a red-tiled Italian convent's guesthouse overlooking the misty Sea of Galilee as dusk approached, the worldly realities of nasty Israeli politics seemed delightfully far away.

title: The Idea That Almost Got Away
description: NINE years after patenting a helicopter-deployed fishing net, Kent Thomas finally went fishing last month in New Zealand's Bay of Plenty.

title: POSTINGS: Filling in the Long-Form Questionnaire; Census Form Omits Co-ops
description: Co-op shareholders who received the long-form version of the year 2000 census questionnaire may be understandably perplexed when trying to complete it.

title: Nancy Barbash, Adam Lerner
description: Nancy Hollis Barbash, a daughter of Janet Barbash of Manhattan and the late Murray Barbash, was married last evening to Adam Howard Lerner, a son of Carole Lerner of Boca Raton, Fla., and Dr. Arthur Lerner of Armonk, N.Y. Rabbi Douglas Krantz officiated at the Metropolitan Pavilion in New York.

title: Corrections
description: An article last Sunday about the writer and eccentric Joe Gould misidentified the screenwriter of ''Joe Gould's Secret,'' the new film about him. The screenplay is by Howard A. Rodman, based on articles in The New Yorker by Joseph Mitchell; it is not by Stanley Tucci, the director.

title: Erin Lothes, Angelo Biviano
description: Erin Lynne Lothes and Dr. Angelo Bartolo Biviano were married yesterday by the Rev. Stephen C. Bicsko at St. Augustine Roman Catholic in Ossining, N.Y.

title: The Dionysian Drama of Today's Design
description: DESIGN has abandoned Socrates for Nietzsche. This is the take-away idea at the first edition of the National Design Triennial at the Cooper-Hewitt Museum. No more pure geometric shapes. No more strict correspondences between form and function. No more efforts to refine materials and production methods to their pure Platonic essence. Instead, we behold room after room of dancing stars. Fluid shapes. Appetizing colors. Laughter in the dark. Flesh.

title: The New American Worker
description: What's the difference between the dot-com billionaire, Mark Cuban, and a 16-year-old boy? Only 25 years and a billion dollars. Eccentrics, rich or otherwise, are fascinating. Boors, rich or otherwise, well, they're just boring. Mark Cuban, you're 41. Now buy yourself an interesting life.

title: Decoding the Fruit Fly
description: At their annual meeting, biologists who study the Drosophila fruit fly got a gift: a CD-ROM, courtesy of the Celera Corporation, containing the DNA code for the fly's 13,601 genes. The decoding of the fly's genome validates a bold strategy that Celera is confident will work on the human genome. The understanding of the fly's genome will be of major help in interpreting the human genome. Wings aside, the organisms have a surprising amount of genetic equipment in common. NICHOLAS WADE

title: Corrections
description: A picture caption on March 12 with an article about new settings of Bob Dylan lyrics misidentified a concert at which Mr. Dylan was shown performing. It was the ''Last Waltz'' concert in 1976 in San Francisco, not the Isle of Wight festival in 1969.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  TURNER, ROGERS. GOUACHE
description: TURNER-Rogers. Gouache still life painter died March 23 in his 91st year. Survived by sister Elizabeth Waller of Shreveport, LA, Rev. Stephen Waller of Dallas, Melinda Mangham of Lafayette, LA, and his lifelong companion Ernest R. Park of NYC.

title: Welles's Chance To Make Television Do His Bidding
description: WITH his insatiable need for the spotlight, not to mention money, Orson Welles turned television into his deadliest collaborator. Late in his life, television helped transform his image from genius to Falstaffian buffoon, that mountainous figure in a flowing black shirt trotted out to amuse Merv Griffin's audiences and shill for Paul Masson wine. But there had been a moment when Welles's connection to television might have taken a happier turn.

title: Corrections
description: An article on Thursday about campaign contributions to Democratic candidates from trial lawyers characterized the Center for Responsive Politics incorrectly. It is a nonprofit research group studying campaign contributions; it does not advocate campaign finance reform.

title: Like a Disneyland for Evenings on the Town
description: MOST evenings, Wayne Wade, 32, heads for the gym after work. But two weeknights in a row recently, Mr. Wade, who owns a women's clothing store, and his friends -- Tamika Reynolds, 29, and Maria Reyes, 22 -- all of Wheatley Heights, went to eat, drink and play at Jillian's in Farmingdale instead.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SHOUP, CARL S.
description: SHOUP-Carl S., on March 23rd, 2000 at the age of 97. Survived by his daughter, Dale S. Mayer of Center Sandwich, NH; his son, Paul S. Shoup of Charlottesville, VA; eight grandchildren and nine great-grandchildren. Memorial donations may be made to the Sandwich Caregivers, Center Sandwich, NH 03227. A memorial service will be held May 7th at 2 PM in the Baptist Meetinghouse, Center Sandwich, NH.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SPRINGER, ALEXANDER
description: SPRINGER-Alexander. March 11, 2000, Laguna Hills, CA. Dearly beloved husband of Arlene. Father of Elyse and Diane. Father-in-law of Lee. Grandfather of Josh and Zach. Brother of Jack. He worked in the composing room of The New York Times for 25 years. Donations in his name may be made to the American Lung Association.

title: Are State Laurels in Store For Leafy Douglaston Hill?
description: It is not often that one reads the words ''commuter suburb'' in a state report suggesting that a neighborhood be placed on the New York Register of Historic Places.

title: A New Prime-Time Address: The Mental Hospital
description: THE scene in the opening episode of ABC's ''Wonderland'' is harrowing. A pregnant doctor in the emergency room of a hospital patterned after the forensic psychiatric unit of New York's Bellevue intervenes when a violently unhinged patient tries to harm himself with a syringe. In the scuffle that follows, the syringe pierces the doctor's stomach.

title: Residential Sales
description: In the following reports, the ''listed at'' price is the asking price when negotiations began that ended in the sale. Time on market is from most recent listing to contract.

title: Medicare Faulted in Forgiving Over $200 Million in Debt
description: The Clinton administration improperly forgave hundreds of millions of dollars of debts owed the government by health care providers for Medicare overpayments and allowed them to continue billing Medicare for some of the questionable expenses, federal investigators have found.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  PLACZEK, ADOLF K. DOLF
description: PLACZEK-Adolf K. Dolf died peacefully at his home on March 20th, having recently celebrated his 87th birthday. Born in Vienna, he came to the United States in 1940. After serving three years in the U.S. Army, he returned to his position at the Avery Architectural Library of Columbia University. In 1960 he became Avery Librarian and Professor of Architecture. Upon his retirment in 1980, he continued, with unfailing grace and erudition, to devote himself to the preservation of the architectural heritage of his adopted country. He is survived by his wife, Beverley, by a large and extended family, by those beloved people chosen as family, and by his sister and brother-in-law, Susan and Paul Stern, their children and grandchildren. In memory of Dolf and in lieu of flowers, donations may be made to Buildings of the United States or to Doctors Without Borders. A memorial service will be held at Calvary Church, Park Avenue at 21st Street, on April 9th at 5:00 P.M.

title: Personal Business; Apply Now. But Learn The Interest Rate Later.
description: IN recent years, consumers have found plenty of reasons to complain about companies that issue credit cards. High interest rates. Less time to pay bills (and hefty penalties for being a day late). Fees for exceeding credit limits. Balances computed in new ways, to the customer's disadvantage. New, sometimes more onerous terms when accounts are sold to another company.

title: For Putin and Markets, the Hard Part Starts
description: BORIS G. FEDOROV, the former Russian finance minister and one-time head of the state tax service, knows an expatriate Russian couple who put a large chunk of their money into Russian stocks in December. Since then, they have doubled their stake and bought a house.

title: Cortlandt Settles
description: As the jury was being selected in Federal District Court in White Plains last week to hear a case against Cortlandt, the town, at the urging of Judge Charles L. Brieant 3d, agreed to pay 18 members of its defunct police department $1.9 million.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  KIRSHNER, JANET
description: KIRSHNER-Janet. One day before her 67th birthday a force of nature has left us too soon. She was the center of many people's lives. Husband Les, daughter Lizzie and her husband Andy, son Jonny & his wife Esty, grandchildren Matty, Jessie, Elie & Ari and her very large extended family of friends will miss her vital presence. Funeral services on Sunday, March 26, 9:30 A.M., at Schwartz Brothers, 114-03 Queens Boulevard, Forest Hills. In lieu of flowers, please make donation to your favorite charity.

title: The Guide
description: Best Bet

title: More Water for Shepaug River
description: A BATTLE between the city of Waterbury and the towns of Washington and Roxbury, along with several environmental groups, over the water rights of the Shepaug River has finally ended with a judge's decision that Waterbury increase the flow of water in the river. Some environmentalists said the decision will have a far-reaching impact.

title: Warm Memories
description: To the Editor:

title: A Dose of Beckett in Montclair
description: Who's afraid of Samuel Beckett? Many theatergoers, even many actors, but not Louis Zorich or Olympia Dukakis, to whom he is married, or Jane Mandell, artistic director of Luna Stage in Montclair.

title: Trail Blazers Trying To Regain Their Path
description: In Joe Kleine's 15-year career, he could not remember a regular-season game more hyped and anticipated than the one between the Portland Trail Blazers and the Los Angeles Lakers on Feb. 29.

title: Political Briefing; What's in a Name? Secret Service Knows
description: When Secret Service agents talk into their sleeves while protecting presidential candidates, they almost always refer to their charges by code names seemingly picked at random -- Dasher for Jimmy Carter, Rawhide for Ronald Reagan, Eagle for Bill Clinton, Sundance for Al Gore.

title: Q&A/Stanley Pottinger; Novel Issue: If Brain Could Be Rid of Bias
description: SUPPOSE there were a way to give police officers a psychological test to determine if they were racially biased and a scan to determine where in the brain the bias resided? Suppose there were a way to eliminate the bias altogether?

description: Tally Last Week in Connecticut, New Jersey and New York.

title: Please Don't Eat The Daisy Hair Gel
description: MOP hair products, packaged in medicinal-looking bottles with tiny lettering, have been selling briskly at Fred Segal in Los Angeles. Now MOP (that's Modern Organic Products) is heading east to see if New Yorkers have an appetite for shampoos and conditioners with ingredients like sage, artichoke, carrot puree and olive oil. One happy customer is Caroline Coleman, a senior producer at the advertising agency Bates U.S.A., who likes the basil mint shampoo and a leave-in conditioner with echinacea and dandelions. ''It makes my hair feel healthy,'' she said of a line that also includes a hair-molding cream made with licorice, marshmallow and orange peel. ''We made them sound like they would be good enough to eat,'' said Laurence Hegarty, a senior vice president of MOP, which is owned by a subsidiary of Revlon. Priced in the $13-to-$20 range, they are available at Barneys and the Louis Licari hair salon. MONIQUE P. YAZIGI

title: IDEAS & TRENDS: Flash Points; Global Trade Meets The Lure of the Gun
description: FOR seven years now, Bill Clinton has been chanting the mantra that countries that invest in education and focus on the Web are far more likely to prosper than those that measure their power in kilotons and argue over bleak pieces of real estate.

title: Gerri Baer, Daniel Isaac
description: Dr. Gerri Rosalyn Baer, a daughter of Barbara and Melvin Baer of Fayetteville, N.C., and Dr. Daniel David Isaac, a son of Etta and Edward Isaac of Jamaica Estates, Queens, were married last evening. Rabbi Frank Fischer officiated at the George Watts Hill Alumni Center at the University of North Carolina at Chapel Hill.

title: Our Towns; Lots of Blame, Few Answers In Nassau
description: THE route to power in county government used to lead to the fourth floor of the executive office building, through a locked wooden door and down a hallway into the expansive dark-wood and red-carpeted office of County Executive Thomas S. Gulotta. Now it's a trail through The Lost Empire of Nassau County.

title: Man Accused of Murder in Fight, One Day After Kin Dies in Fire
description: One day after a man fell 15 stories to his death while trying to escape a fire in his apartment on Friday, the dead man's cousin was arrested on murder and assault charges, the police said yesterday.

title: Enough for All
description: To the Editor:

title: Biz.Com
description: The Cluetrain Manifesto

title: Practical Traveler; Renaissance Loses Insurers
description: TWO recent telephone calls about Renaissance Cruises were coincidental, but they led me to a glimmering of a tempest brewing. A classmate wanted to tell me what a wonderful cruise she and her husband had taken in the South Pacific. Several months earlier they had booked a 900-odd-square-foot suite with wraparound balcony on one of the company's five identical new vessels, which carry 684 passengers, all adults. She hates the heat and has back problems, so when they went in February, she skipped the rougher shore excursions. Her vacation seemed a bargain, she said: $5,000 for two, including air fare between Los Angeles and Tahiti.

title: Quick Bite/Piscataway; Four Seasons, With Plenty of Seasoning
description: When patrons sit down to dine at their small Thai restaurant, the waiter sits down a pitcher of water and Styrofoam cups. The menu tells the rest of the story: Diners can select their food 's range of spiciness - from not spicy to hot. Choose the latter, and the menu bids you fair warning: ''We mean it! Be prepared for the tears. Suggested only for pros or the truly daring.''

title: Mufti Says That Israel Uses Holocaust 'to Win Sympathy'
description: The mufti of Jerusalem, who is scheduled to meet with Pope John Paul II on Sunday, said today that he was fed up with ''the way Israel uses the Holocaust to win sympathy'' and to avoid international censure for its behavior toward the Palestinians.

title: Dancing An Ode To a Fallen Prince
description: AS far as Russian czars go, Paul I is not exactly a household name in the West or a likely subject for a ballet. Unlike his mother, Catherine the Great, he was not even worth a costume drama with a film superstar (Marlene Dietrich in ''The Scarlet Empress'').

title: VIEW; There's Nothing Like a Dame, and She's on a Comeback
description: A SCENE from a reporter's notebook, winter 1993. There is a storm of biblical proportions, and I am on my way to interview Kitty Carlisle Hart, who clowned with the Marx brothers and became the chairwoman of the New York State Council on the Arts. We are to tour the boroughs; Mrs. Hart is off to visit struggling theater companies in Bedford-Stuyvesant and bring cheer to ballerinas in Red Hook. The airports have closed, and out my window in the early morning I see herculean rain. Mrs. Hart is snappish with me on the telephone when I call in the hope that she will cancel. ''We never let the weather slow us down,'' she said.

title: Dreams and Knowledge, Under One Roof
description: THAT magical place on 113th Street between Broadway and Amsterdam is often crowded. Which is not surprising, because this library branch, near Columbia University, is the size of what passes for a three-bedroom apartment in Manhattan. Every nook of the 1,700-square-foot space is filled with books, magazines, encyclopedias, videotapes, income tax forms and so forth.

title: Political Briefing; Republicans Facing An Abortion Battle
description: Leaders of the abortion rights movement in the Republican Party say they will risk precipitating a noisy, divisive fight at this summer's Republican National Convention if the party insists on keeping an anti-abortion plank in its platform.

title: Jazz Weekend at the Shore
description: Some of the best jazz musicians in the country will gather in Cape May on the weekend of April 7, 8 and 9 at the Cape May Jazz Festival to pay tribute to Louis Armstrong as a commemoration of his 100th birthday this year.

title: Bulletproof Vests Going to Dogs
description: BECAUSE serving on the police force of this city is often risky not only for people but also for the six members of the K-9 division, bulletproof vests for both divisions are fast becoming de rigeur here.

title: Sports of The Times; As Their Profession Changes, Coaches' Old Guard Is Changing Too
description: JUST before Friday's regional semifinal game between Oklahoma State and Seton Hall, Eddie Sutton and Tommy Amaker made the customary walk to midcourt to shake hands. Sutton, the 64-year-old Oklahoma State head coach, smiled at the 34-year-old Amaker and said, ''I've been coaching longer than you are old.''

description: ROCANELLI-Fred Louis, of Bay Ridge, Brooklyn on March 24, 2000. Beloved son of Louis and Theresa Rocanelli. Loving brother of Linda and Andrea. Devoted uncle of Olivia, Elena and Simone. Dear brother-in-law of Frank Falcone and Todd Veale. Friends may call at McLaughlin Funeral Home, (97th St and 3rd Ave), 718-238-3600. Mass of Christian Burial, St. Andrew's RC Church, Ridge Boulevard and 67th St to be announced. Interment Greenwood Cemetery. And if one candidate is a Democrat in a heavily Democratic district who has also been endorsed by the Republican, Conservative and Working Families Parties, the race would seem a sure bet for obscurity.

title: The New American Worker

Surely, she knows that since 1984 the United Farm Workers of America has maintained a boycott of nonunion table grapes. The secretary of Labor may be a very busy woman, but justice for farm workers ought to be high on her list of priorities.

description: It was taking a while for Ralph Wilkerson to get around to eating all the squirrel meat that had been in his freezer since he and his son brought it home from their hunting jaunts last fall.

title: The New American Worker
description: Much of your celebration of the new American worker reminded me of the way in which politicians will exaggerate or extrapolate a few examples to paint a generalization and scare a majority of the electorate. What percentage of the population are Internet millionaires, successful freelancers or high-powered consultants? Was your intent to scare the rest of us stuck in old-economy serfdom?

description: IN Havana, everything waits. Forty-one years after Fidel Castro came down from the hills to claim the then-vibrant capital, the island has become, says photographer Stephen Crowley, ''a giant waiting room.''

description: To the Editor:

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SCHECTER, MARTHA (NEE JOSEFSBERG)
description: SCHECTER-Martha (nee Josefsberg). Died peacefully March 24, 2000 after a brief illness. Beloved wife of the late Martin H. Schecter. Devoted mother of Richard and William. Loving mother-in-law of Aileen, devoted grandmother of Robert and Daniel. Loving sister of Albert and the late Sylvia Josefsberg. Private service and interment.

title: Dining Out; Serious About Food? An Italian Contender
description: SEVERAL years ago, Peppercorn's Grill in downtown Hartford had a major makeover in its menu and interior. The stylish decor became a match for the elegant contemporary Italian menu. Once rated Very Good for robust, earthy food, the new Peppercorn's is considerably more polished and sophisticated, now deserving of an Excellent rating.

title: Citizen Canine
description: It is a definitive sign that a culture is enjoying an extended period of peace and prosperity when it is able to extend all of its creature comforts to its creatures. As a devoted dog owner, I've been particularly aware of this trend for some time: the widening application of our own ways and wants to those whose DNA allotment has left them exasperatingly shy of being able to tell us themselves what they desire -- although even this age-old divide between us and dogs may soon be bridged. I heard an interview on the radio not long ago with a man who claims to have built a machine that translates barking into English. He cued up one of his dog's most frequent utterings. I ran to turn up my radio. This was, after all, a moment mankind has dreamed of since about the dawn of consciousness.

title: If Beauty Rules Inside Mile, Where's Sense?
description: WILL it be the story of the kindly abortionist in rural Maine? The Philadelphia child psychiatrist with problems he doesn't know he has? The tobacco industry whistle-blower in Kentucky? The fine human being of a guard and his mysteriously powerful new inmate in a Depression-era Southern prison? Or the disillusioned suburbanite in the mood for change?

title: The Giants Help Counter Violence
description: FOR people who earn their living pounding their opponents into the ground, it may seem an unusual cause to champion. But the New York Giants are sponsors of My Sisters' Place, a shelter for battered women in Mamaroneck, and last Sunday two players took part in a fund-raiser at The Westchester mall here.

title: STUCK IN TRAFFIC
description: New Jersey drivers spend an average of 34 hours a year sitting still in traffic, wasting 72 gallons of gasoline each, according to a New Jersey Institute of Technology study released last week. Drivers in Somerset County are stuck on the road the most, averaging 74 hours of lost time, and Bergen drivers are second, with 62 hours. Cape May County drivers fare the best with 1.89 hours a year. KAREN DeMASTERS

title: Food; Bite of Spring
description: A sprout is the initial thrust, a spindly hope arching toward the light. Having burst from its dark and self-contained world, a sprout is neither what it was -- a possibility within a bean -- nor the fully realized plant that it will become.

title: Mari Kim Coleman, Lars Novak
description: Mari Kim Coleman, a daughter of Rosemary Goodman of Englewood, N.J., and Dr. John W. Coleman of New York, was married yesterday to Lars Theurer Novak, the son of Sigrid and Darryl Novak of South Orange, N.J. The Rev. Mark Hallinan performed the ceremony at the Roman Catholic Church of St. Ignatius Loyola in New York.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  MARCUS, LILIAN KAPLAN
description: MARCUS-Lilian Kaplan. Beloved wife of the late Ben S. Marcus, devoted mother of Judith (Alan) Chyten and Ina Ross, adored Sabta of Marc, Robin, Richard, Kimberly, Stan, David and Jonathan. Treasured great grandmother of Eric Marcus and Lindsay Nicole Ross, Stephanie Elyse and Matthew Brian Pilavin. Sister of Dr. Louis Kaplan (and the late Esther Sabbah, Hannah Marcus, Dr. Nathan Kaplan). She was a woman of extraordinary intelligence and commitment: to her family, whom she nurtured and supported, to Hadassah, serving on the L.I. Board and writing a Hebrew column for the Nat'l magazine, to United Jewish Appeal where she served as co-chair of Greater New York Women's Division and on the Speakers Bureau, to the founding and support of Jewish Education with her husband: Shenkar Textile College in Israel, the Lilian & Ben Marcus pre-school in Jerusalem and the David Posnack School in Florida. She served on the New York Board of Jewish Education, the America-Israel Cultural Foundation, CLAL, the Hillcrest Jewish Center. All who knew her respected her intellectual ability and generosity of self. A lady of grace, dignity and elegance who filled our lives with love and beauty. She will be missed because she is irreplaceable. May G-d bless and keep both Lilian and Ben. May their souls be bound up in the Book of Life. Graveside services will be held at Beth David Cemetery, Elmont, NY on Sunday, March 26, at 2:30 PM. Shiva will be at the home of Ina Ross, 37 Somerset Drive South, Great Neck, NY

title: Habitats/Brooklyn; Finding an Apartment Across From the Office
description: ONE problem with being young, hard-working and successful in New York is that there is no time to find a place to live, especially when the best apartments seem to be snapped up immediately.

description: Most mergers require lawyers to scrutinize the fine print. But what happens when the lawyers and clients are the same and the merger unites three law firms in three different time zones?

description: I am a college student who listens to music I download from the Internet. This is probably illegal and in a sense it is stealing. Can I continue to do it, just as many ethical people jaywalk? Or is this akin to walking into a store and stealing something? /Anonymous, New Jersey

If the settlement is approved by the judge overseeing the case, each woman will get at least $450,000. The suit, which was filed 23 years ago, charges that the women were denied jobs and promotions with the service. IRVIN MOLOTSKY

The living room was emptied of all but a couch, a table and a couple of pairs of socks balled up in the corner. Over the din, a dozen young Internet entrepreneurs swapped business plans and financing tips, gushing over the millions they hoped to make when their companies went public.

title: Think Digging a Hole Is Simple? Think Again
description: DIGGING a hole can be hard work, but the job can be made easier if you have the right tools. Before breaking ground, call your local utility companies and outline your plans. Have them come to the site and locate and mark any underground water, gas, electrical and drainage lines, and telephone and television cables. Cutting into one of these can disrupt service and possibly injure or kill you. These line markings are only approximate, so to be on the safe side, avoid digging within two feet of them.

title: Great Inagua

title: Holbrooke's Campaign
description: Richard C. Holbrooke has a taste for melodrama and derring-do that is practically archaic in the modern world of diplomacy. One epigram Holbrooke uses in ''To End a War,'' a cliffhanging account of his role in the negotiations to end the war in Bosnia, is a quotation from Melville: ''I am tormented with an everlasting itch for things remote. I love to sail forbidden seas, and land on barbarous coasts.'' Holbrooke has a whole stock of literary passages and phrases he likes to quote. Another one comes from Yeats, and has to do with ''the fascination with what's difficult.'' Holbrooke, who since last August has been the United States ambassador to the United Nations, told me that he recited this one to his staff in November as his plane was landing in East Timor. Since the United Nations had authorized a major peacekeeping operation in East Timor, Holbrooke had a perfectly valid reason to fly halfway around the world in order to spend two days there. But East Timor was also the most barbarous coast he could find. Holbrooke has to go looking for danger these days. His current job calls for him to spend most of his time in Manhattan and Washington.

description: Marion Dewar Bell, a daughter of Marion Bell of San Antonio and James Michael Bell of Fredericksburg, Tex., was married yesterday to Jonathan Barcroft Fairbanks, a son of Shannon Fairbanks and Richard M. Fairbanks III of Washington.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  DORF, MARTIN E.
description: DORF-Martin E., 54, died Stamford, CT. A leading architect and designer, he specialized in restaurant, retail and entertainment projects. He completed the awardwinning design for the California Grill restaurant at the Contemporary Hotel in Disney World. He was inducted into Hospitality Design Magazine's Platinum Circle for lifetime achievement. Mr. Dorf was born in Brooklyn and graduated from The City College School of Architecture in New York. He formed his own firm, Dorf Associates in 1979. He wrote ''Restaurants That Work''. For 10 years he was an instructor at Parsons School of Design in New York and he lectured nationwide. Mr. Dorf is survived by his loving wife of 20 years, Ivonne, his daughter, Jodi Warum of Flushing, NY, sister, Rebecca Schaffer of Manalapan, NJ, mother, Ruth of Tamarac, FL and two grandchildren. His adventurous spirit will be remembered and cherished by his loving family and loyal friends. Donations may be made in his memory to Memorial Sloan - Kettering, 1275 York Avenue, New York, NY 10021.

title: Watching as a Country Remembers Its Nightmares
description: THE sunny kitchen here could not be further from the South African homes and hearing rooms where Frances Reid and Deborah Hoffmann filmed their new documentary, ''Long Night's Journey Into Day: South Africa's Search for Truth and Reconciliation.'' Yet it's in this very kitchen that it all began. ''You were reading the first newspaper account of the testimonies over by the counter,'' Ms. Reid recalls. ''No, not there,'' Ms. Hoffmann says. ''I'm sure I was over here, sitting at the table and drinking coffee.'' Then they laugh at the incongruity of such a disagreement from a pair of filmmakers who have spent the past three years fixated on nothing but memory, documenting the remarkable process for remembering institutionalized by South Africa in its Truth and Reconciliation Commission.

title: The Grandeur That Was Roman Glass
description: TO the ancient Romans, glass was magical, a commodity with star potential that was never fully realized by the Greeks. Awed by the transparency and fragility of glass, the Romans in the reign of Augustus (27 B. C. to A. D. 14) transformed its production from a craft to an industry. And the process spanned several decades, about as long it took to develop the computer in the late 20th century.

title: Steve Phillips's Winter of Content
description: In the wee hours last Oct. 20, Kenny Rogers threw his last pitch for the New York Mets, ball four to Andruw Jones of the Atlanta Braves, walking in the winning run in the 11th inning. It was a moment of startling anticlimax, bringing to an abrupt, pallid end an otherwise nerve-jangler of a ballgame, the equally vivid National League Championship Series and, just short of a consummating subway World Series against the Yankees, the Mets' whole preposterously titillating and melodramatic season.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  FISHMAN, JACK, M.D.
description: FISHMAN-Jack, M.D. Of NYC and Delray Beach, FL at age 91. We deeply mourn the loss of our loving father. He was a dedicated surgeon and compassionate family practitioner in NYC for over half a century. During the Second World War he was a Lieutenant Commander in the U.S. Navy, where he was critically wounded. He served on numerous hospital staffs before his retirement. He taught at NY Medical College and was published in medical journals and textbooks. He passed away earlier this year at his home in Florida. We miss him greatly.

title: Call It Modern Clamming, or Strip-Mining
description: WHEN most Long Island baymen harvest hard clams it is a simple and laborious process. A rake is lowered to the bottom in a few feet or a few fathoms of water. The bayman scratches in the sand for his prize, then muscles the long, heavy tool to the surface. If he does it all day long, and if he has a little luck, he'll have a few bushels of clams.

title: Ruling on Cuban Boy
description: The international custody battle over 6-year-old Elian Gonzalez seems to be nearing a conclusion. After a federal judge in Miami concluded that only Attorney General Janet Reno can grant the boy asylum, Ms. Reno said Elian should be reunited with his father in Cuba in a prompt, orderly fashion. Lawyers for both sides wrangled over just how, and if, that would be accomplished. The government wants lawyers for Elian's relatives in Miami to agree to a speedy timetable for any appeal of the ruling, but the lawyers have balked. RICK BRAGG

title: Handling A Dispute On Parking
description: Q I own a co-op apartment and rent a parking space from the co-op corporation for $48.83 a month, plus taxes. On several occasions, I have come home during business hours to find an employee of the co-op parked in my spot. I have asked the management office on several occasions, without success, not to park in my spot. Do I have any legal recourse since I have a parking agreement with the co-op and have not violated any parking rules? . . . Laura Ploetzke, Mineola, N.Y.

title: THEATER; Between Countries, Genders and Genres
description: IT'S funny, I'm not really English anymore and I'm not really American. What am I?'' So asks Elsie, the 80-year-old war bride in ''The English Rose of Indiana,'' one of the nine monologues and duets that make up my latest show, ''Betwixt.''

title: Clarinetists Are a Duo on Stage and in Life
description: DURING 44 years of mar riage and what they call parallel careers as clarinetists -- Stanley and Naomi Drucker have never performed a joint recital. True, Mr. Drucker, 71, the principal clarinetist of the New York Philharmonic who has been with the orchestra for 52 years, often played in chamber groups and orchestras with Ms. Drucker, who has taught at Hofstra University for 30 years and is the co-founder and co-director of the American Chamber Ensemble. This summer, in fact, Mrs. Drucker, who said, ''I don't speak about age,'' will join the Philharmonic and her husband on a European tour as the orchestra's ''extra'' clarinetist.

title: Tenor as Villain: Quaint Notion, but Can It Work Today?
description: STONE guests make grim company. Ask Don Giovanni. Or Zampa, the pirate king in Ferdinand Herold's opera by that name. As Mount Etna erupts in the background (the scene is in Sicily), the scoundrel ends up crushed in the embrace of the statue of Alice Manfredi, a 16-year-old Florentine he seduced and abandoned a decade before the curtain rises. His fate had begun to look dire in the finale of the second of three acts, when the statue refused to surrender a wedding ring he had impiously slipped on its finger. In the meantime he prudently had the stone maiden tossed in the sea. To no avail, and her show-stopping revenge well justifies the opera's alternative title, ''La Fiancee de Marbre,'' or ''The Marble Bride,'' even though -- unlike her booming fatherly counterpart in Mozart -- Alice utters not a sound.

description: The cost of stretching out for a good night's sleep on a flight to London has just fallen 40 percent. Until now, a seat that flattened into a bed was available in first class only, but Virgin Atlantic and British Airways are starting to sell business-class seats that convert to six-foot-long beds.

title: Small Specks of Paradise In a Wide Ocean
description: BOUNCING back to my bungalow atop a squeaky, road-weary bicycle, I savored the pastel sunset I'd just admired from the boulder-strewn beach at Anse Source d'Argent on the Seychelles island of La Digue. But my mind jettisoned that image when I passed Zerof's Restaurant and smelled the aroma of lemony grilled fish adorned with garlic, ginger, nutmeg, and pepper. Funny, I hadn't been the least bit hungry until that moment. But now, following some Pavlovian instinct, I pedaled even faster to sooner enjoy the dinner being prepared for me at that moment.

On their own, however, outside the ennobling frame of a gallery or the design wing of a museum, no one would mistake them for works of art. You wouldn't need a Ph.D. to recognize metaphorical speech if someone remarked about a basketball, ''Now that's a work of art.''

The company said it wanted to concentrate on higher-growth markets like broadband communications and Internet telephony, implying that plain old modems, which let computers send and receive data over wires, had become a boring commodity.

title: PrivateSector; Software as a Lifesaver
description: Bill Rus, a marketing executive for Autodesk Inc. in San Rafael, Calif., gets a thrill refining his company's mapping software for clients whose needs range from checking utility lines after earthquakes to tracking elk migration. ''It's really cool stuff,'' he said. Even cooler is that because of his serendipitous affiliation with Roots for Peace, a group of California vintners working to remove land mines, Mr. Rus is also refining the software into a humanitarian tool.

title: New York City's New Dreams
description: The headlines nowadays are filled with ambitious proposals to transform New York City's landscape. One day, planners unveil a scheme to stage the Olympics in the city, with a new stadium on the West Side and apartment houses for athletes on the Queens waterfront. Another day, Albany debates plans to connect the Long Island Rail Road to Grand Central Terminal or build a new Second Avenue subway. Clearly boom times are producing dreams for big projects, opening a potential new chapter in the city's self-renewal. But dreams also entail tough decisions. It is far from obvious how best to use limited resources for urban growth.

title: Tableware as History: You Are Where You Eat
description: FROM the Fairmont markets to antique fairs around the country, private dealers to eBay, Charles Venable has been collecting dishes. In under a decade, Dr. Venable, the deputy director and chief curator of decorative arts at the Dallas Museum of Art, and his staff have assembled an encyclopedic collection of ceramic and glass tableware used in America over the last century.

title: On Park Bench, Another Jolt In a Bumpy Life; Moved Along by the Police, A Soviet Emigre Vanishes
description: Some Soviet dissidents became international symbols of human rights. Nikolai G. Tolstykh, like thousands of others, served his political imprisonment in obscurity. Confined for years in labor camps for anti-Soviet propaganda in the 1980's, Mr. Tolstykh was nearly 40 and estranged from his wife and son by the time a thaw in the cold war cracked open his cell door and sent him to America.

title: AILING HOSPITALS
description: New Jersey hospitals are among the weakest in the nation financially, with most losing money in 1998 and 1999, according to a report issued earlier this month by Standard and Poor's in New York City. More than half of the hospitals in the state lost money in 1998, double the number from the previous year. The losses were attributed to a growing number of uninsured people, longer stays in hospitals for Medicare patients, whose care is not always fully reimbursed, low payments by managed care networks and the bankruptcy of two New Jersey HMO's in 1998. KAREN DeMASTERS

title: Anti-Gay Bias in Military
description: A Pentagon report found that anti-homosexual harassment in the American military remains widespread, especially in the form of offensive remarks and gestures. The survey, ordered after a gay soldier was beaten to death last July at Fort Campbell, Ky., also found that an overwhelming majority of service members believe their superiors and colleagues tolerate harassment ''to some extent.'' STEVEN LEE MYERS

title: Personal Business; Food Fights
description: For overworked Americans, the two-martini lunch has turned into the two-minute lunch, or a series of hurried snacks, consumed at the desk or in a Spartan break room. Etiquette hasn't kept up. Half-eaten sandwiches are stolen from their owners' desks, while office mircrowaves and refrigerators ooze with months of grime. And few workplaces seem to have any desktop-dining rules. Send your spiciest stories to On the Job, Money & Business, The New York Times, 229 West 43rd Street, New York, N.Y. 10036. Or send them by e-mail to onthejob@nytimes.com Include your name and telephone number. All submissions become the property of The Times and may be republished in any medium.

title: STATE INCREASES
description: Increases in school spending by the state were recommended last week by David Hespe, state commissioner of education. The recommendations, once adopted by the Legislature, will be used to calculate state aid to school districts for the 2001-2002 school year. The numbers have to be revised every other year. The largest increase would be for handicapped students, giving districts $6,607 for each severely handicapped student; they now receive $4,207. Mr. Hespe recommended an $830 increase, for elementary students for a total of $7,913 per student, to reduce class sizes from 21 to 18 and to help in teaching foreign language, which is mandated under the state's new core curriculum standards. title: Coffeehouses Are Making a Comeback

Weren't they tapping their Birkenstocks and hush puppies to this same song, made famous by Peter, Paul and Mary, more than 30 years ago?

title: From the Mouths of Great Grandmothers
description: The term children's literature gets a double meaning with Bronwen DeSena. Her book, ''Babu's Babushka,'' is a fairy tale about a Ukrainian woman and her magic scarf. It is aimed at readers ages 4 to 8. Its author, who wrote it last year at age 11, is a sixth grader at Sparta Middle School. The book resulted from her winning a writing competition run by Raintree Steck-Vaughan Publishers, a branch of Harcourt, and she also received the Young Writer's Award from the Alexander Fischbein Foundation of New York. The book was inspired by stories she heard from her great-grandmother (her ''babu''), Eva Davidyock, whose parents immigrated from Ukraine. (The book is illustrated by Linda Hail Zucker, whose great-grandparents also came fom Ukraine.) Bronwen is making a book tour, like grownup authors, though not far from home: at her first signing, in Sparta, all 125 books on hand were sold, and others are on order. She will appear next month in stores in Newton, Rockaway and Stanhope. The book, which lists at $5.99, is also sold online.

title: ON THE MAP; A Master's Stained Glass Illuminates a Bayonne Church
description: St. Vincent De Paul in Bayonne is the only American church with tained-glass windows by Harry Clarke, considered by some to have been Ireland's foremost stained-glass artist. Clarke, part of the Arts and Crafts Movement of the late 19th and early 20th centuries, developed a distinctive use of colors and mastered the process of fusing painted pieces of glass. The 40 panels include a depiction of George Washington praying in Morristown and a priest traveling by sleigh to visit Roman Catholics throughout northern New Jersey. The model for the window was Father Richard Bulgar, who visited worshipers around 1820, before Catholic churches were built in this part of the state.

title: Life in Parma

The focus on this beautiful northern city was interesting, showing how from something as small as a violet a picture of a place can be suggested. The author captures a courtly feeling present even today.

title: Thinking Like a Town, Working Like a Region; From Economic Development to Traffic Flow, Municipalities Learn to Join Their Neighbors
description: FOR hundreds of years, Connecticut government has been organized along town lines, often set by the distance of a comfortable Sunday horse-and-buggy drive to church on the central green. The result is that Connecticut still has 169 towns and no regional branch of government to link them.

title: Court Rules on Student Fees
description: The First Amendment protects the right to speak -- and sometimes the right not to speak. No one can be forced to salute the flag, for example. Conservative college students have argued that they should not have to support causes they disagree with through mandatory student activity fees. Rejecting that argument, the Supreme Court said the overall quantity of speech at universities mattered more. Unbounded debate is central to a university's mission, the court said, and mandatory fees are constitutional as long as the money collected is distributed without regard to viewpoint. LINDA GREENHOUSE

title: School Newspapers And Free Speech
description: In its landmark decision some 30 years ago establishing student rights in public schools, the Supreme Court stated, ''constitutional rights do not stop at the schoolhouse gate.'' The role of the school administration is to encourage responsible expression of student opinion, not to recall the newspaper.

title: The New American Worker
description: The same drive that allows your big-city real estate agent to pack so much into her professional life robs her own family of attention. In a span of 41 hours, Barbara Corcoran denies the request of her 6-year-old son to read to him during a break from her workout with her trainer; upsets him with news that she has to go out for the night; wakes him when she gets home, at 9, and sings him back to sleep. She calls her husband from a business trip and tells him to join her, warning, ''You can stay with me but I'm working and won't be able to pay any attention to you.'' She leaves her son a ''goodnight message-song'' on the answering machine at 11. Not exactly quality time, but hey, when the going gets tough! . . .

I recognized the name with a jolt: in college almost 20 years earlier, I had daily walked past the name Delbert Tibbs painted on an Illinois Central railway overpass. Convicted in 1974 for a rape and murder he did not commit, Tibbs spent three years on Florida's death row before he was vindicated.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  LOEB, ENID
description: LOEB-Enid. On March 25, 2000, after a long illness. Enid was alive and vital right to the end. She is survived by her loving daughter Marcie Auerbach and son-in-law Alan, as well as her adored grandsons Jason and Philip. The family will always be grateful for the love, care and devotion of her dear friend Joan Linton. Enid gave more than 50 years of community service in addition to her professional career and was a life member of the National Council of Jewish Women, NY Section. Enid initially stared working as a volunteer at Metropolitan Hospital in the Pediatrics Project where she later co-chaired the Pediatric AIDS Project. Most recently, she served on the Council Senior Center Committee where she founded the Jacob M. Hirsch Memorial Library in honor of her late father. In May, she was to have been the first recipient of the Friends of Council Senior Center Award for Service. In lieu of flowers donations may be made to the Council Senior Center, 241 West 72 St, NYC 10023. A memorial service will be held at the home of Mr. and Mrs. Philip Auerbach, 565 Park Ave, at 4 PM, on Tuesday, March 28. Friends will be received until 7 PM.

title: Coming Battles for Reform

Vice President Al Gore is to announce today that his top domestic legislative priority should he win the election would be overhauling the campaign finance laws. He plans to press for prompt passage of the tough McCain-Feingold reform bill and down the road has some imaginative ideas for moving toward public financing of Congressional campaigns and free broadcast time for candidates. That should pose a salutary challenge to Gov. George W. Bush, who tirelessly proclaims himself the ''reformer with results'' but has a campaign reform proposal that is a toothless sham.

A niece of the late Bernard Baruch, she was a partner in the H. Hentz & Co. Brokerage firm on Wall Street. Marina served as Social Secretary to her late father, Dr. Herman Benjamin Baruch, during his administration as Post War Ambassador to Portugal and Holland under Presidents Roosevelt and Truman. She was a Red Cross Volunteer in New York and served as a ''Grey Lady'' at Bellevue Hospital where her late grandfather, Simon Baruch, was honored as the ''Father of Hydrotherapy.'' Marina studied interior design while in New York and became a master gardener after moving to Florida. She was also an expert bridge player and a founding member of the Osceola County, FL, Humane Society. She is survived by daughter Ann S. Reed, son Benjamin K. Symmers and stepson Bruce Doyle; five grandchildren and three greatgrandchildren. Funeral services and interment will take place in Kissimmee, FL, on Monday, March 27. title: Don't Send In the Clowns
description: The choice of ringmaster, in any case, couldn't be better. Studs Terkel, the grand old man of oral history, shows up with a shuffling, lopsided walk, an Olympian laugh and a flair for the dramatic gesture, to usher in ''House Arrest,'' Anna Deavere Smith's wide-ranging and unwieldy consideration of the circus that is the American presidency. Actually that's Mr. Terkel as channeled by Ms. Smith, who is famous for her one-woman shows in which she portrays an assortment of real people whom she has interviewed to create mosaic portraits of the state of a nation. Ms. Smith's theater pieces have often been compared to Mr. Terkel's books, and the melding of the writer and the performance artist here seems a fitting act of homage.

title: F.C.C. Heads For Showdown With Congress Over Radio Plan

title: ORCKIT, ISRAELI COMPANY, MAKES DEAL FOR SILICON VALUE
description: Orckit Communications Inc., an Israeli phone-equipment maker, agreed yesterday to buy the custom chipmaker Silicon Value Ltd. for about $140 million in stock to beef up the semiconductor unit it will spin off later this year. Orckit will pay two million shares of the closely held Silicon Value, which sells customized chips to network equipment companies like Lucent Technologies and 3Com. Orckit, based in Tel Aviv, makes modems and other gear used in digital subscriber line services. Orckit plans to spin off its semiconductor unit by June to focus on DSL products. Orckit's shares rose $1.0156, to $70.25 in Nasdaq trading.

CMD, formerly Construction Market Data Group, provides construction project information and has directories of building products and services. The Atlanta-based company had $126 million in 1999 revenue. title: Paid Notice: Deaths  POLLERT, WILLIAM
description: POLLERT-William, of Southold, Long Island, New York died on Saturday, March 25, 2000 at the age of 90. Mr. Pollert, a chemical engineer, graduated Stuyvesant High School and Cooper Union. He received his Master's degree in engineering from New York University. Mr. Pollert was the president of John Powell and Company, Inc., a multinational corporation that manufactured agricultural chemicals and insecticides. Mr. Pollert retired to Southold in 1955. He was active in the Southold Yacht Club for many years, and served as its Commodore. He was also active in the Southold Historical Society and served on their Board of Directors. Mr. Pollert organized the Jockey Creek association, a property owners association formed to prevent the over development of Jockey Creek. Mr. Pollert is survived by his wife of sixty-six years, Antoinette, his two sons and five grandchildren. In lieu of flowers the family requests donations to be made to Cooper Union. Mass of Chrisitan Burial was held at Saint Patrick's RC Church, Southold.

title: 6 of 13 Herbal Brands Fail a Label Test

A synthetic version of a chemical that naturally occurs in the body, Sam-e is used to treat depression and osteoarthritis.

title: Saudi Arabia Bridles as Rights Group Charges Widespread Abuses
description: In a sharply worded report, Amnesty International today accused the government of Saudi Arabia of widespread human rights abuses, including arbitrary arrests, the torture of detainees and the barring of prisoner access to family members or lawyers.

title: Hollywood's 'Courage'
description: Anyone who watched the Oscars on Sunday knows that the operative self-congratulatory word for the night was ''courage.'' John Irving, honored for adapting his 1985 novel ''The Cider House Rules,'' thanked the academy for honoring a film dealing with abortion and Miramax ''for having the courage to make this movie in the first place.'' The audience burst into thunderous applause when he ended by thanking ''everyone at Planned Parenthood'' and the National Abortion Rights Action League.

title: THE MARKETS: Market Place; OPEC Pricing Revisited: What a Difference 20 Years Makes. Right?
description: As the oil ministers met in Vienna, there was great concern about whether the Organization of Petroleum Exporting Countries would give the rest of the world a break and do something to restrain high oil prices. Reporters were hanging on every word from the ministers, some of whom had felt intense American diplomatic pressure. Iran took a militant position, while Saudi Arabia was more accommodative, and the meeting was extended as agreement proved elusive.

description: I wrote recently in support of the African Growth and Opportunity Act, a bill designed to provide sub-Saharan African countries with duty-free access to the U.S. for their textile and apparel exports. title: VITESSE SEMICONDUCTOR AGREES TO BUY OROLOGIC
description: The Vitesse Semiconductor Corporation agreed yesterday to buy Orologic Inc., a semiconductor designer, for $450 million in stock. Vitesse, which makes integrated circuits for telecommunications manufacturers, said the acquisition will increase its offerings in switches and routers for certain applications. Shares of Vitesse rose $4.875, to $95.9375, in Nasdaq trading. The company, which is based in Camarillo, Calif., reported revenue of $310 million for the last 12 months. Orologic, which is privately held, is based in Morrisville, N.C. It designs semiconductors, but relies on other companies to make them.

title: Putin Tells Advisers to Prepare 'Weighty' Economic Plan

Putin told his cabinet today that it was time to put ''all our work'' on a new economic program into one ''weighty document'' by the time he is sworn in and appoints his new government in early May.

title: In Geneva, Clinton Bet That Assad Would Bend, and Lost
description: The Syrian leader, Hafez al-Assad, was ''immovable'' during his meeting with President Clinton in Geneva, and appeared to have come with the misconception that Mr. Clinton was in a position to give him what he wanted from Israel, a senior administration official said today.

Certainly it was a form of exile that had worked for two of his favorite writers, Ernest Hemingway and Ezra Pound, fixtures of the Left Bank scene between the wars.

title: BATTLE FOR VIDEOTRON
description: A meeting in Montreal of shareholders of Groupe Videotron to vote on a $4 billion takeover by Rogers Communications of Toronto was adjourned until a court rules on a rival bid. On Friday, the province of Quebec's giant pension fund, the Caisse de Depot et Placement du Quebec, and the media company Quebecor made a $4.1 billion bid for Videotron. The fund has 17 percent of Videotron's voting shares and says an agreement with the Chagnon family -- which has 72 percent of the votes, pledged to Rogers in early February -- disallows a sale without its approval. Videotron has been a leader in French-language Internet development. Timothy Pritchard (NYT)

title: Grandeur in Undervalued Mozart
description: ''La Clemenza di Tito,'' the opera Mozart wrote for a coronation in Prague a few months before he died, was long undervalued but now seems absolutely immediate. Not only is it filled with great and glorious music -- strongly presented in the new City Opera production -- but it speaks to concerns that are ours. An era is passing away, and all that people feel they can trust is the world of private emotion. How, though, are they to tell the formal gesture, the attitude, from the native impulse of the heart? And can the machinery of a state go on under these circumstances?

title: Pressuring the Power Plants
description: Each new day seems to bring further proof that something must be done to limit the pollutants that originate in the coal-fired power plants of the Midwest and are carried by air currents into the Northeastern United States, where they contribute mightily to urban smog and acid rain. The latest evidence is a survey conducted by the General Accounting Office. It found a big reduction in one of the pollutants, sulfur dioxide, but a dramatic rise in another pollutant, nitrogen oxide, which is accelerating the decline of many Northeastern lakes and streams, particularly in the Adirondacks.

description: REID-Mrs. Fergus. The Officers and Directors of The Garden Club of America express deep sorrow on the death of their former President, Mrs. Fergus Reid, Jr., and extend deepest sympathy to her family and friends. Etheldreda Seabury Reid served the Garden Club with great distinction and extraordinary ability as its 13th President (1953-1956), and in many other capacities. Beginning in 1944, she served as Recording Secretary, Treasurer, Vice President, Director and Chairman of the Nominating and Policy Committees. title: OPEC Leaves Question Of Oil Increase on Table
description: The Organization of Petroleum Exporting Countries adjourned its ministerial meeting here tonight without an agreement on modest production increases, and delegates agreed to reconvene on Tuesday.

title: French Prime Minister Shuffles His Cabinet and Appoints a Rival
description: After weeks of sinking ratings in the polls, Prime Minister Lionel Jospin announced a shake-up in his cabinet today, including appointing one of his main rivals, former Prime Minister Laurent Fabius, to the important post of finance minister.

title: Tracking the Toll After 2 Breadwinners Lose Jobs
description: For a decade, Bill Moyers has been tracking the downs and ups of two blue-collar Milwaukee families, the Neumanns and the Stanleys. Both were hit hard in the early 1990's, after Tony Neumann and Claude Stanley lost their jobs at Briggs & Stratton, which, like other industrial mainstays, gave way to recession. The company cut some 4,000 jobs in Milwaukee.

title: Post-Traumatic Stress
description: To the Editor:

title: Youths Leaving Foster Care System With Few Skills or Resources
description: Thousands of young adults in New York City's foster care system, many of them neglected or abandoned during the height of the city's crack epidemic a decade ago, have been moved out of the system in recent years, forced to fend for themselves at 18 and often with little education or financial resources.

title: A Microscopic Forest Blooms
description: Talk about a fast-growth forest: a research team at Rensselaer Polytechnic Institute in Troy, N.Y., has created tiny ''trees'' using flashes of extreme heat to deposit carbon atoms in piles on a graphite surface.

title: Shares Close Lower on Declines by Microsoft and Banks
description: Major stock market averages moved lower yesterday, dragged down by financial service and bank stocks and by a big decline in Microsoft, as it slumped on reports that it remained far from any agreement to settle the government's antitrust lawsuit.

title: AVERSTAR TO BE BOUGHT BY TITAN, A CONSULTANT
description: The Titan Corporation, an information technology consulting company, agreed yesterday to buy the privately held AverStar Inc. for about $140 million in stock. It will also assume about $65 million in debt. Titan, based in San Diego, said the deal would give it the technology expertise of AverStar's employees and help Titan increase its government business. AverStar, based in Burlington, Mass., provides information technology consulting services to business and government customers. AverStar has 1,750 employees and $230 million in annual revenue. Titan has 5,400 employees and had $406.6 million in revenue last year. Titan's stock was up $4.1875 a share, to $57.4375, on the New York Stock Exchange.

title: CITIGROUP PROSPERS IN BRAZIL
description: Helped by prescient bets on the direction of currency exchange rates before Brazil's devaluation early last year, earnings at Citigroup's Brazilian unit surged more than fourfold in 1999, to $430 million. The earnings, which were also helped by expanded foreign trade financing, were the highest of any foreign bank in Brazil. Simon Romero (NYT)

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  LONDON, ANITA
description: LONDON-Anita. On March 26. Loving wife of Edward, adored sister of Stanley and Norma, beloved aunt. Graveside services were held on Monday at Mount Judah Cemetery.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  HUNTER, JAMES HEWAT ''BING''
description: HUNTER-James Hewat ''Bing''. Of Manchester, VT, Sea Island, GA and Delray Beach, FL, died Thursday, March 23rd at his home in Delray Beach. Survivors include his wife, Irene Mennen Hunter, and his four children: Elizabeth Solomon of Washington, DC, James M. Hunter of Williamstown, MA, Barbara Trotta of Mt. Kisco, NY and Susan Hunter of Dedham, MA and eleven grandchildren. Also a brother, Richard Hunter. Mr. Hunter was President and C.E.O. of the Hunter Machine Co. in North Adams, MA from 1957 until its sale in 1983. He was also a director of the Mennen Co. in Morristown, NJ until its sale to Colgate Palmolive. An ardent golfer, he was a member of the United States Seniors Golf Association, the Ekwanok Country Club, the Sea Island Golf Club, the Ocean Forrest Golf Club, the Gulf Stream Golf Club, the Country Club of Florida, the Royal Lytham St. Anne's in Scotland. He was also a trustee of the American Museum of Fly Fishing.

title: 80 More Bodies Unearthed on Ugandan Cult Leader's Land
description: Eighty more bodies were exhumed today from a mass grave discovered during the weekend on a rural plot of land once owned by a leader of a doomsday cult, which now appears to be linked to the deaths of at least 500 people.

title: G.O.P. Leader Defends Giuliani's Handling of Police Shooting
description: The Republican majority leader of the State Senate, Joseph L. Bruno, today defended Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani's response to the fatal police shooting of an unarmed black man earlier this month.

title: DaimlerChrysler Buying a Third of Mitsubishi for $2.1 Billion
description: DaimlerChrysler A.G., the world's third-largest maker of motor vehicles, signed an agreement today to invest in the Mitsubishi Motors Corporation, finally securing the toehold in Asia it had long wanted.

Burial services were held Sunday, March 26, 2000 at Maimonides Cemetery in Elmont, L.I., N.Y. Contributions in his name to the Jewish National Fund Project #

title: Lincoln Center President to Leave After 17 Years
description: Nathan Leventhal announced yesterday that he would step down as president of Lincoln Center in December after nearly 17 years in the job, through which he helped bring jazz, an adventurous summer festival and al fresco swing dancing to a bastion of opera, ballet and classical music.

title: Rutgers Gives Stringer 3rd Trip to Final Four
description: With a disruptive defense and relentess rebounding, Rutgers upset top-seeded Georgia, 59-51, in the West Regional final tonight to advance to the Women's Final Four of the National Collegiate Athletic Association tournament.

description: The crime of choice at the Metropolitan Opera -- offstage, at least -- used to be sneaking a tape recorder into the house to preserve the memory of a potentially thrilling performance. Some perpetrators compounded the misdemeanor by running off copies to turn an illicit profit.

title: Microchip Helps Paralyzed Man Walk
description: With an electronic microchip implanted in his back, Marc Merger, of Strasbourg, France, is now able to take a few halting steps for the first time in 10 years. Mr. Merger, 38, had been immobilized since his spinal cord was severed in a car crash. In a project involving six European nations, the I.B.M. Corporation and French scientists, Mr. Merger's leg muscles were stimulated by electronic charges fired by a program stored in the chip.

title: Interior Department Plans to Reduce Traffic in Yosemite
description: Long a victim of its own success, Yosemite National Park would be returned to a wilder condition with major reductions in parking spaces, roads and bridges and the elimination of buildings and other structures in the park under a plan outlined here today by Bruce Babbitt, the secretary of the interior.

title: A World of Opportunity For America's Pastime
description: The Mets and the Chicago Cubs open the baseball season tomorrow, earlier in the calendar than ever before, as well as earlier in the day. The season opener is set to begin at 5:08 a.m. Eastern time, and most fans of both teams will be able to see the game only on television -- because it will be played in Tokyo.

description: RENNA-Sam. On March 26. Survived by two sons, F. Thomas Renna of East Setauket and Richard C. Vaillant of Bucks County, Pa. and one grandchild. Viewing Wednsday evening at Divine Funeral Home, Oyster Bay. Mass of Christian burial St. Dominick's, Oyster Bay on Thurs., March 30.

description: Suddenly, everybody is talking about vice-presidential candidates. Robert Rubin? Colin Powell? Can we bring back John McCain and Bill Bradley? Tom Hanks seems like a nice person.

title: In a Competitive Market, City Runs Ads for Its Hospitals
description: For years, New York City's public hospitals have been known as health care outposts of last resort. If the Health and Hospitals Corporation, which runs them, had advertised their medical services, it would have been considered akin to Albania hawking its tourist attractions: they may exist, but who would want to go there?

title: Talks in Microsoft Case Continue as Judge's Decision Looms
description: An appointed mediator continued working feverishly this evening to work out an 11th-hour settlement in the antitrust case against Microsoft. But opinions among some of the government officials who filed the suit appeared to be hardening, setting up the likelihood that the trial judge would issue a verdict as soon as Tuesday.

description: Klaus Piper, a German publisher who helped build his family's business into one of Europe's most respected intellectual imprints, died on Saturday at his home in Munich. He was 88.
