title: 3DFX INTERACTIVE TO GET GIGAPIXEL FOR $186 MILLION
description: 3dfx Interactive Inc. agreed yesterday to acquire the privately held GigaPixel Corporation for about $186 million in stock. 3dfx, based in San Jose, Calif., develops and markets graphics cards for personal computers. GigaPixel, which is based in Santa Clara, Calif., designs chips for three-dimensional computer graphics. The acquisition will allow 3dfx to improve graphics for set-top boxes, Internet appliances and game consoles, the company said. Shares of 3dfx closed at $13.4375, up $1.50 in Nasdaq trading. The company reported revenue of $360 million for the last 12 months.

title: Albert R. Connelly, Antitrust Lawyer, 91
description: Albert R. Connelly, a retired partner at the New York law firm of Cravath, Swaine & Moore, died at his home in Manhattan last Wednesday. He was 91.

One involved the Denver Broncos and an apparent violation of league rules regarding deferred payments to John Elway, the former quarterback, and Terrell Davis, the team's star running back.

title: A REIT Considers a Spinoff
description: Home Properties of New York Inc., a real estate investment trust, said today that it was considering spinning off or selling part or all of its affordable-housing development subsidiary, the Conifer Realty Corporation. Home Properties has hired Mercury Partners to help it evaluate strategic alternatives. Home Properties said a sale or spinoff of Conifer would allow it to concentrate on owning and operating market-rate apartment communities, while Conifer continued to develop new properties.

title: Robust Economy Is Contributing To a Loss of Affordable Housing
description: While the nation enjoys continuing prosperity, affordable housing for many of the working poor has become harder to find, a federal report said today.

title: Front Row; The new buzz on Fifth Avenue: Henri Bendel, once so calm and staid, kicks back and joins the race for the youth market.
description: A few months ago, Henri Bendel introduced a line of hippie-ish embroidered clothes designed by a young woman who made a name for herself helping the very good-looking look more like regular people -- or at any rate, television's version of regular people. The designer, Debra McGuire, has worked as a costume designer on ''Friends,'' as well as other network series. From his fourth-floor office at Bendel's recently, Ed Burstell, the store's vice president and general manager, rattled off Ms. McGuire's other credits, which he was fairly certain included ''Jesse'' and ''Jack & Jill.''

title: Much-Feared Gang Leader Draws a 25-Year Sentence
description: Leonard McKenzie, a founding member of the East Coast Bloods and one of Brooklyn's most feared gang leaders, received the maximum sentence yesterday -- 25 years to life in prison -- for shooting a man last year in a bodega in Brownsville.

title: THE MARKETS: COMMODITIES
description: GOLD FALLS. Gold fell to its lowest price in three and a half months after a report that the French government was under pressure to sell some reserves. In New York, gold for April delivery fell $4.60, to $280.50 an ounce.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  LOEB, ENID
description: LOEB-Enid. On March 25, 2000, after a long illness. Enid was alive and vital right to the end. She is survived by her loving daughter Marcie Auerbach and son-in-law Alan, as well as her adored grandsons Jason and Philip. The family will always be grateful for the love, care and devotion of her dear friend Joan Lynton. Enid gave more than 50 years of community service in addition to her professional career and was a life member of the National Council of Jewish Women, NY Section. Enid initially started working as a volunteer at Metropolitan Hospital in the Pediatrics Project where she later co-chaired the Pediatric AIDS Project. Most recently, she served on the Council Senior Center Committee where she founded the Jacob M. Hirsch Memorial Library in honor of her late father. In May, she was to have been the first recipient of the Friends of Council Senior Center Award for Service. In lieu of flowers donations may be made to the Council Senior Center, 241 West 72 St, NYC 10023. A memorial service will be held at the home of Mr. and Mrs. Philip Auerbach, 565 Park Ave, at 4 PM, on Tuesday, March 28. Friends will be received until 7 PM.

His new offensive, begun with peace talks still underway, ultimately caused more than one million Kosovars to seek refuge and was marked by burned villages, rapes, murders and ethnic cleansing.

description: The chairman of the House Government Reform Committee asked the Justice Department today to appoint a special counsel to investigate whether the White House obstructed justice by failing to surrender e-mail messages that had been subpoenaed by Congress and other investigators.

title: Nets Try to Tell Selves That There's Still Hope
description: The most light-hearted part of Nets practice is usually the final few minutes, with shooting drills punctuated by banter back and forth. But today, it was just quiet. And when the team huddled at the workout, Coach Don Casey spoke of hope and chances still there for the team. But the players' minds were stuck on Sunday's disastrous loss to the Denver Nuggets and the likely consequences.

description: On her way into the Vanity Fair Oscar party early this morning, Queen Latifah did what any celebrity might do when told she cannot bring her bodyguard into the hottest party in town -- and it's 1 a.m., too late, practically speaking, for a snit. She stripped off the several million dollars' worth of borrowed Harry Winston jewels she had on and handed them to the bodyguard, right on the curb. Like they're loose change or something.

title: Lessons From the Dorismond Funeral
description: The mourners who erupted in violence at Patrick Dorismond's funeral last Saturday made the event immeasurably more painful for the Dorismond family -- and were playing with the kind of fire that easily burns out of control. The melee, which ended with two dozen police officers injured and 27 civilians arrested, was less serious than it might have been, thanks to police officers who behaved with restraint and civilians who urged fellow mourners back from the brink of violence. Even so, the eruptions at the funeral were proof that New York City has reached a critical juncture in its race relations. Mayor Rudolph Giuliani, whose comments over the weekend continued to raise tensions in the black community, needs to reach out and start a dialogue with the black elected officials he has previously shunned.

title: More Diet Drug Lawsuits Ahead Despite Proposed Class Action Accord
description: The advertisements began popping up on television and radio two months ago: Weitz & Luxenberg, a Manhattan law firm, was telling people who said they had been made ill by the diet pill combination fen-phen that their chances of being fairly compensated might be in jeopardy.

title: GERMAN COMPUTER SERVICE DEAL
description: Europe's biggest phone company, Deutsche Telekom, bought 50.1 percent of DaimlerChrysler's Debis Systemhaus software business for 5.5 billion euros ($5.3 billion) to expand its computer services business. Deutsche Telekom will take over management of Systemhaus, which is about a quarter of the Debis unit, and expects to save 150 million to 200 million euros over five years by combining the business with its own. The deal ''will make Deutsche Telekom the second- biggest player in Europe behind I.B.M.'' in information technology, said Ron Sommer, the company's chief executive.

title: Adding to the Risk for Teenage Drivers
description: The greater the number of passengers in a car driven by a 16- or 17-year-old, the higher the risk of a fatal car crash, a new study reports. The findings appear in The Journal of the American Medical Association, and the authors urge greater use of graduated licensing systems that restrict young drivers' ability to carry passengers.

title: Earth, Wind and Fireworks
description: It was a moonless night on Hudson Bay. Dr. David S. Evans, a physicist, was freezing as he tinkered with gear in the dark. Suddenly the sky seemed to explode.

title: Supreme Court Roundup; Justices Reject Case on Cutting Welfare for Legal Immigrants
description: The Supreme Court refused to hear a challenge today to portions of the 1996 welfare law that made legal immigrants ineligible for various kinds of federal welfare assistance.

title: NEOFORMA.COM TO TAKE OVER A COMPETITOR, EQUIPMD
description: Neoforma.com Inc. agreed yesterday to acquire the privately held EquipMD Inc. for 5.4 million shares, worth about $158.6 million. The deal will combine two companies that sell medical products and services online. EquipMD, based in Atlanta, sells health care supplies from companies like Johnson & Johnson, Becton Dickinson and Kimberly-Clark to doctors. EquipMD's customers include about 15,000 doctors in 4,000 practices. Neoforma, with headquarters in Santa Clara, Calif., runs an online health care products shop and auction. It had $1 million in revenue last year and has a market value of $1.7 billion. The company's stock closed at $31.50, up $2.125, in Nasdaq trading.

title: Lethem Journal; Weavers Go Dot-Com, and Elders Move In
description: This village in the remote southern savannas, little more than an airstrip and scattered mud huts, could easily be taken for one of those far-flung places untouched by the digital revolution. It had no phones until two years ago, and the concept of paying with money is still quite foreign to many residents.

title: Mets-Cubs Game in Japan Will Be an Unusual Eye-Opener
description: While the Mets and the Cubs try to shrug off jet lag, the American population gets to share their pain Wednesday morning. Anybody who wants to catch that grand old tradition of opening day will have to get up bright and early.

title: Montenegrin Says Belgrade Is Using Its Army to Oust Him
description: The leader of Montenegro today accused the president of Yugoslavia, Slobodan Milosevic, of using the national army to try to force him from power.

description: HERMAN-Florence, 81, died on Monday, March 27, 2000. She is survived by her beloved husband, Sam Herman. Devoted mother of Amy Shalom, Lisa Sparber, Lauren Herman and Andrea Herman. Devoted sister of Lynn Lapman, and adoring grandmother of Kira and Todd Shalom. For further information, please call Hellman Memorial Chapels at 914-356-8600.

title: Punitive Damages Added In Smoking Case Verdict
description: A San Francisco jury yesterday ordered two cigarette makers to pay a total of $20 million in punitive damages in the first case decided in favor of a person who started smoking after the federal government required the tobacco industry to put warning labels on cigarette packages.

title: Mr. Trimble's Narrow Victory
description: David Trimble, who survived an unexpectedly strong challenge to win re-election as head of the Ulster Unionist Party over the weekend, is the most enlightened political leader Northern Ireland's Protestant majority has yet produced. Some of his tactical maneuvers have been questionable. But without his principled commitment to political power-sharing between Protestants and Roman Catholics and respect for the civil rights of all, there would have been no Good Friday peace agreement two years ago and little hope for reviving Northern Ireland's suspended home-rule government today.

title: Bank One Announces New Chief
description: The Bank One Corporation, rocked by a series of management blunders and earnings shortfalls after one of the biggest mergers in banking history, named James Dimon as its chairman and chief executive yesterday.

title: Corrections

It was shown last night at the Museum of Modern Art, and -- as noted in the credit listing -- is being repeated at 6 tonight, not tomorrow.

description: HOUCK-Louise J. Booth. On March 25, 2000, suddenly at home in Sarasota, FL after a long life of giving friendship and joy to others. Born November 7, 1911, she was a graduate of Carnegie Institute of Technology and loving wife of the late Howard W. Booth and the late Harold E. Houck. She is survived by Howard W. Booth Jr. of Groton, CT, William R. Booth of Toronto, Canada, granddaughters Teresa Bridgeman and Barbara Clay; grandsons Douglas and David Booth and great-grandchildren Michael, Ryan, Emily and Brandon. A memorial service will be held at Bay Village of Sarasota, 8400 Vamo Road on Wednesday, March 29 at 3 PM. In lieu of flowers, the family suggests a donation to the charity of your choice.

title: Growing Pains as the Oscars Play to Jaded Stargazers
description: We can't blame Canada for this one. When Robin Williams sang ''Blame Canada'' from the ''South Park'' movie, joined by a chorus line dressed as Mounties, it was the highlight of this year's Academy Awards show and a revelation. The evening's first production number, this all-singing, all-dancing extravaganza was, significantly, a parody of the inadvertently hilarious routines the Oscar show has made famous.

title: WORLD BUSINESS BRIEFING: AMERICAS; MEXICAN CURRENCY AT 18-MONTH HIGH
description: The Mexican peso has strengthened to the highest level since August 1998, at 9.19 pesos to the dollar. The strength of the peso has reawakened a debate over whether the currency is too high. The daily newspaper Reforma has estimated the peso is overvalued by 28 percent. But many analysts expect the currency to remain strong, supported by higher oil prices, the vibrant United States economy and recent upgrades of Mexico's creditworthiness by Standard & Poor's and Moody's. Dan Fineren (NYT)

title: American Sperm, as Hardy as Ever
description: For some years now, scientists have been debating whether there is any evidence to show that environmental problems may be causing a significant decline in the quality of human sperm, posing a threat to fertility.

title: Documentary Lifts Shroud From Cancer
description: It is rare indeed for commercial television to produce a program of such high quality and importance as the two-and-a-half-hour documentary, ''Cancer: Evolution to Revolution,'' to be shown at 8 p.m. Eastern time this Thursday on HBO. Produced and directed by Joseph F. Lovett, five of whose family members had cancer and four of whom died of it, the film is at once realistic and hopeful about the life-and-death battles being waged daily against this disease.

title: For Daimler, Mitsubishi Opens the Door to Asia
description: FRANKFURT  DaimlerChrysler AG rounded out its vision for the creation of a global automaker with the announcement Monday that it had acquired a 34 percent controlling stake in Mitsubishi Motor Corp. of Japan.

title: Grey Advertising Gets Robitussin
description: Whitehall Robins Healthcare, a division of American Home Products, has expanded its relationship with Grey Advertising by naming the New York office of Grey to handle the domestic account of the Robitussin brand of cough medicine. Billings were estimated at $35 million.

title: Two Unexpected Matchups in Final Four
description: Historians of the future will determine if this year's Final Four is one of the best in college basketball history. The consensus will probably be ''uh, no.'' But contemporary observers might agree that the semifinalists headed to Indianapolis this week make up one of the most interesting, unlikely and eclectic quartets in the modern history of the National Collegiate Athletic Association tournament.

Professor of Medicine at Downstate Medical School. Beloved by his students and patients for his teaching and diagnostic abilities and respect for the dignity of life. Beloved husband of Fannie. Devoted father of Laurie and Gerald. Cherished grandfather of Scott, Teddi and Max. Services are on Tuesday 10AM at SchwartzBrothers Jeffer Memorial Chapels, 114-03 Queens Boulevard at 76th Road, Forest Hills, NY.

title: NIAGARA BANCORP IN ACCORD FOR IROQUOIS BANCORP
description: Niagara Bancorp Inc., owner of Lockport Savings Bank in western New York, agreed yesterday to buy Iroquois Bancorp Inc. for $80.3 million in stock and options, furthering its push into central New York. Niagara will pay $33.25 in stock for each Iroquois share and assume Iroquois's stock options. The shares of Iroquois jumped $13.5625, or 76 percent, to $31.4375, in Nasdaq trading. Iroquois, which has about 2.3 million shares outstanding, owns Cayuga Bank and Homestead Savings. The bank, based in Auburn, has $595 million in assets and serves 10 central New York communities, mainly in Cayuga, Oswego and Oneida Counties. The shares of Niagara, based in Lockport, N.Y., rose 6.25 cents, to $9.4375, in Nasdaq trading.

description: The ghost of Werner Heisenberg, the Nobel Prize winner who led the Nazi atomic bomb program, walked again yesterday as historians and scientists met to determine whether his failure to build a bomb during World War II was deliberate or a simple product of his own incompetence.

Yet the presenters at Symphony Space had organized the event so well that no one had to wait too long, at least during the first third of the marathon, which I attended.

title: Removal of Diabetes Drug Meets With Mixed Feelings
description: The removal of the diabetes drug Rezulin from the market did not come soon enough to help Monica George, a 68-year-old former nurse in Rockville, Md.: It had already caused her death, her daughters said. But the drug's removal upset Frank Hopkins, a Virginia horse-farm owner, who said it greatly improved his health and brought his diabetes under control.

description: The US Airways Group, the sixth-largest United States airline, cut its leisure fares today to win back customers after it reached an agreement on a tentative contract with flight attendants and avoided a shutdown.

Clarence C. Comer, chief executive of the Houston-based Southdown, said the company's shares were undervalued and that it ''intends to evaluate alternatives to make these values more apparent to investors.'' Southdown's shares rose $6, to $60.25. At that price, the stock has a total value of more than $2.16 billion.

description: Henry W. McGee Sr., the first black postmaster in Chicago, died on March 18 at his home in Chicago. He was 90.

title: . . . to the Pedicarts That Link Shanghai's Streets to the Internet
description: ANY day of the week, wiry, 27-year-old Zhang Minyou hoists 40 to 80 water jugs out of his smart, 19th-century-styled pedicart, trudges through a labyrinth of laundry-lined alleys and groans his way up dozens of creaky stairs. After delivering the goods to one customer, Mr. Minyou, an Aquarius water deliveryman, hops back on his tricycle to peddle to his next customer through a city of byzantine streets. He is a cheap but crucial link in an idiosyncratic door-to-door mainland distribution system that fills orders placed with the click of a 21st-century mouse.

title: Shipwrecked on Dry Land
description: On Friday, when Juan Miguel Gonzalez went to school to pick up his son Elian for the weekend, he was told that Elizabet Brotons, his ex-wife and the boy's mother, had taken Elian at midday and had not brought him back in the afternoon. In his routine as a divorced father, this seemed normal to Juan Miguel. From the time when he and Elizabet had separated two years earlier, on the most amicable terms, the boy had lived with his father and spent every other day at his mother's house. But Elizabet's door was padlocked over the weekend and on Monday as well, and Juan Miguel began to make inquiries. This was how he learned the bad news that was already becoming common knowledge in the city of Cardenas: Elian's mother had left with him for Miami, with 12 other people, in an aluminum boat 5 1/2 meters long, with no life preservers and a decrepit motor.

title: Opening the Oil Spigot
description: The decision by the Organization of Petroleum Exporting Countries to increase its oil production by 1.45 million barrels a day is welcome and may, over time, lead to lower American gasoline prices. The action, which Iran, an OPEC member, unexpectedly refused to take part in, restores just over a third of production cut by the cartel over the past two years. But it should not be seen as a definitive answer to the recent sharp rise in oil prices.

title: 1,000 Crates of Sprinkles With That?
description: It's official business-to-business e-commerce is where the money is, or at least will be soon. Most of the projected growth is likely to take place in what analysts call ''e-marketplaces,'' or ''net markets'' - Web sites that bring together many buyers and sellers on a single site. Some will serve different industries, while others will operate within a narrow specialty. What they'll look like in 10 years is anyone's guess, but some current forms are outlined below. While Jane's Ice Cream is a fictional company, its evolution has plenty of parallels in the real world of e-business. STEPHEN MIHM

title: WITH IRAN BALKING, OPEC NATIONS PLAN TO SELL MORE OIL
description: After two days of disputes, OPEC decided today to increase oil production without the participation of its second-largest producer, Iran. But the increase was not what the United States had pressed for, and was not expected to bring down gasoline prices any time soon.

title: Metro Business; A New Web Alliance
description: Cablevision Systems Corporation's Rainbow Media Holdings unit, which broadcasts New York sports and other regional programming, and Primedia Inc.'s New York magazine plan to create a new regional Web service.

title: Corrections
description: An obituary yesterday about Albert R. Connelly, a retired partner at the law firm of Cravath, Swaine & Moore, misstated his birthdate. It was March 24, 1908, not Nov. 24.

title: Mogilny Finally Breaks Out, But Slumping Devils Do Not
description: Shortly after Larry Robinson was named last week to replace Robbie Ftorek as coach of the Devils, he said the team needed to practice three aspects of their game. Judging from the way the Devils played in tonight's 3-2 loss to the Pittsburgh Penguins, they need to practice all aspects of the game.

title: QUOTATION OF THE DAY
description: ''Anybody who expects to get back to gasoline at $1 or $1.20 a gallon will be seriously disappointed.''

title: Elian Interview Brings Criticism
description: ABC's ''Good Morning America'' seemed to score the newsmaker interview of the week with Diane Sawyer's exclusive televised chat with Elian Gonzalez, which ran on Monday and Tuesday.

title: DEUTSCHE BUYS STAKE IN BROKER
description: The world's largest bank, Deutsche Bank A.G., agreed to acquire a 16.3 percent stake in the online broker National Discount Brokers for $136 million, with the option to buy an additional 3 percent. In connection with the deal, Deutsche Bank and National Discount Brokers, based in Jersey City, agreed to form an online brokerage alliance. The agreement calls for the companies to build brokerage Web sites outside of the United States. Shares of National Discount Brokers were up $2 each, to $56.50.

title: The Oscar Rating
description: ABC was more than pleased with the results from this year's Academy Awards broadcast, pointing to ratings up about 2 percent from last year's.

title: Israeli Police Urge Prosecution of Netanyahu and Wife
description: After a seven-month investigation, the Israeli police today recommended that former Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu and his wife, Sara, face criminal prosecution on charges of bribery, fraud and the theft of $100,000 worth of gifts to the state.

title: Special Effects Make Way for Magic
description: SPANISH foam has finally washed ashore on Manhattan Island. It was only a matter of time. For much of the past year, the food press has been enthralled with the mad experiments of Ferran Adria, the three-star chef at El Bulli in Rosas, Spain, who delights in turning traditional recipes inside out and, in a kind of culinary alchemy, presents flavors in foams, gels and even puffs of smoke.

title: War Can Sneak Devastatingly Across a Border
description: It's one thing to be thousands of miles removed from the strife in the Balkans while watching it on television and quite another to live just across the border from it. Barbara Albert's complex, fragmentary debut film, ''Northern Skirts,'' which New Directors/New Films is screening tonight and on Friday night, evokes the social and emotional tremors that rumble through a southern Austrian town near the Slovenian border. The movie, which examines the relationships among some young people (several of them refugees), suggests how a war can sneak across the border, even when no shots are fired, and erode an orderly society's everyday sense of its own continuity.

title: A Defining Moment In Brooklyn
description: FOR all the fuss over the glut of new restaurants in Brooklyn, you would think that the Dodgers had come back to town or that, finally, another tree had grown. Or that no promising young chefs were left in Manhattan.

title: Agency Votes To Accept Bid For 2 A-Plants
description: Capping an unlikely bidding war, the New York Power Authority voted yesterday to sell its two nuclear plants to a Mississippi company for $967 million in what would be by far the largest sale of nuclear reactors in United States history.

title: Training Programs Often Miss the Point on the Job
description: Nanette Solow remembers the day she stood in a row with 10 co-workers, tucked an orange under her chin and transferred it to the space beneath a colleague's chin. The goal was to move the orange down the entire line in less than five minutes. But there was a deeper purpose: to build teamwork, enhance communication and promote problem solving. And, oh yes: to have a hoot in the process.

title: COMPANY NEWS
description: TERAYON COMMUNICATION SYSTEMS INC., Santa Clara, Calif., a maker of high-speed networking equipment, agreed to acquire the privately held Ultracom Communications Holdings, Cupertino, Calif., which makes chips for networks, for $32 million in stock.

title: WALES UTILITY IN TALKS
description: Shares of Wales's water utility, Hyder P.L.C., jumped 48 percent after the company confirmed it was in talks with several suitors about being acquired. Despite the jump, the stock is still below its price at the beginning of the year. Hyder, which posted a first-half loss of $:8 million in December and has been one of the worst-performing British stocks, said it was examining several options that could include a takeover or possibly a sale of some of its assets. Andrew Ross Sorkin

title: MACROVISION IN STOCK DEAL FOR SOFTWARE DISTRIBUTOR
description: The Macrovision Corporation, a software company, agreed yesterday to buy the privately held Globetrotter Software for $861 million in stock. Globetrotter, based in San Jose, Calif., makes software that distributes software licenses over the Internet to prevent duplication of software by unlicensed users. Globetrotter had $15 million in revenue last year. Macrovision, based in Sunnyvale, Calif., develops systems that prevent the duplication of video and audio programs as well as computer software. It had $37.4 million in revenue last year. Macrovision will issue 11.2 million shares, about 28 percent of its outstanding stock. The shares rose $2 each, to $78.875.

title: Standoff Over Cuban Boy's Fate Intensifies

title: Bol.com Serves Local Flavors All Over Europe
description: Europe may be an Internet laggard, but the e-commerce sites that seem to be succeeding are growing on European turf, not imported from the United States. One German company, Bertelsmann Online (www.bol.com), is trying to replicate the success of Amazon.com in Europe, with sites in Britain, France, Germany, Spain, Switzerland and the Netherlands. (Bertelsmann, the parent and media conglomerate, owns a stake of barnesandnoble.com.)

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  HALL, J. PARKER, JR.
description: HALL-J. Parker, Jr., former University of Chicago treasurer for 23 years, pioneer in innovative investing, died March 23, 2000 at age 94. He worked on Wall Street 17 years, was a trustee of TIAACREF, founding trustee of The Common Fund. He helped found the Financial Analysts Federation and financial analysts certification. Son of James Parker Hall, 24 year Dean of the University of Chicago Law School, brother of Livingston Hall, former Vice Dean of Harvard Law School, he is survived by his wife of 68 years, Frances Ferris Hall, three sons, seven grandchildren, and nine great-grandchildren. Burial is private.

title: The Secret Life of Sorrel
description: I HELD the vibrant green sorrel leaves in my hands. They were the color of a sprout and as fragile as flower petals. Moist, cool and tender, they were nothing like the hard, starchy fruits of winter. They seemed to possess both the optimism of spring and its temperament.

title: INDONESIA FINANCIAL PROBLEMS
description: Citing lack of progress in Indonesia's promised economic changes, the International Monetary Fund said it had delayed plans to release part of a $5 billion loan to the country agreed to in January. While the delay will not upset Indonesia's balance of payments, it is likely to damp investor faith in its economic recovery and could affect negotiations to reschedule $2.1 billion in international debt repayments. Separately, the recently appointed chairman of Indonesia's powerful bank restructuring agency fired his deputy, complaining he had not moved quickly enough to recover roughly $86 billion in bad loans. The two sides had clashed over the most effective way to handle delinquent debtors. Wayne Arnold

title: An Anglo-Saxon Chiller(With an Irish Touch); Seamus Heaney Adds His Voice to 'Beowulf'

The book is ''Beowulf,'' Seamus Heaney's modern English translation of the Anglo-Saxon epic, which was created sometime between the 7th and the 10th centuries.

Barton, nearly a half-million dollars. Privately, many Wall Street executives voiced smug I-told-you-so's.

Yet the thousands of students at these campuses seldom venture past the gates to mingle with their city neighbors, who often struggle with poverty, homelessness and the city's faltering attempts at urban renewal.

Even fairly small museums have won fame by wheedling prized artworks from scattered institutions and bringing them together briefly for the world to see.

title: BMW SALES RISE
description: Germany's No. 3 carmaker, BMW A.G., said its first-quarter unit sales rose 4 percent as growth in demand for its vehicles was slowed by a fall in sales at the Rover unit, which is being sold to a British investment group. Over all, unit sales rose to 302,000 units. BMW predicted its 2000 profit would be ''significantly higher'' before charges, although the chief financial officer, Helmut Panke, said losses at Rover would still hold back earnings growth this year. Mr. Panke added that BMW's costs at Rover totaled 9 billion marks ($4.4 billion).

title: Stringer: Overrated? No, Overjoyed
description: The clock was nearly exhausted and C. Vivian Stringer awaited the inevitable, standing with her arms folded at the Rutgers bench. She was about to become the first coach, man or woman, to take three different schools to the Final Four in college basketball. As victory approached, she smacked her fist into her palm, she smiled, she cried, she shook her head slightly in wonder, and finally, she held her hands above her head like a referee signaling a touchdown.

title: EXECUTIVE GETS PRISON TERM
description: The Tokyo District Court sentenced the former president of Yamaichi Securities to prison for hiding losses, illegally paying dividends to shareholders and bribing racketeers linked to the Japanese mob. Atsuo Miki, left, the former president, received a two-year sentence for his role in the actions that ultimately led to Yamaichi's failure in the fall of 1997. Tsugio Yukihira, the firm's former chairman, received the same sentence, but it was suspended for five years. Merrill Lynch & Company bought some of Yamaichi's assets, which it has used to build a retail brokerage unit. Stephanie Strom

title: Beach Ball Bingo, With Flippers and Tentacles
description: Eliot Feld's love of choreographic extravagance was apparent in every work his Ballet Tech Company danced on Friday night at the Joyce Theater.

description: To the Editor:

title: CBS Takes a Gamble on a Blitz of 'Falcone'
description: ''Falcone,'' a new CBS series about the Mafia loosely based on the 1997 movie ''Donnie Brasco,'' is hardly making its debut in typical television style.

title: Key Rates
description: Percent

title: Cota Offers a Perfect Fit To Carolina's Tradition
description: Ed Cota's game is straight out of Brooklyn, a refined version now that fits firmly into North Carolina basketball's ''buddy system.'' Cota began learning his game as a 9-year-old, walking across the street from his front door on East New York Avenue to watch older boys play at Hamilton-Metz Park. On some early mornings, he would practice there alone, tuning his game. At 11, he played in his first Brooklyn basketball league -- his team was called Ice Tea -- and by the time he left for North Carolina, he was ready to dish, shoot, score and shoot some more.

title: EFFICIENT NETWORKS PLANS TO BUY NETSCREEN
description: Efficient Networks, a maker of high-speed modems, said yesterday that it would buy the privately held NetScreen Technologies, which provides security for electronic commerce Web sites, for $905 million in stock. Efficient Networks said it would pay 5.28 million shares for NetScreen, based in Santa Clara, Calif., which has annual sales of about $22 million and 125 employees. The stock of Efficient Networks, which had its initial offering at $15 last July, fell $13.5625 a share yesterday, to $158, in Nasdaq trading.

title: INSIDE
description: Microsoft Talks Continue

title: THE MARKETS: COMMODITIES
description: CORN FALLS. Corn prices dropped as forecasts for rain in the Midwest eased concern that a drought could stunt plant growth this summer. In Chicago, corn for May delivery fell 7.5 cents, or 3.2 percent, to $2.25 a bushel.

title: NEXT NEW ERA; Spinning Off Can Mean Big Money, but Big Danger Too
description: WHEN Wal-Mart Stores Inc. got serious about the Internet, it set up an online company in the heart of Silicon Valley, complete with couches, foosball and late-night brainstorming sessions over pizza and Chinese takeout. The cultural divide between Wal-Mart, the nation's largest retailer, and its dot-com offspring is as great as the 1,500 miles between Wal-Mart's headquarters in Bentonville, Ark., and California -- and that is on purpose.

title: Green Obtains A Court Order Citing Mayor Release of Records
description: Using an obscure, nearly century-old section of the City Charter, Public Advocate Mark Green obtained a court order yesterday directing Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani to show by next week why he should not be held legally accountable for the release of Patrick M. Dorismond's sealed court records.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  LIPMAN, SAMUEL
description: LIPMAN-Samuel. On March 27, 2000. Beloved husband of Penny and the late Roberta Lipman. Devoted father of Larry, Beth and Donna. Loving grandfather of Reed. Sandy's humor, loving spirit and infectious personality are irreplaceable in our hearts and shall be greatly missed. Services Wednesday, 1:30 PM, Plaza Memorial Chapel, 91st and Amsterdam Ave.

title: Corrections
description: A picture caption yesterday about circus performers who were passing the Supreme Court in Washington as demonstrators protested the use of animals in the circus misstated the last name of three spectators. They were Gabriel, Amina and Sophia Ayoud; Otman is their father's given name.

title: Republicans Move on Tax Cuts
description: Republicans in the Senate moved ahead on several fronts with their tax and spending proposals today, calling for a tax reduction for married couples, setting out a budget plan that seeks to restrain the growth of government and laying the groundwork for a vote on reducing gasoline taxes.

title: Celebrating a Prague Spring On a Visit to Lincoln Center
description: Lincoln Center is paying tribute to the Czech Republic on the 10th anniversary of the Velvet Revolution by presenting what it is calling the Prague Festival, the heart of which is a three-concert visit to Avery Fisher Hall by the Czech Philharmonic and Vladimir Ashkenazy, its chief conductor since 1997.

title: Confidence Of Consumers Weakened For 2d Month
description: Consumers' confidence in the economy fell for the second consecutive month in March, and their expectations for later this year sank to a five-month low, a private survey showed yesterday.

title: Help! My Brain's Being Eaten by a Zillion Dot-Com Ads!
description: A gerbil shot from a cannon, a hammy actor crooning a song woefully off key, a college student who burps the alphabet: These were just a few of the colorful images used in the past year by dot-com companies flooding the airwaves with ''edgy'' advertising. To analyze why dot-com advertisements are so wild, whether they work and where they go from here, a group of advertisers -- some old hands, some new faces -- and dot-com clients, including one, Michael Zapolin, who appeared in his own Super Bowl ad, assembled recently in New York, watched one another's commercials and exchanged views. The moderator was Warren Berger, a contributing editor at Wired and editor of the advertising magazine One.

title: Nets Hold On Against the Best in the East
description: As yet another seemingly insurmountable lead sank like a barbell in the ocean tonight, many of the 17,676 Nets fans looked on in stunned disbelief, wondering what type of curse must hover over their woebegone team. After more than three quarters of brilliant basketball, of spectacular alley-oops and feverish defense against the premier team in the Eastern Conference, the Nets were crumbling again.

title: Sentencing a Drug Courier, Judge Rebukes the Hasidim
description: Dozens of Hasidic Jews packed together shoulder to shoulder in a Brooklyn courtroom yesterday, seeking leniency for a teenager who forsook his strict upbringing to help run a huge smuggling ring that flooded New York with the drug Ecstasy.

title: Profit Sharing Set by Airline
description: The Southwest Airlines Company, the largest low-fare carrier, said this week that it would pay a record $138.3 million in profit sharing for last year, with the average payout growing to 14.1 percent of salary.

title: Legislator Seeks Change In Sprinkler Deadline
description: A state legislator, responding to concerns that two years would be too short a time for the installation of sprinklers in all of New Jersey's school dormitories, has introduced a bill to extend the deadline to five years.

title: Is Anybody Not Out for E-Billions? Josie True, for One
description: JOSIE TRUE, a Chinese-American cartoon girl in an online game, hunts for her missing teacher by time-traveling. Along the way, she strikes up conversations with little-known historical heroines like Bessie Coleman, the first African-American to earn an international pilot's license.

title: As Sonics Squabble, Van Gundy & Co. Could Well Profit
description: The Knicks' chances for a successful road trip could improve on Wednesday if they can prey on a Seattle SuperSonics team that has been left physically and mentally vulnerable in the aftermath of a fight between Gary Payton and Vernon Maxwell.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  MCCURDY, ED
description: MCCURDY-Ed, passed away March 23, 2000, in Nova Scotia. He was 81 years old. His wife Beryl, his three children, Mary, James, and Dana, three grandchildren and a sister and a brother in Pennsylvania survive him. He was born in Pennsylvania in 1919. His career as a singer, writer, and actor spanned almost 60 years. The Nova Scotia Harbor Folk Society will host a memorial service at The Dartmouth Regional Library, on March 29th at 7:00 P.M.

title: IRELAND PHONE COMPANY CUTS JOBS
description: Ireland's former state telecommunications company, Eircom, announced a $406 million restructuring plan that would cut 3,500 jobs and save $76 million annually. The employees will be moved to Eircom's various joint ventures, and encouraged to accept voluntary severance packages. In the face of increased competition from British Telecom, Eircom will also sell its Internet divisions in a public stock offering. Brian Lavery

title: The New Economy's Currency Is Stock, Stock and Stock
description: A BAY Area urologist treating a patient who works at an Internet start-up recently had an idea. For their next appointment, the urologist joked, he wanted to be paid in shares.

title: The Kings Bewitch And Dazzle The Knicks
description: The Knicks tried to imitate the Kings' blinding flash and telegenic moves only to find the uniforms didn't fit.

title: Free-for-All on the Name Exchange
description: JOAN KRON, an editor at Allure magazine, did not think of herself as a speculator when she registered some domain names in 1996. But her Net-savvy son, Daniel, who is the founder and creative director of SportsForWomen.com, convinced his mother that the time was right to reserve a few addresses that she could use later to promote a book that she was writing about plastic surgery.

title: To Put G.E. Online Meant Putting a Dozen Industries Online
description: EARLY last year, John F. Welch, the chief executive and chairman of General Electric, set an ambitious goal for the managers of the huge company's businesses -- establish a strategy for using the Internet and put it into effect before the end of 1999.

description: While many chief executives have nailed down the art of the deal, not many know the deal on art.

title: THE MARKETS: CURRENCIES
description: THE YEN GAINS. The yen rose against the dollar on hopes that a coming survey will show an upturn in Japanese business sentiment. In New York, the dollar settled at 105.88 yen, down from 106.87 on Monday.

title: Justices Consider Hate-Crime Sentencing
description: In a Supreme Court argument today on the constitutionality of New Jersey's unusual sentencing procedure for hate crimes, the justices appeared troubled by the state's law but also troubled by the broader implications of overturning it.

title: Foundation Giving Is at $23 Billion High
description: Flush with ballooning endowments and new money from wealthy individuals and corporations, the nation's foundations set a record by giving away an estimated $22.8 billion in grants in 1999, according to a study to be released today.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  REID, ETHELDREDA WINTHROP SEABURY
description: REID-Etheldreda Winthrop Seabury, died at her home in York Harbor, Maine, on March 26th, at the age of 96. Devoted wife of Fergus Reid, Jr., who predeceased her, beloved mother of Fergus Reid III, William Seabury Reid and Winthrop Reid Burns, grandmother of five grandchildren, five stepgrandchildren and seventeen great-grandchildren. She leaves a sister, Mrs. William White Howells, of Kittery Point, Maine. During World War II she was Director of Fund Raising for the Red Cross, Women's Division. She was President of the Garden Club of America from 1953-1956 and President of The New York Exchange for Woman's Work from 1963-1966. A funeral service will be held at 11 AM on Saturday, April 1st, at St. George's Episcopal Church in York Harbor, Maine.

title: Mark Stuart, 80, Columnist in New Jersey
description: Mark Stuart, a longtime newspaper columnist and editor at The Record in Hackensack, N.J., and The Paterson Morning Call, died Friday at the Valley Hospital in Ridgewood, N.J. He was 80.

title: Putting Their Money Where the Future Is
description: BY necessity, venture capitalists are trend predictors. Given that even the most nimble technology companies need time to get started, the firms that finance Internet start-ups need to stay a step ahead of the pack in their search for the next success.

title: Yosemite's New Look
description: Three years ago, when California's Merced River jumped its banks in Yosemite National Park -- uprooting cabins, burying parking lots under mud and rock and generally making a mess of things -- federal officials took it as a sign that the time had come to strike a better balance between man and nature. There was human overload everywhere -- four million visitors a year, shops and restaurants jammed into the Yosemite Valley flood plain, a stream of cars, trucks and recreational vehicles that not only fouled the air but made the mile-long trip through Yosemite Village seem like rush hour in Manhattan. On some days visibility was bad enough to obscure the towering rock formations that rise from the valley floor and the long waterfalls that seem to descend from the heavens.

title: A Simple Solution
description: To the Editor:

title: Agassi Beats Rafter And Referee's Calls
description: It was a defining moment today, the eighth game of the second set between Andre Agassi and Patrick Rafter in the quarterfinals of the Ericsson Open. Agassi was up by a set, clinging to a 4-3 advantage and trying to hold serve.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  HARRIS, VIVIEN
description: HARRIS-Vivien. My family and I mourn the loss of Vivien Harris, a loving friend of 43 years. We send heartfelt condolences to Beth, David, Meryl, Roger and Samantha Our wise, caring and talented friend will be deeply missed. Blossom W. Landsman

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SHEBAIRO, MIRIAM (BUNNY)
description: SHEBAIRO-Miriam (Bunny). The Board of Governors and members of Hampshire Country Club are deeply saddened by the passing of our esteemed member, Bunny Shebairo. Our heartfelt sympathy is extended to her dear husband Akram Shebairo and to all her family. Hampshire Country Club Board of Governors Norman Zarkin, President

title: Now That They've Come, What Can We Sell Them?
description: BEFORE people realized they could make a million dollars on the Web by putting an ''e'' in front of any word in the dictionary, registering the new name and shaking down a venture capitalist for seed money, the Internet was a much more communal place.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  BRONSTEIN, DAVID
description: BRONSTEIN-David. Beloved husband of Marilyn and of the late Mildred. Devoted father of Mark and Leslie, Barbara and Larry Cohen, and Alan and Norma. Beloved stepfather and devoted grandfather. Services are today, 12:45 PM, at ''Parkside'' Chapel, Queens Bouelvard and 66th Avenue, Forest Hills.

title: The I.M.F. as 'a Crucial Cornerstone'
description: Laying out his vision of the future of the International Monetary Fund, Horst Kohler, the new managing director, said today that rather than shrinking as some critics have suggested, the fund should expand its role as ''a crucial cornerstone'' of globalization.

title: Business Travel; A rising number of laptop computers are being stolen at airports by organized rings of thieves.
description: IT used to be that if your briefcase was stolen while you were on the road, you'd probably be out no more than a nice leather bag, some pens, some easily replaced papers and maybe the morning paper and a Snickers bar. But today, the travel accessory of choice for thieves is a laptop or notebook computer, and losing one of those babies can really cause a problem.

title: Air Force Links Agent Orange to Diabetes
description: In its most clear-cut acknowledgment that there is evidence linking Agent Orange to illness among Vietnam veterans, the Air Force said in a new report there was ''particularly strong evidence'' tying the defoliant to the onset of diabetes in veterans who had been involved in spraying it over the Vietnamese countryside.

title: Campaign Briefing
description: THE DEMOCRATS

title: Phillips Says Valentine Must Make It Happen
description: When the Mets played sub-.500 baseball over the first two months of last season, the jobs of three coaches were sacrificed to get the team going. The stakes could be higher now.

title: CAMERON ACCEPTS BUYOUT OFFER FROM INVESTMENT GROUP
description: Cameron Ashley Building Products said yesterday that it had accepted a buyout offer worth about $159 million from an investment group that includes members of Cameron's senior management. The investment group, which includes CGW Southeast Partners IV L.P. and an affiliate of Citigroup's Citicorp Venture Capital Ltd., is offering $18.25 a share. The deal includes assumption of about $189 million in debt. Cameron is a home building products company based in Dallas. Its shares were unchanged at $17.50 on the New York Stock Exchange.

title: Woeful Rangers Fire Smith and Muckler
description: Saying that the Rangers' rapidly escalating late-season collapse had embarrassed the organization and its fans, the Madison Square Garden president, Dave Checketts, fired the club's president and general manager, Neil Smith, and Coach John Muckler yesterday with only four games remaining in what has become another futile season.

title: Apollo Group Offering
description: Apollo Group Inc., which runs programs that allow working adults to get college degrees, said today that it would seek to raise $75 million through an initial public offering of a tracking stock for its online business. The Phoenix-based company offers degrees through its University of Phoenix as well as other programs. As of Jan. 31, University of Phoenix Online had about 12,000 degree candidates. Combined degree enrollment for all programs was 94,046 at the end of February, Apollo said. The shares rose $1.8125, to $26.3125.

title: Treasuries Gain as Investors Shift Makeup of Portfolios
description: Bond prices were mostly higher amid a drop in the main stock market gauges, which caused some investors to seek shelter in fixed-income securities.

title: Charities See Web's Potential, but Are Finding It Hard to Afford
description: BUSINESSES have discovered the power of the Internet for communicating with employees and customers quickly through e-mail or a Web site. Buying automobile parts, selling books or arranging vacations can also be done efficiently online. Nonprofit organizations should find the Internet just as appealing. What better way to reach like-minded advocates, donors and volunteers or to coordinate services?

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  AXELROD, HELENE (NEE GOTTESMAN)
description: AXELROD-Helene (nee Gottesman). Beloved wife of 55 years of Bernard. Loving mother of Robert and Jay, and caring mother-in-law of Christy Wise and Margaret Axelrod. Cherished grandmother of Danielle, Caroline, Lee and Charles. Fond sister of the late Selma Gottesman, & sister-in-law of Brenda & Carlin Axelrod. In lieu of flowers, please direct contributions to the Helene Gottesman Axelrod Scholarship Fund at Barnard College, 3009 Broadway, NY, NY 10027. Services 12:30 Wednesday at ''The Riverside'', 76th Street and Amsterdam Avenue.

title: FOOTLIGHTS
description: NEWS

title: LERNOUT & HAUSPIE PLANS TO BUY DRAGON FOR $593 MILLION
description: Lernout & Hauspie Speech Products of Belgium said yesterday that it had agreed to buy Dragon Systems, its leading United States competitor, for about $593 million in stock to form the biggest maker of speech-recognition software for consumers. The Belgian company will exchange about 5.45 million of its shares for the closely held Dragon, which counts Seagate Technology among its main backers. Dragon is the largest United States maker of speech-recognition software; Lernout is the biggest in Europe. Lernout's shares rose $17 each yesterday, to $125.75.

title: E-tail Sales Follow Their Own Timetable
description: SALE time in the world of brick-and-mortar retailing tends to mean holiday time -- Presidents' Day, Labor Day and other times when people are off work and physically out shopping. On the Web, retailing is also developing its own sale rhythms, though they are less predictable and tied to the times people are in cyberspace or visiting particular sites.

title: Visitors Arrive From Russia With Surprising Companions
description: The violinist and conductor Vladimir Spivakov brought his Moscow Virtuosi chamber orchestra to Avery Fisher Hall on Saturday evening for a concert split evenly -- two works apiece -- between Mozart and Schnittke.

title: French Skater Reports Slashing in Hotel Room
description: NICE, it was another stranger-than-fiction day in figure skating, a sport that seems as drawn to the melodramatic as Aleksei Yagudin does to the medal stand.

title: Turkey to Say if Leader Can Seek 2nd Term
description: After months of intense political maneuvering, the Turkish Parliament is about to begin the delicate work of deciding whether to re-elect President Suleyman Demirel.

title: Survey Discovers Favored Oscar Ads
description: In another sign that the annual broadcast of the Academy Awards is becoming an advertising event like the Super Bowl, a research company that polls consumers after the Super Bowl is releasing results of a similar post-Oscar survey.

title: Will Lissner, 91, Times Reporter Who Specialized in Economics
description: Will Lissner, a reporter for The New York Times from 1926 until he retired in 1976, died on Saturday in a nursing home in Dunedin, Fla. He was 91 and lived in Clearwater, Fla.

title: Bright Israeli Fare With a Leavening of Cheerful Chaos
description: EXCITEMENT filled the bright 30-seat dining room of Hoomoos Asli the other night. Tsachi Cohen, who owns this cheerful five-month-old Middle Eastern restaurant with his business partner, Sheron Fayagh, had just received a videotape of soccer matches from Israel, and a group of his friends were watching it on the monitor opposite the counter that displays kebabs, steaks and salads.

title: Tracking the Web Across China: From the 'Wang Ba' of the West. . .
description: THE roads here are sometimes barely roads. Bathrooms are pits in the ground. Fur coats are a necessity, not fashion. In a nod to tradition, and for self-defense, some men travel with swords at their sides.

title: A Rock Band That Hurled Rocks at 70's Britain
description: By any reasonable standard, the Sex Pistols would scarcely rate a footnote in the annals of rock 'n' roll: in the 26 months of their existence, they recorded exactly one album, were dropped by a succession of record labels and self-destructed in the course of their only tour of the United States. But the violent obliteration of reasonable standards -- of rock decorum, of musical competence, of decent behavior -- was what the Sex Pistols were all about.

title: Corrections
description: An obituary of the actor Rex Everhart on March 20 misspelled the name of his birthplace. It is Watseka, Ill., not Wateska.

title: A World Champion Could Be on the Horizon
description: After the Mets lost to the Tokyo Yomiuri Giants, 9-5, tonight, Bobby Valentine walked to home plate and bowed deeply toward the Giants' dugout. Valentine, who managed the Chiba Lotte Marines in 1995, knows the importance of a respectful gesture in the Japanese culture.

title: China Trade Bill Supporters Pushing for Vote by May
description: Unless the China trade bill comes up for a vote by May, it could be delayed until next year, putting it at serious risk, the measure's top Democratic vote counter in the House predicted today.

title: DNA Tests Cast Doubt on Link Between Neanderthals and Modern Man
description: Did modern humans wipe out the Neanderthal people who inhabited Europe until 28,000 years ago, or did the two populations merge through interbreeding? New DNA evidence, extracted from the ribs of a Neanderthal infant, one of the last of its kind, supports the thesis that these hardy, beetle-browed people left little or no genetic legacy in today's populations.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  GOODSELL, PERCY HAMILTON, JR.
description: GOODSELL-Percy Hamilton, Jr., 89, of 77 Tress Road, Cheshire, CT, died March 24, 2000. Born in Hartford, CT., September 24, 1910 and the only child of Percy and Katharine (Seymour) (Day) (Jackson) Goodsell. He worked as a genealogist with The New York Genealogical and Biographical Society, retiring in 1961; consulting until the mid-1980s. He was a descendant of Oliver Wolcott, former governor of Connecticut and Signer of the Declaration of Independence, historian and lecturer of the American Colonial period. Distinguished member of many genealogical societies, including the Society of the Cincinnati, the Society of the War of 1812, and President-General of Descendants of the Signers of the Declaration of Independence, Inc. He is survived by his double first cousin, Mr. Joseph Hamilton Jackson, of Westhampton Beach, Long Island, New York, as well as other second cousins. Funeral services, Saturday, April 1, 2000 at 2:00PM in Grace Church, 45 New Park Ave., Hartford, CT. Burial following in Cedar Hill Cemetery, Hartford. Contributions to: Scholarship Fund-Descendants of the Signers of the Declaration of Independence, C/O Mrs. Frederick Leadbetter, 101 Holly Avenue, Chestertown, MD 21620.

title: U.N. Peacekeeper Gives Council a Gloomy Briefing on Congo
description: The chances that a United Nations peacekeeping mission can actually be deployed in Congo were not looking good today as the Security Council heard a briefing from the head of its peacekeeping department, who recently visited the region.

description: A token booth clerk has been charged with stealing $327,000 by creating MetroCards, selling them to riders and pocketing the cash, the Queens district attorney, Richard A. Brown, said yesterday.

Mr. Comfort served as a member of the Philip Morris Board of Directors from 1971 until his retirement in 1982. He was named Director Emeritus in April 1982. His colleagues on the Board remember him as a highly dedicated and effective Board member who made significant contributions to the Board, its membership and to the Company. title: MAIL.COM IN STOCK DEAL FOR CHINESE-LANGUAGE PORTAL
description: Mail.com Inc., a provider of Internet-messaging services, agreed yesterday to buy the closely held eLong.com, a Chinese-language portal based in Shanghai, for about $68 million in stock. The acquisition is part of a strategy aimed at forming a new company called World.com Inc. to develop global Web portals. Mail.com, which is based in New York, owns numerous Internet addresses, including Asia.com, India.com, Europe.com and USA.com. Shares of Mail.com rose 75 cents, to $18.875. The company reported a loss of $61.6 million on revenue of $12.7 million for the last 12 months.
