title: INFINITY TO BUY 2 SAN ANTONIO RADIO STATIONS FOR STOCK
description: The Infinity Broadcasting Corporation said yesterday that it had agreed to acquire the radio stations KTFM-FM and KTSA-AM in San Antonio from the privately held Waterman Broadcasting Corporation for about $90 million in stock. The New York-based Infinity operates more than 160 radio stations across the United States and has radio stations in the four largest markets of Texas, covering 80 percent of the state's population. Infinity had $2.5 billion in revenue last year. The majority of the company is owned by CBS. KTSA-AM, a news-talk radio station, became San Antonio's first licensed radio station in 1922.

title: Sports of The Times; Checketts Must Pursue Lamoriello
description: AS the Madison Square Garden impresario who will search for the Rangers' next general manager, Dave Checketts quickly and understandably declined to discuss any candidates to succeed Neil Smith other than to say that he intended to hire ''the best'' he can find, that he ''won't settle'' for anyone but the best.

title: AT&T Puts a Price on Wireless Offering
description: Most things about AT&T are big, so perhaps it is fitting that the coming initial public offering of shares meant to track AT&T's wireless communications unit is set to be the biggest United States I.P.O. yet.

title: Seeing the Future in an Old Triumph: Trolleys
description: A half-century after the region's last streetcar tracks were torn up to make way for more cars and buses, New Jersey officials are set to open the first leg of a $1.1 billion trolley system along the Hudson River. It will carry 25,000 riders a day, and the entire project, when completed in 2010, is expected to move more than 100,000 people through the most densely populated region in the state.

title: POOR MANAGEMENT BY NASA IS BLAMED FOR MARS FAILURE
description: The Mars Polar Lander spacecraft probably failed last year because its descent engine shut down prematurely, but the mission's loss can ultimately be attributed to inadequate management, testing and financing, independent experts told NASA today.

title: Thanks to the Web, Campus Radio Is Casting a Much Wider Net
description: WITH both transmitters out of commission, little money and more than $40,000 in repairs needed to keep Boston University's student radio station, WBTU, on the air, Bill Rigby was getting desperate.

title: Corrections
description: Because of an editing error, a front-page article on Saturday about reports by the state-owned ORT television network that a candidate in the Russian presidential election was supported by Jews, homosexuals and foreigners misstated the affiliation of Igor Malashenko, a media executive who commented. He works for Vladimir V. Gusinsky, who is chairman of Media Most, the conglomerate that includes the independent NTV network. He does not work for Boris A. Berezovsky, a major partner in the state-owned channel.

title: Another Evil Empire, This One in the Mirror
description: BLOWBACK

title: TRANSACTIONS
description: BASEBALL

title: The Government Shops on the Net, Too
description: IT has been two years since the Pentagon decided to build a virtual shopping mall on the Internet, and although its corridors are stocked with goods from rations and uniforms to paper and floppy disks, the military's main venture into e-commerce has been going a little more slowly than planned.

title: BULLETIN BOARD
description: Chancellors for a Day

title: Commercial Real Estate; Small Office Spaces Find A Niche in Cyberspace
description: Manhattan real estate can seem to be mostly about big deals and large numbers. But a pair of entrepreneurs think they have found a neglected niche in the market, the one for small commercial spaces from 500 to 5,000 square feet.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  PAPELL, ROBERT
description: PAPELL-Robert. On March 26, 2000. Former Branch Librarian for the Queensboro Public Library. Beloved husband of Helen. Loving father of David and father-in-law of Bonnie. Adored grandfather to Darci and Marisa. Services Wednesday, March 29, 2000 at 2:00 PM, West End Synagogue, 190 Amsterdam Avenue at 69th Street.

title: Clinton Says Next Move For Peace Is Assad's
description: President Clinton, commenting publicly for the first time on the failure of his talks with the Syrian leader, Hafez al-Assad, said today that it is up to Mr. Assad to make the next move.

title: Behind 'Name Your Own Price' Lies a Mesh of Partners
description: PRICELINE.COM does not even look like your normal dot-com company. Its headquarters are not in Silicon Valley, but in a suburban office park. Instead of 20-somethings in jeans and T-shirts with long hair and short resumes, many of its inhabitants are gray-haired recruits from companies like Citigroup and AT&T. Some wear neat, casual clothes, while others wear suits.

title: THE MARKETS: Market Place; Ben & Jerry's Is Reportedly Going Private
description: Ben & Jerry's Homemade, the ice cream company that became as well known for its commitment to causes like helping the homeless and saving the rain forest as for selling pints of Chubby Hubby and Cherry Garcia, has long struggled to balance its social initiatives with shareholder demands for better profits. Yesterday, it appeared that part of the struggle was over.

title: Customer Service: Solving Problems Or Preventing Them?
description: EXPEDIA, the giant online travel agency that is owned primarily by Microsoft, prides itself on customer service. In a gesture to uneasy visitors to its Web site (www.expedia.msn.com), it recently stopped insisting that they register and provide personal information before browsing for flights, car rentals and hotel rooms. The site now requires registration only when a browser turns into a purchaser.

title: Reckonings; Pursuing Happiness
description: The big winner at the Oscars was ''American Beauty,'' a film based on the daring and original premise that material possessions don't bring happiness. Oh, well. Anyway, not all trite ideas are wrong. In fact, there is quite a lot of evidence indicating that, sure enough, money doesn't buy happiness -- or at least not so you'd notice.

title: Blasting Your Way to the Electronic Checkout Counter
description: FAST forward to this time next year. There's me, crashed on the sofa in front of the television, tapped into a next-generation video-game console, playing another gamer halfway around the world, then using the console to browse the Web and also buy CD's and order pizza. I will eat that during my regular Wednesday-night videoconference call over the console's high-speed connection. After that, I will download a movie.

title: You May be Young, You May be Rich, But My Lobbyist Can Beat Up Yours
description: E-COMMERCE folks know more about routers than riders, about margins than legislative markups. But as they spend more time on Capitol Hill, they are learning one thing fast: it takes a lot more than being this year's darling to get what you want.

title: On the Global, Faceless Web, Trust Counts for Even More
description: IN a Web-based world, where an electronic embrace is replacing the personal encounter, business-to-business entrepreneurs are rediscovering the might of the human touch. Some nouveau Net-setters are even pitching the Internet as the ultimate ''people power'' tool.

title: Aiding Battered Women
description: To the Editor:

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  KING, JOAN HONE
description: KING-Joan Hone. Died March 26, 2000 at age 70. Writer and international art dealer. Beloved wife of the late Nicholas LeRoy King. Loving mother of Sarah, Bayard & Ledyard. Grandmother of Harry, Marina, Nicholas, Samantha & Gregory. Sister of Frederica Neff, Eugenie Angles and Philip Hone Auerbach. Funeral Thursday, March 30, Saint Columba's Chapel at the Cathedral of Saint John the Devine, Amsterdam Avenue at 116 St, 3PM. Interment Friday, 12 noon at Island Cemetery, Newport, R.I. Donations in her memory may be made to the Edward King House senior citizens' center, 35 King St, Newport, R.I. 02840.

title: Brave New Math Tests Limits of Accounting
description: WHEN Priceline.com arranges deals in which consumers name their own price for, say, airline tickets, it reports the money that the passenger pays for the seat as its own revenue, even though it neither owns nor flies any airplanes.

title: Dangerous to Asthmatics
description: To the Editor:

title: Officials to Review Police Chase Through Crowded Schoolyard
description: Police officials said yesterday that they would review the tactics employed Monday by plainclothes officers, including at least one with his gun drawn, who chased a drug suspect through a Brooklyn schoolyard crowded with children.

title: OFF THE MENU
description: Scene Changes

title: Turning Ideas Into Start-Ups at Yale
description: MICHAEL STERN led Ravi Paidipaty, a college sophomore, through room after wood-paneled room, explaining that soon they would all be working here. Mr. Paidipaty, still carrying his bag from class, seemed impressed. And maybe a little bewildered.

title: Costco Brings Its Big Box Onto the Web, but Cautiously
description: HOW can a company shoehorn the quintessential big-box shopping experience onto the small screen of online shopping?

title: Judge in Microsoft Case Delays a Ruling as Mediation Intensifies
description: The federal mediator in the Microsoft antitrust case has told officials that he may be able to broker a settlement, prompting the trial judge to delay his ruling, which had been due today.

title: Notre Dame Makes Its Point With Rout
description: If Notre Dame was out to prove that it belonged in the National Collegiate Athletic Association tournament, the Irish did it last night with a convincing 73-52 victory over Penn State in the semifinals of the National Invitation Tournament at Madison Square Garden before 14,268.

title: HARRIS FINANCIAL PLANS TO ACQUIRE A PENNSYLVANIA BANK
description: Harris Financial Inc. said yesterday that it had agreed to buy a Pennsylvania bank, the York Financial Corporation, for about $172 million. The purchase will be made with stock and some cash. Because about 76 percent of Harris Financial's shares are owned by its mutual holding company, it needs to convert from a mutual company -- one owned by depositors -- to have stock for the transaction. If Harris can raise between $289.5 million and $341.5 million, it will pay $17.25 for each York share. The price will go up or down if the conversion raises more or less money. The purchase can be terminated if the price drops below $15.50 a share. Shares of York Financial, based in York, Pa., rose 37.5 cents, to $15. Shares of Harris, based in Harrisburg, fell 50 cents, to $6.75.

title: Nassau Bus Riders Denounce County's Plan to Cut Service by Half
description: Some Nassau County residents who rely on the bus to get to jobs or appointments boarded the N72 bus this afternoon for a completely optional trip: a ride to a hearing where they joined hundreds of others in blasting a proposal to cut service nearly in half to help the county solve its fiscal crisis.

title: Politician, Heal Thyself (Take a Couch)
description: IN his new role as First Shrink, Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani has accused his critics of ''projecting'' their emotions and ''blocking'' their ''unconscious.'' Jesse Jackson, a less traditional Freudian, has described the mayor as ''mental.''

title: My Web: An Unscientific Shopping Sampler by Intel Science Talent Search Finalists
description: A Shopping Sampler by Intel Science Talent Search Finalists

title: A POLITICAL VOICE, WITHOUT STRINGS
description: The tiny remnant of the American peace movement had a little money and was looking for a voice in the political process. The pharmaceutical industry had a lot of money and was looking for a bullhorn.

title: Gephardt Courts the Technology Industry
description: With the political loyalties of the high-technology community still up for grabs, Representative Richard A. Gephardt, the House Democratic leader, intensified his courtship of the industry today by embracing pieces of its legislative wish list.

title: Pataki Offers Plan for a Women's Museum in Lower Manhattan
description: More than 150 years after the first convention on women's rights in upstate New York, Gov. George E. Pataki has proposed building one of the first museums in the country to be devoted to women's history.

title: Prosecuting War Crimes
description: To the Editor:

title: Surgery Planned For Seattle Slew
description: The 1977 Triple Crown winner, Seattle Slew, will undergo surgery later this week to alleviate compression on his spinal cord, and veterinarians are hoping it will help solve his fertility problems.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  GOODMAN, CYNTHIA (HARKABY)
description: GOODMAN-Cynthia (Harkaby) born January 10, 1913 in New York City. Beloved wife of the late Arthur Goodman. Resided in Greenwich Village. Founder of The Gotham Chapter of B'Nai-Brith, an active member for thirty years. She leaves behind her nephews Warren and Stuart Vogel, her great nieces Melissa, Amy, Kimberly and great nephew Jonathan. Services on Thursday 10AM, at ''The Riverside'', 76th Street and Amsterdam Avenue.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  HARRIS, REGINALD
description: HARRIS-Reginald. The William Morris Agency mourns the passing of its esteemed client and beloved friend, Reginald Harris, and extends our deepest sympathy to the family he loved so much-his wife Diane and his children Rachel and Darren. He was a person with deep reservoirs of love and goodness. He will be missed greatly.

title: Waiting for Oil Costs' Other Shoe
description: Donald Patman, a Texas farmer, is paying 40 cents a gallon more this year to fuel his diesel combines and tractors, adding as much as $240 a day to his costs during cotton-picking season. Soon he expects increases in the costs of pesticides and fertilizers to dent his budget even more. Pass the increases on to his customers? Forget it.

title: A Brain Comes Full Circle
description: Maynard James Keenan's Hollywood loft is a shrine to identity confusion. Red curtains, dozens of sticks of incense and statues of Eastern deities lend an aura of spiritual searching to his front room; at the same time, barbells and weights place him firmly in the cult of body worship. Then there are the soundproof walls and studio equipment of a rocker and artist, and finally a sense of clutter and an aversion to deep cleaning that give the room the look of a bohemian bachelor pad.

title: An Iowa Heirloom: Pork With Real Flavor
description: AGRICULTURE, they tell you the moment you get to Des Moines, no longer rules the local economy. Corn and pigs are no longer kings.

title: California Group Attacks Gore
description: In yet another sign that the general election campaign is already under way, a California group called Shape the Debate began running commercials this week, entitled ''Hypocrisy,'' attacking Vice President Al Gore. The group is headed by George Gorton, a longtime Republican consultant with close ties to former Gov. Pete Wilson of California. Two of the group's top officials have contributed $1,000 each to Gov. George W. Bush.

title: Jury Selection To Begin Today
description: Jury selection is scheduled to start today in United States District Court in Newark in the racketeering and bribery trial of the top officials of the International Boxing Federation, who are accused of taking money from managers, promoters and fighters in exchange for advancing boxers in the rankings to position them for lucrative bouts.

title: A Tart As Dandy As Candy
description: I'VE always been a bit of a question mark to the chocolate lovers in my family. While they negotiated over who would get the chocolate mousse, I was always content with apple pie or a poached pear, choices that drew sidelong looks of wonder from my father and sister, who consigned me to the ranks of fruit-dessert eaters, hopelessly minor league.

title: His Pitch: Come On In, the Water's Lucrative
description: WHO wants to be a centimillionaire?

title: E-Commerce
description: The life forms spawned in the Internet's wild opening days are facing tougher and more traditional competition. Which will survive?

title: Venus Williams Urged to Skip Year
description: Venus Williams's father said yesterday that he would like his 19-year-old daughter to give up tennis for the rest of this year and concentrate on educating herself for the future.

title: New Species, Old Struggle
description: A CENTURY from now, Internet archaeologists may look back at the last several years and liken them to an electronic Precambrian era: a time when new life exploded in spectacular abundance. But as in that prehistoric era, not all the creatures emerging from the fecund swamps are equally adapted for survival; there are crocodiles and then there are dodo birds.

title: Corrections
description: Because of an editing error, a film review on Monday about ''Voyages,'' Emmanuel Finkiel's Holocaust movie in the New Directors/New Films series at Lincoln Center, misidentified the director of another Holocaust film, ''The Sorrow and the Pity.'' He was Marcel Ophuls; Max Ophuls was his father.

title: KOREAN PRICES RISE
description: South Korean consumer prices rose for a third month in March, as higher educational fees more than offset a drop in food and other agricultural goods. Consumer prices have risen 0.3 percent this month, after a 0.3 percent gain in February. From a year ago, prices have risen 1.6 percent. Korea's economy expanded 2.8 percent in the fourth quarter of last year from the third quarter, capping a year in which gross domestic product grew 13 percent, the fastest in 12 years. The swiftness of the recovery from near bankruptcy two years ago may prompt the Bank of Korea to raise rates to keep inflation tame once parliamentary elections have been held on April 13.

title: Honey, There's a Dot-Com Growing in the Living Room!
description: GOOD afternoon, Anthony Dunne's office; I'll see if Mr. Dunne's available.'' I pressed the hold button.

title: Money and the Path to Power
description: To the Editor:

title: A Lehman Music Teacher Comes Home With an Oscar
description: John Corigliano's mother was concerned about whether he could make a living as a composer. So when she met the mother of Lehman College's music department chairman at the beauty parlor in 1972, she asked whether he could get her son a job.

title: New Life for a Welfare Warehouse
description: With its restored oak paneling, Renaissance-style pillars and Edwardian wallpaper, the lobby conjures an English hunting lodge. Upstairs, the apartments are furnished with solid oak chairs, dressers and drop-leaf desks, imported from a wood furniture company in Vermont. In the hallways, the colors of the Art Deco tiling recall the marble mosaic floors of the main lobby and the tearoom, first opened in 1904.

title: New ad agency prefers a homespun approach in pitching whiskey to savvy consumers.
description: THE name of an agency that opened here last month epitomizes its approach to aiming advertising at savvy, skeptical consumers: Hayseed House.

title: Faster Than You Can Say Soup
description: IT would be hard to find a more powerfully complex natural convenience food than miso. This Japanese paste of fermented beans (usually soy), grains (usually rice) and salt can be a revelation to the home cook looking to give food a fast flavor boost.

title: Recasting Lincoln Center's Role, Then Bowing Out
description: As Lincoln Center's third summer arts festival ended in July 1998, Nathan Leventhal, the center's president, made no secret of his profound relief. He announced that the performances, ranging from a multimedia ''Faust'' to a production of ''Twelfth Night'' featuring Helen Hunt, had exceeded box office projections.

title: Since Women Ask for Directions, the Web Is Being Remapped
description: THE demographics of the Internet have changed. Where men once ruled, women are taking over. They account for about half the Web's audience, various studies find, and are signing on in greater numbers than men.

title: Bodies at a New Uganda Site Indicate Earlier Cult Deaths
description: In one room the concrete floor looked a little new, and on a hunch, the police began to dig there today. First they found a human foot, sole upturned, poking up from the rubble.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  WESTON, JEFFREY
description: WESTON-Jeffrey. Beloved husband of Irene. Devoted father of Samantha. Loving son of Beverly and the late Mac. Dear brother of Burton & Joyce Weston. Brotherin-law to Allen and Marilyn Selling. Uncle to Julie, Mike, Lauren, Rob, Ian, Pia, Adam & Logan. Services at ''Boulevard-Riverside'', 1450 Broadway, Hewlett, L.I. Thursday, 11:30AM. In lieu of flowers, contributions to Brooklyn School for Special Children, 376 Bay 44 Street, Brooklyn, New York 11214 would be appreciated.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SOKOLOWER, MORTON H.
description: SOKOLOWER-Morton H. On March 28, 2000. Devoted father of Harriett Arnold, Nancy and Steven Horn, and Julia and Jonathan Rick. Dear brother of Jeanette Krautheimer, Leonard and Lester Sokolower. Cherished grandfather and great grandfather. Services Wednesday, 1:45PM at ''Gutterman's Inc.'', 175 Long Beach Road, Rockville Centre, Long Island.

title: In Israel, Making the Shovels for the Internet Gold Rush
description: INTERNET infrastructure, the veins and muscles of the Web, Internet, has become Israel's entree to e-commerce, a veritable back door to the global Internet market.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  STEEGER, SHIRLEY MEEKER
description: STEEGER-Shirley Meeker. On Friday, March 24, 2000. Beloved wife of the late Henry Steeger, devoted mother of Suzanne Steeger Hall, Nancy Steeger Jennings and her husband, Richard, the late Henry Steeger IV and his wife, Betsey. Adored grandmother of Chris Hall and his wife, Michaela, Jeremy Hall, Anne, Sally and Victoria Jennings and Marie Steeger. Loving sister of Lincoln Meeker. Cherished aunt of Guy Meeker, great-aunt of Bentley Meeker and Melissa Meeker Eustace. A funeral service will be held at the James Chapel, Madison Avenue Presbyterian Church, 73 St and Madison Ave, at 11 AM on Friday, March 31. In lieu of flowers contributions may be made to the Quogue Chapel Fund, 83 Meeting House Road, Westhampton Beach, New York 11978.

title: Corrections
description: Because of an editing error, an obituary on Saturday about Warren Magee, a lawyer who represented unpopular clients, misstated his place of death. It was Tampa, Fla.; he had practiced in Washington.

title: Common Sense Prevails on the Museum
description: Mayor Rudolph Giuliani's decision to end his campaign to evict the Brooklyn Museum from its premises, cut its funding and remove its board of trustees is a sensible bow to First Amendment principles. The agreement between the mayor and the museum ends six months of legal wrangling over the staging of ''Sensation,'' the exhibition that included Chris Ofili's notorious dung-adorned painting of the Madonna. The Brooklyn Museum can now go about mounting shows that will stimulate, and perhaps offend, visitors instead of defending in court its right to do so. The mayor can praise or criticize or ignore those exhibitions as he sees fit, without tying up the courts with fruitless litigation that runs headlong into the First Amendment's guarantees of free expression.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  LOEB, ENID
description: LOEB-Enid. National Council of Jewish Women, N.Y. section, mourns the loss of a valued member and a devoted and important volunteer of our Council Senior Center. Jean Krosner, President Helen Caplin Heller, Exec. Dir.

title: Kings' Williams Pays Price of Forced Fame
description: Imagine being hired by a prominent company and performing the job with such flair, such style, that everyone and his mother soon wants to know where you came from and how you became so good at what you do.

title: Citing a Crisis, Bush Proposes Literacy Effort
description: Once again mooring a traditionally Democratic issue to the agenda of his Republican presidential campaign, Gov. George W. Bush of Texas today proposed a five-year, $5 billion program to address what he termed a national literacy crisis among children.

title: Question Over Fatal Shot Stirs a Death Row Debate
description: There is no dispute that a drug-addicted drifter named Philip Ray Workman robbed a Wendy's restaurant in Memphis on the night of Aug. 5, 1981. There also is no question that Mr. Workman, armed with a .45-caliber pistol, exchanged fire with Memphis police officers as he fled and that Lt. Ronald Oliver was killed.

title: Justices Curb Reach of Anonymous Tips on Guns
description: An anonymous tip that a person is carrying a gun is not enough to justify a stop and frisk by the police without some further sign that the information is reliable, the Supreme Court ruled with surprising unanimity today.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  ORTNER, REV. JOHN MEISS, S.J.
description: ORTNER-Rev. John Meiss, S.J. Beloved brother of Sr. Mary Alois Ortner, IHM. Reposing at the Jesuit Community Chapel, Loyola Hall at Fordham University, on Wednesday, 3-5 and 7-9PM. Mass of Christian Burial at the Loyola Hall Chapel, Thursday, 11 AM. For information contact Farenga Bros., Inc., Directors.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  JOSEPH, IRVING
description: JOSEPH-Irving, 75, noted pianist, conductor and musical director, died suddenly on Tuesday, March 28, after a brief illness. Funeral services will be held Friday, March 31, at noon, at the Riverside Memorial Chapel, 180 West 76th Street. A memorial service will be announced at a later date. He is survived by his beloved wife, Phyllis Dolgin, his brother Dr. Samuel Joseph, and numerous loving nieces, nephews, friends and relatives.

title: Excerpts From Bush's Address About Education and Literacy
description: Following are excerpts from a speech Gov. George W. Bush delivered yesterday in Reston, Va., on a plan to improve literacy among children, as recorded by The New York Times:

title: Share Prices Fall as Analyst Reallocates Model Portfolio
description: Stock prices declined yesterday, as investors took profits in a number of companies that have been big winners so far this year, and Abby Joseph Cohen, the influential stock market strategist at Goldman, Sachs, announced she had pared the exposure to stocks in her model portfolio to 65 percent, a reduction of 5 percentage points.

title: F.C.C. Is Expected to Reject SBC's Long-Distance Proposal
description: It is almost certain that the Federal Communications Commission will thwart SBC Communications' efforts to enter the $80 billion long-distance telephone market early this year, according to people close to the commission.

title: Finding the Criminal Who Fits the Crime
description: UNABLE to make an arrest in the case of the smashed statues of saints in Roman Catholic churches in Brooklyn, New York police detectives have consulted with a fellow who was once one of their own, the psychological profiler Raymond M. Pierce, and if you think Mr. Pierce is going to speak about an ongoing investigation, you are a person of extraordinary naivete.

title: Yahoo Seeking to Avoid Mutual Fund Status
description: Yahoo Inc. has asked the Securities and Exchange Commission to exempt the company from regulation as a mutual fund, a request that could set a precedent for other Web businesses.

title: Extended Closing Set For Indian Point 2
description: Consolidated Edison told the Nuclear Regulatory Commission today that technicians at its Indian Point 2 reactor would have to plug dozens of flawed steam generator tubes like the one that leaked radioactive water on Feb. 15, forcing the plant to close.

title: Intel Wins Latest Battle in War of PC Chips
description: Seeking to one-up its archrival, Advanced Micro Devices, in the relentless creation of faster chips for low-cost computers, the Intel Corporation today introduced its latest Celeron processor for personal computers priced under $1,000.

title: London Journal; Issue Aborning at No. 10: Will Daddy Stay Home?
description: Prime Minister Tony Blair has spent nearly three years in office telling the British that they have to shed their fusty traditions and get with the times. Now his wife is telling him there is no better place to stage the revolution than in his own home.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  BELLAK, LEOPOLD, MD.
description: BELLAK-Leopold, MD. Beloved father of Trina Bellak, Esquire of Maryland and Kerin Adams of New Jersey. Loving grandfather of Dina Adams. Devoted friend of his wife of many years, Sonya Sorel Bellak, brother of Ludwig (deceased). Died on March 24, 2000 of pneumonia. Dr. Bellak was a psychoanalyst, psychiatrist and psychologist and his contributions to all these fields will long be remembered. A Memorial Service to be announced.

title: Corrections
description: An article last Wednesday about Yosef Bienenstock, a boyhood friend of Pope John Paul II who now lives in Israel, misidentified the biblical source of the inscription on the tombstone of Mr. Bienenstock's brother -- ''And I shall raise you from your graves, my people, and I shall bring you to the land of Israel.'' It is Ezekiel, not Jeremiah.

title: The Moral Education of an Innocent
description: The haunting ''Journey to the Sun'' teems with life. Set in Istanbul, it tells the story of Mehmet (Newroz Baz), a young man with one of the more interesting occupations you'll see in modern movies. His job is to find leaks in the water pipes below his city, and he uses a long brass rod he places on the pavement, listening through it to catch the rumbles. He even employs the rod to impress his girlfriend, Arzu (Mizgin Kapazan), using it to tell how far the approaching train is from their stop. The rod becomes a rather awkward metaphor in ''Journey,'' as Mehmet discovers an entire world his senses didn't detect: he can hear turmoil under the streets but not on them.

title: Executive Joins McCann-Erickson
description: Gary Topolewski, a longtime creative executive on the Chrysler account at a Detroit-area agency that has operated under several names, is becoming executive vice president and chief creative officer at McCann-Erickson/A&L in San Francisco.

title: Alex Comfort, 80, Dies; a Multifaceted Man Best Known for Writing 'The Joy of Sex'
description: Dr. Alex Comfort, whose graphically illustrated 1972 book ''The Joy of Sex'' became the coffee-table Kama Sutra of the baby-boom generation, died on Sunday at a nursing home in Banbury, northwest of London. He was 80.

title: American Cheeses Catch Up to the World
description: IT would have been impossible to produce a book like ''The New American Cheese'' 20 years ago. Back then, only about a quarter of the 50 or so American cheese makers featured in this big, lavishly photographed volume by Laura Werlin (Stewart Tabori & Chang, $35) were in business.

title: Two Charged in Killing of Russian Boxer
description: Federal prosecutors have charged two suspected Russian mobsters with abducting and murdering a professional boxer who had mysteriously disappeared from a Brooklyn garage in late 1995.

title: Around the Borough
description: THESE are among my favorite new restaurants in Brooklyn. Each offers the pleasure of a good meal along with the spirit of its neighborhood.

title: Publicis Acquires Stake in Agency
description: Publicis S.A. in Paris said yesterday that it had acquired a majority stake in Winner & Associates, a public relations agency with offices in Los Angeles and Washington. Terms were not disclosed.

title: Dinner Delivered With a Bit Of Civility
description: THE motto of RED WINE WITH FISH? -- a company that delivers evening meals in TriBeCa and the financial district -- is ''Preparing and Delivering Civilized Dinners to Civilized New Yorkers.'' I can't vouch for being a member of that select second group, but I can say that a recent dinner from Red Wine was among the most civilized takeout experiences I've had.

title: SHOPPING; The Web Adds Exotic Colors, but at the Garden's Edge
description: GARDENERS in the United States, who spend about $5 billion a year to watch things grow, can now watch the emergence of gardening Web sites. Many electronic seedlings are in place, but much pinching, pushing and pruning is coming.

title: Metro Business; Giuliani Extends Rent Regulations
description: Rent regulation protections covering 1.1 million New York City apartments were extended for three years yesterday as Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani signed City Council legislation into law.

title: Land of the Automobile
description: To the Editor:

title: State Audit Finds Deficiencies In 1 in 5 Contractors at Schools
description: For the second time in three years, an audit by the state comptroller's office has found that the New York City School Construction Authority failed to adequately screen companies that bid for work on construction and improvement projects.

title: Myms, Pings and Vortals
description: Travelers in the land of the up-and-dot-comers require neither passports nor magic portals, but a dictionary of e-speak isn't a bad idea. As with any industry, this one is generating buzzwords, idioms and acronyms that are spicing up business exchanges and casual chat, while confounding the ill-e-terate with their meanings. What follows are some choice candidates in the categories of office talk, a field ripe for phrase picking, and professional parlance, the terminology tossed around by marketing mavens who are in the know.

title: Judge Says Companies May Deep Link to Rivals
description: Judge Says Companies May 'Deep Link' to Rivals

title: The Impasse Over Elian Gonzalez
description: Everyone involved in the Elian Gonzalez case needs to pull back from the nasty confrontation that now looms so this matter can be resolved without disorder or further harm to young Elian. The Miami relatives who have been caring for him since he was rescued off the Florida coast last November must firmly commit themselves to accepting his return to his father in Cuba if their court appeals are rejected. The Justice Department, which is right to seek his repatriation, should lift its threat to remove the boy from Miami this week, and the Cuban-American community in south Florida ought to cease its disruptive efforts to block Elian's return and to make him into a political symbol.

title: Richard Goode Cancels
description: The pianist Richard Goode has canceled his April 11 recital at Carnegie Hall because of tendinitis. He is to be replaced by Dmitri Bashkirov, who will perform a program of works by Mozart, Schumann, Debussy, and Liszt transcriptions of Schubert songs. Tickets for Mr. Goode's recital will be honored at Mr. Bashkirov's concert. Information: (212) 247-7800.

title: After House Fire, A Mayor Revisits His Nomadic Past
description: To hear John Cesar tell it, he has always been one short step away from homelessness. But a raging fire on Monday erased that step, leaving Mr. Cesar, who at 82 is the oldest and possibly the most unconventional mayor in the state, truly without a home.

title: THE CHEF
description: CREME brulee is all about contrast, about the way the crackling crust of hot caramelized sugar yields to the creamy richness of the cold custard underneath. It's a perfect dessert made with just vanilla, but I wanted to take it to another level.

title: Restaurant and Bar Workers Who Get Tips May Also Get Lesser Increase in Minimum Wage
description: On Friday, the minimum wage will rise for New York's lowest-paid workers, but lawmakers plan to prevent the absolute lowest wage earners, restaurant and bar employees who earn tips, from collecting the entire increase.

title: The Rangers Fall, And So Does the Ax
description: Neil Smith, the president and general manager of the Rangers, and John Muckler, the head coach, were both dismissed yesterday with the team about to miss out on the playoffs for the third straight season. The two were fired by Dave Checketts, the president of Madison Square Garden, with just four games left in the Rangers' regular season and just one day after the team was embarrassed in a 6-0 loss at home to the Detroit Red Wings.

title: Painting a Victory in Shades of Gray; Brooklyn Museum Is Cautious, as Giuliani Looks to November
description: Robert S. Rubin, the formidable chairman of the Brooklyn Museum of Art, sounded a bit grumpy.

title: No Relief at the Pumps Is Seen Until Fall
description: Regardless of how quickly oil-exporting nations can increase production, motorists in the United States may not get relief from high gasoline prices until this autumn at the earliest.

title: Starter Gragg Released
description: Scott Gragg, a starter at offensive tackle for the Giants the last four years, was released yesterday in a salary-cap move.

title: An Internet Dummy Logs On for a Comparative Adventure
description: SENATOR JOHN McCAIN thinks that shopping online is so vital to America's prosperity that it should be tax free. Until now, I had shirked my patriotic duty. I had never shopped online. When I confessed this, people reacted the way women at Vogue magazine would react if someone mispronounced ''Manolo Blahnik.''

title: 50 Years Ago Already? 1994 Sure Feels Like It
description: A few days before the greatest success of his career -- the 1994 Stanley Cup -- Neil Smith sat in a hotel suite in Vancouver, discussing his relationship with Mike Keenan. Smith was the general manager of the Rangers and Keenan was the coach of the New York team that was about to win the trophy for the first time in 54 years. Was Smith happy and filled with gratitude?

title: Japanese Shareholder Activist Loses 2nd Battle With Company
description: A Japanese shareholder activist, whose failed effort to buy a company in Japan's first hostile takeover fight attracted widespread attention, suffered a second defeat today when that company repulsed his requests to raise its dividend and make him a director.

title: National News Briefs; Ex-60's Radical Indicted
description: Jamil Abdullah Al-Amin, the 1960's radical formerly known as H. Rap Brown, was indicted today by a grand jury on murder and assault charges.

title: Putin to Keep Defense Chief, Affirming Chechnya Status Quo
description: With President-elect Vladimir V. Putin moving to put his government in place, Moscow is rife with behind-the-scenes intrigue as he and his aides try to decide which politicians, economists and tycoons should be included in his inner circle.

title: ABC Network President Is Quitting to Run an Internet Company
description: Patricia Fili-Krushel, the first woman to run a broadcast television network, as president of ABC, is quitting the network to join the Internet health care company Healtheon/WebMD.

description: THE Kuhn Rikon grater looks like either a failed attempt at an industrial fly swatter or a very awkward spatzle maker. But this odd little tool is actually a cheese and chocolate grater. And quite a good one at that.

description: Four people were injured last night, one critically, when the driver of a livery cab lost control on a crowded Midtown block, suddenly accelerated and plowed into pedestrians on a sidewalk.

title: REVLON AGREES TO SELL ARGENTINE SHAMPOO BRAND TO DIAL
description: The cosmetics company Revlon Inc. said yesterday that it had agreed to sell its Plusbelle brand of shampoo and conditioners, sold principally in Argentina, to the Dial Corporation, the soap maker, for $46.5 million. The sale also includes a manufacturing plant in Argentina. New York-based Revlon, which had $1.86 billion in sales last year, said it wanted to focus more on its core businesses and reduce its debt. Dial of Scottsdale, Ariz., had $1.72 billion in revenue last year.

title: Japanese Worry About Being Overshadowed
description: For 12-year-old Kenji Nakanishi, watching the Mets and the Chicago Cubs play their season-opening game at the Tokyo Dome tonight was better than opening presents at Kurisumasu, Japanese for Christmas.

title: Jackson Meets Coke Executives on Minority Issues
description: The Rev. Jesse Jackson met today with top Coca-Cola executives to discuss the company's treatment of minority and women employees.

title: CIRCUIT BOARD MAKER PURCHASES UNIT OF WIRE COMPANY
description: Viasystems Group, which makes circuit boards for companies like Cisco Systems and Lucent Technologies, acquired a wire maker yesterday from International Wire Group Inc. for $210 million. International Wire Group, based in St. Louis, designs and makes products that include tin-plated and insulated copper wire. The company said it would use the proceeds to pay debts. The shares of Viasystems, also based in St. Louis, fell 62.5 cents, to $16.125. The company sold 44 million shares at $21 each Friday in an initial public offering.

Adored grandmother of Chris Hall and his wife, Michaela, Jeremy Hall, Anne, Sally and Victoria Jennings and Marie Steeger. Loving sister of Lincoln Meeker. Cherished aunt of Guy Meeker, great-aunt of Bentley Meeker and Melissa Meeker Eustace. A funeral service will be held at the James Chapel, Madison Avenue Presbyterian Church, 73 St and Madison Ave, at 11 AM on Friday, March 31. In lieu of flowers contributions may be made to the Quogue Chapel Fund, 83 Meeting House Road, Westhampton Beach, New York 11978.

title: The Somersaults of a Czech Writer
description: In a land of letters ruled by a playwright presiding from his castle on the hill over a dreamy city that has brought out the absurd in writers from Kafka to Kundera, Jachym Topol is hailed as a bright new literary star. His 1994 novel ''Sestra'' (''Sister'') won plaudits from writers like Ivan Klima and President Vaclav Havel himself. His poetry and second novel, ''Angel,'' have also earned the eclectic Mr. Topol a place in Prague's pantheon of those who chronicle its ever fertile mind-set.

title: It Isn't Elbowing In, It's Balancing Out
description: The aggressive angle jutting out of a two-story building going up at Broadway and 67th Street may seem to horn its way into the intersection and -- if you believe in feng shui, the ancient Chinese art of harmonious arrangements -- disrupt the energy, or chi, at that corner. But the building is in balance with its surroundings, said Peter Samton, its architect, and Pamela Laurence, a feng shui expert consulted by House & Home. Mr. Samton, a partner in Gruzen Samton, said the aggressive angle is characteristic of Broadway, which cuts a diagonal across the city grid. Ms. Laurence, director of the Mountain Institute of TriBeCa, a feng shui school, said the sharp angle balances a similar one on a building diagonally across the intersection.

description: President-elect Chen Shui-bian surprised Taiwan today by choosing the departing Nationalist defense minister as prime minister in his government, which takes office on May 20.

description: President Clinton waded ever so gently into the raging battle over police shootings in New York City by suggesting today that better training of recruits might reduce such shootings without sacrificing public safety.

title: CISCO TO BUY MAKER OF INTERNET VIDEO SYSTEMS
description: Cisco Systems Inc., the world's largest maker of networking equipment, agreed yesterday to acquire SightPath Inc., which makes systems delivering television-quality video to the Internet and corporate intra nets, for $800 million in stock. The deal continues Cisco's recent acquisition spree. SightPath is a privately owned company based in Waltham, Mass., that was formed only two years ago. Cisco said SightPath's products would make it easier for Cisco's clients to offer such services as real-time video and online training. Shares of Cisco fell 81.25 cents, to $77.0625, in heavy Nasdaq trading.

title: Finding New Cracks in an Exposed Life
description: It's the voice of Judy Garland, back from the dead. And it's coming from all the speakers in Gerald Clarke's big house in Bridgehampton. ''No more 'Over the Rainbow' for me,'' Garland says in a throaty drawl. ''I've grown up. Those days are over.'' Garland made those tapes during the mid-60's for a possible autobiography, said Mr. Clarke, whose own biography of her, ''Get Happy: The Life of Judy Garland,'' is being published by Random House this month.

title: Corrections
description: An article on Tuesday and an editorial yesterday about a complaint that lawsuits over New York City's handling of First Amendment issues have burdened the federal courts misstated the number of judges who made the complaint. It was one, not two. Judge Guido Calabresi of the United States Court of Appeals for the Second Circuit made the criticism in a decision in a case involving an artist's plans to photograph nude models on a city street. While Judge Robert D. Sack concurred in the outcome of the decision, he did not join in the criticism.

title: New Web Site Will Track Bird Migrations With Radar
description: Most nonscientists are familiar with Doppler radar as a system that tracks precipitation and excites television meteorologists. But a Web site starting on April 1, Birdcast.org (www.birdcast .org), will adapt the technology to bird watching on a large scale.

title: Chairs to Bring the Outdoors Inside
description: CHAIRS woven in natural fibers like wicker, rattan and banana bark have come in from the veranda to lend an airy beach-house feel to any living room or library. Many reed chairs are hand-woven, like baskets, reflecting the craftsman's touch: each differs slightly from piece to piece, and the uncoated colors are naturally variegated. The chairs are refined in their workmanship so they don't feel scratchy; some are club style, with cushions or a cushioned seat. Natural fibers stay cool in hot weather, so these chairs are a good choice for summerhouse living. None of the ones shown here should be left outside.

title: Nude Dancing and Free Expression
description: A case concerning nude dancing at an Erie, Pa., night spot occasioned a disappointing 6-to-3 Supreme Court opinion yesterday that unduly broadened the government's authority to regulate expressive conduct.

title: More Progress Reported in Decoding Key of Hereditary Information
description: The public consortium of universities engaged in decoding the human genome has accomplished two-thirds of its preliminary goal, Dr. Francis Collins, director of the National Human Genome Research Institute, said yesterday.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  DRILLMAN, RABBI SOLOMON
description: DRILLMAN-Rabbi Solomon. Yeshiva University and its affiliated Rabbi Isaac Elchanan Theological Seminary mourn the passing of an eminent rosh yeshiva and Torah educator who was Eva, Morris, and Jack K. Rubin Memorial Professor of Rabbinics at RIETS. Warmly revered as scholar and mentor, the devoted alumnus was a distinguished faculty member and administrator-at our High School as well as RIETS--for over a half century. The University honored him for outstanding service to the Jewish community and higher education with our 1984 Rabbinic Alumnus Award. We extend our heartfelt condolences to his wife, Chaya; children, Rabbi Yaakov (and Sara) Drillman, Rabbi Yechiel (and Leah) Drillman, and Rabbi Yehoshua (and Nechama) Drillman; grandchildren; and the entire family. May they be comforted among the mourners of Zion and Jerusalem. Dr. Norman Lamm, President Yeshiva University David S. Gottesman, Chairman YU Board of Trustees Judah Feinerman, Chairman RIETS Board of Trustees

title: Coping With Nassau's Fiscal Crisis
description: Nassau County's political leaders are finally responding to the fiscal crisis that has pushed one of the richest counties in New York State and the nation toward junk bond status. On Monday the County Legislature voted 14 to 4 to overhaul Nassau's antiquated and unfair property tax assessment system, a long-resisted move that is essential for the county's long-term financial health. Currently Nassau pays some $100 million a year in refunds to residential and commercial property owners who successfully appeal their assessments -- a tab it has covered by adding to its staggering debt load.

Tchaikovsky's ''Manfred'' Symphony reaches its big climaxes in expressions of guilt and despair, but it never loses belief in the suffering human subject at its center. It is a passionate song of the self, and under Mr. Gergiev on Friday afternoon it was passionately sung by the orchestra, with full vigor.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  ANDON, ASHOD J.
description: ANDON-Ashod J., 75, on March 28, 2000 at his home in Vero Beach, Florida. Born in Pelham, New York on December 15, 1924, Mr. Andon grew up there and graduated from Pelham Memorial High School in 1943. He graduated with honors from Yale University in 1946. In 1949, at age 24, he founded TIC Gums Incorporated in New York City and became the world's leading authority on agricultural hydrocolloids. He served as an advisor to such nations as India, Pakistan, Spain, Sudan, and Turkey. Mr. Andon also founded and served as President of the Treasure Coast Jazz Society in Vero Beach. An avid yachtsman and off-shore fisherman, he was a member of the New York Yacht Club, Yale Club of New York, Moorings Club, Moorings Yacht Squadron, and The Yale Club of the Treasure Coast, of which he was a past President. He is survived by his wife of 53 years, the former Jean Hamilton Eisele, and three children: Christopher E. Andon of Bel Air, MD, Stephen A. Andon of Havre de Grace, MD, and Susan A. McKay of Wellesley, MA. Also by 10 grandchildren and a brother, Arma E. Andon of Westhampton Beach, NY and a sister, Anais A. Corsar of Pelham, NY. A memorial service will be held on Friday, March 31, 2000 at 11 AM in St. Augustine's Episcopal Church, 475 43rd Ave., Vero Beach. In lieu of flowers, memorial contributions may be made to the Treasure Coast Jazz Society, PO Box 4003, Vero Beach, FL. 32964.

What a great, broad sound, and what a comfortable formula: one-chord songs about being on the road and out of luck, steam-shoveled at the audience by two guitars, a bassist who plays almost exactly the same lines as the guitarists, and a drummer whose meat-head rhythms include a cowbell half the time.

Soon after she showed her portfolio to Felissimo, the store not only made Ms. Yunome's listing sake set (called School Trip, above) part of its new Artisan collection, but it also asked her to design three lines of dishware for its popular mail-order catalog in Japan. ''My goal is that people smile whenever they pick up one of my pieces,'' Ms. Yunome, 34, said of her functional yet individualistic wares. The organic forms of her sake set can be mixed and matched at Felissimo, 10 West 56th Street (Fifth Avenue); $48 for the bottle, $18 a cup.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  GRANT, VIRGIL V.
description: GRANT-Virgil V., 87, died March 29 in Atlanta after a long illness. He was Executive Vice President, Chief Financial Officer, and a Director of Caterpillar. He had been elected Treasurer in 1946 at the age of 33, then the youngest officer in the company's history. He was named president of Caterpillar Overseas in 1960 and moved to Geneva, Switzerland, for two years. When he returned in 1962 he was made a Vice President; he was elected Executive Vice President in 1971. For most of his career Mr. Grant was involved in international finance, establishing Caterpillar companies in a dozen foreign countries. His first trip to England was by ship; he was soon flying ''like a bird'' in small planes that could not yet climb above the clouds. In 1954 his plane crashed on landing in Rio de Janeiro Bay; he helped other passengers get out on a wing before they were picked up by the Brazilian Coast Guard. Virgil Grant was born on Feb. 25, 1913, in Southern Illinois, the son of Robert and Dorothy Simmons Grant. He graduated from a small high school in 1930, but driven by a desire for higher education, won a county scholarship to the U. of Illinois, where he earned a BS in accounting. Survivors are his wife, Esther Grant, whom he married in 1936, and his daughters, Lois Grant of Atlanta and Linda Grant of Rye, New York. He leaves three grandchildren and two great grandchildren. The family asks in lieu of flowers contributions in his memory to the United Negro College Fund.

title: Foreign Affairs; Saving The Lost World

The protesters are no doubt sincere, but the truth is the I.M.F. and World Bank are neither the problem nor the solution. They are bit players, of declining importance, in a much larger drama.

title: Building Emotional Truths With Deceptive Ease
description: In her beautiful new cabaret show at the Cafe Carlyle, Barbara Cook has taken a break from saluting individual songwriting teams and stage directors to perform what amounts to a personal history of the Broadway musical and its movie offshoots. From an opening ''That's Entertainment,'' done with a triumphal stateliness, to an unamplified encore of ''Goodnight My Someone'' (from ''The Music Man''), the show, which runs through April 29, has the polish and dramatic range of a master class. If you want to know how to wring the most emotional truth from a theater song while maintaining a measure of formality, this is how it's done.

So here's ''D.C.,'' the earnest drama series that the WB network is unveiling on Sunday night. It's the story of five improbably attractive young adults sharing a house (and their innermost thoughts) in Washington while they try to grab hold of the bottommost rung of the power ladder.

title: Big Shoulders, Buffed for Action
description: When friends from abroad come to the United States, I always send them to Chicago, or try to. It is the quintessential American city: muscular, inventive, wonderfully diverse, worldly-wise (if a bit oafish at times) and as unpretentious as its prairie-flat vowels.

title: Talks With Europeans End
description: Talks in Beijing broke off today without a deal between China and the European Union over the terms of China's entry into the World Trade Organization. No date was set for the resumption of talks.

title: The Music of Time
description: When Anthony Powell, who died Tuesday at 94, finished the 12 novels that make up ''A Dance to the Music of Time,'' it was already 1975. ''Hearing Secret Harmonies,'' the final installment, seemed strangely contemporary, caught up in the social revolutions of the day, and yet anachronistic too, linked to a narrative that reached back to the early 1920's. ''A Dance to the Music of Time,'' one of the great fictional works of this century, closes by echoing the very words with which it began in 1951. As a device, that echo of the beginning in the end is unsurprising -- one of the ways that narrative closure often comes about. But that echo sounds as a reminder of how brilliantly Powell sustains the intricate choreography of ''A Dance,'' all the years and characters that intertwine in those 12 novels that finally become one.

title: Dark Side of New York From The Daily News
description: Like film noir, the tabloids have no illusions about evil lurking in the hearts of men, women and children. For longer than any other tabloid in the country, The New York Daily News -- which began life in June 1919 as The Illustrated Daily News -- has documented the all-too-commonplace human urge to do harm. Unlike film noir, which devotes an hour or two to exploring dark doings, The News has had to tell the story in one arresting photograph.

title: Wake Forest Prevails as Irish Rally Falters
description: After falling into a 20-point deficit against a scrappy Wake Forest team in the National Invitation Tournament championship game last night at Madison Square Garden, Notre Dame furiously tried to claw its way out. But the hole was too deep and Wake Forest held on for a 71-61 victory and its first N.I.T. title.

I've also heard the one about how expensive New York is (it is apparently quite expensive) and, of course, the one about the guy who can't get a date (he can't get a date!). In fact, over the course of the last month, I have heard hundreds of jokes, thousands of near misses and even a couple of howlers, all perpetrated by the city's crack corps of comedians.

The documentary ''The Eyes of Tammy Faye'' walks us through her life, a veritable catalog of bad marriages, lost televangelist empires, squandered relationships with children and, despite it all, Ms. Messner's indomitable optimism.

title: NEOFORMA TO PAY $4.2 BILLION FOR 2 COMPANIES

The aim is to create a company that will provide a complete range of Web-based transaction services for health care organizations. In connection with the deal, Neoforma received a 10-year contract to provide electronic-commerce services to Novation L.L.C., the largest buyer of medical supplies in the world. Eclipsys also dropped a lawsuit related to its hostile takeover bid for the Shared Medical Systems Corporation of Malvern, Pa. In Nasdaq trading, Neoforma's stock plunged $10.50, or 34.5 percent, to $19.875, while Eclipsys's shares dropped $2.5625, or 10 percent, to $23.25.

title: IT'S A SONY BANK
description: Taking a broad step to make the Internet an integral part of its future business, the Sony Corporation announced formal plans to start an online bank. Sony, the world's second-largest consumer electronics company, said it would contribute 30 billion yen, or $285.6 million at current exchange rates, to the online bank, while Sakura Bank and J. P. Morgan will contribute a combined 7.5 billion yen to give them stakes of 16 percent and 4 percent, respectively. Sakura's president, Akishige Okada, far left, said he thought Sony's entry would increase public recognition of online banking, while Sony's president, Nobuyuki Idei, said the company would position the Internet bank ''as one of Sony's key business sectors.'' Stephanie Strom

title: U.S. FRANCHISE SAYS IT IS CONSIDERING 'STRATEGIC OPTIONS'
description: U.S. Franchise Systems Inc., the franchiser of Microtel Inn, Hawthorne Suites and Best Inns hotels, said yesterday that it had hired Banc of America Securities to explore strategic alternatives after receiving several bids. The company, based in Atlanta, said it had received a few unsolicited inquiries regarding the possible sale of the company in recent months. Talks with some suitors did not result in any satisfactory offers, the company said, prompting it to hire the investment bank to explore its options. Shares of U.S. Franchise fell 62.5 cents, to $5, in Nasdaq trading. At that price, the company's stock is worth about $100 million.

title: How a Fan of the Wicked Witch Became a Succes de Scandale

The Wicked Witch of the West and Captain Hook were among his fantasy idols. By the age of 10, under the spell of the movie ''Lili'' and of ''Howdy Doody,'' he was staging his own puppet shows in his neighborhood and earning $25 a week, not a small sum for a boy that age.

This case was important not because of the dollar amount of the award, which is too small to serve as much of a deterrent to the defendants, Philip Morris and R. J. Reynolds, but rather because for the first time, a plaintiff who won had started smoking after warning labels were added to cigarette packages.

title: Static Over Low-Powered Radio
description: A House committee, egged on by the nation's broadcasters, passed regrettable legislation this week that would largely undermine the Federal Communications Commission's plan to give schools, churches and other community groups the right to set up low-powered FM radio stations. These stations would broadcast local ball games, municipal meetings or anything else they think their communities wanted to hear. The idea is a good one. The commission wants to let non-commercial groups cater to audiences living within a few miles of the radio station, providing a powerful antidote to the increasing concentration of radio broadcasters. In recent years the number of radio station owners has fallen by about a fifth.

title: Decalogue Series Is Out, Finally
description: Next month a large and fine item indeed lands among assorted good little foreign films to be released on tape and disc. In 1988 the Polish director Krzysztof Kieslowski produced a series of 10 one-hour films, called ''The Decalogue,'' for television. A year later they were shown at the Venice Film Festival, and then in 1996 at Lincoln Center, the year Kieslowski died at 54. Other than that, what many critics consider a masterpiece has been screened infrequently and has never appeared on video. On April 11, the series will be released on five cassettes from Facets Multimedia, the Chicago distributor. (Information: 800-331-6197).

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  BENET, SHAUN CATHERINE
description: BENET-Shaun Catherine, Director of Educational Marketing at Channel 13, WNET, died of brain cancer March 28 at her mother's home in Boston. She was 44. Ms. Benet was born in Pittsburgh. She graduated from Smith College in 1977. She was Vice President of the Bank of New York, the Boston Company and Mellon Bank before leaving in 1996 to pursue a career in the nonprofit sector. She was a consultant with the National Multiple Sclerosis Society, NYC and was the Executive Director of the Breast Cancer Research Foundation before becoming an executive with WNET in 1998. She leaves her mother Sarah; her father L. Peter, Sr., and stepmother Jonna; two sisters Maria and Pia; three brothers Lorenzo, Jr., Edwin and John; and her companion Pasquale Servodidio. A memorial service will take place on Tuesday, April 4, at 2:30 PM at Trinity Church, Broadway and Wall St., in Manhattan. Donations in Shaun's memory may be sent to the Shaun Benet Glioblastoma Research Fund, care of The Brain Tumor Society, 124 Watertown St. 3H, Watertown, MA 02472.

title: Nassau Democrats Suggest Broad Changes to Save Millions in Police Costs
description: Treading heavily on ground that Nassau County's elected officials have traditionally avoided, Democrats in the Legislature called yesterday for a shake-up in the county's police department that they said could save Nassau $15 million this year and $25 million in years ahead.

title: Scandinavian Dealer Sells His Treasures
description: Sotheby's sale of the Arne Schlesch collection next week marks the passing of an era. Mr. Schlesch, 77, has sold his five-story Scandinavian antiques gallery on East 64th Street, consigned its contents to Sotheby's and retired to Copenhagen. ''There's a limit to how long you can go on buying chandeliers and chairs,'' he said. ''I made my hobby into a lucrative business. I was thrilled to buy things, especially from families I knew. It was fun.''

title: Modigliani's Message: It's a Bubble, and Bubbles Will Burst
description: RANCO MODIGLIANI says that the current mania for Internet and other technology stocks is not irrational. But it is a bubble, and it will burst.

title: NATIONWIDE ACQUIRES GARTMORE
description: The Edinburgh-based Royal Bank of Scotland Group sold its fund management unit, Gartmore Investment Management, for $:1.03 billion, or $1.64 billion, in cash to the Nationwide Mutual Insurance Company. Royal Bank acquired Gartmore when it won a bidding war for National Westminster Bank earlier this year. Andrew Ross Sorkin

title: DINER'S JOURNAL
description: Manhattan's loss is Brooklyn's gain. After failing to generate excitement at Scarabee in Midtown, Ken Johnson has pulled up stakes and taken his French-Mediterranean sensibility to Rustic, a small cafe in Cobble Hill. The change of air seems to be doing him good. In a no-frills, casual setting, he has devised a simplified menu that shows off his talents much better than the overproduced fare at Scarabee did.

title: Young Group Brings Back An Old Work
description: The Second Avenue Dance Company always looks polished. Yet its dancers are never the same. That's because the group is made up of students in their final year in the dance department of the Tisch School of the Arts at New York University. And they invariably give sharp performances under the direction of Kay Cummings and Cherylyn Lavagnino. Their program on Monday in the school's Fifth Floor Theater featured a major revival, premieres by guest choreographers and examples of student choreography.

title: Four Get Prison Time in Death Of Girl From Date Rape Drug
description: Concluding a case that drew national attention to GHB, a drug that has been linked to date rapes, a judge sentenced four young men to prison here today for putting what proved to be a fatal quantity of the substance in the soft drink of an unsuspecting 15-year-old girl a year ago.

title: Raise a Toast to Dear Old Y, Where the Nosy Guys All Die
description: The title ''The Skulls'' suggests a William Castle horror film of the late 1950's, filmed perhaps in his patented Percepto process, with giant death's heads jumping out of the screen. But the only supernatural element in this Rob Cohen film is the mysterious vanishing university.

title: WORLD BUSINESS BRIEFING: AMERICAS; WEB ACCESS BY PHONE
description: The Mexican cell-phone operators Pegaso PCS and Grupo Iusacell announced that their customers would be able to link to the Internet through cellular phones, starting in April, beating the market leader Telcel in the race to offer PC-free mobile Web access in Mexico. Telcel said it would accelerate development of its system. Dan Fineren

description: SILFEN-Herman (Hy). 80. On March 30 after a long and courageous battle. Beloved husband of Rhoda and the late Esther. Devoted father of David and Lyn, Susan, Ellen and Buzz Margolin. Cherished grandfather of Adam, Jane, Sam and Emma. Loving brother of Bill, Marilyn, Norman and Helen. You will be forever in our hearts and memories. Friends may call Saturday, April 1 from 7-9 PM. Services Sunday, April 2 at 10 AM at ''The Riverside'', 76 St. and Amsterdam Ave. In lieu of flowers contributions may be made to the Herman Silfen Fund, Y.A.I. title: Florida Measure May Ease Lawsuit's Threat to Cigarette Makers
description: State lawmakers in Florida may soon take up legislation intended to reduce the financial threat to cigarette makers in a high-stakes tobacco case that is reaching a critical phase in Miami.

title: They're Off on the (Animated) Road to El Dorado
description: Beavis and Butt-head and Wayne and Garth and the crew from ''South Park'' have so thoroughly coarsened the comic buddy movie that it comes as a slight shock when ''The Road to El Dorado'' hurtles us back six decades to the mild-mannered zaniness of the Bing Crosby-Bob Hope ''road'' movies.

title: ITALIAN INTERNET SHARES
description: The holding company of the former Italian prime minister, Silvio Berlusconi, left, Fininvest, said it would sell 20 percent of Jumpy, its Internet unit, in an initial sale of shares later this year. Massimo Armanini, a former executive of Parmalat, Italy's largest dairy company, is Jumpy's chief executive. Jumpy says it has 400,000 users, up from 300,000 in mid-February, and 18 million page views a month. Fininvest plans to expand the Internet unit into Spain in May and later into Germany and France.

title: Anger Still Fires the Hell That Was Sierra Leone
description: In one of the two camps here where rebels, ex-soldiers, militiamen and traditional hunters from the country's nine-year civil war are supposed to give up their weapons and start becoming law-abiding citizens, Sheak Bnyallay stalked up to a visitor and angrily removed his sunglasses.

title: Residential Real Estate; Twin Towers in Lincoln Center Area
description: A 504-apartment mixed-income rental building is nearing completion along West End Avenue on the southwestern edge of the Lincoln Center neighborhood, continuing the area's swing to more residential development.

title: Juan Gonzalez and His Son
description: The Elian Gonzalez case grows more tangled and charged by the hour, and the fate of the young Cuban boy is now yoked to a destructive combination of cold-war animosities and presidential politics. The furor is a terrible disservice to Elian and is rapidly becoming a national embarrassment. Elian needs to be reunited with his father, and all those involved should be working to find a reasonable way to accomplish that rather than using the boy to score political points.

title: Fed Isn't Aiming at Markets, Greenspan Says in a Letter
description: Alan Greenspan, the Federal Reserve chairman, told members of Congress in a letter made public today that the central bank's goal in raising interest rates was not to bring down the stock market, and he reiterated his opposition to growing calls for the Fed to make it more difficult for investors to buy stock with borrowed money.

description: Icahn Seeks to Take Control Of Nabisco Group Holdings

title: 724 SOLUTIONS IS ACQUIRING TWO SOFTWARE COMPANIES
description: 724 Solutions Inc. agreed yesterday to acquire two closely held companies for about $121.4 million in cash and stock to increase the services offered with its software for banking and financial transactions over wireless devices. 724 Solutions, based in Toronto, is buying ezlogin.com, based in Santa Clara, Calif., a company whose software lets people customize the information they get from the Internet, for 888,934 shares, or about $115.6 million. The company also agreed to buy the YRLess Internet Corporation, an Oakville, Ontario, company that makes wireless messaging software, for about $5.8 million in cash and stock. The stock of 724 Solutions fell $12.50, or 8.7 percent, to $130.
